gutenberg_id	text
35	The Time Machine, by H. G. Wells [1898]
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	I
35	
35	
35	The Time Traveller (for so it will be convenient to speak of him)
35	was expounding a recondite matter to us. His grey eyes shone and
35	twinkled, and his usually pale face was flushed and animated. The
35	fire burned brightly, and the soft radiance of the incandescent
35	lights in the lilies of silver caught the bubbles that flashed and
35	passed in our glasses. Our chairs, being his patents, embraced and
35	caressed us rather than submitted to be sat upon, and there was that
35	luxurious after-dinner atmosphere when thought roams gracefully
35	free of the trammels of precision. And he put it to us in this
35	way--marking the points with a lean forefinger--as we sat and lazily
35	admired his earnestness over this new paradox (as we thought it)
35	and his fecundity.
35	
35	'You must follow me carefully. I shall have to controvert one or two
35	ideas that are almost universally accepted. The geometry, for
35	instance, they taught you at school is founded on a misconception.'
35	
35	'Is not that rather a large thing to expect us to begin upon?'
35	said Filby, an argumentative person with red hair.
35	
35	'I do not mean to ask you to accept anything without reasonable
35	ground for it. You will soon admit as much as I need from you. You
35	know of course that a mathematical line, a line of thickness _nil_,
35	has no real existence. They taught you that? Neither has a
35	mathematical plane. These things are mere abstractions.'
35	
35	'That is all right,' said the Psychologist.
35	
35	'Nor, having only length, breadth, and thickness, can a cube have a
35	real existence.'
35	
35	'There I object,' said Filby. 'Of course a solid body may exist. All
35	real things--'
35	
35	'So most people think. But wait a moment. Can an _instantaneous_
35	cube exist?'
35	
35	'Don't follow you,' said Filby.
35	
35	'Can a cube that does not last for any time at all, have a real
35	existence?'
35	
35	Filby became pensive. 'Clearly,' the Time Traveller proceeded, 'any
35	real body must have extension in _four_ directions: it must have
35	Length, Breadth, Thickness, and--Duration. But through a natural
35	infirmity of the flesh, which I will explain to you in a moment, we
35	incline to overlook this fact. There are really four dimensions,
35	three which we call the three planes of Space, and a fourth, Time.
35	There is, however, a tendency to draw an unreal distinction between
35	the former three dimensions and the latter, because it happens that
35	our consciousness moves intermittently in one direction along the
35	latter from the beginning to the end of our lives.'
35	
35	'That,' said a very young man, making spasmodic efforts to relight
35	his cigar over the lamp; 'that ... very clear indeed.'
35	
35	'Now, it is very remarkable that this is so extensively overlooked,'
35	continued the Time Traveller, with a slight accession of
35	cheerfulness. 'Really this is what is meant by the Fourth Dimension,
35	though some people who talk about the Fourth Dimension do not know
35	they mean it. It is only another way of looking at Time. _There is
35	no difference between Time and any of the three dimensions of Space
35	except that our consciousness moves along it_. But some foolish
35	people have got hold of the wrong side of that idea. You have all
35	heard what they have to say about this Fourth Dimension?'
35	
35	'_I_ have not,' said the Provincial Mayor.
35	
35	'It is simply this. That Space, as our mathematicians have it, is
35	spoken of as having three dimensions, which one may call Length,
35	Breadth, and Thickness, and is always definable by reference to
35	three planes, each at right angles to the others. But some
35	philosophical people have been asking why _three_ dimensions
35	particularly--why not another direction at right angles to the other
35	three?--and have even tried to construct a Four-Dimension geometry.
35	Professor Simon Newcomb was expounding this to the New York
35	Mathematical Society only a month or so ago. You know how on a flat
35	surface, which has only two dimensions, we can represent a figure of
35	a three-dimensional solid, and similarly they think that by models
35	of three dimensions they could represent one of four--if they could
35	master the perspective of the thing. See?'
35	
35	'I think so,' murmured the Provincial Mayor; and, knitting his
35	brows, he lapsed into an introspective state, his lips moving as one
35	who repeats mystic words. 'Yes, I think I see it now,' he said after
35	some time, brightening in a quite transitory manner.
35	
35	'Well, I do not mind telling you I have been at work upon this
35	geometry of Four Dimensions for some time. Some of my results
35	are curious. For instance, here is a portrait of a man at eight
35	years old, another at fifteen, another at seventeen, another at
35	twenty-three, and so on. All these are evidently sections, as it
35	were, Three-Dimensional representations of his Four-Dimensioned
35	being, which is a fixed and unalterable thing.
35	
35	'Scientific people,' proceeded the Time Traveller, after the pause
35	required for the proper assimilation of this, 'know very well that
35	Time is only a kind of Space. Here is a popular scientific diagram,
35	a weather record. This line I trace with my finger shows the
35	movement of the barometer. Yesterday it was so high, yesterday night
35	it fell, then this morning it rose again, and so gently upward to
35	here. Surely the mercury did not trace this line in any of the
35	dimensions of Space generally recognized? But certainly it traced
35	such a line, and that line, therefore, we must conclude was along
35	the Time-Dimension.'
35	
35	'But,' said the Medical Man, staring hard at a coal in the fire, 'if
35	Time is really only a fourth dimension of Space, why is it, and why
35	has it always been, regarded as something different? And why cannot
35	we move in Time as we move about in the other dimensions of Space?'
35	
35	The Time Traveller smiled. 'Are you sure we can move freely in
35	Space? Right and left we can go, backward and forward freely enough,
35	and men always have done so. I admit we move freely in two
35	dimensions. But how about up and down? Gravitation limits us there.'
35	
35	'Not exactly,' said the Medical Man. 'There are balloons.'
35	
35	'But before the balloons, save for spasmodic jumping and the
35	inequalities of the surface, man had no freedom of vertical
35	movement.'
35	
35	'Still they could move a little up and down,' said the Medical Man.
35	
35	'Easier, far easier down than up.'
35	
35	'And you cannot move at all in Time, you cannot get away from the
35	present moment.'
35	
35	'My dear sir, that is just where you are wrong. That is just where
35	the whole world has gone wrong. We are always getting away from the
35	present moment. Our mental existences, which are immaterial and have
35	no dimensions, are passing along the Time-Dimension with a uniform
35	velocity from the cradle to the grave. Just as we should travel _down_
35	if we began our existence fifty miles above the earth's surface.'
35	
35	'But the great difficulty is this,' interrupted the Psychologist.
35	'You _can_ move about in all directions of Space, but you cannot
35	move about in Time.'
35	
35	'That is the germ of my great discovery. But you are wrong to say
35	that we cannot move about in Time. For instance, if I am recalling
35	an incident very vividly I go back to the instant of its occurrence:
35	I become absent-minded, as you say. I jump back for a moment. Of
35	course we have no means of staying back for any length of Time, any
35	more than a savage or an animal has of staying six feet above the
35	ground. But a civilized man is better off than the savage in this
35	respect. He can go up against gravitation in a balloon, and why
35	should he not hope that ultimately he may be able to stop or
35	accelerate his drift along the Time-Dimension, or even turn about
35	and travel the other way?'
35	
35	'Oh, _this_,' began Filby, 'is all--'
35	
35	'Why not?' said the Time Traveller.
35	
35	'It's against reason,' said Filby.
35	
35	'What reason?' said the Time Traveller.
35	
35	'You can show black is white by argument,' said Filby, 'but you will
35	never convince me.'
35	
35	'Possibly not,' said the Time Traveller. 'But now you begin to see
35	the object of my investigations into the geometry of Four
35	Dimensions. Long ago I had a vague inkling of a machine--'
35	
35	'To travel through Time!' exclaimed the Very Young Man.
35	
35	'That shall travel indifferently in any direction of Space and Time,
35	as the driver determines.'
35	
35	Filby contented himself with laughter.
35	
35	'But I have experimental verification,' said the Time Traveller.
35	
35	'It would be remarkably convenient for the historian,' the
35	Psychologist suggested. 'One might travel back and verify the
35	accepted account of the Battle of Hastings, for instance!'
35	
35	'Don't you think you would attract attention?' said the Medical Man.
35	'Our ancestors had no great tolerance for anachronisms.'
35	
35	'One might get one's Greek from the very lips of Homer and Plato,'
35	the Very Young Man thought.
35	
35	'In which case they would certainly plough you for the Little-go.
35	The German scholars have improved Greek so much.'
35	
35	'Then there is the future,' said the Very Young Man. 'Just think!
35	One might invest all one's money, leave it to accumulate at
35	interest, and hurry on ahead!'
35	
35	'To discover a society,' said I, 'erected on a strictly communistic
35	basis.'
35	
35	'Of all the wild extravagant theories!' began the Psychologist.
35	
35	'Yes, so it seemed to me, and so I never talked of it until--'
35	
35	'Experimental verification!' cried I. 'You are going to verify
35	_that_?'
35	
35	'The experiment!' cried Filby, who was getting brain-weary.
35	
35	'Let's see your experiment anyhow,' said the Psychologist, 'though
35	it's all humbug, you know.'
35	
35	The Time Traveller smiled round at us. Then, still smiling faintly,
35	and with his hands deep in his trousers pockets, he walked slowly
35	out of the room, and we heard his slippers shuffling down the long
35	passage to his laboratory.
35	
35	The Psychologist looked at us. 'I wonder what he's got?'
35	
35	'Some sleight-of-hand trick or other,' said the Medical Man, and
35	Filby tried to tell us about a conjurer he had seen at Burslem; but
35	before he had finished his preface the Time Traveller came back, and
35	Filby's anecdote collapsed.
35	
35	The thing the Time Traveller held in his hand was a glittering
35	metallic framework, scarcely larger than a small clock, and very
35	delicately made. There was ivory in it, and some transparent
35	crystalline substance. And now I must be explicit, for this that
35	follows--unless his explanation is to be accepted--is an absolutely
35	unaccountable thing. He took one of the small octagonal tables that
35	were scattered about the room, and set it in front of the fire, with
35	two legs on the hearthrug. On this table he placed the mechanism.
35	Then he drew up a chair, and sat down. The only other object on the
35	table was a small shaded lamp, the bright light of which fell upon
35	the model. There were also perhaps a dozen candles about, two in
35	brass candlesticks upon the mantel and several in sconces, so that
35	the room was brilliantly illuminated. I sat in a low arm-chair
35	nearest the fire, and I drew this forward so as to be almost between
35	the Time Traveller and the fireplace. Filby sat behind him, looking
35	over his shoulder. The Medical Man and the Provincial Mayor watched
35	him in profile from the right, the Psychologist from the left. The
35	Very Young Man stood behind the Psychologist. We were all on the
35	alert. It appears incredible to me that any kind of trick, however
35	subtly conceived and however adroitly done, could have been played
35	upon us under these conditions.
35	
35	The Time Traveller looked at us, and then at the mechanism. 'Well?'
35	said the Psychologist.
35	
35	'This little affair,' said the Time Traveller, resting his elbows
35	upon the table and pressing his hands together above the apparatus,
35	'is only a model. It is my plan for a machine to travel through
35	time. You will notice that it looks singularly askew, and that there
35	is an odd twinkling appearance about this bar, as though it was in
35	some way unreal.' He pointed to the part with his finger. 'Also,
35	here is one little white lever, and here is another.'
35	
35	The Medical Man got up out of his chair and peered into the thing.
35	'It's beautifully made,' he said.
35	
35	'It took two years to make,' retorted the Time Traveller. Then, when
35	we had all imitated the action of the Medical Man, he said: 'Now I
35	want you clearly to understand that this lever, being pressed over,
35	sends the machine gliding into the future, and this other reverses
35	the motion. This saddle represents the seat of a time traveller.
35	Presently I am going to press the lever, and off the machine will
35	go. It will vanish, pass into future Time, and disappear. Have a
35	good look at the thing. Look at the table too, and satisfy
35	yourselves there is no trickery. I don't want to waste this model,
35	and then be told I'm a quack.'
35	
35	There was a minute's pause perhaps. The Psychologist seemed about to
35	speak to me, but changed his mind. Then the Time Traveller put forth
35	his finger towards the lever. 'No,' he said suddenly. 'Lend me your
35	hand.' And turning to the Psychologist, he took that individual's
35	hand in his own and told him to put out his forefinger. So that it
35	was the Psychologist himself who sent forth the model Time Machine
35	on its interminable voyage. We all saw the lever turn. I am
35	absolutely certain there was no trickery. There was a breath of
35	wind, and the lamp flame jumped. One of the candles on the mantel
35	was blown out, and the little machine suddenly swung round, became
35	indistinct, was seen as a ghost for a second perhaps, as an eddy of
35	faintly glittering brass and ivory; and it was gone--vanished! Save
35	for the lamp the table was bare.
35	
35	Everyone was silent for a minute. Then Filby said he was damned.
35	
35	The Psychologist recovered from his stupor, and suddenly looked
35	under the table. At that the Time Traveller laughed cheerfully.
35	'Well?' he said, with a reminiscence of the Psychologist. Then,
35	getting up, he went to the tobacco jar on the mantel, and with his
35	back to us began to fill his pipe.
35	
35	We stared at each other. 'Look here,' said the Medical Man, 'are you
35	in earnest about this? Do you seriously believe that that machine
35	has travelled into time?'
35	
35	'Certainly,' said the Time Traveller, stooping to light a spill at
35	the fire. Then he turned, lighting his pipe, to look at the
35	Psychologist's face. (The Psychologist, to show that he was not
35	unhinged, helped himself to a cigar and tried to light it uncut.)
35	'What is more, I have a big machine nearly finished in there'--he
35	indicated the laboratory--'and when that is put together I mean to
35	have a journey on my own account.'
35	
35	'You mean to say that that machine has travelled into the future?'
35	said Filby.
35	
35	'Into the future or the past--I don't, for certain, know which.'
35	
35	After an interval the Psychologist had an inspiration. 'It must have
35	gone into the past if it has gone anywhere,' he said.
35	
35	'Why?' said the Time Traveller.
35	
35	'Because I presume that it has not moved in space, and if it
35	travelled into the future it would still be here all this time,
35	since it must have travelled through this time.'
35	
35	'But,' I said, 'If it travelled into the past it would have been
35	visible when we came first into this room; and last Thursday when we
35	were here; and the Thursday before that; and so forth!'
35	
35	'Serious objections,' remarked the Provincial Mayor, with an air of
35	impartiality, turning towards the Time Traveller.
35	
35	'Not a bit,' said the Time Traveller, and, to the Psychologist: 'You
35	think. You can explain that. It's presentation below the threshold,
35	you know, diluted presentation.'
35	
35	'Of course,' said the Psychologist, and reassured us. 'That's a
35	simple point of psychology. I should have thought of it. It's plain
35	enough, and helps the paradox delightfully. We cannot see it, nor
35	can we appreciate this machine, any more than we can the spoke of
35	a wheel spinning, or a bullet flying through the air. If it is
35	travelling through time fifty times or a hundred times faster than
35	we are, if it gets through a minute while we get through a second,
35	the impression it creates will of course be only one-fiftieth or
35	one-hundredth of what it would make if it were not travelling in
35	time. That's plain enough.' He passed his hand through the space in
35	which the machine had been. 'You see?' he said, laughing.
35	
35	We sat and stared at the vacant table for a minute or so. Then the
35	Time Traveller asked us what we thought of it all.
35	
35	'It sounds plausible enough to-night,' said the Medical Man; 'but
35	wait until to-morrow. Wait for the common sense of the morning.'
35	
35	'Would you like to see the Time Machine itself?' asked the Time
35	Traveller. And therewith, taking the lamp in his hand, he led the
35	way down the long, draughty corridor to his laboratory. I remember
35	vividly the flickering light, his queer, broad head in silhouette,
35	the dance of the shadows, how we all followed him, puzzled but
35	incredulous, and how there in the laboratory we beheld a larger
35	edition of the little mechanism which we had seen vanish from before
35	our eyes. Parts were of nickel, parts of ivory, parts had certainly
35	been filed or sawn out of rock crystal. The thing was generally
35	complete, but the twisted crystalline bars lay unfinished upon the
35	bench beside some sheets of drawings, and I took one up for a better
35	look at it. Quartz it seemed to be.
35	
35	'Look here,' said the Medical Man, 'are you perfectly serious?
35	Or is this a trick--like that ghost you showed us last Christmas?'
35	
35	'Upon that machine,' said the Time Traveller, holding the lamp
35	aloft, 'I intend to explore time. Is that plain? I was never more
35	serious in my life.'
35	
35	None of us quite knew how to take it.
35	
35	I caught Filby's eye over the shoulder of the Medical Man, and he
35	winked at me solemnly.
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	II
35	
35	
35	I think that at that time none of us quite believed in the Time
35	Machine. The fact is, the Time Traveller was one of those men who
35	are too clever to be believed: you never felt that you saw all round
35	him; you always suspected some subtle reserve, some ingenuity in
35	ambush, behind his lucid frankness. Had Filby shown the model and
35	explained the matter in the Time Traveller's words, we should have
35	shown _him_ far less scepticism. For we should have perceived his
35	motives; a pork butcher could understand Filby. But the Time
35	Traveller had more than a touch of whim among his elements, and we
35	distrusted him. Things that would have made the frame of a less
35	clever man seemed tricks in his hands. It is a mistake to do things
35	too easily. The serious people who took him seriously never felt
35	quite sure of his deportment; they were somehow aware that trusting
35	their reputations for judgment with him was like furnishing a
35	nursery with egg-shell china. So I don't think any of us said very
35	much about time travelling in the interval between that Thursday and
35	the next, though its odd potentialities ran, no doubt, in most of
35	our minds: its plausibility, that is, its practical incredibleness,
35	the curious possibilities of anachronism and of utter confusion it
35	suggested. For my own part, I was particularly preoccupied with the
35	trick of the model. That I remember discussing with the Medical Man,
35	whom I met on Friday at the Linnaean. He said he had seen a similar
35	thing at Tubingen, and laid considerable stress on the blowing out
35	of the candle. But how the trick was done he could not explain.
35	
35	The next Thursday I went again to Richmond--I suppose I was one of
35	the Time Traveller's most constant guests--and, arriving late, found
35	four or five men already assembled in his drawing-room. The Medical
35	Man was standing before the fire with a sheet of paper in one hand
35	and his watch in the other. I looked round for the Time Traveller,
35	and--'It's half-past seven now,' said the Medical Man. 'I suppose
35	we'd better have dinner?'
35	
35	'Where's----?' said I, naming our host.
35	
35	'You've just come? It's rather odd. He's unavoidably detained. He
35	asks me in this note to lead off with dinner at seven if he's not
35	back. Says he'll explain when he comes.'
35	
35	'It seems a pity to let the dinner spoil,' said the Editor of a
35	well-known daily paper; and thereupon the Doctor rang the bell.
35	
35	The Psychologist was the only person besides the Doctor and myself
35	who had attended the previous dinner. The other men were Blank, the
35	Editor aforementioned, a certain journalist, and another--a quiet,
35	shy man with a beard--whom I didn't know, and who, as far as my
35	observation went, never opened his mouth all the evening. There was
35	some speculation at the dinner-table about the Time Traveller's
35	absence, and I suggested time travelling, in a half-jocular spirit.
35	The Editor wanted that explained to him, and the Psychologist
35	volunteered a wooden account of the 'ingenious paradox and trick' we
35	had witnessed that day week. He was in the midst of his exposition
35	when the door from the corridor opened slowly and without noise. I
35	was facing the door, and saw it first. 'Hallo!' I said. 'At last!'
35	And the door opened wider, and the Time Traveller stood before us.
35	I gave a cry of surprise. 'Good heavens! man, what's the matter?'
35	cried the Medical Man, who saw him next. And the whole tableful
35	turned towards the door.
35	
35	He was in an amazing plight. His coat was dusty and dirty, and
35	smeared with green down the sleeves; his hair disordered, and as it
35	seemed to me greyer--either with dust and dirt or because its colour
35	had actually faded. His face was ghastly pale; his chin had a brown
35	cut on it--a cut half healed; his expression was haggard and drawn,
35	as by intense suffering. For a moment he hesitated in the doorway,
35	as if he had been dazzled by the light. Then he came into the room.
35	He walked with just such a limp as I have seen in footsore tramps.
35	We stared at him in silence, expecting him to speak.
35	
35	He said not a word, but came painfully to the table, and made a
35	motion towards the wine. The Editor filled a glass of champagne, and
35	pushed it towards him. He drained it, and it seemed to do him good:
35	for he looked round the table, and the ghost of his old smile
35	flickered across his face. 'What on earth have you been up to, man?'
35	said the Doctor. The Time Traveller did not seem to hear. 'Don't let
35	me disturb you,' he said, with a certain faltering articulation.
35	'I'm all right.' He stopped, held out his glass for more, and took
35	it off at a draught. 'That's good,' he said. His eyes grew brighter,
35	and a faint colour came into his cheeks. His glance flickered over
35	our faces with a certain dull approval, and then went round the warm
35	and comfortable room. Then he spoke again, still as it were feeling
35	his way among his words. 'I'm going to wash and dress, and then I'll
35	come down and explain things ... Save me some of that mutton. I'm
35	starving for a bit of meat.'
35	
35	He looked across at the Editor, who was a rare visitor, and hoped he
35	was all right. The Editor began a question. 'Tell you presently,'
35	said the Time Traveller. 'I'm--funny! Be all right in a minute.'
35	
35	He put down his glass, and walked towards the staircase door. Again
35	I remarked his lameness and the soft padding sound of his footfall,
35	and standing up in my place, I saw his feet as he went out. He had
35	nothing on them but a pair of tattered, blood-stained socks. Then the
35	door closed upon him. I had half a mind to follow, till I remembered
35	how he detested any fuss about himself. For a minute, perhaps, my
35	mind was wool-gathering. Then, 'Remarkable Behaviour of an Eminent
35	Scientist,' I heard the Editor say, thinking (after his wont) in
35	headlines. And this brought my attention back to the bright
35	dinner-table.
35	
35	'What's the game?' said the Journalist. 'Has he been doing the
35	Amateur Cadger? I don't follow.' I met the eye of the Psychologist,
35	and read my own interpretation in his face. I thought of the Time
35	Traveller limping painfully upstairs. I don't think any one else had
35	noticed his lameness.
35	
35	The first to recover completely from this surprise was the Medical
35	Man, who rang the bell--the Time Traveller hated to have servants
35	waiting at dinner--for a hot plate. At that the Editor turned to his
35	knife and fork with a grunt, and the Silent Man followed suit. The
35	dinner was resumed. Conversation was exclamatory for a little while,
35	with gaps of wonderment; and then the Editor got fervent in his
35	curiosity. 'Does our friend eke out his modest income with a
35	crossing? or has he his Nebuchadnezzar phases?' he inquired. 'I feel
35	assured it's this business of the Time Machine,' I said, and took up
35	the Psychologist's account of our previous meeting. The new guests
35	were frankly incredulous. The Editor raised objections. 'What _was_
35	this time travelling? A man couldn't cover himself with dust by
35	rolling in a paradox, could he?' And then, as the idea came home to
35	him, he resorted to caricature. Hadn't they any clothes-brushes in
35	the Future? The Journalist too, would not believe at any price, and
35	joined the Editor in the easy work of heaping ridicule on the whole
35	thing. They were both the new kind of journalist--very joyous,
35	irreverent young men. 'Our Special Correspondent in the Day
35	after To-morrow reports,' the Journalist was saying--or rather
35	shouting--when the Time Traveller came back. He was dressed in
35	ordinary evening clothes, and nothing save his haggard look remained
35	of the change that had startled me.
35	
35	'I say,' said the Editor hilariously, 'these chaps here say you have
35	been travelling into the middle of next week! Tell us all about
35	little Rosebery, will you? What will you take for the lot?'
35	
35	The Time Traveller came to the place reserved for him without a
35	word. He smiled quietly, in his old way. 'Where's my mutton?' he
35	said. 'What a treat it is to stick a fork into meat again!'
35	
35	'Story!' cried the Editor.
35	
35	'Story be damned!' said the Time Traveller. 'I want something to
35	eat. I won't say a word until I get some peptone into my arteries.
35	Thanks. And the salt.'
35	
35	'One word,' said I. 'Have you been time travelling?'
35	
35	'Yes,' said the Time Traveller, with his mouth full, nodding his
35	head.
35	
35	'I'd give a shilling a line for a verbatim note,' said the Editor.
35	The Time Traveller pushed his glass towards the Silent Man and rang
35	it with his fingernail; at which the Silent Man, who had been
35	staring at his face, started convulsively, and poured him wine.
35	The rest of the dinner was uncomfortable. For my own part, sudden
35	questions kept on rising to my lips, and I dare say it was the same
35	with the others. The Journalist tried to relieve the tension by
35	telling anecdotes of Hettie Potter. The Time Traveller devoted his
35	attention to his dinner, and displayed the appetite of a tramp.
35	The Medical Man smoked a cigarette, and watched the Time Traveller
35	through his eyelashes. The Silent Man seemed even more clumsy than
35	usual, and drank champagne with regularity and determination out of
35	sheer nervousness. At last the Time Traveller pushed his plate away,
35	and looked round us. 'I suppose I must apologize,' he said. 'I was
35	simply starving. I've had a most amazing time.' He reached out his
35	hand for a cigar, and cut the end. 'But come into the smoking-room.
35	It's too long a story to tell over greasy plates.' And ringing the
35	bell in passing, he led the way into the adjoining room.
35	
35	'You have told Blank, and Dash, and Chose about the machine?' he
35	said to me, leaning back in his easy-chair and naming the three new
35	guests.
35	
35	'But the thing's a mere paradox,' said the Editor.
35	
35	'I can't argue to-night. I don't mind telling you the story, but
35	I can't argue. I will,' he went on, 'tell you the story of what
35	has happened to me, if you like, but you must refrain from
35	interruptions. I want to tell it. Badly. Most of it will sound like
35	lying. So be it! It's true--every word of it, all the same. I was in
35	my laboratory at four o'clock, and since then ... I've lived eight
35	days ... such days as no human being ever lived before! I'm nearly
35	worn out, but I shan't sleep till I've told this thing over to you.
35	Then I shall go to bed. But no interruptions! Is it agreed?'
35	
35	'Agreed,' said the Editor, and the rest of us echoed 'Agreed.' And
35	with that the Time Traveller began his story as I have set it forth.
35	He sat back in his chair at first, and spoke like a weary man.
35	Afterwards he got more animated. In writing it down I feel with only
35	too much keenness the inadequacy of pen and ink--and, above all, my
35	own inadequacy--to express its quality. You read, I will suppose,
35	attentively enough; but you cannot see the speaker's white,
35	sincere face in the bright circle of the little lamp, nor hear the
35	intonation of his voice. You cannot know how his expression followed
35	the turns of his story! Most of us hearers were in shadow, for the
35	candles in the smoking-room had not been lighted, and only the face
35	of the Journalist and the legs of the Silent Man from the knees
35	downward were illuminated. At first we glanced now and again at each
35	other. After a time we ceased to do that, and looked only at the
35	Time Traveller's face.
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	III
35	
35	
35	'I told some of you last Thursday of the principles of the Time
35	Machine, and showed you the actual thing itself, incomplete in the
35	workshop. There it is now, a little travel-worn, truly; and one of
35	the ivory bars is cracked, and a brass rail bent; but the rest of
35	it's sound enough. I expected to finish it on Friday, but on Friday,
35	when the putting together was nearly done, I found that one of the
35	nickel bars was exactly one inch too short, and this I had to get
35	remade; so that the thing was not complete until this morning. It
35	was at ten o'clock to-day that the first of all Time Machines began
35	its career. I gave it a last tap, tried all the screws again, put
35	one more drop of oil on the quartz rod, and sat myself in the
35	saddle. I suppose a suicide who holds a pistol to his skull feels
35	much the same wonder at what will come next as I felt then. I took
35	the starting lever in one hand and the stopping one in the other,
35	pressed the first, and almost immediately the second. I seemed to
35	reel; I felt a nightmare sensation of falling; and, looking round,
35	I saw the laboratory exactly as before. Had anything happened? For
35	a moment I suspected that my intellect had tricked me. Then I noted
35	the clock. A moment before, as it seemed, it had stood at a minute
35	or so past ten; now it was nearly half-past three!
35	
35	'I drew a breath, set my teeth, gripped the starting lever with both
35	hands, and went off with a thud. The laboratory got hazy and went
35	dark. Mrs. Watchett came in and walked, apparently without seeing
35	me, towards the garden door. I suppose it took her a minute or so to
35	traverse the place, but to me she seemed to shoot across the room
35	like a rocket. I pressed the lever over to its extreme position. The
35	night came like the turning out of a lamp, and in another moment
35	came to-morrow. The laboratory grew faint and hazy, then fainter
35	and ever fainter. To-morrow night came black, then day again, night
35	again, day again, faster and faster still. An eddying murmur filled
35	my ears, and a strange, dumb confusedness descended on my mind.
35	
35	'I am afraid I cannot convey the peculiar sensations of time
35	travelling. They are excessively unpleasant. There is a feeling
35	exactly like that one has upon a switchback--of a helpless headlong
35	motion! I felt the same horrible anticipation, too, of an imminent
35	smash. As I put on pace, night followed day like the flapping of a
35	black wing. The dim suggestion of the laboratory seemed presently to
35	fall away from me, and I saw the sun hopping swiftly across the sky,
35	leaping it every minute, and every minute marking a day. I supposed
35	the laboratory had been destroyed and I had come into the open air.
35	I had a dim impression of scaffolding, but I was already going too
35	fast to be conscious of any moving things. The slowest snail that
35	ever crawled dashed by too fast for me. The twinkling succession of
35	darkness and light was excessively painful to the eye. Then, in the
35	intermittent darknesses, I saw the moon spinning swiftly through her
35	quarters from new to full, and had a faint glimpse of the circling
35	stars. Presently, as I went on, still gaining velocity, the
35	palpitation of night and day merged into one continuous greyness;
35	the sky took on a wonderful deepness of blue, a splendid luminous
35	color like that of early twilight; the jerking sun became a streak
35	of fire, a brilliant arch, in space; the moon a fainter fluctuating
35	band; and I could see nothing of the stars, save now and then a
35	brighter circle flickering in the blue.
35	
35	'The landscape was misty and vague. I was still on the hill-side
35	upon which this house now stands, and the shoulder rose above me
35	grey and dim. I saw trees growing and changing like puffs of vapour,
35	now brown, now green; they grew, spread, shivered, and passed away.
35	I saw huge buildings rise up faint and fair, and pass like dreams.
35	The whole surface of the earth seemed changed--melting and flowing
35	under my eyes. The little hands upon the dials that registered my
35	speed raced round faster and faster. Presently I noted that the sun
35	belt swayed up and down, from solstice to solstice, in a minute or
35	less, and that consequently my pace was over a year a minute; and
35	minute by minute the white snow flashed across the world, and
35	vanished, and was followed by the bright, brief green of spring.
35	
35	'The unpleasant sensations of the start were less poignant now. They
35	merged at last into a kind of hysterical exhilaration. I remarked
35	indeed a clumsy swaying of the machine, for which I was unable to
35	account. But my mind was too confused to attend to it, so with a
35	kind of madness growing upon me, I flung myself into futurity. At
35	first I scarce thought of stopping, scarce thought of anything but
35	these new sensations. But presently a fresh series of impressions
35	grew up in my mind--a certain curiosity and therewith a certain
35	dread--until at last they took complete possession of me. What
35	strange developments of humanity, what wonderful advances upon our
35	rudimentary civilization, I thought, might not appear when I came to
35	look nearly into the dim elusive world that raced and fluctuated
35	before my eyes! I saw great and splendid architecture rising about
35	me, more massive than any buildings of our own time, and yet, as it
35	seemed, built of glimmer and mist. I saw a richer green flow up the
35	hill-side, and remain there, without any wintry intermission. Even
35	through the veil of my confusion the earth seemed very fair. And so
35	my mind came round to the business of stopping.
35	
35	'The peculiar risk lay in the possibility of my finding some
35	substance in the space which I, or the machine, occupied. So long
35	as I travelled at a high velocity through time, this scarcely
35	mattered; I was, so to speak, attenuated--was slipping like a vapour
35	through the interstices of intervening substances! But to come to
35	a stop involved the jamming of myself, molecule by molecule, into
35	whatever lay in my way; meant bringing my atoms into such intimate
35	contact with those of the obstacle that a profound chemical
35	reaction--possibly a far-reaching explosion--would result, and blow
35	myself and my apparatus out of all possible dimensions--into the
35	Unknown. This possibility had occurred to me again and again while I
35	was making the machine; but then I had cheerfully accepted it as an
35	unavoidable risk--one of the risks a man has got to take! Now the
35	risk was inevitable, I no longer saw it in the same cheerful light.
35	The fact is that, insensibly, the absolute strangeness of everything,
35	the sickly jarring and swaying of the machine, above all, the
35	feeling of prolonged falling, had absolutely upset my nerve. I told
35	myself that I could never stop, and with a gust of petulance I
35	resolved to stop forthwith. Like an impatient fool, I lugged over
35	the lever, and incontinently the thing went reeling over, and I was
35	flung headlong through the air.
35	
35	'There was the sound of a clap of thunder in my ears. I may have
35	been stunned for a moment. A pitiless hail was hissing round me,
35	and I was sitting on soft turf in front of the overset machine.
35	Everything still seemed grey, but presently I remarked that the
35	confusion in my ears was gone. I looked round me. I was on what
35	seemed to be a little lawn in a garden, surrounded by rhododendron
35	bushes, and I noticed that their mauve and purple blossoms were
35	dropping in a shower under the beating of the hail-stones. The
35	rebounding, dancing hail hung in a cloud over the machine, and drove
35	along the ground like smoke. In a moment I was wet to the skin.
35	""Fine hospitality,"" said I, ""to a man who has travelled innumerable
35	years to see you.""
35	
35	'Presently I thought what a fool I was to get wet. I stood up and
35	looked round me. A colossal figure, carved apparently in some white
35	stone, loomed indistinctly beyond the rhododendrons through the hazy
35	downpour. But all else of the world was invisible.
35	
35	'My sensations would be hard to describe. As the columns of hail
35	grew thinner, I saw the white figure more distinctly. It was very
35	large, for a silver birch-tree touched its shoulder. It was of white
35	marble, in shape something like a winged sphinx, but the wings,
35	instead of being carried vertically at the sides, were spread so
35	that it seemed to hover. The pedestal, it appeared to me, was of
35	bronze, and was thick with verdigris. It chanced that the face was
35	towards me; the sightless eyes seemed to watch me; there was the
35	faint shadow of a smile on the lips. It was greatly weather-worn,
35	and that imparted an unpleasant suggestion of disease. I stood
35	looking at it for a little space--half a minute, perhaps, or half an
35	hour. It seemed to advance and to recede as the hail drove before it
35	denser or thinner. At last I tore my eyes from it for a moment and
35	saw that the hail curtain had worn threadbare, and that the sky was
35	lightening with the promise of the sun.
35	
35	'I looked up again at the crouching white shape, and the full
35	temerity of my voyage came suddenly upon me. What might appear when
35	that hazy curtain was altogether withdrawn? What might not have
35	happened to men? What if cruelty had grown into a common passion?
35	What if in this interval the race had lost its manliness and had
35	developed into something inhuman, unsympathetic, and overwhelmingly
35	powerful? I might seem some old-world savage animal, only the more
35	dreadful and disgusting for our common likeness--a foul creature to
35	be incontinently slain.
35	
35	'Already I saw other vast shapes--huge buildings with intricate
35	parapets and tall columns, with a wooded hill-side dimly creeping
35	in upon me through the lessening storm. I was seized with a panic
35	fear. I turned frantically to the Time Machine, and strove hard to
35	readjust it. As I did so the shafts of the sun smote through the
35	thunderstorm. The grey downpour was swept aside and vanished like
35	the trailing garments of a ghost. Above me, in the intense blue
35	of the summer sky, some faint brown shreds of cloud whirled into
35	nothingness. The great buildings about me stood out clear and
35	distinct, shining with the wet of the thunderstorm, and picked out
35	in white by the unmelted hailstones piled along their courses. I
35	felt naked in a strange world. I felt as perhaps a bird may feel in
35	the clear air, knowing the hawk wings above and will swoop. My fear
35	grew to frenzy. I took a breathing space, set my teeth, and again
35	grappled fiercely, wrist and knee, with the machine. It gave under
35	my desperate onset and turned over. It struck my chin violently. One
35	hand on the saddle, the other on the lever, I stood panting heavily
35	in attitude to mount again.
35	
35	'But with this recovery of a prompt retreat my courage recovered. I
35	looked more curiously and less fearfully at this world of the remote
35	future. In a circular opening, high up in the wall of the nearer
35	house, I saw a group of figures clad in rich soft robes. They had
35	seen me, and their faces were directed towards me.
35	
35	'Then I heard voices approaching me. Coming through the bushes by
35	the White Sphinx were the heads and shoulders of men running. One of
35	these emerged in a pathway leading straight to the little lawn upon
35	which I stood with my machine. He was a slight creature--perhaps
35	four feet high--clad in a purple tunic, girdled at the waist with a
35	leather belt. Sandals or buskins--I could not clearly distinguish
35	which--were on his feet; his legs were bare to the knees, and his
35	head was bare. Noticing that, I noticed for the first time how warm
35	the air was.
35	
35	'He struck me as being a very beautiful and graceful creature, but
35	indescribably frail. His flushed face reminded me of the more
35	beautiful kind of consumptive--that hectic beauty of which we used
35	to hear so much. At the sight of him I suddenly regained confidence.
35	I took my hands from the machine.
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	IV
35	
35	
35	'In another moment we were standing face to face, I and this fragile
35	thing out of futurity. He came straight up to me and laughed into my
35	eyes. The absence from his bearing of any sign of fear struck me at
35	once. Then he turned to the two others who were following him and
35	spoke to them in a strange and very sweet and liquid tongue.
35	
35	'There were others coming, and presently a little group of perhaps
35	eight or ten of these exquisite creatures were about me. One of them
35	addressed me. It came into my head, oddly enough, that my voice was
35	too harsh and deep for them. So I shook my head, and, pointing to my
35	ears, shook it again. He came a step forward, hesitated, and then
35	touched my hand. Then I felt other soft little tentacles upon my
35	back and shoulders. They wanted to make sure I was real. There was
35	nothing in this at all alarming. Indeed, there was something in
35	these pretty little people that inspired confidence--a graceful
35	gentleness, a certain childlike ease. And besides, they looked so
35	frail that I could fancy myself flinging the whole dozen of them
35	about like nine-pins. But I made a sudden motion to warn them when I
35	saw their little pink hands feeling at the Time Machine. Happily
35	then, when it was not too late, I thought of a danger I had hitherto
35	forgotten, and reaching over the bars of the machine I unscrewed the
35	little levers that would set it in motion, and put these in my
35	pocket. Then I turned again to see what I could do in the way of
35	communication.
35	
35	'And then, looking more nearly into their features, I saw some
35	further peculiarities in their Dresden-china type of prettiness.
35	Their hair, which was uniformly curly, came to a sharp end at the
35	neck and cheek; there was not the faintest suggestion of it on the
35	face, and their ears were singularly minute. The mouths were small,
35	with bright red, rather thin lips, and the little chins ran to a
35	point. The eyes were large and mild; and--this may seem egotism on
35	my part--I fancied even that there was a certain lack of the
35	interest I might have expected in them.
35	
35	'As they made no effort to communicate with me, but simply stood
35	round me smiling and speaking in soft cooing notes to each other, I
35	began the conversation. I pointed to the Time Machine and to myself.
35	Then hesitating for a moment how to express time, I pointed to the
35	sun. At once a quaintly pretty little figure in chequered purple and
35	white followed my gesture, and then astonished me by imitating the
35	sound of thunder.
35	
35	'For a moment I was staggered, though the import of his gesture was
35	plain enough. The question had come into my mind abruptly: were
35	these creatures fools? You may hardly understand how it took me.
35	You see I had always anticipated that the people of the year Eight
35	Hundred and Two Thousand odd would be incredibly in front of us in
35	knowledge, art, everything. Then one of them suddenly asked me a
35	question that showed him to be on the intellectual level of one of
35	our five-year-old children--asked me, in fact, if I had come from
35	the sun in a thunderstorm! It let loose the judgment I had suspended
35	upon their clothes, their frail light limbs, and fragile features.
35	A flow of disappointment rushed across my mind. For a moment I felt
35	that I had built the Time Machine in vain.
35	
35	'I nodded, pointed to the sun, and gave them such a vivid rendering
35	of a thunderclap as startled them. They all withdrew a pace or so
35	and bowed. Then came one laughing towards me, carrying a chain of
35	beautiful flowers altogether new to me, and put it about my neck.
35	The idea was received with melodious applause; and presently they
35	were all running to and fro for flowers, and laughingly flinging
35	them upon me until I was almost smothered with blossom. You who
35	have never seen the like can scarcely imagine what delicate and
35	wonderful flowers countless years of culture had created. Then
35	someone suggested that their plaything should be exhibited in the
35	nearest building, and so I was led past the sphinx of white marble,
35	which had seemed to watch me all the while with a smile at my
35	astonishment, towards a vast grey edifice of fretted stone. As I
35	went with them the memory of my confident anticipations of a
35	profoundly grave and intellectual posterity came, with irresistible
35	merriment, to my mind.
35	
35	'The building had a huge entry, and was altogether of colossal
35	dimensions. I was naturally most occupied with the growing crowd of
35	little people, and with the big open portals that yawned before me
35	shadowy and mysterious. My general impression of the world I saw
35	over their heads was a tangled waste of beautiful bushes and
35	flowers, a long neglected and yet weedless garden. I saw a number
35	of tall spikes of strange white flowers, measuring a foot perhaps
35	across the spread of the waxen petals. They grew scattered, as if
35	wild, among the variegated shrubs, but, as I say, I did not examine
35	them closely at this time. The Time Machine was left deserted on the
35	turf among the rhododendrons.
35	
35	'The arch of the doorway was richly carved, but naturally I did
35	not observe the carving very narrowly, though I fancied I saw
35	suggestions of old Phoenician decorations as I passed through, and
35	it struck me that they were very badly broken and weather-worn.
35	Several more brightly clad people met me in the doorway, and so we
35	entered, I, dressed in dingy nineteenth-century garments, looking
35	grotesque enough, garlanded with flowers, and surrounded by an
35	eddying mass of bright, soft-colored robes and shining white limbs,
35	in a melodious whirl of laughter and laughing speech.
35	
35	'The big doorway opened into a proportionately great hall hung with
35	brown. The roof was in shadow, and the windows, partially glazed
35	with coloured glass and partially unglazed, admitted a tempered
35	light. The floor was made up of huge blocks of some very hard white
35	metal, not plates nor slabs--blocks, and it was so much worn, as I
35	judged by the going to and fro of past generations, as to be deeply
35	channelled along the more frequented ways. Transverse to the length
35	were innumerable tables made of slabs of polished stone, raised
35	perhaps a foot from the floor, and upon these were heaps of fruits.
35	Some I recognized as a kind of hypertrophied raspberry and orange,
35	but for the most part they were strange.
35	
35	'Between the tables was scattered a great number of cushions.
35	Upon these my conductors seated themselves, signing for me to do
35	likewise. With a pretty absence of ceremony they began to eat the
35	fruit with their hands, flinging peel and stalks, and so forth, into
35	the round openings in the sides of the tables. I was not loath to
35	follow their example, for I felt thirsty and hungry. As I did so I
35	surveyed the hall at my leisure.
35	
35	'And perhaps the thing that struck me most was its dilapidated look.
35	The stained-glass windows, which displayed only a geometrical
35	pattern, were broken in many places, and the curtains that hung
35	across the lower end were thick with dust. And it caught my eye that
35	the corner of the marble table near me was fractured. Nevertheless,
35	the general effect was extremely rich and picturesque. There were,
35	perhaps, a couple of hundred people dining in the hall, and most of
35	them, seated as near to me as they could come, were watching me with
35	interest, their little eyes shining over the fruit they were eating.
35	All were clad in the same soft and yet strong, silky material.
35	
35	'Fruit, by the by, was all their diet. These people of the remote
35	future were strict vegetarians, and while I was with them, in spite
35	of some carnal cravings, I had to be frugivorous also. Indeed, I
35	found afterwards that horses, cattle, sheep, dogs, had followed the
35	Ichthyosaurus into extinction. But the fruits were very delightful;
35	one, in particular, that seemed to be in season all the time I was
35	there--a floury thing in a three-sided husk--was especially good,
35	and I made it my staple. At first I was puzzled by all these strange
35	fruits, and by the strange flowers I saw, but later I began to
35	perceive their import.
35	
35	'However, I am telling you of my fruit dinner in the distant future
35	now. So soon as my appetite was a little checked, I determined to
35	make a resolute attempt to learn the speech of these new men of
35	mine. Clearly that was the next thing to do. The fruits seemed a
35	convenient thing to begin upon, and holding one of these up I began
35	a series of interrogative sounds and gestures. I had some
35	considerable difficulty in conveying my meaning. At first my efforts
35	met with a stare of surprise or inextinguishable laughter, but
35	presently a fair-haired little creature seemed to grasp my intention
35	and repeated a name. They had to chatter and explain the business
35	at great length to each other, and my first attempts to make the
35	exquisite little sounds of their language caused an immense amount
35	of amusement. However, I felt like a schoolmaster amidst children,
35	and persisted, and presently I had a score of noun substantives at
35	least at my command; and then I got to demonstrative pronouns, and
35	even the verb ""to eat."" But it was slow work, and the little people
35	soon tired and wanted to get away from my interrogations, so I
35	determined, rather of necessity, to let them give their lessons in
35	little doses when they felt inclined. And very little doses I found
35	they were before long, for I never met people more indolent or more
35	easily fatigued.
35	
35	'A queer thing I soon discovered about my little hosts, and that was
35	their lack of interest. They would come to me with eager cries of
35	astonishment, like children, but like children they would soon stop
35	examining me and wander away after some other toy. The dinner and my
35	conversational beginnings ended, I noted for the first time that
35	almost all those who had surrounded me at first were gone. It is
35	odd, too, how speedily I came to disregard these little people. I
35	went out through the portal into the sunlit world again as soon as
35	my hunger was satisfied. I was continually meeting more of these men
35	of the future, who would follow me a little distance, chatter and
35	laugh about me, and, having smiled and gesticulated in a friendly
35	way, leave me again to my own devices.
35	
35	'The calm of evening was upon the world as I emerged from the great
35	hall, and the scene was lit by the warm glow of the setting sun.
35	At first things were very confusing. Everything was so entirely
35	different from the world I had known--even the flowers. The big
35	building I had left was situated on the slope of a broad river
35	valley, but the Thames had shifted perhaps a mile from its present
35	position. I resolved to mount to the summit of a crest, perhaps a
35	mile and a half away, from which I could get a wider view of this
35	our planet in the year Eight Hundred and Two Thousand Seven Hundred
35	and One A.D. For that, I should explain, was the date the little
35	dials of my machine recorded.
35	
35	'As I walked I was watching for every impression that could possibly
35	help to explain the condition of ruinous splendour in which I
35	found the world--for ruinous it was. A little way up the hill, for
35	instance, was a great heap of granite, bound together by masses of
35	aluminium, a vast labyrinth of precipitous walls and crumpled
35	heaps, amidst which were thick heaps of very beautiful pagoda-like
35	plants--nettles possibly--but wonderfully tinted with brown about
35	the leaves, and incapable of stinging. It was evidently the derelict
35	remains of some vast structure, to what end built I could not
35	determine. It was here that I was destined, at a later date, to have
35	a very strange experience--the first intimation of a still stranger
35	discovery--but of that I will speak in its proper place.
35	
35	'Looking round with a sudden thought, from a terrace on which I
35	rested for a while, I realized that there were no small houses to be
35	seen. Apparently the single house, and possibly even the household,
35	had vanished. Here and there among the greenery were palace-like
35	buildings, but the house and the cottage, which form such
35	characteristic features of our own English landscape, had
35	disappeared.
35	
35	'""Communism,"" said I to myself.
35	
35	'And on the heels of that came another thought. I looked at the
35	half-dozen little figures that were following me. Then, in a flash,
35	I perceived that all had the same form of costume, the same soft
35	hairless visage, and the same girlish rotundity of limb. It may seem
35	strange, perhaps, that I had not noticed this before. But everything
35	was so strange. Now, I saw the fact plainly enough. In costume, and
35	in all the differences of texture and bearing that now mark off the
35	sexes from each other, these people of the future were alike. And
35	the children seemed to my eyes to be but the miniatures of their
35	parents. I judged, then, that the children of that time were
35	extremely precocious, physically at least, and I found afterwards
35	abundant verification of my opinion.
35	
35	'Seeing the ease and security in which these people were living, I
35	felt that this close resemblance of the sexes was after all what
35	one would expect; for the strength of a man and the softness of a
35	woman, the institution of the family, and the differentiation of
35	occupations are mere militant necessities of an age of physical
35	force; where population is balanced and abundant, much childbearing
35	becomes an evil rather than a blessing to the State; where
35	violence comes but rarely and off-spring are secure, there is less
35	necessity--indeed there is no necessity--for an efficient family,
35	and the specialization of the sexes with reference to their
35	children's needs disappears. We see some beginnings of this even
35	in our own time, and in this future age it was complete. This, I
35	must remind you, was my speculation at the time. Later, I was to
35	appreciate how far it fell short of the reality.
35	
35	'While I was musing upon these things, my attention was attracted by
35	a pretty little structure, like a well under a cupola. I thought in
35	a transitory way of the oddness of wells still existing, and then
35	resumed the thread of my speculations. There were no large buildings
35	towards the top of the hill, and as my walking powers were evidently
35	miraculous, I was presently left alone for the first time. With a
35	strange sense of freedom and adventure I pushed on up to the crest.
35	
35	'There I found a seat of some yellow metal that I did not recognize,
35	corroded in places with a kind of pinkish rust and half smothered
35	in soft moss, the arm-rests cast and filed into the resemblance of
35	griffins' heads. I sat down on it, and I surveyed the broad view of
35	our old world under the sunset of that long day. It was as sweet and
35	fair a view as I have ever seen. The sun had already gone below the
35	horizon and the west was flaming gold, touched with some horizontal
35	bars of purple and crimson. Below was the valley of the Thames, in
35	which the river lay like a band of burnished steel. I have already
35	spoken of the great palaces dotted about among the variegated
35	greenery, some in ruins and some still occupied. Here and there rose
35	a white or silvery figure in the waste garden of the earth, here and
35	there came the sharp vertical line of some cupola or obelisk. There
35	were no hedges, no signs of proprietary rights, no evidences of
35	agriculture; the whole earth had become a garden.
35	
35	'So watching, I began to put my interpretation upon the things I had
35	seen, and as it shaped itself to me that evening, my interpretation
35	was something in this way. (Afterwards I found I had got only a
35	half-truth--or only a glimpse of one facet of the truth.)
35	
35	'It seemed to me that I had happened upon humanity upon the wane.
35	The ruddy sunset set me thinking of the sunset of mankind. For the
35	first time I began to realize an odd consequence of the social
35	effort in which we are at present engaged. And yet, come to think,
35	it is a logical consequence enough. Strength is the outcome of need;
35	security sets a premium on feebleness. The work of ameliorating the
35	conditions of life--the true civilizing process that makes life more
35	and more secure--had gone steadily on to a climax. One triumph of a
35	united humanity over Nature had followed another. Things that are
35	now mere dreams had become projects deliberately put in hand and
35	carried forward. And the harvest was what I saw!
35	
35	'After all, the sanitation and the agriculture of to-day are still
35	in the rudimentary stage. The science of our time has attacked but
35	a little department of the field of human disease, but even so,
35	it spreads its operations very steadily and persistently. Our
35	agriculture and horticulture destroy a weed just here and there and
35	cultivate perhaps a score or so of wholesome plants, leaving the
35	greater number to fight out a balance as they can. We improve our
35	favourite plants and animals--and how few they are--gradually by
35	selective breeding; now a new and better peach, now a seedless
35	grape, now a sweeter and larger flower, now a more convenient breed
35	of cattle. We improve them gradually, because our ideals are vague
35	and tentative, and our knowledge is very limited; because Nature,
35	too, is shy and slow in our clumsy hands. Some day all this will
35	be better organized, and still better. That is the drift of the
35	current in spite of the eddies. The whole world will be intelligent,
35	educated, and co-operating; things will move faster and faster
35	towards the subjugation of Nature. In the end, wisely and carefully
35	we shall readjust the balance of animal and vegetable life to suit
35	our human needs.
35	
35	'This adjustment, I say, must have been done, and done well; done
35	indeed for all Time, in the space of Time across which my machine
35	had leaped. The air was free from gnats, the earth from weeds or
35	fungi; everywhere were fruits and sweet and delightful flowers;
35	brilliant butterflies flew hither and thither. The ideal of
35	preventive medicine was attained. Diseases had been stamped out. I
35	saw no evidence of any contagious diseases during all my stay. And I
35	shall have to tell you later that even the processes of putrefaction
35	and decay had been profoundly affected by these changes.
35	
35	'Social triumphs, too, had been effected. I saw mankind housed in
35	splendid shelters, gloriously clothed, and as yet I had found them
35	engaged in no toil. There were no signs of struggle, neither social
35	nor economical struggle. The shop, the advertisement, traffic, all
35	that commerce which constitutes the body of our world, was gone. It
35	was natural on that golden evening that I should jump at the idea of
35	a social paradise. The difficulty of increasing population had been
35	met, I guessed, and population had ceased to increase.
35	
35	'But with this change in condition comes inevitably adaptations to
35	the change. What, unless biological science is a mass of errors, is
35	the cause of human intelligence and vigour? Hardship and freedom:
35	conditions under which the active, strong, and subtle survive and
35	the weaker go to the wall; conditions that put a premium upon the
35	loyal alliance of capable men, upon self-restraint, patience, and
35	decision. And the institution of the family, and the emotions that
35	arise therein, the fierce jealousy, the tenderness for offspring,
35	parental self-devotion, all found their justification and support in
35	the imminent dangers of the young. _Now_, where are these imminent
35	dangers? There is a sentiment arising, and it will grow, against
35	connubial jealousy, against fierce maternity, against passion
35	of all sorts; unnecessary things now, and things that make us
35	uncomfortable, savage survivals, discords in a refined and pleasant
35	life.
35	
35	'I thought of the physical slightness of the people, their lack of
35	intelligence, and those big abundant ruins, and it strengthened my
35	belief in a perfect conquest of Nature. For after the battle comes
35	Quiet. Humanity had been strong, energetic, and intelligent, and had
35	used all its abundant vitality to alter the conditions under which
35	it lived. And now came the reaction of the altered conditions.
35	
35	'Under the new conditions of perfect comfort and security, that
35	restless energy, that with us is strength, would become weakness.
35	Even in our own time certain tendencies and desires, once necessary
35	to survival, are a constant source of failure. Physical courage and
35	the love of battle, for instance, are no great help--may even be
35	hindrances--to a civilized man. And in a state of physical balance
35	and security, power, intellectual as well as physical, would be out
35	of place. For countless years I judged there had been no danger of
35	war or solitary violence, no danger from wild beasts, no wasting
35	disease to require strength of constitution, no need of toil. For
35	such a life, what we should call the weak are as well equipped as
35	the strong, are indeed no longer weak. Better equipped indeed they
35	are, for the strong would be fretted by an energy for which there
35	was no outlet. No doubt the exquisite beauty of the buildings I saw
35	was the outcome of the last surgings of the now purposeless energy
35	of mankind before it settled down into perfect harmony with the
35	conditions under which it lived--the flourish of that triumph which
35	began the last great peace. This has ever been the fate of energy in
35	security; it takes to art and to eroticism, and then come languor
35	and decay.
35	
35	'Even this artistic impetus would at last die away--had almost died
35	in the Time I saw. To adorn themselves with flowers, to dance, to
35	sing in the sunlight: so much was left of the artistic spirit, and
35	no more. Even that would fade in the end into a contented
35	inactivity. We are kept keen on the grindstone of pain and
35	necessity, and, it seemed to me, that here was that hateful
35	grindstone broken at last!
35	
35	'As I stood there in the gathering dark I thought that in this
35	simple explanation I had mastered the problem of the world--mastered
35	the whole secret of these delicious people. Possibly the checks they
35	had devised for the increase of population had succeeded too well,
35	and their numbers had rather diminished than kept stationary.
35	That would account for the abandoned ruins. Very simple was my
35	explanation, and plausible enough--as most wrong theories are!
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	V
35	
35	
35	'As I stood there musing over this too perfect triumph of man, the
35	full moon, yellow and gibbous, came up out of an overflow of silver
35	light in the north-east. The bright little figures ceased to move
35	about below, a noiseless owl flitted by, and I shivered with the
35	chill of the night. I determined to descend and find where I could
35	sleep.
35	
35	'I looked for the building I knew. Then my eye travelled along to
35	the figure of the White Sphinx upon the pedestal of bronze, growing
35	distinct as the light of the rising moon grew brighter. I could see
35	the silver birch against it. There was the tangle of rhododendron
35	bushes, black in the pale light, and there was the little lawn.
35	I looked at the lawn again. A queer doubt chilled my complacency.
35	""No,"" said I stoutly to myself, ""that was not the lawn.""
35	
35	'But it _was_ the lawn. For the white leprous face of the sphinx was
35	towards it. Can you imagine what I felt as this conviction came
35	home to me? But you cannot. The Time Machine was gone!
35	
35	'At once, like a lash across the face, came the possibility of
35	losing my own age, of being left helpless in this strange new world.
35	The bare thought of it was an actual physical sensation. I could
35	feel it grip me at the throat and stop my breathing. In another
35	moment I was in a passion of fear and running with great leaping
35	strides down the slope. Once I fell headlong and cut my face; I lost
35	no time in stanching the blood, but jumped up and ran on, with a
35	warm trickle down my cheek and chin. All the time I ran I was saying
35	to myself: ""They have moved it a little, pushed it under the bushes
35	out of the way."" Nevertheless, I ran with all my might. All the
35	time, with the certainty that sometimes comes with excessive dread,
35	I knew that such assurance was folly, knew instinctively that the
35	machine was removed out of my reach. My breath came with pain. I
35	suppose I covered the whole distance from the hill crest to the
35	little lawn, two miles perhaps, in ten minutes. And I am not a young
35	man. I cursed aloud, as I ran, at my confident folly in leaving the
35	machine, wasting good breath thereby. I cried aloud, and none
35	answered. Not a creature seemed to be stirring in that moonlit
35	world.
35	
35	'When I reached the lawn my worst fears were realized. Not a trace
35	of the thing was to be seen. I felt faint and cold when I faced the
35	empty space among the black tangle of bushes. I ran round it
35	furiously, as if the thing might be hidden in a corner, and then
35	stopped abruptly, with my hands clutching my hair. Above me towered
35	the sphinx, upon the bronze pedestal, white, shining, leprous, in
35	the light of the rising moon. It seemed to smile in mockery of my
35	dismay.
35	
35	'I might have consoled myself by imagining the little people had put
35	the mechanism in some shelter for me, had I not felt assured of
35	their physical and intellectual inadequacy. That is what dismayed
35	me: the sense of some hitherto unsuspected power, through whose
35	intervention my invention had vanished. Yet, for one thing I felt
35	assured: unless some other age had produced its exact duplicate,
35	the machine could not have moved in time. The attachment of the
35	levers--I will show you the method later--prevented any one from
35	tampering with it in that way when they were removed. It had moved,
35	and was hid, only in space. But then, where could it be?
35	
35	'I think I must have had a kind of frenzy. I remember running
35	violently in and out among the moonlit bushes all round the sphinx,
35	and startling some white animal that, in the dim light, I took for a
35	small deer. I remember, too, late that night, beating the bushes
35	with my clenched fist until my knuckles were gashed and bleeding
35	from the broken twigs. Then, sobbing and raving in my anguish of
35	mind, I went down to the great building of stone. The big hall was
35	dark, silent, and deserted. I slipped on the uneven floor, and fell
35	over one of the malachite tables, almost breaking my shin. I lit a
35	match and went on past the dusty curtains, of which I have told you.
35	
35	'There I found a second great hall covered with cushions, upon
35	which, perhaps, a score or so of the little people were sleeping. I
35	have no doubt they found my second appearance strange enough, coming
35	suddenly out of the quiet darkness with inarticulate noises and the
35	splutter and flare of a match. For they had forgotten about matches.
35	""Where is my Time Machine?"" I began, bawling like an angry child,
35	laying hands upon them and shaking them up together. It must have
35	been very queer to them. Some laughed, most of them looked sorely
35	frightened. When I saw them standing round me, it came into my head
35	that I was doing as foolish a thing as it was possible for me to do
35	under the circumstances, in trying to revive the sensation of fear.
35	For, reasoning from their daylight behaviour, I thought that fear
35	must be forgotten.
35	
35	'Abruptly, I dashed down the match, and, knocking one of the people
35	over in my course, went blundering across the big dining-hall again,
35	out under the moonlight. I heard cries of terror and their little
35	feet running and stumbling this way and that. I do not remember all
35	I did as the moon crept up the sky. I suppose it was the unexpected
35	nature of my loss that maddened me. I felt hopelessly cut off from
35	my own kind--a strange animal in an unknown world. I must have raved
35	to and fro, screaming and crying upon God and Fate. I have a memory
35	of horrible fatigue, as the long night of despair wore away; of
35	looking in this impossible place and that; of groping among moon-lit
35	ruins and touching strange creatures in the black shadows; at last,
35	of lying on the ground near the sphinx and weeping with absolute
35	wretchedness. I had nothing left but misery. Then I slept, and when
35	I woke again it was full day, and a couple of sparrows were hopping
35	round me on the turf within reach of my arm.
35	
35	'I sat up in the freshness of the morning, trying to remember how
35	I had got there, and why I had such a profound sense of desertion
35	and despair. Then things came clear in my mind. With the plain,
35	reasonable daylight, I could look my circumstances fairly in the
35	face. I saw the wild folly of my frenzy overnight, and I could
35	reason with myself. ""Suppose the worst?"" I said. ""Suppose the
35	machine altogether lost--perhaps destroyed? It behoves me to be
35	calm and patient, to learn the way of the people, to get a clear
35	idea of the method of my loss, and the means of getting materials
35	and tools; so that in the end, perhaps, I may make another."" That
35	would be my only hope, perhaps, but better than despair. And, after
35	all, it was a beautiful and curious world.
35	
35	'But probably, the machine had only been taken away. Still, I must
35	be calm and patient, find its hiding-place, and recover it by force
35	or cunning. And with that I scrambled to my feet and looked about
35	me, wondering where I could bathe. I felt weary, stiff, and
35	travel-soiled. The freshness of the morning made me desire an equal
35	freshness. I had exhausted my emotion. Indeed, as I went about
35	my business, I found myself wondering at my intense excitement
35	overnight. I made a careful examination of the ground about the
35	little lawn. I wasted some time in futile questionings, conveyed, as
35	well as I was able, to such of the little people as came by. They
35	all failed to understand my gestures; some were simply stolid, some
35	thought it was a jest and laughed at me. I had the hardest task in
35	the world to keep my hands off their pretty laughing faces. It was
35	a foolish impulse, but the devil begotten of fear and blind anger
35	was ill curbed and still eager to take advantage of my perplexity.
35	The turf gave better counsel. I found a groove ripped in it, about
35	midway between the pedestal of the sphinx and the marks of my feet
35	where, on arrival, I had struggled with the overturned machine.
35	There were other signs of removal about, with queer narrow
35	footprints like those I could imagine made by a sloth. This directed
35	my closer attention to the pedestal. It was, as I think I have said,
35	of bronze. It was not a mere block, but highly decorated with deep
35	framed panels on either side. I went and rapped at these. The
35	pedestal was hollow. Examining the panels with care I found them
35	discontinuous with the frames. There were no handles or keyholes,
35	but possibly the panels, if they were doors, as I supposed, opened
35	from within. One thing was clear enough to my mind. It took no very
35	great mental effort to infer that my Time Machine was inside that
35	pedestal. But how it got there was a different problem.
35	
35	'I saw the heads of two orange-clad people coming through the bushes
35	and under some blossom-covered apple-trees towards me. I turned
35	smiling to them and beckoned them to me. They came, and then,
35	pointing to the bronze pedestal, I tried to intimate my wish to open
35	it. But at my first gesture towards this they behaved very oddly. I
35	don't know how to convey their expression to you. Suppose you were
35	to use a grossly improper gesture to a delicate-minded woman--it is
35	how she would look. They went off as if they had received the last
35	possible insult. I tried a sweet-looking little chap in white next,
35	with exactly the same result. Somehow, his manner made me feel
35	ashamed of myself. But, as you know, I wanted the Time Machine, and
35	I tried him once more. As he turned off, like the others, my temper
35	got the better of me. In three strides I was after him, had him by
35	the loose part of his robe round the neck, and began dragging him
35	towards the sphinx. Then I saw the horror and repugnance of his
35	face, and all of a sudden I let him go.
35	
35	'But I was not beaten yet. I banged with my fist at the bronze
35	panels. I thought I heard something stir inside--to be explicit,
35	I thought I heard a sound like a chuckle--but I must have been
35	mistaken. Then I got a big pebble from the river, and came and
35	hammered till I had flattened a coil in the decorations, and the
35	verdigris came off in powdery flakes. The delicate little people
35	must have heard me hammering in gusty outbreaks a mile away on
35	either hand, but nothing came of it. I saw a crowd of them upon the
35	slopes, looking furtively at me. At last, hot and tired, I sat down
35	to watch the place. But I was too restless to watch long; I am too
35	Occidental for a long vigil. I could work at a problem for years,
35	but to wait inactive for twenty-four hours--that is another matter.
35	
35	'I got up after a time, and began walking aimlessly through the
35	bushes towards the hill again. ""Patience,"" said I to myself. ""If you
35	want your machine again you must leave that sphinx alone. If they
35	mean to take your machine away, it's little good your wrecking their
35	bronze panels, and if they don't, you will get it back as soon as
35	you can ask for it. To sit among all those unknown things before a
35	puzzle like that is hopeless. That way lies monomania. Face this
35	world. Learn its ways, watch it, be careful of too hasty guesses
35	at its meaning. In the end you will find clues to it all."" Then
35	suddenly the humour of the situation came into my mind: the thought
35	of the years I had spent in study and toil to get into the future
35	age, and now my passion of anxiety to get out of it. I had made
35	myself the most complicated and the most hopeless trap that ever a
35	man devised. Although it was at my own expense, I could not help
35	myself. I laughed aloud.
35	
35	'Going through the big palace, it seemed to me that the little
35	people avoided me. It may have been my fancy, or it may have had
35	something to do with my hammering at the gates of bronze. Yet I felt
35	tolerably sure of the avoidance. I was careful, however, to show no
35	concern and to abstain from any pursuit of them, and in the course
35	of a day or two things got back to the old footing. I made what
35	progress I could in the language, and in addition I pushed my
35	explorations here and there. Either I missed some subtle point or
35	their language was excessively simple--almost exclusively composed
35	of concrete substantives and verbs. There seemed to be few, if any,
35	abstract terms, or little use of figurative language. Their
35	sentences were usually simple and of two words, and I failed to
35	convey or understand any but the simplest propositions. I determined
35	to put the thought of my Time Machine and the mystery of the bronze
35	doors under the sphinx as much as possible in a corner of memory,
35	until my growing knowledge would lead me back to them in a natural
35	way. Yet a certain feeling, you may understand, tethered me in a
35	circle of a few miles round the point of my arrival.
35	
35	'So far as I could see, all the world displayed the same exuberant
35	richness as the Thames valley. From every hill I climbed I saw the
35	same abundance of splendid buildings, endlessly varied in material
35	and style, the same clustering thickets of evergreens, the same
35	blossom-laden trees and tree-ferns. Here and there water shone like
35	silver, and beyond, the land rose into blue undulating hills, and
35	so faded into the serenity of the sky. A peculiar feature, which
35	presently attracted my attention, was the presence of certain
35	circular wells, several, as it seemed to me, of a very great depth.
35	One lay by the path up the hill, which I had followed during my
35	first walk. Like the others, it was rimmed with bronze, curiously
35	wrought, and protected by a little cupola from the rain. Sitting by
35	the side of these wells, and peering down into the shafted darkness,
35	I could see no gleam of water, nor could I start any reflection
35	with a lighted match. But in all of them I heard a certain sound:
35	a thud--thud--thud, like the beating of some big engine; and I
35	discovered, from the flaring of my matches, that a steady current of
35	air set down the shafts. Further, I threw a scrap of paper into the
35	throat of one, and, instead of fluttering slowly down, it was at
35	once sucked swiftly out of sight.
35	
35	'After a time, too, I came to connect these wells with tall towers
