35	day, as pleasant as the day of the cattle in the field. Like the
35	cattle, they knew of no enemies and provided against no needs. And
35	their end was the same.
35	
35	'I grieved to think how brief the dream of the human intellect had
35	been. It had committed suicide. It had set itself steadfastly
35	towards comfort and ease, a balanced society with security and
35	permanency as its watchword, it had attained its hopes--to come
35	to this at last. Once, life and property must have reached almost
35	absolute safety. The rich had been assured of his wealth and
35	comfort, the toiler assured of his life and work. No doubt in that
35	perfect world there had been no unemployed problem, no social
35	question left unsolved. And a great quiet had followed.
35	
35	'It is a law of nature we overlook, that intellectual versatility
35	is the compensation for change, danger, and trouble. An animal
35	perfectly in harmony with its environment is a perfect mechanism.
35	Nature never appeals to intelligence until habit and instinct are
35	useless. There is no intelligence where there is no change and no
35	need of change. Only those animals partake of intelligence that have
35	to meet a huge variety of needs and dangers.
35	
35	'So, as I see it, the Upper-world man had drifted towards his
35	feeble prettiness, and the Under-world to mere mechanical industry.
35	But that perfect state had lacked one thing even for mechanical
35	perfection--absolute permanency. Apparently as time went on, the
35	feeding of the Under-world, however it was effected, had become
35	disjointed. Mother Necessity, who had been staved off for a
35	few thousand years, came back again, and she began below. The
35	Under-world being in contact with machinery, which, however perfect,
35	still needs some little thought outside habit, had probably retained
35	perforce rather more initiative, if less of every other human
35	character, than the Upper. And when other meat failed them, they
35	turned to what old habit had hitherto forbidden. So I say I saw it
35	in my last view of the world of Eight Hundred and Two Thousand Seven
35	Hundred and One. It may be as wrong an explanation as mortal wit
35	could invent. It is how the thing shaped itself to me, and as that I
35	give it to you.
35	
35	'After the fatigues, excitements, and terrors of the past days, and
35	in spite of my grief, this seat and the tranquil view and the warm
35	sunlight were very pleasant. I was very tired and sleepy, and soon
35	my theorizing passed into dozing. Catching myself at that, I took my
35	own hint, and spreading myself out upon the turf I had a long and
35	refreshing sleep.
35	
35	'I awoke a little before sunsetting. I now felt safe against being
35	caught napping by the Morlocks, and, stretching myself, I came on
35	down the hill towards the White Sphinx. I had my crowbar in one
35	hand, and the other hand played with the matches in my pocket.
35	
35	'And now came a most unexpected thing. As I approached the pedestal
35	of the sphinx I found the bronze valves were open. They had slid
35	down into grooves.
35	
35	'At that I stopped short before them, hesitating to enter.
35	
35	'Within was a small apartment, and on a raised place in the corner
35	of this was the Time Machine. I had the small levers in my pocket.
35	So here, after all my elaborate preparations for the siege of the
35	White Sphinx, was a meek surrender. I threw my iron bar away, almost
35	sorry not to use it.
35	
35	'A sudden thought came into my head as I stooped towards the portal.
35	For once, at least, I grasped the mental operations of the Morlocks.
35	Suppressing a strong inclination to laugh, I stepped through the
35	bronze frame and up to the Time Machine. I was surprised to find it
35	had been carefully oiled and cleaned. I have suspected since that
35	the Morlocks had even partially taken it to pieces while trying in
35	their dim way to grasp its purpose.
35	
35	'Now as I stood and examined it, finding a pleasure in the mere
35	touch of the contrivance, the thing I had expected happened. The
35	bronze panels suddenly slid up and struck the frame with a clang.
35	I was in the dark--trapped. So the Morlocks thought. At that I
35	chuckled gleefully.
35	
35	'I could already hear their murmuring laughter as they came towards
35	me. Very calmly I tried to strike the match. I had only to fix on
35	the levers and depart then like a ghost. But I had overlooked one
35	little thing. The matches were of that abominable kind that light
35	only on the box.
35	
35	'You may imagine how all my calm vanished. The little brutes were
35	close upon me. One touched me. I made a sweeping blow in the dark at
35	them with the levers, and began to scramble into the saddle of the
35	machine. Then came one hand upon me and then another. Then I had
35	simply to fight against their persistent fingers for my levers, and
35	at the same time feel for the studs over which these fitted. One,
35	indeed, they almost got away from me. As it slipped from my hand,
35	I had to butt in the dark with my head--I could hear the Morlock's
35	skull ring--to recover it. It was a nearer thing than the fight in
35	the forest, I think, this last scramble.
35	
35	'But at last the lever was fitted and pulled over. The clinging
35	hands slipped from me. The darkness presently fell from my eyes.
35	I found myself in the same grey light and tumult I have already
35	described.
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	XI
35	
35	
35	'I have already told you of the sickness and confusion that comes
35	with time travelling. And this time I was not seated properly in the
35	saddle, but sideways and in an unstable fashion. For an indefinite
35	time I clung to the machine as it swayed and vibrated, quite
35	unheeding how I went, and when I brought myself to look at the dials
35	again I was amazed to find where I had arrived. One dial records
35	days, and another thousands of days, another millions of days, and
35	another thousands of millions. Now, instead of reversing the levers,
35	I had pulled them over so as to go forward with them, and when I
35	came to look at these indicators I found that the thousands hand was
35	sweeping round as fast as the seconds hand of a watch--into
35	futurity.
35	
35	'As I drove on, a peculiar change crept over the appearance of
35	things. The palpitating greyness grew darker; then--though I was
35	still travelling with prodigious velocity--the blinking succession
35	of day and night, which was usually indicative of a slower pace,
35	returned, and grew more and more marked. This puzzled me very much
35	at first. The alternations of night and day grew slower and slower,
35	and so did the passage of the sun across the sky, until they seemed
35	to stretch through centuries. At last a steady twilight brooded over
35	the earth, a twilight only broken now and then when a comet glared
35	across the darkling sky. The band of light that had indicated the
35	sun had long since disappeared; for the sun had ceased to set--it
35	simply rose and fell in the west, and grew ever broader and more
35	red. All trace of the moon had vanished. The circling of the stars,
35	growing slower and slower, had given place to creeping points of
35	light. At last, some time before I stopped, the sun, red and very
35	large, halted motionless upon the horizon, a vast dome glowing with
35	a dull heat, and now and then suffering a momentary extinction. At
35	one time it had for a little while glowed more brilliantly again,
35	but it speedily reverted to its sullen red heat. I perceived by this
35	slowing down of its rising and setting that the work of the tidal
35	drag was done. The earth had come to rest with one face to the sun,
35	even as in our own time the moon faces the earth. Very cautiously,
35	for I remembered my former headlong fall, I began to reverse
35	my motion. Slower and slower went the circling hands until the
35	thousands one seemed motionless and the daily one was no longer a
35	mere mist upon its scale. Still slower, until the dim outlines of a
35	desolate beach grew visible.
35	
35	'I stopped very gently and sat upon the Time Machine, looking round.
35	The sky was no longer blue. North-eastward it was inky black,
35	and out of the blackness shone brightly and steadily the pale
35	white stars. Overhead it was a deep Indian red and starless, and
35	south-eastward it grew brighter to a glowing scarlet where, cut by
35	the horizon, lay the huge hull of the sun, red and motionless. The
35	rocks about me were of a harsh reddish colour, and all the trace of
35	life that I could see at first was the intensely green vegetation
35	that covered every projecting point on their south-eastern face. It
35	was the same rich green that one sees on forest moss or on the
35	lichen in caves: plants which like these grow in a perpetual
35	twilight.
35	
35	'The machine was standing on a sloping beach. The sea stretched away
35	to the south-west, to rise into a sharp bright horizon against the
35	wan sky. There were no breakers and no waves, for not a breath of
35	wind was stirring. Only a slight oily swell rose and fell like a
35	gentle breathing, and showed that the eternal sea was still moving
35	and living. And along the margin where the water sometimes broke was
35	a thick incrustation of salt--pink under the lurid sky. There was a
35	sense of oppression in my head, and I noticed that I was breathing
35	very fast. The sensation reminded me of my only experience of
35	mountaineering, and from that I judged the air to be more rarefied
35	than it is now.
35	
35	'Far away up the desolate slope I heard a harsh scream, and saw a
35	thing like a huge white butterfly go slanting and fluttering up into
35	the sky and, circling, disappear over some low hillocks beyond. The
35	sound of its voice was so dismal that I shivered and seated myself
35	more firmly upon the machine. Looking round me again, I saw that,
35	quite near, what I had taken to be a reddish mass of rock was moving
35	slowly towards me. Then I saw the thing was really a monstrous
35	crab-like creature. Can you imagine a crab as large as yonder table,
35	with its many legs moving slowly and uncertainly, its big claws
35	swaying, its long antennae, like carters' whips, waving and feeling,
35	and its stalked eyes gleaming at you on either side of its metallic
35	front? Its back was corrugated and ornamented with ungainly bosses,
35	and a greenish incrustation blotched it here and there. I could see
35	the many palps of its complicated mouth flickering and feeling as it
35	moved.
35	
35	'As I stared at this sinister apparition crawling towards me, I felt
35	a tickling on my cheek as though a fly had lighted there. I tried to
35	brush it away with my hand, but in a moment it returned, and almost
35	immediately came another by my ear. I struck at this, and caught
35	something threadlike. It was drawn swiftly out of my hand. With a
35	frightful qualm, I turned, and I saw that I had grasped the antenna
35	of another monster crab that stood just behind me. Its evil eyes
35	were wriggling on their stalks, its mouth was all alive with
35	appetite, and its vast ungainly claws, smeared with an algal slime,
35	were descending upon me. In a moment my hand was on the lever, and
35	I had placed a month between myself and these monsters. But I was
35	still on the same beach, and I saw them distinctly now as soon as I
35	stopped. Dozens of them seemed to be crawling here and there, in the
35	sombre light, among the foliated sheets of intense green.
35	
35	'I cannot convey the sense of abominable desolation that hung over
35	the world. The red eastern sky, the northward blackness, the salt
35	Dead Sea, the stony beach crawling with these foul, slow-stirring
35	monsters, the uniform poisonous-looking green of the lichenous
35	plants, the thin air that hurts one's lungs: all contributed to an
35	appalling effect. I moved on a hundred years, and there was the same
35	red sun--a little larger, a little duller--the same dying sea, the
35	same chill air, and the same crowd of earthy crustacea creeping in
35	and out among the green weed and the red rocks. And in the westward
35	sky, I saw a curved pale line like a vast new moon.
35	
35	'So I travelled, stopping ever and again, in great strides of a
35	thousand years or more, drawn on by the mystery of the earth's fate,
35	watching with a strange fascination the sun grow larger and duller
35	in the westward sky, and the life of the old earth ebb away. At
35	last, more than thirty million years hence, the huge red-hot dome of
35	the sun had come to obscure nearly a tenth part of the darkling
35	heavens. Then I stopped once more, for the crawling multitude of
35	crabs had disappeared, and the red beach, save for its livid green
35	liverworts and lichens, seemed lifeless. And now it was flecked with
35	white. A bitter cold assailed me. Rare white flakes ever and again
35	came eddying down. To the north-eastward, the glare of snow lay
35	under the starlight of the sable sky and I could see an undulating
35	crest of hillocks pinkish white. There were fringes of ice along the
35	sea margin, with drifting masses further out; but the main expanse
35	of that salt ocean, all bloody under the eternal sunset, was still
35	unfrozen.
35	
35	'I looked about me to see if any traces of animal life remained. A
35	certain indefinable apprehension still kept me in the saddle of the
35	machine. But I saw nothing moving, in earth or sky or sea. The green
35	slime on the rocks alone testified that life was not extinct. A
35	shallow sandbank had appeared in the sea and the water had receded
35	from the beach. I fancied I saw some black object flopping about
35	upon this bank, but it became motionless as I looked at it, and I
35	judged that my eye had been deceived, and that the black object was
35	merely a rock. The stars in the sky were intensely bright and seemed
35	to me to twinkle very little.
35	
35	'Suddenly I noticed that the circular westward outline of the sun
35	had changed; that a concavity, a bay, had appeared in the curve. I
35	saw this grow larger. For a minute perhaps I stared aghast at this
35	blackness that was creeping over the day, and then I realized that
35	an eclipse was beginning. Either the moon or the planet Mercury was
35	passing across the sun's disk. Naturally, at first I took it to be
35	the moon, but there is much to incline me to believe that what I
35	really saw was the transit of an inner planet passing very near to
35	the earth.
35	
35	'The darkness grew apace; a cold wind began to blow in freshening
35	gusts from the east, and the showering white flakes in the air
35	increased in number. From the edge of the sea came a ripple and
35	whisper. Beyond these lifeless sounds the world was silent. Silent?
35	It would be hard to convey the stillness of it. All the sounds of
35	man, the bleating of sheep, the cries of birds, the hum of insects,
35	the stir that makes the background of our lives--all that was over.
35	As the darkness thickened, the eddying flakes grew more abundant,
35	dancing before my eyes; and the cold of the air more intense. At
35	last, one by one, swiftly, one after the other, the white peaks of
35	the distant hills vanished into blackness. The breeze rose to a
35	moaning wind. I saw the black central shadow of the eclipse sweeping
35	towards me. In another moment the pale stars alone were visible. All
35	else was rayless obscurity. The sky was absolutely black.
35	
35	'A horror of this great darkness came on me. The cold, that smote
35	to my marrow, and the pain I felt in breathing, overcame me. I
35	shivered, and a deadly nausea seized me. Then like a red-hot bow
35	in the sky appeared the edge of the sun. I got off the machine to
35	recover myself. I felt giddy and incapable of facing the return
35	journey. As I stood sick and confused I saw again the moving thing
35	upon the shoal--there was no mistake now that it was a moving
35	thing--against the red water of the sea. It was a round thing, the
35	size of a football perhaps, or, it may be, bigger, and tentacles
35	trailed down from it; it seemed black against the weltering
35	blood-red water, and it was hopping fitfully about. Then I felt I
35	was fainting. But a terrible dread of lying helpless in that remote
35	and awful twilight sustained me while I clambered upon the saddle.
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	XII
35	
35	
35	'So I came back. For a long time I must have been insensible upon
35	the machine. The blinking succession of the days and nights was
35	resumed, the sun got golden again, the sky blue. I breathed with
35	greater freedom. The fluctuating contours of the land ebbed and
35	flowed. The hands spun backward upon the dials. At last I saw again
35	the dim shadows of houses, the evidences of decadent humanity.
35	These, too, changed and passed, and others came. Presently, when the
35	million dial was at zero, I slackened speed. I began to recognize
35	our own pretty and familiar architecture, the thousands hand ran back
35	to the starting-point, the night and day flapped slower and slower.
35	Then the old walls of the laboratory came round me. Very gently,
35	now, I slowed the mechanism down.
35	
35	'I saw one little thing that seemed odd to me. I think I have told
35	you that when I set out, before my velocity became very high, Mrs.
35	Watchett had walked across the room, travelling, as it seemed to me,
35	like a rocket. As I returned, I passed again across that minute when
35	she traversed the laboratory. But now her every motion appeared to
35	be the exact inversion of her previous ones. The door at the lower
35	end opened, and she glided quietly up the laboratory, back foremost,
35	and disappeared behind the door by which she had previously entered.
35	Just before that I seemed to see Hillyer for a moment; but he passed
35	like a flash.
35	
35	'Then I stopped the machine, and saw about me again the old familiar
35	laboratory, my tools, my appliances just as I had left them. I got
35	off the thing very shakily, and sat down upon my bench. For several
35	minutes I trembled violently. Then I became calmer. Around me was
35	my old workshop again, exactly as it had been. I might have slept
35	there, and the whole thing have been a dream.
35	
35	'And yet, not exactly! The thing had started from the south-east
35	corner of the laboratory. It had come to rest again in the
35	north-west, against the wall where you saw it. That gives you the
35	exact distance from my little lawn to the pedestal of the White
35	Sphinx, into which the Morlocks had carried my machine.
35	
35	'For a time my brain went stagnant. Presently I got up and came
35	through the passage here, limping, because my heel was still
35	painful, and feeling sorely begrimed. I saw the _Pall Mall Gazette_
35	on the table by the door. I found the date was indeed to-day, and
35	looking at the timepiece, saw the hour was almost eight o'clock. I
35	heard your voices and the clatter of plates. I hesitated--I felt so
35	sick and weak. Then I sniffed good wholesome meat, and opened the
35	door on you. You know the rest. I washed, and dined, and now I am
35	telling you the story.
35	
35	'I know,' he said, after a pause, 'that all this will be absolutely
35	incredible to you. To me the one incredible thing is that I am here
35	to-night in this old familiar room looking into your friendly faces
35	and telling you these strange adventures.'
35	
35	He looked at the Medical Man. 'No. I cannot expect you to believe
35	it. Take it as a lie--or a prophecy. Say I dreamed it in the
35	workshop. Consider I have been speculating upon the destinies of our
35	race until I have hatched this fiction. Treat my assertion of its
35	truth as a mere stroke of art to enhance its interest. And taking
35	it as a story, what do you think of it?'
35	
35	He took up his pipe, and began, in his old accustomed manner, to tap
35	with it nervously upon the bars of the grate. There was a momentary
35	stillness. Then chairs began to creak and shoes to scrape upon the
35	carpet. I took my eyes off the Time Traveller's face, and looked
35	round at his audience. They were in the dark, and little spots of
35	colour swam before them. The Medical Man seemed absorbed in the
35	contemplation of our host. The Editor was looking hard at the end
35	of his cigar--the sixth. The Journalist fumbled for his watch. The
35	others, as far as I remember, were motionless.
35	
35	The Editor stood up with a sigh. 'What a pity it is you're not
35	a writer of stories!' he said, putting his hand on the Time
35	Traveller's shoulder.
35	
35	'You don't believe it?'
35	
35	'Well----'
35	
35	'I thought not.'
35	
35	The Time Traveller turned to us. 'Where are the matches?' he said.
35	He lit one and spoke over his pipe, puffing. 'To tell you the truth
35	... I hardly believe it myself.... And yet...'
35	
35	His eye fell with a mute inquiry upon the withered white flowers
35	upon the little table. Then he turned over the hand holding his
35	pipe, and I saw he was looking at some half-healed scars on his
35	knuckles.
35	
35	The Medical Man rose, came to the lamp, and examined the flowers.
35	'The gynaeceum's odd,' he said. The Psychologist leant forward to
35	see, holding out his hand for a specimen.
35	
35	'I'm hanged if it isn't a quarter to one,' said the Journalist.
35	'How shall we get home?'
35	
35	'Plenty of cabs at the station,' said the Psychologist.
35	
35	'It's a curious thing,' said the Medical Man; 'but I certainly don't
35	know the natural order of these flowers. May I have them?'
35	
35	The Time Traveller hesitated. Then suddenly: 'Certainly not.'
35	
35	'Where did you really get them?' said the Medical Man.
35	
35	The Time Traveller put his hand to his head. He spoke like one who
35	was trying to keep hold of an idea that eluded him. 'They were put
35	into my pocket by Weena, when I travelled into Time.' He stared
35	round the room. 'I'm damned if it isn't all going. This room and you
35	and the atmosphere of every day is too much for my memory. Did I
35	ever make a Time Machine, or a model of a Time Machine? Or is it all
35	only a dream? They say life is a dream, a precious poor dream at
35	times--but I can't stand another that won't fit. It's madness. And
35	where did the dream come from? ... I must look at that machine. If
35	there is one!'
35	
35	He caught up the lamp swiftly, and carried it, flaring red, through
35	the door into the corridor. We followed him. There in the flickering
35	light of the lamp was the machine sure enough, squat, ugly, and
35	askew; a thing of brass, ebony, ivory, and translucent glimmering
35	quartz. Solid to the touch--for I put out my hand and felt the rail
35	of it--and with brown spots and smears upon the ivory, and bits of
35	grass and moss upon the lower parts, and one rail bent awry.
35	
35	The Time Traveller put the lamp down on the bench, and ran his hand
35	along the damaged rail. 'It's all right now,' he said. 'The story I
35	told you was true. I'm sorry to have brought you out here in the
35	cold.' He took up the lamp, and, in an absolute silence, we
35	returned to the smoking-room.
35	
35	He came into the hall with us and helped the Editor on with his
35	coat. The Medical Man looked into his face and, with a certain
35	hesitation, told him he was suffering from overwork, at which he
35	laughed hugely. I remember him standing in the open doorway, bawling
35	good night.
35	
35	I shared a cab with the Editor. He thought the tale a 'gaudy lie.'
35	For my own part I was unable to come to a conclusion. The story was
35	so fantastic and incredible, the telling so credible and sober. I
35	lay awake most of the night thinking about it. I determined to go
35	next day and see the Time Traveller again. I was told he was in the
35	laboratory, and being on easy terms in the house, I went up to him.
35	The laboratory, however, was empty. I stared for a minute at the
35	Time Machine and put out my hand and touched the lever. At that the
35	squat substantial-looking mass swayed like a bough shaken by the
35	wind. Its instability startled me extremely, and I had a queer
35	reminiscence of the childish days when I used to be forbidden to
35	meddle. I came back through the corridor. The Time Traveller met me
35	in the smoking-room. He was coming from the house. He had a small
35	camera under one arm and a knapsack under the other. He laughed when
35	he saw me, and gave me an elbow to shake. 'I'm frightfully busy,'
35	said he, 'with that thing in there.'
35	
35	'But is it not some hoax?' I said. 'Do you really travel through
35	time?'
35	
35	'Really and truly I do.' And he looked frankly into my eyes. He
35	hesitated. His eye wandered about the room. 'I only want half an
35	hour,' he said. 'I know why you came, and it's awfully good of you.
35	There's some magazines here. If you'll stop to lunch I'll prove you
35	this time travelling up to the hilt, specimen and all. If you'll
35	forgive my leaving you now?'
35	
35	I consented, hardly comprehending then the full import of his words,
35	and he nodded and went on down the corridor. I heard the door of
35	the laboratory slam, seated myself in a chair, and took up a daily
35	paper. What was he going to do before lunch-time? Then suddenly
35	I was reminded by an advertisement that I had promised to meet
35	Richardson, the publisher, at two. I looked at my watch, and saw
35	that I could barely save that engagement. I got up and went down the
35	passage to tell the Time Traveller.
35	
35	As I took hold of the handle of the door I heard an exclamation,
35	oddly truncated at the end, and a click and a thud. A gust of air
35	whirled round me as I opened the door, and from within came the
35	sound of broken glass falling on the floor. The Time Traveller was
35	not there. I seemed to see a ghostly, indistinct figure sitting in
35	a whirling mass of black and brass for a moment--a figure so
35	transparent that the bench behind with its sheets of drawings was
35	absolutely distinct; but this phantasm vanished as I rubbed my eyes.
35	The Time Machine had gone. Save for a subsiding stir of dust, the
35	further end of the laboratory was empty. A pane of the skylight had,
35	apparently, just been blown in.
35	
35	I felt an unreasonable amazement. I knew that something strange had
35	happened, and for the moment could not distinguish what the strange
35	thing might be. As I stood staring, the door into the garden opened,
35	and the man-servant appeared.
35	
35	We looked at each other. Then ideas began to come. 'Has Mr. ----
35	gone out that way?' said I.
35	
35	'No, sir. No one has come out this way. I was expecting to find him
35	here.'
35	
35	At that I understood. At the risk of disappointing Richardson I
35	stayed on, waiting for the Time Traveller; waiting for the second,
35	perhaps still stranger story, and the specimens and photographs he
35	would bring with him. But I am beginning now to fear that I must
35	wait a lifetime. The Time Traveller vanished three years ago. And,
35	as everybody knows now, he has never returned.
35	
35	
35	
35	
35	EPILOGUE
35	
35	
35	One cannot choose but wonder. Will he ever return? It may be that he
35	swept back into the past, and fell among the blood-drinking, hairy
35	savages of the Age of Unpolished Stone; into the abysses of the
35	Cretaceous Sea; or among the grotesque saurians, the huge reptilian
35	brutes of the Jurassic times. He may even now--if I may use the
35	phrase--be wandering on some plesiosaurus-haunted Oolitic coral
35	reef, or beside the lonely saline lakes of the Triassic Age. Or did
35	he go forward, into one of the nearer ages, in which men are still
35	men, but with the riddles of our own time answered and its wearisome
35	problems solved? Into the manhood of the race: for I, for my own
35	part, cannot think that these latter days of weak experiment,
35	fragmentary theory, and mutual discord are indeed man's culminating
35	time! I say, for my own part. He, I know--for the question had been
35	discussed among us long before the Time Machine was made--thought
35	but cheerlessly of the Advancement of Mankind, and saw in the
35	growing pile of civilization only a foolish heaping that must
35	inevitably fall back upon and destroy its makers in the end. If that
35	is so, it remains for us to live as though it were not so. But to me
35	the future is still black and blank--is a vast ignorance, lit at a
35	few casual places by the memory of his story. And I have by me, for
35	my comfort, two strange white flowers--shrivelled now, and brown and
35	flat and brittle--to witness that even when mind and strength had
35	gone, gratitude and a mutual tenderness still lived on in the heart
35	of man.
36	The War of the Worlds
36	
36	by H. G. Wells [1898]
36	
36	
36	     But who shall dwell in these worlds if they be
36	     inhabited? .  .  .  Are we or they Lords of the
36	     World? .  .  .  And how are all things made for man?--
36	          KEPLER (quoted in The Anatomy of Melancholy)
36	
36	
36	
36	BOOK ONE
36	
36	THE COMING OF THE MARTIANS
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER ONE
36	
36	THE EVE OF THE WAR
36	
36	
36	No one would have believed in the last years of the nineteenth
36	century that this world was being watched keenly and closely by
36	intelligences greater than man's and yet as mortal as his own; that as
36	men busied themselves about their various concerns they were
36	scrutinised and studied, perhaps almost as narrowly as a man with a
36	microscope might scrutinise the transient creatures that swarm and
36	multiply in a drop of water.  With infinite complacency men went to
36	and fro over this globe about their little affairs, serene in their
36	assurance of their empire over matter.  It is possible that the
36	infusoria under the microscope do the same.  No one gave a thought to
36	the older worlds of space as sources of human danger, or thought of
36	them only to dismiss the idea of life upon them as impossible or
36	improbable.  It is curious to recall some of the mental habits of
36	those departed days.  At most terrestrial men fancied there might be
36	other men upon Mars, perhaps inferior to themselves and ready to
36	welcome a missionary enterprise.  Yet across the gulf of space, minds
36	that are to our minds as ours are to those of the beasts that perish,
36	intellects vast and cool and unsympathetic, regarded this earth with
36	envious eyes, and slowly and surely drew their plans against us.  And
36	early in the twentieth century came the great disillusionment.
36	
36	The planet Mars, I scarcely need remind the reader, revolves about the
36	sun at a mean distance of 140,000,000 miles, and the light and heat it
36	receives from the sun is barely half of that received by this world.
36	It must be, if the nebular hypothesis has any truth, older than our
36	world; and long before this earth ceased to be molten, life upon its
36	surface must have begun its course.  The fact that it is scarcely one
36	seventh of the volume of the earth must have accelerated its cooling
36	to the temperature at which life could begin.  It has air and water
36	and all that is necessary for the support of animated existence.
36	
36	Yet so vain is man, and so blinded by his vanity, that no writer,
36	up to the very end of the nineteenth century, expressed any idea that
36	intelligent life might have developed there far, or indeed at all,
36	beyond its earthly level.  Nor was it generally understood that since
36	Mars is older than our earth, with scarcely a quarter of the
36	superficial area and remoter from the sun, it necessarily follows that
36	it is not only more distant from time's beginning but nearer its end.
36	
36	The secular cooling that must someday overtake our planet has
36	already gone far indeed with our neighbour.  Its physical condition is
36	still largely a mystery, but we know now that even in its equatorial
36	region the midday temperature barely approaches that of our coldest
36	winter.  Its air is much more attenuated than ours, its oceans have
36	shrunk until they cover but a third of its surface, and as its slow
36	seasons change huge snowcaps gather and melt about either pole and
36	periodically inundate its temperate zones.  That last stage of
36	exhaustion, which to us is still incredibly remote, has become a
36	present-day problem for the inhabitants of Mars.  The immediate
36	pressure of necessity has brightened their intellects, enlarged their
36	powers, and hardened their hearts.  And looking across space with
36	instruments, and intelligences such as we have scarcely dreamed of,
36	they see, at its nearest distance only 35,000,000 of miles sunward of
36	them, a morning star of hope, our own warmer planet, green with
36	vegetation and grey with water, with a cloudy atmosphere eloquent of
36	fertility, with glimpses through its drifting cloud wisps of broad
36	stretches of populous country and narrow, navy-crowded seas.
36	
36	And we men, the creatures who inhabit this earth, must be to them
36	at least as alien and lowly as are the monkeys and lemurs to us.  The
36	intellectual side of man already admits that life is an incessant
36	struggle for existence, and it would seem that this too is the belief
36	of the minds upon Mars.  Their world is far gone in its cooling and
36	this world is still crowded with life, but crowded only with what they
36	regard as inferior animals.  To carry warfare sunward is, indeed,
36	their only escape from the destruction that, generation after
36	generation, creeps upon them.
36	
36	And before we judge of them too harshly we must remember what
36	ruthless and utter destruction our own species has wrought, not only
36	upon animals, such as the vanished bison and the dodo, but upon its
36	inferior races.  The Tasmanians, in spite of their human likeness,
36	were entirely swept out of existence in a war of extermination waged
36	by European immigrants, in the space of fifty years.  Are we such
36	apostles of mercy as to complain if the Martians warred in the same
36	spirit?
36	
36	The Martians seem to have calculated their descent with amazing
36	subtlety--their mathematical learning is evidently far in excess of
36	ours--and to have carried out their preparations with a well-nigh
36	perfect unanimity.  Had our instruments permitted it, we might have
36	seen the gathering trouble far back in the nineteenth century.  Men
36	like Schiaparelli watched the red planet--it is odd, by-the-bye, that
36	for countless centuries Mars has been the star of war--but failed to
36	interpret the fluctuating appearances of the markings they mapped so
36	well.  All that time the Martians must have been getting ready.
36	
36	During the opposition of 1894 a great light was seen on the
36	illuminated part of the disk, first at the Lick Observatory, then by
36	Perrotin of Nice, and then by other observers.  English readers heard
36	of it first in the issue of _Nature_ dated August 2.  I am inclined to
36	think that this blaze may have been the casting of the huge gun, in
36	the vast pit sunk into their planet, from which their shots were fired
36	at us.  Peculiar markings, as yet unexplained, were seen near the site
36	of that outbreak during the next two oppositions.
36	
36	The storm burst upon us six years ago now.  As Mars approached
36	opposition, Lavelle of Java set the wires of the astronomical exchange
36	palpitating with the amazing intelligence of a huge outbreak of
36	incandescent gas upon the planet.  It had occurred towards midnight of
36	the twelfth; and the spectroscope, to which he had at once resorted,
36	indicated a mass of flaming gas, chiefly hydrogen, moving with an
36	enormous velocity towards this earth.  This jet of fire had become
36	invisible about a quarter past twelve.  He compared it to a colossal
36	puff of flame suddenly and violently squirted out of the planet, ""as
36	flaming gases rushed out of a gun.""
36	
36	A singularly appropriate phrase it proved.  Yet the next day there
36	was nothing of this in the papers except a little note in the _Daily
36	Telegraph_, and the world went in ignorance of one of the gravest
36	dangers that ever threatened the human race. I might not have heard of
36	the eruption at all had I not met Ogilvy, the well-known astronomer,
36	at Ottershaw.  He was immensely excited at the news, and in the excess
36	of his feelings invited me up to take a turn with him that night in a
36	scrutiny of the red planet.
36	
36	In spite of all that has happened since, I still remember that
36	vigil very distinctly: the black and silent observatory, the shadowed
36	lantern throwing a feeble glow upon the floor in the corner, the
36	steady ticking of the clockwork of the telescope, the little slit in
36	the roof--an oblong profundity with the stardust streaked across it.
36	Ogilvy moved about, invisible but audible.  Looking through the
36	telescope, one saw a circle of deep blue and the little round planet
36	swimming in the field.  It seemed such a little thing, so bright and
36	small and still, faintly marked with transverse stripes, and slightly
36	flattened from the perfect round.  But so little it was, so silvery
36	warm--a pin's-head of light! It was as if it quivered, but really this
36	was the telescope vibrating with the activity of the clockwork that
36	kept the planet in view.
36	
36	As I watched, the planet seemed to grow larger and smaller and to
36	advance and recede, but that was simply that my eye was tired.  Forty
36	millions of miles it was from us--more than forty millions of miles of
36	void.  Few people realise the immensity of vacancy in which the dust
36	of the material universe swims.
36	
36	Near it in the field, I remember, were three faint points of light,
36	three telescopic stars infinitely remote, and all around it was the
36	unfathomable darkness of empty space.  You know how that blackness
36	looks on a frosty starlight night.  In a telescope it seems far
36	profounder.  And invisible to me because it was so remote and small,
36	flying swiftly and steadily towards me across that incredible
36	distance, drawing nearer every minute by so many thousands of miles,
36	came the Thing they were sending us, the Thing that was to bring so
36	much struggle and calamity and death to the earth.  I never dreamed of
36	it then as I watched; no one on earth dreamed of that unerring
36	missile.
36	
36	That night, too, there was another jetting out of gas from the
36	distant planet.  I saw it.  A reddish flash at the edge, the slightest
36	projection of the outline just as the chronometer struck midnight; and
36	at that I told Ogilvy and he took my place.  The night was warm and I
36	was thirsty, and I went stretching my legs clumsily and feeling my way
36	in the darkness, to the little table where the siphon stood, while
36	Ogilvy exclaimed at the streamer of gas that came out towards us.
36	
36	That night another invisible missile started on its way to the
36	earth from Mars, just a second or so under twenty-four hours after the
36	first one.  I remember how I sat on the table there in the blackness,
36	with patches of green and crimson swimming before my eyes.  I wished I
36	had a light to smoke by, little suspecting the meaning of the minute
36	gleam I had seen and all that it would presently bring me.  Ogilvy
36	watched till one, and then gave it up; and we lit the lantern and
36	walked over to his house.  Down below in the darkness were Ottershaw
36	and Chertsey and all their hundreds of people, sleeping in peace.
36	
36	He was full of speculation that night about the condition of Mars,
36	and scoffed at the vulgar idea of its having inhabitants who were
36	signalling us.  His idea was that meteorites might be falling in a
36	heavy shower upon the planet, or that a huge volcanic explosion was in
36	progress.  He pointed out to me how unlikely it was that organic
36	evolution had taken the same direction in the two adjacent planets.
36	
36	""The chances against anything manlike on Mars are a million to
36	one,"" he said.
36	
36	Hundreds of observers saw the flame that night and the night after
36	about midnight, and again the night after; and so for ten nights, a
36	flame each night.  Why the shots ceased after the tenth no one on
36	earth has attempted to explain.  It may be the gases of the firing
36	caused the Martians inconvenience.  Dense clouds of smoke or dust,
36	visible through a powerful telescope on earth as little grey,
36	fluctuating patches, spread through the clearness of the planet's
36	atmosphere and obscured its more familiar features.
36	
36	Even the daily papers woke up to the disturbances at last, and
36	popular notes appeared here, there, and everywhere concerning the
36	volcanoes upon Mars.  The seriocomic periodical _Punch_, I remember,
36	made a happy use of it in the political cartoon.  And, all
36	unsuspected, those missiles the Martians had fired at us drew
36	earthward, rushing now at a pace of many miles a second through the
36	empty gulf of space, hour by hour and day by day, nearer and nearer.
36	It seems to me now almost incredibly wonderful that, with that swift
36	fate hanging over us, men could go about their petty concerns as they
36	did.  I remember how jubilant Markham was at securing a new photograph
36	of the planet for the illustrated paper he edited in those days.
36	People in these latter times scarcely realise the abundance and
36	enterprise of our nineteenth-century papers.  For my own part, I was
36	much occupied in learning to ride the bicycle, and busy upon a series
36	of papers discussing the probable developments of moral ideas as
36	civilisation progressed.
36	
36	One night (the first missile then could scarcely have been
36	10,000,000 miles away) I went for a walk with my wife.  It was
36	starlight and I explained the Signs of the Zodiac to her, and pointed
36	out Mars, a bright dot of light creeping zenithward, towards which so
36	many telescopes were pointed.  It was a warm night.  Coming home, a
36	party of excursionists from Chertsey or Isleworth passed us singing
36	and playing music.  There were lights in the upper windows of the
36	houses as the people went to bed.  From the railway station in the
36	distance came the sound of shunting trains, ringing and rumbling,
36	softened almost into melody by the distance.  My wife pointed out to
36	me the brightness of the red, green, and yellow signal lights hanging
36	in a framework against the sky.  It seemed so safe and tranquil.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER TWO
36	
36	THE FALLING STAR
36	
36	
36	Then came the night of the first falling star.  It was seen early
36	in the morning, rushing over Winchester eastward, a line of flame high
36	in the atmosphere.  Hundreds must have seen it, and taken it for an
36	ordinary falling star.  Albin described it as leaving a greenish
36	streak behind it that glowed for some seconds.  Denning, our greatest
36	authority on meteorites, stated that the height of its first
36	appearance was about ninety or one hundred miles.  It seemed to him
36	that it fell to earth about one hundred miles east of him.
36	
36	I was at home at that hour and writing in my study; and although my
36	French windows face towards Ottershaw and the blind was up (for I
36	loved in those days to look up at the night sky), I saw nothing of it.
36	Yet this strangest of all things that ever came to earth from outer
36	space must have fallen while I was sitting there, visible to me had I
36	only looked up as it passed.  Some of those who saw its flight say it
36	travelled with a hissing sound.  I myself heard nothing of that.  Many
36	people in Berkshire, Surrey, and Middlesex must have seen the fall of
36	it, and, at most, have thought that another meteorite had descended.
36	No one seems to have troubled to look for the fallen mass that night.
36	
36	But very early in the morning poor Ogilvy, who had seen the
36	shooting star and who was persuaded that a meteorite lay somewhere on
36	the common between Horsell, Ottershaw, and Woking, rose early with the
36	idea of finding it.  Find it he did, soon after dawn, and not far from
36	the sand pits.  An enormous hole had been made by the impact of the
36	projectile, and the sand and gravel had been flung violently in every
36	direction over the heath, forming heaps visible a mile and a half
36	away.  The heather was on fire eastward, and a thin blue smoke rose
36	against the dawn.
36	
36	The Thing itself lay almost entirely buried in sand, amidst the
36	scattered splinters of a fir tree it had shivered to fragments in its
36	descent.  The uncovered part had the appearance of a huge cylinder,
36	caked over and its outline softened by a thick scaly dun-coloured
36	incrustation.  It had a diameter of about thirty yards.  He approached
36	the mass, surprised at the size and more so at the shape, since most
36	meteorites are rounded more or less completely.  It was, however,
36	still so hot from its flight through the air as to forbid his near
36	approach.  A stirring noise within its cylinder he ascribed to the
36	unequal cooling of its surface; for at that time it had not occurred
36	to him that it might be hollow.
36	
36	He remained standing at the edge of the pit that the Thing had made
36	for itself, staring at its strange appearance, astonished chiefly at
36	its unusual shape and colour, and dimly perceiving even then some
36	evidence of design in its arrival.  The early morning was wonderfully
36	still, and the sun, just clearing the pine trees towards Weybridge,
36	was already warm.  He did not remember hearing any birds that morning,
36	there was certainly no breeze stirring, and the only sounds were the
36	faint movements from within the cindery cylinder.  He was all alone on
36	the common.
36	
36	Then suddenly he noticed with a start that some of the grey
36	clinker, the ashy incrustation that covered the meteorite, was falling
36	off the circular edge of the end.  It was dropping off in flakes and
36	raining down upon the sand.  A large piece suddenly came off and fell
36	with a sharp noise that brought his heart into his mouth.
36	
36	For a minute he scarcely realised what this meant, and, although
36	the heat was excessive, he clambered down into the pit close to the
36	bulk to see the Thing more clearly.  He fancied even then that the
36	cooling of the body might account for this, but what disturbed that
36	idea was the fact that the ash was falling only from the end of the
36	cylinder.
36	
36	And then he perceived that, very slowly, the circular top of the
36	cylinder was rotating on its body.  It was such a gradual movement
36	that he discovered it only through noticing that a black mark that had
36	been near him five minutes ago was now at the other side of the
36	circumference.  Even then he scarcely understood what this indicated,
36	until he heard a muffled grating sound and saw the black mark jerk
36	forward an inch or so.  Then the thing came upon him in a flash.  The
36	cylinder was artificial--hollow--with an end that screwed out!
36	Something within the cylinder was unscrewing the top!
36	
36	""Good heavens!"" said Ogilvy.  ""There's a man in it--men in it! Half
36	roasted to death!  Trying to escape!""
36	
36	At once, with a quick mental leap, he linked the Thing with the
36	flash upon Mars.
36	
36	The thought of the confined creature was so dreadful to him that he
36	forgot the heat and went forward to the cylinder to help turn.  But
36	luckily the dull radiation arrested him before he could burn his hands
36	on the still-glowing metal.  At that he stood irresolute for a moment,
36	then turned, scrambled out of the pit, and set off running wildly into
36	Woking.  The time then must have been somewhere about six o'clock.
36	He met a waggoner and tried to make him understand, but the tale he
36	told and his appearance were so wild--his hat had fallen off in the
36	pit--that the man simply drove on.  He was equally unsuccessful with the
36	potman who was just unlocking the doors of the public-house by Horsell
36	Bridge.  The fellow thought he was a lunatic at large and made an
36	unsuccessful attempt to shut him into the taproom.  That sobered him a
36	little; and when he saw Henderson, the London journalist, in his
36	garden, he called over the palings and made himself understood.
36	
36	""Henderson,"" he called, ""you saw that shooting star last night?""
36	
36	""Well?"" said Henderson.
36	
36	""It's out on Horsell Common now.""
36	
36	""Good Lord!"" said Henderson.  ""Fallen meteorite!  That's good.""
36	
36	""But it's something more than a meteorite.  It's a cylinder--an
36	artificial cylinder, man!  And there's something inside.""
36	
36	Henderson stood up with his spade in his hand.
36	
36	""What's that?"" he said.  He was deaf in one ear.
36	
36	Ogilvy told him all that he had seen.  Henderson was a minute or so
36	taking it in.  Then he dropped his spade, snatched up his jacket, and
36	came out into the road.  The two men hurried back at once to the
36	common, and found the cylinder still lying in the same position.  But
36	now the sounds inside had ceased, and a thin circle of bright metal
36	showed between the top and the body of the cylinder.  Air was either
36	entering or escaping at the rim with a thin, sizzling sound.
36	
36	They listened, rapped on the scaly burnt metal with a stick, and,
36	meeting with no response, they both concluded the man or men inside
36	must be insensible or dead.
36	
36	Of course the two were quite unable to do anything.  They shouted
36	consolation and promises, and went off back to the town again to get
36	help.  One can imagine them, covered with sand, excited and
36	disordered, running up the little street in the bright sunlight just
36	as the shop folks were taking down their shutters and people were
36	opening their bedroom windows.  Henderson went into the railway
36	station at once, in order to telegraph the news to London.  The
36	newspaper articles had prepared men's minds for the reception of the
36	idea.
36	
36	By eight o'clock a number of boys and unemployed men had already
36	started for the common to see the ""dead men from Mars.""  That was the
36	form the story took.  I heard of it first from my newspaper boy about
36	a quarter to nine when I went out to get my _Daily Chronicle_.  I was
36	naturally startled, and lost no time in going out and across the
36	Ottershaw bridge to the sand pits.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER THREE
36	
36	ON HORSELL COMMON
36	
36	
36	I found a little crowd of perhaps twenty people surrounding the
36	huge hole in which the cylinder lay.  I have already described the
36	appearance of that colossal bulk, embedded in the ground.  The turf
36	and gravel about it seemed charred as if by a sudden explosion.  No
36	doubt its impact had caused a flash of fire.  Henderson and Ogilvy
36	were not there.  I think they perceived that nothing was to be done
36	for the present, and had gone away to breakfast at Henderson's house.
36	
36	There were four or five boys sitting on the edge of the Pit, with
36	their feet dangling, and amusing themselves--until I stopped them--by
36	throwing stones at the giant mass.  After I had spoken to them about
36	it, they began playing at ""touch"" in and out of the group of
36	bystanders.
36	
36	Among these were a couple of cyclists, a jobbing gardener I
36	employed sometimes, a girl carrying a baby, Gregg the butcher and his
36	little boy, and two or three loafers and golf caddies who were
36	accustomed to hang about the railway station.  There was very little
36	talking.  Few of the common people in England had anything but the
36	vaguest astronomical ideas in those days.  Most of them were staring
36	quietly at the big table like end of the cylinder, which was still as
36	Ogilvy and Henderson had left it.  I fancy the popular expectation of
36	a heap of charred corpses was disappointed at this inanimate bulk.
36	Some went away while I was there, and other people came.  I clambered
36	into the pit and fancied I heard a faint movement under my feet.  The
36	top had certainly ceased to rotate.
36	
36	It was only when I got thus close to it that the strangeness of
36	this object was at all evident to me.  At the first glance it was
36	really no more exciting than an overturned carriage or a tree blown
36	across the road.  Not so much so, indeed.  It looked like a rusty gas
36	float.  It required a certain amount of scientific education to
36	perceive that the grey scale of the Thing was no common oxide, that
36	the yellowish-white metal that gleamed in the crack between the lid
36	and the cylinder had an unfamiliar hue.  ""Extra-terrestrial"" had no
36	meaning for most of the onlookers.
36	
36	At that time it was quite clear in my own mind that the Thing had
36	come from the planet Mars, but I judged it improbable that it
36	contained any living creature.  I thought the unscrewing might be
36	automatic.  In spite of Ogilvy, I still believed that there were men
36	in Mars.  My mind ran fancifully on the possibilities of its
36	containing manuscript, on the difficulties in translation that might
36	arise, whether we should find coins and models in it, and so forth.
36	Yet it was a little too large for assurance on this idea.  I felt an
36	impatience to see it opened.  About eleven, as nothing seemed
36	happening, I walked back, full of such thought, to my home in Maybury.
36	But I found it difficult to get to work upon my abstract
36	investigations.
36	
36	In the afternoon the appearance of the common had altered very
36	much.  The early editions of the evening papers had startled London
36	with enormous headlines:
36	
36	  ""A MESSAGE RECEIVED FROM MARS.""
36	
36	  ""REMARKABLE STORY FROM WOKING,""
36	
36	and so forth.  In addition, Ogilvy's wire to the Astronomical Exchange
36	had roused every observatory in the three kingdoms.
36	
36	There were half a dozen flies or more from the Woking station
36	standing in the road by the sand pits, a basket-chaise from Chobham,
36	and a rather lordly carriage.  Besides that, there was quite a heap of
36	bicycles.  In addition, a large number of people must have walked, in
36	spite of the heat of the day, from Woking and Chertsey, so that there
36	was altogether quite a considerable crowd--one or two gaily dressed
36	ladies among the others.
36	
36	It was glaringly hot, not a cloud in the sky nor a breath of wind,
36	and the only shadow was that of the few scattered pine trees.  The
36	burning heather had been extinguished, but the level ground towards
36	Ottershaw was blackened as far as one could see, and still giving off
36	vertical streamers of smoke.  An enterprising sweet-stuff dealer in
36	the Chobham Road had sent up his son with a barrow-load of green
36	apples and ginger beer.
36	
36	Going to the edge of the pit, I found it occupied by a group of
36	about half a dozen men--Henderson, Ogilvy, and a tall, fair-haired man
36	that I afterwards learned was Stent, the Astronomer Royal, with
36	several workmen wielding spades and pickaxes.  Stent was giving
36	directions in a clear, high-pitched voice.  He was standing on the
36	cylinder, which was now evidently much cooler; his face was crimson
36	and streaming with perspiration, and something seemed to have
36	irritated him.
36	
36	A large portion of the cylinder had been uncovered, though its
36	lower end was still embedded.  As soon as Ogilvy saw me among the
36	staring crowd on the edge of the pit he called to me to come down, and
36	asked me if I would mind going over to see Lord Hilton, the lord of
36	the manor.
36	
36	The growing crowd, he said, was becoming a serious impediment to
36	their excavations, especially the boys.  They wanted a light railing
36	put up, and help to keep the people back.  He told me that a faint
36	stirring was occasionally still audible within the case, but that the
36	workmen had failed to unscrew the top, as it afforded no grip to them.
36	The case appeared to be enormously thick, and it was possible that the
36	faint sounds we heard represented a noisy tumult in the interior.
36	
36	I was very glad to do as he asked, and so become one of the
36	privileged spectators within the contemplated enclosure.  I failed to
36	find Lord Hilton at his house, but I was told he was expected from
36	London by the six o'clock train from Waterloo; and as it was then
36	about a quarter past five, I went home, had some tea, and walked up to
36	the station to waylay him.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER FOUR
36	
36	THE CYLINDER OPENS
36	
36	
36	When I returned to the common the sun was setting.  Scattered groups
36	were hurrying from the direction of Woking, and one or two persons
36	were returning.  The crowd about the pit had increased, and stood out
36	black against the lemon yellow of the sky--a couple of hundred people,
36	perhaps.  There were raised voices, and some sort of struggle appeared
36	to be going on about the pit.  Strange imaginings passed through my
36	mind.  As I drew nearer I heard Stent's voice:
36	
36	""Keep back!  Keep back!""
36	
36	A boy came running towards me.
36	
36	""It's a-movin',"" he said to me as he passed; ""a-screwin' and
36	a-screwin' out.  I don't like it.  I'm a-goin' 'ome, I am.""
36	
36	I went on to the crowd.  There were really, I should think, two or
36	three hundred people elbowing and jostling one another, the one or two
36	ladies there being by no means the least active.
36	
36	""He's fallen in the pit!"" cried some one.
36	
36	""Keep back!"" said several.
36	
36	The crowd swayed a little, and I elbowed my way through.  Every one
36	seemed greatly excited.  I heard a peculiar humming sound from the
36	pit.
36	
36	""I say!"" said Ogilvy; ""help keep these idiots back.  We don't know
36	what's in the confounded thing, you know!""
36	
36	I saw a young man, a shop assistant in Woking I believe he was,
36	standing on the cylinder and trying to scramble out of the hole again.
36	The crowd had pushed him in.
36	
36	The end of the cylinder was being screwed out from within.  Nearly
36	two feet of shining screw projected.  Somebody blundered against me,
36	and I narrowly missed being pitched onto the top of the screw.  I
36	turned, and as I did so the screw must have come out, for the lid of
36	the cylinder fell upon the gravel with a ringing concussion.  I stuck
36	my elbow into the person behind me, and turned my head towards the
36	Thing again.  For a moment that circular cavity seemed perfectly black.
36	I had the sunset in my eyes.
36	
36	I think everyone expected to see a man emerge--possibly something a
36	little unlike us terrestrial men, but in all essentials a man.  I know
36	I did.  But, looking, I presently saw something stirring within the
36	shadow: greyish billowy movements, one above another, and then two
36	luminous disks--like eyes.  Then something resembling a little grey
36	snake, about the thickness of a walking stick, coiled up out of the
36	writhing middle, and wriggled in the air towards me--and then another.
36	
36	A sudden chill came over me.  There was a loud shriek from a woman
36	behind.  I half turned, keeping my eyes fixed upon the cylinder still,
36	from which other tentacles were now projecting, and began pushing my
36	way back from the edge of the pit.  I saw astonishment giving place to
36	horror on the faces of the people about me.  I heard inarticulate
36	exclamations on all sides.  There was a general movement backwards.
36	I saw the shopman struggling still on the edge of the pit.  I found
36	myself alone, and saw the people on the other side of the pit running
36	off, Stent among them.  I looked again at the cylinder, and
36	ungovernable terror gripped me.  I stood petrified and staring.
36	
36	A big greyish rounded bulk, the size, perhaps, of a bear, was
36	rising slowly and painfully out of the cylinder.  As it bulged up and
36	caught the light, it glistened like wet leather.
36	
36	Two large dark-coloured eyes were regarding me steadfastly.  The
36	mass that framed them, the head of the thing, was rounded, and had,
36	one might say, a face.  There was a mouth under the eyes, the lipless
36	brim of which quivered and panted, and dropped saliva.  The whole
36	creature heaved and pulsated convulsively.  A lank tentacular
36	appendage gripped the edge of the cylinder, another swayed in the air.
36	
36	Those who have never seen a living Martian can scarcely imagine the
36	strange horror of its appearance.  The peculiar V-shaped mouth with
36	its pointed upper lip, the absence of brow ridges, the absence of a
36	chin beneath the wedgelike lower lip, the incessant quivering of this
36	mouth, the Gorgon groups of tentacles, the tumultuous breathing of the
36	lungs in a strange atmosphere, the evident heaviness and painfulness
36	of movement due to the greater gravitational energy of the earth--above
36	all, the extraordinary intensity of the immense eyes--were at
36	once vital, intense, inhuman, crippled and monstrous.  There was
36	something fungoid in the oily brown skin, something in the clumsy
36	deliberation of the tedious movements unspeakably nasty.  Even at this
36	first encounter, this first glimpse, I was overcome with disgust and
36	dread.
36	
36	Suddenly the monster vanished.  It had toppled over the brim of the
36	cylinder and fallen into the pit, with a thud like the fall of a great
36	mass of leather.  I heard it give a peculiar thick cry, and forthwith
36	another of these creatures appeared darkly in the deep shadow of the
36	aperture.
36	
36	I turned and, running madly, made for the first group of trees,
36	perhaps a hundred yards away; but I ran slantingly and stumbling, for
36	I could not avert my face from these things.
36	
36	There, among some young pine trees and furze bushes, I stopped,
36	panting, and waited further developments.  The common round the sand
36	pits was dotted with people, standing like myself in a half-fascinated
36	terror, staring at these creatures, or rather at the heaped gravel at
36	the edge of the pit in which they lay.  And then, with a renewed
36	horror, I saw a round, black object bobbing up and down on the edge of
36	the pit.  It was the head of the shopman who had fallen in, but
36	showing as a little black object against the hot western sun.  Now he
36	got his shoulder and knee up, and again he seemed to slip back until
36	only his head was visible.  Suddenly he vanished, and I could have
36	fancied a faint shriek had reached me.  I had a momentary impulse to
36	go back and help him that my fears overruled.
36	
36	Everything was then quite invisible, hidden by the deep pit and the
36	heap of sand that the fall of the cylinder had made.  Anyone coming
36	along the road from Chobham or Woking would have been amazed at the
36	sight--a dwindling multitude of perhaps a hundred people or more
36	standing in a great irregular circle, in ditches, behind bushes,
36	behind gates and hedges, saying little to one another and that in
36	short, excited shouts, and staring, staring hard at a few heaps of
36	sand.  The barrow of ginger beer stood, a queer derelict, black
36	against the burning sky, and in the sand pits was a row of deserted
36	vehicles with their horses feeding out of nosebags or pawing the
36	ground.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER FIVE
36	
36	THE HEAT-RAY
36	
36	
36	After the glimpse I had had of the Martians emerging from the
36	cylinder in which they had come to the earth from their planet, a kind
36	of fascination paralysed my actions.  I remained standing knee-deep in
36	the heather, staring at the mound that hid them.  I was a battleground
36	of fear and curiosity.
36	
36	I did not dare to go back towards the pit, but I felt a passionate
36	longing to peer into it.  I began walking, therefore, in a big curve,
36	seeking some point of vantage and continually looking at the sand
36	heaps that hid these new-comers to our earth.  Once a leash of thin
36	black whips, like the arms of an octopus, flashed across the sunset
36	and was immediately withdrawn, and afterwards a thin rod rose up,
36	joint by joint, bearing at its apex a circular disk that spun with a
36	wobbling motion.  What could be going on there?
36	
36	Most of the spectators had gathered in one or two groups--one a
36	little crowd towards Woking, the other a knot of people in the
36	direction of Chobham.  Evidently they shared my mental conflict.
36	There were few near me.  One man I approached--he was, I perceived,
36	a neighbour of mine, though I did not know his name--and accosted.
36	But it was scarcely a time for articulate conversation.
36	
36	""What ugly _brutes_!"" he said.  ""Good God!  What ugly brutes!""  He
36	repeated this over and over again.
36	
36	""Did you see a man in the pit?"" I said; but he made no answer to
36	that.  We became silent, and stood watching for a time side by side,
36	deriving, I fancy, a certain comfort in one another's company.  Then I
36	shifted my position to a little knoll that gave me the advantage of a
36	yard or more of elevation and when I looked for him presently he was
36	walking towards Woking.
36	
36	The sunset faded to twilight before anything further happened.  The
36	crowd far away on the left, towards Woking, seemed to grow, and I
36	heard now a faint murmur from it.  The little knot of people towards
36	Chobham dispersed.  There was scarcely an intimation of movement from
36	the pit.
36	
36	It was this, as much as anything, that gave people courage, and I
36	suppose the new arrivals from Woking also helped to restore
36	confidence.  At any rate, as the dusk came on a slow, intermittent
36	movement upon the sand pits began, a movement that seemed to gather
36	force as the stillness of the evening about the cylinder remained
36	unbroken.  Vertical black figures in twos and threes would advance,
36	stop, watch, and advance again, spreading out as they did so in a thin
36	irregular crescent that promised to enclose the pit in its attenuated
36	horns.  I, too, on my side began to move towards the pit.
36	
36	Then I saw some cabmen and others had walked boldly into the sand
36	pits, and heard the clatter of hoofs and the gride of wheels.  I saw a
36	lad trundling off the barrow of apples.  And then, within thirty yards
36	of the pit, advancing from the direction of Horsell, I noted a little
36	black knot of men, the foremost of whom was waving a white flag.
36	
36	This was the Deputation.  There had been a hasty consultation, and
36	since the Martians were evidently, in spite of their repulsive forms,
36	intelligent creatures, it had been resolved to show them, by
36	approaching them with signals, that we too were intelligent.
36	
36	Flutter, flutter, went the flag, first to the right, then to the
36	left.  It was too far for me to recognise anyone there, but afterwards
36	I learned that Ogilvy, Stent, and Henderson were with others in this
36	attempt at communication.  This little group had in its advance
36	dragged inward, so to speak, the circumference of the now almost
36	complete circle of people, and a number of dim black figures followed
36	it at discreet distances.
36	
36	Suddenly there was a flash of light, and a quantity of luminous
36	greenish smoke came out of the pit in three distinct puffs, which
36	drove up, one after the other, straight into the still air.
36	
36	This smoke (or flame, perhaps, would be the better word for it) was
36	so bright that the deep blue sky overhead and the hazy stretches of
36	brown common towards Chertsey, set with black pine trees, seemed to
36	darken abruptly as these puffs arose, and to remain the darker after
36	their dispersal.  At the same time a faint hissing sound became
36	audible.
36	
36	Beyond the pit stood the little wedge of people with the white flag
36	at its apex, arrested by these phenomena, a little knot of small
36	vertical black shapes upon the black ground.  As the green smoke arose,
36	their faces flashed out pallid green, and faded again as it vanished.
36	Then slowly the hissing passed into a humming, into a long, loud,
36	droning noise.  Slowly a humped shape rose out of the pit, and the
36	ghost of a beam of light seemed to flicker out from it.
36	
36	Forthwith flashes of actual flame, a bright glare leaping from one
36	to another, sprang from the scattered group of men.  It was as if some
36	invisible jet impinged upon them and flashed into white flame.  It was
36	as if each man were suddenly and momentarily turned to fire.
36	
36	Then, by the light of their own destruction, I saw them staggering
36	and falling, and their supporters turning to run.
36	
36	I stood staring, not as yet realising that this was death leaping
36	from man to man in that little distant crowd.  All I felt was that it
36	was something very strange.  An almost noiseless and blinding flash of
36	light, and a man fell headlong and lay still; and as the unseen shaft
36	of heat passed over them, pine trees burst into fire, and every dry
36	furze bush became with one dull thud a mass of flames.  And far away
36	towards Knaphill I saw the flashes of trees and hedges and wooden
36	buildings suddenly set alight.
36	
36	It was sweeping round swiftly and steadily, this flaming death,
36	this invisible, inevitable sword of heat.  I perceived it coming
36	towards me by the flashing bushes it touched, and was too astounded
36	and stupefied to stir.  I heard the crackle of fire in the sand pits
36	and the sudden squeal of a horse that was as suddenly stilled.  Then
36	it was as if an invisible yet intensely heated finger were drawn
36	through the heather between me and the Martians, and all along a
36	curving line beyond the sand pits the dark ground smoked and crackled.
36	Something fell with a crash far away to the left where the road from
36	Woking station opens out on the common.  Forth-with the hissing and
36	humming ceased, and the black, dome-like object sank slowly out of
36	sight into the pit.
36	
36	All this had happened with such swiftness that I had stood
36	motionless, dumbfounded and dazzled by the flashes of light.  Had that
36	death swept through a full circle, it must inevitably have slain me in
36	my surprise.  But it passed and spared me, and left the night about me
36	suddenly dark and unfamiliar.
36	
36	The undulating common seemed now dark almost to blackness, except
36	where its roadways lay grey and pale under the deep blue sky of the
36	early night.  It was dark, and suddenly void of men.  Overhead the
36	stars were mustering, and in the west the sky was still a pale,
36	bright, almost greenish blue.  The tops of the pine trees and the
36	roofs of Horsell came out sharp and black against the western
36	afterglow.  The Martians and their appliances were altogether
36	invisible, save for that thin mast upon which their restless mirror
36	wobbled.  Patches of bush and isolated trees here and there smoked and
36	glowed still, and the houses towards Woking station were sending up
36	spires of flame into the stillness of the evening air.
36	
36	Nothing was changed save for that and a terrible astonishment.  The
36	little group of black specks with the flag of white had been swept out
36	of existence, and the stillness of the evening, so it seemed to me,
36	had scarcely been broken.
36	
36	It came to me that I was upon this dark common, helpless,
36	unprotected, and alone.  Suddenly, like a thing falling upon me from
36	without, came--fear.
36	
36	With an effort I turned and began a stumbling run through the
36	heather.
36	
36	The fear I felt was no rational fear, but a panic terror not only
36	of the Martians, but of the dusk and stillness all about me.  Such an
36	extraordinary effect in unmanning me it had that I ran weeping
36	silently as a child might do.  Once I had turned, I did not dare to
36	look back.
36	
36	I remember I felt an extraordinary persuasion that I was being
36	played with, that presently, when I was upon the very verge of safety,
36	this mysterious death--as swift as the passage of light--would leap
36	after me from the pit about the cylinder and strike me down.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER SIX
36	
36	THE HEAT-RAY IN THE CHOBHAM ROAD
36	
36	
36	It is still a matter of wonder how the Martians are able to slay
36	men so swiftly and so silently.  Many think that in some way they are
36	able to generate an intense heat in a chamber of practically absolute
36	non-conductivity.  This intense heat they project in a parallel beam
36	against any object they choose, by means of a polished parabolic
36	mirror of unknown composition, much as the parabolic mirror of a
36	lighthouse projects a beam of light.  But no one has absolutely proved
36	these details.  However it is done, it is certain that a beam of heat
36	is the essence of the matter.  Heat, and invisible, instead of
36	visible, light.  Whatever is combustible flashes into flame at its
36	touch, lead runs like water, it softens iron, cracks and melts glass,
36	and when it falls upon water, incontinently that explodes into steam.
36	
36	That night nearly forty people lay under the starlight about the
36	pit, charred and distorted beyond recognition, and all night long the
36	common from Horsell to Maybury was deserted and brightly ablaze.
36	
36	The news of the massacre probably reached Chobham, Woking, and
36	Ottershaw about the same time.  In Woking the shops had closed when
36	the tragedy happened, and a number of people, shop people and so
36	forth, attracted by the stories they had heard, were walking over the
36	Horsell Bridge and along the road between the hedges that runs out at
36	last upon the common.  You may imagine the young people brushed up
36	after the labours of the day, and making this novelty, as they would
36	make any novelty, the excuse for walking together and enjoying a
36	trivial flirtation.  You may figure to yourself the hum of voices
36	along the road in the gloaming. . . .
36	
36	As yet, of course, few people in Woking even knew that the cylinder
36	had opened, though poor Henderson had sent a messenger on a bicycle to
36	the post office with a special wire to an evening paper.
36	
36	As these folks came out by twos and threes upon the open, they
36	found little knots of people talking excitedly and peering at the
36	spinning mirror over the sand pits, and the newcomers were, no doubt,
36	soon infected by the excitement of the occasion.
36	
36	By half past eight, when the Deputation was destroyed, there may
36	have been a crowd of three hundred people or more at this place,
36	besides those who had left the road to approach the Martians nearer.
36	There were three policemen too, one of whom was mounted, doing their
36	best, under instructions from Stent, to keep the people back and deter
36	them from approaching the cylinder.  There was some booing from those
36	more thoughtless and excitable souls to whom a crowd is always an
36	occasion for noise and horse-play.
36	
36	Stent and Ogilvy, anticipating some possibilities of a collision,
36	had telegraphed from Horsell to the barracks as soon as the Martians
36	emerged, for the help of a company of soldiers to protect these
36	strange creatures from violence.  After that they returned to lead that
36	ill-fated advance.  The description of their death, as it was seen by
36	the crowd, tallies very closely with my own impressions: the three
36	puffs of green smoke, the deep humming note, and the flashes of flame.
36	
36	But that crowd of people had a far narrower escape than mine.  Only
36	the fact that a hummock of heathery sand intercepted the lower part of
36	the Heat-Ray saved them.  Had the elevation of the parabolic mirror
36	been a few yards higher, none could have lived to tell the tale.  They
36	saw the flashes and the men falling and an invisible hand, as it were,
36	lit the bushes as it hurried towards them through the twilight.  Then,
36	with a whistling note that rose above the droning of the pit, the beam
36	swung close over their heads, lighting the tops of the beech trees
36	that line the road, and splitting the bricks, smashing the windows,
36	firing the window frames, and bringing down in crumbling ruin a
36	portion of the gable of the house nearest the corner.
36	
36	In the sudden thud, hiss, and glare of the igniting trees, the
36	panic-stricken crowd seems to have swayed hesitatingly for some
36	moments.  Sparks and burning twigs began to fall into the road, and
36	single leaves like puffs of flame.  Hats and dresses caught fire.  Then
36	came a crying from the common.  There were shrieks and shouts, and
36	suddenly a mounted policeman came galloping through the confusion with
36	his hands clasped over his head, screaming.
36	
36	""They're coming!"" a woman shrieked, and incontinently everyone was
36	turning and pushing at those behind, in order to clear their way to
36	Woking again.  They must have bolted as blindly as a flock of sheep.
36	Where the road grows narrow and black between the high banks the crowd
36	jammed, and a desperate struggle occurred.  All that crowd did not
36	escape; three persons at least, two women and a little boy, were
36	crushed and trampled there, and left to die amid the terror and the
36	darkness.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER SEVEN
36	
36	HOW I REACHED HOME
36	
36	
36	For my own part, I remember nothing of my flight except the stress
36	of blundering against trees and stumbling through the heather.  All
36	about me gathered the invisible terrors of the Martians; that pitiless
36	sword of heat seemed whirling to and fro, flourishing overhead before
36	it descended and smote me out of life.  I came into the road between
36	the crossroads and Horsell, and ran along this to the crossroads.
36	
36	At last I could go no further; I was exhausted with the violence of
36	my emotion and of my flight, and I staggered and fell by the wayside.
36	That was near the bridge that crosses the canal by the gasworks.  I
36	fell and lay still.
36	
36	I must have remained there some time.
36	
36	I sat up, strangely perplexed.  For a moment, perhaps, I could not
36	clearly understand how I came there.  My terror had fallen from me
36	like a garment.  My hat had gone, and my collar had burst away from
36	its fastener.  A few minutes before, there had only been three real
36	things before me--the immensity of the night and space and nature, my
36	own feebleness and anguish, and the near approach of death.  Now it
36	was as if something turned over, and the point of view altered
36	abruptly.  There was no sensible transition from one state of mind to
36	the other.  I was immediately the self of every day again--a decent,
36	ordinary citizen.  The silent common, the impulse of my flight, the
36	starting flames, were as if they had been in a dream.  I asked myself
36	had these latter things indeed happened?  I could not credit it.
36	
36	I rose and walked unsteadily up the steep incline of the bridge.  My
36	mind was blank wonder.  My muscles and nerves seemed drained of their
36	strength.  I dare say I staggered drunkenly.  A head rose over the
36	arch, and the figure of a workman carrying a basket appeared.  Beside
36	him ran a little boy.  He passed me, wishing me good night.  I was
36	minded to speak to him, but did not.  I answered his greeting with a
36	meaningless mumble and went on over the bridge.
36	
36	Over the Maybury arch a train, a billowing tumult of white, firelit
36	smoke, and a long caterpillar of lighted windows, went flying
36	south--clatter, clatter, clap, rap, and it had gone.  A dim group of
36	people talked in the gate of one of the houses in the pretty little
36	row of gables that was called Oriental Terrace.  It was all so real
36	and so familiar.  And that behind me!  It was frantic, fantastic!
36	Such things, I told myself, could not be.
36	
36	Perhaps I am a man of exceptional moods.  I do not know how far my
36	experience is common.  At times I suffer from the strangest sense of
36	detachment from myself and the world about me; I seem to watch it all
