36	from the outside, from somewhere inconceivably remote, out of time,
36	out of space, out of the stress and tragedy of it all.  This feeling
36	was very strong upon me that night.  Here was another side to my
36	dream.
36	
36	But the trouble was the blank incongruity of this serenity and the
36	swift death flying yonder, not two miles away.  There was a noise of
36	business from the gasworks, and the electric lamps were all alight.  I
36	stopped at the group of people.
36	
36	""What news from the common?"" said I.
36	
36	There were two men and a woman at the gate.
36	
36	""Eh?"" said one of the men, turning.
36	
36	""What news from the common?"" I said.
36	
36	""'Ain't yer just _been_ there?"" asked the men.
36	
36	""People seem fair silly about the common,"" said the woman over the
36	gate.  ""What's it all abart?""
36	
36	""Haven't you heard of the men from Mars?"" said I; ""the creatures
36	from Mars?""
36	
36	""Quite enough,"" said the woman over the gate.  ""Thenks""; and all
36	three of them laughed.
36	
36	I felt foolish and angry.  I tried and found I could not tell them
36	what I had seen.  They laughed again at my broken sentences.
36	
36	""You'll hear more yet,"" I said, and went on to my home.
36	
36	I startled my wife at the doorway, so haggard was I.  I went into
36	the dining room, sat down, drank some wine, and so soon as I could
36	collect myself sufficiently I told her the things I had seen.  The
36	dinner, which was a cold one, had already been served, and remained
36	neglected on the table while I told my story.
36	
36	""There is one thing,"" I said, to allay the fears I had aroused;
36	""they are the most sluggish things I ever saw crawl.  They may keep
36	the pit and kill people who come near them, but they cannot get out
36	of it. . . .  But the horror of them!""
36	
36	""Don't, dear!"" said my wife, knitting her brows and putting her
36	hand on mine.
36	
36	""Poor Ogilvy!"" I said.  ""To think he may be lying dead there!""
36	
36	My wife at least did not find my experience incredible.  When I saw
36	how deadly white her face was, I ceased abruptly.
36	
36	""They may come here,"" she said again and again.
36	
36	I pressed her to take wine, and tried to reassure her.
36	
36	""They can scarcely move,"" I said.
36	
36	I began to comfort her and myself by repeating all that Ogilvy had
36	told me of the impossibility of the Martians establishing themselves
36	on the earth.  In particular I laid stress on the gravitational
36	difficulty.  On the surface of the earth the force of gravity is three
36	times what it is on the surface of Mars.  A Martian, therefore, would
36	weigh three times more than on Mars, albeit his muscular strength
36	would be the same.  His own body would be a cope of lead to him.  That,
36	indeed, was the general opinion.  Both _The Times_ and the _Daily
36	Telegraph_, for instance, insisted on it the next morning, and both
36	overlooked, just as I did, two obvious modifying influences.
36	
36	The atmosphere of the earth, we now know, contains far more oxygen
36	or far less argon (whichever way one likes to put it) than does Mars.
36	The invigorating influences of this excess of oxygen upon the Martians
36	indisputably did much to counterbalance the increased weight of their
36	bodies.  And, in the second place, we all overlooked the fact that
36	such mechanical intelligence as the Martian possessed was quite able
36	to dispense with muscular exertion at a pinch.
36	
36	But I did not consider these points at the time, and so my
36	reasoning was dead against the chances of the invaders.  With wine and
36	food, the confidence of my own table, and the necessity of reassuring
36	my wife, I grew by insensible degrees courageous and secure.
36	
36	""They have done a foolish thing,"" said I, fingering my wineglass.
36	""They are dangerous because, no doubt, they are mad with terror.
36	Perhaps they expected to find no living things--certainly no
36	intelligent living things.""
36	
36	""A shell in the pit"" said I, ""if the worst comes to the worst will
36	kill them all.""
36	
36	The intense excitement of the events had no doubt left my
36	perceptive powers in a state of erethism.  I remember that dinner
36	table with extraordinary vividness even now.  My dear wife's sweet
36	anxious face peering at me from under the pink lamp shade, the white
36	cloth with its silver and glass table furniture--for in those days
36	even philosophical writers had many little luxuries--the crimson-purple
36	wine in my glass, are photographically distinct.  At the end of
36	it I sat, tempering nuts with a cigarette, regretting Ogilvy's
36	rashness, and denouncing the shortsighted timidity of the Martians.
36	
36	So some respectable dodo in the Mauritius might have lorded it in
36	his nest, and discussed the arrival of that shipful of pitiless
36	sailors in want of animal food.  ""We will peck them to death tomorrow,
36	my dear.""
36	
36	I did not know it, but that was the last civilised dinner I was to
36	eat for very many strange and terrible days.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER EIGHT
36	
36	FRIDAY NIGHT
36	
36	
36	The most extraordinary thing to my mind, of all the strange and
36	wonderful things that happened upon that Friday, was the dovetailing
36	of the commonplace habits of our social order with the first
36	beginnings of the series of events that was to topple that social
36	order headlong.  If on Friday night you had taken a pair of compasses
36	and drawn a circle with a radius of five miles round the Woking sand
36	pits, I doubt if you would have had one human being outside it, unless
36	it were some relation of Stent or of the three or four cyclists or
36	London people lying dead on the common, whose emotions or habits were
36	at all affected by the new-comers.  Many people had heard of the
36	cylinder, of course, and talked about it in their leisure, but it
36	certainly did not make the sensation that an ultimatum to Germany
36	would have done.
36	
36	In London that night poor Henderson's telegram describing the
36	gradual unscrewing of the shot was judged to be a canard, and his
36	evening paper, after wiring for authentication from him and receiving
36	no reply--the man was killed--decided not to print a special edition.
36	
36	Even within the five-mile circle the great majority of people were
36	inert.  I have already described the behaviour of the men and women to
36	whom I spoke.  All over the district people were dining and supping;
36	working men were gardening after the labours of the day, children
36	were being put to bed, young people were wandering through the lanes
36	love-making, students sat over their books.
36	
36	Maybe there was a murmur in the village streets, a novel and
36	dominant topic in the public-houses, and here and there a messenger,
36	or even an eye-witness of the later occurrences, caused a whirl of
36	excitement, a shouting, and a running to and fro; but for the most
36	part the daily routine of working, eating, drinking, sleeping, went on
36	as it had done for countless years--as though no planet Mars existed
36	in the sky.  Even at Woking station and Horsell and Chobham that was
36	the case.
36	
36	In Woking junction, until a late hour, trains were stopping and
36	going on, others were shunting on the sidings, passengers were
36	alighting and waiting, and everything was proceeding in the most
36	ordinary way.  A boy from the town, trenching on Smith's monopoly, was
36	selling papers with the afternoon's news.  The ringing impact of
36	trucks, the sharp whistle of the engines from the junction, mingled
36	with their shouts of ""Men from Mars!""  Excited men came into the
36	station about nine o'clock with incredible tidings, and caused no more
36	disturbance than drunkards might have done.  People rattling
36	Londonwards peered into the darkness outside the carriage windows, and
36	saw only a rare, flickering, vanishing spark dance up from the
36	direction of Horsell, a red glow and a thin veil of smoke driving
36	across the stars, and thought that nothing more serious than a heath
36	fire was happening.  It was only round the edge of the common that any
36	disturbance was perceptible.  There were half a dozen villas burning
36	on the Woking border.  There were lights in all the houses on the
36	common side of the three villages, and the people there kept awake
36	till dawn.
36	
36	A curious crowd lingered restlessly, people coming and going but
36	the crowd remaining, both on the Chobham and Horsell bridges.  One or
36	two adventurous souls, it was afterwards found, went into the darkness
36	and crawled quite near the Martians; but they never returned, for now
36	and again a light-ray, like the beam of a warship's searchlight swept
36	the common, and the Heat-Ray was ready to follow.  Save for such, that
36	big area of common was silent and desolate, and the charred bodies lay
36	about on it all night under the stars, and all the next day.  A noise
36	of hammering from the pit was heard by many people.
36	
36	So you have the state of things on Friday night.  In the centre,
36	sticking into the skin of our old planet Earth like a poisoned dart,
36	was this cylinder.  But the poison was scarcely working yet.  Around
36	it was a patch of silent common, smouldering in places, and with a few
36	dark, dimly seen objects lying in contorted attitudes here and there.
36	Here and there was a burning bush or tree.  Beyond was a fringe of
36	excitement, and farther than that fringe the inflammation had not
36	crept as yet.  In the rest of the world the stream of life still
36	flowed as it had flowed for immemorial years.  The fever of war that
36	would presently clog vein and artery, deaden nerve and destroy brain,
36	had still to develop.
36	
36	All night long the Martians were hammering and stirring, sleepless,
36	indefatigable, at work upon the machines they were making ready, and
36	ever and again a puff of greenish-white smoke whirled up to the
36	starlit sky.
36	
36	About eleven a company of soldiers came through Horsell, and
36	deployed along the edge of the common to form a cordon.  Later a
36	second company marched through Chobham to deploy on the north side of
36	the common.  Several officers from the Inkerman barracks had been on
36	the common earlier in the day, and one, Major Eden, was reported to be
36	missing.  The colonel of the regiment came to the Chobham bridge and
36	was busy questioning the crowd at midnight.  The military authorities
36	were certainly alive to the seriousness of the business.  About
36	eleven, the next morning's papers were able to say, a squadron of
36	hussars, two Maxims, and about four hundred men of the Cardigan
36	regiment started from Aldershot.
36	
36	A few seconds after midnight the crowd in the Chertsey road,
36	Woking, saw a star fall from heaven into the pine woods to the
36	northwest.  It had a greenish colour, and caused a silent brightness
36	like summer lightning.  This was the second cylinder.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER NINE
36	
36	THE FIGHTING BEGINS
36	
36	
36	Saturday lives in my memory as a day of suspense.  It was a day of
36	lassitude too, hot and close, with, I am told, a rapidly fluctuating
36	barometer.  I had slept but little, though my wife had succeeded in
36	sleeping, and I rose early.  I went into my garden before breakfast
36	and stood listening, but towards the common there was nothing stirring
36	but a lark.
36	
36	The milkman came as usual.  I heard the rattle of his chariot and I
36	went round to the side gate to ask the latest news.  He told me that
36	during the night the Martians had been surrounded by troops, and that
36	guns were expected.  Then--a familiar, reassuring note--I heard a train
36	running towards Woking.
36	
36	""They aren't to be killed,"" said the milkman, ""if that can possibly
36	be avoided.""
36	
36	I saw my neighbour gardening, chatted with him for a time, and then
36	strolled in to breakfast.  It was a most unexceptional morning.  My
36	neighbour was of opinion that the troops would be able to capture or
36	to destroy the Martians during the day.
36	
36	""It's a pity they make themselves so unapproachable,"" he said.  ""It
36	would be curious to know how they live on another planet; we might
36	learn a thing or two.""
36	
36	He came up to the fence and extended a handful of strawberries, for
36	his gardening was as generous as it was enthusiastic.  At the same
36	time he told me of the burning of the pine woods about the Byfleet
36	Golf Links.
36	
36	""They say,"" said he, ""that there's another of those blessed things
36	fallen there--number two.  But one's enough, surely.  This lot'll cost
36	the insurance people a pretty penny before everything's settled.""  He
36	laughed with an air of the greatest good humour as he said this.  The
36	woods, he said, were still burning, and pointed out a haze of smoke to
36	me.  ""They will be hot under foot for days, on account of the thick
36	soil of pine needles and turf,"" he said, and then grew serious over
36	""poor Ogilvy.""
36	
36	After breakfast, instead of working, I decided to walk down
36	towards the common.  Under the railway bridge I found a group of
36	soldiers--sappers, I think, men in small round caps, dirty red jackets
36	unbuttoned, and showing their blue shirts, dark trousers, and boots
36	coming to the calf.  They told me no one was allowed over the canal,
36	and, looking along the road towards the bridge, I saw one of the
36	Cardigan men standing sentinel there.  I talked with these soldiers
36	for a time; I told them of my sight of the Martians on the previous
36	evening.  None of them had seen the Martians, and they had but the
36	vaguest ideas of them, so that they plied me with questions.  They
36	said that they did not know who had authorised the movements of the
36	troops; their idea was that a dispute had arisen at the Horse Guards.
36	The ordinary sapper is a great deal better educated than the common
36	soldier, and they discussed the peculiar conditions of the possible
36	fight with some acuteness.  I described the Heat-Ray to them, and they
36	began to argue among themselves.
36	
36	""Crawl up under cover and rush 'em, say I,"" said one.
36	
36	""Get aht!"" said another.  ""What's cover against this 'ere 'eat?
36	Sticks to cook yer!  What we got to do is to go as near as the
36	ground'll let us, and then drive a trench.""
36	
36	""Blow yer trenches!  You always want trenches; you ought to ha'
36	been born a rabbit Snippy.""
36	
36	""Ain't they got any necks, then?"" said a third, abruptly--a little,
36	contemplative, dark man, smoking a pipe.
36	
36	I repeated my description.
36	
36	""Octopuses,"" said he, ""that's what I calls 'em.  Talk about fishers
36	of men--fighters of fish it is this time!""
36	
36	""It ain't no murder killing beasts like that,"" said the first
36	speaker.
36	
36	""Why not shell the darned things strite off and finish 'em?"" said
36	the little dark man.  ""You carn tell what they might do.""
36	
36	""Where's your shells?"" said the first speaker.  ""There ain't no
36	time.  Do it in a rush, that's my tip, and do it at once.""
36	
36	So they discussed it.  After a while I left them, and went on to
36	the railway station to get as many morning papers as I could.
36	
36	But I will not weary the reader with a description of that long
36	morning and of the longer afternoon.  I did not succeed in getting a
36	glimpse of the common, for even Horsell and Chobham church towers were
36	in the hands of the military authorities.  The soldiers I addressed
36	didn't know anything; the officers were mysterious as well as busy.  I
36	found people in the town quite secure again in the presence of the
36	military, and I heard for the first time from Marshall, the
36	tobacconist, that his son was among the dead on the common.  The
36	soldiers had made the people on the outskirts of Horsell lock up and
36	leave their houses.
36	
36	I got back to lunch about two, very tired for, as I have said, the
36	day was extremely hot and dull; and in order to refresh myself I took
36	a cold bath in the afternoon.  About half past four I went up to the
36	railway station to get an evening paper, for the morning papers had
36	contained only a very inaccurate description of the killing of Stent,
36	Henderson, Ogilvy, and the others.  But there was little I didn't
36	know.  The Martians did not show an inch of themselves.  They seemed
36	busy in their pit, and there was a sound of hammering and an almost
36	continuous streamer of smoke.  Apparently they were busy getting ready
36	for a struggle.  ""Fresh attempts have been made to signal, but without
36	success,"" was the stereotyped formula of the papers.  A sapper told me
36	it was done by a man in a ditch with a flag on a long pole.  The
36	Martians took as much notice of such advances as we should of the
36	lowing of a cow.
36	
36	I must confess the sight of all this armament, all this
36	preparation, greatly excited me.  My imagination became belligerent,
36	and defeated the invaders in a dozen striking ways; something of my
36	schoolboy dreams of battle and heroism came back.  It hardly seemed a
36	fair fight to me at that time.  They seemed very helpless in that pit
36	of theirs.
36	
36	About three o'clock there began the thud of a gun at measured
36	intervals from Chertsey or Addlestone.  I learned that the smouldering
36	pine wood into which the second cylinder had fallen was being shelled,
36	in the hope of destroying that object before it opened.  It was only
36	about five, however, that a field gun reached Chobham for use against
36	the first body of Martians.
36	
36	About six in the evening, as I sat at tea with my wife in the
36	summerhouse talking vigorously about the battle that was lowering upon
36	us, I heard a muffled detonation from the common, and immediately
36	after a gust of firing.  Close on the heels of that came a violent
36	rattling crash, quite close to us, that shook the ground; and,
36	starting out upon the lawn, I saw the tops of the trees about the
36	Oriental College burst into smoky red flame, and the tower of the
36	little church beside it slide down into ruin.  The pinnacle of the
36	mosque had vanished, and the roof line of the college itself looked as
36	if a hundred-ton gun had been at work upon it.  One of our chimneys
36	cracked as if a shot had hit it, flew, and a piece of it came
36	clattering down the tiles and made a heap of broken red fragments upon
36	the flower bed by my study window.
36	
36	I and my wife stood amazed.  Then I realised that the crest of
36	Maybury Hill must be within range of the Martians' Heat-Ray now that
36	the college was cleared out of the way.
36	
36	At that I gripped my wife's arm, and without ceremony ran her out
36	into the road.  Then I fetched out the servant, telling her I would go
36	upstairs myself for the box she was clamouring for.
36	
36	""We can't possibly stay here,"" I said; and as I spoke the firing
36	reopened for a moment upon the common.
36	
36	""But where are we to go?"" said my wife in terror.
36	
36	I thought perplexed.  Then I remembered her cousins at Leatherhead.
36	
36	""Leatherhead!"" I shouted above the sudden noise.
36	
36	She looked away from me downhill.  The people were coming out of
36	their houses, astonished.
36	
36	""How are we to get to Leatherhead?"" she said.
36	
36	Down the hill I saw a bevy of hussars ride under the railway
36	bridge; three galloped through the open gates of the Oriental College;
36	two others dismounted, and began running from house to house.  The
36	sun, shining through the smoke that drove up from the tops of the
36	trees, seemed blood red, and threw an unfamiliar lurid light upon
36	everything.
36	
36	""Stop here,"" said I; ""you are safe here""; and I started off at once
36	for the Spotted Dog, for I knew the landlord had a horse and dog cart.
36	I ran, for I perceived that in a moment everyone upon this side of the
36	hill would be moving.  I found him in his bar, quite unaware of what
36	was going on behind his house.  A man stood with his back to me,
36	talking to him.
36	
36	""I must have a pound,"" said the landlord, ""and I've no one to drive
36	it.""
36	
36	""I'll give you two,"" said I, over the stranger's shoulder.
36	
36	""What for?""
36	
36	""And I'll bring it back by midnight,"" I said.
36	
36	""Lord!"" said the landlord; ""what's the hurry?  I'm selling my bit
36	of a pig.  Two pounds, and you bring it back?  What's going on now?""
36	
36	I explained hastily that I had to leave my home, and so secured the
36	dog cart.  At the time it did not seem to me nearly so urgent that the
36	landlord should leave his.  I took care to have the cart there and
36	then, drove it off down the road, and, leaving it in charge of my wife
36	and servant, rushed into my house and packed a few valuables, such
36	plate as we had, and so forth.  The beech trees below the house were
36	burning while I did this, and the palings up the road glowed red.
36	While I was occupied in this way, one of the dismounted hussars came
36	running up.  He was going from house to house, warning people to
36	leave.  He was going on as I came out of my front door, lugging my
36	treasures, done up in a tablecloth.  I shouted after him:
36	
36	""What news?""
36	
36	He turned, stared, bawled something about ""crawling out in a thing
36	like a dish cover,"" and ran on to the gate of the house at the crest.
36	A sudden whirl of black smoke driving across the road hid him for a
36	moment.  I ran to my neighbour's door and rapped to satisfy myself of
36	what I already knew, that his wife had gone to London with him and had
36	locked up their house.  I went in again, according to my promise, to
36	get my servant's box, lugged it out, clapped it beside her on the tail
36	of the dog cart, and then caught the reins and jumped up into the
36	driver's seat beside my wife.  In another moment we were clear of the
36	smoke and noise, and spanking down the opposite slope of Maybury Hill
36	towards Old Woking.
36	
36	In front was a quiet sunny landscape, a wheat field ahead on either
36	side of the road, and the Maybury Inn with its swinging sign.  I saw
36	the doctor's cart ahead of me.  At the bottom of the hill I turned my
36	head to look at the hillside I was leaving.  Thick streamers of black
36	smoke shot with threads of red fire were driving up into the still
36	air, and throwing dark shadows upon the green treetops eastward.  The
36	smoke already extended far away to the east and west--to the Byfleet
36	pine woods eastward, and to Woking on the west.  The road was dotted
36	with people running towards us.  And very faint now, but very distinct
36	through the hot, quiet air, one heard the whirr of a machine-gun that
36	was presently stilled, and an intermittent cracking of rifles.
36	Apparently the Martians were setting fire to everything within range
36	of their Heat-Ray.
36	
36	I am not an expert driver, and I had immediately to turn my
36	attention to the horse.  When I looked back again the second hill had
36	hidden the black smoke.  I slashed the horse with the whip, and gave
36	him a loose rein until Woking and Send lay between us and that
36	quivering tumult.  I overtook and passed the doctor between Woking and
36	Send.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER TEN
36	
36	IN THE STORM
36	
36	
36	Leatherhead is about twelve miles from Maybury Hill.  The scent of
36	hay was in the air through the lush meadows beyond Pyrford, and the
36	hedges on either side were sweet and gay with multitudes of dog-roses.
36	The heavy firing that had broken out while we were driving down
36	Maybury Hill ceased as abruptly as it began, leaving the evening very
36	peaceful and still.  We got to Leatherhead without misadventure about
36	nine o'clock, and the horse had an hour's rest while I took supper
36	with my cousins and commended my wife to their care.
36	
36	My wife was curiously silent throughout the drive, and seemed
36	oppressed with forebodings of evil.  I talked to her reassuringly,
36	pointing out that the Martians were tied to the Pit by sheer
36	heaviness, and at the utmost could but crawl a little out of it; but
36	she answered only in monosyllables.  Had it not been for my promise to
36	the innkeeper, she would, I think, have urged me to stay in
36	Leatherhead that night.  Would that I had!  Her face, I remember, was
36	very white as we parted.
36	
36	For my own part, I had been feverishly excited all day.  Something
36	very like the war fever that occasionally runs through a civilised
36	community had got into my blood, and in my heart I was not so very
36	sorry that I had to return to Maybury that night.  I was even afraid
36	that that last fusillade I had heard might mean the extermination of
36	our invaders from Mars.  I can best express my state of mind by saying
36	that I wanted to be in at the death.
36	
36	It was nearly eleven when I started to return.  The night was
36	unexpectedly dark; to me, walking out of the lighted passage of my
36	cousins' house, it seemed indeed black, and it was as hot and close as
36	the day.  Overhead the clouds were driving fast, albeit not a breath
36	stirred the shrubs about us.  My cousins' man lit both lamps.  Happily,
36	I knew the road intimately.  My wife stood in the light of the
36	doorway, and watched me until I jumped up into the dog cart.  Then
36	abruptly she turned and went in, leaving my cousins side by side
36	wishing me good hap.
36	
36	I was a little depressed at first with the contagion of my wife's
36	fears, but very soon my thoughts reverted to the Martians.  At that
36	time I was absolutely in the dark as to the course of the evening's
36	fighting.  I did not know even the circumstances that had precipitated
36	the conflict.  As I came through Ockham (for that was the way I
36	returned, and not through Send and Old Woking) I saw along the western
36	horizon a blood-red glow, which as I drew nearer, crept slowly up the
36	sky.  The driving clouds of the gathering thunderstorm mingled there
36	with masses of black and red smoke.
36	
36	Ripley Street was deserted, and except for a lighted window or so
36	the village showed not a sign of life; but I narrowly escaped an
36	accident at the corner of the road to Pyrford, where a knot of people
36	stood with their backs to me.  They said nothing to me as I passed.  I
36	do not know what they knew of the things happening beyond the hill,
36	nor do I know if the silent houses I passed on my way were sleeping
36	securely, or deserted and empty, or harassed and watching against the
36	terror of the night.
36	
36	From Ripley until I came through Pyrford I was in the valley of the
36	Wey, and the red glare was hidden from me.  As I ascended the little
36	hill beyond Pyrford Church the glare came into view again, and the
36	trees about me shivered with the first intimation of the storm that
36	was upon me.  Then I heard midnight pealing out from Pyrford Church
36	behind me, and then came the silhouette of Maybury Hill, with its
36	tree-tops and roofs black and sharp against the red.
36	
36	Even as I beheld this a lurid green glare lit the road about me and
36	showed the distant woods towards Addlestone.  I felt a tug at the
36	reins.  I saw that the driving clouds had been pierced as it were by a
36	thread of green fire, suddenly lighting their confusion and falling
36	into the field to my left.  It was the third falling star!
36	
36	Close on its apparition, and blindingly violet by contrast, danced
36	out the first lightning of the gathering storm, and the thunder burst
36	like a rocket overhead.  The horse took the bit between his teeth and
36	bolted.
36	
36	A moderate incline runs towards the foot of Maybury Hill, and down
36	this we clattered.  Once the lightning had begun, it went on in as
36	rapid a succession of flashes as I have ever seen.  The thunderclaps,
36	treading one on the heels of another and with a strange crackling
36	accompaniment, sounded more like the working of a gigantic electric
36	machine than the usual detonating reverberations.  The flickering
36	light was blinding and confusing, and a thin hail smote gustily at my
36	face as I drove down the slope.
36	
36	At first I regarded little but the road before me, and then
36	abruptly my attention was arrested by something that was moving
36	rapidly down the opposite slope of Maybury Hill.  At first I took it
36	for the wet roof of a house, but one flash following another showed it
36	to be in swift rolling movement.  It was an elusive vision--a moment
36	of bewildering darkness, and then, in a flash like daylight, the red
36	masses of the Orphanage near the crest of the hill, the green tops of
36	the pine trees, and this problematical object came out clear and sharp
36	and bright.
36	
36	And this Thing I saw!  How can I describe it?  A monstrous tripod,
36	higher than many houses, striding over the young pine trees, and
36	smashing them aside in its career; a walking engine of glittering
36	metal, striding now across the heather; articulate ropes of steel
36	dangling from it, and the clattering tumult of its passage mingling
36	with the riot of the thunder.  A flash, and it came out vividly,
36	heeling over one way with two feet in the air, to vanish and reappear
36	almost instantly as it seemed, with the next flash, a hundred yards
36	nearer.  Can you imagine a milking stool tilted and bowled violently
36	along the ground?  That was the impression those instant flashes gave.
36	But instead of a milking stool imagine it a great body of machinery on
36	a tripod stand.
36	
36	Then suddenly the trees in the pine wood ahead of me were parted,
36	as brittle reeds are parted by a man thrusting through them; they were
36	snapped off and driven headlong, and a second huge tripod appeared,
36	rushing, as it seemed, headlong towards me.  And I was galloping hard
36	to meet it! At the sight of the second monster my nerve went
36	altogether.  Not stopping to look again, I wrenched the horse's head
36	hard round to the right and in another moment the dog cart had heeled
36	over upon the horse; the shafts smashed noisily, and I was flung
36	sideways and fell heavily into a shallow pool of water.
36	
36	I crawled out almost immediately, and crouched, my feet still in
36	the water, under a clump of furze.  The horse lay motionless (his neck
36	was broken, poor brute!) and by the lightning flashes I saw the black
36	bulk of the overturned dog cart and the silhouette of the wheel still
36	spinning slowly.  In another moment the colossal mechanism went
36	striding by me, and passed uphill towards Pyrford.
36	
36	Seen nearer, the Thing was incredibly strange, for it was no mere
36	insensate machine driving on its way.  Machine it was, with a ringing
36	metallic pace, and long, flexible, glittering tentacles (one of which
36	gripped a young pine tree) swinging and rattling about its strange
36	body.  It picked its road as it went striding along, and the brazen
36	hood that surmounted it moved to and fro with the inevitable
36	suggestion of a head looking about.  Behind the main body was a huge
36	mass of white metal like a gigantic fisherman's basket, and puffs of
36	green smoke squirted out from the joints of the limbs as the monster
36	swept by me.  And in an instant it was gone.
36	
36	So much I saw then, all vaguely for the flickering of the
36	lightning, in blinding highlights and dense black shadows.
36	
36	As it passed it set up an exultant deafening howl that drowned the
36	thunder--""Aloo!  Aloo!""--and in another minute it was with its
36	companion, half a mile away, stooping over something in the field.  I
36	have no doubt this Thing in the field was the third of the ten
36	cylinders they had fired at us from Mars.
36	
36	For some minutes I lay there in the rain and darkness watching, by
36	the intermittent light, these monstrous beings of metal moving about
36	in the distance over the hedge tops.  A thin hail was now beginning,
36	and as it came and went their figures grew misty and then flashed into
36	clearness again.  Now and then came a gap in the lightning, and the
36	night swallowed them up.
36	
36	I was soaked with hail above and puddle water below.  It was some
36	time before my blank astonishment would let me struggle up the bank to
36	a drier position, or think at all of my imminent peril.
36	
36	Not far from me was a little one-roomed squatter's hut of wood,
36	surrounded by a patch of potato garden.  I struggled to my feet at
36	last, and, crouching and making use of every chance of cover, I made a
36	run for this.  I hammered at the door, but I could not make the people
36	hear (if there were any people inside), and after a time I desisted,
36	and, availing myself of a ditch for the greater part of the way,
36	succeeded in crawling, unobserved by these monstrous machines, into
36	the pine woods towards Maybury.
36	
36	Under cover of this I pushed on, wet and shivering now, towards my
36	own house.  I walked among the trees trying to find the footpath.  It
36	was very dark indeed in the wood, for the lightning was now becoming
36	infrequent, and the hail, which was pouring down in a torrent, fell in
36	columns through the gaps in the heavy foliage.
36	
36	If I had fully realised the meaning of all the things I had seen I
36	should have immediately worked my way round through Byfleet to Street
36	Cobham, and so gone back to rejoin my wife at Leatherhead.  But that
36	night the strangeness of things about me, and my physical
36	wretchedness, prevented me, for I was bruised, weary, wet to the skin,
36	deafened and blinded by the storm.
36	
36	I had a vague idea of going on to my own house, and that was as
36	much motive as I had.  I staggered through the trees, fell into a
36	ditch and bruised my knees against a plank, and finally splashed out
36	into the lane that ran down from the College Arms.  I say splashed,
36	for the storm water was sweeping the sand down the hill in a muddy
36	torrent.  There in the darkness a man blundered into me and sent me
36	reeling back.
36	
36	He gave a cry of terror, sprang sideways, and rushed on before I
36	could gather my wits sufficiently to speak to him.  So heavy was the
36	stress of the storm just at this place that I had the hardest task to
36	win my way up the hill.  I went close up to the fence on the left and
36	worked my way along its palings.
36	
36	Near the top I stumbled upon something soft, and, by a flash of
36	lightning, saw between my feet a heap of black broadcloth and a pair
36	of boots.  Before I could distinguish clearly how the man lay, the
36	flicker of light had passed.  I stood over him waiting for the next
36	flash.  When it came, I saw that he was a sturdy man, cheaply but not
36	shabbily dressed; his head was bent under his body, and he lay
36	crumpled up close to the fence, as though he had been flung violently
36	against it.
36	
36	Overcoming the repugnance natural to one who had never before
36	touched a dead body, I stooped and turned him over to feel for his
36	heart.  He was quite dead.  Apparently his neck had been broken.  The
36	lightning flashed for a third time, and his face leaped upon me.  I
36	sprang to my feet.  It was the landlord of the Spotted Dog, whose
36	conveyance I had taken.
36	
36	I stepped over him gingerly and pushed on up the hill.  I made my
36	way by the police station and the College Arms towards my own house.
36	Nothing was burning on the hillside, though from the common there
36	still came a red glare and a rolling tumult of ruddy smoke beating up
36	against the drenching hail.  So far as I could see by the flashes, the
36	houses about me were mostly uninjured.  By the College Arms a dark
36	heap lay in the road.
36	
36	Down the road towards Maybury Bridge there were voices and the
36	sound of feet, but I had not the courage to shout or to go to them.  I
36	let myself in with my latchkey, closed, locked and bolted the door,
36	staggered to the foot of the staircase, and sat down.  My imagination
36	was full of those striding metallic monsters, and of the dead body
36	smashed against the fence.
36	
36	I crouched at the foot of the staircase with my back to the wall,
36	shivering violently.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER ELEVEN
36	
36	AT THE WINDOW
36	
36	
36	I have already said that my storms of emotion have a trick of
36	exhausting themselves.  After a time I discovered that I was cold and
36	wet, and with little pools of water about me on the stair carpet.  I
36	got up almost mechanically, went into the dining room and drank some
36	whiskey, and then I was moved to change my clothes.
36	
36	After I had done that I went upstairs to my study, but why I did so
36	I do not know.  The window of my study looks over the trees and the
36	railway towards Horsell Common.  In the hurry of our departure this
36	window had been left open.  The passage was dark, and, by contrast with
36	the picture the window frame enclosed, the side of the room seemed
36	impenetrably dark.  I stopped short in the doorway.
36	
36	The thunderstorm had passed.  The towers of the Oriental College
36	and the pine trees about it had gone, and very far away, lit by a
36	vivid red glare, the common about the sand pits was visible.  Across
36	the light huge black shapes, grotesque and strange, moved busily to
36	and fro.
36	
36	It seemed indeed as if the whole country in that direction was on
36	fire--a broad hillside set with minute tongues of flame, swaying and
36	writhing with the gusts of the dying storm, and throwing a red
36	reflection upon the cloud-scud above.  Every now and then a haze of
36	smoke from some nearer conflagration drove across the window and hid
36	the Martian shapes.  I could not see what they were doing, nor the
36	clear form of them, nor recognise the black objects they were busied
36	upon.  Neither could I see the nearer fire, though the reflections of
36	it danced on the wall and ceiling of the study.  A sharp, resinous
36	tang of burning was in the air.
36	
36	I closed the door noiselessly and crept towards the window.  As I
36	did so, the view opened out until, on the one hand, it reached to the
36	houses about Woking station, and on the other to the charred and
36	blackened pine woods of Byfleet.  There was a light down below the
36	hill, on the railway, near the arch, and several of the houses along
36	the Maybury road and the streets near the station were glowing ruins.
36	The light upon the railway puzzled me at first; there were a black
36	heap and a vivid glare, and to the right of that a row of yellow
36	oblongs.  Then I perceived this was a wrecked train, the fore part
36	smashed and on fire, the hinder carriages still upon the rails.
36	
36	Between these three main centres of light--the houses, the train,
36	and the burning county towards Chobham--stretched irregular patches of
36	dark country, broken here and there by intervals of dimly glowing and
36	smoking ground.  It was the strangest spectacle, that black expanse set
36	with fire.  It reminded me, more than anything else, of the Potteries
36	at night.  At first I could distinguish no people at all, though I
36	peered intently for them.  Later I saw against the light of Woking
36	station a number of black figures hurrying one after the other across
36	the line.
36	
36	And this was the little world in which I had been living securely
36	for years, this fiery chaos!  What had happened in the last seven
36	hours I still did not know; nor did I know, though I was beginning to
36	guess, the relation between these mechanical colossi and the sluggish
36	lumps I had seen disgorged from the cylinder.  With a queer feeling of
36	impersonal interest I turned my desk chair to the window, sat down,
36	and stared at the blackened country, and particularly at the three
36	gigantic black things that were going to and fro in the glare about
36	the sand pits.
36	
36	They seemed amazingly busy.  I began to ask myself what they could
36	be.  Were they intelligent mechanisms?  Such a thing I felt was
36	impossible.  Or did a Martian sit within each, ruling, directing,
36	using, much as a man's brain sits and rules in his body?  I began to
36	compare the things to human machines, to ask myself for the first time
36	in my life how an ironclad or a steam engine would seem to an
36	intelligent lower animal.
36	
36	The storm had left the sky clear, and over the smoke of the burning
36	land the little fading pinpoint of Mars was dropping into the west,
36	when a soldier came into my garden.  I heard a slight scraping at the
36	fence, and rousing myself from the lethargy that had fallen upon me, I
36	looked down and saw him dimly, clambering over the palings.  At the
36	sight of another human being my torpor passed, and I leaned out of the
36	window eagerly.
36	
36	""Hist!"" said I, in a whisper.
36	
36	He stopped astride of the fence in doubt.  Then he came over and
36	across the lawn to the corner of the house.  He bent down and stepped
36	softly.
36	
36	""Who's there?"" he said, also whispering, standing under the window
36	and peering up.
36	
36	""Where are you going?"" I asked.
36	
36	""God knows.""
36	
36	""Are you trying to hide?""
36	
36	""That's it.""
36	
36	""Come into the house,"" I said.
36	
36	I went down, unfastened the door, and let him in, and locked the
36	door again.  I could not see his face.  He was hatless, and his coat
36	was unbuttoned.
36	
36	""My God!"" he said, as I drew him in.
36	
36	""What has happened?"" I asked.
36	
36	""What hasn't?""  In the obscurity I could see he made a gesture of
36	despair.  ""They wiped us out--simply wiped us out,"" he repeated again
36	and again.
36	
36	He followed me, almost mechanically, into the dining room.
36	
36	""Take some whiskey,"" I said, pouring out a stiff dose.
36	
36	He drank it.  Then abruptly he sat down before the table, put his
36	head on his arms, and began to sob and weep like a little boy, in a
36	perfect passion of emotion, while I, with a curious forgetfulness of
36	my own recent despair, stood beside him, wondering.
36	
36	It was a long time before he could steady his nerves to answer my
36	questions, and then he answered perplexingly and brokenly.  He was a
36	driver in the artillery, and had only come into action about seven.  At
36	that time firing was going on across the common, and it was said the
36	first party of Martians were crawling slowly towards their second
36	cylinder under cover of a metal shield.
36	
36	Later this shield staggered up on tripod legs and became the first
36	of the fighting-machines I had seen.  The gun he drove had been
36	unlimbered near Horsell, in order to command the sand pits, and its
36	arrival it was that had precipitated the action.  As the limber
36	gunners went to the rear, his horse trod in a rabbit hole and came
36	down, throwing him into a depression of the ground.  At the same
36	moment the gun exploded behind him, the ammunition blew up, there was
36	fire all about him, and he found himself lying under a heap of charred
36	dead men and dead horses.
36	
36	""I lay still,"" he said, ""scared out of my wits, with the fore quarter
36	of a horse atop of me.  We'd been wiped out.  And the smell--good
36	God!  Like burnt meat!  I was hurt across the back by the fall of
36	the horse, and there I had to lie until I felt better.  Just like
36	parade it had been a minute before--then stumble, bang, swish!""
36	
36	""Wiped out!"" he said.
36	
36	He had hid under the dead horse for a long time, peeping out
36	furtively across the common.  The Cardigan men had tried a rush, in
36	skirmishing order, at the pit, simply to be swept out of existence.
36	Then the monster had risen to its feet and had begun to walk leisurely
36	to and fro across the common among the few fugitives, with its
36	headlike hood turning about exactly like the head of a cowled human
36	being.  A kind of arm carried a complicated metallic case, about which
36	green flashes scintillated, and out of the funnel of this there smoked
36	the Heat-Ray.
36	
36	In a few minutes there was, so far as the soldier could see, not a
36	living thing left upon the common, and every bush and tree upon it
36	that was not already a blackened skeleton was burning.  The hussars
36	had been on the road beyond the curvature of the ground, and he saw
36	nothing of them.  He heard the Martians rattle for a time and then
36	become still.  The giant saved Woking station and its cluster of houses
36	until the last; then in a moment the Heat-Ray was brought to bear, and
36	the town became a heap of fiery ruins.  Then the Thing shut off the
36	Heat-Ray, and turning its back upon the artilleryman, began to waddle
36	away towards the smouldering pine woods that sheltered the second
36	cylinder.  As it did so a second glittering Titan built itself up out
36	of the pit.
36	
36	The second monster followed the first, and at that the artilleryman
36	began to crawl very cautiously across the hot heather ash towards
36	Horsell.  He managed to get alive into the ditch by the side of the
36	road, and so escaped to Woking.  There his story became ejaculatory.
36	The place was impassable.  It seems there were a few people alive
36	there, frantic for the most part and many burned and scalded.  He was
36	turned aside by the fire, and hid among some almost scorching heaps of
36	broken wall as one of the Martian giants returned.  He saw this one
36	pursue a man, catch him up in one of its steely tentacles, and knock
36	his head against the trunk of a pine tree.  At last, after nightfall,
36	the artilleryman made a rush for it and got over the railway
36	embankment.
36	
36	Since then he had been skulking along towards Maybury, in the hope
36	of getting out of danger Londonward.  People were hiding in trenches
36	and cellars, and many of the survivors had made off towards Woking
36	village and Send.  He had been consumed with thirst until he found one
36	of the water mains near the railway arch smashed, and the water
36	bubbling out like a spring upon the road.
36	
36	That was the story I got from him, bit by bit.  He grew calmer
36	telling me and trying to make me see the things he had seen.  He had
36	eaten no food since midday, he told me early in his narrative, and I
36	found some mutton and bread in the pantry and brought it into the
36	room.  We lit no lamp for fear of attracting the Martians, and ever
36	and again our hands would touch upon bread or meat.  As he talked,
36	things about us came darkly out of the darkness, and the trampled
36	bushes and broken rose trees outside the window grew distinct.  It
36	would seem that a number of men or animals had rushed across the lawn.
36	I began to see his face, blackened and haggard, as no doubt mine was
36	also.
36	
36	When we had finished eating we went softly upstairs to my study,
36	and I looked again out of the open window.  In one night the valley
36	had become a valley of ashes.  The fires had dwindled now.  Where
36	flames had been there were now streamers of smoke; but the countless
36	ruins of shattered and gutted houses and blasted and blackened trees
36	that the night had hidden stood out now gaunt and terrible in the
36	pitiless light of dawn.  Yet here and there some object had had the
36	luck to escape--a white railway signal here, the end of a greenhouse
36	there, white and fresh amid the wreckage.  Never before in the history
36	of warfare had destruction been so indiscriminate and so universal.
36	And shining with the growing light of the east, three of the metallic
36	giants stood about the pit, their cowls rotating as though they were
36	surveying the desolation they had made.
36	
36	It seemed to me that the pit had been enlarged, and ever and again
36	puffs of vivid green vapour streamed up and out of it towards the
36	brightening dawn--streamed up, whirled, broke, and vanished.
36	
36	Beyond were the pillars of fire about Chobham.  They became pillars
36	of bloodshot smoke at the first touch of day.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER TWELVE
36	
36	WHAT I SAW OF THE DESTRUCTION OF WEYBRIDGE AND SHEPPERTON
36	
36	
36	As the dawn grew brighter we withdrew from the window from which we
36	had watched the Martians, and went very quietly downstairs.
36	
36	The artilleryman agreed with me that the house was no place to stay
36	in.  He proposed, he said, to make his way Londonward, and thence
36	rejoin his battery--No. 12, of the Horse Artillery.  My plan was to
36	return at once to Leatherhead; and so greatly had the strength of the
36	Martians impressed me that I had determined to take my wife to
36	Newhaven, and go with her out of the country forthwith.  For I already
36	perceived clearly that the country about London must inevitably be the
36	scene of a disastrous struggle before such creatures as these could be
36	destroyed.
36	
36	Between us and Leatherhead, however, lay the third cylinder, with
36	its guarding giants.  Had I been alone, I think I should have taken my
36	chance and struck across country.  But the artilleryman dissuaded me:
36	""It's no kindness to the right sort of wife,"" he said, ""to make her a
36	widow""; and in the end I agreed to go with him, under cover of the
36	woods, northward as far as Street Cobham before I parted with him.
36	Thence I would make a big detour by Epsom to reach Leatherhead.
36	
36	I should have started at once, but my companion had been in active
36	service and he knew better than that.  He made me ransack the house
36	for a flask, which he filled with whiskey; and we lined every
36	available pocket with packets of biscuits and slices of meat.  Then
36	we crept out of the house, and ran as quickly as we could down the
36	ill-made road by which I had come overnight.  The houses seemed
36	deserted. In the road lay a group of three charred bodies close
36	together, struck dead by the Heat-Ray; and here and there were things
36	that people had dropped--a clock, a slipper, a silver spoon, and the
36	like poor valuables.  At the corner turning up towards the post
36	office a little cart, filled with boxes and furniture, and horseless,
36	heeled over on a broken wheel.  A cash box had been hastily smashed
36	open and thrown under the debris.
36	
36	Except the lodge at the Orphanage, which was still on fire, none of
36	the houses had suffered very greatly here.  The Heat-Ray had shaved
36	the chimney tops and passed.  Yet, save ourselves, there did not seem
36	to be a living soul on Maybury Hill.  The majority of the inhabitants
36	had escaped, I suppose, by way of the Old Woking road--the road I had
36	taken when I drove to Leatherhead--or they had hidden.
36	
36	We went down the lane, by the body of the man in black, sodden now
36	from the overnight hail, and broke into the woods at the foot of the
36	hill.  We pushed through these towards the railway without meeting a
36	soul.  The woods across the line were but the scarred and blackened
36	ruins of woods; for the most part the trees had fallen, but a certain
36	proportion still stood, dismal grey stems, with dark brown foliage
36	instead of green.
36	
36	On our side the fire had done no more than scorch the nearer trees;
36	it had failed to secure its footing.  In one place the woodmen had
36	been at work on Saturday; trees, felled and freshly trimmed, lay in a
36	clearing, with heaps of sawdust by the sawing-machine and its engine.
36	Hard by was a temporary hut, deserted.  There was not a breath of wind
36	this morning, and everything was strangely still.  Even the birds were
36	hushed, and as we hurried along I and the artilleryman talked in
36	whispers and looked now and again over our shoulders.  Once or twice
36	we stopped to listen.
36	
36	After a time we drew near the road, and as we did so we heard the
36	clatter of hoofs and saw through the tree stems three cavalry soldiers
36	riding slowly towards Woking.  We hailed them, and they halted while
36	we hurried towards them.  It was a lieutenant and a couple of privates
36	of the 8th Hussars, with a stand like a theodolite, which the
36	artilleryman told me was a heliograph.
36	
36	""You are the first men I've seen coming this way this morning,""
36	said the lieutenant.  ""What's brewing?""
36	
36	His voice and face were eager.  The men behind him stared
36	curiously.  The artilleryman jumped down the bank into the road and
36	saluted.
36	
36	""Gun destroyed last night, sir.  Have been hiding.  Trying to
36	rejoin battery, sir.  You'll come in sight of the Martians, I expect,
36	about half a mile along this road.""
36	
36	""What the dickens are they like?"" asked the lieutenant.
36	
36	""Giants in armour, sir.  Hundred feet high.  Three legs and a body
36	like 'luminium, with a mighty great head in a hood, sir.""
36	
36	""Get out!"" said the lieutenant.  ""What confounded nonsense!""
36	
36	""You'll see, sir.  They carry a kind of box, sir, that shoots fire
36	and strikes you dead.""
36	
36	""What d'ye mean--a gun?""
36	
36	""No, sir,"" and the artilleryman began a vivid account of the Heat-Ray.
36	Halfway through, the lieutenant interrupted him and looked up at
36	me.  I was still standing on the bank by the side of the road.
36	
36	""It's perfectly true,"" I said.
36	
36	""Well,"" said the lieutenant, ""I suppose it's my business to see it
36	too.  Look here""--to the artilleryman--""we're detailed here clearing
36	people out of their houses.  You'd better go along and report yourself
36	to Brigadier-General Marvin, and tell him all you know.  He's at
36	Weybridge.  Know the way?""
36	
36	""I do,"" I said; and he turned his horse southward again.
36	
36	""Half a mile, you say?"" said he.
36	
36	""At most,"" I answered, and pointed over the treetops southward.  He
36	thanked me and rode on, and we saw them no more.
36	
36	Farther along we came upon a group of three women and two children
36	in the road, busy clearing out a labourer's cottage.  They had
36	got hold of a little hand truck, and were piling it up with
36	unclean-looking bundles and shabby furniture.  They were all too
36	assiduously engaged to talk to us as we passed.
36	
36	By Byfleet station we emerged from the pine trees, and found the
36	country calm and peaceful under the morning sunlight.  We were far
36	beyond the range of the Heat-Ray there, and had it not been for the
36	silent desertion of some of the houses, the stirring movement of
36	packing in others, and the knot of soldiers standing on the bridge
36	over the railway and staring down the line towards Woking, the day
36	would have seemed very like any other Sunday.
36	
36	Several farm waggons and carts were moving creakily along the road
36	to Addlestone, and suddenly through the gate of a field we saw, across
36	a stretch of flat meadow, six twelve-pounders standing neatly at equal
36	distances pointing towards Woking.  The gunners stood by the guns
36	waiting, and the ammunition waggons were at a business-like distance.
36	The men stood almost as if under inspection.
36	
36	""That's good!"" said I.  ""They will get one fair shot, at any rate.""
36	
36	The artilleryman hesitated at the gate.
36	
36	""I shall go on,"" he said.
36	
36	Farther on towards Weybridge, just over the bridge, there were a
36	number of men in white fatigue jackets throwing up a long rampart, and
36	more guns behind.
36	
36	""It's bows and arrows against the lightning, anyhow,"" said the
36	artilleryman.  ""They 'aven't seen that fire-beam yet.""
36	
36	The officers who were not actively engaged stood and stared over
36	the treetops southwestward, and the men digging would stop every now
36	and again to stare in the same direction.
36	
36	Byfleet was in a tumult; people packing, and a score of hussars,
36	some of them dismounted, some on horseback, were hunting them about.
36	Three or four black government waggons, with crosses in white circles,
36	and an old omnibus, among other vehicles, were being loaded in the
36	village street.  There were scores of people, most of them
36	sufficiently sabbatical to have assumed their best clothes.  The
36	soldiers were having the greatest difficulty in making them realise
36	the gravity of their position.  We saw one shrivelled old fellow with
36	a huge box and a score or more of flower pots containing orchids,
36	angrily expostulating with the corporal who would leave them behind.
36	I stopped and gripped his arm.
36	
36	""Do you know what's over there?"" I said, pointing at the pine tops
36	that hid the Martians.
36	
36	""Eh?"" said he, turning.  ""I was explainin' these is vallyble.""
36	
36	""Death!"" I shouted.  ""Death is coming!  Death!"" and leaving him to
36	digest that if he could, I hurried on after the artillery-man.  At the
36	corner I looked back.  The soldier had left him, and he was still
36	standing by his box, with the pots of orchids on the lid of it, and
36	staring vaguely over the trees.
36	
36	No one in Weybridge could tell us where the headquarters were
36	established; the whole place was in such confusion as I had never seen
36	in any town before.  Carts, carriages everywhere, the most astonishing
36	miscellany of conveyances and horseflesh.  The respectable inhabitants
36	of the place, men in golf and boating costumes, wives prettily
36	dressed, were packing, river-side loafers energetically helping,
36	children excited, and, for the most part, highly delighted at this
36	astonishing variation of their Sunday experiences.  In the midst of it
36	all the worthy vicar was very pluckily holding an early celebration,
36	and his bell was jangling out above the excitement.
36	
36	I and the artilleryman, seated on the step of the drinking
36	fountain, made a very passable meal upon what we had brought with
36	us. Patrols of soldiers--here no longer hussars, but grenadiers in
36	white--were warning people to move now or to take refuge in their
36	cellars as soon as the firing began.  We saw as we crossed the
36	railway bridge that a growing crowd of people had assembled in and
36	about the railway station, and the swarming platform was piled with
36	boxes and packages. The ordinary traffic had been stopped, I believe,
36	in order to allow of the passage of troops and guns to Chertsey, and
36	I have heard since that a savage struggle occurred for places in the
36	special trains that were put on at a later hour.
36	
36	We remained at Weybridge until midday, and at that hour we found
36	ourselves at the place near Shepperton Lock where the Wey and Thames
36	join.  Part of the time we spent helping two old women to pack a
36	little cart.  The Wey has a treble mouth, and at this point boats are
36	to be hired, and there was a ferry across the river.  On the
36	Shepperton side was an inn with a lawn, and beyond that the tower of
36	Shepperton Church--it has been replaced by a spire--rose above the
36	trees.
36	
36	Here we found an excited and noisy crowd of fugitives.  As yet the
36	flight had not grown to a panic, but there were already far more
36	people than all the boats going to and fro could enable to cross.
36	People came panting along under heavy burdens; one husband and wife
36	were even carrying a small outhouse door between them, with some of
36	their household goods piled thereon.  One man told us he meant to try
36	to get away from Shepperton station.
36	
36	There was a lot of shouting, and one man was even jesting.  The idea
36	people seemed to have here was that the Martians were simply
36	formidable human beings, who might attack and sack the town, to be
36	certainly destroyed in the end.  Every now and then people would
36	glance nervously across the Wey, at the meadows towards Chertsey, but
36	everything over there was still.
36	
36	Across the Thames, except just where the boats landed, everything
36	was quiet, in vivid contrast with the Surrey side.  The people who
36	landed there from the boats went tramping off down the lane.  The big
36	ferryboat had just made a journey.  Three or four soldiers stood on
36	the lawn of the inn, staring and jesting at the fugitives, without
36	offering to help.  The inn was closed, as it was now within prohibited
36	hours.
36	
36	""What's that?"" cried a boatman, and ""Shut up, you fool!"" said a man
36	near me to a yelping dog.  Then the sound came again, this time from
36	the direction of Chertsey, a muffled thud--the sound of a gun.
36	
36	The fighting was beginning.  Almost immediately unseen batteries
36	across the river to our right, unseen because of the trees, took up
36	the chorus, firing heavily one after the other.  A woman screamed.
36	Everyone stood arrested by the sudden stir of battle, near us and yet
36	invisible to us.  Nothing was to be seen save flat meadows, cows
36	feeding unconcernedly for the most part, and silvery pollard willows
36	motionless in the warm sunlight.
36	
36	""The sojers'll stop 'em,"" said a woman beside me, doubtfully.  A
36	haziness rose over the treetops.
36	
36	Then suddenly we saw a rush of smoke far away up the river, a puff
36	of smoke that jerked up into the air and hung; and forthwith the
36	ground heaved under foot and a heavy explosion shook the air, smashing
36	two or three windows in the houses near, and leaving us astonished.
36	
36	""Here they are!"" shouted a man in a blue jersey.  ""Yonder! D'yer
36	see them?  Yonder!""
36	
36	Quickly, one after the other, one, two, three, four of the armoured
36	Martians appeared, far away over the little trees, across the flat
36	meadows that stretched towards Chertsey, and striding hurriedly
36	towards the river.  Little cowled figures they seemed at first, going
36	with a rolling motion and as fast as flying birds.
36	
36	Then, advancing obliquely towards us, came a fifth.  Their armoured
36	bodies glittered in the sun as they swept swiftly forward upon the
36	guns, growing rapidly larger as they drew nearer.  One on the extreme
36	left, the remotest that is, flourished a huge case high in the air,
36	and the ghostly, terrible Heat-Ray I had already seen on Friday night
36	smote towards Chertsey, and struck the town.
36	
36	At sight of these strange, swift, and terrible creatures the crowd
36	near the water's edge seemed to me to be for a moment horror-struck.
36	There was no screaming or shouting, but a silence.  Then a hoarse
36	murmur and a movement of feet--a splashing from the water.  A man, too
36	frightened to drop the portmanteau he carried on his shoulder, swung
36	round and sent me staggering with a blow from the corner of his
36	burden.  A woman thrust at me with her hand and rushed past me.  I
36	turned with the rush of the people, but I was not too terrified for
36	thought.  The terrible Heat-Ray was in my mind.  To get under water!
36	That was it!
36	
36	""Get under water!"" I shouted, unheeded.
36	
36	I faced about again, and rushed towards the approaching Martian,
36	rushed right down the gravelly beach and headlong into the water.
36	Others did the same.  A boatload of people putting back came leaping
36	out as I rushed past.  The stones under my feet were muddy and
36	slippery, and the river was so low that I ran perhaps twenty feet
36	scarcely waist-deep.  Then, as the Martian towered overhead scarcely
36	a couple of hundred yards away, I flung myself forward under the
36	surface.  The splashes of the people in the boats leaping into the
36	river sounded like thunderclaps in my ears.  People were landing
36	hastily on both sides of the river.  But the Martian machine took no
36	more notice for the moment of the people running this way and that
36	than a man would of the confusion of ants in a nest against which his
36	foot has kicked.  When, half suffocated, I raised my head above water,
36	the Martian's hood pointed at the batteries that were still firing
36	across the river, and as it advanced it swung loose what must have
36	been the generator of the Heat-Ray.
36	
36	In another moment it was on the bank, and in a stride wading
36	halfway across.  The knees of its foremost legs bent at the farther
36	bank, and in another moment it had raised itself to its full height
36	again, close to the village of Shepperton.  Forthwith the six guns
36	which, unknown to anyone on the right bank, had been hidden behind the
36	outskirts of that village, fired simultaneously.  The sudden near
36	concussion, the last close upon the first, made my heart jump.  The
36	monster was already raising the case generating the Heat-Ray as the
36	first shell burst six yards above the hood.
36	
36	I gave a cry of astonishment.  I saw and thought nothing of the
36	other four Martian monsters; my attention was riveted upon the nearer
36	incident.  Simultaneously two other shells burst in the air near the
36	body as the hood twisted round in time to receive, but not in time to
36	dodge, the fourth shell.
36	
36	The shell burst clean in the face of the Thing.  The hood bulged,
36	flashed, was whirled off in a dozen tattered fragments of red flesh
36	and glittering metal.
36	
36	""Hit!"" shouted I, with something between a scream and a cheer.
36	
36	I heard answering shouts from the people in the water about me.  I
36	could have leaped out of the water with that momentary exultation.
36	
36	The decapitated colossus reeled like a drunken giant; but it did
36	not fall over.  It recovered its balance by a miracle, and, no longer
36	heeding its steps and with the camera that fired the Heat-Ray now
36	rigidly upheld, it reeled swiftly upon Shepperton.  The living
36	intelligence, the Martian within the hood, was slain and splashed to
36	the four winds of heaven, and the Thing was now but a mere intricate
36	device of metal whirling to destruction.  It drove along in a straight
36	line, incapable of guidance.  It struck the tower of Shepperton
36	Church, smashing it down as the impact of a battering ram might have
36	done, swerved aside, blundered on and collapsed with tremendous force
36	into the river out of my sight.
36	
36	A violent explosion shook the air, and a spout of water, steam,
36	mud, and shattered metal shot far up into the sky.  As the camera of
36	the Heat-Ray hit the water, the latter had immediately flashed into
36	steam.  In another moment a huge wave, like a muddy tidal bore but
36	almost scaldingly hot, came sweeping round the bend upstream.  I saw
36	people struggling shorewards, and heard their screaming and shouting
36	faintly above the seething and roar of the Martian's collapse.
36	
36	For a moment I heeded nothing of the heat, forgot the patent need
36	of self-preservation.  I splashed through the tumultuous water,
36	pushing aside a man in black to do so, until I could see round the
36	bend.  Half a dozen deserted boats pitched aimlessly upon the
36	confusion of the waves.  The fallen Martian came into sight
36	downstream, lying across the river, and for the most part submerged.
36	
36	Thick clouds of steam were pouring off the wreckage, and through
36	the tumultuously whirling wisps I could see, intermittently and
36	vaguely, the gigantic limbs churning the water and flinging a splash
36	and spray of mud and froth into the air.  The tentacles swayed and
36	struck like living arms, and, save for the helpless purposelessness of
36	these movements, it was as if some wounded thing were struggling for
36	its life amid the waves.  Enormous quantities of a ruddy-brown fluid
36	were spurting up in noisy jets out of the machine.
36	
36	My attention was diverted from this death flurry by a furious
36	yelling, like that of the thing called a siren in our manufacturing
36	towns.  A man, knee-deep near the towing path, shouted inaudibly to me
36	and pointed.  Looking back, I saw the other Martians advancing with
36	gigantic strides down the riverbank from the direction of Chertsey.
36	The Shepperton guns spoke this time unavailingly.
36	
36	At that I ducked at once under water, and, holding my breath until
36	movement was an agony, blundered painfully ahead under the surface as
36	long as I could.  The water was in a tumult about me, and rapidly
36	growing hotter.
36	
36	When for a moment I raised my head to take breath and throw the
36	hair and water from my eyes, the steam was rising in a whirling white
36	fog that at first hid the Martians altogether.  The noise was
36	deafening.  Then I saw them dimly, colossal figures of grey, magnified
36	by the mist.  They had passed by me, and two were stooping over the
36	frothing, tumultuous ruins of their comrade.
36	
36	The third and fourth stood beside him in the water, one perhaps two
36	hundred yards from me, the other towards Laleham.  The generators of
36	the Heat-Rays waved high, and the hissing beams smote down this way
36	and that.
36	
36	The air was full of sound, a deafening and confusing conflict of
36	noises--the clangorous din of the Martians, the crash of falling
36	houses, the thud of trees, fences, sheds flashing into flame, and the
36	crackling and roaring of fire.  Dense black smoke was leaping up to
36	mingle with the steam from the river, and as the Heat-Ray went to and
36	fro over Weybridge its impact was marked by flashes of incandescent
36	white, that gave place at once to a smoky dance of lurid flames.  The
36	nearer houses still stood intact, awaiting their fate, shadowy, faint
36	and pallid in the steam, with the fire behind them going to and fro.
36	
36	For a moment perhaps I stood there, breast-high in the almost
36	boiling water, dumbfounded at my position, hopeless of escape.  Through
36	the reek I could see the people who had been with me in the river
36	scrambling out of the water through the reeds, like little frogs
36	hurrying through grass from the advance of a man, or running to and
36	fro in utter dismay on the towing path.
36	
36	Then suddenly the white flashes of the Heat-Ray came leaping
36	towards me.  The houses caved in as they dissolved at its touch, and
36	darted out flames; the trees changed to fire with a roar.  The Ray
36	flickered up and down the towing path, licking off the people who ran
36	this way and that, and came down to the water's edge not fifty yards
36	from where I stood.  It swept across the river to Shepperton, and the
36	water in its track rose in a boiling weal crested with steam.  I
36	turned shoreward.
36	
36	In another moment the huge wave, well-nigh at the boiling-point had
36	rushed upon me.  I screamed aloud, and scalded, half blinded,
36	agonised, I staggered through the leaping, hissing water towards the
36	shore.  Had my foot stumbled, it would have been the end.  I fell
36	helplessly, in full sight of the Martians, upon the broad, bare
36	gravelly spit that runs down to mark the angle of the Wey and Thames.
36	I expected nothing but death.
36	
36	I have a dim memory of the foot of a Martian coming down within a
36	score of yards of my head, driving straight into the loose gravel,
36	whirling it this way and that and lifting again; of a long suspense,
36	and then of the four carrying the debris of their comrade between
36	them, now clear and then presently faint through a veil of smoke,
36	receding interminably, as it seemed to me, across a vast space of
36	river and meadow.  And then, very slowly, I realised that by a miracle
36	I had escaped.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER THIRTEEN
36	
36	HOW I FELL IN WITH THE CURATE
36	
36	
36	After getting this sudden lesson in the power of terrestrial
36	weapons, the Martians retreated to their original position upon
36	Horsell Common; and in their haste, and encumbered with the debris of
36	their smashed companion, they no doubt overlooked many such a stray
36	and negligible victim as myself.  Had they left their comrade and
36	pushed on forthwith, there was nothing at that time between them and
36	London but batteries of twelve-pounder guns, and they would certainly
36	have reached the capital in advance of the tidings of their approach;
36	as sudden, dreadful, and destructive their advent would have been as
36	the earthquake that destroyed Lisbon a century ago.
36	
36	But they were in no hurry.  Cylinder followed cylinder on its
36	interplanetary flight; every twenty-four hours brought them
36	reinforcement.  And meanwhile the military and naval authorities, now
36	fully alive to the tremendous power of their antagonists, worked with
36	furious energy.  Every minute a fresh gun came into position until,
36	before twilight, every copse, every row of suburban villas on the
36	hilly slopes about Kingston and Richmond, masked an expectant black
36	muzzle.  And through the charred and desolated area--perhaps twenty
36	square miles altogether--that encircled the Martian encampment on
36	Horsell Common, through charred and ruined villages among the green
36	trees, through the blackened and smoking arcades that had been but a
36	day ago pine spinneys, crawled the devoted scouts with the heliographs
36	that were presently to warn the gunners of the Martian approach.  But
36	the Martians now understood our command of artillery and the danger of
36	human proximity, and not a man ventured within a mile of either
36	cylinder, save at the price of his life.
36	
36	It would seem that these giants spent the earlier part of the
36	afternoon in going to and fro, transferring everything from the second
36	and third cylinders--the second in Addlestone Golf Links and the third
36	at Pyrford--to their original pit on Horsell Common.  Over that, above
36	the blackened heather and ruined buildings that stretched far and
36	wide, stood one as sentinel, while the rest abandoned their vast
36	fighting-machines and descended into the pit.  They were hard at work
36	there far into the night, and the towering pillar of dense green smoke
36	that rose therefrom could be seen from the hills about Merrow, and
36	even, it is said, from Banstead and Epsom Downs.
36	
36	And while the Martians behind me were thus preparing for their next
36	sally, and in front of me Humanity gathered for the battle, I made my
36	way with infinite pains and labour from the fire and smoke of burning
36	Weybridge towards London.
36	
36	I saw an abandoned boat, very small and remote, drifting down-stream;
36	and throwing off the most of my sodden clothes, I went after it,
36	gained it, and so escaped out of that destruction.  There were no
36	oars in the boat, but I contrived to paddle, as well as my parboiled
36	hands would allow, down the river towards Halliford and Walton, going
36	very tediously and continually looking behind me, as you may well
36	understand.  I followed the river, because I considered that the water
36	gave me my best chance of escape should these giants return.
36	
36	The hot water from the Martian's overthrow drifted downstream with
36	me, so that for the best part of a mile I could see little of either
36	bank.  Once, however, I made out a string of black figures hurrying
36	across the meadows from the direction of Weybridge.  Halliford, it
36	seemed, was deserted, and several of the houses facing the river were
36	on fire.  It was strange to see the place quite tranquil, quite
36	desolate under the hot blue sky, with the smoke and little threads of
36	flame going straight up into the heat of the afternoon.  Never before
36	had I seen houses burning without the accompaniment of an obstructive
36	crowd.  A little farther on the dry reeds up the bank were smoking and
36	glowing, and a line of fire inland was marching steadily across a late
36	field of hay.
36	
36	For a long time I drifted, so painful and weary was I after the
36	violence I had been through, and so intense the heat upon the water.
36	Then my fears got the better of me again, and I resumed my paddling.
36	The sun scorched my bare back.  At last, as the bridge at Walton was
36	coming into sight round the bend, my fever and faintness overcame my
36	fears, and I landed on the Middlesex bank and lay down, deadly sick,
36	amid the long grass.  I suppose the time was then about four or five
36	o'clock.  I got up presently, walked perhaps half a mile without
36	meeting a soul, and then lay down again in the shadow of a hedge.  I
36	seem to remember talking, wanderingly, to myself during that last
36	spurt.  I was also very thirsty, and bitterly regretful I had drunk no
36	more water.  It is a curious thing that I felt angry with my wife; I
36	cannot account for it, but my impotent desire to reach Leatherhead
36	worried me excessively.
36	
36	I do not clearly remember the arrival of the curate, so that probably
36	I dozed.  I became aware of him as a seated figure in soot-smudged
36	shirt sleeves, and with his upturned, clean-shaven face staring at
36	a faint flickering that danced over the sky.  The sky was what is
36	called a mackerel sky--rows and rows of faint down-plumes of
36	cloud, just tinted with the midsummer sunset.
36	
36	I sat up, and at the rustle of my motion he looked at me quickly.
36	
36	""Have you any water?"" I asked abruptly.
36	
36	He shook his head.
36	
36	""You have been asking for water for the last hour,"" he said.
36	
36	For a moment we were silent, taking stock of each other.  I
36	dare say he found me a strange enough figure, naked, save for my
36	water-soaked trousers and socks, scalded, and my face and shoulders
36	blackened by the smoke.  His face was a fair weakness, his chin
36	retreated, and his hair lay in crisp, almost flaxen curls on his low
36	forehead; his eyes were rather large, pale blue, and blankly staring.
36	He spoke abruptly, looking vacantly away from me.
36	
36	""What does it mean?"" he said.  ""What do these things mean?""
36	
36	I stared at him and made no answer.
36	
36	He extended a thin white hand and spoke in almost a complaining
36	tone.
36	
36	""Why are these things permitted?  What sins have we done?  The
36	morning service was over, I was walking through the roads to clear my
36	brain for the afternoon, and then--fire, earthquake, death!  As if it
36	were Sodom and Gomorrah!  All our work undone, all the work---- What
36	are these Martians?""
36	
36	""What are we?"" I answered, clearing my throat.
36	
36	He gripped his knees and turned to look at me again.  For half a
36	minute, perhaps, he stared silently.
36	
36	""I was walking through the roads to clear my brain,"" he said.  ""And
36	suddenly--fire, earthquake, death!""
36	
36	He relapsed into silence, with his chin now sunken almost to his
36	knees.
36	
36	Presently he began waving his hand.
36	
36	""All the work--all the Sunday schools--What have we done--what has
36	Weybridge done?  Everything gone--everything destroyed.  The church!
36	We rebuilt it only three years ago.  Gone!  Swept out of existence!
36	Why?""
36	
36	Another pause, and he broke out again like one demented.
36	
36	""The smoke of her burning goeth up for ever and ever!"" he shouted.
36	
36	His eyes flamed, and he pointed a lean finger in the direction of
36	Weybridge.
36	
36	By this time I was beginning to take his measure.  The tremendous
36	tragedy in which he had been involved--it was evident he was a
36	fugitive from Weybridge--had driven him to the very verge of his
36	reason.
36	
36	""Are we far from Sunbury?"" I said, in a matter-of-fact tone.
36	
36	""What are we to do?"" he asked.  ""Are these creatures everywhere?
36	Has the earth been given over to them?""
36	
36	""Are we far from Sunbury?""
36	
36	""Only this morning I officiated at early celebration----""
36	
36	""Things have changed,"" I said, quietly.  ""You must keep your head.
36	There is still hope.""
36	
36	""Hope!""
36	
36	""Yes.  Plentiful hope--for all this destruction!""
36	
36	I began to explain my view of our position.  He listened at first,
36	but as I went on the interest dawning in his eyes gave place to their
36	former stare, and his regard wandered from me.
36	
36	""This must be the beginning of the end,"" he said, interrupting me.
36	""The end!  The great and terrible day of the Lord!  When men shall
36	call upon the mountains and the rocks to fall upon them and hide
36	them--hide them from the face of Him that sitteth upon the throne!""
36
