36	I began to understand the position.  I ceased my laboured
36	reasoning, struggled to my feet, and, standing over him, laid my hand
36	on his shoulder.
36	
36	""Be a man!"" said I.  ""You are scared out of your wits!  What good
36	is religion if it collapses under calamity?  Think of what earthquakes
36	and floods, wars and volcanoes, have done before to men!  Did you
36	think God had exempted Weybridge?  He is not an insurance agent.""
36	
36	For a time he sat in blank silence.
36	
36	""But how can we escape?"" he asked, suddenly.  ""They are
36	invulnerable, they are pitiless.""
36	
36	""Neither the one nor, perhaps, the other,"" I answered. ""And the
36	mightier they are the more sane and wary should we be.  One of them
36	was killed yonder not three hours ago.""
36	
36	""Killed!"" he said, staring about him.  ""How can God's ministers be
36	killed?""
36	
36	""I saw it happen."" I proceeded to tell him.  ""We have chanced to
36	come in for the thick of it,"" said I, ""and that is all.""
36	
36	""What is that flicker in the sky?"" he asked abruptly.
36	
36	I told him it was the heliograph signalling--that it was the sign
36	of human help and effort in the sky.
36	
36	""We are in the midst of it,"" I said, ""quiet as it is.  That flicker
36	in the sky tells of the gathering storm.  Yonder, I take it are the
36	Martians, and Londonward, where those hills rise about Richmond and
36	Kingston and the trees give cover, earthworks are being thrown up and
36	guns are being placed.  Presently the Martians will be coming this way
36	again.""
36	
36	And even as I spoke he sprang to his feet and stopped me by a
36	gesture.
36	
36	""Listen!"" he said.
36	
36	From beyond the low hills across the water came the dull resonance
36	of distant guns and a remote weird crying.  Then everything was still.
36	A cockchafer came droning over the hedge and past us.  High in the
36	west the crescent moon hung faint and pale above the smoke of
36	Weybridge and Shepperton and the hot, still splendour of the sunset.
36	
36	""We had better follow this path,"" I said, ""northward.""
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER FOURTEEN
36	
36	IN LONDON
36	
36	
36	My younger brother was in London when the Martians fell at Woking.
36	He was a medical student working for an imminent examination, and he
36	heard nothing of the arrival until Saturday morning.  The morning
36	papers on Saturday contained, in addition to lengthy special articles
36	on the planet Mars, on life in the planets, and so forth, a brief and
36	vaguely worded telegram, all the more striking for its brevity.
36	
36	The Martians, alarmed by the approach of a crowd, had killed a
36	number of people with a quick-firing gun, so the story ran.  The
36	telegram concluded with the words: ""Formidable as they seem to be, the
36	Martians have not moved from the pit into which they have fallen, and,
36	indeed, seem incapable of doing so.  Probably this is due to the
36	relative strength of the earth's gravitational energy.""  On that last
36	text their leader-writer expanded very comfortingly.
36	
36	Of course all the students in the crammer's biology class, to which
36	my brother went that day, were intensely interested, but there were no
36	signs of any unusual excitement in the streets.  The afternoon papers
36	puffed scraps of news under big headlines.  They had nothing to tell
36	beyond the movements of troops about the common, and the burning of
36	the pine woods between Woking and Weybridge, until eight.  Then the
36	_St. James's Gazette_, in an extra-special edition, announced the bare
36	fact of the interruption of telegraphic communication.  This was
36	thought to be due to the falling of burning pine trees across the
36	line.  Nothing more of the fighting was known that night, the night of
36	my drive to Leatherhead and back.
36	
36	My brother felt no anxiety about us, as he knew from the
36	description in the papers that the cylinder was a good two miles from
36	my house.  He made up his mind to run down that night to me, in order,
36	as he says, to see the Things before they were killed.  He dispatched
36	a telegram, which never reached me, about four o'clock, and spent the
36	evening at a music hall.
36	
36	In London, also, on Saturday night there was a thunderstorm, and my
36	brother reached Waterloo in a cab.  On the platform from which the
36	midnight train usually starts he learned, after some waiting, that an
36	accident prevented trains from reaching Woking that night.  The nature
36	of the accident he could not ascertain; indeed, the railway
36	authorities did not clearly know at that time.  There was very little
36	excitement in the station, as the officials, failing to realise that
36	anything further than a breakdown between Byfleet and Woking junction
36	had occurred, were running the theatre trains which usually passed
36	through Woking round by Virginia Water or Guildford.  They were busy
36	making the necessary arrangements to alter the route of the
36	Southampton and Portsmouth Sunday League excursions.  A nocturnal
36	newspaper reporter, mistaking my brother for the traffic manager, to
36	whom he bears a slight resemblance, waylaid and tried to interview
36	him.  Few people, excepting the railway officials, connected the
36	breakdown with the Martians.
36	
36	I have read, in another account of these events, that on Sunday
36	morning ""all London was electrified by the news from Woking.""  As a
36	matter of fact, there was nothing to justify that very extravagant
36	phrase.  Plenty of Londoners did not hear of the Martians until the
36	panic of Monday morning.  Those who did took some time to realise all
36	that the hastily worded telegrams in the Sunday papers conveyed.  The
36	majority of people in London do not read Sunday papers.
36	
36	The habit of personal security, moreover, is so deeply fixed in the
36	Londoner's mind, and startling intelligence so much a matter of course
36	in the papers, that they could read without any personal tremors:
36	""About seven o'clock last night the Martians came out of the cylinder,
36	and, moving about under an armour of metallic shields, have completely
36	wrecked Woking station with the adjacent houses, and massacred an
36	entire battalion of the Cardigan Regiment.  No details are known.
36	Maxims have been absolutely useless against their armour; the field
36	guns have been disabled by them.  Flying hussars have been galloping
36	into Chertsey.  The Martians appear to be moving slowly towards
36	Chertsey or Windsor.  Great anxiety prevails in West Surrey, and
36	earthworks are being thrown up to check the advance Londonward.""  That
36	was how the Sunday _Sun_ put it, and a clever and remarkably prompt
36	""handbook"" article in the _Referee_ compared the affair to a menagerie
36	suddenly let loose in a village.
36	
36	No one in London knew positively of the nature of the armoured
36	Martians, and there was still a fixed idea that these monsters must be
36	sluggish: ""crawling,"" ""creeping painfully""--such expressions occurred
36	in almost all the earlier reports.  None of the telegrams could have
36	been written by an eyewitness of their advance.  The Sunday papers
36	printed separate editions as further news came to hand, some even in
36	default of it.  But there was practically nothing more to tell people
36	until late in the afternoon, when the authorities gave the press
36	agencies the news in their possession.  It was stated that the people
36	of Walton and Weybridge, and all the district were pouring along the
36	roads Londonward, and that was all.
36	
36	My brother went to church at the Foundling Hospital in the morning,
36	still in ignorance of what had happened on the previous night.  There
36	he heard allusions made to the invasion, and a special prayer for
36	peace.  Coming out, he bought a _Referee_.  He became alarmed at the
36	news in this, and went again to Waterloo station to find out if
36	communication were restored.  The omnibuses, carriages, cyclists, and
36	innumerable people walking in their best clothes seemed scarcely
36	affected by the strange intelligence that the news venders were
36	disseminating.  People were interested, or, if alarmed, alarmed only
36	on account of the local residents.  At the station he heard for the
36	first time that the Windsor and Chertsey lines were now interrupted.
36	The porters told him that several remarkable telegrams had been
36	received in the morning from Byfleet and Chertsey stations, but that
36	these had abruptly ceased.  My brother could get very little precise
36	detail out of them.
36	
36	""There's fighting going on about Weybridge"" was the extent of their
36	information.
36	
36	The train service was now very much disorganised.  Quite a number
36	of people who had been expecting friends from places on the
36	South-Western network were standing about the station.  One
36	grey-headed old gentleman came and abused the South-Western Company
36	bitterly to my brother.  ""It wants showing up,"" he said.
36	
36	One or two trains came in from Richmond, Putney, and Kingston,
36	containing people who had gone out for a day's boating and found the
36	locks closed and a feeling of panic in the air.  A man in a blue and
36	white blazer addressed my brother, full of strange tidings.
36	
36	""There's hosts of people driving into Kingston in traps and carts
36	and things, with boxes of valuables and all that,"" he said.  ""They
36	come from Molesey and Weybridge and Walton, and they say there's been
36	guns heard at Chertsey, heavy firing, and that mounted soldiers have
36	told them to get off at once because the Martians are coming.  We
36	heard guns firing at Hampton Court station, but we thought it was
36	thunder.  What the dickens does it all mean?  The Martians can't get
36	out of their pit, can they?""
36	
36	My brother could not tell him.
36	
36	Afterwards he found that the vague feeling of alarm had spread to
36	the clients of the underground railway, and that the Sunday
36	excursionists began to return from all over the South-Western
36	""lung""--Barnes, Wimbledon, Richmond Park, Kew, and so forth--at
36	unnaturally early hours; but not a soul had anything more than vague
36	hearsay to tell of.  Everyone connected with the terminus seemed
36	ill-tempered.
36	
36	About five o'clock the gathering crowd in the station was immensely
36	excited by the opening of the line of communication, which is almost
36	invariably closed, between the South-Eastern and the South-Western
36	stations, and the passage of carriage trucks bearing huge guns and
36	carriages crammed with soldiers.  These were the guns that were
36	brought up from Woolwich and Chatham to cover Kingston.  There was
36	an exchange of pleasantries: ""You'll get eaten!""  ""We're the
36	beast-tamers!"" and so forth.  A little while after that a squad of
36	police came into the station and began to clear the public off the
36	platforms, and my brother went out into the street again.
36	
36	The church bells were ringing for evensong, and a squad of
36	Salvation Army lassies came singing down Waterloo Road.  On the bridge
36	a number of loafers were watching a curious brown scum that came
36	drifting down the stream in patches.  The sun was just setting, and the
36	Clock Tower and the Houses of Parliament rose against one of the most
36	peaceful skies it is possible to imagine, a sky of gold, barred with
36	long transverse stripes of reddish-purple cloud.  There was talk of a
36	floating body.  One of the men there, a reservist he said he was, told
36	my brother he had seen the heliograph flickering in the west.
36	
36	In Wellington Street my brother met a couple of sturdy roughs who
36	had just been rushed out of Fleet Street with still-wet newspapers and
36	staring placards.  ""Dreadful catastrophe!"" they bawled one to the
36	other down Wellington Street.  ""Fighting at Weybridge!  Full
36	description!  Repulse of the Martians! London in Danger!""  He had to
36	give threepence for a copy of that paper.
36	
36	Then it was, and then only, that he realised something of the full
36	power and terror of these monsters.  He learned that they were not
36	merely a handful of small sluggish creatures, but that they were minds
36	swaying vast mechanical bodies; and that they could move swiftly and
36	smite with such power that even the mightiest guns could not stand
36	against them.
36	
36	They were described as ""vast spiderlike machines, nearly a hundred
36	feet high, capable of the speed of an express train, and able to shoot
36	out a beam of intense heat.""  Masked batteries, chiefly of field guns,
36	had been planted in the country about Horsell Common, and especially
36	between the Woking district and London.  Five of the machines had been
36	seen moving towards the Thames, and one, by a happy chance, had been
36	destroyed.  In the other cases the shells had missed, and the
36	batteries had been at once annihilated by the Heat-Rays.  Heavy
36	losses of soldiers were mentioned, but the tone of the dispatch was
36	optimistic.
36	
36	The Martians had been repulsed; they were not invulnerable.  They
36	had retreated to their triangle of cylinders again, in the circle
36	about Woking.  Signallers with heliographs were pushing forward upon
36	them from all sides.  Guns were in rapid transit from Windsor,
36	Portsmouth, Aldershot, Woolwich--even from the north; among others,
36	long wire-guns of ninety-five tons from Woolwich.  Altogether one
36	hundred and sixteen were in position or being hastily placed, chiefly
36	covering London.  Never before in England had there been such a vast
36	or rapid concentration of military material.
36	
36	Any further cylinders that fell, it was hoped, could be destroyed
36	at once by high explosives, which were being rapidly manufactured and
36	distributed.  No doubt, ran the report, the situation was of the
36	strangest and gravest description, but the public was exhorted to
36	avoid and discourage panic.  No doubt the Martians were strange and
36	terrible in the extreme, but at the outside there could not be more
36	than twenty of them against our millions.
36	
36	The authorities had reason to suppose, from the size of the
36	cylinders, that at the outside there could not be more than five in
36	each cylinder--fifteen altogether.  And one at least was disposed
36	of--perhaps more.  The public would be fairly warned of the approach
36	of danger, and elaborate measures were being taken for the protection
36	of the people in the threatened southwestern suburbs.  And so, with
36	reiterated assurances of the safety of London and the ability of the
36	authorities to cope with the difficulty, this quasi-proclamation
36	closed.
36	
36	This was printed in enormous type on paper so fresh that it was
36	still wet, and there had been no time to add a word of comment.  It
36	was curious, my brother said, to see how ruthlessly the usual contents
36	of the paper had been hacked and taken out to give this place.
36	
36	All down Wellington Street people could be seen fluttering out the
36	pink sheets and reading, and the Strand was suddenly noisy with the
36	voices of an army of hawkers following these pioneers.  Men came
36	scrambling off buses to secure copies.  Certainly this news excited
36	people intensely, whatever their previous apathy.  The shutters of a
36	map shop in the Strand were being taken down, my brother said, and a
36	man in his Sunday raiment, lemon-yellow gloves even, was visible
36	inside the window hastily fastening maps of Surrey to the glass.
36	
36	Going on along the Strand to Trafalgar Square, the paper in his
36	hand, my brother saw some of the fugitives from West Surrey.  There
36	was a man with his wife and two boys and some articles of furniture in
36	a cart such as greengrocers use.  He was driving from the direction of
36	Westminster Bridge; and close behind him came a hay waggon with five
36	or six respectable-looking people in it, and some boxes and bundles.
36	The faces of these people were haggard, and their entire appearance
36	contrasted conspicuously with the Sabbath-best appearance of the
36	people on the omnibuses.  People in fashionable clothing peeped at
36	them out of cabs.  They stopped at the Square as if undecided which
36	way to take, and finally turned eastward along the Strand.  Some way
36	behind these came a man in workday clothes, riding one of those
36	old-fashioned tricycles with a small front wheel.  He was dirty and
36	white in the face.
36	
36	My brother turned down towards Victoria, and met a number of such
36	people.  He had a vague idea that he might see something of me.  He
36	noticed an unusual number of police regulating the traffic.  Some of
36	the refugees were exchanging news with the people on the omnibuses.
36	One was professing to have seen the Martians.  ""Boilers on stilts, I
36	tell you, striding along like men.""  Most of them were excited and
36	animated by their strange experience.
36	
36	Beyond Victoria the public-houses were doing a lively trade with
36	these arrivals.  At all the street corners groups of people were
36	reading papers, talking excitedly, or staring at these unusual Sunday
36	visitors.  They seemed to increase as night drew on, until at last the
36	roads, my brother said, were like Epsom High Street on a Derby Day.  My
36	brother addressed several of these fugitives and got unsatisfactory
36	answers from most.
36	
36	None of them could tell him any news of Woking except one man, who
36	assured him that Woking had been entirely destroyed on the previous
36	night.
36	
36	""I come from Byfleet,"" he said; ""man on a bicycle came through the
36	place in the early morning, and ran from door to door warning us to
36	come away.  Then came soldiers.  We went out to look, and there were
36	clouds of smoke to the south--nothing but smoke, and not a soul coming
36	that way.  Then we heard the guns at Chertsey, and folks coming from
36	Weybridge.  So I've locked up my house and come on.""
36	
36	At the time there was a strong feeling in the streets that the
36	authorities were to blame for their incapacity to dispose of the
36	invaders without all this inconvenience.
36	
36	About eight o'clock a noise of heavy firing was distinctly audible
36	all over the south of London.  My brother could not hear it for the
36	traffic in the main thoroughfares, but by striking through the quiet
36	back streets to the river he was able to distinguish it quite plainly.
36	
36	He walked from Westminster to his apartments near Regent's Park,
36	about two.  He was now very anxious on my account, and disturbed at
36	the evident magnitude of the trouble.  His mind was inclined to run,
36	even as mine had run on Saturday, on military details.  He thought of
36	all those silent, expectant guns, of the suddenly nomadic countryside;
36	he tried to imagine ""boilers on stilts"" a hundred feet high.
36	
36	There were one or two cartloads of refugees passing along Oxford
36	Street, and several in the Marylebone Road, but so slowly was the news
36	spreading that Regent Street and Portland Place were full of their
36	usual Sunday-night promenaders, albeit they talked in groups, and
36	along the edge of Regent's Park there were as many silent couples
36	""walking out"" together under the scattered gas lamps as ever there had
36	been.  The night was warm and still, and a little oppressive; the
36	sound of guns continued intermittently, and after midnight there
36	seemed to be sheet lightning in the south.
36	
36	He read and re-read the paper, fearing the worst had happened to me.
36	He was restless, and after supper prowled out again aimlessly.  He
36	returned and tried in vain to divert his attention to his examination
36	notes.  He went to bed a little after midnight, and was awakened from
36	lurid dreams in the small hours of Monday by the sound of door
36	knockers, feet running in the street, distant drumming, and a clamour
36	of bells.  Red reflections danced on the ceiling.  For a moment he lay
36	astonished, wondering whether day had come or the world gone mad.
36	Then he jumped out of bed and ran to the window.
36	
36	His room was an attic and as he thrust his head out, up and down
36	the street there were a dozen echoes to the noise of his window sash,
36	and heads in every kind of night disarray appeared.  Enquiries were
36	being shouted.  ""They are coming!"" bawled a policeman, hammering at
36	the door; ""the Martians are coming!"" and hurried to the next door.
36	
36	The sound of drumming and trumpeting came from the Albany Street
36	Barracks, and every church within earshot was hard at work killing
36	sleep with a vehement disorderly tocsin.  There was a noise of doors
36	opening, and window after window in the houses opposite flashed from
36	darkness into yellow illumination.
36	
36	Up the street came galloping a closed carriage, bursting abruptly
36	into noise at the corner, rising to a clattering climax under the
36	window, and dying away slowly in the distance.  Close on the rear of
36	this came a couple of cabs, the forerunners of a long procession of
36	flying vehicles, going for the most part to Chalk Farm station, where
36	the North-Western special trains were loading up, instead of coming
36	down the gradient into Euston.
36	
36	For a long time my brother stared out of the window in blank
36	astonishment, watching the policemen hammering at door after door, and
36	delivering their incomprehensible message.  Then the door behind him
36	opened, and the man who lodged across the landing came in, dressed
36	only in shirt, trousers, and slippers, his braces loose about his
36	waist, his hair disordered from his pillow.
36	
36	""What the devil is it?"" he asked.  ""A fire?  What a devil of a
36	row!""
36	
36	They both craned their heads out of the window, straining to hear
36	what the policemen were shouting.  People were coming out of the side
36	streets, and standing in groups at the corners talking.
36	
36	""What the devil is it all about?"" said my brother's fellow lodger.
36	
36	My brother answered him vaguely and began to dress, running with
36	each garment to the window in order to miss nothing of the growing
36	excitement.  And presently men selling unnaturally early newspapers
36	came bawling into the street:
36	
36	""London in danger of suffocation!  The Kingston and Richmond
36	defences forced!  Fearful massacres in the Thames Valley!""
36	
36	And all about him--in the rooms below, in the houses on each side
36	and across the road, and behind in the Park Terraces and in the
36	hundred other streets of that part of Marylebone, and the Westbourne
36	Park district and St. Pancras, and westward and northward in Kilburn
36	and St. John's Wood and Hampstead, and eastward in Shoreditch and
36	Highbury and Haggerston and Hoxton, and, indeed, through all the
36	vastness of London from Ealing to East Ham--people were rubbing their
36	eyes, and opening windows to stare out and ask aimless questions,
36	dressing hastily as the first breath of the coming storm of Fear blew
36	through the streets.  It was the dawn of the great panic.  London,
36	which had gone to bed on Sunday night oblivious and inert, was
36	awakened, in the small hours of Monday morning, to a vivid sense of
36	danger.
36	
36	Unable from his window to learn what was happening, my brother went
36	down and out into the street, just as the sky between the parapets of
36	the houses grew pink with the early dawn.  The flying people on foot
36	and in vehicles grew more numerous every moment.  ""Black Smoke!"" he
36	heard people crying, and again ""Black Smoke!""  The contagion of such
36	a unanimous fear was inevitable.  As my brother hesitated on the
36	door-step, he saw another news vender approaching, and got a paper
36	forthwith.  The man was running away with the rest, and selling his
36	papers for a shilling each as he ran--a grotesque mingling of profit
36	and panic.
36	
36	And from this paper my brother read that catastrophic dispatch of
36	the Commander-in-Chief:
36	
36	""The Martians are able to discharge enormous clouds of a black and
36	poisonous vapour by means of rockets.  They have smothered our
36	batteries, destroyed Richmond, Kingston, and Wimbledon, and are
36	advancing slowly towards London, destroying everything on the way.  It
36	is impossible to stop them.  There is no safety from the Black Smoke
36	but in instant flight.""
36	
36	That was all, but it was enough.  The whole population of the great
36	six-million city was stirring, slipping, running; presently it would
36	be pouring _en masse_ northward.
36	
36	""Black Smoke!"" the voices cried.  ""Fire!""
36	
36	The bells of the neighbouring church made a jangling tumult, a cart
36	carelessly driven smashed, amid shrieks and curses, against the water
36	trough up the street.  Sickly yellow lights went to and fro in the
36	houses, and some of the passing cabs flaunted unextinguished lamps.
36	And overhead the dawn was growing brighter, clear and steady and calm.
36	
36	He heard footsteps running to and fro in the rooms, and up and down
36	stairs behind him.  His landlady came to the door, loosely wrapped in
36	dressing gown and shawl; her husband followed ejaculating.
36	
36	As my brother began to realise the import of all these things, he
36	turned hastily to his own room, put all his available money--some ten
36	pounds altogether--into his pockets, and went out again into the
36	streets.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER FIFTEEN
36	
36	WHAT HAD HAPPENED IN SURREY
36	
36	
36	It was while the curate had sat and talked so wildly to me under
36	the hedge in the flat meadows near Halliford, and while my brother was
36	watching the fugitives stream over Westminster Bridge, that the
36	Martians had resumed the offensive.  So far as one can ascertain from
36	the conflicting accounts that have been put forth, the majority of
36	them remained busied with preparations in the Horsell pit until nine
36	that night, hurrying on some operation that disengaged huge volumes of
36	green smoke.
36	
36	But three certainly came out about eight o'clock and, advancing
36	slowly and cautiously, made their way through Byfleet and Pyrford
36	towards Ripley and Weybridge, and so came in sight of the expectant
36	batteries against the setting sun.  These Martians did not advance in
36	a body, but in a line, each perhaps a mile and a half from his nearest
36	fellow.  They communicated with one another by means of sirenlike
36	howls, running up and down the scale from one note to another.
36	
36	It was this howling and firing of the guns at Ripley and St.
36	George's Hill that we had heard at Upper Halliford.  The Ripley
36	gunners, unseasoned artillery volunteers who ought never to have been
36	placed in such a position, fired one wild, premature, ineffectual
36	volley, and bolted on horse and foot through the deserted village,
36	while the Martian, without using his Heat-Ray, walked serenely over
36	their guns, stepped gingerly among them, passed in front of them, and
36	so came unexpectedly upon the guns in Painshill Park, which he
36	destroyed.
36	
36	The St. George's Hill men, however, were better led or of a better
36	mettle.  Hidden by a pine wood as they were, they seem to have been
36	quite unsuspected by the Martian nearest to them.  They laid their
36	guns as deliberately as if they had been on parade, and fired at about
36	a thousand yards' range.
36	
36	The shells flashed all round him, and he was seen to advance a few
36	paces, stagger, and go down.  Everybody yelled together, and the guns
36	were reloaded in frantic haste.  The overthrown Martian set up a
36	prolonged ululation, and immediately a second glittering giant,
36	answering him, appeared over the trees to the south.  It would seem
36	that a leg of the tripod had been smashed by one of the shells.  The
36	whole of the second volley flew wide of the Martian on the ground,
36	and, simultaneously, both his companions brought their Heat-Rays to
36	bear on the battery.  The ammunition blew up, the pine trees all about
36	the guns flashed into fire, and only one or two of the men who were
36	already running over the crest of the hill escaped.
36	
36	After this it would seem that the three took counsel together and
36	halted, and the scouts who were watching them report that they
36	remained absolutely stationary for the next half hour.  The Martian
36	who had been overthrown crawled tediously out of his hood, a small
36	brown figure, oddly suggestive from that distance of a speck of
36	blight, and apparently engaged in the repair of his support.  About
36	nine he had finished, for his cowl was then seen above the trees
36	again.
36	
36	It was a few minutes past nine that night when these three
36	sentinels were joined by four other Martians, each carrying a thick
36	black tube.  A similar tube was handed to each of the three, and the
36	seven proceeded to distribute themselves at equal distances along a
36	curved line between St. George's Hill, Weybridge, and the village of
36	Send, southwest of Ripley.
36	
36	A dozen rockets sprang out of the hills before them so soon as they
36	began to move, and warned the waiting batteries about Ditton and
36	Esher.  At the same time four of their fighting machines, similarly
36	armed with tubes, crossed the river, and two of them, black against
36	the western sky, came into sight of myself and the curate as we
36	hurried wearily and painfully along the road that runs northward out
36	of Halliford.  They moved, as it seemed to us, upon a cloud, for a
36	milky mist covered the fields and rose to a third of their height.
36	
36	At this sight the curate cried faintly in his throat, and began
36	running; but I knew it was no good running from a Martian, and I
36	turned aside and crawled through dewy nettles and brambles into the
36	broad ditch by the side of the road.  He looked back, saw what I was
36	doing, and turned to join me.
36	
36	The two halted, the nearer to us standing and facing Sunbury, the
36	remoter being a grey indistinctness towards the evening star, away
36	towards Staines.
36	
36	The occasional howling of the Martians had ceased; they took up
36	their positions in the huge crescent about their cylinders in absolute
36	silence.  It was a crescent with twelve miles between its horns.  Never
36	since the devising of gunpowder was the beginning of a battle so
36	still.  To us and to an observer about Ripley it would have had
36	precisely the same effect--the Martians seemed in solitary possession
36	of the darkling night, lit only as it was by the slender moon, the
36	stars, the afterglow of the daylight, and the ruddy glare from St.
36	George's Hill and the woods of Painshill.
36	
36	But facing that crescent everywhere--at Staines, Hounslow, Ditton,
36	Esher, Ockham, behind hills and woods south of the river, and across
36	the flat grass meadows to the north of it, wherever a cluster of trees
36	or village houses gave sufficient cover--the guns were waiting.  The
36	signal rockets burst and rained their sparks through the night and
36	vanished, and the spirit of all those watching batteries rose to a
36	tense expectation.  The Martians had but to advance into the line of
36	fire, and instantly those motionless black forms of men, those guns
36	glittering so darkly in the early night, would explode into a
36	thunderous fury of battle.
36	
36	No doubt the thought that was uppermost in a thousand of those
36	vigilant minds, even as it was uppermost in mine, was the riddle--how
36	much they understood of us.  Did they grasp that we in our millions
36	were organized, disciplined, working together?  Or did they interpret
36	our spurts of fire, the sudden stinging of our shells, our steady
36	investment of their encampment, as we should the furious unanimity of
36	onslaught in a disturbed hive of bees?  Did they dream they might
36	exterminate us?  (At that time no one knew what food they needed.)  A
36	hundred such questions struggled together in my mind as I watched that
36	vast sentinel shape.  And in the back of my mind was the sense of all
36	the huge unknown and hidden forces Londonward.  Had they prepared
36	pitfalls? Were the powder mills at Hounslow ready as a snare?  Would
36	the Londoners have the heart and courage to make a greater Moscow of
36	their mighty province of houses?
36	
36	Then, after an interminable time, as it seemed to us, crouching and
36	peering through the hedge, came a sound like the distant concussion of
36	a gun.  Another nearer, and then another.  And then the Martian beside
36	us raised his tube on high and discharged it, gunwise, with a heavy
36	report that made the ground heave.  The one towards Staines answered
36	him.  There was no flash, no smoke, simply that loaded detonation.
36	
36	I was so excited by these heavy minute-guns following one another
36	that I so far forgot my personal safety and my scalded hands as to
36	clamber up into the hedge and stare towards Sunbury.  As I did so a
36	second report followed, and a big projectile hurtled overhead towards
36	Hounslow.  I expected at least to see smoke or fire, or some such
36	evidence of its work.  But all I saw was the deep blue sky above, with
36	one solitary star, and the white mist spreading wide and low beneath.
36	And there had been no crash, no answering explosion.  The silence was
36	restored; the minute lengthened to three.
36	
36	""What has happened?"" said the curate, standing up beside me.
36	
36	""Heaven knows!"" said I.
36	
36	A bat flickered by and vanished.  A distant tumult of shouting
36	began and ceased.  I looked again at the Martian, and saw he was now
36	moving eastward along the riverbank, with a swift, rolling motion.
36	
36	Every moment I expected the fire of some hidden battery to spring
36	upon him; but the evening calm was unbroken.  The figure of the Martian
36	grew smaller as he receded, and presently the mist and the gathering
36	night had swallowed him up.  By a common impulse we clambered higher.
36	Towards Sunbury was a dark appearance, as though a conical hill had
36	suddenly come into being there, hiding our view of the farther
36	country; and then, remoter across the river, over Walton, we saw
36	another such summit.  These hill-like forms grew lower and broader
36	even as we stared.
36	
36	Moved by a sudden thought, I looked northward, and there I
36	perceived a third of these cloudy black kopjes had risen.
36	
36	Everything had suddenly become very still.  Far away to the
36	southeast, marking the quiet, we heard the Martians hooting to one
36	another, and then the air quivered again with the distant thud of
36	their guns.  But the earthly artillery made no reply.
36	
36	Now at the time we could not understand these things, but later I
36	was to learn the meaning of these ominous kopjes that gathered in the
36	twilight.  Each of the Martians, standing in the great crescent I have
36	described, had discharged, by means of the gunlike tube he carried, a
36	huge canister over whatever hill, copse, cluster of houses, or other
36	possible cover for guns, chanced to be in front of him.  Some fired
36	only one of these, some two--as in the case of the one we had seen;
36	the one at Ripley is said to have discharged no fewer than five at
36	that time.  These canisters smashed on striking the ground--they did
36	not explode--and incontinently disengaged an enormous volume of heavy,
36	inky vapour, coiling and pouring upward in a huge and ebony cumulus
36	cloud, a gaseous hill that sank and spread itself slowly over the
36	surrounding country.  And the touch of that vapour, the inhaling of
36	its pungent wisps, was death to all that breathes.
36	
36	It was heavy, this vapour, heavier than the densest smoke, so that,
36	after the first tumultuous uprush and outflow of its impact, it sank
36	down through the air and poured over the ground in a manner rather
36	liquid than gaseous, abandoning the hills, and streaming into the
36	valleys and ditches and watercourses even as I have heard the
36	carbonic-acid gas that pours from volcanic clefts is wont to do.  And
36	where it came upon water some chemical action occurred, and the
36	surface would be instantly covered with a powdery scum that sank
36	slowly and made way for more.  The scum was absolutely insoluble, and
36	it is a strange thing, seeing the instant effect of the gas, that one
36	could drink without hurt the water from which it had been strained.
36	The vapour did not diffuse as a true gas would do.  It hung together
36	in banks, flowing sluggishly down the slope of the land and driving
36	reluctantly before the wind, and very slowly it combined with the mist
36	and moisture of the air, and sank to the earth in the form of dust.
36	Save that an unknown element giving a group of four lines in the blue
36	of the spectrum is concerned, we are still entirely ignorant of the
36	nature of this substance.
36	
36	Once the tumultuous upheaval of its dispersion was over, the black
36	smoke clung so closely to the ground, even before its precipitation,
36	that fifty feet up in the air, on the roofs and upper stories of high
36	houses and on great trees, there was a chance of escaping its poison
36	altogether, as was proved even that night at Street Cobham and Ditton.
36	
36	The man who escaped at the former place tells a wonderful story of
36	the strangeness of its coiling flow, and how he looked down from the
36	church spire and saw the houses of the village rising like ghosts out
36	of its inky nothingness.  For a day and a half he remained there,
36	weary, starving and sun-scorched, the earth under the blue sky and
36	against the prospect of the distant hills a velvet-black expanse, with
36	red roofs, green trees, and, later, black-veiled shrubs and gates,
36	barns, outhouses, and walls, rising here and there into the sunlight.
36	
36	But that was at Street Cobham, where the black vapour was allowed
36	to remain until it sank of its own accord into the ground.  As a rule
36	the Martians, when it had served its purpose, cleared the air of it
36	again by wading into it and directing a jet of steam upon it.
36	
36	This they did with the vapour banks near us, as we saw in the
36	starlight from the window of a deserted house at Upper Halliford,
36	whither we had returned.  From there we could see the searchlights on
36	Richmond Hill and Kingston Hill going to and fro, and about eleven the
36	windows rattled, and we heard the sound of the huge siege guns that
36	had been put in position there.  These continued intermittently for
36	the space of a quarter of an hour, sending chance shots at the
36	invisible Martians at Hampton and Ditton, and then the pale beams of
36	the electric light vanished, and were replaced by a bright red glow.
36	
36	Then the fourth cylinder fell--a brilliant green meteor--as I
36	learned afterwards, in Bushey Park.  Before the guns on the Richmond
36	and Kingston line of hills began, there was a fitful cannonade far
36	away in the southwest, due, I believe, to guns being fired haphazard
36	before the black vapour could overwhelm the gunners.
36	
36	So, setting about it as methodically as men might smoke out a
36	wasps' nest, the Martians spread this strange stifling vapour over the
36	Londonward country.  The horns of the crescent slowly moved apart,
36	until at last they formed a line from Hanwell to Coombe and Malden.
36	All night through their destructive tubes advanced.  Never once, after
36	the Martian at St. George's Hill was brought down, did they give the
36	artillery the ghost of a chance against them.  Wherever there was a
36	possibility of guns being laid for them unseen, a fresh canister of
36	the black vapour was discharged, and where the guns were openly
36	displayed the Heat-Ray was brought to bear.
36	
36	By midnight the blazing trees along the slopes of Richmond Park and
36	the glare of Kingston Hill threw their light upon a network of black
36	smoke, blotting out the whole valley of the Thames and extending as
36	far as the eye could reach.  And through this two Martians slowly
36	waded, and turned their hissing steam jets this way and that.
36	
36	They were sparing of the Heat-Ray that night, either because they
36	had but a limited supply of material for its production or because
36	they did not wish to destroy the country but only to crush and overawe
36	the opposition they had aroused.  In the latter aim they certainly
36	succeeded.  Sunday night was the end of the organised opposition to
36	their movements.  After that no body of men would stand against them,
36	so hopeless was the enterprise.  Even the crews of the torpedo-boats
36	and destroyers that had brought their quick-firers up the Thames
36	refused to stop, mutinied, and went down again.  The only offensive
36	operation men ventured upon after that night was the preparation of
36	mines and pitfalls, and even in that their energies were frantic and
36	spasmodic.
36	
36	One has to imagine, as well as one may, the fate of those batteries
36	towards Esher, waiting so tensely in the twilight.  Survivors there
36	were none.  One may picture the orderly expectation, the officers
36	alert and watchful, the gunners ready, the ammunition piled to hand,
36	the limber gunners with their horses and waggons, the groups of
36	civilian spectators standing as near as they were permitted, the
36	evening stillness, the ambulances and hospital tents with the burned
36	and wounded from Weybridge; then the dull resonance of the shots the
36	Martians fired, and the clumsy projectile whirling over the trees and
36	houses and smashing amid the neighbouring fields.
36	
36	One may picture, too, the sudden shifting of the attention, the
36	swiftly spreading coils and bellyings of that blackness advancing
36	headlong, towering heavenward, turning the twilight to a palpable
36	darkness, a strange and horrible antagonist of vapour striding upon
36	its victims, men and horses near it seen dimly, running, shrieking,
36	falling headlong, shouts of dismay, the guns suddenly abandoned, men
36	choking and writhing on the ground, and the swift broadening-out of
36	the opaque cone of smoke.  And then night and extinction--nothing but
36	a silent mass of impenetrable vapour hiding its dead.
36	
36	Before dawn the black vapour was pouring through the streets of
36	Richmond, and the disintegrating organism of government was, with a
36	last expiring effort, rousing the population of London to the
36	necessity of flight.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER SIXTEEN
36	
36	THE EXODUS FROM LONDON
36	
36	
36	So you understand the roaring wave of fear that swept through the
36	greatest city in the world just as Monday was dawning--the stream of
36	flight rising swiftly to a torrent, lashing in a foaming tumult round
36	the railway stations, banked up into a horrible struggle about the
36	shipping in the Thames, and hurrying by every available channel
36	northward and eastward.  By ten o'clock the police organisation, and
36	by midday even the railway organisations, were losing coherency,
36	losing shape and efficiency, guttering, softening, running at last in
36	that swift liquefaction of the social body.
36	
36	All the railway lines north of the Thames and the South-Eastern
36	people at Cannon Street had been warned by midnight on Sunday, and
36	trains were being filled.  People were fighting savagely for
36	standing-room in the carriages even at two o'clock.  By three, people
36	were being trampled and crushed even in Bishopsgate Street, a couple
36	of hundred yards or more from Liverpool Street station; revolvers were
36	fired, people stabbed, and the policemen who had been sent to direct
36	the traffic, exhausted and infuriated, were breaking the heads of the
36	people they were called out to protect.
36	
36	And as the day advanced and the engine drivers and stokers refused
36	to return to London, the pressure of the flight drove the people in an
36	ever-thickening multitude away from the stations and along the
36	northward-running roads.  By midday a Martian had been seen at Barnes,
36	and a cloud of slowly sinking black vapour drove along the Thames and
36	across the flats of Lambeth, cutting off all escape over the bridges
36	in its sluggish advance.  Another bank drove over Ealing, and
36	surrounded a little island of survivors on Castle Hill, alive, but
36	unable to escape.
36	
36	After a fruitless struggle to get aboard a North-Western train at
36	Chalk Farm--the engines of the trains that had loaded in the goods
36	yard there _ploughed_ through shrieking people, and a dozen stalwart men
36	fought to keep the crowd from crushing the driver against his
36	furnace--my brother emerged upon the Chalk Farm road, dodged across
36	through a hurrying swarm of vehicles, and had the luck to be foremost
36	in the sack of a cycle shop.  The front tire of the machine he got was
36	punctured in dragging it through the window, but he got up and off,
36	notwithstanding, with no further injury than a cut wrist.  The steep
36	foot of Haverstock Hill was impassable owing to several overturned
36	horses, and my brother struck into Belsize Road.
36	
36	So he got out of the fury of the panic, and, skirting the Edgware
36	Road, reached Edgware about seven, fasting and wearied, but well ahead
36	of the crowd.  Along the road people were standing in the roadway,
36	curious, wondering.  He was passed by a number of cyclists, some
36	horsemen, and two motor cars.  A mile from Edgware the rim of the
36	wheel broke, and the machine became unridable.  He left it by the
36	roadside and trudged through the village.  There were shops half
36	opened in the main street of the place, and people crowded on the
36	pavement and in the doorways and windows, staring astonished at this
36	extraordinary procession of fugitives that was beginning.  He
36	succeeded in getting some food at an inn.
36	
36	For a time he remained in Edgware not knowing what next to do.  The
36	flying people increased in number.  Many of them, like my brother,
36	seemed inclined to loiter in the place.  There was no fresh news of
36	the invaders from Mars.
36	
36	At that time the road was crowded, but as yet far from congested.
36	Most of the fugitives at that hour were mounted on cycles, but there
36	were soon motor cars, hansom cabs, and carriages hurrying along, and
36	the dust hung in heavy clouds along the road to St. Albans.
36	
36	It was perhaps a vague idea of making his way to Chelmsford, where
36	some friends of his lived, that at last induced my brother to strike
36	into a quiet lane running eastward.  Presently he came upon a stile,
36	and, crossing it, followed a footpath northeastward.  He passed near
36	several farmhouses and some little places whose names he did not
36	learn.  He saw few fugitives until, in a grass lane towards High
36	Barnet, he happened upon two ladies who became his fellow travellers.
36	He came upon them just in time to save them.
36	
36	He heard their screams, and, hurrying round the corner, saw a
36	couple of men struggling to drag them out of the little pony-chaise in
36	which they had been driving, while a third with difficulty held the
36	frightened pony's head.  One of the ladies, a short woman dressed in
36	white, was simply screaming; the other, a dark, slender figure,
36	slashed at the man who gripped her arm with a whip she held in her
36	disengaged hand.
36	
36	My brother immediately grasped the situation, shouted, and hurried
36	towards the struggle.  One of the men desisted and turned towards him,
36	and my brother, realising from his antagonist's face that a fight was
36	unavoidable, and being an expert boxer, went into him forthwith and
36	sent him down against the wheel of the chaise.
36	
36	It was no time for pugilistic chivalry and my brother laid him
36	quiet with a kick, and gripped the collar of the man who pulled at the
36	slender lady's arm.  He heard the clatter of hoofs, the whip stung
36	across his face, a third antagonist struck him between the eyes, and
36	the man he held wrenched himself free and made off down the lane in
36	the direction from which he had come.
36	
36	Partly stunned, he found himself facing the man who had held the
36	horse's head, and became aware of the chaise receding from him down
36	the lane, swaying from side to side, and with the women in it looking
36	back.  The man before him, a burly rough, tried to close, and he
36	stopped him with a blow in the face.  Then, realising that he was
36	deserted, he dodged round and made off down the lane after the chaise,
36	with the sturdy man close behind him, and the fugitive, who had turned
36	now, following remotely.
36	
36	Suddenly he stumbled and fell; his immediate pursuer went headlong,
36	and he rose to his feet to find himself with a couple of antagonists
36	again.  He would have had little chance against them had not the
36	slender lady very pluckily pulled up and returned to his help.  It
36	seems she had had a revolver all this time, but it had been under the
36	seat when she and her companion were attacked.  She fired at six
36	yards' distance, narrowly missing my brother.  The less courageous of
36	the robbers made off, and his companion followed him, cursing his
36	cowardice.  They both stopped in sight down the lane, where the third
36	man lay insensible.
36	
36	""Take this!"" said the slender lady, and she gave my brother her
36	revolver.
36	
36	""Go back to the chaise,"" said my brother, wiping the blood from his
36	split lip.
36	
36	She turned without a word--they were both panting--and they went
36	back to where the lady in white struggled to hold back the frightened
36	pony.
36	
36	The robbers had evidently had enough of it.  When my brother looked
36	again they were retreating.
36	
36	""I'll sit here,"" said my brother, ""if I may""; and he got upon the
36	empty front seat.  The lady looked over her shoulder.
36	
36	""Give me the reins,"" she said, and laid the whip along the pony's
36	side.  In another moment a bend in the road hid the three men from my
36	brother's eyes.
36	
36	So, quite unexpectedly, my brother found himself, panting, with a
36	cut mouth, a bruised jaw, and bloodstained knuckles, driving along an
36	unknown lane with these two women.
36	
36	He learned they were the wife and the younger sister of a surgeon
36	living at Stanmore, who had come in the small hours from a dangerous
36	case at Pinner, and heard at some railway station on his way of the
36	Martian advance.  He had hurried home, roused the women--their servant
36	had left them two days before--packed some provisions, put his
36	revolver under the seat--luckily for my brother--and told them to
36	drive on to Edgware, with the idea of getting a train there.  He
36	stopped behind to tell the neighbours.  He would overtake them, he
36	said, at about half past four in the morning, and now it was nearly
36	nine and they had seen nothing of him.  They could not stop in Edgware
36	because of the growing traffic through the place, and so they had come
36	into this side lane.
36	
36	That was the story they told my brother in fragments when presently
36	they stopped again, nearer to New Barnet.  He promised to stay with
36	them, at least until they could determine what to do, or until the
36	missing man arrived, and professed to be an expert shot with the
36	revolver--a weapon strange to him--in order to give them confidence.
36	
36	They made a sort of encampment by the wayside, and the pony became
36	happy in the hedge.  He told them of his own escape out of London, and
36	all that he knew of these Martians and their ways.  The sun crept
36	higher in the sky, and after a time their talk died out and gave place
36	to an uneasy state of anticipation.  Several wayfarers came along the
36	lane, and of these my brother gathered such news as he could.  Every
36	broken answer he had deepened his impression of the great disaster
36	that had come on humanity, deepened his persuasion of the immediate
36	necessity for prosecuting this flight.  He urged the matter upon them.
36	
36	""We have money,"" said the slender woman, and hesitated.
36	
36	Her eyes met my brother's, and her hesitation ended.
36	
36	""So have I,"" said my brother.
36	
36	She explained that they had as much as thirty pounds in gold,
36	besides a five-pound note, and suggested that with that they might get
36	upon a train at St. Albans or New Barnet.  My brother thought that was
36	hopeless, seeing the fury of the Londoners to crowd upon the trains,
36	and broached his own idea of striking across Essex towards Harwich and
36	thence escaping from the country altogether.
36	
36	Mrs. Elphinstone--that was the name of the woman in white--would
36	listen to no reasoning, and kept calling upon ""George""; but her
36	sister-in-law was astonishingly quiet and deliberate, and at last
36	agreed to my brother's suggestion.  So, designing to cross the Great
36	North Road, they went on towards Barnet, my brother leading the pony
36	to save it as much as possible.  As the sun crept up the sky the day
36	became excessively hot, and under foot a thick, whitish sand grew
36	burning and blinding, so that they travelled only very slowly.  The
36	hedges were grey with dust.  And as they advanced towards Barnet a
36	tumultuous murmuring grew stronger.
36	
36	They began to meet more people.  For the most part these were
36	staring before them, murmuring indistinct questions, jaded, haggard,
36	unclean.  One man in evening dress passed them on foot, his eyes on
36	the ground.  They heard his voice, and, looking back at him, saw one
36	hand clutched in his hair and the other beating invisible things.  His
36	paroxysm of rage over, he went on his way without once looking back.
36	
36	As my brother's party went on towards the crossroads to the south
36	of Barnet they saw a woman approaching the road across some fields on
36	their left, carrying a child and with two other children; and then
36	passed a man in dirty black, with a thick stick in one hand and a
36	small portmanteau in the other.  Then round the corner of the lane,
36	from between the villas that guarded it at its confluence with the
36	high road, came a little cart drawn by a sweating black pony and
36	driven by a sallow youth in a bowler hat, grey with dust.  There were
36	three girls, East End factory girls, and a couple of little children
36	crowded in the cart.
36	
36	""This'll tike us rahnd Edgware?"" asked the driver, wild-eyed,
36	white-faced; and when my brother told him it would if he turned to the
36	left, he whipped up at once without the formality of thanks.
36	
36	My brother noticed a pale grey smoke or haze rising among the
36	houses in front of them, and veiling the white facade of a terrace
36	beyond the road that appeared between the backs of the villas.  Mrs.
36	Elphinstone suddenly cried out at a number of tongues of smoky red
36	flame leaping up above the houses in front of them against the hot,
36	blue sky.  The tumultuous noise resolved itself now into the
36	disorderly mingling of many voices, the gride of many wheels, the
36	creaking of waggons, and the staccato of hoofs.  The lane came round
36	sharply not fifty yards from the crossroads.
36	
36	""Good heavens!"" cried Mrs. Elphinstone.  ""What is this you are
36	driving us into?""
36	
36	My brother stopped.
36	
36	For the main road was a boiling stream of people, a torrent of
36	human beings rushing northward, one pressing on another.  A great bank
36	of dust, white and luminous in the blaze of the sun, made everything
36	within twenty feet of the ground grey and indistinct and was
36	perpetually renewed by the hurrying feet of a dense crowd of horses
36	and of men and women on foot, and by the wheels of vehicles of every
36	description.
36	
36	""Way!"" my brother heard voices crying.  ""Make way!""
36	
36	It was like riding into the smoke of a fire to approach the meeting
36	point of the lane and road; the crowd roared like a fire, and the dust
36	was hot and pungent.  And, indeed, a little way up the road a villa
36	was burning and sending rolling masses of black smoke across the road
36	to add to the confusion.
36	
36	Two men came past them.  Then a dirty woman, carrying a heavy
36	bundle and weeping.  A lost retriever dog, with hanging tongue,
36	circled dubiously round them, scared and wretched, and fled at my
36	brother's threat.
36	
36	So much as they could see of the road Londonward between the houses
36	to the right was a tumultuous stream of dirty, hurrying people, pent
36	in between the villas on either side; the black heads, the crowded
36	forms, grew into distinctness as they rushed towards the corner,
36	hurried past, and merged their individuality again in a receding
36	multitude that was swallowed up at last in a cloud of dust.
36	
36	""Go on!  Go on!"" cried the voices.  ""Way!  Way!""
36	
36	One man's hands pressed on the back of another.  My brother stood
36	at the pony's head.  Irresistibly attracted, he advanced slowly, pace
36	by pace, down the lane.
36	
36	Edgware had been a scene of confusion, Chalk Farm a riotous tumult,
36	but this was a whole population in movement.  It is hard to imagine
36	that host.  It had no character of its own.  The figures poured out
36	past the corner, and receded with their backs to the group in the
36	lane.  Along the margin came those who were on foot threatened by the
36	wheels, stumbling in the ditches, blundering into one another.
36	
36	The carts and carriages crowded close upon one another, making
36	little way for those swifter and more impatient vehicles that darted
36	forward every now and then when an opportunity showed itself of doing
36	so, sending the people scattering against the fences and gates of the
36	villas.
36	
36	""Push on!"" was the cry.  ""Push on!  They are coming!""
36	
36	In one cart stood a blind man in the uniform of the Salvation Army,
36	gesticulating with his crooked fingers and bawling, ""Eternity!
36	Eternity!""  His voice was hoarse and very loud so that my brother
36	could hear him long after he was lost to sight in the dust.  Some of
36	the people who crowded in the carts whipped stupidly at their horses
36	and quarrelled with other drivers; some sat motionless, staring at
36	nothing with miserable eyes; some gnawed their hands with thirst, or
36	lay prostrate in the bottoms of their conveyances.  The horses' bits
36	were covered with foam, their eyes bloodshot.
36	
36	There were cabs, carriages, shop cars, waggons, beyond counting; a
36	mail cart, a road-cleaner's cart marked ""Vestry of St. Pancras,"" a
36	huge timber waggon crowded with roughs.  A brewer's dray rumbled by
36	with its two near wheels splashed with fresh blood.
36	
36	""Clear the way!"" cried the voices.  ""Clear the way!""
36	
36	""Eter-nity!  Eter-nity!"" came echoing down the road.
36	
36	There were sad, haggard women tramping by, well dressed, with
36	children that cried and stumbled, their dainty clothes smothered in
36	dust, their weary faces smeared with tears.  With many of these came
36	men, sometimes helpful, sometimes lowering and savage.  Fighting side
36	by side with them pushed some weary street outcast in faded black
36	rags, wide-eyed, loud-voiced, and foul-mouthed.  There were sturdy
36	workmen thrusting their way along, wretched, unkempt men, clothed like
36	clerks or shopmen, struggling spasmodically; a wounded soldier my
36	brother noticed, men dressed in the clothes of railway porters, one
36	wretched creature in a nightshirt with a coat thrown over it.
36	
36	But varied as its composition was, certain things all that host had
36	in common.  There were fear and pain on their faces, and fear behind
36	them.  A tumult up the road, a quarrel for a place in a waggon, sent
36	the whole host of them quickening their pace; even a man so scared and
36	broken that his knees bent under him was galvanised for a moment into
36	renewed activity.  The heat and dust had already been at work upon
36	this multitude.  Their skins were dry, their lips black and cracked.
36	They were all thirsty, weary, and footsore.  And amid the various
36	cries one heard disputes, reproaches, groans of weariness and fatigue;
36	the voices of most of them were hoarse and weak.  Through it all ran a
36	refrain:
36	
36	""Way!  Way!  The Martians are coming!""
36	
36	Few stopped and came aside from that flood.  The lane opened
36	slantingly into the main road with a narrow opening, and had a
36	delusive appearance of coming from the direction of London.  Yet a
36	kind of eddy of people drove into its mouth; weaklings elbowed out of
36	the stream, who for the most part rested but a moment before plunging
36	into it again.  A little way down the lane, with two friends bending
36	over him, lay a man with a bare leg, wrapped about with bloody rags.
36	He was a lucky man to have friends.
36	
36	A little old man, with a grey military moustache and a filthy black
36	frock coat, limped out and sat down beside the trap, removed his
36	boot--his sock was blood-stained--shook out a pebble, and hobbled on
36	again; and then a little girl of eight or nine, all alone, threw
36	herself under the hedge close by my brother, weeping.
36	
36	""I can't go on!  I can't go on!""
36	
36	My brother woke from his torpor of astonishment and lifted her up,
36	speaking gently to her, and carried her to Miss Elphinstone.  So soon
36	as my brother touched her she became quite still, as if frightened.
36	
36	""Ellen!"" shrieked a woman in the crowd, with tears in her
36	voice--""Ellen!""  And the child suddenly darted away from my brother,
36	crying ""Mother!""
36	
36	""They are coming,"" said a man on horseback, riding past along the
36	lane.
36	
36	""Out of the way, there!"" bawled a coachman, towering high; and my
36	brother saw a closed carriage turning into the lane.
36	
36	The people crushed back on one another to avoid the horse.  My
36	brother pushed the pony and chaise back into the hedge, and the man
36	drove by and stopped at the turn of the way.  It was a carriage, with
36	a pole for a pair of horses, but only one was in the traces.  My
36	brother saw dimly through the dust that two men lifted out something
36	on a white stretcher and put it gently on the grass beneath the privet
36	hedge.
36	
36	One of the men came running to my brother.
36	
36	""Where is there any water?"" he said.  ""He is dying fast, and very
36	thirsty.  It is Lord Garrick.""
36	
36	""Lord Garrick!"" said my brother; ""the Chief Justice?""
36	
36	""The water?"" he said.
36	
36	""There may be a tap,"" said my brother, ""in some of the houses.  We
36	have no water.  I dare not leave my people.""
36	
36	The man pushed against the crowd towards the gate of the corner
36	house.
36	
36	""Go on!"" said the people, thrusting at him.  ""They are coming!  Go
36	on!""
36	
36	Then my brother's attention was distracted by a bearded, eagle-faced
36	man lugging a small handbag, which split even as my brother's
36	eyes rested on it and disgorged a mass of sovereigns that seemed to
36	break up into separate coins as it struck the ground.  They rolled
36	hither and thither among the struggling feet of men and horses.  The
36	man stopped and looked stupidly at the heap, and the shaft of a cab
36	struck his shoulder and sent him reeling.  He gave a shriek and dodged
36	back, and a cartwheel shaved him narrowly.
36	
36	""Way!"" cried the men all about him.  ""Make way!""
36	
36	So soon as the cab had passed, he flung himself, with both hands
36	open, upon the heap of coins, and began thrusting handfuls in his
36	pocket.  A horse rose close upon him, and in another moment, half
36	rising, he had been borne down under the horse's hoofs.
36	
36	""Stop!"" screamed my brother, and pushing a woman out of his way,
36	tried to clutch the bit of the horse.
36	
36	Before he could get to it, he heard a scream under the wheels, and
36	saw through the dust the rim passing over the poor wretch's back.  The
36	driver of the cart slashed his whip at my brother, who ran round
36	behind the cart.  The multitudinous shouting confused his ears.  The
36	man was writhing in the dust among his scattered money, unable to
36	rise, for the wheel had broken his back, and his lower limbs lay limp
36	and dead.  My brother stood up and yelled at the next driver, and a
36	man on a black horse came to his assistance.
36	
36	""Get him out of the road,"" said he; and, clutching the man's collar
36	with his free hand, my brother lugged him sideways.  But he still
36	clutched after his money, and regarded my brother fiercely, hammering
36	at his arm with a handful of gold.  ""Go on!  Go on!"" shouted angry
36	voices behind.
36	
36	""Way!  Way!""
36	
36	There was a smash as the pole of a carriage crashed into the cart
36	that the man on horseback stopped.  My brother looked up, and the man
36	with the gold twisted his head round and bit the wrist that held his
36	collar.  There was a concussion, and the black horse came staggering
36	sideways, and the carthorse pushed beside it.  A hoof missed my
36	brother's foot by a hair's breadth.  He released his grip on the
36	fallen man and jumped back.  He saw anger change to terror on the face
36	of the poor wretch on the ground, and in a moment he was hidden and my
36	brother was borne backward and carried past the entrance of the lane,
36	and had to fight hard in the torrent to recover it.
36	
36	He saw Miss Elphinstone covering her eyes, and a little child, with
36	all a child's want of sympathetic imagination, staring with dilated
36	eyes at a dusty something that lay black and still, ground and crushed
36	under the rolling wheels.  ""Let us go back!"" he shouted, and began
36	turning the pony round. ""We cannot cross this--hell,"" he said and they
36	went back a hundred yards the way they had come, until the fighting
36	crowd was hidden.  As they passed the bend in the lane my brother saw
36	the face of the dying man in the ditch under the privet, deadly white
36	and drawn, and shining with perspiration.  The two women sat silent,
36	crouching in their seat and shivering.
36	
36	Then beyond the bend my brother stopped again.  Miss Elphinstone
36	was white and pale, and her sister-in-law sat weeping, too wretched
36	even to call upon ""George.""  My brother was horrified and perplexed.
36	So soon as they had retreated he realised how urgent and unavoidable
36	it was to attempt this crossing.  He turned to Miss Elphinstone,
36	suddenly resolute.
36	
36	""We must go that way,"" he said, and led the pony round again.
36	
36	For the second time that day this girl proved her quality.  To force
36	their way into the torrent of people, my brother plunged into the
36	traffic and held back a cab horse, while she drove the pony across its
36	head.  A waggon locked wheels for a moment and ripped a long splinter
36	from the chaise.  In another moment they were caught and swept forward
36	by the stream.  My brother, with the cabman's whip marks red across
36	his face and hands, scrambled into the chaise and took the reins from
36	her.
36	
36	""Point the revolver at the man behind,"" he said, giving it to her,
36	""if he presses us too hard.  No!--point it at his horse.""
36	
36	Then he began to look out for a chance of edging to the right
36	across the road.  But once in the stream he seemed to lose volition,
36	to become a part of that dusty rout.  They swept through Chipping
36	Barnet with the torrent; they were nearly a mile beyond the centre of
36	the town before they had fought across to the opposite side of the
36	way.  It was din and confusion indescribable; but in and beyond the
36	town the road forks repeatedly, and this to some extent relieved the
36	stress.
36	
36	They struck eastward through Hadley, and there on either side of
36	the road, and at another place farther on they came upon a great
36	multitude of people drinking at the stream, some fighting to come at
36	the water.  And farther on, from a lull near East Barnet, they saw
36	two trains running slowly one after the other without signal or
36	order--trains swarming with people, with men even among the coals
36	behind the engines--going northward along the Great Northern Railway.
36	My brother supposes they must have filled outside London, for at that
36	time the furious terror of the people had rendered the central
36	termini impossible.
36	
36	Near this place they halted for the rest of the afternoon, for the
36	violence of the day had already utterly exhausted all three of them.
36	They began to suffer the beginnings of hunger; the night was cold, and
36	none of them dared to sleep.  And in the evening many people came
36	hurrying along the road nearby their stopping place, fleeing from
36	unknown dangers before them, and going in the direction from which my
36	brother had come.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER SEVENTEEN
36	
36	THE ""THUNDER CHILD""
36	
36	
36	Had the Martians aimed only at destruction, they might on Monday
36	have annihilated the entire population of London, as it spread itself
36	slowly through the home counties.  Not only along the road through
36	Barnet, but also through Edgware and Waltham Abbey, and along the
36	roads eastward to Southend and Shoeburyness, and south of the Thames
36	to Deal and Broadstairs, poured the same frantic rout.  If one could
36	have hung that June morning in a balloon in the blazing blue above
36	London every northward and eastward road running out of the tangled
36	maze of streets would have seemed stippled black with the streaming
36	fugitives, each dot a human agony of terror and physical distress.  I
36	have set forth at length in the last chapter my brother's account of
36	the road through Chipping Barnet, in order that my readers may realise
36	how that swarming of black dots appeared to one of those concerned.
36	Never before in the history of the world had such a mass of human
36	beings moved and suffered together.  The legendary hosts of Goths and
36	Huns, the hugest armies Asia has ever seen, would have been but a drop
36	in that current.  And this was no disciplined march; it was a
36	stampede--a stampede gigantic and terrible--without order and without
36	a goal, six million people unarmed and unprovisioned, driving
36	headlong.  It was the beginning of the rout of civilisation, of the
36	massacre of mankind.
36	
36	Directly below him the balloonist would have seen the network of
36	streets far and wide, houses, churches, squares, crescents,
36	gardens--already derelict--spread out like a huge map, and in the
36	southward _blotted_.  Over Ealing, Richmond, Wimbledon, it would
36	have seemed as if some monstrous pen had flung ink upon the chart.
36	Steadily, incessantly, each black splash grew and spread, shooting out
36	ramifications this way and that, now banking itself against rising
36	ground, now pouring swiftly over a crest into a new-found valley,
36	exactly as a gout of ink would spread itself upon blotting paper.
36	
36	And beyond, over the blue hills that rise southward of the river,
36	the glittering Martians went to and fro, calmly and methodically
36	spreading their poison cloud over this patch of country and then over
36	that, laying it again with their steam jets when it had served its
36	purpose, and taking possession of the conquered country.  They do not
36	seem to have aimed at extermination so much as at complete
36	demoralisation and the destruction of any opposition.  They exploded
36	any stores of powder they came upon, cut every telegraph, and wrecked
36	the railways here and there.  They were hamstringing mankind.  They
36	seemed in no hurry to extend the field of their operations, and did
36	not come beyond the central part of London all that day.  It is
36	possible that a very considerable number of people in London stuck to
36	their houses through Monday morning.  Certain it is that many died at
36	home suffocated by the Black Smoke.
36	
36	Until about midday the Pool of London was an astonishing scene.
36	Steamboats and shipping of all sorts lay there, tempted by the
36	enormous sums of money offered by fugitives, and it is said that many
36	who swam out to these vessels were thrust off with boathooks and
36	drowned.  About one o'clock in the afternoon the thinning remnant of a
36	cloud of the black vapour appeared between the arches of Blackfriars
36	Bridge.  At that the Pool became a scene of mad confusion, fighting,
36	and collision, and for some time a multitude of boats and barges
36	jammed in the northern arch of the Tower Bridge, and the sailors and
36	lightermen had to fight savagely against the people who swarmed upon
36	them from the riverfront.  People were actually clambering down the
36	piers of the bridge from above.
36	
36	When, an hour later, a Martian appeared beyond the Clock Tower and
36	waded down the river, nothing but wreckage floated above Limehouse.
36	
36	Of the falling of the fifth cylinder I have presently to tell.  The
36	sixth star fell at Wimbledon.  My brother, keeping watch beside the
36	women in the chaise in a meadow, saw the green flash of it far beyond
36	the hills.  On Tuesday the little party, still set upon getting across
36	the sea, made its way through the swarming country towards Colchester.
36	The news that the Martians were now in possession of the whole of
36	London was confirmed.  They had been seen at Highgate, and even, it
36	was said, at Neasden.  But they did not come into my brother's view
36	until the morrow.
36	
36	That day the scattered multitudes began to realise the urgent need
36	of provisions.  As they grew hungry the rights of property ceased to
36	be regarded.  Farmers were out to defend their cattle-sheds,
36	granaries, and ripening root crops with arms in their hands.  A number
36	of people now, like my brother, had their faces eastward, and there
36	were some desperate souls even going back towards London to get food.
36	These were chiefly people from the northern suburbs, whose knowledge
36	of the Black Smoke came by hearsay.  He heard that about half the
36	members of the government had gathered at Birmingham, and that
36	enormous quantities of high explosives were being prepared to be used
36	in automatic mines across the Midland counties.
36	
36	He was also told that the Midland Railway Company had replaced the
36	desertions of the first day's panic, had resumed traffic, and was
36	running northward trains from St. Albans to relieve the congestion of
36	the home counties.  There was also a placard in Chipping Ongar
36	announcing that large stores of flour were available in the northern
36	towns and that within twenty-four hours bread would be distributed
36	among the starving people in the neighbourhood.  But this intelligence
36	did not deter him from the plan of escape he had formed, and the three
36	pressed eastward all day, and heard no more of the bread distribution
36	than this promise.  Nor, as a matter of fact, did anyone else hear
36	more of it.  That night fell the seventh star, falling upon Primrose
36	Hill.  It fell while Miss Elphinstone was watching, for she took that
36	duty alternately with my brother.  She saw it.
36	
36	On Wednesday the three fugitives--they had passed the night in a
36	field of unripe wheat--reached Chelmsford, and there a body of the
36	inhabitants, calling itself the Committee of Public Supply, seized the
36	pony as provisions, and would give nothing in exchange for it but the
36	promise of a share in it the next day.  Here there were rumours of
36	Martians at Epping, and news of the destruction of Waltham Abbey
36	Powder Mills in a vain attempt to blow up one of the invaders.
36	
36	People were watching for Martians here from the church towers.  My
36	brother, very luckily for him as it chanced, preferred to push on at
36	once to the coast rather than wait for food, although all three of
36	them were very hungry.  By midday they passed through Tillingham,
36	which, strangely enough, seemed to be quite silent and deserted, save
36	for a few furtive plunderers hunting for food.  Near Tillingham they
36	suddenly came in sight of the sea, and the most amazing crowd of
36	shipping of all sorts that it is possible to imagine.
36	
36	For after the sailors could no longer come up the Thames, they came
36	on to the Essex coast, to Harwich and Walton and Clacton, and
36	afterwards to Foulness and Shoebury, to bring off the people.  They
36	lay in a huge sickle-shaped curve that vanished into mist at last
36	towards the Naze.  Close inshore was a multitude of fishing
36	smacks--English, Scotch, French, Dutch, and Swedish; steam launches
36	from the Thames, yachts, electric boats; and beyond were ships of large
36	burden, a multitude of filthy colliers, trim merchantmen, cattle ships,
36	passenger boats, petroleum tanks, ocean tramps, an old white transport
36	even, neat white and grey liners from Southampton and Hamburg; and
36	along the blue coast across the Blackwater my brother could make out
36	dimly a dense swarm of boats chaffering with the people on the beach,
36	a swarm which also extended up the Blackwater almost to Maldon.
36	
36	About a couple of miles out lay an ironclad, very low in the water,
36	almost, to my brother's perception, like a water-logged ship.  This
36	was the ram _Thunder Child_.  It was the only warship in sight, but far
36	away to the right over the smooth surface of the sea--for that day
36	there was a dead calm--lay a serpent of black smoke to mark the next
36	ironclads of the Channel Fleet, which hovered in an extended line,
36	steam up and ready for action, across the Thames estuary during the
36	course of the Martian conquest, vigilant and yet powerless to prevent
36	it.
36	
36	At the sight of the sea, Mrs. Elphinstone, in spite of the
36	assurances of her sister-in-law, gave way to panic.  She had never
36	been out of England before, she would rather die than trust herself
36	friendless in a foreign country, and so forth.  She seemed, poor woman,
36	to imagine that the French and the Martians might prove very similar.
36	She had been growing increasingly hysterical, fearful, and depressed
36	during the two days' journeyings.  Her great idea was to return to
36	Stanmore.  Things had been always well and safe at Stanmore.  They
36	would find George at Stanmore.
36	
36	It was with the greatest difficulty they could get her down to the
36	beach, where presently my brother succeeded in attracting the
36	attention of some men on a paddle steamer from the Thames.  They sent
36	a boat and drove a bargain for thirty-six pounds for the three.  The
36	steamer was going, these men said, to Ostend.
36	
36	It was about two o'clock when my brother, having paid their fares
36	at the gangway, found himself safely aboard the steamboat with his
36	charges.  There was food aboard, albeit at exorbitant prices, and the
36	three of them contrived to eat a meal on one of the seats forward.
36	
36	There were already a couple of score of passengers aboard, some of
36	whom had expended their last money in securing a passage, but the
36	captain lay off the Blackwater until five in the afternoon, picking up
36	passengers until the seated decks were even dangerously crowded.  He
36	would probably have remained longer had it not been for the sound of
36	guns that began about that hour in the south.  As if in answer, the
36	ironclad seaward fired a small gun and hoisted a string of flags.  A
36	jet of smoke sprang out of her funnels.
36	
36	Some of the passengers were of opinion that this firing came from
36	Shoeburyness, until it was noticed that it was growing louder.  At the
36	same time, far away in the southeast the masts and upperworks of three
36	ironclads rose one after the other out of the sea, beneath clouds of
36	black smoke.  But my brother's attention speedily reverted to the
36	distant firing in the south.  He fancied he saw a column of smoke
36	rising out of the distant grey haze.
36
