36	The little steamer was already flapping her way eastward of the big
36	crescent of shipping, and the low Essex coast was growing blue and
36	hazy, when a Martian appeared, small and faint in the remote distance,
36	advancing along the muddy coast from the direction of Foulness.  At
36	that the captain on the bridge swore at the top of his voice with fear
36	and anger at his own delay, and the paddles seemed infected with his
36	terror.  Every soul aboard stood at the bulwarks or on the seats of
36	the steamer and stared at that distant shape, higher than the trees or
36	church towers inland, and advancing with a leisurely parody of a human
36	stride.
36	
36	It was the first Martian my brother had seen, and he stood, more
36	amazed than terrified, watching this Titan advancing deliberately
36	towards the shipping, wading farther and farther into the water as the
36	coast fell away.  Then, far away beyond the Crouch, came another,
36	striding over some stunted trees, and then yet another, still farther
36	off, wading deeply through a shiny mudflat that seemed to hang halfway
36	up between sea and sky.  They were all stalking seaward, as if to
36	intercept the escape of the multitudinous vessels that were crowded
36	between Foulness and the Naze.  In spite of the throbbing exertions of
36	the engines of the little paddle-boat, and the pouring foam that her
36	wheels flung behind her, she receded with terrifying slowness from
36	this ominous advance.
36	
36	Glancing northwestward, my brother saw the large crescent of
36	shipping already writhing with the approaching terror; one ship
36	passing behind another, another coming round from broadside to end on,
36	steamships whistling and giving off volumes of steam, sails being let
36	out, launches rushing hither and thither.  He was so fascinated by
36	this and by the creeping danger away to the left that he had no eyes
36	for anything seaward.  And then a swift movement of the steamboat (she
36	had suddenly come round to avoid being run down) flung him headlong
36	from the seat upon which he was standing.  There was a shouting all
36	about him, a trampling of feet, and a cheer that seemed to be answered
36	faintly.  The steamboat lurched and rolled him over upon his hands.
36	
36	He sprang to his feet and saw to starboard, and not a hundred yards
36	from their heeling, pitching boat, a vast iron bulk like the blade of
36	a plough tearing through the water, tossing it on either side in huge
36	waves of foam that leaped towards the steamer, flinging her paddles
36	helplessly in the air, and then sucking her deck down almost to the
36	waterline.
36	
36	A douche of spray blinded my brother for a moment.  When his eyes
36	were clear again he saw the monster had passed and was rushing
36	landward.  Big iron upperworks rose out of this headlong structure,
36	and from that twin funnels projected and spat a smoking blast shot
36	with fire.  It was the torpedo ram, _Thunder Child_, steaming headlong,
36	coming to the rescue of the threatened shipping.
36	
36	Keeping his footing on the heaving deck by clutching the bulwarks,
36	my brother looked past this charging leviathan at the Martians again,
36	and he saw the three of them now close together, and standing so far
36	out to sea that their tripod supports were almost entirely submerged.
36	Thus sunken, and seen in remote perspective, they appeared far less
36	formidable than the huge iron bulk in whose wake the steamer was
36	pitching so helplessly.  It would seem they were regarding this new
36	antagonist with astonishment.  To their intelligence, it may be, the
36	giant was even such another as themselves.  The _Thunder Child_ fired no
36	gun, but simply drove full speed towards them.  It was probably her
36	not firing that enabled her to get so near the enemy as she did.  They
36	did not know what to make of her.  One shell, and they would have sent
36	her to the bottom forthwith with the Heat-Ray.
36	
36	She was steaming at such a pace that in a minute she seemed halfway
36	between the steamboat and the Martians--a diminishing black bulk
36	against the receding horizontal expanse of the Essex coast.
36	
36	Suddenly the foremost Martian lowered his tube and discharged a
36	canister of the black gas at the ironclad.  It hit her larboard side
36	and glanced off in an inky jet that rolled away to seaward, an
36	unfolding torrent of Black Smoke, from which the ironclad drove clear.
36	To the watchers from the steamer, low in the water and with the sun in
36	their eyes, it seemed as though she were already among the Martians.
36	
36	They saw the gaunt figures separating and rising out of the water
36	as they retreated shoreward, and one of them raised the camera-like
36	generator of the Heat-Ray.  He held it pointing obliquely downward,
36	and a bank of steam sprang from the water at its touch.  It must have
36	driven through the iron of the ship's side like a white-hot iron rod
36	through paper.
36	
36	A flicker of flame went up through the rising steam, and then the
36	Martian reeled and staggered.  In another moment he was cut down, and
36	a great body of water and steam shot high in the air.  The guns of the
36	_Thunder Child_ sounded through the reek, going off one after the other,
36	and one shot splashed the water high close by the steamer, ricocheted
36	towards the other flying ships to the north, and smashed a smack to
36	matchwood.
36	
36	But no one heeded that very much.  At the sight of the Martian's
36	collapse the captain on the bridge yelled inarticulately, and all the
36	crowding passengers on the steamer's stern shouted together.  And then
36	they yelled again.  For, surging out beyond the white tumult, drove
36	something long and black, the flames streaming from its middle parts,
36	its ventilators and funnels spouting fire.
36	
36	She was alive still; the steering gear, it seems, was intact and
36	her engines working.  She headed straight for a second Martian, and
36	was within a hundred yards of him when the Heat-Ray came to bear.  Then
36	with a violent thud, a blinding flash, her decks, her funnels, leaped
36	upward.  The Martian staggered with the violence of her explosion, and
36	in another moment the flaming wreckage, still driving forward with the
36	impetus of its pace, had struck him and crumpled him up like a thing
36	of cardboard.  My brother shouted involuntarily.  A boiling tumult of
36	steam hid everything again.
36	
36	""Two!"" yelled the captain.
36	
36	Everyone was shouting.  The whole steamer from end to end rang with
36	frantic cheering that was taken up first by one and then by all in the
36	crowding multitude of ships and boats that was driving out to sea.
36	
36	The steam hung upon the water for many minutes, hiding the third
36	Martian and the coast altogether.  And all this time the boat was
36	paddling steadily out to sea and away from the fight; and when at last
36	the confusion cleared, the drifting bank of black vapour intervened,
36	and nothing of the _Thunder Child_ could be made out, nor could the
36	third Martian be seen.  But the ironclads to seaward were now quite
36	close and standing in towards shore past the steamboat.
36	
36	The little vessel continued to beat its way seaward, and the
36	ironclads receded slowly towards the coast, which was hidden still by
36	a marbled bank of vapour, part steam, part black gas, eddying and
36	combining in the strangest way.  The fleet of refugees was scattering
36	to the northeast; several smacks were sailing between the ironclads
36	and the steamboat.  After a time, and before they reached the sinking
36	cloud bank, the warships turned northward, and then abruptly went
36	about and passed into the thickening haze of evening southward.  The
36	coast grew faint, and at last indistinguishable amid the low banks of
36	clouds that were gathering about the sinking sun.
36	
36	Then suddenly out of the golden haze of the sunset came the
36	vibration of guns, and a form of black shadows moving.  Everyone
36	struggled to the rail of the steamer and peered into the blinding
36	furnace of the west, but nothing was to be distinguished clearly.  A
36	mass of smoke rose slanting and barred the face of the sun.  The
36	steamboat throbbed on its way through an interminable suspense.
36	
36	The sun sank into grey clouds, the sky flushed and darkened, the
36	evening star trembled into sight.  It was deep twilight when the
36	captain cried out and pointed.  My brother strained his eyes.
36	Something rushed up into the sky out of the greyness--rushed
36	slantingly upward and very swiftly into the luminous clearness above
36	the clouds in the western sky; something flat and broad, and very
36	large, that swept round in a vast curve, grew smaller, sank slowly,
36	and vanished again into the grey mystery of the night.  And as it flew
36	it rained down darkness upon the land.
36	
36	
36	
36	BOOK TWO
36	
36	THE EARTH UNDER THE MARTIANS
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER ONE
36	
36	UNDER FOOT
36	
36	
36	In the first book I have wandered so much from my own adventures to
36	tell of the experiences of my brother that all through the last two
36	chapters I and the curate have been lurking in the empty house at
36	Halliford whither we fled to escape the Black Smoke.  There I will
36	resume.  We stopped there all Sunday night and all the next day--the
36	day of the panic--in a little island of daylight, cut off by the Black
36	Smoke from the rest of the world.  We could do nothing but wait in
36	aching inactivity during those two weary days.
36	
36	My mind was occupied by anxiety for my wife.  I figured her at
36	Leatherhead, terrified, in danger, mourning me already as a dead man.
36	I paced the rooms and cried aloud when I thought of how I was cut off
36	from her, of all that might happen to her in my absence.  My cousin I
36	knew was brave enough for any emergency, but he was not the sort of
36	man to realise danger quickly, to rise promptly.  What was needed now
36	was not bravery, but circumspection.  My only consolation was to
36	believe that the Martians were moving London-ward and away from her.
36	Such vague anxieties keep the mind sensitive and painful.  I grew very
36	weary and irritable with the curate's perpetual ejaculations; I tired
36	of the sight of his selfish despair.  After some ineffectual
36	remonstrance I kept away from him, staying in a room--evidently a
36	children's schoolroom--containing globes, forms, and copybooks.  When
36	he followed me thither, I went to a box room at the top of the house
36	and, in order to be alone with my aching miseries, locked myself in.
36	
36	We were hopelessly hemmed in by the Black Smoke all that day and
36	the morning of the next.  There were signs of people in the next house
36	on Sunday evening--a face at a window and moving lights, and later the
36	slamming of a door.  But I do not know who these people were, nor what
36	became of them.  We saw nothing of them next day.  The Black Smoke
36	drifted slowly riverward all through Monday morning, creeping nearer
36	and nearer to us, driving at last along the roadway outside the house
36	that hid us.
36	
36	A Martian came across the fields about midday, laying the stuff
36	with a jet of superheated steam that hissed against the walls, smashed
36	all the windows it touched, and scalded the curate's hand as he fled
36	out of the front room.  When at last we crept across the sodden rooms
36	and looked out again, the country northward was as though a black
36	snowstorm had passed over it.  Looking towards the river, we were
36	astonished to see an unaccountable redness mingling with the black of
36	the scorched meadows.
36	
36	For a time we did not see how this change affected our position,
36	save that we were relieved of our fear of the Black Smoke.  But later
36	I perceived that we were no longer hemmed in, that now we might get
36	away.  So soon as I realised that the way of escape was open, my dream
36	of action returned.  But the curate was lethargic, unreasonable.
36	
36	""We are safe here,"" he repeated; ""safe here.""
36	
36	I resolved to leave him--would that I had!  Wiser now for the
36	artilleryman's teaching, I sought out food and drink.  I had found oil
36	and rags for my burns, and I also took a hat and a flannel shirt that
36	I found in one of the bedrooms.  When it was clear to him that I meant
36	to go alone--had reconciled myself to going alone--he suddenly roused
36	himself to come.  And all being quiet throughout the afternoon, we
36	started about five o'clock, as I should judge, along the blackened
36	road to Sunbury.
36	
36	In Sunbury, and at intervals along the road, were dead bodies lying
36	in contorted attitudes, horses as well as men, overturned carts and
36	luggage, all covered thickly with black dust.  That pall of cindery
36	powder made me think of what I had read of the destruction of Pompeii.
36	We got to Hampton Court without misadventure, our minds full of
36	strange and unfamiliar appearances, and at Hampton Court our eyes were
36	relieved to find a patch of green that had escaped the suffocating
36	drift.  We went through Bushey Park, with its deer going to and fro
36	under the chestnuts, and some men and women hurrying in the distance
36	towards Hampton, and so we came to Twickenham.  These were the first
36	people we saw.
36	
36	Away across the road the woods beyond Ham and Petersham were still
36	afire.  Twickenham was uninjured by either Heat-Ray or Black Smoke,
36	and there were more people about here, though none could give us news.
36	For the most part they were like ourselves, taking advantage of a lull
36	to shift their quarters.  I have an impression that many of the houses
36	here were still occupied by scared inhabitants, too frightened even
36	for flight.  Here too the evidence of a hasty rout was abundant along
36	the road.  I remember most vividly three smashed bicycles in a heap,
36	pounded into the road by the wheels of subsequent carts.  We crossed
36	Richmond Bridge about half past eight.  We hurried across the exposed
36	bridge, of course, but I noticed floating down the stream a number
36	of red masses, some many feet across.  I did not know what these
36	were--there was no time for scrutiny--and I put a more horrible
36	interpretation on them than they deserved.  Here again on the Surrey
36	side were black dust that had once been smoke, and dead bodies--a heap
36	near the approach to the station; but we had no glimpse of the
36	Martians until we were some way towards Barnes.
36	
36	We saw in the blackened distance a group of three people running
36	down a side street towards the river, but otherwise it seemed
36	deserted.  Up the hill Richmond town was burning briskly; outside the
36	town of Richmond there was no trace of the Black Smoke.
36	
36	Then suddenly, as we approached Kew, came a number of people
36	running, and the upperworks of a Martian fighting-machine loomed in
36	sight over the housetops, not a hundred yards away from us.  We stood
36	aghast at our danger, and had the Martian looked down we must
36	immediately have perished.  We were so terrified that we dared not go
36	on, but turned aside and hid in a shed in a garden.  There the curate
36	crouched, weeping silently, and refusing to stir again.
36	
36	But my fixed idea of reaching Leatherhead would not let me rest,
36	and in the twilight I ventured out again.  I went through a shrubbery,
36	and along a passage beside a big house standing in its own grounds,
36	and so emerged upon the road towards Kew.  The curate I left in the
36	shed, but he came hurrying after me.
36	
36	That second start was the most foolhardy thing I ever did.  For it
36	was manifest the Martians were about us.  No sooner had the curate
36	overtaken me than we saw either the fighting-machine we had seen
36	before or another, far away across the meadows in the direction of Kew
36	Lodge.  Four or five little black figures hurried before it across the
36	green-grey of the field, and in a moment it was evident this Martian
36	pursued them.  In three strides he was among them, and they ran
36	radiating from his feet in all directions.  He used no Heat-Ray to
36	destroy them, but picked them up one by one.  Apparently he tossed
36	them into the great metallic carrier which projected behind him, much
36	as a workman's basket hangs over his shoulder.
36	
36	It was the first time I realised that the Martians might have any
36	other purpose than destruction with defeated humanity.  We stood for a
36	moment petrified, then turned and fled through a gate behind us into a
36	walled garden, fell into, rather than found, a fortunate ditch, and
36	lay there, scarce daring to whisper to each other until the stars were
36	out.
36	
36	I suppose it was nearly eleven o'clock before we gathered courage
36	to start again, no longer venturing into the road, but sneaking along
36	hedgerows and through plantations, and watching keenly through the
36	darkness, he on the right and I on the left, for the Martians, who
36	seemed to be all about us.  In one place we blundered upon a scorched
36	and blackened area, now cooling and ashen, and a number of scattered
36	dead bodies of men, burned horribly about the heads and trunks but
36	with their legs and boots mostly intact; and of dead horses, fifty
36	feet, perhaps, behind a line of four ripped guns and smashed gun
36	carriages.
36	
36	Sheen, it seemed, had escaped destruction, but the place was silent
36	and deserted.  Here we happened on no dead, though the night was too
36	dark for us to see into the side roads of the place.  In Sheen my
36	companion suddenly complained of faintness and thirst, and we decided
36	to try one of the houses.
36	
36	The first house we entered, after a little difficulty with the
36	window, was a small semi-detached villa, and I found nothing eatable
36	left in the place but some mouldy cheese.  There was, however, water
36	to drink; and I took a hatchet, which promised to be useful in our
36	next house-breaking.
36	
36	We then crossed to a place where the road turns towards Mortlake.
36	Here there stood a white house within a walled garden, and in the
36	pantry of this domicile we found a store of food--two loaves of bread
36	in a pan, an uncooked steak, and the half of a ham.  I give this
36	catalogue so precisely because, as it happened, we were destined to
36	subsist upon this store for the next fortnight.  Bottled beer stood
36	under a shelf, and there were two bags of haricot beans and some limp
36	lettuces.  This pantry opened into a kind of wash-up kitchen, and in
36	this was firewood; there was also a cupboard, in which we found nearly
36	a dozen of burgundy, tinned soups and salmon, and two tins of
36	biscuits.
36	
36	We sat in the adjacent kitchen in the dark--for we dared not strike
36	a light--and ate bread and ham, and drank beer out of the same bottle.
36	The curate, who was still timorous and restless, was now, oddly
36	enough, for pushing on, and I was urging him to keep up his strength
36	by eating when the thing happened that was to imprison us.
36	
36	""It can't be midnight yet,"" I said, and then came a blinding glare
36	of vivid green light.  Everything in the kitchen leaped out, clearly
36	visible in green and black, and vanished again.  And then followed such
36	a concussion as I have never heard before or since.  So close on the
36	heels of this as to seem instantaneous came a thud behind me, a clash
36	of glass, a crash and rattle of falling masonry all about us, and the
36	plaster of the ceiling came down upon us, smashing into a multitude of
36	fragments upon our heads.  I was knocked headlong across the floor
36	against the oven handle and stunned.  I was insensible for a long
36	time, the curate told me, and when I came to we were in darkness
36	again, and he, with a face wet, as I found afterwards, with blood from
36	a cut forehead, was dabbing water over me.
36	
36	For some time I could not recollect what had happened.  Then things
36	came to me slowly.  A bruise on my temple asserted itself.
36	
36	""Are you better?"" asked the curate in a whisper.
36	
36	At last I answered him.  I sat up.
36	
36	""Don't move,"" he said.  ""The floor is covered with smashed crockery
36	from the dresser.  You can't possibly move without making a noise, and
36	I fancy _they_ are outside.""
36	
36	We both sat quite silent, so that we could scarcely hear each other
36	breathing.  Everything seemed deadly still, but once something near
36	us, some plaster or broken brickwork, slid down with a rumbling sound.
36	Outside and very near was an intermittent, metallic rattle.
36	
36	""That!"" said the curate, when presently it happened again.
36	
36	""Yes,"" I said.  ""But what is it?""
36	
36	""A Martian!"" said the curate.
36	
36	I listened again.
36	
36	""It was not like the Heat-Ray,"" I said, and for a time I was
36	inclined to think one of the great fighting-machines had stumbled
36	against the house, as I had seen one stumble against the tower of
36	Shepperton Church.
36	
36	Our situation was so strange and incomprehensible that for three or
36	four hours, until the dawn came, we scarcely moved.  And then the light
36	filtered in, not through the window, which remained black, but through
36	a triangular aperture between a beam and a heap of broken bricks in
36	the wall behind us.  The interior of the kitchen we now saw greyly for
36	the first time.
36	
36	The window had been burst in by a mass of garden mould, which
36	flowed over the table upon which we had been sitting and lay about our
36	feet.  Outside, the soil was banked high against the house.  At the
36	top of the window frame we could see an uprooted drainpipe.  The floor
36	was littered with smashed hardware; the end of the kitchen towards the
36	house was broken into, and since the daylight shone in there, it was
36	evident the greater part of the house had collapsed.  Contrasting
36	vividly with this ruin was the neat dresser, stained in the fashion,
36	pale green, and with a number of copper and tin vessels below it, the
36	wallpaper imitating blue and white tiles, and a couple of coloured
36	supplements fluttering from the walls above the kitchen range.
36	
36	As the dawn grew clearer, we saw through the gap in the wall the
36	body of a Martian, standing sentinel, I suppose, over the still
36	glowing cylinder.  At the sight of that we crawled as circumspectly as
36	possible out of the twilight of the kitchen into the darkness of the
36	scullery.
36	
36	Abruptly the right interpretation dawned upon my mind.
36	
36	""The fifth cylinder,"" I whispered, ""the fifth shot from Mars, has
36	struck this house and buried us under the ruins!""
36	
36	For a time the curate was silent, and then he whispered:
36	
36	""God have mercy upon us!""
36	
36	I heard him presently whimpering to himself.
36	
36	Save for that sound we lay quite still in the scullery; I for my
36	part scarce dared breathe, and sat with my eyes fixed on the faint
36	light of the kitchen door.  I could just see the curate's face, a dim,
36	oval shape, and his collar and cuffs.  Outside there began a metallic
36	hammering, then a violent hooting, and then again, after a quiet
36	interval, a hissing like the hissing of an engine.  These noises, for
36	the most part problematical, continued intermittently, and seemed if
36	anything to increase in number as time wore on.  Presently a measured
36	thudding and a vibration that made everything about us quiver and the
36	vessels in the pantry ring and shift, began and continued.  Once the
36	light was eclipsed, and the ghostly kitchen doorway became absolutely
36	dark.  For many hours we must have crouched there, silent and
36	shivering, until our tired attention failed. . . .
36	
36	At last I found myself awake and very hungry.  I am inclined to
36	believe we must have spent the greater portion of a day before that
36	awakening.  My hunger was at a stride so insistent that it moved me to
36	action.  I told the curate I was going to seek food, and felt my way
36	towards the pantry.  He made me no answer, but so soon as I began
36	eating the faint noise I made stirred him up and I heard him crawling
36	after me.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER TWO
36	
36	WHAT WE SAW FROM THE RUINED HOUSE
36	
36	
36	After eating we crept back to the scullery, and there I must have
36	dozed again, for when presently I looked round I was alone.  The
36	thudding vibration continued with wearisome persistence.  I whispered
36	for the curate several times, and at last felt my way to the door of
36	the kitchen.  It was still daylight, and I perceived him across the
36	room, lying against the triangular hole that looked out upon the
36	Martians.  His shoulders were hunched, so that his head was hidden
36	from me.
36	
36	I could hear a number of noises almost like those in an engine
36	shed; and the place rocked with that beating thud.  Through the
36	aperture in the wall I could see the top of a tree touched with gold
36	and the warm blue of a tranquil evening sky.  For a minute or so I
36	remained watching the curate, and then I advanced, crouching and
36	stepping with extreme care amid the broken crockery that littered the
36	floor.
36	
36	I touched the curate's leg, and he started so violently that a mass
36	of plaster went sliding down outside and fell with a loud impact.  I
36	gripped his arm, fearing he might cry out, and for a long time we
36	crouched motionless.  Then I turned to see how much of our rampart
36	remained.  The detachment of the plaster had left a vertical slit open
36	in the debris, and by raising myself cautiously across a beam I was
36	able to see out of this gap into what had been overnight a quiet
36	suburban roadway.  Vast, indeed, was the change that we beheld.
36	
36	The fifth cylinder must have fallen right into the midst of the
36	house we had first visited.  The building had vanished, completely
36	smashed, pulverised, and dispersed by the blow.  The cylinder lay now
36	far beneath the original foundations--deep in a hole, already vastly
36	larger than the pit I had looked into at Woking.  The earth all round
36	it had splashed under that tremendous impact--""splashed"" is the only
36	word--and lay in heaped piles that hid the masses of the adjacent
36	houses.  It had behaved exactly like mud under the violent blow of a
36	hammer.  Our house had collapsed backward; the front portion, even on
36	the ground floor, had been destroyed completely; by a chance the
36	kitchen and scullery had escaped, and stood buried now under soil and
36	ruins, closed in by tons of earth on every side save towards the
36	cylinder.  Over that aspect we hung now on the very edge of the great
36	circular pit the Martians were engaged in making.  The heavy beating
36	sound was evidently just behind us, and ever and again a bright green
36	vapour drove up like a veil across our peephole.
36	
36	The cylinder was already opened in the centre of the pit, and on
36	the farther edge of the pit, amid the smashed and gravel-heaped
36	shrubbery, one of the great fighting-machines, deserted by its
36	occupant, stood stiff and tall against the evening sky.  At first I
36	scarcely noticed the pit and the cylinder, although it has been
36	convenient to describe them first, on account of the extraordinary
36	glittering mechanism I saw busy in the excavation, and on account of
36	the strange creatures that were crawling slowly and painfully across
36	the heaped mould near it.
36	
36	The mechanism it certainly was that held my attention first.  It
36	was one of those complicated fabrics that have since been called
36	handling-machines, and the study of which has already given such an
36	enormous impetus to terrestrial invention.  As it dawned upon me
36	first, it presented a sort of metallic spider with five jointed,
36	agile legs, and with an extraordinary number of jointed levers, bars,
36	and reaching and clutching tentacles about its body.  Most of its
36	arms were retracted, but with three long tentacles it was fishing
36	out a number of rods, plates, and bars which lined the covering and
36	apparently strengthened the walls of the cylinder.  These, as it
36	extracted them, were lifted out and deposited upon a level surface
36	of earth behind it.
36	
36	Its motion was so swift, complex, and perfect that at first I did
36	not see it as a machine, in spite of its metallic glitter.  The
36	fighting-machines were coordinated and animated to an extraordinary
36	pitch, but nothing to compare with this.  People who have never seen
36	these structures, and have only the ill-imagined efforts of artists or
36	the imperfect descriptions of such eye-witnesses as myself to go upon,
36	scarcely realise that living quality.
36	
36	I recall particularly the illustration of one of the first
36	pamphlets to give a consecutive account of the war.  The artist had
36	evidently made a hasty study of one of the fighting-machines, and
36	there his knowledge ended.  He presented them as tilted, stiff
36	tripods, without either flexibility or subtlety, and with an
36	altogether misleading monotony of effect.  The pamphlet containing
36	these renderings had a considerable vogue, and I mention them here
36	simply to warn the reader against the impression they may have
36	created.  They were no more like the Martians I saw in action than a
36	Dutch doll is like a human being.  To my mind, the pamphlet would have
36	been much better without them.
36	
36	At first, I say, the handling-machine did not impress me as a
36	machine, but as a crablike creature with a glittering integument, the
36	controlling Martian whose delicate tentacles actuated its movements
36	seeming to be simply the equivalent of the crab's cerebral portion.
36	But then I perceived the resemblance of its grey-brown, shiny,
36	leathery integument to that of the other sprawling bodies beyond, and
36	the true nature of this dexterous workman dawned upon me.  With that
36	realisation my interest shifted to those other creatures, the real
36	Martians.  Already I had had a transient impression of these, and the
36	first nausea no longer obscured my observation.  Moreover, I was
36	concealed and motionless, and under no urgency of action.
36	
36	They were, I now saw, the most unearthly creatures it is possible
36	to conceive.  They were huge round bodies--or, rather, heads--about
36	four feet in diameter, each body having in front of it a face.  This
36	face had no nostrils--indeed, the Martians do not seem to have had any
36	sense of smell, but it had a pair of very large dark-coloured eyes,
36	and just beneath this a kind of fleshy beak.  In the back of this head
36	or body--I scarcely know how to speak of it--was the single tight
36	tympanic surface, since known to be anatomically an ear, though it
36	must have been almost useless in our dense air.  In a group round the
36	mouth were sixteen slender, almost whiplike tentacles, arranged in two
36	bunches of eight each.  These bunches have since been named rather
36	aptly, by that distinguished anatomist, Professor Howes, the _hands_.
36	Even as I saw these Martians for the first time they seemed to be
36	endeavouring to raise themselves on these hands, but of course, with
36	the increased weight of terrestrial conditions, this was impossible.
36	There is reason to suppose that on Mars they may have progressed upon
36	them with some facility.
36	
36	The internal anatomy, I may remark here, as dissection has since
36	shown, was almost equally simple.  The greater part of the structure
36	was the brain, sending enormous nerves to the eyes, ear, and tactile
36	tentacles.  Besides this were the bulky lungs, into which the mouth
36	opened, and the heart and its vessels.  The pulmonary distress caused
36	by the denser atmosphere and greater gravitational attraction was only
36	too evident in the convulsive movements of the outer skin.
36	
36	And this was the sum of the Martian organs.  Strange as it may seem
36	to a human being, all the complex apparatus of digestion, which makes
36	up the bulk of our bodies, did not exist in the Martians.  They were
36	heads--merely heads.  Entrails they had none.  They did not eat, much
36	less digest.  Instead, they took the fresh, living blood of other
36	creatures, and _injected_ it into their own veins.  I have myself seen
36	this being done, as I shall mention in its place.  But, squeamish as I
36	may seem, I cannot bring myself to describe what I could not endure
36	even to continue watching.  Let it suffice to say, blood obtained from
36	a still living animal, in most cases from a human being, was run
36	directly by means of a little pipette into the recipient canal. . . .
36	
36	The bare idea of this is no doubt horribly repulsive to us, but at
36	the same time I think that we should remember how repulsive our
36	carnivorous habits would seem to an intelligent rabbit.
36	
36	The physiological advantages of the practice of injection are
36	undeniable, if one thinks of the tremendous waste of human time and
36	energy occasioned by eating and the digestive process.  Our bodies are
36	half made up of glands and tubes and organs, occupied in turning
36	heterogeneous food into blood.  The digestive processes and their
36	reaction upon the nervous system sap our strength and colour our
36	minds.  Men go happy or miserable as they have healthy or unhealthy
36	livers, or sound gastric glands.  But the Martians were lifted above
36	all these organic fluctuations of mood and emotion.
36	
36	Their undeniable preference for men as their source of nourishment
36	is partly explained by the nature of the remains of the victims they
36	had brought with them as provisions from Mars.  These creatures, to
36	judge from the shrivelled remains that have fallen into human hands,
36	were bipeds with flimsy, silicious skeletons (almost like those of the
36	silicious sponges) and feeble musculature, standing about six feet
36	high and having round, erect heads, and large eyes in flinty sockets.
36	Two or three of these seem to have been brought in each cylinder, and
36	all were killed before earth was reached.  It was just as well for
36	them, for the mere attempt to stand upright upon our planet would have
36	broken every bone in their bodies.
36	
36	And while I am engaged in this description, I may add in this place
36	certain further details which, although they were not all evident to
36	us at the time, will enable the reader who is unacquainted with them
36	to form a clearer picture of these offensive creatures.
36	
36	In three other points their physiology differed strangely from
36	ours.  Their organisms did not sleep, any more than the heart of man
36	sleeps.  Since they had no extensive muscular mechanism to recuperate,
36	that periodical extinction was unknown to them.  They had little or
36	no sense of fatigue, it would seem.  On earth they could never have
36	moved without effort, yet even to the last they kept in action.  In
36	twenty-four hours they did twenty-four hours of work, as even on earth
36	is perhaps the case with the ants.
36	
36	In the next place, wonderful as it seems in a sexual world, the
36	Martians were absolutely without sex, and therefore without any of the
36	tumultuous emotions that arise from that difference among men.  A
36	young Martian, there can now be no dispute, was really born upon earth
36	during the war, and it was found attached to its parent, partially
36	_budded_ off, just as young lilybulbs bud off, or like the young animals
36	in the fresh-water polyp.
36	
36	In man, in all the higher terrestrial animals, such a method of
36	increase has disappeared; but even on this earth it was certainly the
36	primitive method.  Among the lower animals, up even to those first
36	cousins of the vertebrated animals, the Tunicates, the two processes
36	occur side by side, but finally the sexual method superseded its
36	competitor altogether.  On Mars, however, just the reverse has
36	apparently been the case.
36	
36	It is worthy of remark that a certain speculative writer of
36	quasi-scientific repute, writing long before the Martian invasion, did
36	forecast for man a final structure not unlike the actual Martian
36	condition.  His prophecy, I remember, appeared in November or
36	December, 1893, in a long-defunct publication, the _Pall Mall Budget_,
36	and I recall a caricature of it in a pre-Martian periodical called
36	_Punch_.  He pointed out--writing in a foolish, facetious tone--that the
36	perfection of mechanical appliances must ultimately supersede limbs;
36	the perfection of chemical devices, digestion; that such organs as
36	hair, external nose, teeth, ears, and chin were no longer essential
36	parts of the human being, and that the tendency of natural selection
36	would lie in the direction of their steady diminution through the
36	coming ages.  The brain alone remained a cardinal necessity.  Only one
36	other part of the body had a strong case for survival, and that was
36	the hand, ""teacher and agent of the brain.""  While the rest of the
36	body dwindled, the hands would grow larger.
36	
36	There is many a true word written in jest, and here in the Martians
36	we have beyond dispute the actual accomplishment of such a suppression
36	of the animal side of the organism by the intelligence.  To me it is
36	quite credible that the Martians may be descended from beings not
36	unlike ourselves, by a gradual development of brain and hands (the
36	latter giving rise to the two bunches of delicate tentacles at last)
36	at the expense of the rest of the body.  Without the body the brain
36	would, of course, become a mere selfish intelligence, without any of
36	the emotional substratum of the human being.
36	
36	The last salient point in which the systems of these creatures
36	differed from ours was in what one might have thought a very trivial
36	particular.  Micro-organisms, which cause so much disease and pain on
36	earth, have either never appeared upon Mars or Martian sanitary
36	science eliminated them ages ago.  A hundred diseases, all the fevers
36	and contagions of human life, consumption, cancers, tumours and such
36	morbidities, never enter the scheme of their life.  And speaking of
36	the differences between the life on Mars and terrestrial life, I may
36	allude here to the curious suggestions of the red weed.
36	
36	Apparently the vegetable kingdom in Mars, instead of having green
36	for a dominant colour, is of a vivid blood-red tint.  At any rate, the
36	seeds which the Martians (intentionally or accidentally) brought with
36	them gave rise in all cases to red-coloured growths.  Only that known
36	popularly as the red weed, however, gained any footing in competition
36	with terrestrial forms.  The red creeper was quite a transitory
36	growth, and few people have seen it growing.  For a time, however, the
36	red weed grew with astonishing vigour and luxuriance.  It spread up
36	the sides of the pit by the third or fourth day of our imprisonment,
36	and its cactus-like branches formed a carmine fringe to the edges of
36	our triangular window.  And afterwards I found it broadcast throughout
36	the country, and especially wherever there was a stream of water.
36	
36	The Martians had what appears to have been an auditory organ, a
36	single round drum at the back of the head-body, and eyes with a visual
36	range not very different from ours except that, according to Philips,
36	blue and violet were as black to them.  It is commonly supposed that
36	they communicated by sounds and tentacular gesticulations; this is
36	asserted, for instance, in the able but hastily compiled pamphlet
36	(written evidently by someone not an eye-witness of Martian actions)
36	to which I have already alluded, and which, so far, has been the chief
36	source of information concerning them.  Now no surviving human being
36	saw so much of the Martians in action as I did.  I take no credit to
36	myself for an accident, but the fact is so.  And I assert that I
36	watched them closely time after time, and that I have seen four, five,
36	and (once) six of them sluggishly performing the most elaborately
36	complicated operations together without either sound or gesture.  Their
36	peculiar hooting invariably preceded feeding; it had no modulation,
36	and was, I believe, in no sense a signal, but merely the expiration of
36	air preparatory to the suctional operation.  I have a certain claim to
36	at least an elementary knowledge of psychology, and in this matter I
36	am convinced--as firmly as I am convinced of anything--that the
36	Martians interchanged thoughts without any physical intermediation.
36	And I have been convinced of this in spite of strong preconceptions.
36	Before the Martian invasion, as an occasional reader here or there may
36	remember, I had written with some little vehemence against the
36	telepathic theory.
36	
36	The Martians wore no clothing.  Their conceptions of ornament and
36	decorum were necessarily different from ours; and not only were they
36	evidently much less sensible of changes of temperature than we are,
36	but changes of pressure do not seem to have affected their health at
36	all seriously.  Yet though they wore no clothing, it was in the other
36	artificial additions to their bodily resources that their great
36	superiority over man lay.  We men, with our bicycles and road-skates,
36	our Lilienthal soaring-machines, our guns and sticks and so forth, are
36	just in the beginning of the evolution that the Martians have worked
36	out.  They have become practically mere brains, wearing different
36	bodies according to their needs just as men wear suits of clothes and
36	take a bicycle in a hurry or an umbrella in the wet.  And of their
36	appliances, perhaps nothing is more wonderful to a man than the
36	curious fact that what is the dominant feature of almost all human
36	devices in mechanism is absent--the _wheel_ is absent; among all the
36	things they brought to earth there is no trace or suggestion of their
36	use of wheels.  One would have at least expected it in locomotion.  And
36	in this connection it is curious to remark that even on this earth
36	Nature has never hit upon the wheel, or has preferred other expedients
36	to its development.  And not only did the Martians either not know of
36	(which is incredible), or abstain from, the wheel, but in their
36	apparatus singularly little use is made of the fixed pivot or
36	relatively fixed pivot, with circular motions thereabout confined
36	to one plane.  Almost all the joints of the machinery present a
36	complicated system of sliding parts moving over small but beautifully
36	curved friction bearings.  And while upon this matter of detail, it is
36	remarkable that the long leverages of their machines are in most cases
36	actuated by a sort of sham musculature of the disks in an elastic
36	sheath; these disks become polarised and drawn closely and powerfully
36	together when traversed by a current of electricity.  In this way the
36	curious parallelism to animal motions, which was so striking and
36	disturbing to the human beholder, was attained.  Such quasi-muscles
36	abounded in the crablike handling-machine which, on my first peeping
36	out of the slit, I watched unpacking the cylinder.  It seemed
36	infinitely more alive than the actual Martians lying beyond it in the
36	sunset light, panting, stirring ineffectual tentacles, and moving
36	feebly after their vast journey across space.
36	
36	While I was still watching their sluggish motions in the sunlight,
36	and noting each strange detail of their form, the curate reminded me
36	of his presence by pulling violently at my arm.  I turned to a
36	scowling face, and silent, eloquent lips.  He wanted the slit, which
36	permitted only one of us to peep through; and so I had to forego
36	watching them for a time while he enjoyed that privilege.
36	
36	When I looked again, the busy handling-machine had already put
36	together several of the pieces of apparatus it had taken out of the
36	cylinder into a shape having an unmistakable likeness to its own; and
36	down on the left a busy little digging mechanism had come into view,
36	emitting jets of green vapour and working its way round the pit,
36	excavating and embanking in a methodical and discriminating manner.
36	This it was which had caused the regular beating noise, and the
36	rhythmic shocks that had kept our ruinous refuge quivering.  It piped
36	and whistled as it worked.  So far as I could see, the thing was
36	without a directing Martian at all.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER THREE
36	
36	THE DAYS OF IMPRISONMENT
36	
36	
36	The arrival of a second fighting-machine drove us from our peephole
36	into the scullery, for we feared that from his elevation the Martian
36	might see down upon us behind our barrier.  At a later date we began
36	to feel less in danger of their eyes, for to an eye in the dazzle of
36	the sunlight outside our refuge must have been blank blackness, but at
36	first the slightest suggestion of approach drove us into the scullery
36	in heart-throbbing retreat.  Yet terrible as was the danger we
36	incurred, the attraction of peeping was for both of us irresistible.
36	And I recall now with a sort of wonder that, in spite of the infinite
36	danger in which we were between starvation and a still more terrible
36	death, we could yet struggle bitterly for that horrible privilege of
36	sight.  We would race across the kitchen in a grotesque way between
36	eagerness and the dread of making a noise, and strike each other, and
36	thrust and kick, within a few inches of exposure.
36	
36	The fact is that we had absolutely incompatible dispositions and
36	habits of thought and action, and our danger and isolation only
36	accentuated the incompatibility.  At Halliford I had already come to
36	hate the curate's trick of helpless exclamation, his stupid rigidity
36	of mind.  His endless muttering monologue vitiated every effort I made
36	to think out a line of action, and drove me at times, thus pent up and
36	intensified, almost to the verge of craziness.  He was as lacking in
36	restraint as a silly woman.  He would weep for hours together, and I
36	verily believe that to the very end this spoiled child of life thought
36	his weak tears in some way efficacious.  And I would sit in the
36	darkness unable to keep my mind off him by reason of his
36	importunities.  He ate more than I did, and it was in vain I pointed
36	out that our only chance of life was to stop in the house until the
36	Martians had done with their pit, that in that long patience a time
36	might presently come when we should need food.  He ate and drank
36	impulsively in heavy meals at long intervals.  He slept little.
36	
36	As the days wore on, his utter carelessness of any consideration so
36	intensified our distress and danger that I had, much as I loathed
36	doing it, to resort to threats, and at last to blows.  That brought him
36	to reason for a time.  But he was one of those weak creatures, void of
36	pride, timorous, anaemic, hateful souls, full of shifty cunning, who
36	face neither God nor man, who face not even themselves.
36	
36	It is disagreeable for me to recall and write these things, but I
36	set them down that my story may lack nothing.  Those who have escaped
36	the dark and terrible aspects of life will find my brutality, my flash
36	of rage in our final tragedy, easy enough to blame; for they know what
36	is wrong as well as any, but not what is possible to tortured men.  But
36	those who have been under the shadow, who have gone down at last to
36	elemental things, will have a wider charity.
36	
36	And while within we fought out our dark, dim contest of whispers,
36	snatched food and drink, and gripping hands and blows, without, in the
36	pitiless sunlight of that terrible June, was the strange wonder, the
36	unfamiliar routine of the Martians in the pit.  Let me return to those
36	first new experiences of mine.  After a long time I ventured back to
36	the peephole, to find that the new-comers had been reinforced by the
36	occupants of no fewer than three of the fighting-machines.  These last
36	had brought with them certain fresh appliances that stood in an
36	orderly manner about the cylinder.  The second handling-machine was now
36	completed, and was busied in serving one of the novel contrivances the
36	big machine had brought.  This was a body resembling a milk can in its
36	general form, above which oscillated a pear-shaped receptacle, and
36	from which a stream of white powder flowed into a circular basin
36	below.
36	
36	The oscillatory motion was imparted to this by one tentacle of the
36	handling-machine.  With two spatulate hands the handling-machine was
36	digging out and flinging masses of clay into the pear-shaped
36	receptacle above, while with another arm it periodically opened a door
36	and removed rusty and blackened clinkers from the middle part of the
36	machine.  Another steely tentacle directed the powder from the basin
36	along a ribbed channel towards some receiver that was hidden from me
36	by the mound of bluish dust.  From this unseen receiver a little
36	thread of green smoke rose vertically into the quiet air.  As I looked,
36	the handling-machine, with a faint and musical clinking, extended,
36	telescopic fashion, a tentacle that had been a moment before a mere
36	blunt projection, until its end was hidden behind the mound of clay.
36	In another second it had lifted a bar of white aluminium into sight,
36	untarnished as yet, and shining dazzlingly, and deposited it in a
36	growing stack of bars that stood at the side of the pit.  Between
36	sunset and starlight this dexterous machine must have made more than a
36	hundred such bars out of the crude clay, and the mound of bluish dust
36	rose steadily until it topped the side of the pit.
36	
36	The contrast between the swift and complex movements of these
36	contrivances and the inert panting clumsiness of their masters was
36	acute, and for days I had to tell myself repeatedly that these latter
36	were indeed the living of the two things.
36	
36	The curate had possession of the slit when the first men were
36	brought to the pit.  I was sitting below, huddled up, listening with
36	all my ears.  He made a sudden movement backward, and I, fearful that
36	we were observed, crouched in a spasm of terror.  He came sliding down
36	the rubbish and crept beside me in the darkness, inarticulate,
36	gesticulating, and for a moment I shared his panic.  His gesture
36	suggested a resignation of the slit, and after a little while my
36	curiosity gave me courage, and I rose up, stepped across him, and
36	clambered up to it.  At first I could see no reason for his frantic
36	behaviour.  The twilight had now come, the stars were little and
36	faint, but the pit was illuminated by the flickering green fire that
36	came from the aluminium-making.  The whole picture was a flickering
36	scheme of green gleams and shifting rusty black shadows, strangely
36	trying to the eyes.  Over and through it all went the bats, heeding it
36	not at all.  The sprawling Martians were no longer to be seen, the
36	mound of blue-green powder had risen to cover them from sight, and a
36	fighting-machine, with its legs contracted, crumpled, and abbreviated,
36	stood across the corner of the pit.  And then, amid the clangour of
36	the machinery, came a drifting suspicion of human voices, that I
36	entertained at first only to dismiss.
36	
36	I crouched, watching this fighting-machine closely, satisfying
36	myself now for the first time that the hood did indeed contain a
36	Martian.  As the green flames lifted I could see the oily gleam of
36	his integument and the brightness of his eyes.  And suddenly I heard
36	a yell, and saw a long tentacle reaching over the shoulder of the
36	machine to the little cage that hunched upon its back.  Then
36	something--something struggling violently--was lifted high against the
36	sky, a black, vague enigma against the starlight; and as this black
36	object came down again, I saw by the green brightness that it was a
36	man.  For an instant he was clearly visible.  He was a stout, ruddy,
36	middle-aged man, well dressed; three days before, he must have been
36	walking the world, a man of considerable consequence.  I could see his
36	staring eyes and gleams of light on his studs and watch chain.  He
36	vanished behind the mound, and for a moment there was silence.  And
36	then began a shrieking and a sustained and cheerful hooting from the
36	Martians.
36	
36	I slid down the rubbish, struggled to my feet, clapped my hands
36	over my ears, and bolted into the scullery.  The curate, who had been
36	crouching silently with his arms over his head, looked up as I passed,
36	cried out quite loudly at my desertion of him, and came running after
36	me.
36	
36	That night, as we lurked in the scullery, balanced between our
36	horror and the terrible fascination this peeping had, although I felt
36	an urgent need of action I tried in vain to conceive some plan of
36	escape; but afterwards, during the second day, I was able to consider
36	our position with great clearness.  The curate, I found, was quite
36	incapable of discussion; this new and culminating atrocity had robbed
36	him of all vestiges of reason or forethought.  Practically he had
36	already sunk to the level of an animal.  But as the saying goes, I
36	gripped myself with both hands.  It grew upon my mind, once I could
36	face the facts, that terrible as our position was, there was as yet
36	no justification for absolute despair.  Our chief chance lay in the
36	possibility of the Martians making the pit nothing more than a
36	temporary encampment.  Or even if they kept it permanently, they might
36	not consider it necessary to guard it, and a chance of escape might be
36	afforded us.  I also weighed very carefully the possibility of our
36	digging a way out in a direction away from the pit, but the chances of
36	our emerging within sight of some sentinel fighting-machine seemed at
36	first too great.  And I should have had to do all the digging myself.
36	The curate would certainly have failed me.
36	
36	It was on the third day, if my memory serves me right, that I saw
36	the lad killed.  It was the only occasion on which I actually saw the
36	Martians feed.  After that experience I avoided the hole in the wall
36	for the better part of a day.  I went into the scullery, removed the
36	door, and spent some hours digging with my hatchet as silently as
36	possible; but when I had made a hole about a couple of feet deep the
36	loose earth collapsed noisily, and I did not dare continue.  I lost
36	heart, and lay down on the scullery floor for a long time, having no
36	spirit even to move.  And after that I abandoned altogether the idea
36	of escaping by excavation.
36	
36	It says much for the impression the Martians had made upon me that
36	at first I entertained little or no hope of our escape being brought
36	about by their overthrow through any human effort.  But on the fourth
36	or fifth night I heard a sound like heavy guns.
36	
36	It was very late in the night, and the moon was shining brightly.
36	The Martians had taken away the excavating-machine, and, save for a
36	fighting-machine that stood in the remoter bank of the pit and a
36	handling-machine that was buried out of my sight in a corner of the
36	pit immediately beneath my peephole, the place was deserted by them.
36	Except for the pale glow from the handling-machine and the bars and
36	patches of white moonlight the pit was in darkness, and, except for
36	the clinking of the handling-machine, quite still.  That night was a
36	beautiful serenity; save for one planet, the moon seemed to have the
36	sky to herself.  I heard a dog howling, and that familiar sound it was
36	that made me listen.  Then I heard quite distinctly a booming exactly
36	like the sound of great guns.  Six distinct reports I counted, and
36	after a long interval six again.  And that was all.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER FOUR
36	
36	THE DEATH OF THE CURATE
36	
36	
36	It was on the sixth day of our imprisonment that I peeped for the
36	last time, and presently found myself alone.  Instead of keeping close
36	to me and trying to oust me from the slit, the curate had gone back
36	into the scullery.  I was struck by a sudden thought.  I went back
36	quickly and quietly into the scullery.  In the darkness I heard the
36	curate drinking.  I snatched in the darkness, and my fingers caught a
36	bottle of burgundy.
36	
36	For a few minutes there was a tussle.  The bottle struck the floor
36	and broke, and I desisted and rose.  We stood panting and threatening
36	each other.  In the end I planted myself between him and the food, and
36	told him of my determination to begin a discipline.  I divided the
36	food in the pantry, into rations to last us ten days.  I would not let
36	him eat any more that day.  In the afternoon he made a feeble effort
36	to get at the food.  I had been dozing, but in an instant I was awake.
36	All day and all night we sat face to face, I weary but resolute, and
36	he weeping and complaining of his immediate hunger.  It was, I know, a
36	night and a day, but to me it seemed--it seems now--an interminable
36	length of time.
36	
36	And so our widened incompatibility ended at last in open conflict.
36	For two vast days we struggled in undertones and wrestling contests.
36	There were times when I beat and kicked him madly, times when I
36	cajoled and persuaded him, and once I tried to bribe him with the last
36	bottle of burgundy, for there was a rain-water pump from which I could
36	get water.  But neither force nor kindness availed; he was indeed
36	beyond reason.  He would neither desist from his attacks on the food
36	nor from his noisy babbling to himself.  The rudimentary precautions
36	to keep our imprisonment endurable he would not observe.  Slowly I
36	began to realise the complete overthrow of his intelligence, to
36	perceive that my sole companion in this close and sickly darkness was
36	a man insane.
36	
36	From certain vague memories I am inclined to think my own mind
36	wandered at times.  I had strange and hideous dreams whenever I slept.
36	It sounds paradoxical, but I am inclined to think that the weakness
36	and insanity of the curate warned me, braced me, and kept me a sane
36	man.
36	
36	On the eighth day he began to talk aloud instead of whispering, and
36	nothing I could do would moderate his speech.
36	
36	""It is just, O God!"" he would say, over and over again. ""It is
36	just.  On me and mine be the punishment laid.  We have sinned, we have
36	fallen short.  There was poverty, sorrow; the poor were trodden in
36	the dust, and I held my peace.  I preached acceptable folly--my God,
36	what folly!--when I should have stood up, though I died for it, and
36	called upon them to repent--repent! . . .  Oppressors of the poor and
36	needy . . . !  The wine press of God!""
36	
36	Then he would suddenly revert to the matter of the food I withheld
36	from him, praying, begging, weeping, at last threatening.  He began to
36	raise his voice--I prayed him not to.  He perceived a hold on me--he
36	threatened he would shout and bring the Martians upon us.  For a time
36	that scared me; but any concession would have shortened our chance of
36	escape beyond estimating.  I defied him, although I felt no assurance
36	that he might not do this thing.  But that day, at any rate, he did
36	not.  He talked with his voice rising slowly, through the greater part
36	of the eighth and ninth days--threats, entreaties, mingled with a
36	torrent of half-sane and always frothy repentance for his vacant sham
36	of God's service, such as made me pity him.  Then he slept awhile, and
36	began again with renewed strength, so loudly that I must needs make
36	him desist.
36	
36	""Be still!"" I implored.
36	
36	He rose to his knees, for he had been sitting in the darkness near
36	the copper.
36	
36	""I have been still too long,"" he said, in a tone that must have
36	reached the pit, ""and now I must bear my witness.  Woe unto this
36	unfaithful city!  Woe!  Woe!  Woe!  Woe!  Woe! To the inhabitants of
36	the earth by reason of the other voices of the trumpet----""
36	
36	""Shut up!"" I said, rising to my feet, and in a terror lest the
36	Martians should hear us.  ""For God's sake----""
36	
36	""Nay,"" shouted the curate, at the top of his voice, standing
36	likewise and extending his arms.  ""Speak!  The word of the Lord is
36	upon me!""
36	
36	In three strides he was at the door leading into the kitchen.
36	
36	""I must bear my witness!  I go!  It has already been too long
36	delayed.""
36	
36	I put out my hand and felt the meat chopper hanging to the wall.
36	In a flash I was after him.  I was fierce with fear.  Before he was
36	halfway across the kitchen I had overtaken him.  With one last touch
36	of humanity I turned the blade back and struck him with the butt.  He
36	went headlong forward and lay stretched on the ground.  I stumbled
36	over him and stood panting.  He lay still.
36	
36	Suddenly I heard a noise without, the run and smash of slipping
36	plaster, and the triangular aperture in the wall was darkened.  I
36	looked up and saw the lower surface of a handling-machine coming
36	slowly across the hole.  One of its gripping limbs curled amid the
36	debris; another limb appeared, feeling its way over the fallen beams.
36	I stood petrified, staring.  Then I saw through a sort of glass plate
36	near the edge of the body the face, as we may call it, and the large
36	dark eyes of a Martian, peering, and then a long metallic snake of
36	tentacle came feeling slowly through the hole.
36	
36	I turned by an effort, stumbled over the curate, and stopped at the
36	scullery door.  The tentacle was now some way, two yards or more, in
36	the room, and twisting and turning, with queer sudden movements, this
36	way and that.  For a while I stood fascinated by that slow, fitful
36	advance.  Then, with a faint, hoarse cry, I forced myself across the
36	scullery.  I trembled violently; I could scarcely stand upright.  I
36	opened the door of the coal cellar, and stood there in the darkness
36	staring at the faintly lit doorway into the kitchen, and listening.
36	Had the Martian seen me?  What was it doing now?
36	
36	Something was moving to and fro there, very quietly; every now and
36	then it tapped against the wall, or started on its movements with a
36	faint metallic ringing, like the movements of keys on a split-ring.
36	Then a heavy body--I knew too well what--was dragged across the floor
36	of the kitchen towards the opening.  Irresistibly attracted, I crept
36	to the door and peeped into the kitchen.  In the triangle of bright
36	outer sunlight I saw the Martian, in its Briareus of a handling-machine,
36	scrutinizing the curate's head.  I thought at once that it would infer
36	my presence from the mark of the blow I had given him.
36	
36	I crept back to the coal cellar, shut the door, and began to cover
36	myself up as much as I could, and as noiselessly as possible in the
36	darkness, among the firewood and coal therein.  Every now and then I
36	paused, rigid, to hear if the Martian had thrust its tentacles through
36	the opening again.
36	
36	Then the faint metallic jingle returned.  I traced it slowly
36	feeling over the kitchen.  Presently I heard it nearer--in the
36	scullery, as I judged.  I thought that its length might be
36	insufficient to reach me.  I prayed copiously.  It passed, scraping
36	faintly across the cellar door.  An age of almost intolerable suspense
36	intervened; then I heard it fumbling at the latch! It had found the
36	door!  The Martians understood doors!
36	
36	It worried at the catch for a minute, perhaps, and then the door
36	opened.
36	
36	In the darkness I could just see the thing--like an elephant's
36	trunk more than anything else--waving towards me and touching and
36	examining the wall, coals, wood and ceiling.  It was like a black worm
36	swaying its blind head to and fro.
36	
36	Once, even, it touched the heel of my boot.  I was on the verge of
36	screaming; I bit my hand.  For a time the tentacle was silent.  I
36	could have fancied it had been withdrawn.  Presently, with an abrupt
36	click, it gripped something--I thought it had me!--and seemed to go
36	out of the cellar again.  For a minute I was not sure.  Apparently it
36	had taken a lump of coal to examine.
36	
36	I seized the opportunity of slightly shifting my position, which
36	had become cramped, and then listened.  I whispered passionate prayers
36	for safety.
36	
36	Then I heard the slow, deliberate sound creeping towards me again.
36	Slowly, slowly it drew near, scratching against the walls and tapping
36	the furniture.
36	
36	While I was still doubtful, it rapped smartly against the cellar
36	door and closed it.  I heard it go into the pantry, and the biscuit-tins
36	rattled and a bottle smashed, and then came a heavy bump against
36	the cellar door.  Then silence that passed into an infinity of
36	suspense.
36	
36	Had it gone?
36	
36	At last I decided that it had.
36	
36	It came into the scullery no more; but I lay all the tenth day in
36	the close darkness, buried among coals and firewood, not daring even
36	to crawl out for the drink for which I craved.  It was the eleventh day
36	before I ventured so far from my security.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER FIVE
36	
36	THE STILLNESS
36	
36	
36	My first act before I went into the pantry was to fasten the door
36	between the kitchen and the scullery.  But the pantry was empty; every
36	scrap of food had gone.  Apparently, the Martian had taken it all on
36	the previous day.  At that discovery I despaired for the first time.  I
36	took no food, or no drink either, on the eleventh or the twelfth day.
36	
36	At first my mouth and throat were parched, and my strength ebbed
36	sensibly.  I sat about in the darkness of the scullery, in a state of
36	despondent wretchedness.  My mind ran on eating.  I thought I had
36	become deaf, for the noises of movement I had been accustomed to hear
36	from the pit had ceased absolutely.  I did not feel strong enough to
36	crawl noiselessly to the peephole, or I would have gone there.
36	
36	On the twelfth day my throat was so painful that, taking the chance
36	of alarming the Martians, I attacked the creaking rain-water pump that
36	stood by the sink, and got a couple of glassfuls of blackened and
36	tainted rain water.  I was greatly refreshed by this, and emboldened
36	by the fact that no enquiring tentacle followed the noise of my
36	pumping.
36	
36	During these days, in a rambling, inconclusive way, I thought much
36	of the curate and of the manner of his death.
36	
36	On the thirteenth day I drank some more water, and dozed and
36	thought disjointedly of eating and of vague impossible plans of
36	escape.  Whenever I dozed I dreamt of horrible phantasms, of the death
36	of the curate, or of sumptuous dinners; but, asleep or awake, I felt a
36	keen pain that urged me to drink again and again.  The light that came
36	into the scullery was no longer grey, but red.  To my disordered
36	imagination it seemed the colour of blood.
36	
36	On the fourteenth day I went into the kitchen, and I was surprised
36	to find that the fronds of the red weed had grown right across
36	the hole in the wall, turning the half-light of the place into a
36	crimson-coloured obscurity.
36	
36	It was early on the fifteenth day that I heard a curious, familiar
36	sequence of sounds in the kitchen, and, listening, identified it as
36	the snuffing and scratching of a dog.  Going into the kitchen, I saw a
36	dog's nose peering in through a break among the ruddy fronds.  This
36	greatly surprised me.  At the scent of me he barked shortly.
36	
36	I thought if I could induce him to come into the place quietly I
36	should be able, perhaps, to kill and eat him; and in any case, it
36	would be advisable to kill him, lest his actions attracted the
36	attention of the Martians.
36	
36	I crept forward, saying ""Good dog!"" very softly; but he suddenly
36	withdrew his head and disappeared.
36	
36	I listened--I was not deaf--but certainly the pit was still.  I
36	heard a sound like the flutter of a bird's wings, and a hoarse
36	croaking, but that was all.
36	
36	For a long while I lay close to the peephole, but not daring to
36	move aside the red plants that obscured it.  Once or twice I heard a
36	faint pitter-patter like the feet of the dog going hither and thither
36	on the sand far below me, and there were more birdlike sounds, but
36	that was all.  At length, encouraged by the silence, I looked out.
36	
36	Except in the corner, where a multitude of crows hopped and fought
36	over the skeletons of the dead the Martians had consumed, there was
36	not a living thing in the pit.
36	
36	I stared about me, scarcely believing my eyes.  All the machinery
36	had gone.  Save for the big mound of greyish-blue powder in one
36	corner, certain bars of aluminium in another, the black birds, and the
36	skeletons of the killed, the place was merely an empty circular pit in
36	the sand.
36	
36	Slowly I thrust myself out through the red weed, and stood upon the
36	mound of rubble.  I could see in any direction save behind me, to the
36	north, and neither Martians nor sign of Martians were to be seen.  The
36	pit dropped sheerly from my feet, but a little way along the rubbish
36	afforded a practicable slope to the summit of the ruins.  My chance of
36	escape had come.  I began to tremble.
36	
36	I hesitated for some time, and then, in a gust of desperate
36	resolution, and with a heart that throbbed violently, I scrambled to
36	the top of the mound in which I had been buried so long.
36	
36	I looked about again.  To the northward, too, no Martian was
36	visible.
36	
36	When I had last seen this part of Sheen in the daylight it had been
36	a straggling street of comfortable white and red houses, interspersed
36	with abundant shady trees.  Now I stood on a mound of smashed
36	brickwork, clay, and gravel, over which spread a multitude of red
36	cactus-shaped plants, knee-high, without a solitary terrestrial growth
36	to dispute their footing.  The trees near me were dead and brown, but
36	further a network of red thread scaled the still living stems.
36	
36	The neighbouring houses had all been wrecked, but none had been
36	burned; their walls stood, sometimes to the second story, with smashed
36	windows and shattered doors.  The red weed grew tumultuously in their
36	roofless rooms.  Below me was the great pit, with the crows struggling
36	for its refuse.  A number of other birds hopped about among the ruins.
36	Far away I saw a gaunt cat slink crouchingly along a wall, but traces
36	of men there were none.
36	
36	The day seemed, by contrast with my recent confinement, dazzlingly
36	bright, the sky a glowing blue.  A gentle breeze kept the red weed
36	that covered every scrap of unoccupied ground gently swaying.  And oh!
36	the sweetness of the air!
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER SIX
36	
36	THE WORK OF FIFTEEN DAYS
36	
36	
36	For some time I stood tottering on the mound regardless of my
36	safety.  Within that noisome den from which I had emerged I had
36	thought with a narrow intensity only of our immediate security.  I had
36	not realised what had been happening to the world, had not anticipated
36	this startling vision of unfamiliar things.  I had expected to see
36	Sheen in ruins--I found about me the landscape, weird and lurid, of
36	another planet.
36	
36	For that moment I touched an emotion beyond the common range of
36	men, yet one that the poor brutes we dominate know only too well.  I
36	felt as a rabbit might feel returning to his burrow and suddenly
36	confronted by the work of a dozen busy navvies digging the foundations
36	of a house.  I felt the first inkling of a thing that presently grew
36	quite clear in my mind, that oppressed me for many days, a sense of
36	dethronement, a persuasion that I was no longer a master, but an
36	animal among the animals, under the Martian heel.  With us it would be
36	as with them, to lurk and watch, to run and hide; the fear and empire
36	of man had passed away.
36	
36	But so soon as this strangeness had been realised it passed, and my
36	dominant motive became the hunger of my long and dismal fast.  In the
36	direction away from the pit I saw, beyond a red-covered wall, a patch
36	of garden ground unburied.  This gave me a hint, and I went knee-deep,
36	and sometimes neck-deep, in the red weed.  The density of the
36	weed gave me a reassuring sense of hiding.  The wall was some six feet
36	high, and when I attempted to clamber it I found I could not lift my
36	feet to the crest.  So I went along by the side of it, and came to a
36	corner and a rockwork that enabled me to get to the top, and tumble
36	into the garden I coveted.  Here I found some young onions, a couple
36	of gladiolus bulbs, and a quantity of immature carrots, all of which I
36	secured, and, scrambling over a ruined wall, went on my way through
36	scarlet and crimson trees towards Kew--it was like walking through an
36	avenue of gigantic blood drops--possessed with two ideas: to get more
36	food, and to limp, as soon and as far as my strength permitted, out of
36	this accursed unearthly region of the pit.
36	
36	Some way farther, in a grassy place, was a group of mushrooms which
36	also I devoured, and then I came upon a brown sheet of flowing shallow
36	water, where meadows used to be.  These fragments of nourishment served
36	only to whet my hunger.  At first I was surprised at this flood in a
36	hot, dry summer, but afterwards I discovered that it was caused by the
36	tropical exuberance of the red weed.  Directly this extraordinary
36	growth encountered water it straightway became gigantic and of
36	unparalleled fecundity.  Its seeds were simply poured down into the
36	water of the Wey and Thames, and its swiftly growing and Titanic water
36	fronds speedily choked both those rivers.
36	
36	At Putney, as I afterwards saw, the bridge was almost lost in a
36	tangle of this weed, and at Richmond, too, the Thames water poured in
36	a broad and shallow stream across the meadows of Hampton and
36	Twickenham.  As the water spread the weed followed them, until the
36	ruined villas of the Thames valley were for a time lost in this red
36	swamp, whose margin I explored, and much of the desolation the
36	Martians had caused was concealed.
36	
36	In the end the red weed succumbed almost as quickly as it had
36	spread.  A cankering disease, due, it is believed, to the action of
36	certain bacteria, presently seized upon it.  Now by the action of
36	natural selection, all terrestrial plants have acquired a resisting
36	power against bacterial diseases--they never succumb without a severe
36	struggle, but the red weed rotted like a thing already dead.  The
36	fronds became bleached, and then shrivelled and brittle.  They broke
36	off at the least touch, and the waters that had stimulated their early
36	growth carried their last vestiges out to sea.
36	
36	My first act on coming to this water was, of course, to slake my
36	thirst.  I drank a great deal of it and, moved by an impulse, gnawed
36	some fronds of red weed; but they were watery, and had a sickly,
36	metallic taste.  I found the water was sufficiently shallow for me to
36	wade securely, although the red weed impeded my feet a little; but the
36	flood evidently got deeper towards the river, and I turned back to
36	Mortlake.  I managed to make out the road by means of occasional ruins
36	of its villas and fences and lamps, and so presently I got out of this
36	spate and made my way to the hill going up towards Roehampton and came
36	out on Putney Common.
36	
36	Here the scenery changed from the strange and unfamiliar to the
36	wreckage of the familiar: patches of ground exhibited the devastation
36	of a cyclone, and in a few score yards I would come upon perfectly
36	undisturbed spaces, houses with their blinds trimly drawn and doors
36	closed, as if they had been left for a day by the owners, or as if
36	their inhabitants slept within.  The red weed was less abundant; the
36	tall trees along the lane were free from the red creeper.  I hunted
36	for food among the trees, finding nothing, and I also raided a couple
36	of silent houses, but they had already been broken into and ransacked.
36	I rested for the remainder of the daylight in a shrubbery, being, in
36	my enfeebled condition, too fatigued to push on.
36	
36	All this time I saw no human beings, and no signs of the Martians.
36	I encountered a couple of hungry-looking dogs, but both hurried
36	circuitously away from the advances I made them.  Near Roehampton I
36	had seen two human skeletons--not bodies, but skeletons, picked
36	clean--and in the wood by me I found the crushed and scattered bones
36	of several cats and rabbits and the skull of a sheep.  But though I
36	gnawed parts of these in my mouth, there was nothing to be got from
36	them.
36	
36	After sunset I struggled on along the road towards Putney, where I
36	think the Heat-Ray must have been used for some reason.  And in the
36	garden beyond Roehampton I got a quantity of immature potatoes,
36	sufficient to stay my hunger.  From this garden one looked down upon
36	Putney and the river.  The aspect of the place in the dusk was
36	singularly desolate: blackened trees, blackened, desolate ruins, and
36	down the hill the sheets of the flooded river, red-tinged with the
36	weed.  And over all--silence.  It filled me with indescribable terror
36	to think how swiftly that desolating change had come.
36	
36	For a time I believed that mankind had been swept out of existence,
36	and that I stood there alone, the last man left alive.  Hard by the
36	top of Putney Hill I came upon another skeleton, with the arms
36	dislocated and removed several yards from the rest of the body.  As I
36	proceeded I became more and more convinced that the extermination of
36	mankind was, save for such stragglers as myself, already accomplished
36	in this part of the world.  The Martians, I thought, had gone on and
36	left the country desolated, seeking food elsewhere.  Perhaps even now
36	they were destroying Berlin or Paris, or it might be they had gone
36	northward.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER SEVEN
36	
36	THE MAN ON PUTNEY HILL
36	
36	
36	I spent that night in the inn that stands at the top of Putney
36	Hill, sleeping in a made bed for the first time since my flight to
36	Leatherhead.  I will not tell the needless trouble I had breaking into
36	that house--afterwards I found the front door was on the latch--nor
36	how I ransacked every room for food, until just on the verge of
36	despair, in what seemed to me to be a servant's bedroom, I found a
36	rat-gnawed crust and two tins of pineapple.  The place had been
36	already searched and emptied.  In the bar I afterwards found some
36	biscuits and sandwiches that had been overlooked.  The latter I could
36	not eat, they were too rotten, but the former not only stayed my
36	hunger, but filled my pockets.  I lit no lamps, fearing some Martian
36	might come beating that part of London for food in the night.  Before
36	I went to bed I had an interval of restlessness, and prowled from
36	window to window, peering out for some sign of these monsters.  I
36	slept little.  As I lay in bed I found myself thinking consecutively--a
36	thing I do not remember to have done since my last argument with the
36	curate.  During all the intervening time my mental condition had been
36	a hurrying succession of vague emotional states or a sort of stupid
36	receptivity.  But in the night my brain, reinforced, I suppose, by the
36	food I had eaten, grew clear again, and I thought.
36
