36	Three things struggled for possession of my mind: the killing of
36	the curate, the whereabouts of the Martians, and the possible fate of
36	my wife.  The former gave me no sensation of horror or remorse to
36	recall; I saw it simply as a thing done, a memory infinitely
36	disagreeable but quite without the quality of remorse.  I saw myself
36	then as I see myself now, driven step by step towards that hasty blow,
36	the creature of a sequence of accidents leading inevitably to that.  I
36	felt no condemnation; yet the memory, static, unprogressive, haunted
36	me.  In the silence of the night, with that sense of the nearness of
36	God that sometimes comes into the stillness and the darkness, I stood
36	my trial, my only trial, for that moment of wrath and fear.  I
36	retraced every step of our conversation from the moment when I had
36	found him crouching beside me, heedless of my thirst, and pointing to
36	the fire and smoke that streamed up from the ruins of Weybridge.  We
36	had been incapable of co-operation--grim chance had taken no heed of
36	that.  Had I foreseen, I should have left him at Halliford.  But I did
36	not foresee; and crime is to foresee and do.  And I set this down as I
36	have set all this story down, as it was.  There were no witnesses--all
36	these things I might have concealed.  But I set it down, and the
36	reader must form his judgment as he will.
36	
36	And when, by an effort, I had set aside that picture of a prostrate
36	body, I faced the problem of the Martians and the fate of my wife.  For
36	the former I had no data; I could imagine a hundred things, and so,
36	unhappily, I could for the latter.  And suddenly that night became
36	terrible.  I found myself sitting up in bed, staring at the dark.  I
36	found myself praying that the Heat-Ray might have suddenly and
36	painlessly struck her out of being.  Since the night of my return from
36	Leatherhead I had not prayed.  I had uttered prayers, fetish prayers,
36	had prayed as heathens mutter charms when I was in extremity; but now
36	I prayed indeed, pleading steadfastly and sanely, face to face with
36	the darkness of God.  Strange night!  Strangest in this, that so soon
36	as dawn had come, I, who had talked with God, crept out of the house
36	like a rat leaving its hiding place--a creature scarcely larger, an
36	inferior animal, a thing that for any passing whim of our masters
36	might be hunted and killed.  Perhaps they also prayed confidently to
36	God.  Surely, if we have learned nothing else, this war has taught us
36	pity--pity for those witless souls that suffer our dominion.
36	
36	The morning was bright and fine, and the eastern sky glowed pink,
36	and was fretted with little golden clouds.  In the road that runs from
36	the top of Putney Hill to Wimbledon was a number of poor vestiges of
36	the panic torrent that must have poured Londonward on the Sunday night
36	after the fighting began.  There was a little two-wheeled cart
36	inscribed with the name of Thomas Lobb, Greengrocer, New Malden, with
36	a smashed wheel and an abandoned tin trunk; there was a straw hat
36	trampled into the now hardened mud, and at the top of West Hill a lot
36	of blood-stained glass about the overturned water trough.  My
36	movements were languid, my plans of the vaguest.  I had an idea of
36	going to Leatherhead, though I knew that there I had the poorest
36	chance of finding my wife.  Certainly, unless death had overtaken them
36	suddenly, my cousins and she would have fled thence; but it seemed to
36	me I might find or learn there whither the Surrey people had fled.  I
36	knew I wanted to find my wife, that my heart ached for her and the
36	world of men, but I had no clear idea how the finding might be done.  I
36	was also sharply aware now of my intense loneliness.  From the corner
36	I went, under cover of a thicket of trees and bushes, to the edge of
36	Wimbledon Common, stretching wide and far.
36	
36	That dark expanse was lit in patches by yellow gorse and broom;
36	there was no red weed to be seen, and as I prowled, hesitating, on the
36	verge of the open, the sun rose, flooding it all with light and
36	vitality.  I came upon a busy swarm of little frogs in a swampy place
36	among the trees.  I stopped to look at them, drawing a lesson from
36	their stout resolve to live.  And presently, turning suddenly, with an
36	odd feeling of being watched, I beheld something crouching amid a
36	clump of bushes.  I stood regarding this.  I made a step towards it,
36	and it rose up and became a man armed with a cutlass.  I approached
36	him slowly.  He stood silent and motionless, regarding me.
36	
36	As I drew nearer I perceived he was dressed in clothes as dusty and
36	filthy as my own; he looked, indeed, as though he had been dragged
36	through a culvert.  Nearer, I distinguished the green slime of ditches
36	mixing with the pale drab of dried clay and shiny, coaly patches.  His
36	black hair fell over his eyes, and his face was dark and dirty and
36	sunken, so that at first I did not recognise him.  There was a red cut
36	across the lower part of his face.
36	
36	""Stop!"" he cried, when I was within ten yards of him, and I
36	stopped.  His voice was hoarse.  ""Where do you come from?"" he said.
36	
36	I thought, surveying him.
36	
36	""I come from Mortlake,"" I said.  ""I was buried near the pit the
36	Martians made about their cylinder.  I have worked my way out and
36	escaped.""
36	
36	""There is no food about here,"" he said.  ""This is my country.  All
36	this hill down to the river, and back to Clapham, and up to the edge
36	of the common.  There is only food for one.  Which way are you going?""
36	
36	I answered slowly.
36	
36	""I don't know,"" I said.  ""I have been buried in the ruins of a
36	house thirteen or fourteen days.  I don't know what has happened.""
36	
36	He looked at me doubtfully, then started, and looked with a changed
36	expression.
36	
36	""I've no wish to stop about here,"" said I.  ""I think I shall go to
36	Leatherhead, for my wife was there.""
36	
36	He shot out a pointing finger.
36	
36	""It is you,"" said he; ""the man from Woking.  And you weren't killed
36	at Weybridge?""
36	
36	I recognised him at the same moment.
36	
36	""You are the artilleryman who came into my garden.""
36	
36	""Good luck!"" he said.  ""We are lucky ones!  Fancy _you_!""  He put out
36	a hand, and I took it.  ""I crawled up a drain,"" he said. ""But they
36	didn't kill everyone.  And after they went away I got off towards
36	Walton across the fields.  But---- It's not sixteen days altogether--and
36	your hair is grey.""  He looked over his shoulder suddenly.  ""Only
36	a rook,"" he said.  ""One gets to know that birds have shadows these
36	days.  This is a bit open.  Let us crawl under those bushes and talk.""
36	
36	""Have you seen any Martians?"" I said.  ""Since I crawled out----""
36	
36	""They've gone away across London,"" he said.  ""I guess they've got a
36	bigger camp there.  Of a night, all over there, Hampstead way, the sky
36	is alive with their lights.  It's like a great city, and in the glare
36	you can just see them moving.  By daylight you can't.  But nearer--I
36	haven't seen them--"" (he counted on his fingers) ""five days.  Then I
36	saw a couple across Hammersmith way carrying something big.  And the
36	night before last""--he stopped and spoke impressively--""it was just a
36	matter of lights, but it was something up in the air.  I believe
36	they've built a flying-machine, and are learning to fly.""
36	
36	I stopped, on hands and knees, for we had come to the bushes.
36	
36	""Fly!""
36	
36	""Yes,"" he said, ""fly.""
36	
36	I went on into a little bower, and sat down.
36	
36	""It is all over with humanity,"" I said.  ""If they can do that they
36	will simply go round the world.""
36	
36	He nodded.
36	
36	""They will.  But---- It will relieve things over here a bit.  And
36	besides----""  He looked at me.  ""Aren't you satisfied it _is_ up with
36	humanity?  I am.  We're down; we're beat.""
36	
36	I stared.  Strange as it may seem, I had not arrived at this fact--a
36	fact perfectly obvious so soon as he spoke.  I had still held a
36	vague hope; rather, I had kept a lifelong habit of mind.  He repeated
36	his words, ""We're beat.""  They carried absolute conviction.
36	
36	""It's all over,"" he said.  ""They've lost _one_--just _one_.  And they've
36	made their footing good and crippled the greatest power in the world.
36	They've walked over us.  The death of that one at Weybridge was an
36	accident.  And these are only pioneers.  They kept on coming.  These
36	green stars--I've seen none these five or six days, but I've no doubt
36	they're falling somewhere every night.  Nothing's to be done.  We're
36	under! We're beat!""
36	
36	I made him no answer.  I sat staring before me, trying in vain to
36	devise some countervailing thought.
36	
36	""This isn't a war,"" said the artilleryman.  ""It never was a war,
36	any more than there's war between man and ants.""
36	
36	Suddenly I recalled the night in the observatory.
36	
36	""After the tenth shot they fired no more--at least, until the first
36	cylinder came.""
36	
36	""How do you know?"" said the artilleryman.  I explained.  He thought.
36	""Something wrong with the gun,"" he said.  ""But what if there is?
36	They'll get it right again.  And even if there's a delay, how can it
36	alter the end?  It's just men and ants.  There's the ants builds their
36	cities, live their lives, have wars, revolutions, until the men want
36	them out of the way, and then they go out of the way.  That's what we
36	are now--just ants.  Only----""
36	
36	""Yes,"" I said.
36	
36	""We're eatable ants.""
36	
36	We sat looking at each other.
36	
36	""And what will they do with us?"" I said.
36	
36	""That's what I've been thinking,"" he said; ""that's what I've been
36	thinking.  After Weybridge I went south--thinking.  I saw what was up.
36	Most of the people were hard at it squealing and exciting themselves.
36	But I'm not so fond of squealing.  I've been in sight of death once or
36	twice; I'm not an ornamental soldier, and at the best and worst,
36	death--it's just death.  And it's the man that keeps on thinking comes
36	through.  I saw everyone tracking away south.  Says I, 'Food won't
36	last this way,' and I turned right back.  I went for the Martians like
36	a sparrow goes for man.  All round""--he waved a hand to the
36	horizon--""they're starving in heaps, bolting, treading on each other.
36	. . .""
36	
36	He saw my face, and halted awkwardly.
36	
36	""No doubt lots who had money have gone away to France,"" he said.  He
36	seemed to hesitate whether to apologise, met my eyes, and went on:
36	""There's food all about here.  Canned things in shops; wines, spirits,
36	mineral waters; and the water mains and drains are empty.  Well, I was
36	telling you what I was thinking.  'Here's intelligent things,' I said,
36	'and it seems they want us for food.  First, they'll smash us up--ships,
36	machines, guns, cities, all the order and organisation.  All
36	that will go.  If we were the size of ants we might pull through.  But
36	we're not.  It's all too bulky to stop.  That's the first certainty.'
36	Eh?""
36	
36	I assented.
36	
36	""It is; I've thought it out.  Very well, then--next; at present
36	we're caught as we're wanted.  A Martian has only to go a few miles to
36	get a crowd on the run.  And I saw one, one day, out by Wandsworth,
36	picking houses to pieces and routing among the wreckage.  But they
36	won't keep on doing that.  So soon as they've settled all our guns and
36	ships, and smashed our railways, and done all the things they are
36	doing over there, they will begin catching us systematic, picking the
36	best and storing us in cages and things.  That's what they will start
36	doing in a bit.  Lord!  They haven't begun on us yet.  Don't you see
36	that?""
36	
36	""Not begun!"" I exclaimed.
36	
36	""Not begun.  All that's happened so far is through our not having
36	the sense to keep quiet--worrying them with guns and such foolery.  And
36	losing our heads, and rushing off in crowds to where there wasn't any
36	more safety than where we were.  They don't want to bother us yet.
36	They're making their things--making all the things they couldn't bring
36	with them, getting things ready for the rest of their people.  Very
36	likely that's why the cylinders have stopped for a bit, for fear of
36	hitting those who are here.  And instead of our rushing about blind,
36	on the howl, or getting dynamite on the chance of busting them up,
36	we've got to fix ourselves up according to the new state of affairs.
36	That's how I figure it out.  It isn't quite according to what a man
36	wants for his species, but it's about what the facts point to.  And
36	that's the principle I acted upon.  Cities, nations, civilisation,
36	progress--it's all over.  That game's up.  We're beat.""
36	
36	""But if that is so, what is there to live for?""
36	
36	The artilleryman looked at me for a moment.
36	
36	""There won't be any more blessed concerts for a million years or
36	so; there won't be any Royal Academy of Arts, and no nice little feeds
36	at restaurants.  If it's amusement you're after, I reckon the game is
36	up.  If you've got any drawing-room manners or a dislike to eating
36	peas with a knife or dropping aitches, you'd better chuck 'em away.
36	They ain't no further use.""
36	
36	""You mean----""
36	
36	""I mean that men like me are going on living--for the sake of the
36	breed.  I tell you, I'm grim set on living.  And if I'm not mistaken,
36	you'll show what insides _you've_ got, too, before long.  We aren't
36	going to be exterminated.  And I don't mean to be caught either, and
36	tamed and fattened and bred like a thundering ox.  Ugh! Fancy those
36	brown creepers!""
36	
36	""You don't mean to say----""
36	
36	""I do.  I'm going on, under their feet.  I've got it planned; I've
36	thought it out.  We men are beat.  We don't know enough.  We've got to
36	learn before we've got a chance.  And we've got to live and keep
36	independent while we learn.  See! That's what has to be done.""
36	
36	I stared, astonished, and stirred profoundly by the man's
36	resolution.
36	
36	""Great God!"" cried I.  ""But you are a man indeed!""  And suddenly I
36	gripped his hand.
36	
36	""Eh!"" he said, with his eyes shining.  ""I've thought it out, eh?""
36	
36	""Go on,"" I said.
36	
36	""Well, those who mean to escape their catching must get ready.  I'm
36	getting ready.  Mind you, it isn't all of us that are made for wild
36	beasts; and that's what it's got to be.  That's why I watched you.  I
36	had my doubts.  You're slender.  I didn't know that it was you, you
36	see, or just how you'd been buried.  All these--the sort of people
36	that lived in these houses, and all those damn little clerks that used
36	to live down that way--they'd be no good.  They haven't any spirit in
36	them--no proud dreams and no proud lusts; and a man who hasn't one or
36	the other--Lord!  What is he but funk and precautions?  They just used
36	to skedaddle off to work--I've seen hundreds of 'em, bit of breakfast
36	in hand, running wild and shining to catch their little season-ticket
36	train, for fear they'd get dismissed if they didn't; working at
36	businesses they were afraid to take the trouble to understand;
36	skedaddling back for fear they wouldn't be in time for dinner; keeping
36	indoors after dinner for fear of the back streets, and sleeping with
36	the wives they married, not because they wanted them, but because they
36	had a bit of money that would make for safety in their one little
36	miserable skedaddle through the world.  Lives insured and a bit
36	invested for fear of accidents.  And on Sundays--fear of the
36	hereafter.  As if hell was built for rabbits!  Well, the Martians will
36	just be a godsend to these.  Nice roomy cages, fattening food, careful
36	breeding, no worry.  After a week or so chasing about the fields and
36	lands on empty stomachs, they'll come and be caught cheerful.  They'll
36	be quite glad after a bit.  They'll wonder what people did before
36	there were Martians to take care of them.  And the bar loafers, and
36	mashers, and singers--I can imagine them.  I can imagine them,"" he
36	said, with a sort of sombre gratification.  ""There'll be any amount of
36	sentiment and religion loose among them.  There's hundreds of things I
36	saw with my eyes that I've only begun to see clearly these last few
36	days.  There's lots will take things as they are--fat and stupid; and
36	lots will be worried by a sort of feeling that it's all wrong, and
36	that they ought to be doing something.  Now whenever things are so
36	that a lot of people feel they ought to be doing something, the weak,
36	and those who go weak with a lot of complicated thinking, always make
36	for a sort of do-nothing religion, very pious and superior, and
36	submit to persecution and the will of the Lord.  Very likely you've
36	seen the same thing.  It's energy in a gale of funk, and turned clean
36	inside out.  These cages will be full of psalms and hymns and piety.
36	And those of a less simple sort will work in a bit of--what is
36	it?--eroticism.""
36	
36	He paused.
36	
36	""Very likely these Martians will make pets of some of them; train
36	them to do tricks--who knows?--get sentimental over the pet boy who
36	grew up and had to be killed.  And some, maybe, they will train to
36	hunt us.""
36	
36	""No,"" I cried, ""that's impossible!  No human being----""
36	
36	""What's the good of going on with such lies?"" said the
36	artilleryman.  ""There's men who'd do it cheerful.  What nonsense to
36	pretend there isn't!""
36	
36	And I succumbed to his conviction.
36	
36	""If they come after me,"" he said; ""Lord, if they come after me!""
36	and subsided into a grim meditation.
36	
36	I sat contemplating these things.  I could find nothing to bring
36	against this man's reasoning.  In the days before the invasion no one
36	would have questioned my intellectual superiority to his--I, a
36	professed and recognised writer on philosophical themes, and he, a
36	common soldier; and yet he had already formulated a situation that I
36	had scarcely realised.
36	
36	""What are you doing?"" I said presently.  ""What plans have you
36	made?""
36	
36	He hesitated.
36	
36	""Well, it's like this,"" he said.  ""What have we to do?  We have to
36	invent a sort of life where men can live and breed, and be
36	sufficiently secure to bring the children up.  Yes--wait a bit, and
36	I'll make it clearer what I think ought to be done.  The tame ones
36	will go like all tame beasts; in a few generations they'll be big,
36	beautiful, rich-blooded, stupid--rubbish! The risk is that we who keep
36	wild will go savage--degenerate into a sort of big, savage rat. . . .
36	You see, how I mean to live is underground.  I've been thinking about
36	the drains.  Of course those who don't know drains think horrible
36	things; but under this London are miles and miles--hundreds of
36	miles--and a few days rain and London empty will leave them sweet and
36	clean. The main drains are big enough and airy enough for anyone.
36	Then there's cellars, vaults, stores, from which bolting passages may
36	be made to the drains. And the railway tunnels and subways.  Eh?  You
36	begin to see?  And we form a band--able-bodied, clean-minded men.
36	We're not going to pick up any rubbish that drifts in.  Weaklings
36	go out again.""
36	
36	""As you meant me to go?""
36	
36	""Well--I parleyed, didn't I?""
36	
36	""We won't quarrel about that.  Go on.""
36	
36	""Those who stop obey orders.  Able-bodied, clean-minded women we
36	want also--mothers and teachers.  No lackadaisical ladies--no blasted
36	rolling eyes.  We can't have any weak or silly.  Life is real again,
36	and the useless and cumbersome and mischievous have to die.  They
36	ought to die.  They ought to be willing to die.  It's a sort of
36	disloyalty, after all, to live and taint the race.  And they can't be
36	happy.  Moreover, dying's none so dreadful; it's the funking makes it
36	bad.  And in all those places we shall gather.  Our district will be
36	London.  And we may even be able to keep a watch, and run about in the
36	open when the Martians keep away.  Play cricket, perhaps.  That's how
36	we shall save the race.  Eh?  It's a possible thing?  But saving the
36	race is nothing in itself.  As I say, that's only being rats.  It's
36	saving our knowledge and adding to it is the thing.  There men like
36	you come in.  There's books, there's models.  We must make great safe
36	places down deep, and get all the books we can; not novels and poetry
36	swipes, but ideas, science books.  That's where men like you come in.
36	We must go to the British Museum and pick all those books through.
36	Especially we must keep up our science--learn more.  We must watch
36	these Martians.  Some of us must go as spies.  When it's all working,
36	perhaps I will.  Get caught, I mean.  And the great thing is, we must
36	leave the Martians alone.  We mustn't even steal.  If we get in their
36	way, we clear out.  We must show them we mean no harm.  Yes, I know.
36	But they're intelligent things, and they won't hunt us down if they
36	have all they want, and think we're just harmless vermin.""
36	
36	The artilleryman paused and laid a brown hand upon my arm.
36	
36	""After all, it may not be so much we may have to learn before--Just
36	imagine this: four or five of their fighting machines suddenly
36	starting off--Heat-Rays right and left, and not a Martian in 'em.  Not
36	a Martian in 'em, but men--men who have learned the way how.  It may
36	be in my time, even--those men.  Fancy having one of them lovely
36	things, with its Heat-Ray wide and free!  Fancy having it in control!
36	What would it matter if you smashed to smithereens at the end of the
36	run, after a bust like that?  I reckon the Martians'll open their
36	beautiful eyes!  Can't you see them, man?  Can't you see them
36	hurrying, hurrying--puffing and blowing and hooting to their other
36	mechanical affairs?  Something out of gear in every case.  And swish,
36	bang, rattle, swish!  Just as they are fumbling over it, _swish_ comes
36	the Heat-Ray, and, behold! man has come back to his own.""
36	
36	For a while the imaginative daring of the artilleryman, and the
36	tone of assurance and courage he assumed, completely dominated my
36	mind.  I believed unhesitatingly both in his forecast of human destiny
36	and in the practicability of his astonishing scheme, and the reader
36	who thinks me susceptible and foolish must contrast his position,
36	reading steadily with all his thoughts about his subject, and mine,
36	crouching fearfully in the bushes and listening, distracted by
36	apprehension.  We talked in this manner through the early morning
36	time, and later crept out of the bushes, and, after scanning the sky
36	for Martians, hurried precipitately to the house on Putney Hill where
36	he had made his lair.  It was the coal cellar of the place, and when I
36	saw the work he had spent a week upon--it was a burrow scarcely ten
36	yards long, which he designed to reach to the main drain on Putney
36	Hill--I had my first inkling of the gulf between his dreams and his
36	powers.  Such a hole I could have dug in a day.  But I believed in him
36	sufficiently to work with him all that morning until past midday at
36	his digging.  We had a garden barrow and shot the earth we removed
36	against the kitchen range.  We refreshed ourselves with a tin of
36	mock-turtle soup and wine from the neighbouring pantry.  I found a
36	curious relief from the aching strangeness of the world in this steady
36	labour. As we worked, I turned his project over in my mind, and
36	presently objections and doubts began to arise; but I worked there all
36	the morning, so glad was I to find myself with a purpose again.  After
36	working an hour I began to speculate on the distance one had to go
36	before the cloaca was reached, the chances we had of missing it
36	altogether.  My immediate trouble was why we should dig this long
36	tunnel, when it was possible to get into the drain at once down one of
36	the manholes, and work back to the house.  It seemed to me, too, that
36	the house was inconveniently chosen, and required a needless length of
36	tunnel.  And just as I was beginning to face these things, the
36	artilleryman stopped digging, and looked at me.
36	
36	""We're working well,"" he said.  He put down his spade. ""Let us
36	knock off a bit"" he said.  ""I think it's time we reconnoitred from the
36	roof of the house.""
36	
36	I was for going on, and after a little hesitation he resumed his
36	spade; and then suddenly I was struck by a thought.  I stopped, and so
36	did he at once.
36	
36	""Why were you walking about the common,"" I said, ""instead of being
36	here?""
36	
36	""Taking the air,"" he said.  ""I was coming back.  It's safer by
36	night.""
36	
36	""But the work?""
36	
36	""Oh, one can't always work,"" he said, and in a flash I saw the man
36	plain.  He hesitated, holding his spade.  ""We ought to reconnoitre
36	now,"" he said, ""because if any come near they may hear the spades and
36	drop upon us unawares.""
36	
36	I was no longer disposed to object.  We went together to the roof
36	and stood on a ladder peeping out of the roof door.  No Martians were
36	to be seen, and we ventured out on the tiles, and slipped down under
36	shelter of the parapet.
36	
36	From this position a shrubbery hid the greater portion of Putney,
36	but we could see the river below, a bubbly mass of red weed, and the
36	low parts of Lambeth flooded and red.  The red creeper swarmed up the
36	trees about the old palace, and their branches stretched gaunt and
36	dead, and set with shrivelled leaves, from amid its clusters.  It was
36	strange how entirely dependent both these things were upon flowing
36	water for their propagation.  About us neither had gained a footing;
36	laburnums, pink mays, snowballs, and trees of arbor-vitae, rose out of
36	laurels and hydrangeas, green and brilliant into the sunlight.  Beyond
36	Kensington dense smoke was rising, and that and a blue haze hid the
36	northward hills.
36	
36	The artilleryman began to tell me of the sort of people who still
36	remained in London.
36	
36	""One night last week,"" he said, ""some fools got the electric light
36	in order, and there was all Regent Street and the Circus ablaze,
36	crowded with painted and ragged drunkards, men and women, dancing and
36	shouting till dawn.  A man who was there told me.  And as the day came
36	they became aware of a fighting-machine standing near by the Langham
36	and looking down at them.  Heaven knows how long he had been there.
36	It must have given some of them a nasty turn.  He came down the road
36	towards them, and picked up nearly a hundred too drunk or frightened
36	to run away.""
36	
36	Grotesque gleam of a time no history will ever fully describe!
36	
36	From that, in answer to my questions, he came round to his
36	grandiose plans again.  He grew enthusiastic.  He talked so eloquently
36	of the possibility of capturing a fighting-machine that I more than
36	half believed in him again.  But now that I was beginning to
36	understand something of his quality, I could divine the stress he laid
36	on doing nothing precipitately.  And I noted that now there was no
36	question that he personally was to capture and fight the great
36	machine.
36	
36	After a time we went down to the cellar.  Neither of us seemed
36	disposed to resume digging, and when he suggested a meal, I was
36	nothing loath.  He became suddenly very generous, and when we had
36	eaten he went away and returned with some excellent cigars.  We lit
36	these, and his optimism glowed.  He was inclined to regard my coming
36	as a great occasion.
36	
36	""There's some champagne in the cellar,"" he said.
36	
36	""We can dig better on this Thames-side burgundy,"" said I.
36	
36	""No,"" said he; ""I am host today.  Champagne!  Great God! We've a
36	heavy enough task before us!  Let us take a rest and gather strength
36	while we may.  Look at these blistered hands!""
36	
36	And pursuant to this idea of a holiday, he insisted upon playing
36	cards after we had eaten.  He taught me euchre, and after dividing
36	London between us, I taking the northern side and he the southern, we
36	played for parish points.  Grotesque and foolish as this will seem to
36	the sober reader, it is absolutely true, and what is more remarkable,
36	I found the card game and several others we played extremely
36	interesting.
36	
36	Strange mind of man! that, with our species upon the edge of
36	extermination or appalling degradation, with no clear prospect before
36	us but the chance of a horrible death, we could sit following the
36	chance of this painted pasteboard, and playing the ""joker"" with vivid
36	delight.  Afterwards he taught me poker, and I beat him at three tough
36	chess games.  When dark came we decided to take the risk, and lit a
36	lamp.
36	
36	After an interminable string of games, we supped, and the
36	artilleryman finished the champagne.  We went on smoking the cigars.
36	He was no longer the energetic regenerator of his species I had
36	encountered in the morning.  He was still optimistic, but it was a
36	less kinetic, a more thoughtful optimism.  I remember he wound up with
36	my health, proposed in a speech of small variety and considerable
36	intermittence.  I took a cigar, and went upstairs to look at the
36	lights of which he had spoken that blazed so greenly along the
36	Highgate hills.
36	
36	At first I stared unintelligently across the London valley.  The
36	northern hills were shrouded in darkness; the fires near Kensington
36	glowed redly, and now and then an orange-red tongue of flame flashed
36	up and vanished in the deep blue night.  All the rest of London
36	was black.  Then, nearer, I perceived a strange light, a pale,
36	violet-purple fluorescent glow, quivering under the night breeze.  For
36	a space I could not understand it, and then I knew that it must be
36	the red weed from which this faint irradiation proceeded.  With that
36	realisation my dormant sense of wonder, my sense of the proportion of
36	things, awoke again.  I glanced from that to Mars, red and clear,
36	glowing high in the west, and then gazed long and earnestly at the
36	darkness of Hampstead and Highgate.
36	
36	I remained a very long time upon the roof, wondering at the
36	grotesque changes of the day.  I recalled my mental states from the
36	midnight prayer to the foolish card-playing.  I had a violent
36	revulsion of feeling.  I remember I flung away the cigar with a
36	certain wasteful symbolism.  My folly came to me with glaring
36	exaggeration.  I seemed a traitor to my wife and to my kind; I was
36	filled with remorse.  I resolved to leave this strange undisciplined
36	dreamer of great things to his drink and gluttony, and to go on into
36	London.  There, it seemed to me, I had the best chance of learning
36	what the Martians and my fellowmen were doing.  I was still upon the
36	roof when the late moon rose.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER EIGHT
36	
36	DEAD LONDON
36	
36	
36	After I had parted from the artilleryman, I went down the hill, and
36	by the High Street across the bridge to Fulham.  The red weed was
36	tumultuous at that time, and nearly choked the bridge roadway; but its
36	fronds were already whitened in patches by the spreading disease that
36	presently removed it so swiftly.
36	
36	At the corner of the lane that runs to Putney Bridge station I
36	found a man lying.  He was as black as a sweep with the black dust,
36	alive, but helplessly and speechlessly drunk.  I could get nothing
36	from him but curses and furious lunges at my head.  I think I should
36	have stayed by him but for the brutal expression of his face.
36	
36	There was black dust along the roadway from the bridge onwards, and
36	it grew thicker in Fulham.  The streets were horribly quiet.  I got
36	food--sour, hard, and mouldy, but quite eatable--in a baker's shop
36	here.  Some way towards Walham Green the streets became clear of
36	powder, and I passed a white terrace of houses on fire; the noise of
36	the burning was an absolute relief.  Going on towards Brompton, the
36	streets were quiet again.
36	
36	Here I came once more upon the black powder in the streets and upon
36	dead bodies.  I saw altogether about a dozen in the length of the
36	Fulham Road.  They had been dead many days, so that I hurried quickly
36	past them.  The black powder covered them over, and softened their
36	outlines.  One or two had been disturbed by dogs.
36	
36	Where there was no black powder, it was curiously like a Sunday in
36	the City, with the closed shops, the houses locked up and the blinds
36	drawn, the desertion, and the stillness.  In some places plunderers
36	had been at work, but rarely at other than the provision and wine
36	shops.  A jeweller's window had been broken open in one place, but
36	apparently the thief had been disturbed, and a number of gold chains
36	and a watch lay scattered on the pavement.  I did not trouble to touch
36	them.  Farther on was a tattered woman in a heap on a doorstep; the
36	hand that hung over her knee was gashed and bled down her rusty brown
36	dress, and a smashed magnum of champagne formed a pool across the
36	pavement.  She seemed asleep, but she was dead.
36	
36	The farther I penetrated into London, the profounder grew the
36	stillness.  But it was not so much the stillness of death--it was the
36	stillness of suspense, of expectation.  At any time the destruction
36	that had already singed the northwestern borders of the metropolis,
36	and had annihilated Ealing and Kilburn, might strike among these
36	houses and leave them smoking ruins.  It was a city condemned and
36	derelict. . . .
36	
36	In South Kensington the streets were clear of dead and of black
36	powder.  It was near South Kensington that I first heard the howling.
36	It crept almost imperceptibly upon my senses.  It was a sobbing
36	alternation of two notes, ""Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,"" keeping on
36	perpetually.  When I passed streets that ran northward it grew in
36	volume, and houses and buildings seemed to deaden and cut it off
36	again.  It came in a full tide down Exhibition Road.  I stopped,
36	staring towards Kensington Gardens, wondering at this strange, remote
36	wailing.  It was as if that mighty desert of houses had found a voice
36	for its fear and solitude.
36	
36	""Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,"" wailed that superhuman note--great waves
36	of sound sweeping down the broad, sunlit roadway, between the tall
36	buildings on each side.  I turned northwards, marvelling, towards the
36	iron gates of Hyde Park.  I had half a mind to break into the Natural
36	History Museum and find my way up to the summits of the towers, in
36	order to see across the park.  But I decided to keep to the ground,
36	where quick hiding was possible, and so went on up the Exhibition
36	Road.  All the large mansions on each side of the road were empty and
36	still, and my footsteps echoed against the sides of the houses.  At
36	the top, near the park gate, I came upon a strange sight--a bus
36	overturned, and the skeleton of a horse picked clean.  I puzzled over
36	this for a time, and then went on to the bridge over the Serpentine.
36	The voice grew stronger and stronger, though I could see nothing above
36	the housetops on the north side of the park, save a haze of smoke to
36	the northwest.
36	
36	""Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,"" cried the voice, coming, as it seemed to
36	me, from the district about Regent's Park.  The desolating cry worked
36	upon my mind.  The mood that had sustained me passed.  The wailing
36	took possession of me.  I found I was intensely weary, footsore, and
36	now again hungry and thirsty.
36	
36	It was already past noon.  Why was I wandering alone in this city
36	of the dead?  Why was I alone when all London was lying in state, and
36	in its black shroud?  I felt intolerably lonely.  My mind ran on old
36	friends that I had forgotten for years.  I thought of the poisons in
36	the chemists' shops, of the liquors the wine merchants stored; I
36	recalled the two sodden creatures of despair, who so far as I knew,
36	shared the city with myself. . . .
36	
36	I came into Oxford Street by the Marble Arch, and here again were
36	black powder and several bodies, and an evil, ominous smell from the
36	gratings of the cellars of some of the houses.  I grew very thirsty
36	after the heat of my long walk.  With infinite trouble I managed to
36	break into a public-house and get food and drink.  I was weary after
36	eating, and went into the parlour behind the bar, and slept on a black
36	horsehair sofa I found there.
36	
36	I awoke to find that dismal howling still in my ears, ""Ulla, ulla,
36	ulla, ulla.""  It was now dusk, and after I had routed out some
36	biscuits and a cheese in the bar--there was a meat safe, but it
36	contained nothing but maggots--I wandered on through the silent
36	residential squares to Baker Street--Portman Square is the only one I
36	can name--and so came out at last upon Regent's Park.  And as I
36	emerged from the top of Baker Street, I saw far away over the trees in
36	the clearness of the sunset the hood of the Martian giant from which
36	this howling proceeded.  I was not terrified.  I came upon him as if
36	it were a matter of course.  I watched him for some time, but he did
36	not move.  He appeared to be standing and yelling, for no reason that
36	I could discover.
36	
36	I tried to formulate a plan of action.  That perpetual sound of
36	""Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,"" confused my mind.  Perhaps I was too tired
36	to be very fearful.  Certainly I was more curious to know the reason
36	of this monotonous crying than afraid.  I turned back away from the
36	park and struck into Park Road, intending to skirt the park, went
36	along under the shelter of the terraces, and got a view of this
36	stationary, howling Martian from the direction of St. John's Wood.  A
36	couple of hundred yards out of Baker Street I heard a yelping chorus,
36	and saw, first a dog with a piece of putrescent red meat in his jaws
36	coming headlong towards me, and then a pack of starving mongrels in
36	pursuit of him.  He made a wide curve to avoid me, as though he feared
36	I might prove a fresh competitor.  As the yelping died away down the
36	silent road, the wailing sound of ""Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,"" reasserted
36	itself.
36	
36	I came upon the wrecked handling-machine halfway to St. John's Wood
36	station.  At first I thought a house had fallen across the road.  It
36	was only as I clambered among the ruins that I saw, with a start, this
36	mechanical Samson lying, with its tentacles bent and smashed and
36	twisted, among the ruins it had made.  The forepart was shattered.  It
36	seemed as if it had driven blindly straight at the house, and had been
36	overwhelmed in its overthrow.  It seemed to me then that this might
36	have happened by a handling-machine escaping from the guidance of its
36	Martian.  I could not clamber among the ruins to see it, and the
36	twilight was now so far advanced that the blood with which its seat
36	was smeared, and the gnawed gristle of the Martian that the dogs had
36	left, were invisible to me.
36	
36	Wondering still more at all that I had seen, I pushed on towards
36	Primrose Hill.  Far away, through a gap in the trees, I saw a second
36	Martian, as motionless as the first, standing in the park towards the
36	Zoological Gardens, and silent.  A little beyond the ruins about the
36	smashed handling-machine I came upon the red weed again, and found the
36	Regent's Canal, a spongy mass of dark-red vegetation.
36	
36	As I crossed the bridge, the sound of ""Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,""
36	ceased.  It was, as it were, cut off.  The silence came like a
36	thunderclap.
36	
36	The dusky houses about me stood faint and tall and dim; the trees
36	towards the park were growing black.  All about me the red weed
36	clambered among the ruins, writhing to get above me in the dimness.
36	Night, the mother of fear and mystery, was coming upon me.  But while
36	that voice sounded the solitude, the desolation, had been endurable;
36	by virtue of it London had still seemed alive, and the sense of life
36	about me had upheld me.  Then suddenly a change, the passing of
36	something--I knew not what--and then a stillness that could be felt.
36	Nothing but this gaunt quiet.
36	
36	London about me gazed at me spectrally.  The windows in the white
36	houses were like the eye sockets of skulls.  About me my imagination
36	found a thousand noiseless enemies moving.  Terror seized me, a horror
36	of my temerity.  In front of me the road became pitchy black as though
36	it was tarred, and I saw a contorted shape lying across the pathway.  I
36	could not bring myself to go on.  I turned down St. John's Wood Road,
36	and ran headlong from this unendurable stillness towards Kilburn.  I
36	hid from the night and the silence, until long after midnight, in a
36	cabmen's shelter in Harrow Road.  But before the dawn my courage
36	returned, and while the stars were still in the sky I turned once more
36	towards Regent's Park.  I missed my way among the streets, and
36	presently saw down a long avenue, in the half-light of the early dawn,
36	the curve of Primrose Hill.  On the summit, towering up to the fading
36	stars, was a third Martian, erect and motionless like the others.
36	
36	An insane resolve possessed me.  I would die and end it.  And I
36	would save myself even the trouble of killing myself.  I marched on
36	recklessly towards this Titan, and then, as I drew nearer and the
36	light grew, I saw that a multitude of black birds was circling and
36	clustering about the hood.  At that my heart gave a bound, and I began
36	running along the road.
36	
36	I hurried through the red weed that choked St. Edmund's Terrace (I
36	waded breast-high across a torrent of water that was rushing down from
36	the waterworks towards the Albert Road), and emerged upon the grass
36	before the rising of the sun.  Great mounds had been heaped about the
36	crest of the hill, making a huge redoubt of it--it was the final and
36	largest place the Martians had made--and from behind these heaps there
36	rose a thin smoke against the sky.  Against the sky line an eager dog
36	ran and disappeared.  The thought that had flashed into my mind grew
36	real, grew credible.  I felt no fear, only a wild, trembling
36	exultation, as I ran up the hill towards the motionless monster.  Out
36	of the hood hung lank shreds of brown, at which the hungry birds
36	pecked and tore.
36	
36	In another moment I had scrambled up the earthen rampart and stood
36	upon its crest, and the interior of the redoubt was below me.  A
36	mighty space it was, with gigantic machines here and there within it,
36	huge mounds of material and strange shelter places.  And scattered
36	about it, some in their overturned war-machines, some in the now rigid
36	handling-machines, and a dozen of them stark and silent and laid in a
36	row, were the Martians--_dead_!--slain by the putrefactive and disease
36	bacteria against which their systems were unprepared; slain as the red
36	weed was being slain; slain, after all man's devices had failed, by
36	the humblest things that God, in his wisdom, has put upon this earth.
36	
36	For so it had come about, as indeed I and many men might have
36	foreseen had not terror and disaster blinded our minds.  These
36	germs of disease have taken toll of humanity since the beginning of
36	things--taken toll of our prehuman ancestors since life began here.
36	But by virtue of this natural selection of our kind we have developed
36	resisting power; to no germs do we succumb without a struggle, and to
36	many--those that cause putrefaction in dead matter, for instance--our
36	living frames are altogether immune.  But there are no bacteria in
36	Mars, and directly these invaders arrived, directly they drank and
36	fed, our microscopic allies began to work their overthrow.  Already
36	when I watched them they were irrevocably doomed, dying and rotting
36	even as they went to and fro.  It was inevitable.  By the toll of a
36	billion deaths man has bought his birthright of the earth, and it is
36	his against all comers; it would still be his were the Martians ten
36	times as mighty as they are.  For neither do men live nor die in vain.
36	
36	Here and there they were scattered, nearly fifty altogether, in
36	that great gulf they had made, overtaken by a death that must have
36	seemed to them as incomprehensible as any death could be.  To me also
36	at that time this death was incomprehensible.  All I knew was that
36	these things that had been alive and so terrible to men were dead.
36	For a moment I believed that the destruction of Sennacherib had been
36	repeated, that God had repented, that the Angel of Death had slain
36	them in the night.
36	
36	I stood staring into the pit, and my heart lightened gloriously,
36	even as the rising sun struck the world to fire about me with his
36	rays.  The pit was still in darkness; the mighty engines, so great and
36	wonderful in their power and complexity, so unearthly in their
36	tortuous forms, rose weird and vague and strange out of the shadows
36	towards the light.  A multitude of dogs, I could hear, fought over the
36	bodies that lay darkly in the depth of the pit, far below me.  Across
36	the pit on its farther lip, flat and vast and strange, lay the great
36	flying-machine with which they had been experimenting upon our denser
36	atmosphere when decay and death arrested them.  Death had come not a
36	day too soon.  At the sound of a cawing overhead I looked up at the
36	huge fighting-machine that would fight no more for ever, at the
36	tattered red shreds of flesh that dripped down upon the overturned
36	seats on the summit of Primrose Hill.
36	
36	I turned and looked down the slope of the hill to where, enhaloed
36	now in birds, stood those other two Martians that I had seen
36	overnight, just as death had overtaken them.  The one had died, even
36	as it had been crying to its companions; perhaps it was the last to
36	die, and its voice had gone on perpetually until the force of its
36	machinery was exhausted.  They glittered now, harmless tripod towers
36	of shining metal, in the brightness of the rising sun.
36	
36	All about the pit, and saved as by a miracle from everlasting
36	destruction, stretched the great Mother of Cities.  Those who have only
36	seen London veiled in her sombre robes of smoke can scarcely imagine
36	the naked clearness and beauty of the silent wilderness of houses.
36	
36	Eastward, over the blackened ruins of the Albert Terrace and the
36	splintered spire of the church, the sun blazed dazzling in a clear
36	sky, and here and there some facet in the great wilderness of roofs
36	caught the light and glared with a white intensity.
36	
36	Northward were Kilburn and Hampsted, blue and crowded with houses;
36	westward the great city was dimmed; and southward, beyond the
36	Martians, the green waves of Regent's Park, the Langham Hotel, the
36	dome of the Albert Hall, the Imperial Institute, and the giant
36	mansions of the Brompton Road came out clear and little in the
36	sunrise, the jagged ruins of Westminster rising hazily beyond.  Far
36	away and blue were the Surrey hills, and the towers of the Crystal
36	Palace glittered like two silver rods.  The dome of St. Paul's was
36	dark against the sunrise, and injured, I saw for the first time, by a
36	huge gaping cavity on its western side.
36	
36	And as I looked at this wide expanse of houses and factories and
36	churches, silent and abandoned; as I thought of the multitudinous
36	hopes and efforts, the innumerable hosts of lives that had gone to
36	build this human reef, and of the swift and ruthless destruction that
36	had hung over it all; when I realised that the shadow had been rolled
36	back, and that men might still live in the streets, and this dear vast
36	dead city of mine be once more alive and powerful, I felt a wave of
36	emotion that was near akin to tears.
36	
36	The torment was over.  Even that day the healing would begin.  The
36	survivors of the people scattered over the country--leaderless,
36	lawless, foodless, like sheep without a shepherd--the thousands who
36	had fled by sea, would begin to return; the pulse of life, growing
36	stronger and stronger, would beat again in the empty streets and pour
36	across the vacant squares.  Whatever destruction was done, the hand of
36	the destroyer was stayed.  All the gaunt wrecks, the blackened
36	skeletons of houses that stared so dismally at the sunlit grass of the
36	hill, would presently be echoing with the hammers of the restorers and
36	ringing with the tapping of their trowels.  At the thought I extended
36	my hands towards the sky and began thanking God.  In a year, thought
36	I--in a year. . .
36	
36	With overwhelming force came the thought of myself, of my wife, and
36	the old life of hope and tender helpfulness that had ceased for ever.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER NINE
36	
36	WRECKAGE
36	
36	
36	And now comes the strangest thing in my story.  Yet, perhaps, it is
36	not altogether strange.  I remember, clearly and coldly and vividly,
36	all that I did that day until the time that I stood weeping and
36	praising God upon the summit of Primrose Hill.  And then I forget.
36	
36	Of the next three days I know nothing.  I have learned since that,
36	so far from my being the first discoverer of the Martian overthrow,
36	several such wanderers as myself had already discovered this on the
36	previous night.  One man--the first--had gone to St. Martin's-le-Grand,
36	and, while I sheltered in the cabmen's hut, had contrived to
36	telegraph to Paris.  Thence the joyful news had flashed all over the
36	world; a thousand cities, chilled by ghastly apprehensions, suddenly
36	flashed into frantic illuminations; they knew of it in Dublin,
36	Edinburgh, Manchester, Birmingham, at the time when I stood upon the
36	verge of the pit.  Already men, weeping with joy, as I have heard,
36	shouting and staying their work to shake hands and shout, were making
36	up trains, even as near as Crewe, to descend upon London.  The church
36	bells that had ceased a fortnight since suddenly caught the news,
36	until all England was bell-ringing.  Men on cycles, lean-faced,
36	unkempt, scorched along every country lane shouting of unhoped
36	deliverance, shouting to gaunt, staring figures of despair.  And for
36	the food!  Across the Channel, across the Irish Sea, across the
36	Atlantic, corn, bread, and meat were tearing to our relief.  All the
36	shipping in the world seemed going Londonward in those days.  But of
36	all this I have no memory.  I drifted--a demented man.  I found myself
36	in a house of kindly people, who had found me on the third day
36	wandering, weeping, and raving through the streets of St. John's Wood.
36	They have told me since that I was singing some insane doggerel about
36	""The Last Man Left Alive! Hurrah!  The Last Man Left Alive!""  Troubled
36	as they were with their own affairs, these people, whose name, much as
36	I would like to express my gratitude to them, I may not even give
36	here, nevertheless cumbered themselves with me, sheltered me, and
36	protected me from myself.  Apparently they had learned something of my
36	story from me during the days of my lapse.
36	
36	Very gently, when my mind was assured again, did they break to me
36	what they had learned of the fate of Leatherhead.  Two days after I
36	was imprisoned it had been destroyed, with every soul in it, by a
36	Martian.  He had swept it out of existence, as it seemed, without any
36	provocation, as a boy might crush an ant hill, in the mere wantonness
36	of power.
36	
36	I was a lonely man, and they were very kind to me.  I was a lonely
36	man and a sad one, and they bore with me.  I remained with them four
36	days after my recovery.  All that time I felt a vague, a growing
36	craving to look once more on whatever remained of the little life that
36	seemed so happy and bright in my past.  It was a mere hopeless desire
36	to feast upon my misery.  They dissuaded me.  They did all they could
36	to divert me from this morbidity.  But at last I could resist the
36	impulse no longer, and, promising faithfully to return to them, and
36	parting, as I will confess, from these four-day friends with tears, I
36	went out again into the streets that had lately been so dark and
36	strange and empty.
36	
36	Already they were busy with returning people; in places even there
36	were shops open, and I saw a drinking fountain running water.
36	
36	I remember how mockingly bright the day seemed as I went back on my
36	melancholy pilgrimage to the little house at Woking, how busy the
36	streets and vivid the moving life about me.  So many people were
36	abroad everywhere, busied in a thousand activities, that it seemed
36	incredible that any great proportion of the population could have been
36	slain.  But then I noticed how yellow were the skins of the people I
36	met, how shaggy the hair of the men, how large and bright their eyes,
36	and that every other man still wore his dirty rags.  Their faces
36	seemed all with one of two expressions--a leaping exultation and
36	energy or a grim resolution.  Save for the expression of the faces,
36	London seemed a city of tramps.  The vestries were indiscriminately
36	distributing bread sent us by the French government.  The ribs of the
36	few horses showed dismally.  Haggard special constables with white
36	badges stood at the corners of every street.  I saw little of the
36	mischief wrought by the Martians until I reached Wellington Street,
36	and there I saw the red weed clambering over the buttresses of
36	Waterloo Bridge.
36	
36	At the corner of the bridge, too, I saw one of the common contrasts
36	of that grotesque time--a sheet of paper flaunting against a thicket
36	of the red weed, transfixed by a stick that kept it in place.  It was
36	the placard of the first newspaper to resume publication--the _Daily
36	Mail_.  I bought a copy for a blackened shilling I found in my pocket.
36	Most of it was in blank, but the solitary compositor who did the thing
36	had amused himself by making a grotesque scheme of advertisement
36	stereo on the back page.  The matter he printed was emotional; the
36	news organisation had not as yet found its way back.  I learned
36	nothing fresh except that already in one week the examination of the
36	Martian mechanisms had yielded astonishing results.  Among other
36	things, the article assured me what I did not believe at the time,
36	that the ""Secret of Flying,"" was discovered.  At Waterloo I found the
36	free trains that were taking people to their homes.  The first rush
36	was already over.  There were few people in the train, and I was in no
36	mood for casual conversation.  I got a compartment to myself, and sat
36	with folded arms, looking greyly at the sunlit devastation that flowed
36	past the windows.  And just outside the terminus the train jolted over
36	temporary rails, and on either side of the railway the houses were
36	blackened ruins.  To Clapham Junction the face of London was grimy
36	with powder of the Black Smoke, in spite of two days of thunderstorms
36	and rain, and at Clapham Junction the line had been wrecked again;
36	there were hundreds of out-of-work clerks and shopmen working side by
36	side with the customary navvies, and we were jolted over a hasty
36	relaying.
36	
36	All down the line from there the aspect of the country was gaunt
36	and unfamiliar; Wimbledon particularly had suffered.  Walton, by virtue
36	of its unburned pine woods, seemed the least hurt of any place along
36	the line.  The Wandle, the Mole, every little stream, was a heaped
36	mass of red weed, in appearance between butcher's meat and pickled
36	cabbage.  The Surrey pine woods were too dry, however, for the festoons
36	of the red climber.  Beyond Wimbledon, within sight of the line, in
36	certain nursery grounds, were the heaped masses of earth about the
36	sixth cylinder.  A number of people were standing about it, and some
36	sappers were busy in the midst of it.  Over it flaunted a Union Jack,
36	flapping cheerfully in the morning breeze.  The nursery grounds were
36	everywhere crimson with the weed, a wide expanse of livid colour cut
36	with purple shadows, and very painful to the eye.  One's gaze went
36	with infinite relief from the scorched greys and sullen reds of the
36	foreground to the blue-green softness of the eastward hills.
36	
36	The line on the London side of Woking station was still undergoing
36	repair, so I descended at Byfleet station and took the road to
36	Maybury, past the place where I and the artilleryman had talked to the
36	hussars, and on by the spot where the Martian had appeared to me in
36	the thunderstorm.  Here, moved by curiosity, I turned aside to find,
36	among a tangle of red fronds, the warped and broken dog cart with the
36	whitened bones of the horse scattered and gnawed.  For a time I stood
36	regarding these vestiges. . . .
36	
36	Then I returned through the pine wood, neck-high with red weed here
36	and there, to find the landlord of the Spotted Dog had already found
36	burial, and so came home past the College Arms.  A man standing at an
36	open cottage door greeted me by name as I passed.
36	
36	I looked at my house with a quick flash of hope that faded
36	immediately.  The door had been forced; it was unfast and was opening
36	slowly as I approached.
36	
36	It slammed again.  The curtains of my study fluttered out of the
36	open window from which I and the artilleryman had watched the dawn.  No
36	one had closed it since.  The smashed bushes were just as I had left
36	them nearly four weeks ago.  I stumbled into the hall, and the house
36	felt empty.  The stair carpet was ruffled and discoloured where I had
36	crouched, soaked to the skin from the thunderstorm the night of the
36	catastrophe.  Our muddy footsteps I saw still went up the stairs.
36	
36	I followed them to my study, and found lying on my writing-table
36	still, with the selenite paper weight upon it, the sheet of work I had
36	left on the afternoon of the opening of the cylinder.  For a space I
36	stood reading over my abandoned arguments.  It was a paper on the
36	probable development of Moral Ideas with the development of the
36	civilising process; and the last sentence was the opening of a
36	prophecy: ""In about two hundred years,"" I had written, ""we may
36	expect----""  The sentence ended abruptly.  I remembered my inability
36	to fix my mind that morning, scarcely a month gone by, and how I had
36	broken off to get my _Daily Chronicle_ from the newsboy.  I remembered
36	how I went down to the garden gate as he came along, and how I had
36	listened to his odd story of ""Men from Mars.""
36	
36	I came down and went into the dining room.  There were the mutton
36	and the bread, both far gone now in decay, and a beer bottle
36	overturned, just as I and the artilleryman had left them.  My home was
36	desolate.  I perceived the folly of the faint hope I had cherished so
36	long.  And then a strange thing occurred.  ""It is no use,"" said a
36	voice.  ""The house is deserted.  No one has been here these ten days.
36	Do not stay here to torment yourself.  No one escaped but you.""
36	
36	I was startled.  Had I spoken my thought aloud?  I turned, and the
36	French window was open behind me.  I made a step to it, and stood
36	looking out.
36	
36	And there, amazed and afraid, even as I stood amazed and afraid,
36	were my cousin and my wife--my wife white and tearless.  She gave a
36	faint cry.
36	
36	""I came,"" she said.  ""I knew--knew----""
36	
36	She put her hand to her throat--swayed.  I made a step forward, and
36	caught her in my arms.
36	
36	
36	
36	CHAPTER TEN
36	
36	THE EPILOGUE
36	
36	
36	I cannot but regret, now that I am concluding my story, how little
36	I am able to contribute to the discussion of the many debatable
36	questions which are still unsettled.  In one respect I shall certainly
36	provoke criticism.  My particular province is speculative philosophy.
36	My knowledge of comparative physiology is confined to a book or two,
36	but it seems to me that Carver's suggestions as to the reason of the
36	rapid death of the Martians is so probable as to be regarded almost as
36	a proven conclusion.  I have assumed that in the body of my narrative.
36	
36	At any rate, in all the bodies of the Martians that were examined
36	after the war, no bacteria except those already known as terrestrial
36	species were found.  That they did not bury any of their dead, and the
36	reckless slaughter they perpetrated, point also to an entire ignorance
36	of the putrefactive process.  But probable as this seems, it is by no
36	means a proven conclusion.
36	
36	Neither is the composition of the Black Smoke known, which the
36	Martians used with such deadly effect, and the generator of the
36	Heat-Rays remains a puzzle.  The terrible disasters at the Ealing
36	and South Kensington laboratories have disinclined analysts for further
36	investigations upon the latter.  Spectrum analysis of the black powder
36	points unmistakably to the presence of an unknown element with a
36	brilliant group of three lines in the green, and it is possible that
36	it combines with argon to form a compound which acts at once with
36	deadly effect upon some constituent in the blood.  But such unproven
36	speculations will scarcely be of interest to the general reader, to
36	whom this story is addressed.  None of the brown scum that drifted
36	down the Thames after the destruction of Shepperton was examined at
36	the time, and now none is forthcoming.
36	
36	The results of an anatomical examination of the Martians, so far
36	as the prowling dogs had left such an examination possible, I have
36	already given.  But everyone is familiar with the magnificent and
36	almost complete specimen in spirits at the Natural History Museum, and
36	the countless drawings that have been made from it; and beyond that
36	the interest of their physiology and structure is purely scientific.
36	
36	A question of graver and universal interest is the possibility of
36	another attack from the Martians.  I do not think that nearly enough
36	attention is being given to this aspect of the matter.  At present the
36	planet Mars is in conjunction, but with every return to opposition I,
36	for one, anticipate a renewal of their adventure.  In any case, we
36	should be prepared.  It seems to me that it should be possible to
36	define the position of the gun from which the shots are discharged, to
36	keep a sustained watch upon this part of the planet, and to anticipate
36	the arrival of the next attack.
36	
36	In that case the cylinder might be destroyed with dynamite or
36	artillery before it was sufficiently cool for the Martians to emerge,
36	or they might be butchered by means of guns so soon as the screw
36	opened.  It seems to me that they have lost a vast advantage in the
36	failure of their first surprise.  Possibly they see it in the same
36	light.
36	
36	Lessing has advanced excellent reasons for supposing that the
36	Martians have actually succeeded in effecting a landing on the planet
36	Venus.  Seven months ago now, Venus and Mars were in alignment with
36	the sun; that is to say, Mars was in opposition from the point of view
36	of an observer on Venus.  Subsequently a peculiar luminous and sinuous
36	marking appeared on the unillumined half of the inner planet, and
36	almost simultaneously a faint dark mark of a similar sinuous character
36	was detected upon a photograph of the Martian disk.  One needs to see
36	the drawings of these appearances in order to appreciate fully their
36	remarkable resemblance in character.
36	
36	At any rate, whether we expect another invasion or not, our views
36	of the human future must be greatly modified by these events.  We have
36	learned now that we cannot regard this planet as being fenced in and a
36	secure abiding place for Man; we can never anticipate the unseen good
36	or evil that may come upon us suddenly out of space.  It may be that
36	in the larger design of the universe this invasion from Mars is not
36	without its ultimate benefit for men; it has robbed us of that serene
36	confidence in the future which is the most fruitful source of
36	decadence, the gifts to human science it has brought are enormous, and
36	it has done much to promote the conception of the commonweal of
36	mankind.  It may be that across the immensity of space the Martians
36	have watched the fate of these pioneers of theirs and learned their
36	lesson, and that on the planet Venus they have found a securer
36	settlement.  Be that as it may, for many years yet there will
36	certainly be no relaxation of the eager scrutiny of the Martian disk,
36	and those fiery darts of the sky, the shooting stars, will bring with
36	them as they fall an unavoidable apprehension to all the sons of men.
36	
36	The broadening of men's views that has resulted can scarcely be
36	exaggerated.  Before the cylinder fell there was a general persuasion
36	that through all the deep of space no life existed beyond the petty
36	surface of our minute sphere.  Now we see further.  If the Martians
36	can reach Venus, there is no reason to suppose that the thing is
36	impossible for men, and when the slow cooling of the sun makes this
36	earth uninhabitable, as at last it must do, it may be that the thread
36	of life that has begun here will have streamed out and caught our
36	sister planet within its toils.
36	
36	Dim and wonderful is the vision I have conjured up in my mind of
36	life spreading slowly from this little seed bed of the solar system
36	throughout the inanimate vastness of sidereal space.  But that is a
36	remote dream.  It may be, on the other hand, that the destruction of
36	the Martians is only a reprieve.  To them, and not to us, perhaps, is
36	the future ordained.
36	
36	I must confess the stress and danger of the time have left an
36	abiding sense of doubt and insecurity in my mind.  I sit in my study
36	writing by lamplight, and suddenly I see again the healing valley
36	below set with writhing flames, and feel the house behind and about me
36	empty and desolate.  I go out into the Byfleet Road, and vehicles pass
36	me, a butcher boy in a cart, a cabful of visitors, a workman on a
36	bicycle, children going to school, and suddenly they become vague and
36	unreal, and I hurry again with the artilleryman through the hot,
36	brooding silence.  Of a night I see the black powder darkening the
36	silent streets, and the contorted bodies shrouded in that layer; they
36	rise upon me tattered and dog-bitten.  They gibber and grow fiercer,
36	paler, uglier, mad distortions of humanity at last, and I wake, cold
36	and wretched, in the darkness of the night.
36	
36	I go to London and see the busy multitudes in Fleet Street and the
36	Strand, and it comes across my mind that they are but the ghosts of
36	the past, haunting the streets that I have seen silent and wretched,
36	going to and fro, phantasms in a dead city, the mockery of life in a
36	galvanised body.  And strange, too, it is to stand on Primrose Hill,
36	as I did but a day before writing this last chapter, to see the great
36	province of houses, dim and blue through the haze of the smoke and
36	mist, vanishing at last into the vague lower sky, to see the people
36	walking to and fro among the flower beds on the hill, to see the
36	sight-seers about the Martian machine that stands there still, to hear
36	the tumult of playing children, and to recall the time when I saw it
36	all bright and clear-cut, hard and silent, under the dawn of that last
36	great day. . . .
36	
36	And strangest of all is it to hold my wife's hand again, and to think
36	that I have counted her, and that she has counted me, among the dead.

159	THE ISLAND OF DOCTOR MOREAU
159	
159	by
159	H. G. Wells

159

159	
159	
159	INTRODUCTION.
159	
159	ON February the First 1887, the Lady Vain was lost by collision
159	with a derelict when about the latitude 1 degree S. and longitude
159	107 degrees W.
159	
159	On January the Fifth, 1888--that is eleven months and four days after--my
159	uncle, Edward Prendick, a private gentleman, who certainly went
159	aboard the Lady Vain at Callao, and who had been considered drowned,
159	was picked up in latitude 5 degrees 3' S. and longitude 101 degrees W.
159	in a small open boat of which the name was illegible, but which is
159	supposed to have belonged to the missing schooner Ipecacuanha.
159	He gave such a strange account of himself that he was supposed demented.
159	Subsequently he alleged that his mind was a blank from the moment
159	of his escape from the Lady Vain.  His case was discussed among
159	psychologists at the time as a curious instance of the lapse
159	of memory consequent upon physical and mental stress.
159	The following narrative was found among his papers by the undersigned,
159	his nephew and heir, but unaccompanied by any definite request
159	for publication.
159	
159	The only island known to exist in the region in which my uncle was
159	picked up is Noble's Isle, a small volcanic islet and uninhabited.
159	It was visited in 1891 by H. M. S. Scorpion.  A party of sailors
159	then landed, but found nothing living thereon except certain curious
159	white moths, some hogs and rabbits, and some rather peculiar rats.
159	So that this narrative is without confirmation in its most
159	essential particular.  With that understood, there seems no harm
159	in putting this strange story before the public in accordance,
159	as I believe, with my uncle's intentions.  There is at least this
159	much in its behalf:  my uncle passed out of human knowledge about
159	latitude 5 degrees S. and longitude 105 degrees E., and reappeared
159	in the same part of the ocean after a space of eleven months.
159	In some way he must have lived during the interval.  And it seems that
159	a schooner called the Ipecacuanha with a drunken captain, John Davies,
159	did start from Africa with a puma and certain other animals aboard
159	in January, 1887, that the vessel was well known at several ports
159	in the South Pacific, and that it finally disappeared from those seas
159	(with a considerable amount of copra aboard), sailing to its unknown
159	fate from Bayna in December, 1887, a date that tallies entirely with my
159	uncle's story.
159	
159	CHARLES EDWARD PRENDICK.
159	
159	(The Story written by Edward Prendick.)
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	I.  IN THE DINGEY OF THE ""LADY VAIN.""
159	
159	
159	I DO not propose to add anything to what has already been written
159	concerning the loss of the ""Lady Vain.""  As everyone knows,
159	she collided with a derelict when ten days out from Callao.
159	The longboat, with seven of the crew, was picked up eighteen days after
159	by H. M. gunboat ""Myrtle,"" and the story of their terrible privations
159	has become quite as well known as the far more horrible ""Medusa"" case.
159	But I have to add to the published story of the ""Lady Vain""
159	another, possibly as horrible and far stranger.  It has hitherto
159	been supposed that the four men who were in the dingey perished,
159	but this is incorrect.  I have the best of evidence for this assertion:
159	I was one of the four men.
159	
159	But in the first place I must state that there never were four men
159	in the dingey,--the number was three.  Constans, who was ""seen
159	by the captain to jump into the gig,""{1} luckily for us and unluckily
159	for himself did not reach us.  He came down out of the tangle
159	of ropes under the stays of the smashed bowsprit, some small rope
159	caught his heel as he let go, and he hung for a moment head downward,
159	and then fell and struck a block or spar floating in the water.
159	We pulled towards him, but he never came up.
159	
159	{1} Daily News, March 17, 1887.
159	
159	I say luckily for us he did not reach us, and I might almost
159	say luckily for himself; for we had only a small beaker
159	of water and some soddened ship's biscuits with us, so sudden
159	had been the alarm, so unprepared the ship for any disaster.
159	We thought the people on the launch would be better provisioned
159	(though it seems they were not), and we tried to hail them.  They could
159	not have heard us, and the next morning when the drizzle cleared,--which
159	was not until past midday,--we could see nothing of them.  We could
159	not stand up to look about us, because of the pitching of the boat.
159	The two other men who had escaped so far with me were a man named Helmar,
159	a passenger like myself, and a seaman whose name I don't know,--a short
159	sturdy man, with a stammer.
159	
159	We drifted famishing, and, after our water had come to an end,
159	tormented by an intolerable thirst, for eight days altogether.
159	After the second day the sea subsided slowly to a glassy calm.  It is
159	quite impossible for the ordinary reader to imagine those eight days.
159	He has not, luckily for himself, anything in his memory to imagine with.
159	After the first day we said little to one another, and lay
159	in our places in the boat and stared at the horizon, or watched,
159	with eyes that grew larger and more haggard every day, the misery
159	and weakness gaining upon our companions.  The sun became pitiless.
159	The water ended on the fourth day, and we were already thinking
159	strange things and saying them with our eyes; but it was, I think,
159	the sixth before Helmar gave voice to the thing we had all been thinking.
159	I remember our voices were dry and thin, so that we bent towards
159	one another and spared our words.  I stood out against it with all
159	my might, was rather for scuttling the boat and perishing together
159	among the sharks that followed us; but when Helmar said that if his
159	proposal was accepted we should have drink, the sailor came round
159	to him.
159	
159	I would not draw lots however, and in the night the sailor whispered
159	to Helmar again and again, and I sat in the bows with my clasp-knife
159	in my hand, though I doubt if I had the stuff in me to fight;
159	and in the morning I agreed to Helmar's proposal, and we handed
159	halfpence to find the odd man.  The lot fell upon the sailor;
159	but he was the strongest of us and would not abide by it, and attacked
159	Helmar with his hands.  They grappled together and almost stood up.
159	I crawled along the boat to them, intending to help Helmar by grasping
159	the sailor's leg; but the sailor stumbled with the swaying of the boat,
159	and the two fell upon the gunwale and rolled overboard together.
159	They sank like stones.  I remember laughing at that, and wondering
159	why I laughed.  The laugh caught me suddenly like a thing
159	from without.
159	
159	I lay across one of the thwarts for I know not how long,
159	thinking that if I had the strength I would drink sea-water
159	and madden myself to die quickly.  And even as I lay there I saw,
159	with no more interest than if it had been a picture, a sail come
159	up towards me over the sky-line. My mind must have been wandering,
159	and yet I remember all that happened, quite distinctly.
159	I remember how my head swayed with the seas, and the horizon
159	with the sail above it danced up and down; but I also remember
159	as distinctly that I had a persuasion that I was dead, and that I
159	thought what a jest it was that they should come too late by such
159	a little to catch me in my body.
159	
159	For an endless period, as it seemed to me, I lay with my head
159	on the thwart watching the schooner (she was a little ship,
159	schooner-rigged fore and aft) come up out of the sea.
159	She kept tacking to and fro in a widening compass, for she was
159	sailing dead into the wind.  It never entered my head to attempt
159	to attract attention, and I do not remember anything distinctly after
159	the sight of her side until I found myself in a little cabin aft.
159	There's a dim half-memory of being lifted up to the gangway, and of
159	a big round countenance covered with freckles and surrounded with red
159	hair staring at me over the bulwarks.  I also had a disconnected
159	impression of a dark face, with extraordinary eyes, close to mine;
159	but that I thought was a nightmare, until I met it again.
159	I fancy I recollect some stuff being poured in between my teeth;
159	and that is all.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	II.  THE MAN WHO WAS GOING NOWHERE.
159	
159	
159	THE cabin in which I found myself was small and rather untidy.
159	A youngish man with flaxen hair, a bristly straw-coloured moustache,
159	and a dropping nether lip, was sitting and holding my wrist.
159	For a minute we stared at each other without speaking.
159	He had watery grey eyes, oddly void of expression.
159	Then just overhead came a sound like an iron bedstead being
159	knocked about, and the low angry growling of some large animal.
159	At the same time the man spoke.  He repeated his question,--""How do you
159	feel now?""
159	
159	I think I said I felt all right.  I could not recollect how I
159	had got there.  He must have seen the question in my face,
159	for my voice was inaccessible to me.
159	
159	""You were picked up in a boat, starving.  The name on the boat
159	was the 'Lady Vain,' and there were spots of blood on the gunwale.""
159	
159	At the same time my eye caught my hand, so thin that it looked
159	like a dirty skin-purse full of loose bones, and all the business
159	of the boat came back to me.
159	
159	""Have some of this,"" said he, and gave me a dose of some
159	scarlet stuff, iced.
159	
159	It tasted like blood, and made me feel stronger.
159	
159	""You were in luck,"" said he, ""to get picked up by a ship with a
159	medical man aboard.""  He spoke with a slobbering articulation,
159	with the ghost of a lisp.
159	
159	""What ship is this?""  I said slowly, hoarse from my long silence.
159	
159	""It's a little trader from Arica and Callao.  I never asked
159	where she came from in the beginning,--out of the land
159	of born fools, I guess.  I'm a passenger myself, from Arica.
159	The silly ass who owns her,--he's captain too, named Davies,--he's
159	lost his certificate, or something.  You know the kind of man,--calls
159	the thing the 'Ipecacuanha,' of all silly, infernal names;
159	though when there's much of a sea without any wind, she certainly
159	acts according.""
159	
159	(Then the noise overhead began again, a snarling growl
159	and the voice of a human being together.  Then another voice,
159	telling some ""Heaven-forsaken idiot"" to desist.)
159	
159	""You were nearly dead,"" said my interlocutor.  ""It was a very
159	near thing, indeed.  But I've put some stuff into you now.
159	Notice your arm's sore?  Injections.  You've been insensible for nearly
159	thirty hours.""
159	
159	I thought slowly.  (I was distracted now by the yelping of a number
159	of dogs.) ""Am I eligible for solid food?"" I asked.
159	
159	""Thanks to me,"" he said.  ""Even now the mutton is boiling.""
159	
159	""Yes,"" I said with assurance; ""I could eat some mutton.""
159	
159	""But,"" said he with a momentary hesitation, ""you know I'm dying to hear
159	of how you came to be alone in that boat.  Damn that howling!""
159	I thought I detected a certain suspicion in his eyes.
159	
159	He suddenly left the cabin, and I heard him in violent controversy
159	with some one, who seemed to me to talk gibberish in response to him.
