159	The matter sounded as though it ended in blows, but in that I thought
159	my ears were mistaken.  Then he shouted at the dogs, and returned to
159	the cabin.
159	
159	""Well?"" said he in the doorway.  ""You were just beginning to tell me.""
159	
159	I told him my name, Edward Prendick, and how I had taken to Natural
159	History as a relief from the dulness of my comfortable independence.
159	
159	He seemed interested in this.  ""I've done some science myself.  I did
159	my Biology at University College,--getting out the ovary of the earthworm
159	and the radula of the snail, and all that.  Lord!  It's ten years ago.
159	But go on! go on! tell me about the boat.""
159	
159	He was evidently satisfied with the frankness of my story,
159	which I told in concise sentences enough, for I felt horribly weak;
159	and when it was finished he reverted at once to the topic
159	of Natural History and his own biological studies.  He began to
159	question me closely about Tottenham Court Road and Gower Street.
159	""Is Caplatzi still flourishing?  What a shop that was!""
159	He had evidently been a very ordinary medical student, and drifted
159	incontinently to the topic of the music halls.  He told me
159	some anecdotes.
159	
159	""Left it all,"" he said, ""ten years ago.  How jolly it all used to be!
159	But I made a young ass of myself,--played myself out before I was
159	twenty-one. I daresay it's all different now.  But I must look up
159	that ass of a cook, and see what he's done to your mutton.""
159	
159	The growling overhead was renewed, so suddenly and with so much savage
159	anger that it startled me.  ""What's that?""  I called after him,
159	but the door had closed.  He came back again with the boiled mutton,
159	and I was so excited by the appetising smell of it that I forgot
159	the noise of the beast that had troubled me.
159	
159	After a day of alternate sleep and feeding I was so far recovered
159	as to be able to get from my bunk to the scuttle, and see the green
159	seas trying to keep pace with us.  I judged the schooner was running
159	before the wind.  Montgomery--that was the name of the flaxen-haired
159	man--came in again as I stood there, and I asked him for some clothes.
159	He lent me some duck things of his own, for those I had worn in the boat
159	had been thrown overboard.  They were rather loose for me, for he was
159	large and long in his limbs.  He told me casually that the captain
159	was three-parts drunk in his own cabin.  As I assumed the clothes,
159	I began asking him some questions about the destination of the ship.
159	He said the ship was bound to Hawaii, but that it had to land
159	him first.
159	
159	""Where?"" said I.
159	
159	""It's an island, where I live.  So far as I know, it hasn't got
159	a name.""
159	
159	He stared at me with his nether lip dropping, and looked so wilfully
159	stupid of a sudden that it came into my head that he desired
159	to avoid my questions.  I had the discretion to ask no more.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	III.  THE STRANGE FACE.
159	
159	
159	WE left the cabin and found a man at the companion obstructing
159	our way.  He was standing on the ladder with his back to us,
159	peering over the combing of the hatchway.  He was, I could see,
159	a misshapen man, short, broad, and clumsy, with a crooked back,
159	a hairy neck, and a head sunk between his shoulders.  He was dressed
159	in dark-blue serge, and had peculiarly thick, coarse, black hair.
159	I heard the unseen dogs growl furiously, and forthwith he ducked
159	back,--coming into contact with the hand I put out to fend him off
159	from myself.  He turned with animal swiftness.
159	
159	In some indefinable way the black face thus flashed upon me
159	shocked me profoundly.  It was a singularly deformed one.
159	The facial part projected, forming something dimly suggestive
159	of a muzzle, and the huge half-open mouth showed as big white teeth
159	as I had ever seen in a human mouth.  His eyes were blood-shot
159	at the edges, with scarcely a rim of white round the hazel pupils.
159	There was a curious glow of excitement in his face.
159	
159	""Confound you!"" said Montgomery.  ""Why the devil don't you get
159	out of the way?""
159	
159	The black-faced man started aside without a word.
159	I went on up the companion, staring at him instinctively
159	as I did so.  Montgomery stayed at the foot for a moment.
159	""You have no business here, you know,"" he said in a deliberate tone.
159	""Your place is forward.""
159	
159	The black-faced man cowered.  ""They--won't have me forward.""
159	He spoke slowly, with a queer, hoarse quality in his voice.
159	
159	""Won't have you forward!"" said Montgomery, in a menacing voice.
159	""But I tell you to go!""  He was on the brink of saying something further,
159	then looked up at me suddenly and followed me up the ladder.
159	
159	I had paused half way through the hatchway, looking back, still astonished
159	beyond measure at the grotesque ugliness of this black-faced creature.
159	I had never beheld such a repulsive and extraordinary face before,
159	and yet--if the contradiction is credible--I experienced at
159	the same time an odd feeling that in some way I _had_ already
159	encountered exactly the features and gestures that now amazed me.
159	Afterwards it occurred to me that probably I had seen him as I
159	was lifted aboard; and yet that scarcely satisfied my suspicion
159	of a previous acquaintance.  Yet how one could have set eyes on
159	so singular a face and yet have forgotten the precise occasion,
159	passed my imagination.
159	
159	Montgomery's movement to follow me released my attention, and I
159	turned and looked about me at the flush deck of the little schooner.
159	I was already half prepared by the sounds I had heard for what I saw.
159	Certainly I never beheld a deck so dirty.  It was littered with
159	scraps of carrot, shreds of green stuff, and indescribable filth.
159	Fastened by chains to the mainmast were a number of grisly staghounds,
159	who now began leaping and barking at me, and by the mizzen a huge puma was
159	cramped in a little iron cage far too small even to give it turning room.
159	Farther under the starboard bulwark were some big hutches containing
159	a number of rabbits, and a solitary llama was squeezed in a mere
159	box of a cage forward.  The dogs were muzzled by leather straps.
159	The only human being on deck was a gaunt and silent sailor at
159	the wheel.
159	
159	The patched and dirty spankers were tense before the wind,
159	and up aloft the little ship seemed carrying every sail she had.
159	The sky was clear, the sun midway down the western sky;
159	long waves, capped by the breeze with froth, were running with us.
159	We went past the steersman to the taffrail, and saw the water come
159	foaming under the stern and the bubbles go dancing and vanishing
159	in her wake.  I turned and surveyed the unsavoury length of
159	the ship.
159	
159	""Is this an ocean menagerie?"" said I.
159	
159	""Looks like it,"" said Montgomery.
159	
159	""What are these beasts for?  Merchandise, curios?  Does the captain
159	think he is going to sell them somewhere in the South Seas?""
159	
159	""It looks like it, doesn't it?"" said Montgomery, and turned towards
159	the wake again.
159	
159	Suddenly we heard a yelp and a volley of furious blasphemy
159	from the companion hatchway, and the deformed man with the black
159	face came up hurriedly.  He was immediately followed by a heavy
159	red-haired man in a white cap.  At the sight of the former
159	the staghounds, who had all tired of barking at me by this time,
159	became furiously excited, howling and leaping against their chains.
159	The black hesitated before them, and this gave the red-haired man
159	time to come up with him and deliver a tremendous blow between
159	the shoulder-blades. The poor devil went down like a felled ox,
159	and rolled in the dirt among the furiously excited dogs.
159	It was lucky for him that they were muzzled.  The red-haired man gave
159	a yawp of exultation and stood staggering, and as it seemed to me
159	in serious danger of either going backwards down the companion hatchway
159	or forwards upon his victim.
159	
159	So soon as the second man had appeared, Montgomery had started forward.
159	""Steady on there!"" he cried, in a tone of remonstrance.
159	A couple of sailors appeared on the forecastle.  The black-faced man,
159	howling in a singular voice rolled about under the feet of the dogs.
159	No one attempted to help him.  The brutes did their best to worry him,
159	butting their muzzles at him.  There was a quick dance of their
159	lithe grey-figured bodies over the clumsy, prostrate figure.
159	The sailors forward shouted, as though it was admirable sport.
159	Montgomery gave an angry exclamation, and went striding down
159	the deck, and I followed him.  The black-faced man scrambled
159	up and staggered forward, going and leaning over the bulwark
159	by the main shrouds, where he remained, panting and glaring
159	over his shoulder at the dogs.  The red-haired man laughed a
159	satisfied laugh.
159	
159	""Look here, Captain,"" said Montgomery, with his lisp a little accentuated,
159	gripping the elbows of the red-haired man, ""this won't do!""
159	
159	I stood behind Montgomery.  The captain came half round,
159	and regarded him with the dull and solemn eyes of a drunken man.
159	""Wha' won't do?"" he said, and added, after looking sleepily into
159	Montgomery's face for a minute, ""Blasted Sawbones!""
159	
159	With a sudden movement he shook his arms free, and after two
159	ineffectual attempts stuck his freckled fists into his side pockets.
159	
159	""That man's a passenger,"" said Montgomery.  ""I'd advise you to keep
159	your hands off him.""
159	
159	""Go to hell!"" said the captain, loudly.  He suddenly turned
159	and staggered towards the side.  ""Do what I like on my own ship,""
159	he said.
159	
159	I think Montgomery might have left him then, seeing the brute was drunk;
159	but he only turned a shade paler, and followed the captain
159	to the bulwarks.
159	
159	""Look you here, Captain,"" he said; ""that man of mine is not to be
159	ill-treated. He has been hazed ever since he came aboard.""
159	
159	For a minute, alcoholic fumes kept the captain speechless.
159	""Blasted Sawbones!"" was all he considered necessary.
159	
159	I could see that Montgomery had one of those slow, pertinacious tempers
159	that will warm day after day to a white heat, and never again
159	cool to forgiveness; and I saw too that this quarrel had been
159	some time growing.  ""The man's drunk,"" said I, perhaps officiously;
159	""you'll do no good.""
159	
159	Montgomery gave an ugly twist to his dropping lip.  ""He's always drunk.
159	Do you think that excuses his assaulting his passengers?""
159	
159	""My ship,"" began the captain, waving his hand unsteadily
159	towards the cages, ""was a clean ship.  Look at it now!""
159	It was certainly anything but clean.  ""Crew,"" continued the captain,
159	""clean, respectable crew.""
159	
159	""You agreed to take the beasts.""
159	
159	""I wish I'd never set eyes on your infernal island.  What the
159	devil--want beasts for on an island like that?  Then, that man of
159	yours--understood he was a man.  He's a lunatic; and he hadn't no
159	business aft.  Do you think the whole damned ship belongs to you?""
159	
159	""Your sailors began to haze the poor devil as soon as he came aboard.""
159	
159	""That's just what he is--he's a devil! an ugly devil!  My men
159	can't stand him.  _I_ can't stand him.  None of us can't stand him.
159	Nor _you_ either!""
159	
159	Montgomery turned away.  ""_You_ leave that man alone, anyhow,"" he said,
159	nodding his head as he spoke.
159	
159	But the captain meant to quarrel now.  He raised his voice.  ""If he comes
159	this end of the ship again I'll cut his insides out, I tell you.
159	Cut out his blasted insides!  Who are you, to tell me what I'm to do?
159	I tell you I'm captain of this ship,--captain and owner.
159	I'm the law here, I tell you,--the law and the prophets.
159	I bargained to take a man and his attendant to and from Arica,
159	and bring back some animals.  I never bargained to carry a mad devil
159	and a silly Sawbones, a--""
159	
159	Well, never mind what he called Montgomery.  I saw the latter take
159	a step forward, and interposed.  ""He's drunk,"" said I. The captain
159	began some abuse even fouler than the last.  ""Shut up!"" I said,
159	turning on him sharply, for I had seen danger in Montgomery's white face.
159	With that I brought the downpour on myself.
159	
159	However, I was glad to avert what was uncommonly near a scuffle,
159	even at the price of the captain's drunken ill-will. I do not think
159	I have ever heard quite so much vile language come in a continuous
159	stream from any man's lips before, though I have frequented eccentric
159	company enough.  I found some of it hard to endure, though I am
159	a mild-tempered man; but, certainly, when I told the captain to
159	""shut up"" I had forgotten that I was merely a bit of human flotsam,
159	cut off from my resources and with my fare unpaid; a mere casual
159	dependant on the bounty, or speculative enterprise, of the ship.
159	He reminded me of it with considerable vigour; but at any rate I prevented
159	a fight.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	IV.  AT THE SCHOONER'S RAIL.
159	
159	
159	THAT night land was sighted after sundown, and the schooner
159	hove to.  Montgomery intimated that was his destination.
159	It was too far to see any details; it seemed to me then simply
159	a low-lying patch of dim blue in the uncertain blue-grey sea.
159	An almost vertical streak of smoke went up from it into the sky.
159	The captain was not on deck when it was sighted.  After he had vented
159	his wrath on me he had staggered below, and I understand he went to sleep
159	on the floor of his own cabin.  The mate practically assumed the command.
159	He was the gaunt, taciturn individual we had seen at the wheel.
159	Apparently he was in an evil temper with Montgomery.  He took
159	not the slightest notice of either of us.  We dined with him in a
159	sulky silence, after a few ineffectual efforts on my part to talk.
159	It struck me too that the men regarded my companion and his animals
159	in a singularly unfriendly manner.  I found Montgomery very reticent
159	about his purpose with these creatures, and about his destination;
159	and though I was sensible of a growing curiosity as to both, I did not
159	press him.
159	
159	We remained talking on the quarter deck until the sky was thick
159	with stars.  Except for an occasional sound in the yellow-lit forecastle
159	and a movement of the animals now and then, the night was very still.
159	The puma lay crouched together, watching us with shining eyes, a black
159	heap in the corner of its cage.  Montgomery produced some cigars.
159	He talked to me of London in a tone of half-painful reminiscence,
159	asking all kinds of questions about changes that had taken place.
159	He spoke like a man who had loved his life there, and had been
159	suddenly and irrevocably cut off from it.  I gossiped as well as I
159	could of this and that.  All the time the strangeness of him was
159	shaping itself in my mind; and as I talked I peered at his odd,
159	pallid face in the dim light of the binnacle lantern behind me.  Then I
159	looked out at the darkling sea, where in the dimness his little island
159	was hidden.
159	
159	This man, it seemed to me, had come out of Immensity merely to save
159	my life.  To-morrow he would drop over the side, and vanish again out
159	of my existence.  Even had it been under commonplace circumstances,
159	it would have made me a trifle thoughtful; but in the first place was
159	the singularity of an educated man living on this unknown little island,
159	and coupled with that the extraordinary nature of his luggage.
159	I found myself repeating the captain's question. What did he want
159	with the beasts?  Why, too, had he pretended they were not his when I
159	had remarked about them at first?  Then, again, in his personal attendant
159	there was a bizarre quality which had impressed me profoundly.
159	These circumstances threw a haze of mystery round the man.  They laid
159	hold of my imagination, and hampered my tongue.
159	
159	Towards midnight our talk of London died away, and we stood
159	side by side leaning over the bulwarks and staring dreamily
159	over the silent, starlit sea, each pursuing his own thoughts.
159	It was the atmosphere for sentiment, and I began upon my gratitude.
159	
159	""If I may say it,"" said I, after a time, ""you have saved my life.""
159	
159	""Chance,"" he answered.  ""Just chance.""
159	
159	""I prefer to make my thanks to the accessible agent.""
159	
159	""Thank no one.  You had the need, and I had the knowledge;
159	and I injected and fed you much as I might have collected a specimen.
159	I was bored and wanted something to do.  If I'd been jaded that day,
159	or hadn't liked your face, well--it's a curious question where you would
159	have been now!""
159	
159	This damped my mood a little.  ""At any rate,"" I began.
159	
159	""It's a chance, I tell you,"" he interrupted, ""as everything is in
159	a man's life.  Only the asses won't see it!  Why am I here now,
159	an outcast from civilisation, instead of being a happy man enjoying
159	all the pleasures of London?  Simply because eleven years ago--I
159	lost my head for ten minutes on a foggy night.""
159	
159	He stopped.  ""Yes?"" said I.
159	
159	""That's all.""
159	
159	We relapsed into silence.  Presently he laughed.
159	""There's something in this starlight that loosens one's tongue.
159	I'm an ass, and yet somehow I would like to tell you.""
159	
159	""Whatever you tell me, you may rely upon my keeping to myself--if
159	that's it.""
159	
159	He was on the point of beginning, and then shook his head, doubtfully.
159	
159	""Don't,"" said I.  ""It is all the same to me.  After all, it is better
159	to keep your secret.  There's nothing gained but a little relief
159	if I respect your confidence.  If I don't--well?""
159	
159	He grunted undecidedly.  I felt I had him at a disadvantage, had caught
159	him in the mood of indiscretion; and to tell the truth I was not curious
159	to learn what might have driven a young medical student out of London.
159	I have an imagination.  I shrugged my shoulders and turned away.
159	Over the taffrail leant a silent black figure, watching the stars.
159	It was Montgomery's strange attendant.  It looked over its shoulder
159	quickly with my movement, then looked away again.
159	
159	It may seem a little thing to you, perhaps, but it came like a sudden
159	blow to me.  The only light near us was a lantern at the wheel.
159	The creature's face was turned for one brief instant out of the dimness
159	of the stern towards this illumination, and I saw that the eyes
159	that glanced at me shone with a pale-green light.  I did not know then
159	that a reddish luminosity, at least, is not uncommon in human eyes.
159	The thing came to me as stark inhumanity.  That black figure with its
159	eyes of fire struck down through all my adult thoughts and feelings,
159	and for a moment the forgotten horrors of childhood came back to my mind.
159	Then the effect passed as it had come.  An uncouth black figure
159	of a man, a figure of no particular import, hung over the taffrail
159	against the starlight, and I found Montgomery was speaking
159	to me.
159	
159	""I'm thinking of turning in, then,"" said he, ""if you've had enough
159	of this.""
159	
159	I answered him incongruously.  We went below, and he wished me
159	good-night at the door of my cabin.
159	
159	That night I had some very unpleasant dreams.  The waning
159	moon rose late.  Its light struck a ghostly white beam across
159	my cabin, and made an ominous shape on the planking by my bunk.
159	Then the staghounds woke, and began howling and baying;
159	so that I dreamt fitfully, and scarcely slept until the approach
159	of dawn.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	V.  THE MAN WHO HAD NOWHERE TO GO.
159	
159	
159	IN the early morning (it was the second morning after my recovery,
159	and I believe the fourth after I was picked up), I awoke through an avenue
159	of tumultuous dreams,--dreams of guns and howling mobs,--and became
159	sensible of a hoarse shouting above me.  I rubbed my eyes and lay
159	listening to the noise, doubtful for a little while of my whereabouts.
159	Then came a sudden pattering of bare feet, the sound of heavy objects
159	being thrown about, a violent creaking and the rattling of chains.
159	I heard the swish of the water as the ship was suddenly brought round,
159	and a foamy yellow-green wave flew across the little round
159	window and left it streaming.  I jumped into my clothes and went
159	on deck.
159	
159	As I came up the ladder I saw against the flushed sky--for the sun
159	was just rising--the broad back and red hair of the captain,
159	and over his shoulder the puma spinning from a tackle rigged on
159	to the mizzen spanker-boom.
159	
159	The poor brute seemed horribly scared, and crouched in the bottom
159	of its little cage.
159	
159	""Overboard with 'em!"" bawled the captain.  ""Overboard with 'em!
159	We'll have a clean ship soon of the whole bilin' of 'em.""
159	
159	He stood in my way, so that I had perforce to tap his shoulder
159	to come on deck.  He came round with a start, and staggered back
159	a few paces to stare at me.  It needed no expert eye to tell
159	that the man was still drunk.
159	
159	""Hullo!"" said he, stupidly; and then with a light coming into his eyes,
159	""Why, it's Mister--Mister?""
159	
159	""Prendick,"" said I.
159	
159	""Prendick be damned!"" said he.  ""Shut-up,--that's your name.
159	Mister Shut-up.""
159	
159	It was no good answering the brute; but I certainly did not expect
159	his next move.  He held out his hand to the gangway by which Montgomery
159	stood talking to a massive grey-haired man in dirty-blue flannels,
159	who had apparently just come aboard.
159	
159	""That way, Mister Blasted Shut-up! that way!"" roared the captain.
159	
159	Montgomery and his companion turned as he spoke.
159	
159	""What do you mean?""  I said.
159	
159	""That way, Mister Blasted Shut-up,--that's what I mean!
159	Overboard, Mister Shut-up,--and sharp!  We're cleaning the ship
159	out,--cleaning the whole blessed ship out; and overboard you go!""
159	
159	I stared at him dumfounded.  Then it occurred to me that it was
159	exactly the thing I wanted.  The lost prospect of a journey as sole
159	passenger with this quarrelsome sot was not one to mourn over.
159	I turned towards Montgomery.
159	
159	""Can't have you,"" said Montgomery's companion, concisely.
159	
159	""You can't have me!"" said I, aghast.  He had the squarest and most
159	resolute face I ever set eyes upon.
159	
159	""Look here,"" I began, turning to the captain.
159	
159	""Overboard!"" said the captain.  ""This ship aint for beasts
159	and cannibals and worse than beasts, any more.  Overboard you go,
159	Mister Shut-up. If they can't have you, you goes overboard.
159	But, anyhow, you go--with your friends.  I've done with this blessed
159	island for evermore, amen!  I've had enough of it.""
159	
159	""But, Montgomery,"" I appealed.
159	
159	He distorted his lower lip, and nodded his head hopelessly at
159	the grey-haired man beside him, to indicate his powerlessness to help me.
159	
159	""I'll see to _you_, presently,"" said the captain.
159	
159	Then began a curious three-cornered altercation.
159	Alternately I appealed to one and another of the three men,--first
159	to the grey-haired man to let me land, and then to the drunken
159	captain to keep me aboard.  I even bawled entreaties to the sailors.
159	Montgomery said never a word, only shook his head.
159	""You're going overboard, I tell you,"" was the captain's refrain.
159	""Law be damned!  I'm king here.""  At last I must confess
159	my voice suddenly broke in the middle of a vigorous threat.
159	I felt a gust of hysterical petulance, and went aft and stared dismally
159	at nothing.
159	
159	Meanwhile the sailors progressed rapidly with the task of
159	unshipping the packages and caged animals.  A large launch,
159	with two standing lugs, lay under the lee of the schooner;
159	and into this the strange assortment of goods were swung.
159	I did not then see the hands from the island that were receiving
159	the packages, for the hull of the launch was hidden from me
159	by the side of the schooner.  Neither Montgomery nor his companion
159	took the slightest notice of me, but busied themselves in assisting
159	and directing the four or five sailors who were unloading the goods.
159	The captain went forward interfering rather than assisting.
159	I was alternately despairful and desperate.  Once or twice
159	as I stood waiting there for things to accomplish themselves,
159	I could not resist an impulse to laugh at my miserable quandary.
159	I felt all the wretcheder for the lack of a breakfast.
159	Hunger and a lack of blood-corpuscles take all the manhood from a man.
159	I perceived pretty clearly that I had not the stamina
159	either to resist what the captain chose to do to expel me,
159	or to force myself upon Montgomery and his companion.
159	So I waited passively upon fate; and the work of transferring
159	Montgomery's possessions to the launch went on as if I did
159	not exist.
159	
159	Presently that work was finished, and then came a struggle.
159	I was hauled, resisting weakly enough, to the gangway.
159	Even then I noticed the oddness of the brown faces of the men who were
159	with Montgomery in the launch; but the launch was now fully laden,
159	and was shoved off hastily.  A broadening gap of green water
159	appeared under me, and I pushed back with all my strength to avoid
159	falling headlong.  The hands in the launch shouted derisively,
159	and I heard Montgomery curse at them; and then the captain,
159	the mate, and one of the seamen helping him, ran me aft towards
159	the stern.
159	
159	The dingey of the ""Lady Vain"" had been towing behind; it was
159	half full of water, had no oars, and was quite unvictualled.
159	I refused to go aboard her, and flung myself full length on the deck.
159	In the end, they swung me into her by a rope (for they had no
159	stern ladder), and then they cut me adrift.  I drifted slowly
159	from the schooner.  In a kind of stupor I watched all hands take
159	to the rigging, and slowly but surely she came round to the wind;
159	the sails fluttered, and then bellied out as the wind came into them.
159	I stared at her weather-beaten side heeling steeply towards me;
159	and then she passed out of my range of view.
159	
159	I did not turn my head to follow her.  At first I could scarcely
159	believe what had happened.  I crouched in the bottom of the dingey,
159	stunned, and staring blankly at the vacant, oily sea.  Then I realised
159	that I was in that little hell of mine again, now half swamped;
159	and looking back over the gunwale, I saw the schooner standing away
159	from me, with the red-haired captain mocking at me over the taffrail,
159	and turning towards the island saw the launch growing smaller as she
159	approached the beach.
159	
159	Abruptly the cruelty of this desertion became clear to me.
159	I had no means of reaching the land unless I should chance to drift there.
159	I was still weak, you must remember, from my exposure in the boat;
159	I was empty and very faint, or I should have had more heart.
159	But as it was I suddenly began to sob and weep, as I had never done
159	since I was a little child.  The tears ran down my face.  In a passion
159	of despair I struck with my fists at the water in the bottom of the boat,
159	and kicked savagely at the gunwale.  I prayed aloud for God to let
159	me die.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	VI.  THE EVIL-LOOKING BOATMEN.
159	
159	
159	BUT the islanders, seeing that I was really adrift, took pity on me.
159	I drifted very slowly to the eastward, approaching the island slantingly;
159	and presently I saw, with hysterical relief, the launch come round and
159	return towards me.  She was heavily laden, and I could make out as she
159	drew nearer Montgomery's white-haired, broad-shouldered companion sitting
159	cramped up with the dogs and several packing-cases in the stern sheets.
159	This individual stared fixedly at me without moving or speaking.
159	The black-faced cripple was glaring at me as fixedly in the bows
159	near the puma.  There were three other men besides,--three strange
159	brutish-looking fellows, at whom the staghounds were snarling savagely.
159	Montgomery, who was steering, brought the boat by me, and rising,
159	caught and fastened my painter to the tiller to tow me, for there was no
159	room aboard.
159	
159	I had recovered from my hysterical phase by this time
159	and answered his hail, as he approached, bravely enough.
159	I told him the dingey was nearly swamped, and he reached me a piggin.
159	I was jerked back as the rope tightened between the boats.
159	For some time I was busy baling.
159	
159	It was not until I had got the water under (for the water
159	in the dingey had been shipped; the boat was perfectly sound)
159	that I had leisure to look at the people in the launch again.
159	
159	The white-haired man I found was still regarding me steadfastly,
159	but with an expression, as I now fancied, of some perplexity.
159	When my eyes met his, he looked down at the staghound that sat
159	between his knees.  He was a powerfully-built man, as I have said,
159	with a fine forehead and rather heavy features; but his eyes
159	had that odd drooping of the skin above the lids which often
159	comes with advancing years, and the fall of his heavy mouth
159	at the corners gave him an expression of pugnacious resolution.
159	He talked to Montgomery in a tone too low for me to hear.
159	
159	From him my eyes travelled to his three men; and a strange crew they were.
159	I saw only their faces, yet there was something in their
159	faces--I knew not what--that gave me a queer spasm of disgust.
159	I looked steadily at them, and the impression did not pass,
159	though I failed to see what had occasioned it.  They seemed
159	to me then to be brown men; but their limbs were oddly swathed
159	in some thin, dirty, white stuff down even to the fingers and feet:
159	I have never seen men so wrapped up before, and women so only in the East.
159	They wore turbans too, and thereunder peered out their elfin
159	faces at me,--faces with protruding lower-jaws and bright eyes.
159	They had lank black hair, almost like horsehair, and seemed
159	as they sat to exceed in stature any race of men I have seen.
159	The white-haired man, who I knew was a good six feet in height,
159	sat a head below any one of the three.  I found afterwards that really
159	none were taller than myself; but their bodies were abnormally long,
159	and the thigh-part of the leg short and curiously twisted.
159	At any rate, they were an amazingly ugly gang, and over the heads
159	of them under the forward lug peered the black face of the man whose
159	eyes were luminous in the dark.  As I stared at them, they met my gaze;
159	and then first one and then another turned away from my direct stare,
159	and looked at me in an odd, furtive manner.  It occurred to me that I
159	was perhaps annoying them, and I turned my attention to the island
159	we were approaching.
159	
159	It was low, and covered with thick vegetation,--chiefly a kind of palm,
159	that was new to me.  From one point a thin white thread of vapour rose
159	slantingly to an immense height, and then frayed out like a down feather.
159	We were now within the embrace of a broad bay flanked on either
159	hand by a low promontory.  The beach was of dull-grey sand,
159	and sloped steeply up to a ridge, perhaps sixty or seventy feet above
159	the sea-level, and irregularly set with trees and undergrowth.
159	Half way up was a square enclosure of some greyish stone, which I found
159	subsequently was built partly of coral and partly of pumiceous lava.
159	Two thatched roofs peeped from within this enclosure.
159	A man stood awaiting us at the water's edge.  I fancied while we
159	were still far off that I saw some other and very grotesque-looking
159	creatures scuttle into the bushes upon the slope; but I saw nothing
159	of these as we drew nearer.  This man was of a moderate size,
159	and with a black negroid face.  He had a large, almost lipless,
159	mouth, extraordinary lank arms, long thin feet, and bow-legs,
159	and stood with his heavy face thrust forward staring at us.
159	He was dressed like Montgomery and his white-haired companion,
159	in jacket and trousers of blue serge.  As we came still nearer,
159	this individual began to run to and fro on the beach, making the most
159	grotesque movements.
159	
159	At a word of command from Montgomery, the four men in the launch
159	sprang up, and with singularly awkward gestures struck the lugs.
159	Montgomery steered us round and into a narrow little dock excavated
159	in the beach.  Then the man on the beach hastened towards us.
159	This dock, as I call it, was really a mere ditch just long
159	enough at this phase of the tide to take the longboat.
159	I heard the bows ground in the sand, staved the dingey off the rudder
159	of the big boat with my piggin, and freeing the painter, landed.
159	The three muffled men, with the clumsiest movements, scrambled out
159	upon the sand, and forthwith set to landing the cargo, assisted by
159	the man on the beach.  I was struck especially by the curious
159	movements of the legs of the three swathed and bandaged boatmen,--not
159	stiff they were, but distorted in some odd way, almost as if they
159	were jointed in the wrong place.  The dogs were still snarling,
159	and strained at their chains after these men, as the white-haired
159	man landed with them.  The three big fellows spoke to one another
159	in odd guttural tones, and the man who had waited for us on
159	the beach began chattering to them excitedly--a foreign language,
159	as I fancied--as they laid hands on some bales piled near the stern.
159	Somewhere I had heard such a voice before, and I could not think where.
159	The white-haired man stood, holding in a tumult of six dogs, and bawling
159	orders over their din.  Montgomery, having unshipped the rudder,
159	landed likewise, and all set to work at unloading.  I was too faint,
159	what with my long fast and the sun beating down on my bare head, to offer
159	any assistance.
159	
159	Presently the white-haired man seemed to recollect my presence,
159	and came up to me.
159	
159	""You look,"" said he, ""as though you had scarcely breakfasted.""
159	His little eyes were a brilliant black under his heavy brows.
159	""I must apologise for that.  Now you are our guest, we must
159	make you comfortable,--though you are uninvited, you know.""
159	He looked keenly into my face.  ""Montgomery says you are an educated man,
159	Mr. Prendick; says you know something of science.  May I ask what
159	that signifies?""
159	
159	I told him I had spent some years at the Royal College of Science,
159	and had done some researches in biology under Huxley.  He raised
159	his eyebrows slightly at that.
159	
159	""That alters the case a little, Mr. Prendick,"" he said,
159	with a trifle more respect in his manner.  ""As it happens,
159	we are biologists here.  This is a biological station--of a sort.""
159	His eye rested on the men in white who were busily hauling the puma,
159	on rollers, towards the walled yard.  ""I and Montgomery, at least,""
159	he added.  Then, ""When you will be able to get away, I can't say.
159	We're off the track to anywhere.  We see a ship once in a twelve-month
159	or so.""
159	
159	He left me abruptly, and went up the beach past this group, and I
159	think entered the enclosure.  The other two men were with Montgomery,
159	erecting a pile of smaller packages on a low-wheeled truck.
159	The llama was still on the launch with the rabbit hutches;
159	the staghounds were still lashed to the thwarts.
159	The pile of things completed, all three men laid hold of the truck
159	and began shoving the ton-weight or so upon it after the puma.
159	Presently Montgomery left them, and coming back to me held out
159	his hand.
159	
159	""I'm glad,"" said he, ""for my own part.  That captain was a silly ass.
159	He'd have made things lively for you.""
159	
159	""It was you,"" said I, ""that saved me again.""
159	
159	""That depends.  You'll find this island an infernally rum place,
159	I promise you.  I'd watch my goings carefully, if I were you.
159	_He_--"" He hesitated, and seemed to alter his mind about what
159	was on his lips.  ""I wish you'd help me with these rabbits,""
159	he said.
159	
159	His procedure with the rabbits was singular.  I waded
159	in with him, and helped him lug one of the hutches ashore.
159	No sooner was that done than he opened the door of it, and tilting
159	the thing on one end turned its living contents out on the ground.
159	They fell in a struggling heap one on the top of the other.
159	He clapped his hands, and forthwith they went off with that hopping
159	run of theirs, fifteen or twenty of them I should think, up
159	the beach.
159	
159	""Increase and multiply, my friends,"" said Montgomery.
159	""Replenish the island.  Hitherto we've had a certain lack of meat here.""
159	
159	As I watched them disappearing, the white-haired man returned with a
159	brandy-flask and some biscuits.  ""Something to go on with, Prendick,""
159	said he, in a far more familiar tone than before.  I made no ado,
159	but set to work on the biscuits at once, while the white-haired man
159	helped Montgomery to release about a score more of the rabbits.
159	Three big hutches, however, went up to the house with the puma.
159	The brandy I did not touch, for I have been an abstainer from
159	my birth.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	VII.  THE LOCKED DOOR.
159	
159	
159	THE reader will perhaps understand that at first everything was so strange
159	about me, and my position was the outcome of such unexpected adventures,
159	that I had no discernment of the relative strangeness of this
159	or that thing.  I followed the llama up the beach, and was overtaken
159	by Montgomery, who asked me not to enter the stone enclosure.
159	I noticed then that the puma in its cage and the pile of packages
159	had been placed outside the entrance to this quadrangle.
159	
159	I turned and saw that the launch had now been unloaded, run out again,
159	and was being beached, and the white-haired man was walking towards us.
159	He addressed Montgomery.
159	
159	""And now comes the problem of this uninvited guest.  What are we
159	to do with him?""
159	
159	""He knows something of science,"" said Montgomery.
159	
159	""I'm itching to get to work again--with this new stuff,""
159	said the white-haired man, nodding towards the enclosure.
159	His eyes grew brighter.
159	
159	""I daresay you are,"" said Montgomery, in anything but a cordial tone.
159	
159	""We can't send him over there, and we can't spare the time to build
159	him a new shanty; and we certainly can't take him into our confidence
159	just yet.""
159	
159	""I'm in your hands,"" said I. I had no idea of what he meant
159	by ""over there.""
159	
159	""I've been thinking of the same things,"" Montgomery answered.
159	""There's my room with the outer door--""
159	
159	""That's it,"" said the elder man, promptly, looking at Montgomery;
159	and all three of us went towards the enclosure.  ""I'm sorry to make
159	a mystery, Mr. Prendick; but you'll remember you're uninvited.
159	Our little establishment here contains a secret or so, is a kind
159	of Blue-Beard's chamber, in fact.  Nothing very dreadful, really, to a
159	sane man; but just now, as we don't know you--""
159	
159	""Decidedly,"" said I, ""I should be a fool to take offence at any want
159	of confidence.""
159	
159	He twisted his heavy mouth into a faint smile--he was one of those
159	saturnine people who smile with the corners of the mouth down,--and
159	bowed his acknowledgment of my complaisance.  The main entrance
159	to the enclosure was passed; it was a heavy wooden gate, framed in iron
159	and locked, with the cargo of the launch piled outside it, and at
159	the corner we came to a small doorway I had not previously observed.
159	The white-haired man produced a bundle of keys from the pocket
159	of his greasy blue jacket, opened this door, and entered.
159	His keys, and the elaborate locking-up of the place even while it
159	was still under his eye, struck me as peculiar.  I followed him,
159	and found myself in a small apartment, plainly but not uncomfortably
159	furnished and with its inner door, which was slightly ajar, opening into
159	a paved courtyard.  This inner door Montgomery at once closed.
159	A hammock was slung across the darker corner of the room, and a
159	small unglazed window defended by an iron bar looked out towards
159	the sea.
159	
159	This the white-haired man told me was to be my apartment;
159	and the inner door, which ""for fear of accidents,"" he said,
159	he would lock on the other side, was my limit inward.
159	He called my attention to a convenient deck-chair before the window,
159	and to an array of old books, chiefly, I found, surgical works
159	and editions of the Latin and Greek classics (languages I
159	cannot read with any comfort), on a shelf near the hammock.
159	He left the room by the outer door, as if to avoid opening the inner
159	one again.
159	
159	""We usually have our meals in here,"" said Montgomery, and then,
159	as if in doubt, went out after the other.  ""Moreau!"" I heard
159	him call, and for the moment I do not think I noticed.
159	Then as I handled the books on the shelf it came up in consciousness:
159	Where had I heard the name of Moreau before?  I sat down before
159	the window, took out the biscuits that still remained to me,
159	and ate them with an excellent appetite.  Moreau!
159	
159	Through the window I saw one of those unaccountable men in white, lugging a
159	packing-case along the beach.  Presently the window-frame hid him.
159	Then I heard a key inserted and turned in the lock behind me.
159	After a little while I heard through the locked door the noise
159	of the staghounds, that had now been brought up from the beach.
159	They were not barking, but sniffing and growling in a curious fashion.
159	I could hear the rapid patter of their feet, and Montgomery's voice
159	soothing them.
159	
159	I was very much impressed by the elaborate secrecy of these two men
159	regarding the contents of the place, and for some time I was thinking
159	of that and of the unaccountable familiarity of the name of Moreau;
159	but so odd is the human memory that I could not then recall that
159	well-known name in its proper connection.  From that my thoughts
159	went to the indefinable queerness of the deformed man on the beach.
159	I never saw such a gait, such odd motions as he pulled at the box.
159	I recalled that none of these men had spoken to me, though most
159	of them I had found looking at me at one time or another in a
159	peculiarly furtive manner, quite unlike the frank stare of your
159	unsophisticated savage.  Indeed, they had all seemed remarkably taciturn,
159	and when they did speak, endowed with very uncanny voices.
159	What was wrong with them?  Then I recalled the eyes of Montgomery's
159	ungainly attendant.
159	
159	Just as I was thinking of him he came in.  He was now dressed in white,
159	and carried a little tray with some coffee and boiled vegetables thereon.
159	I could hardly repress a shuddering recoil as he came, bending amiably,
159	and placed the tray before me on the table.  Then astonishment
159	paralysed me.  Under his stringy black locks I saw his ear;
159	it jumped upon me suddenly close to my face.  The man had pointed ears,
159	covered with a fine brown fur!
159	
159	""Your breakfast, sair,"" he said.
159	
159	I stared at his face without attempting to answer him.  He turned
159	and went towards the door, regarding me oddly over his shoulder.
159	I followed him out with my eyes; and as I did so, by some odd trick
159	of unconscious cerebration, there came surging into my head the phrase,
159	""The Moreau Hollows""--was it?  ""The Moreau--"" Ah!  It sent my memory
159	back ten years.  ""The Moreau Horrors!""  The phrase drifted loose
159	in my mind for a moment, and then I saw it in red lettering on a little
159	buff-coloured pamphlet, to read which made one shiver and creep.
159	Then I remembered distinctly all about it.  That long-forgotten
159	pamphlet came back with startling vividness to my mind.
159	I had been a mere lad then, and Moreau was, I suppose, about fifty,--a
159	prominent and masterful physiologist, well-known in scientific
159	circles for his extraordinary imagination and his brutal directness
159	in discussion.
159	
159	Was this the same Moreau?  He had published some very astonishing
159	facts in connection with the transfusion of blood, and in
159	addition was known to be doing valuable work on morbid growths.
159	Then suddenly his career was closed.  He had to leave England.
159	A journalist obtained access to his laboratory in the capacity
159	of laboratory-assistant, with the deliberate intention of making
159	sensational exposures; and by the help of a shocking accident
159	(if it was an accident), his gruesome pamphlet became notorious.
159	On the day of its publication a wretched dog, flayed and
159	otherwise mutilated, escaped from Moreau's house.  It was in
159	the silly season, and a prominent editor, a cousin of the temporary
159	laboratory-assistant, appealed to the conscience of the nation.
159	It was not the first time that conscience has turned against the methods
159	of research.  The doctor was simply howled out of the country.
159	It may be that he deserved to be; but I still think that the tepid
159	support of his fellow-investigators and his desertion by the great
159	body of scientific workers was a shameful thing.  Yet some of
159	his experiments, by the journalist's account, were wantonly cruel.
159	He might perhaps have purchased his social peace by abandoning
159	his investigations; but he apparently preferred the latter, as most men
159	would who have once fallen under the overmastering spell of research.
159	He was unmarried, and had indeed nothing but his own interest
159	to consider.
159	
159	I felt convinced that this must be the same man.  Everything pointed
159	to it.  It dawned upon me to what end the puma and the other
159	animals--which had now been brought with other luggage into the
159	enclosure behind the house--were destined; and a curious faint odour,
159	the halitus of something familiar, an odour that had been in
159	the background of my consciousness hitherto, suddenly came forward
159	into the forefront of my thoughts.  It was the antiseptic odour
159	of the dissecting-room. I heard the puma growling through the wall,
159	and one of the dogs yelped as though it had been struck.
159	
159	Yet surely, and especially to another scientific man, there was
159	nothing so horrible in vivisection as to account for this secrecy;
159	and by some odd leap in my thoughts the pointed ears and luminous
159	eyes of Montgomery's attendant came back again before me with
159	the sharpest definition.  I stared before me out at the green sea,
159	frothing under a freshening breeze, and let these and other strange
159	memories of the last few days chase one another through my mind.
159	
159	What could it all mean?  A locked enclosure on a lonely island,
159	a notorious vivisector, and these crippled and distorted men?
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	VIII.  THE CRYING OF THE PUMA.
159	
159	
159	MONTGOMERY interrupted my tangle of mystification and suspicion
159	about one o'clock, and his grotesque attendant followed him
159	with a tray bearing bread, some herbs and other eatables,
159	a flask of whiskey, a jug of water, and three glasses and knives.
159	I glanced askance at this strange creature, and found him watching
159	me with his queer, restless eyes.  Montgomery said he would lunch
159	with me, but that Moreau was too preoccupied with some work
159	to come.
159	
159	""Moreau!"" said I.  ""I know that name.""
159	
159	""The devil you do!"" said he.  ""What an ass I was to mention it to you!
159	I might have thought.  Anyhow, it will give you an inkling
159	of our--mysteries.  Whiskey?""
159	
159	""No, thanks; I'm an abstainer.""
159	
159	""I wish I'd been.  But it's no use locking the door
159	after the steed is stolen.  It was that infernal
159	stuff which led to my coming here,--that, and a foggy night.
159	I thought myself in luck at the time, when Moreau offered to get me off.
159	It's queer--""
159	
159	""Montgomery,"" said I, suddenly, as the outer door closed, ""why has
159	your man pointed ears?""
159	
159	""Damn!"" he said, over his first mouthful of food.  He stared at me
159	for a moment, and then repeated, ""Pointed ears?""
159	
159	""Little points to them,"" said I, as calmly as possible, with a catch
159	in my breath; ""and a fine black fur at the edges?""
159	
159	He helped himself to whiskey and water with great deliberation.
159	""I was under the impression--that his hair covered his ears.""
159	
159	""I saw them as he stooped by me to put that coffee you sent to me
159	on the table.  And his eyes shine in the dark.""
159	
159	By this time Montgomery had recovered from the surprise of my question.
159	""I always thought,"" he said deliberately, with a certain
159	accentuation of his flavouring of lisp, ""that there _was_ something
159	the matter with his ears, from the way he covered them.
159	What were they like?""
159	
159	I was persuaded from his manner that this ignorance was a pretence.
159	Still, I could hardly tell the man that I thought him a liar.
159	""Pointed,"" I said; ""rather small and furry,--distinctly furry.
159	But the whole man is one of the strangest beings I ever set
159	eyes on.""
159	
159	A sharp, hoarse cry of animal pain came from the enclosure behind us.
159	Its depth and volume testified to the puma.  I saw Montgomery wince.
159	
159	""Yes?"" he said.
159	
159	""Where did you pick up the creature?""
159	
159	""San Francisco.  He's an ugly brute, I admit.  Half-witted, you know.
159	Can't remember where he came from.  But I'm used to him, you know.
159	We both are.  How does he strike you?""
159	
159	""He's unnatural,"" I said.  ""There's something about him--don't
159	think me fanciful, but it gives me a nasty little sensation,
159	a tightening of my muscles, when he comes near me.  It's a touch--of
159	the diabolical, in fact.""
159	
159	Montgomery had stopped eating while I told him this.  ""Rum!"" he said.
159	""I can't see it.""  He resumed his meal.  ""I had no idea of it,""
159	he said, and masticated.  ""The crew of the schooner must have
159	felt it the same.  Made a dead set at the poor devil.  You saw
159	the captain?""
159	
159	Suddenly the puma howled again, this time more painfully.
159	Montgomery swore under his breath.  I had half a mind to attack him
159	about the men on the beach.  Then the poor brute within gave vent
159	to a series of short, sharp cries.
159	
159	""Your men on the beach,"" said I; ""what race are they?""
159	
159	""Excellent fellows, aren't they?"" said he, absentmindedly,
159	knitting his brows as the animal yelled out sharply.
159	
159	I said no more.  There was another outcry worse than the former.
159	He looked at me with his dull grey eyes, and then took some
159	more whiskey.  He tried to draw me into a discussion about alcohol,
159	professing to have saved my life with it.  He seemed anxious
159	to lay stress on the fact that I owed my life to him.  I answered
159	him distractedly.
159	
159	Presently our meal came to an end; the misshapen monster with
159	the pointed ears cleared the remains away, and Montgomery left
159	me alone in the room again.  All the time he had been in a state
159	of ill-concealed irritation at the noise of the vivisected puma.
159	He had spoken of his odd want of nerve, and left me to the
159	obvious application.
159	
159	I found myself that the cries were singularly irritating,
159	and they grew in depth and intensity as the afternoon wore on.
159	They were painful at first, but their constant resurgence at last
159	altogether upset my balance.  I flung aside a crib of Horace I
159	had been reading, and began to clench my fists, to bite my lips,
159	and to pace the room.  Presently I got to stopping my ears with
159	my fingers.
159	
159	The emotional appeal of those yells grew upon me steadily,
159	grew at last to such an exquisite expression of suffering that I
159	could stand it in that confined room no longer.  I stepped
159	out of the door into the slumberous heat of the late afternoon,
159	and walking past the main entrance--locked again, I noticed--turned
159	the corner of the wall.
159	
159	The crying sounded even louder out of doors.  It was as if all the pain
159	in the world had found a voice.  Yet had I known such pain was in
159	the next room, and had it been dumb, I believe--I have thought since--I
159	could have stood it well enough.  It is when suffering finds a voice
159	and sets our nerves quivering that this pity comes troubling us.
159	But in spite of the brilliant sunlight and the green fans of the trees
159	waving in the soothing sea-breeze, the world was a confusion,
159	blurred with drifting black and red phantasms, until I was out of earshot
159	of the house in the chequered wall.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	IX.  THE THING IN THE FOREST.
159	
159	
159	I STRODE through the undergrowth that clothed the ridge behind the house,
159	scarcely heeding whither I went; passed on through the shadow of a thick
159	cluster of straight-stemmed trees beyond it, and so presently found
159	myself some way on the other side of the ridge, and descending towards
159	a streamlet that ran through a narrow valley.  I paused and listened.
159	The distance I had come, or the intervening masses of thicket,
159	deadened any sound that might be coming from the enclosure.
159	The air was still.  Then with a rustle a rabbit emerged, and went
159	scampering up the slope before me.  I hesitated, and sat down in the edge
159	of the shade.
159	
159	The place was a pleasant one.  The rivulet was hidden
159	by the luxuriant vegetation of the banks save at one point,
159	where I caught a triangular patch of its glittering water.
159	On the farther side I saw through a bluish haze a tangle of trees
159	and creepers, and above these again the luminous blue of the sky.
159	Here and there a splash of white or crimson marked the blooming of some
159	trailing epiphyte.  I let my eyes wander over this scene for a while,
159	and then began to turn over in my mind again the strange peculiarities
159	of Montgomery's man.  But it was too hot to think elaborately,
159	and presently I fell into a tranquil state midway between dozing
159	and waking.
159	
159	From this I was aroused, after I know not how long, by a
159	rustling amidst the greenery on the other side of the stream.
159	For a moment I could see nothing but the waving summits of
159	the ferns and reeds.  Then suddenly upon the bank of the stream
159	appeared something--at first I could not distinguish what it was.
159	It bowed its round head to the water, and began to drink.
159	Then I saw it was a man, going on all-fours like a beast.  He was clothed
159	in bluish cloth, and was of a copper-coloured hue, with black hair.
159	It seemed that grotesque ugliness was an invariable character of
159	these islanders.  I could hear the suck of the water at his lips as
159	he drank.
159	
159	I leant forward to see him better, and a piece of lava, detached by
159	my hand, went pattering down the slope.  He looked up guiltily,
159	and his eyes met mine.  Forthwith he scrambled to his feet,
159	and stood wiping his clumsy hand across his mouth and regarding me.
159	His legs were scarcely half the length of his body.
159	So, staring one another out of countenance, we remained for perhaps
159	the space of a minute.  Then, stopping to look back once or twice,
159	he slunk off among the bushes to the right of me, and I heard
159	the swish of the fronds grow faint in the distance and die away.
159	Long after he had disappeared, I remained sitting up staring
159	in the direction of his retreat.  My drowsy tranquillity
159	had gone.
159	
159	I was startled by a noise behind me, and turning suddenly saw
159	the flapping white tail of a rabbit vanishing up the slope.
159	I jumped to my feet.  The apparition of this grotesque, half-bestial
159	creature had suddenly populated the stillness of the afternoon for me.
159	I looked around me rather nervously, and regretted that I was unarmed.
159	Then I thought that the man I had just seen had been clothed
159	in bluish cloth, had not been naked as a savage would have been;
159	and I tried to persuade myself from that fact that he was after all
159	probably a peaceful character, that the dull ferocity of his countenance
159	belied him.
159	
159	Yet I was greatly disturbed at the apparition.  I walked
159	to the left along the slope, turning my head about and peering
159	this way and that among the straight stems of the trees.
159	Why should a man go on all-fours and drink with his lips?  Presently I
159	heard an animal wailing again, and taking it to be the puma, I turned
159	about and walked in a direction diametrically opposite to the sound.
159	This led me down to the stream, across which I stepped and pushed
159	my way up through the undergrowth beyond.
159	
159	I was startled by a great patch of vivid scarlet on the ground,
159	and going up to it found it to be a peculiar fungus, branched and
159	corrugated like a foliaceous lichen, but deliquescing into slime
159	at the touch; and then in the shadow of some luxuriant ferns I
159	came upon an unpleasant thing,--the dead body of a rabbit covered
159	with shining flies, but still warm and with the head torn off.
159	I stopped aghast at the sight of the scattered blood.
159	Here at least was one visitor to the island disposed of!
159	There were no traces of other violence about it.  It looked as though it
159	had been suddenly snatched up and killed; and as I stared at the little
159	furry body came the difficulty of how the thing had been done.
159	The vague dread that had been in my mind since I had seen the inhuman
159	face of the man at the stream grew distincter as I stood there.
159	I began to realise the hardihood of my expedition among these
159	unknown people.  The thicket about me became altered to my imagination.
159	Every shadow became something more than a shadow,--became an ambush;
159	every rustle became a threat.  Invisible things seemed watching me.
159	I resolved to go back to the enclosure on the beach.  I suddenly
159	turned away and thrust myself violently, possibly even frantically,
159	through the bushes, anxious to get a clear space about me
159	again.
159	
159	I stopped just in time to prevent myself emerging upon an open space.
159	It was a kind of glade in the forest, made by a fall; seedlings were
159	already starting up to struggle for the vacant space; and beyond,
159	the dense growth of stems and twining vines and splashes of fungus
159	and flowers closed in again.  Before me, squatting together upon
159	the fungoid ruins of a huge fallen tree and still unaware of my approach,
159	were three grotesque human figures.  One was evidently a female;
159	the other two were men.  They were naked, save for swathings
159	of scarlet cloth about the middle; and their skins were of a dull
159	pinkish-drab colour, such as I had seen in no savages before.
159	They had fat, heavy, chinless faces, retreating foreheads,
159	and a scant bristly hair upon their heads.  I never saw such
159	bestial-looking creatures.
159	
159	They were talking, or at least one of the men was talking to the other two,
159	and all three had been too closely interested to heed the rustling of
159	my approach.  They swayed their heads and shoulders from side to side.
159	The speaker's words came thick and sloppy, and though I could
159	hear them distinctly I could not distinguish what he said.
159	He seemed to me to be reciting some complicated gibberish.
159	Presently his articulation became shriller, and spreading his hands
159	he rose to his feet.  At that the others began to gibber in unison,
159	also rising to their feet, spreading their hands and swaying their
159	bodies in rhythm with their chant.  I noticed then the abnormal
159	shortness of their legs, and their lank, clumsy feet.  All three began
159	slowly to circle round, raising and stamping their feet and waving
159	their arms; a kind of tune crept into their rhythmic recitation,
159	and a refrain,--""Aloola,"" or ""Balloola,"" it sounded like.
159	Their eyes began to sparkle, and their ugly faces to brighten,
159	with an expression of strange pleasure.  Saliva dripped from their
159	lipless mouths.
159	
159	Suddenly, as I watched their grotesque and unaccountable gestures,
159	I perceived clearly for the first time what it was that had offended me,
159	what had given me the two inconsistent and conflicting impressions
159	of utter strangeness and yet of the strangest familiarity.
159	The three creatures engaged in this mysterious rite were human in shape,
159	and yet human beings with the strangest air about them of some
159	familiar animal.  Each of these creatures, despite its human form,
159	its rag of clothing, and the rough humanity of its bodily form,
159	had woven into it--into its movements, into the expression of
159	its countenance, into its whole presence--some now irresistible
159	suggestion of a hog, a swinish taint, the unmistakable mark of
159	the beast.
159	
159	I stood overcome by this amazing realisation and then the most horrible
159	questionings came rushing into my mind.  They began leaping in the air,
159	first one and then the other, whooping and grunting.  Then one slipped,
159	and for a moment was on all-fours,--to recover, indeed, forthwith.
159	But that transitory gleam of the true animalism of these monsters
159	was enough.
159	
159	I turned as noiselessly as possible, and becoming every now
159	and then rigid with the fear of being discovered, as a branch
159	cracked or a leaf rustled, I pushed back into the bushes.
159	It was long before I grew bolder, and dared to move freely.
159	My only idea for the moment was to get away from these foul beings, and I
159	scarcely noticed that I had emerged upon a faint pathway amidst the trees.
159	Then suddenly traversing a little glade, I saw with an unpleasant start
159	two clumsy legs among the trees, walking with noiseless footsteps
159	parallel with my course, and perhaps thirty yards away from me.
159	The head and upper part of the body were hidden by a tangle of creeper.
159	I stopped abruptly, hoping the creature did not see me.
159	The feet stopped as I did.  So nervous was I that I controlled
159	an impulse to headlong flight with the utmost difficulty.
159	Then looking hard, I distinguished through the interlacing network
159	the head and body of the brute I had seen drinking.  He moved his head.
159	There was an emerald flash in his eyes as he glanced at me from
159	the shadow of the trees, a half-luminous colour that vanished as
159	he turned his head again.  He was motionless for a moment, and then
159	with a noiseless tread began running through the green confusion.
159	In another moment he had vanished behind some bushes.
159	I could not see him, but I felt that he had stopped and was watching me
159	again.
159	
159	What on earth was he,--man or beast?  What did he want with me?
159	I had no weapon, not even a stick.  Flight would be madness.
159	At any rate the Thing, whatever it was, lacked the courage to attack me.
159	Setting my teeth hard, I walked straight towards him.
159	I was anxious not to show the fear that seemed chilling my backbone.
159	I pushed through a tangle of tall white-flowered bushes,
159	and saw him twenty paces beyond, looking over his shoulder at me
159	and hesitating.  I advanced a step or two, looking steadfastly into
159	his eyes.
159	
159	""Who are you?"" said I.
159	
159	He tried to meet my gaze.  ""No!"" he said suddenly, and turning went
159	bounding away from me through the undergrowth.  Then he turned
159	and stared at me again.  His eyes shone brightly out of the dusk
159	under the trees.
159	
159	My heart was in my mouth; but I felt my only chance was bluff,
159	and walked steadily towards him.  He turned again, and vanished
159	into the dusk.  Once more I thought I caught the glint of his eyes,
159	and that was all.
159	
159	For the first time I realised how the lateness of the hour
159	might affect me.  The sun had set some minutes since, the swift
159	dusk of the tropics was already fading out of the eastern sky,
159	and a pioneer moth fluttered silently by my head.  Unless I would
159	spend the night among the unknown dangers of the mysterious forest,
159	I must hasten back to the enclosure.  The thought of a return
159	to that pain-haunted refuge was extremely disagreeable, but still
159	more so was the idea of being overtaken in the open by darkness
159	and all that darkness might conceal.  I gave one more look
159	into the blue shadows that had swallowed up this odd creature,
159	and then retraced my way down the slope towards the stream,
159	going as I judged in the direction from which I had come.
159	
159	I walked eagerly, my mind confused with many things,
159	and presently found myself in a level place among scattered trees.
159	The colourless clearness that comes after the sunset flush
159	was darkling; the blue sky above grew momentarily deeper,
159	and the little stars one by one pierced the attenuated light;
159	the interspaces of the trees, the gaps in the further vegetation,
159	that had been hazy blue in the daylight, grew black and mysterious.
159	I pushed on.  The colour vanished from the world.
159	The tree-tops rose against the luminous blue sky in inky silhouette,
159	and all below that outline melted into one formless blackness.
159	Presently the trees grew thinner, and the shrubby undergrowth
159	more abundant.  Then there was a desolate space covered with
159	a white sand, and then another expanse of tangled bushes.
159	I did not remember crossing the sand-opening before.
159	I began to be tormented by a faint rustling upon my right hand.
159	I thought at first it was fancy, for whenever I stopped there
159	was silence, save for the evening breeze in the tree-tops.
159	Then when I turned to hurry on again there was an echo to
159	my footsteps.
159	
159	I turned away from the thickets, keeping to the more open ground,
159	and endeavouring by sudden turns now and then to surprise something
159	in the act of creeping upon me.  I saw nothing, and nevertheless
159	my sense of another presence grew steadily.  I increased my pace,
159	and after some time came to a slight ridge, crossed it, and turned sharply,
159	regarding it steadfastly from the further side.  It came out black
159	and clear-cut against the darkling sky; and presently a shapeless
159	lump heaved up momentarily against the sky-line and vanished again.
159	I felt assured now that my tawny-faced antagonist was stalking me
159	once more; and coupled with that was another unpleasant realisation,
159	that I had lost my way.
159	
159	For a time I hurried on hopelessly perplexed, and pursued by that
159	stealthy approach.  Whatever it was, the Thing either lacked the courage
159	to attack me, or it was waiting to take me at some disadvantage.
159	I kept studiously to the open.  At times I would turn and listen;
159	and presently I had half persuaded myself that my pursuer had abandoned
159	the chase, or was a mere creation of my disordered imagination.
159	Then I heard the sound of the sea.  I quickened my footsteps
159	almost into a run, and immediately there was a stumble in
159	my rear.
159	
159	I turned suddenly, and stared at the uncertain trees behind me.
159	One black shadow seemed to leap into another.  I listened,
159	rigid, and heard nothing but the creep of the blood in my ears.
159	I thought that my nerves were unstrung, and that my imagination
159	was tricking me, and turned resolutely towards the sound of the
159	sea again.
159	
159	In a minute or so the trees grew thinner, and I emerged upon
159	a bare, low headland running out into the sombre water.
159	The night was calm and clear, and the reflection of the growing
159	multitude of the stars shivered in the tranquil heaving of the sea.
159	Some way out, the wash upon an irregular band of reef shone
159	with a pallid light of its own.  Westward I saw the zodiacal
159	light mingling with the yellow brilliance of the evening star.
159	The coast fell away from me to the east, and westward it was hidden
159	by the shoulder of the cape.  Then I recalled the fact that Moreau's
159	beach lay to the west.
159	
159	A twig snapped behind me, and there was a rustle.  I turned, and stood
159	facing the dark trees.  I could see nothing--or else I could see too much.
159	Every dark form in the dimness had its ominous quality, its peculiar
159	suggestion of alert watchfulness.  So I stood for perhaps a minute,
159	and then, with an eye to the trees still, turned westward to cross
159	the headland; and as I moved, one among the lurking shadows moved
159	to follow me.
159	
159	My heart beat quickly.  Presently the broad sweep of a bay
159	to the westward became visible, and I halted again.
159	The noiseless shadow halted a dozen yards from me.
159	A little point of light shone on the further bend of the curve,
159	and the grey sweep of the sandy beach lay faint under the starlight.
159	Perhaps two miles away was that little point of light.
159	To get to the beach I should have to go through the trees where the
159	shadows lurked, and down a bushy slope.
159	
159	I could see the Thing rather more distinctly now.  It was no animal,
159	for it stood erect.  At that I opened my mouth to speak, and found
159	a hoarse phlegm choked my voice.  I tried again, and shouted,
159	""Who is there?""  There was no answer.  I advanced a step.
159	The Thing did not move, only gathered itself together.  My foot
159	struck a stone.  That gave me an idea.  Without taking my eyes off
159	the black form before me, I stooped and picked up this lump of rock;
159	but at my motion the Thing turned abruptly as a dog might have done,
159	and slunk obliquely into the further darkness.  Then I recalled
159	a schoolboy expedient against big dogs, and twisted the rock into
159	my handkerchief, and gave this a turn round my wrist.  I heard a movement
159	further off among the shadows, as if the Thing was in retreat.
159	Then suddenly my tense excitement gave way; I broke into a profuse
159	perspiration and fell a-trembling, with my adversary routed and this
159	weapon in my hand.
159	
159	It was some time before I could summon resolution to go down through
159	the trees and bushes upon the flank of the headland to the beach.
159	At last I did it at a run; and as I emerged from the thicket
159	upon the sand, I heard some other body come crashing after me.
159	At that I completely lost my head with fear, and began running
159	along the sand.  Forthwith there came the swift patter of soft
159	feet in pursuit.  I gave a wild cry, and redoubled my pace.
159	Some dim, black things about three or four times the size of rabbits
159	went running or hopping up from the beach towards the bushes as
159	I passed.
159	
159	So long as I live, I shall remember the terror of that chase.
159	I ran near the water's edge, and heard every now and then the splash
159	of the feet that gained upon me.  Far away, hopelessly far,
159	was the yellow light.  All the night about us was black and still.
159	Splash, splash, came the pursuing feet, nearer and nearer.
159	I felt my breath going, for I was quite out of training; it whooped
159	as I drew it, and I felt a pain like a knife at my side.  I perceived
159	the Thing would come up with me long before I reached the enclosure,
159	and, desperate and sobbing for my breath, I wheeled round upon it
159	and struck at it as it came up to me,--struck with all my strength.
159	The stone came out of the sling of the handkerchief as I did so.
159	As I turned, the Thing, which had been running on all-fours,
159	rose to its feet, and the missile fell fair on its left temple.
159	The skull rang loud, and the animal-man blundered into me,
159	thrust me back with its hands, and went staggering past me to fall
159	headlong upon the sand with its face in the water; and there it lay
159	still.
159	
159	I could not bring myself to approach that black heap.  I left
159	it there, with the water rippling round it, under the still stars,
159	and giving it a wide berth pursued my way towards the yellow glow
159	of the house; and presently, with a positive effect of relief,
159	came the pitiful moaning of the puma, the sound that had
159	originally driven me out to explore this mysterious island.
159	At that, though I was faint and horribly fatigued, I gathered
159	together all my strength, and began running again towards the light.
159	I thought I heard a voice calling me.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	X.  THE CRYING OF THE MAN.
159	
159	
159	AS I drew near the house I saw that the light shone from
159	the open door of my room; and then I heard coming from out
159	of the darkness at the side of that orange oblong of light,
159	the voice of Montgomery shouting, ""Prendick!""  I continued running.
159	Presently I heard him again.  I replied by a feeble ""Hullo!""
159	and in another moment had staggered up to him.
159	
159	""Where have you been?"" said he, holding me at arm's length,
159	so that the light from the door fell on my face.  ""We have both
159	been so busy that we forgot you until about half an hour ago.""
159	He led me into the room and sat me down in the deck chair.
159	For awhile I was blinded by the light.  ""We did not think you would start
159	to explore this island of ours without telling us,"" he said; and then,
159	""I was afraid--But--what--Hullo!""
159	
159	My last remaining strength slipped from me, and my head fell forward
159	on my chest.  I think he found a certain satisfaction in giving
159	me brandy.
159	
159	""For God's sake,"" said I, ""fasten that door.""
159	
159	""You've been meeting some of our curiosities, eh?"" said he.
159	
159	He locked the door and turned to me again.  He asked me no questions,
159	but gave me some more brandy and water and pressed me to eat.
159	I was in a state of collapse.  He said something vague about his
159	forgetting to warn me, and asked me briefly when I left the house
159	and what I had seen.
159	
159	I answered him as briefly, in fragmentary sentences.  ""Tell me
159	what it all means,"" said I, in a state bordering on hysterics.
159	
159	""It's nothing so very dreadful,"" said he.  ""But I think you
159	have had about enough for one day.""  The puma suddenly gave
159	a sharp yell of pain.  At that he swore under his breath.
159	""I'm damned,"" said he, ""if this place is not as bad as Gower Street,
159	with its cats.""
159	
159	""Montgomery,"" said I, ""what was that thing that came after me?
159	Was it a beast or was it a man?""
159	
159	""If you don't sleep to-night,"" he said, ""you'll be off your
159	head to-morrow.""
159	
159	I stood up in front of him.  ""What was that thing that came after me?""
159	I asked.
159	
159	He looked me squarely in the eyes, and twisted his mouth askew.
159	His eyes, which had seemed animated a minute before, went dull.
159	""From your account,"" said he, ""I'm thinking it was a bogle.""
159	
159	I felt a gust of intense irritation, which passed as quickly as it came.
159	I flung myself into the chair again, and pressed my hands on my forehead.
159	The puma began once more.
159	
159	Montgomery came round behind me and put his hand on my shoulder.
159	""Look here, Prendick,"" he said, ""I had no business to let
159	you drift out into this silly island of ours.  But it's not
159	so bad as you feel, man.  Your nerves are worked to rags.
159	Let me give you something that will make you sleep.  _That_--will keep
159	on for hours yet.  You must simply get to sleep, or I won't answer
159	for it.""
159	
159	I did not reply.  I bowed forward, and covered my face with my hands.
159	Presently he returned with a small measure containing a dark liquid.
159	This he gave me.  I took it unresistingly, and he helped me into
159	the hammock.
159	
159	When I awoke, it was broad day.  For a little while I lay flat,
159	staring at the roof above me.  The rafters, I observed, were made
159	out of the timbers of a ship.  Then I turned my head, and saw a meal
159	prepared for me on the table.  I perceived that I was hungry,
159	and prepared to clamber out of the hammock, which, very politely
159	anticipating my intention, twisted round and deposited me upon
159	all-fours on the floor.
159	
159	I got up and sat down before the food.  I had a heavy feeling
159	in my head, and only the vaguest memory at first of the things
159	that had happened over night.  The morning breeze blew very
159	pleasantly through the unglazed window, and that and the food
159	contributed to the sense of animal comfort which I experienced.
159	Presently the door behind me--the door inward towards the yard
159	of the enclosure--opened.  I turned and saw Montgomery's face.
159	
159	""All right,"" said he.  ""I'm frightfully busy.""  And he shut the door.
159	
159	Afterwards I discovered that he forgot to re-lock it.
159	Then I recalled the expression of his face the previous night,
159	and with that the memory of all I had experienced reconstructed
159	itself before me.  Even as that fear came back to me came a cry
159	from within; but this time it was not the cry of a puma.
159	I put down the mouthful that hesitated upon my lips, and listened.
159	Silence, save for the whisper of the morning breeze.  I began to think my
159	ears had deceived me.
159	
159	After a long pause I resumed my meal, but with my ears still vigilant.
159	Presently I heard something else, very faint and low.
159	I sat as if frozen in my attitude.  Though it was faint and low,
159	it moved me more profoundly than all that I had hitherto heard of
159	the abominations behind the wall.  There was no mistake this time in
159	the quality of the dim, broken sounds; no doubt at all of their source.
159	For it was groaning, broken by sobs and gasps of anguish.
159	It was no brute this time; it was a human being in torment!
159	
159	As I realised this I rose, and in three steps had crossed the room,
159	seized the handle of the door into the yard, and flung it open
159	before me.
159	
159	""Prendick, man!  Stop!"" cried Montgomery, intervening.
159	
159	A startled deerhound yelped and snarled.  There was blood, I saw,
159	in the sink,--brown, and some scarlet--and I smelt the peculiar
159	smell of carbolic acid.  Then through an open doorway beyond,
159	in the dim light of the shadow, I saw something bound painfully
159	upon a framework, scarred, red, and bandaged; and then blotting
159	this out appeared the face of old Moreau, white and terrible.
159	In a moment he had gripped me by the shoulder with a hand that was
159	smeared red, had twisted me off my feet, and flung me headlong back
159	into my own room.  He lifted me as though I was a little child.
159	I fell at full length upon the floor, and the door slammed
