159	and shut out the passionate intensity of his face.
159	Then I heard the key turn in the lock, and Montgomery's voice
159	in expostulation.
159	
159	""Ruin the work of a lifetime,"" I heard Moreau say.
159	
159	""He does not understand,"" said Montgomery.  and other things
159	that were inaudible.
159	
159	""I can't spare the time yet,"" said Moreau.
159	
159	The rest I did not hear.  I picked myself up and stood trembling,
159	my mind a chaos of the most horrible misgivings.  Could it be possible,
159	I thought, that such a thing as the vivisection of men was carried
159	on here?  The question shot like lightning across a tumultuous sky;
159	and suddenly the clouded horror of my mind condensed into a vivid
159	realisation of my own danger.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XI.  THE HUNTING OF THE MAN.
159	
159	
159	IT came before my mind with an unreasonable hope of escape that
159	the outer door of my room was still open to me.  I was convinced now,
159	absolutely assured, that Moreau had been vivisecting a human being.
159	All the time since I had heard his name, I had been trying to link
159	in my mind in some way the grotesque animalism of the islanders
159	with his abominations; and now I thought I saw it all.
159	The memory of his work on the transfusion of blood recurred to me.
159	These creatures I had seen were the victims of some hideous experiment.
159	These sickening scoundrels had merely intended to keep me back,
159	to fool me with their display of confidence, and presently to fall
159	upon me with a fate more horrible than death,--with torture;
159	and after torture the most hideous degradation it is possible
159	to conceive,--to send me off a lost soul, a beast, to the rest of their
159	Comus rout.
159	
159	I looked round for some weapon.  Nothing.  Then with an inspiration I
159	turned over the deck chair, put my foot on the side of it, and tore
159	away the side rail.  It happened that a nail came away with the wood,
159	and projecting, gave a touch of danger to an otherwise petty weapon.
159	I heard a step outside, and incontinently flung open the door and found
159	Montgomery within a yard of it.  He meant to lock the outer door!
159	I raised this nailed stick of mine and cut at his face;
159	but he sprang back.  I hesitated a moment, then turned and fled,
159	round the corner of the house.  ""Prendick, man!""  I heard his
159	astonished cry, ""don't be a silly ass, man!""
159	
159	Another minute, thought I, and he would have had me locked in,
159	and as ready as a hospital rabbit for my fate.  He emerged behind
159	the corner, for I heard him shout, ""Prendick!""  Then he began to run
159	after me, shouting things as he ran.  This time running blindly,
159	I went northeastward in a direction at right angles to my
159	previous expedition.  Once, as I went running headlong up the beach,
159	I glanced over my shoulder and saw his attendant with him.
159	I ran furiously up the slope, over it, then turning eastward along
159	a rocky valley fringed on either side with jungle I ran for perhaps
159	a mile altogether, my chest straining, my heart beating in my ears;
159	and then hearing nothing of Montgomery or his man, and feeling
159	upon the verge of exhaustion, I doubled sharply back towards
159	the beach as I judged, and lay down in the shelter of a canebrake.
159	There I remained for a long time, too fearful to move, and indeed
159	too fearful even to plan a course of action.  The wild scene about me
159	lay sleeping silently under the sun, and the only sound near me was
159	the thin hum of some small gnats that had discovered me.  Presently I
159	became aware of a drowsy breathing sound, the soughing of the sea upon
159	the beach.
159	
159	After about an hour I heard Montgomery shouting my name,
159	far away to the north.  That set me thinking of my plan of action.
159	As I interpreted it then, this island was inhabited only by these two
159	vivisectors and their animalised victims.  Some of these no doubt
159	they could press into their service against me if need arose.
159	I knew both Moreau and Montgomery carried revolvers; and, save for a feeble
159	bar of deal spiked with a small nail, the merest mockery of a mace,
159	I was unarmed.
159	
159	So I lay still there, until I began to think of food and drink;
159	and at that thought the real hopelessness of my position came home to me.
159	I knew no way of getting anything to eat.  I was too ignorant of botany
159	to discover any resort of root or fruit that might lie about me;
159	I had no means of trapping the few rabbits upon the island.
159	It grew blanker the more I turned the prospect over.  At last in
159	the desperation of my position, my mind turned to the animal men I
159	had encountered.  I tried to find some hope in what I remembered of them.
159	In turn I recalled each one I had seen, and tried to draw some augury
159	of assistance from my memory.
159	
159	Then suddenly I heard a staghound bay, and at that realised a new danger.
159	I took little time to think, or they would have caught me then,
159	but snatching up my nailed stick, rushed headlong from my hiding-place
159	towards the sound of the sea.  I remember a growth of thorny plants,
159	with spines that stabbed like pen-knives. I emerged bleeding and
159	with torn clothes upon the lip of a long creek opening northward.
159	I went straight into the water without a minute's hesitation, wading up
159	the creek, and presently finding myself kneedeep in a little stream.
159	I scrambled out at last on the westward bank, and with my heart beating
159	loudly in my ears, crept into a tangle of ferns to await the issue.
159	I heard the dog (there was only one) draw nearer, and yelp when it came
159	to the thorns.  Then I heard no more, and presently began to think I
159	had escaped.
159	
159	The minutes passed; the silence lengthened out, and at last
159	after an hour of security my courage began to return to me.
159	By this time I was no longer very much terrified or very miserable.
159	I had, as it were, passed the limit of terror and despair.
159	I felt now that my life was practically lost, and that persuasion
159	made me capable of daring anything.  I had even a certain wish
159	to encounter Moreau face to face; and as I had waded into the water,
159	I remembered that if I were too hard pressed at least one path
159	of escape from torment still lay open to me,--they could not
159	very well prevent my drowning myself.  I had half a mind to drown
159	myself then; but an odd wish to see the whole adventure out,
159	a queer, impersonal, spectacular interest in myself, restrained me.
159	I stretched my limbs, sore and painful from the pricks of the spiny plants,
159	and stared around me at the trees; and, so suddenly that it seemed
159	to jump out of the green tracery about it, my eyes lit upon a black
159	face watching me.  I saw that it was the simian creature who had
159	met the launch upon the beach.  He was clinging to the oblique
159	stem of a palm-tree. I gripped my stick, and stood up facing him.
159	He began chattering.  ""You, you, you,"" was all I could distinguish
159	at first.  Suddenly he dropped from the tree, and in another
159	moment was holding the fronds apart and staring curiously
159	at me.
159	
159	I did not feel the same repugnance towards this creature which I
159	had experienced in my encounters with the other Beast Men.
159	""You,"" he said, ""in the boat.""  He was a man, then,--at least as much
159	of a man as Montgomery's attendant,--for he could talk.
159	
159	""Yes,"" I said, ""I came in the boat.  From the ship.""
159	
159	""Oh!"" he said, and his bright, restless eyes travelled over me,
159	to my hands, to the stick I carried, to my feet, to the tattered places
159	in my coat, and the cuts and scratches I had received from the thorns.
159	He seemed puzzled at something.  His eyes came back to my hands.
159	He held his own hand out and counted his digits slowly, ""One, two,
159	three, four, five--eigh?""
159	
159	I did not grasp his meaning then; afterwards I was to find that
159	a great proportion of these Beast People had malformed hands,
159	lacking sometimes even three digits.  But guessing this was
159	in some way a greeting, I did the same thing by way of reply.
159	He grinned with immense satisfaction.  Then his swift roving
159	glance went round again; he made a swift movement--and vanished.
159	The fern fronds he had stood between came swishing together.
159	
159	I pushed out of the brake after him, and was astonished to find
159	him swinging cheerfully by one lank arm from a rope of creepers
159	that looped down from the foliage overhead.  His back was to me.
159	
159	""Hullo!"" said I.
159	
159	He came down with a twisting jump, and stood facing me.
159	
159	""I say,"" said I, ""where can I get something to eat?""
159	
159	""Eat!"" he said.  ""Eat Man's food, now.""  And his eye went back
159	to the swing of ropes.  ""At the huts.""
159	
159	""But where are the huts?""
159	
159	""Oh!""
159	
159	""I'm new, you know.""
159	
159	At that he swung round, and set off at a quick walk.
159	All his motions were curiously rapid.  ""Come along,"" said he.
159	
159	I went with him to see the adventure out.  I guessed the huts were some
159	rough shelter where he and some more of these Beast People lived.
159	I might perhaps find them friendly, find some handle in their minds
159	to take hold of.  I did not know how far they had forgotten their
159	human heritage.
159	
159	My ape-like companion trotted along by my side, with his hands
159	hanging down and his jaw thrust forward.  I wondered what memory
159	he might have in him.  ""How long have you been on this island?""
159	said I.
159	
159	""How long?"" he asked; and after having the question repeated,
159	he held up three fingers.
159	
159	The creature was little better than an idiot.  I tried
159	to make out what he meant by that, and it seems I bored him.
159	After another question or two he suddenly left my side and went
159	leaping at some fruit that hung from a tree.  He pulled down
159	a handful of prickly husks and went on eating the contents.
159	I noted this with satisfaction, for here at least was a hint for feeding.
159	I tried him with some other questions, but his chattering, prompt responses
159	were as often as not quite at cross purposes with my question.
159	Some few were appropriate, others quite parrot-like.
159	
159	I was so intent upon these peculiarities that I scarcely noticed the path
159	we followed.  Presently we came to trees, all charred and brown,
159	and so to a bare place covered with a yellow-white incrustation,
159	across which a drifting smoke, pungent in whiffs to nose and eyes,
159	went drifting.  On our right, over a shoulder of bare rock, I saw
159	the level blue of the sea.  The path coiled down abruptly into a narrow
159	ravine between two tumbled and knotty masses of blackish scoriae.
159	Into this we plunged.
159	
159	It was extremely dark, this passage, after the blinding sunlight reflected
159	from the sulphurous ground.  Its walls grew steep, and approached
159	each other.  Blotches of green and crimson drifted across my eyes.
159	My conductor stopped suddenly.  ""Home!"" said he, and I stood
159	in a floor of a chasm that was at first absolutely dark to me.
159	I heard some strange noises, and thrust the knuckles of my left hand
159	into my eyes.  I became aware of a disagreeable odor, like that of
159	a monkey's cage ill-cleaned. Beyond, the rock opened again upon
159	a gradual slope of sunlit greenery, and on either hand the light
159	smote down through narrow ways into the central gloom.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XII.  THE SAYERS OF THE LAW.
159	
159	
159	THEN something cold touched my hand.  I started violently,
159	and saw close to me a dim pinkish thing, looking more like a flayed
159	child than anything else in the world.  The creature had exactly
159	the mild but repulsive features of a sloth, the same low forehead
159	and slow gestures.
159	
159	As the first shock of the change of light passed, I saw about me
159	more distinctly.  The little sloth-like creature was standing and
159	staring at me.  My conductor had vanished.  The place was a narrow
159	passage between high walls of lava, a crack in the knotted rock,
159	and on either side interwoven heaps of sea-mat, palm-fans, and reeds
159	leaning against the rock formed rough and impenetrably dark dens.
159	The winding way up the ravine between these was scarcely three yards wide,
159	and was disfigured by lumps of decaying fruit-pulp and other refuse,
159	which accounted for the disagreeable stench of the place.
159	
159	The little pink sloth-creature was still blinking at me when my
159	Ape-man reappeared at the aperture of the nearest of these dens,
159	and beckoned me in.  As he did so a slouching monster wriggled out
159	of one of the places, further up this strange street, and stood up in
159	featureless silhouette against the bright green beyond, staring at me.
159	I hesitated, having half a mind to bolt the way I had come; and then,
159	determined to go through with the adventure, I gripped my nailed stick
159	about the middle and crawled into the little evil-smelling lean-to
159	after my conductor.
159	
159	It was a semi-circular space, shaped like the half of a bee-hive;
159	and against the rocky wall that formed the inner side of it was a pile
159	of variegated fruits, cocoa-nuts among others.  Some rough vessels
159	of lava and wood stood about the floor, and one on a rough stool.
159	There was no fire.  In the darkest corner of the hut sat a shapeless
159	mass of darkness that grunted ""Hey!"" as I came in, and my Ape-man
159	stood in the dim light of the doorway and held out a split cocoa-nut
159	to me as I crawled into the other corner and squatted down.
159	I took it, and began gnawing it, as serenely as possible, in spite of a
159	certain trepidation and the nearly intolerable closeness of the den.
159	The little pink sloth-creature stood in the aperture of the hut,
159	and something else with a drab face and bright eyes came staring over
159	its shoulder.
159	
159	""Hey!"" came out of the lump of mystery opposite.  ""It is a man.""
159	
159	""It is a man,"" gabbled my conductor, ""a man, a man, a five-man,
159	like me.""
159	
159	""Shut up!"" said the voice from the dark, and grunted.
159	I gnawed my cocoa-nut amid an impressive stillness.
159	
159	I peered hard into the blackness, but could distinguish nothing.
159	
159	""It is a man,"" the voice repeated.  ""He comes to live with us?""
159	
159	It was a thick voice, with something in it--a kind of whistling
159	overtone--that struck me as peculiar; but the English accent was
159	strangely good.
159	
159	The Ape-man looked at me as though he expected something.
159	I perceived the pause was interrogative.  ""He comes to live with you,""
159	I said.
159	
159	""It is a man.  He must learn the Law.""
159	
159	I began to distinguish now a deeper blackness in the black,
159	a vague outline of a hunched-up figure.  Then I noticed
159	the opening of the place was darkened by two more black heads.
159	My hand tightened on my stick.
159	
159	The thing in the dark repeated in a louder tone, ""Say the words.""
159	I had missed its last remark.  ""Not to go on all-fours; that is the Law,""
159	it repeated in a kind of sing-song.
159	
159	I was puzzled.
159	
159	""Say the words,"" said the Ape-man, repeating, and the figures
159	in the doorway echoed this, with a threat in the tone of their voices.
159	
159	I realised that I had to repeat this idiotic formula; and then
159	began the insanest ceremony.  The voice in the dark began intoning
159	a mad litany, line by line, and I and the rest to repeat it.
159	As they did so, they swayed from side to side in the oddest way,
159	and beat their hands upon their knees; and I followed their example.
159	I could have imagined I was already dead and in another world.
159	That dark hut, these grotesque dim figures, just flecked here and
159	there by a glimmer of light, and all of them swaying in unison and
159	chanting,
159	
159	     ""Not to go on all-fours; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?
159	     ""Not to suck up Drink; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?
159	     ""Not to eat Fish or Flesh; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?
159	     ""Not to claw the Bark of Trees; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?
159	     ""Not to chase other Men; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?""
159	
159	And so from the prohibition of these acts of folly,
159	on to the prohibition of what I thought then were the maddest,
159	most impossible, and most indecent things one could well imagine.
159	A kind of rhythmic fervour fell on all of us; we gabbled
159	and swayed faster and faster, repeating this amazing Law.
159	Superficially the contagion of these brutes was upon me, but deep
159	down within me the laughter and disgust struggled together.
159	We ran through a long list of prohibitions, and then the chant swung
159	round to a new formula.
159	
159	     ""_His_ is the House of Pain.
159	     ""_His_ is the Hand that makes.
159	     ""_His_ is the Hand that wounds.
159	     ""_His_ is the Hand that heals.""
159	
159	And so on for another long series, mostly quite incomprehensible
159	gibberish to me about _Him_, whoever he might be.  I could have fancied
159	it was a dream, but never before have I heard chanting in a dream.
159	
159	""_His_ is the lightning flash,"" we sang.  ""_His_ is the deep, salt sea.""
159	
159	A horrible fancy came into my head that Moreau, after animalising
159	these men, had infected their dwarfed brains with a kind of
159	deification of himself.  However, I was too keenly aware of white
159	teeth and strong claws about me to stop my chanting on that account.
159	
159	""_His_ are the stars in the sky.""
159	
159	At last that song ended.  I saw the Ape-man's face shining
159	with perspiration; and my eyes being now accustomed to the darkness,
159	I saw more distinctly the figure in the corner from which the voice came.
159	It was the size of a man, but it seemed covered with a dull grey
159	hair almost like a Skye-terrier. What was it?  What were they all?
159	Imagine yourself surrounded by all the most horrible cripples
159	and maniacs it is possible to conceive, and you may understand
159	a little of my feelings with these grotesque caricatures of humanity
159	about me.
159	
159	""He is a five-man, a five-man, a five-man--like me,"" said the Ape-man.
159	
159	I held out my hands.  The grey creature in the corner leant forward.
159	
159	""Not to run on all-fours; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?""
159	he said.
159	
159	He put out a strangely distorted talon and gripped my fingers.
159	The thing was almost like the hoof of a deer produced into claws.
159	I could have yelled with surprise and pain.  His face came
159	forward and peered at my nails, came forward into the light of
159	the opening of the hut and I saw with a quivering disgust that it
159	was like the face of neither man nor beast, but a mere shock
159	of grey hair, with three shadowy over-archings to mark the eyes
159	and mouth.
159	
159	""He has little nails,"" said this grisly creature in his hairy beard.
159	""It is well.""
159	
159	He threw my hand down, and instinctively I gripped my stick.
159	
159	""Eat roots and herbs; it is His will,"" said the Ape-man.
159	
159	""I am the Sayer of the Law,"" said the grey figure.  ""Here come
159	all that be new to learn the Law.  I sit in the darkness and say
159	the Law.""
159	
159	""It is even so,"" said one of the beasts in the doorway.
159	
159	""Evil are the punishments of those who break the Law.
159	None escape.""
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the Beast Folk, glancing furtively at one another.
159	
159	""None, none,"" said the Ape-man,--""none escape.  See!  I did a little thing,
159	a wrong thing, once.  I jabbered, jabbered, stopped talking.
159	None could understand.  I am burnt, branded in the hand.  He is great.
159	He is good!""
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the grey creature in the corner.
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the Beast People, looking askance at one another.
159	
159	""For every one the want that is bad,"" said the grey Sayer of the Law.
159	""What you will want we do not know; we shall know.  Some want
159	to follow things that move, to watch and slink and wait and spring;
159	to kill and bite, bite deep and rich, sucking the blood.
159	It is bad.  'Not to chase other Men; that is the Law.
159	Are we not Men?  Not to eat Flesh or Fish; that is the Law.  Are we
159	not Men?'""
159	
159	""None escape,"" said a dappled brute standing in the doorway.
159	
159	""For every one the want is bad,"" said the grey Sayer of the Law.
159	""Some want to go tearing with teeth and hands into the roots of things,
159	snuffing into the earth.  It is bad.""
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the men in the door.
159	
159	""Some go clawing trees; some go scratching at the graves of the dead;
159	some go fighting with foreheads or feet or claws; some bite suddenly,
159	none giving occasion; some love uncleanness.""
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the Ape-man, scratching his calf.
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the little pink sloth-creature.
159	
159	""Punishment is sharp and sure.  Therefore learn the Law.
159	Say the words.""
159	
159	And incontinently he began again the strange litany of the Law,
159	and again I and all these creatures began singing and swaying.
159	My head reeled with this jabbering and the close stench of the place;
159	but I kept on, trusting to find presently some chance of a
159	new development.
159	
159	""Not to go on all-fours; that is the Law.  Are we not Men?""
159	
159	We were making such a noise that I noticed nothing of a tumult outside,
159	until some one, who I think was one of the two Swine Men I
159	had seen, thrust his head over the little pink sloth-creature
159	and shouted something excitedly, something that I did not catch.
159	Incontinently those at the opening of the hut vanished; my Ape-man
159	rushed out; the thing that had sat in the dark followed him
159	(I only observed that it was big and clumsy, and covered with silvery
159	hair), and I was left alone.  Then before I reached the aperture I heard
159	the yelp of a staghound.
159	
159	In another moment I was standing outside the hovel, my chair-rail
159	in my hand, every muscle of me quivering.  Before me were the clumsy
159	backs of perhaps a score of these Beast People, their misshapen heads
159	half hidden by their shoulder-blades. They were gesticulating excitedly.
159	Other half-animal faces glared interrogation out of the hovels.
159	Looking in the direction in which they faced, I saw coming through
159	the haze under the trees beyond the end of the passage of dens the dark
159	figure and awful white face of Moreau.  He was holding the leaping
159	staghound back, and close behind him came Montgomery revolver
159	in hand.
159	
159	For a moment I stood horror-struck. I turned and saw the passage
159	behind me blocked by another heavy brute, with a huge grey
159	face and twinkling little eyes, advancing towards me.
159	I looked round and saw to the right of me and a half-dozen yards
159	in front of me a narrow gap in the wall of rock through which a ray
159	of light slanted into the shadows.
159	
159	""Stop!"" cried Moreau as I strode towards this, and then, ""Hold him!""
159	
159	At that, first one face turned towards me and then others.
159	Their bestial minds were happily slow.  I dashed my shoulder
159	into a clumsy monster who was turning to see what Moreau meant,
159	and flung him forward into another.  I felt his hands fly round,
159	clutching at me and missing me.  The little pink sloth-creature
159	dashed at me, and I gashed down its ugly face with the nail
159	in my stick and in another minute was scrambling up a steep
159	side pathway, a kind of sloping chimney, out of the ravine.
159	I heard a howl behind me, and cries of ""Catch him!""  ""Hold him!""
159	and the grey-faced creature appeared behind me and jammed
159	his huge bulk into the cleft.  ""Go on! go on!"" they howled.
159	I clambered up the narrow cleft in the rock and came out upon
159	the sulphur on the westward side of the village of the Beast Men.
159	
159	That gap was altogether fortunate for me, for the narrow chimney,
159	slanting obliquely upward, must have impeded the nearer pursuers.
159	I ran over the white space and down a steep slope,
159	through a scattered growth of trees, and came to a low-lying
159	stretch of tall reeds, through which I pushed into a dark,
159	thick undergrowth that was black and succulent under foot.
159	As I plunged into the reeds, my foremost pursuers emerged from the gap.
159	I broke my way through this undergrowth for some minutes.
159	The air behind me and about me was soon full of threatening cries.
159	I heard the tumult of my pursuers in the gap up the slope, then the
159	crashing of the reeds, and every now and then the crackling crash
159	of a branch.  Some of the creatures roared like excited beasts of prey.
159	The staghound yelped to the left.  I heard Moreau and Montgomery shouting
159	in the same direction.  I turned sharply to the right.  It seemed
159	to me even then that I heard Montgomery shouting for me to run for
159	my life.
159	
159	Presently the ground gave rich and oozy under my feet; but I was
159	desperate and went headlong into it, struggled through kneedeep,
159	and so came to a winding path among tall canes.  The noise of my
159	pursuers passed away to my left.  In one place three strange, pink,
159	hopping animals, about the size of cats, bolted before my footsteps.
159	This pathway ran up hill, across another open space covered
159	with white incrustation, and plunged into a canebrake again.
159	Then suddenly it turned parallel with the edge of a steep-walled gap,
159	which came without warning, like the ha-ha of an English park,--turned
159	with an unexpected abruptness.  I was still running with all
159	my might, and I never saw this drop until I was flying headlong through
159	the air.
159	
159	I fell on my forearms and head, among thorns, and rose with a torn
159	ear and bleeding face.  I had fallen into a precipitous ravine,
159	rocky and thorny, full of a hazy mist which drifted about me in wisps,
159	and with a narrow streamlet from which this mist came meandering
159	down the centre.  I was astonished at this thin fog in the full
159	blaze of daylight; but I had no time to stand wondering then.
159	I turned to my right, down-stream, hoping to come to the sea
159	in that direction, and so have my way open to drown myself.
159	It was only later I found that I had dropped my nailed stick in
159	my fall.
159	
159	Presently the ravine grew narrower for a space, and carelessly
159	I stepped into the stream.  I jumped out again pretty quickly,
159	for the water was almost boiling.  I noticed too there was a thin
159	sulphurous scum drifting upon its coiling water.  Almost immediately
159	came a turn in the ravine, and the indistinct blue horizon.
159	The nearer sea was flashing the sun from a myriad facets.
159	I saw my death before me; but I was hot and panting, with the warm
159	blood oozing out on my face and running pleasantly through my veins.
159	I felt more than a touch of exultation too, at having distanced
159	my pursuers.  It was not in me then to go out and drown myself yet.
159	I stared back the way I had come.
159	
159	I listened.  Save for the hum of the gnats and the chirp of some small
159	insects that hopped among the thorns, the air was absolutely still.
159	Then came the yelp of a dog, very faint, and a chattering and gibbering,
159	the snap of a whip, and voices.  They grew louder, then fainter again.
159	The noise receded up the stream and faded away.  For a while the chase
159	was over; but I knew now how much hope of help for me lay in the
159	Beast People.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XIII.  A PARLEY.
159	
159	
159	I TURNED again and went on down towards the sea.  I found the hot stream
159	broadened out to a shallow, weedy sand, in which an abundance of crabs
159	and long-bodied, many-legged creatures started from my footfall.
159	I walked to the very edge of the salt water, and then I felt I was safe.
159	I turned and stared, arms akimbo, at the thick green behind me,
159	into which the steamy ravine cut like a smoking gash.
159	But, as I say, I was too full of excitement and (a true saying,
159	though those who have never known danger may doubt it) too desperate
159	to die.
159	
159	Then it came into my head that there was one chance before me yet.
159	While Moreau and Montgomery and their bestial rabble chased me
159	through the island, might I not go round the beach until I came
159	to their enclosure,--make a flank march upon them, in fact,
159	and then with a rock lugged out of their loosely-built wall, perhaps,
159	smash in the lock of the smaller door and see what I could find
159	(knife, pistol, or what not) to fight them with when they returned?
159	It was at any rate something to try.
159	
159	So I turned to the westward and walked along by the water's edge.
159	The setting sun flashed his blinding heat into my eyes.
159	The slight Pacific tide was running in with a gentle ripple.
159	Presently the shore fell away southward, and the sun came round
159	upon my right hand.  Then suddenly, far in front of me, I saw
159	first one and then several figures emerging from the bushes,--Moreau,
159	with his grey staghound, then Montgomery, and two others.
159	At that I stopped.
159	
159	They saw me, and began gesticulating and advancing.  I stood watching
159	them approach.  The two Beast Men came running forward to cut me
159	off from the undergrowth, inland.  Montgomery came, running also,
159	but straight towards me.  Moreau followed slower with the dog.
159	
159	At last I roused myself from my inaction, and turning seaward walked
159	straight into the water.  The water was very shallow at first.
159	I was thirty yards out before the waves reached to my waist.
159	Dimly I could see the intertidal creatures darting away from
159	my feet.
159	
159	""What are you doing, man?"" cried Montgomery.
159	
159	I turned, standing waist deep, and stared at them.
159	Montgomery stood panting at the margin of the water.  His face
159	was bright-red with exertion, his long flaxen hair blown about
159	his head, and his dropping nether lip showed his irregular teeth.
159	Moreau was just coming up, his face pale and firm, and the dog at his
159	hand barked at me.  Both men had heavy whips.  Farther up the beach
159	stared the Beast Men.
159	
159	""What am I doing?  I am going to drown myself,"" said I.
159	
159	Montgomery and Moreau looked at each other.  ""Why?"" asked Moreau.
159	
159	""Because that is better than being tortured by you.""
159	
159	""I told you so,"" said Montgomery, and Moreau said something
159	in a low tone.
159	
159	""What makes you think I shall torture you?"" asked Moreau.
159	
159	""What I saw,"" I said.  ""And those--yonder.""
159	
159	""Hush!"" said Moreau, and held up his hand.
159	
159	""I will not,"" said I. ""They were men:  what are they now?
159	I at least will not be like them.""
159	
159	I looked past my interlocutors.  Up the beach were M'ling, Montgomery's
159	attendant, and one of the white-swathed brutes from the boat.
159	Farther up, in the shadow of the trees, I saw my little Ape-man,
159	and behind him some other dim figures.
159	
159	""Who are these creatures?"" said I, pointing to them and raising
159	my voice more and more that it might reach them.  ""They were men,
159	men like yourselves, whom you have infected with some bestial
159	taint,--men whom you have enslaved, and whom you still fear.
159	
159	""You who listen,"" I cried, pointing now to Moreau and shouting past
159	him to the Beast Men,--""You who listen!  Do you not see these men
159	still fear you, go in dread of you?  Why, then, do you fear them?
159	You are many--""
159	
159	""For God's sake,"" cried Montgomery, ""stop that, Prendick!""
159	
159	""Prendick!"" cried Moreau.
159	
159	They both shouted together, as if to drown my voice; and behind
159	them lowered the staring faces of the Beast Men, wondering,
159	their deformed hands hanging down, their shoulders hunched up.
159	They seemed, as I fancied, to be trying to understand me, to remember,
159	I thought, something of their human past.
159	
159	I went on shouting, I scarcely remember what,--that Moreau
159	and Montgomery could be killed, that they were not to be feared:
159	that was the burden of what I put into the heads of the Beast People.
159	I saw the green-eyed man in the dark rags, who had met me on
159	the evening of my arrival, come out from among the trees, and others
159	followed him, to hear me better.  At last for want of breath
159	I paused.
159	
159	""Listen to me for a moment,"" said the steady voice of Moreau;
159	""and then say what you will.""
159	
159	""Well?"" said I.
159	
159	He coughed, thought, then shouted:  ""Latin, Prendick! bad Latin,
159	schoolboy Latin; but try and understand.  Hi non sunt homines;
159	sunt animalia qui nos habemus--vivisected.  A humanising process.
159	I will explain.  Come ashore.""
159	
159	I laughed.  ""A pretty story,"" said I. ""They talk, build houses.
159	They were men.  It's likely I'll come ashore.""
159	
159	""The water just beyond where you stand is deep--and full of sharks.""
159	
159	""That's my way,"" said I. ""Short and sharp.  Presently.""
159	
159	""Wait a minute.""  He took something out of his pocket that flashed back
159	the sun, and dropped the object at his feet.  ""That's a loaded revolver,""
159	said he.  ""Montgomery here will do the same.  Now we are going
159	up the beach until you are satisfied the distance is safe.
159	Then come and take the revolvers.""
159	
159	""Not I!  You have a third between you.""
159	
159	""I want you to think over things, Prendick.  In the first place,
159	I never asked you to come upon this island.  If we vivisected men,
159	we should import men, not beasts.  In the next, we had you
159	drugged last night, had we wanted to work you any mischief;
159	and in the next, now your first panic is over and you can think
159	a little, is Montgomery here quite up to the character you give him?
159	We have chased you for your good.  Because this island is full
159	of inimical phenomena.  Besides, why should we want to shoot you
159	when you have just offered to drown yourself?""
159	
159	""Why did you set--your people onto me when I was in the hut?""
159	
159	""We felt sure of catching you, and bringing you out of danger.
159	Afterwards we drew away from the scent, for your good.""
159	
159	I mused.  It seemed just possible.  Then I remembered something again.
159	""But I saw,"" said I, ""in the enclosure--""
159	
159	""That was the puma.""
159	
159	""Look here, Prendick,"" said Montgomery, ""you're a silly ass!
159	Come out of the water and take these revolvers, and talk.
159	We can't do anything more than we could do now.""
159	
159	I will confess that then, and indeed always, I distrusted
159	and dreaded Moreau; but Montgomery was a man I felt I understood.
159	
159	""Go up the beach,"" said I, after thinking, and added, ""holding your
159	hands up.""
159	
159	""Can't do that,"" said Montgomery, with an explanatory nod over
159	his shoulder.  ""Undignified.""
159	
159	""Go up to the trees, then,"" said I, ""as you please.""
159	
159	""It's a damned silly ceremony,"" said Montgomery.
159	
159	Both turned and faced the six or seven grotesque creatures,
159	who stood there in the sunlight, solid, casting shadows, moving,
159	and yet so incredibly unreal.  Montgomery cracked his whip at them,
159	and forthwith they all turned and fled helter-skelter into the trees;
159	and when Montgomery and Moreau were at a distance I judged sufficient,
159	I waded ashore, and picked up and examined the revolvers.
159	To satisfy myself against the subtlest trickery, I discharged one at
159	a round lump of lava, and had the satisfaction of seeing the stone
159	pulverised and the beach splashed with lead.  Still I hesitated for
159	a moment.
159	
159	""I'll take the risk,"" said I, at last; and with a revolver in each
159	hand I walked up the beach towards them.
159	
159	""That's better,"" said Moreau, without affectation.  ""As it is, you have
159	wasted the best part of my day with your confounded imagination.""
159	And with a touch of contempt which humiliated me, he and Montgomery
159	turned and went on in silence before me.
159	
159	The knot of Beast Men, still wondering, stood back among the trees.
159	I passed them as serenely as possible.  One started to follow me,
159	but retreated again when Montgomery cracked his whip.  The rest
159	stood silent--watching.  They may once have been animals; but I never
159	before saw an animal trying to think.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XIV.  DOCTOR MOREAU EXPLAINS.
159	
159	
159	""AND now, Prendick, I will explain,"" said Doctor Moreau,
159	so soon as we had eaten and drunk.  ""I must confess that
159	you are the most dictatorial guest I ever entertained.
159	I warn you that this is the last I shall do to oblige you.
159	The next thing you threaten to commit suicide about, I shan't
159	do,--even at some personal inconvenience.""
159	
159	He sat in my deck chair, a cigar half consumed in his white,
159	dexterous-looking fingers.  The light of the swinging lamp fell on his
159	white hair; he stared through the little window out at the starlight.
159	I sat as far away from him as possible, the table between us
159	and the revolvers to hand.  Montgomery was not present.
159	I did not care to be with the two of them in such a little room.
159	
159	""You admit that the vivisected human being, as you called it, is,
159	after all, only the puma?"" said Moreau.  He had made me visit
159	that horror in the inner room, to assure myself of its inhumanity.
159	
159	""It is the puma,"" I said, ""still alive, but so cut and mutilated
159	as I pray I may never see living flesh again.  Of all vile--""
159	
159	""Never mind that,"" said Moreau; ""at least, spare me those
159	youthful horrors.  Montgomery used to be just the same.
159	You admit that it is the puma.  Now be quiet, while I reel off
159	my physiological lecture to you.""
159	
159	And forthwith, beginning in the tone of a man supremely bored,
159	but presently warming a little, he explained his work to me.
159	He was very simple and convincing.  Now and then there was a touch
159	of sarcasm in his voice.  Presently I found myself hot with shame at our
159	mutual positions.
159	
159	The creatures I had seen were not men, had never been men.
159	They were animals, humanised animals,--triumphs of vivisection.
159	
159	""You forget all that a skilled vivisector can do with living things,""
159	said Moreau.  ""For my own part, I'm puzzled why the things
159	I have done here have not been done before.  Small efforts,
159	of course, have been made,--amputation, tongue-cutting, excisions.
159	Of course you know a squint may be induced or cured by surgery?
159	Then in the case of excisions you have all kinds of secondary changes,
159	pigmentary disturbances, modifications of the passions, alterations in
159	the secretion of fatty tissue.  I have no doubt you have heard of
159	these things?""
159	
159	""Of course,"" said I. ""But these foul creatures of yours--""
159	
159	""All in good time,"" said he, waving his hand at me; ""I am only beginning.
159	Those are trivial cases of alteration.  Surgery can do better things
159	than that.  There is building up as well as breaking down and changing.
159	You have heard, perhaps, of a common surgical operation resorted to in
159	cases where the nose has been destroyed:  a flap of skin is cut from
159	the forehead, turned down on the nose, and heals in the new position.
159	This is a kind of grafting in a new position of part of an animal
159	upon itself.  Grafting of freshly obtained material from another
159	animal is also possible,--the case of teeth, for example.
159	The grafting of skin and bone is done to facilitate healing:
159	the surgeon places in the middle of the wound pieces of skin snipped
159	from another animal, or fragments of bone from a victim freshly killed.
159	Hunter's cock-spur--possibly you have heard of that--flourished on
159	the bull's neck; and the rhinoceros rats of the Algerian zouaves are
159	also to be thought of,--monsters manufactured by transferring a slip
159	from the tail of an ordinary rat to its snout, and allowing it to heal in
159	that position.""
159	
159	""Monsters manufactured!"" said I. ""Then you mean to tell me--""
159	
159	""Yes.  These creatures you have seen are animals carven and wrought
159	into new shapes.  To that, to the study of the plasticity of
159	living forms, my life has been devoted.  I have studied for years,
159	gaining in knowledge as I go.  I see you look horrified, and yet I
159	am telling you nothing new.  It all lay in the surface of practical
159	anatomy years ago, but no one had the temerity to touch it.
159	It is not simply the outward form of an animal which I can change.
159	The physiology, the chemical rhythm of the creature, may also be made
159	to undergo an enduring modification,--of which vaccination and other
159	methods of inoculation with living or dead matter are examples
159	that will, no doubt, be familiar to you.  A similar operation is
159	the transfusion of blood,--with which subject, indeed, I began.
159	These are all familiar cases.  Less so, and probably far more extensive,
159	were the operations of those mediaeval practitioners who made
159	dwarfs and beggar-cripples, show-monsters,--some vestiges of whose
159	art still remain in the preliminary manipulation of the young
159	mountebank or contortionist.  Victor Hugo gives an account of them
159	in 'L'Homme qui Rit.'--But perhaps my meaning grows plain now.
159	You begin to see that it is a possible thing to transplant tissue
159	from one part of an animal to another, or from one animal to another;
159	to alter its chemical reactions and methods of growth; to modify
159	the articulations of its limbs; and, indeed, to change it in its most
159	intimate structure.
159	
159	""And yet this extraordinary branch of knowledge has never been sought
159	as an end, and systematically, by modern investigators until I took it up!
159	Some such things have been hit upon in the last resort of surgery;
159	most of the kindred evidence that will recur to your mind has been
159	demonstrated as it were by accident,--by tyrants, by criminals,
159	by the breeders of horses and dogs, by all kinds of untrained
159	clumsy-handed men working for their own immediate ends.
159	I was the first man to take up this question armed with antiseptic surgery,
159	and with a really scientific knowledge of the laws of growth.
159	Yet one would imagine it must have been practised in secret before.
159	Such creatures as the Siamese Twins--And in the vaults of
159	the Inquisition.  No doubt their chief aim was artistic torture,
159	but some at least of the inquisitors must have had a touch of
159	scientific curiosity.""
159	
159	""But,"" said I, ""these things--these animals talk!""
159	
159	He said that was so, and proceeded to point out that the possibility
159	of vivisection does not stop at a mere physical metamorphosis.
159	A pig may be educated.  The mental structure is even less determinate
159	than the bodily.  In our growing science of hypnotism we find
159	the promise of a possibility of superseding old inherent instincts by
159	new suggestions, grafting upon or replacing the inherited fixed ideas.
159	Very much indeed of what we call moral education, he said,
159	is such an artificial modification and perversion of instinct;
159	pugnacity is trained into courageous self-sacrifice, and suppressed
159	sexuality into religious emotion.  And the great difference
159	between man and monkey is in the larynx, he continued,--in the
159	incapacity to frame delicately different sound-symbols by which
159	thought could be sustained.  In this I failed to agree with him,
159	but with a certain incivility he declined to notice my objection.
159	He repeated that the thing was so, and continued his account of
159	his work.
159	
159	I asked him why he had taken the human form as a model.
159	There seemed to me then, and there still seems to me now, a strange
159	wickedness for that choice.
159	
159	He confessed that he had chosen that form by chance.  ""I might just
159	as well have worked to form sheep into llamas and llamas into sheep.
159	I suppose there is something in the human form that appeals to
159	the artistic turn of mind more powerfully than any animal shape can.
159	But I've not confined myself to man-making. Once or twice--"" He was silent,
159	for a minute perhaps.  ""These years!  How they have slipped by!
159	And here I have wasted a day saving your life, and am now wasting an hour
159	explaining myself!""
159	
159	""But,"" said I, ""I still do not understand.  Where is your justification
159	for inflicting all this pain?  The only thing that could excuse
159	vivisection to me would be some application--""
159	
159	""Precisely,"" said he.  ""But, you see, I am differently constituted.
159	We are on different platforms.  You are a materialist.""
159	
159	""I am _not_ a materialist,"" I began hotly.
159	
159	""In my view--in my view.  For it is just this question of pain
159	that parts us.  So long as visible or audible pain turns you sick;
159	so long as your own pains drive you; so long as pain underlies
159	your propositions about sin,--so long, I tell you, you are
159	an animal, thinking a little less obscurely what an animal feels.
159	This pain--""
159	
159	I gave an impatient shrug at such sophistry.
159	
159	""Oh, but it is such a little thing!  A mind truly opened to
159	what science has to teach must see that it is a little thing.
159	It may be that save in this little planet, this speck of cosmic dust,
159	invisible long before the nearest star could be attained--it may be,
159	I say, that nowhere else does this thing called pain occur.
159	But the laws we feel our way towards--Why, even on this earth, even among
159	living things, what pain is there?""
159	
159	As he spoke he drew a little penknife from his pocket, opened the
159	smaller blade, and moved his chair so that I could see his thigh.
159	Then, choosing the place deliberately, he drove the blade into
159	his leg and withdrew it.
159	
159	""No doubt,"" he said, ""you have seen that before.  It does not hurt
159	a pin-prick. But what does it show?  The capacity for pain is not
159	needed in the muscle, and it is not placed there,--is but little
159	needed in the skin, and only here and there over the thigh is
159	a spot capable of feeling pain.  Pain is simply our intrinsic
159	medical adviser to warn us and stimulate us.  Not all living
159	flesh is painful; nor is all nerve, not even all sensory nerve.
159	There's no taint of pain, real pain, in the sensations of the optic
159	nerve.  If you wound the optic nerve, you merely see flashes of
159	light,--just as disease of the auditory nerve merely means a humming
159	in our ears.  Plants do not feel pain, nor the lower animals;
159	it's possible that such animals as the starfish and crayfish do not
159	feel pain at all.  Then with men, the more intelligent they become,
159	the more intelligently they will see after their own welfare,
159	and the less they will need the goad to keep them out of danger.
159	I never yet heard of a useless thing that was not ground out
159	of existence by evolution sooner or later.  Did you?  And pain
159	gets needless.
159	
159	""Then I am a religious man, Prendick, as every sane man must be.
159	It may be, I fancy, that I have seen more of the ways of this world's
159	Maker than you,--for I have sought his laws, in _my_ way, all my life,
159	while you, I understand, have been collecting butterflies.
159	And I tell you, pleasure and pain have nothing to do with heaven or hell.
159	Pleasure and pain--bah!  What is your theologian's ecstasy but
159	Mahomet's houri in the dark?  This store which men and women set
159	on pleasure and pain, Prendick, is the mark of the beast upon
159	them,--the mark of the beast from which they came!  Pain, pain and
159	pleasure, they are for us only so long as we wriggle in the dust.
159	
159	""You see, I went on with this research just the way it led me.
159	That is the only way I ever heard of true research going.
159	I asked a question, devised some method of obtaining an answer,
159	and got a fresh question.  Was this possible or that possible?
159	You cannot imagine what this means to an investigator,
159	what an intellectual passion grows upon him!  You cannot imagine
159	the strange, colourless delight of these intellectual desires!
159	The thing before you is no longer an animal, a fellow-creature,
159	but a problem!  Sympathetic pain,--all I know of it I remember
159	as a thing I used to suffer from years ago.  I wanted--it was
159	the one thing I wanted--to find out the extreme limit of plasticity
159	in a living shape.""
159	
159	""But,"" said I, ""the thing is an abomination--""
159	
159	""To this day I have never troubled about the ethics of the matter,""
159	he continued.  ""The study of Nature makes a man at last as remorseless
159	as Nature.  I have gone on, not heeding anything but the question I
159	was pursuing; and the material has--dripped into the huts yonder.
159	It is nearly eleven years since we came here, I and Montgomery
159	and six Kanakas.  I remember the green stillness of the island
159	and the empty ocean about us, as though it was yesterday.
159	The place seemed waiting for me.
159	
159	""The stores were landed and the house was built.  The Kanakas founded
159	some huts near the ravine.  I went to work here upon what I had brought
159	with me.  There were some disagreeable things happened at first.
159	I began with a sheep, and killed it after a day and a half by a slip
159	of the scalpel.  I took another sheep, and made a thing of pain and fear
159	and left it bound up to heal.  It looked quite human to me when I
159	had finished it; but when I went to it I was discontented with it.
159	It remembered me, and was terrified beyond imagination; and it had no
159	more than the wits of a sheep.  The more I looked at it the clumsier
159	it seemed, until at last I put the monster out of its misery.
159	These animals without courage, these fear-haunted, pain-driven things,
159	without a spark of pugnacious energy to face torment,--they are no good for
159	man-making.
159	
159	""Then I took a gorilla I had; and upon that, working with infinite
159	care and mastering difficulty after difficulty, I made my first man.
159	All the week, night and day, I moulded him.  With him it was chiefly
159	the brain that needed moulding; much had to be added, much changed.
159	I thought him a fair specimen of the negroid type when I had
159	finished him, and he lay bandaged, bound, and motionless before me.
159	It was only when his life was assured that I left him and came
159	into this room again, and found Montgomery much as you are.
159	He had heard some of the cries as the thing grew human,--cries
159	like those that disturbed _you_ so.  I didn't take him
159	completely into my confidence at first.  And the Kanakas too,
159	had realised something of it.  They were scared out of their wits
159	by the sight of me.  I got Montgomery over to me--in a way;
159	but I and he had the hardest job to prevent the Kanakas deserting.
159	Finally they did; and so we lost the yacht.  I spent many days
159	educating the brute,--altogether I had him for three or four months.
159	I taught him the rudiments of English; gave him ideas of counting;
159	even made the thing read the alphabet.  But at that he was slow,
159	though I've met with idiots slower.  He began with a clean sheet,
159	mentally; had no memories left in his mind of what he had been.
159	When his scars were quite healed, and he was no longer anything
159	but painful and stiff, and able to converse a little, I took
159	him yonder and introduced him to the Kanakas as an interesting
159	stowaway.
159	
159	""They were horribly afraid of him at first, somehow,--which offended
159	me rather, for I was conceited about him; but his ways seemed so mild,
159	and he was so abject, that after a time they received him and took his
159	education in hand.  He was quick to learn, very imitative and adaptive,
159	and built himself a hovel rather better, it seemed to me, than their
159	own shanties.  There was one among the boys a bit of a missionary,
159	and he taught the thing to read, or at least to pick out letters,
159	and gave him some rudimentary ideas of morality; but it seems
159	the beast's habits were not all that is desirable.
159	
159	""I rested from work for some days after this, and was in a mind to
159	write an account of the whole affair to wake up English physiology.
159	Then I came upon the creature squatting up in a tree and gibbering
159	at two of the Kanakas who had been teasing him.  I threatened him,
159	told him the inhumanity of such a proceeding, aroused his sense of shame,
159	and came home resolved to do better before I took my work back to England.
159	I have been doing better.  But somehow the things drift back again:
159	the stubborn beast-flesh grows day by day back again.
159	But I mean to do better things still.  I mean to conquer that.
159	This puma--
159	
159	""But that's the story.  All the Kanaka boys are dead now;
159	one fell overboard of the launch, and one died of a wounded
159	heel that he poisoned in some way with plant-juice. Three
159	went away in the yacht, and I suppose and hope were drowned.
159	The other one--was killed.  Well, I have replaced them.
159	Montgomery went on much as you are disposed to do at first,
159	and then--
159	
159	""What became of the other one?"" said I, sharply,--""the other Kanaka
159	who was killed?""
159	
159	""The fact is, after I had made a number of human creatures I made
159	a Thing--""  He hesitated.
159	
159	""Yes?"" said I.
159	
159	""It was killed.""
159	
159	""I don't understand,"" said I; ""do you mean to say--""
159	
159	""It killed the Kanaka--yes.  It killed several other things that
159	it caught.  We chased it for a couple of days.  It only got loose
159	by accident--I never meant it to get away.  It wasn't finished.
159	It was purely an experiment.  It was a limbless thing, with a
159	horrible face, that writhed along the ground in a serpentine fashion.
159	It was immensely strong, and in infuriating pain.  It lurked in
159	the woods for some days, until we hunted it; and then it wriggled
159	into the northern part of the island, and we divided the party
159	to close in upon it.  Montgomery insisted upon coming with me.
159	The man had a rifle; and when his body was found, one of the barrels
159	was curved into the shape of an S and very nearly bitten through.
159	Montgomery shot the thing.  After that I stuck to the ideal of
159	humanity--except for little things.""
159	
159	He became silent.  I sat in silence watching his face.
159	
159	""So for twenty years altogether--counting nine years in England--I
159	have been going on; and there is still something in everything I do
159	that defeats me, makes me dissatisfied, challenges me to further effort.
159	Sometimes I rise above my level, sometimes I fall below it; but always
159	I fall short of the things I dream.  The human shape I can get now,
159	almost with ease, so that it is lithe and graceful, or thick and strong;
159	but often there is trouble with the hands and the claws,--painful things,
159	that I dare not shape too freely.  But it is in the subtle grafting
159	and reshaping one must needs do to the brain that my trouble lies.
159	The intelligence is often oddly low, with unaccountable blank ends,
159	unexpected gaps.  And least satisfactory of all is something that I
159	cannot touch, somewhere--I cannot determine where--in the seat
159	of the emotions.  Cravings, instincts, desires that harm humanity,
159	a strange hidden reservoir to burst forth suddenly and inundate
159	the whole being of the creature with anger, hate, or fear.
159	These creatures of mine seemed strange and uncanny to you so soon
159	as you began to observe them; but to me, just after I make them,
159	they seem to be indisputably human beings.  It's afterwards, as I
159	observe them, that the persuasion fades.  First one animal trait,
159	then another, creeps to the surface and stares out at me.
159	But I will conquer yet!  Each time I dip a living creature into the bath
159	of burning pain, I say, 'This time I will burn out all the animal;
159	this time I will make a rational creature of my own!'  After all,
159	what is ten years?  Men have been a hundred thousand in the making.""
159	He thought darkly.  ""But I am drawing near the fastness.
159	This puma of mine--"" After a silence, ""And they revert.
159	As soon as my hand is taken from them the beast begins
159	to creep back, begins to assert itself again.""  Another long
159	silence.
159	
159	""Then you take the things you make into those dens?"" said I.
159	
159	""They go.  I turn them out when I begin to feel the beast in them,
159	and presently they wander there.  They all dread this house and me.
159	There is a kind of travesty of humanity over there.  Montgomery knows
159	about it, for he interferes in their affairs.  He has trained one
159	or two of them to our service.  He's ashamed of it, but I believe
159	he half likes some of those beasts.  It's his business, not mine.
159	They only sicken me with a sense of failure.  I take no interest in them.
159	I fancy they follow in the lines the Kanaka missionary marked out,
159	and have a kind of mockery of a rational life, poor beasts!
159	There's something they call the Law.  Sing hymns about 'all thine.'
159	They build themselves their dens, gather fruit, and pull herbs--marry
159	even.  But I can see through it all, see into their very souls,
159	and see there nothing but the souls of beasts, beasts that perish,
159	anger and the lusts to live and gratify themselves.--Yet they're odd;
159	complex, like everything else alive.  There is a kind of upward
159	striving in them, part vanity, part waste sexual emotion,
159	part waste curiosity.  It only mocks me.  I have some hope of this puma.
159	I have worked hard at her head and brain--
159	
159	""And now,"" said he, standing up after a long gap of silence, during
159	which we had each pursued our own thoughts, ""what do you think?  Are
159	you in fear of me still?""
159	
159	I looked at him, and saw but a white-faced, white-haired man,
159	with calm eyes.  Save for his serenity, the touch almost of beauty that
159	resulted from his set tranquillity and his magnificent build, he might
159	have passed muster among a hundred other comfortable old gentlemen.
159	Then I shivered.  By way of answer to his second question, I handed
159	him a revolver with either hand.
159	
159	""Keep them,"" he said, and snatched at a yawn.  He stood up, stared at
159	me for a moment, and smiled.  ""You have had two eventful days,""
159	said he.  ""I should advise some sleep.  I'm glad it's all clear.
159	Good-night."" He thought me over for a moment, then went out by
159	the inner door.
159	
159	I immediately turned the key in the outer one.  I sat down again;
159	sat for a time in a kind of stagnant mood, so weary, emotionally,
159	mentally, and physically, that I could not think beyond the point
159	at which he had left me.  The black window stared at me like an eye.
159	At last with an effort I put out the light and got into the hammock.
159	Very soon I was asleep.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XV.  CONCERNING THE BEAST FOLK.
159	
159	
159	I WOKE early.  Moreau's explanation stood before my mind,
159	clear and definite, from the moment of my awakening.  I got out
159	of the hammock and went to the door to assure myself that the key
159	was turned.  Then I tried the window-bar, and found it firmly fixed.
159	That these man-like creatures were in truth only bestial monsters,
159	mere grotesque travesties of men, filled me with a vague uncertainty
159	of their possibilities which was far worse than any definite fear.
159	
159	A tapping came at the door, and I heard the glutinous accents
159	of M'ling speaking.  I pocketed one of the revolvers (keeping one
159	hand upon it), and opened to him.
159	
159	""Good-morning, sair,"" he said, bringing in, in addition to the customary
159	herb-breakfast, an ill-cooked rabbit.  Montgomery followed him.
159	His roving eye caught the position of my arm and he smiled askew.
159	
159	The puma was resting to heal that day; but Moreau, who was singularly
159	solitary in his habits, did not join us.  I talked with Montgomery
159	to clear my ideas of the way in which the Beast Folk lived.
159	In particular, I was urgent to know how these inhuman monsters were kept
159	from falling upon Moreau and Montgomery and from rending one another.
159	He explained to me that the comparative safety of Moreau and
159	himself was due to the limited mental scope of these monsters.
159	In spite of their increased intelligence and the tendency of their
159	animal instincts to reawaken, they had certain fixed ideas implanted
159	by Moreau in their minds, which absolutely bounded their imaginations.
159	They were really hypnotised; had been told that certain things
159	were impossible, and that certain things were not to be done,
159	and these prohibitions were woven into the texture of their minds beyond
159	any possibility of disobedience or dispute.
159	
159	Certain matters, however, in which old instinct was at war
159	with Moreau's convenience, were in a less stable condition.
159	A series of propositions called the Law (I had already heard them recited)
159	battled in their minds with the deep-seated, ever-rebellious cravings
159	of their animal natures.  This Law they were ever repeating,
159	I found, and ever breaking.  Both Montgomery and Moreau displayed
159	particular solicitude to keep them ignorant of the taste of blood;
159	they feared the inevitable suggestions of that flavour.
159	Montgomery told me that the Law, especially among the feline Beast People,
159	became oddly weakened about nightfall; that then the animal was at
159	its strongest; that a spirit of adventure sprang up in them at the dusk,
159	when they would dare things they never seemed to dream about by day.
159	To that I owed my stalking by the Leopard-man, on the night of my arrival.
159	But during these earlier days of my stay they broke the Law only
159	furtively and after dark; in the daylight there was a general
159	atmosphere of respect for its multifarious prohibitions.
159	
159	And here perhaps I may give a few general facts about the island
159	and the Beast People.  The island, which was of irregular outline
159	and lay low upon the wide sea, had a total area, I suppose,
159	of seven or eight square miles.{2} It was volcanic in origin,
159	and was now fringed on three sides by coral reefs; some fumaroles
159	to the northward, and a hot spring, were the only vestiges of
159	the forces that had long since originated it.  Now and then a faint
159	quiver of earthquake would be sensible, and sometimes the ascent
159	of the spire of smoke would be rendered tumultuous by gusts of steam;
159	but that was all.  The population of the island, Montgomery informed me,
159	now numbered rather more than sixty of these strange creations
159	of Moreau's art, not counting the smaller monstrosities
159	which lived in the undergrowth and were without human form.
159	Altogether he had made nearly a hundred and twenty; but many had died,
159	and others--like the writhing Footless Thing of which he had told
159	me--had come by violent ends.  In answer to my question, Montgomery
159	said that they actually bore offspring, but that these generally died.
159	When they lived, Moreau took them and stamped the human form upon them.
159	There was no evidence of the inheritance of their acquired
159	human characteristics.  The females were less numerous than the males,
159	and liable to much furtive persecution in spite of the monogamy the
159	Law enjoined.
159	
159	     {2} This description corresponds in every respect to Noble's Isle.
159	         -- C. E. P.
159	
159	It would be impossible for me to describe these Beast People in detail;
159	my eye has had no training in details, and unhappily I cannot sketch.
159	Most striking, perhaps, in their general appearance was the
159	disproportion between the legs of these creatures and the length
159	of their bodies; and yet--so relative is our idea of grace--my
159	eye became habituated to their forms, and at last I even fell
159	in with their persuasion that my own long thighs were ungainly.
159	Another point was the forward carriage of the head and the clumsy
159	and inhuman curvature of the spine.  Even the Ape-man lacked
159	that inward sinuous curve of the back which makes the human
159	figure so graceful.  Most had their shoulders hunched clumsily,
159	and their short forearms hung weakly at their sides.  Few of them
159	were conspicuously hairy, at least until the end of my time upon
159	the island.
159	
159	The next most obvious deformity was in their faces,
159	almost all of which were prognathous, malformed about the ears,
159	with large and protuberant noses, very furry or very bristly hair,
159	and often strangely-coloured or strangely-placed eyes.
159	None could laugh, though the Ape-man had a chattering titter.
159	Beyond these general characters their heads had little in common;
159	each preserved the quality of its particular species:
159	the human mark distorted but did not hide the leopard, the ox,
159	or the sow, or other animal or animals, from which the creature
159	had been moulded.  The voices, too, varied exceedingly.
159	The hands were always malformed; and though some surprised me by their
159	unexpected human appearance, almost all were deficient in the number
159	of the digits, clumsy about the finger-nails, and lacking any
159	tactile sensibility.
159	
159	The two most formidable Animal Men were my Leopard-man and a creature
159	made of hyena and swine.  Larger than these were the three bull-creatures
159	who pulled in the boat.  Then came the silvery-hairy-man, who was also
159	the Sayer of the Law, M'ling, and a satyr-like creature of ape and goat.
159	There were three Swine-men and a Swine-woman, a mare-rhinoceros-creature,
159	and several other females whose sources I did not ascertain.
159	There were several wolf-creatures, a bear-bull, and a Saint-Bernard-man. I
159	have already described the Ape-man, and there was a particularly hateful
159	(and evil-smelling) old woman made of vixen and bear, whom I hated
159	from the beginning.  She was said to be a passionate votary of the Law.
159	Smaller creatures were certain dappled youths and my little
159	sloth-creature. But enough of this catalogue.
159	
159	At first I had a shivering horror of the brutes, felt all too keenly
159	that they were still brutes; but insensibly I became a little
159	habituated to the idea of them, and moreover I was affected by
159	Montgomery's attitude towards them.  He had been with them so long
159	that he had come to regard them as almost normal human beings.
159	His London days seemed a glorious, impossible past to him.
159	Only once in a year or so did he go to Arica to deal with
159	Moreau's agent, a trader in animals there.  He hardly met the finest
159	type of mankind in that seafaring village of Spanish mongrels.
159	The men aboard-ship, he told me, seemed at first just as strange
159	to him as the Beast Men seemed to me,--unnaturally long in the leg,
159	flat in the face, prominent in the forehead, suspicious, dangerous,
159	and cold-hearted. In fact, he did not like men:  his heart
159	had warmed to me, he thought, because he had saved my life.
159	I fancied even then that he had a sneaking kindness for some of these
159	metamorphosed brutes, a vicious sympathy with some of their ways,
159	but that he attempted to veil it from me at first.
159	
159	M'ling, the black-faced man, Montgomery's attendant, the first of
159	the Beast Folk I had encountered, did not live with the others across
159	the island, but in a small kennel at the back of the enclosure.
159	The creature was scarcely so intelligent as the Ape-man, but far
159	more docile, and the most human-looking of all the Beast Folk;
159	and Montgomery had trained it to prepare food, and indeed to
159	discharge all the trivial domestic offices that were required.
159	It was a complex trophy of Moreau's horrible skill,--a bear, tainted with
159	dog and ox, and one of the most elaborately made of all his creatures.
159	It treated Montgomery with a strange tenderness and devotion.
159	Sometimes he would notice it, pat it, call it half-mocking, half-jocular
159	names, and so make it caper with extraordinary delight; sometimes he
159	would ill-treat it, especially after he had been at the whiskey,
159	kicking it, beating it, pelting it with stones or lighted fusees.
159	But whether he treated it well or ill, it loved nothing so much as to be
159	near him.
159	
159	I say I became habituated to the Beast People, that a thousand
159	things which had seemed unnatural and repulsive speedily became
159	natural and ordinary to me.  I suppose everything in existence
159	takes its colour from the average hue of our surroundings.
159	Montgomery and Moreau were too peculiar and individual
159	to keep my general impressions of humanity well defined.
159	I would see one of the clumsy bovine-creatures who worked the launch
159	treading heavily through the undergrowth, and find myself asking,
159	trying hard to recall, how he differed from some really human
159	yokel trudging home from his mechanical labours; or I would meet
159	the Fox-bear woman's vulpine, shifty face, strangely human in its
159	speculative cunning, and even imagine I had met it before in some
159	city byway.
159	
159	Yet every now and then the beast would flash out upon me beyond
159	doubt or denial.  An ugly-looking man, a hunch-backed human savage
159	to all appearance, squatting in the aperture of one of the dens,
159	would stretch his arms and yawn, showing with startling suddenness
159	scissor-edged incisors and sabre-like canines, keen and brilliant
159	as knives.  Or in some narrow pathway, glancing with a transitory
159	daring into the eyes of some lithe, white-swathed female figure,
159	I would suddenly see (with a spasmodic revulsion) that she had
159	slit-like pupils, or glancing down note the curving nail with which
159	she held her shapeless wrap about her.  It is a curious thing, by
159	the bye, for which I am quite unable to account, that these weird
159	creatures--the females, I mean--had in the earlier days of my stay an
159	instinctive sense of their own repulsive clumsiness, and displayed
159	in consequence a more than human regard for the decency and decorum
159	of extensive costume.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XVI.  HOW THE BEAST FOLK TASTE BLOOD.
159	
159	
159	MY inexperience as a writer betrays me, and I wander from the thread
159	of my story.
159	
159	After I had breakfasted with Montgomery, he took me across
159	the island to see the fumarole and the source of the hot spring
159	into whose scalding waters I had blundered on the previous day.
159	Both of us carried whips and loaded revolvers.  While going through
159	a leafy jungle on our road thither, we heard a rabbit squealing.
159	We stopped and listened, but we heard no more; and presently we
159	went on our way, and the incident dropped out of our minds.
159	Montgomery called my attention to certain little pink animals
159	with long hind-legs, that went leaping through the undergrowth.
159	He told me they were creatures made of the offspring of the Beast People,
159	that Moreau had invented.  He had fancied they might serve for meat,
159	but a rabbit-like habit of devouring their young had defeated
159	this intention.  I had already encountered some of these
159	creatures,--once during my moonlight flight from the Leopard-man,
159	and once during my pursuit by Moreau on the previous day.
159	By chance, one hopping to avoid us leapt into the hole caused
159	by the uprooting of a wind-blown tree; before it could extricate
159	itself we managed to catch it.  It spat like a cat, scratched and
159	kicked vigorously with its hind-legs, and made an attempt to bite;
159	but its teeth were too feeble to inflict more than a painless pinch.
159	It seemed to me rather a pretty little creature; and as Montgomery stated
159	that it never destroyed the turf by burrowing, and was very cleanly
159	in its habits, I should imagine it might prove a convenient substitute
159	for the common rabbit in gentlemen's parks.
159	
159	We also saw on our way the trunk of a tree barked in long strips
159	and splintered deeply.  Montgomery called my attention to this.
159	""Not to claw bark of trees, _that_ is the Law,"" he said.
159	""Much some of them care for it!""  It was after this, I think, that we
159	met the Satyr and the Ape-man. The Satyr was a gleam of classical memory
159	on the part of Moreau,--his face ovine in expression, like the coarser
159	Hebrew type; his voice a harsh bleat, his nether extremities Satanic.
159	He was gnawing the husk of a pod-like fruit as he passed us.
159	Both of them saluted Montgomery.
159	
159	""Hail,"" said they, ""to the Other with the Whip!""
159	
159	""There's a Third with a Whip now,"" said Montgomery.  ""So you'd
159	better mind!""
159	
159	""Was he not made?"" said the Ape-man. ""He said--he said he was made.""
159	
159	The Satyr-man looked curiously at me.  ""The Third with the Whip,
159	he that walks weeping into the sea, has a thin white face.""
159	
159	""He has a thin long whip,"" said Montgomery.
159	
159	""Yesterday he bled and wept,"" said the Satyr.  ""You never bleed nor weep.
159	The Master does not bleed or weep.""
159	
159	""Ollendorffian beggar!"" said Montgomery, ""you'll bleed and weep
159	if you don't look out!""
159	
159	""He has five fingers, he is a five-man like me,"" said the Ape-man.
159	
159	""Come along, Prendick,"" said Montgomery, taking my arm; and I went
159	on with him.
159	
159	The Satyr and the Ape-man stood watching us and making other remarks
159	to each other.
159	
159	""He says nothing,"" said the Satyr.  ""Men have voices.""
159	
159	""Yesterday he asked me of things to eat,"" said the Ape-man. ""He
159	did not know.""
159	
159	Then they spoke inaudible things, and I heard the Satyr laughing.
159	
159	It was on our way back that we came upon the dead rabbit.
159	The red body of the wretched little beast was rent to pieces, many of
159	the ribs stripped white, and the backbone indisputably gnawed.
159	
159	At that Montgomery stopped.  ""Good God!"" said he, stooping down,
159	and picking up some of the crushed vertebrae to examine them more closely.
159	""Good God!"" he repeated, ""what can this mean?""
159	
159	""Some carnivore of yours has remembered its old habits,""
159	I said after a pause.  ""This backbone has been bitten through.""
159	
159	He stood staring, with his face white and his lip pulled askew.
159	""I don't like this,"" he said slowly.
159	
159	""I saw something of the same kind,"" said I, ""the first day I came here.""
159	
159	""The devil you did!  What was it?""
159	
159	""A rabbit with its head twisted off.""
159	
159	""The day you came here?""
159	
159	""The day I came here.  In the undergrowth at the back of the enclosure,
159	when I went out in the evening.  The head was completely wrung off.""
159	
159	He gave a long, low whistle.
159	
159	""And what is more, I have an idea which of your brutes did the thing.
159	It's only a suspicion, you know.  Before I came on the rabbit I saw one
159	of your monsters drinking in the stream.""
159	
159	""Sucking his drink?""
159	
159	""Yes.""
159	
159	""'Not to suck your drink; that is the Law.'  Much the brutes care
159	for the Law, eh? when Moreau's not about!""
159	
159	""It was the brute who chased me.""
159	
159	""Of course,"" said Montgomery; ""it's just the way with carnivores.
159	After a kill, they drink.  It's the taste of blood, you know.--What
159	was the brute like?"" he continued.  ""Would you know him again?""
159	He glanced about us, standing astride over the mess of dead rabbit,
159	his eyes roving among the shadows and screens of greenery,
159	the lurking-places and ambuscades of the forest that bounded us in.
159	""The taste of blood,"" he said again.
159	
159	He took out his revolver, examined the cartridges in it and replaced it.
159	Then he began to pull at his dropping lip.
159	
159	""I think I should know the brute again,"" I said.  ""I stunned him.
159	He ought to have a handsome bruise on the forehead of him.""
159	
159	""But then we have to _prove_ that he killed the rabbit,"" said
159	Montgomery. ""I wish I'd never brought the things here.""
159	
159	I should have gone on, but he stayed there thinking over the mangled
159	rabbit in a puzzle-headed way.  As it was, I went to such a distance
159	that the rabbit's remains were hidden.
159	
159	""Come on!"" I said.
159	
159	Presently he woke up and came towards me.  ""You see,"" he said,
159	almost in a whisper, ""they are all supposed to have a fixed idea
159	against eating anything that runs on land.  If some brute has
159	by any accident tasted blood--""
159	
159	We went on some way in silence.  ""I wonder what can have happened,""
159	he said to himself.  Then, after a pause again:  ""I did a foolish
159	thing the other day.  That servant of mine--I showed him how to skin
159	and cook a rabbit.  It's odd--I saw him licking his hands--It never
159	occurred to me.""
159	
159	Then:  ""We must put a stop to this.  I must tell Moreau.""
159	
159	He could think of nothing else on our homeward journey.
159	
159	Moreau took the matter even more seriously than Montgomery, and I
159	need scarcely say that I was affected by their evident consternation.
159	
159	""We must make an example,"" said Moreau.  ""I've no doubt in my own
159	mind that the Leopard-man was the sinner.  But how can we prove it?
159	I wish, Montgomery, you had kept your taste for meat in hand, and gone
159	without these exciting novelties.  We may find ourselves in a mess yet,
159	through it.""
159	
159	""I was a silly ass,"" said Montgomery.  ""But the thing's done now;
159	and you said I might have them, you know.""
159	
159	""We must see to the thing at once,"" said Moreau.  ""I suppose
159	if anything should turn up, M'ling can take care of himself?""
159	
159	""I'm not so sure of M'ling,"" said Montgomery.  ""I think I ought
159	to know him.""
159	
159	In the afternoon, Moreau, Montgomery, myself, and M'ling went
159	across the island to the huts in the ravine.  We three were armed;
159	M'ling carried the little hatchet he used in chopping firewood,
159	and some coils of wire.  Moreau had a huge cowherd's horn slung over
159	his shoulder.
159	
159	""You will see a gathering of the Beast People,"" said Montgomery.
159	""It is a pretty sight!""
159	
159	Moreau said not a word on the way, but the expression of his heavy,
159	white-fringed face was grimly set.
159	
159	We crossed the ravine down which smoked the stream of hot water,
159	and followed the winding pathway through the canebrakes
159	until we reached a wide area covered over with a thick,
159	powdery yellow substance which I believe was sulphur.
159	Above the shoulder of a weedy bank the sea glittered.  We came to a kind
159	of shallow natural amphitheatre, and here the four of us halted.
