159	Then Moreau sounded the horn, and broke the sleeping stillness
159	of the tropical afternoon.  He must have had strong lungs.
159	The hooting note rose and rose amidst its echoes, to at last an
159	ear-penetrating intensity.
159	
159	""Ah!"" said Moreau, letting the curved instrument fall to his side again.
159	
159	Immediately there was a crashing through the yellow canes,
159	and a sound of voices from the dense green jungle that marked
159	the morass through which I had run on the previous day.
159	Then at three or four points on the edge of the sulphurous area
159	appeared the grotesque forms of the Beast People hurrying towards us.
159	I could not help a creeping horror, as I perceived first one and then
159	another trot out from the trees or reeds and come shambling along
159	over the hot dust.  But Moreau and Montgomery stood calmly enough;
159	and, perforce, I stuck beside them.
159	
159	First to arrive was the Satyr, strangely unreal for all that he cast
159	a shadow and tossed the dust with his hoofs.  After him from
159	the brake came a monstrous lout, a thing of horse and rhinoceros,
159	chewing a straw as it came; then appeared the Swine-woman
159	and two Wolf-women; then the Fox-bear witch, with her red eyes
159	in her peaked red face, and then others,--all hurrying eagerly.
159	As they came forward they began to cringe towards Moreau and chant,
159	quite regardless of one another, fragments of the latter half
159	of the litany of the Law,--""His is the Hand that wounds;
159	His is the Hand that heals,"" and so forth.  As soon as they had
159	approached within a distance of perhaps thirty yards they halted,
159	and bowing on knees and elbows began flinging the white dust upon
159	their heads.
159	
159	Imagine the scene if you can!  We three blue-clad men, with our
159	misshapen black-faced attendant, standing in a wide expanse
159	of sunlit yellow dust under the blazing blue sky, and surrounded
159	by this circle of crouching and gesticulating monstrosities,--some
159	almost human save in their subtle expression and gestures,
159	some like cripples, some so strangely distorted as to resemble nothing
159	but the denizens of our wildest dreams; and, beyond, the reedy
159	lines of a canebrake in one direction, a dense tangle of palm-trees
159	on the other, separating us from the ravine with the huts,
159	and to the north the hazy horizon of the Pacific Ocean.
159	
159	""Sixty-two, sixty-three,"" counted Moreau.  ""There are four more.""
159	
159	""I do not see the Leopard-man,"" said I.
159	
159	Presently Moreau sounded the great horn again, and at the sound
159	of it all the Beast People writhed and grovelled in the dust.
159	Then, slinking out of the canebrake, stooping near the ground
159	and trying to join the dust-throwing circle behind Moreau's back,
159	came the Leopard-man. The last of the Beast People to arrive was the little
159	Ape-man. The earlier animals, hot and weary with their grovelling,
159	shot vicious glances at him.
159	
159	""Cease!"" said Moreau, in his firm, loud voice; and the Beast People
159	sat back upon their hams and rested from their worshipping.
159	
159	""Where is the Sayer of the Law?"" said Moreau, and the hairy-grey
159	monster bowed his face in the dust.
159	
159	""Say the words!"" said Moreau.
159	
159	Forthwith all in the kneeling assembly, swaying from side to side
159	and dashing up the sulphur with their hands,--first the right hand
159	and a puff of dust, and then the left,--began once more to chant
159	their strange litany.  When they reached, ""Not to eat Flesh or Fish,
159	that is the Law,"" Moreau held up his lank white hand.
159	
159	""Stop!"" he cried, and there fell absolute silence upon them all.
159	
159	I think they all knew and dreaded what was coming.
159	I looked round at their strange faces.  When I saw their wincing
159	attitudes and the furtive dread in their bright eyes, I wondered
159	that I had ever believed them to be men.
159	
159	""That Law has been broken!"" said Moreau.
159	
159	""None escape,"" from the faceless creature with the silvery hair.
159	""None escape,"" repeated the kneeling circle of Beast People.
159	
159	""Who is he?"" cried Moreau, and looked round at their faces,
159	cracking his whip.  I fancied the Hyena-swine looked dejected,
159	so too did the Leopard-man. Moreau stopped, facing this creature,
159	who cringed towards him with the memory and dread of infinite torment.
159	
159	""Who is he?"" repeated Moreau, in a voice of thunder.
159	
159	""Evil is he who breaks the Law,"" chanted the Sayer of the Law.
159	
159	Moreau looked into the eyes of the Leopard-man, and seemed to be
159	dragging the very soul out of the creature.
159	
159	""Who breaks the Law--"" said Moreau, taking his eyes off his victim,
159	and turning towards us (it seemed to me there was a touch of exultation
159	in his voice).
159	
159	""Goes back to the House of Pain,"" they all clamoured,--""goes back
159	to the House of Pain, O Master!""
159	
159	""Back to the House of Pain,--back to the House of Pain,""
159	gabbled the Ape-man, as though the idea was sweet to him.
159	
159	""Do you hear?"" said Moreau, turning back to the criminal,
159	""my friend--Hullo!""
159	
159	For the Leopard-man, released from Moreau's eye, had risen straight
159	from his knees, and now, with eyes aflame and his huge feline tusks
159	flashing out from under his curling lips, leapt towards his tormentor.
159	I am convinced that only the madness of unendurable fear could have
159	prompted this attack.  The whole circle of threescore monsters seemed
159	to rise about us.  I drew my revolver.  The two figures collided.
159	I saw Moreau reeling back from the Leopard-man's blow.  There was a
159	furious yelling and howling all about us.  Every one was moving rapidly.
159	For a moment I thought it was a general revolt.  The furious face
159	of the Leopard-man flashed by mine, with M'ling close in pursuit.
159	I saw the yellow eyes of the Hyena-swine blazing with excitement,
159	his attitude as if he were half resolved to attack me.
159	The Satyr, too, glared at me over the Hyena-swine's hunched shoulders.
159	I heard the crack of Moreau's pistol, and saw the pink flash
159	dart across the tumult.  The whole crowd seemed to swing round
159	in the direction of the glint of fire, and I too was swung round
159	by the magnetism of the movement.  In another second I was running,
159	one of a tumultuous shouting crowd, in pursuit of the escaping
159	Leopard-man.
159	
159	That is all I can tell definitely.  I saw the Leopard-man strike Moreau,
159	and then everything spun about me until I was running headlong.
159	M'ling was ahead, close in pursuit of the fugitive.  Behind, their tongues
159	already lolling out, ran the Wolf-women in great leaping strides.
159	The Swine folk followed, squealing with excitement, and the two
159	Bull-men in their swathings of white.  Then came Moreau in a
159	cluster of the Beast People, his wide-brimmed straw hat blown off,
159	his revolver in hand, and his lank white hair streaming out.
159	The Hyena-swine ran beside me, keeping pace with me and glancing furtively
159	at me out of his feline eyes, and the others came pattering and shouting
159	behind us.
159	
159	The Leopard-man went bursting his way through the long canes,
159	which sprang back as he passed, and rattled in M'ling's face.
159	We others in the rear found a trampled path for us when we reached
159	the brake.  The chase lay through the brake for perhaps a quarter
159	of a mile, and then plunged into a dense thicket, which retarded
159	our movements exceedingly, though we went through it in a crowd
159	together,--fronds flicking into our faces, ropy creepers catching
159	us under the chin or gripping our ankles, thorny plants hooking into
159	and tearing cloth and flesh together.
159	
159	""He has gone on all-fours through this,"" panted Moreau, now just
159	ahead of me.
159	
159	""None escape,"" said the Wolf-bear, laughing into my face with
159	the exultation of hunting.  We burst out again among rocks,
159	and saw the quarry ahead running lightly on all-fours and snarling
159	at us over his shoulder.  At that the Wolf Folk howled with delight.
159	The Thing was still clothed, and at a distance its face still seemed human;
159	but the carriage of its four limbs was feline, and the furtive
159	droop of its shoulder was distinctly that of a hunted animal.
159	It leapt over some thorny yellow-flowering bushes, and was hidden.
159	M'ling was halfway across the space.
159	
159	Most of us now had lost the first speed of the chase, and had fallen
159	into a longer and steadier stride.  I saw as we traversed the open
159	that the pursuit was now spreading from a column into a line.
159	The Hyena-swine still ran close to me, watching me as it ran,
159	every now and then puckering its muzzle with a snarling laugh.
159	At the edge of the rocks the Leopard-man, realising that he was
159	making for the projecting cape upon which he had stalked me
159	on the night of my arrival, had doubled in the undergrowth;
159	but Montgomery had seen the manoeuvre, and turned him again.
159	So, panting, tumbling against rocks, torn by brambles, impeded by
159	ferns and reeds, I helped to pursue the Leopard-man who had broken
159	the Law, and the Hyena-swine ran, laughing savagely, by my side.
159	I staggered on, my head reeling and my heart beating against my ribs,
159	tired almost to death, and yet not daring to lose sight of the chase
159	lest I should be left alone with this horrible companion.
159	I staggered on in spite of infinite fatigue and the dense heat of the
159	tropical afternoon.
159	
159	At last the fury of the hunt slackened.  We had pinned the wretched
159	brute into a corner of the island.  Moreau, whip in hand, marshalled us
159	all into an irregular line, and we advanced now slowly, shouting to one
159	another as we advanced and tightening the cordon about our victim.
159	He lurked noiseless and invisible in the bushes through which I
159	had run from him during that midnight pursuit.
159	
159	""Steady!"" cried Moreau, ""steady!"" as the ends of the line crept
159	round the tangle of undergrowth and hemmed the brute in.
159	
159	""Ware a rush!"" came the voice of Montgomery from beyond the thicket.
159	
159	I was on the slope above the bushes; Montgomery and Moreau beat
159	along the beach beneath.  Slowly we pushed in among the fretted
159	network of branches and leaves.  The quarry was silent.
159	
159	""Back to the House of Pain, the House of Pain, the House of Pain!""
159	yelped the voice of the Ape-man, some twenty yards to the right.
159	
159	When I heard that, I forgave the poor wretch all the fear he had
159	inspired in me.  I heard the twigs snap and the boughs swish aside
159	before the heavy tread of the Horse-rhinoceros upon my right.
159	Then suddenly through a polygon of green, in the half darkness
159	under the luxuriant growth, I saw the creature we were hunting.
159	I halted.  He was crouched together into the smallest possible compass,
159	his luminous green eyes turned over his shoulder regarding me.
159	
159	It may seem a strange contradiction in me,--I cannot explain the
159	fact,--but now, seeing the creature there in a perfectly animal
159	attitude, with the light gleaming in its eyes and its imperfectly
159	human face distorted with terror, I realised again the fact of its
159	humanity.  In another moment other of its pursuers would see it,
159	and it would be overpowered and captured, to experience once more
159	the horrible tortures of the enclosure.  Abruptly I slipped out
159	my revolver, aimed between its terror-struck eyes, and fired.
159	As I did so, the Hyena-swine saw the Thing, and flung itself upon
159	it with an eager cry, thrusting thirsty teeth into its neck.
159	All about me the green masses of the thicket were swaying and cracking
159	as the Beast People came rushing together.  One face and then
159	another appeared.
159	
159	""Don't kill it, Prendick!"" cried Moreau.  ""Don't kill it!""
159	and I saw him stooping as he pushed through under the fronds
159	of the big ferns.
159	
159	In another moment he had beaten off the Hyena-swine with the handle of
159	his whip, and he and Montgomery were keeping away the excited carnivorous
159	Beast People, and particularly M'ling, from the still quivering body.
159	The hairy-grey Thing came sniffing at the corpse under my arm.
159	The other animals, in their animal ardour, jostled me to get a
159	nearer view.
159	
159	""Confound you, Prendick!"" said Moreau.  ""I wanted him.""
159	
159	""I'm sorry,"" said I, though I was not.  ""It was the impulse
159	of the moment.""  I felt sick with exertion and excitement.
159	Turning, I pushed my way out of the crowding Beast People and went
159	on alone up the slope towards the higher part of the headland.
159	Under the shouted directions of Moreau I heard the three white-swathed
159	Bull-men begin dragging the victim down towards the water.
159	
159	It was easy now for me to be alone.  The Beast People manifested a quite
159	human curiosity about the dead body, and followed it in a thick knot,
159	sniffing and growling at it as the Bull-men dragged it down the beach.
159	I went to the headland and watched the bull-men, black against
159	the evening sky as they carried the weighted dead body out to sea;
159	and like a wave across my mind came the realisation of the unspeakable
159	aimlessness of things upon the island.  Upon the beach among
159	the rocks beneath me were the Ape-man, the Hyena-swine, and several
159	other of the Beast People, standing about Montgomery and Moreau.
159	They were all still intensely excited, and all overflowing with noisy
159	expressions of their loyalty to the Law; yet I felt an absolute
159	assurance in my own mind that the Hyena-swine was implicated
159	in the rabbit-killing. A strange persuasion came upon me, that,
159	save for the grossness of the line, the grotesqueness of the forms,
159	I had here before me the whole balance of human life in miniature,
159	the whole interplay of instinct, reason, and fate in its simplest form.
159	The Leopard-man had happened to go under:  that was all the difference.
159	Poor brute!
159	
159	Poor brutes!  I began to see the viler aspect of Moreau's cruelty.
159	I had not thought before of the pain and trouble that came
159	to these poor victims after they had passed from Moreau's hands.
159	I had shivered only at the days of actual torment in the enclosure.
159	But now that seemed to me the lesser part.  Before, they had
159	been beasts, their instincts fitly adapted to their surroundings,
159	and happy as living things may be.  Now they stumbled in the shackles
159	of humanity, lived in a fear that never died, fretted by a law they
159	could not understand; their mock-human existence, begun in an agony,
159	was one long internal struggle, one long dread of Moreau--and for what?
159	It was the wantonness of it that stirred me.
159	
159	Had Moreau had any intelligible object, I could have sympathised at
159	least a little with him.  I am not so squeamish about pain as that.
159	I could have forgiven him a little even, had his motive been only hate.
159	But he was so irresponsible, so utterly careless!  His curiosity,
159	his mad, aimless investigations, drove him on; and the Things were
159	thrown out to live a year or so, to struggle and blunder and suffer,
159	and at last to die painfully.  They were wretched in themselves;
159	the old animal hate moved them to trouble one another; the Law held
159	them back from a brief hot struggle and a decisive end to their
159	natural animosities.
159	
159	In those days my fear of the Beast People went the way of my personal
159	fear for Moreau.  I fell indeed into a morbid state, deep and enduring,
159	and alien to fear, which has left permanent scars upon my mind.
159	I must confess that I lost faith in the sanity of the world
159	when I saw it suffering the painful disorder of this island.
159	A blind Fate, a vast pitiless mechanism, seemed to cut and
159	shape the fabric of existence and I, Moreau (by his passion
159	for research), Montgomery (by his passion for drink), the Beast
159	People with their instincts and mental restrictions, were torn
159	and crushed, ruthlessly, inevitably, amid the infinite complexity
159	of its incessant wheels.  But this condition did not come all at once:
159	I think indeed that I anticipate a little in speaking of
159	it now.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XVII.  A CATASTROPHE.
159	
159	
159	SCARCELY six weeks passed before I had lost every feeling but
159	dislike and abhorrence for this infamous experiment of Moreau's.
159	My one idea was to get away from these horrible caricatures of my
159	Maker's image, back to the sweet and wholesome intercourse of men.
159	My fellow-creatures, from whom I was thus separated, began to assume
159	idyllic virtue and beauty in my memory.  My first friendship with
159	Montgomery did not increase.  His long separation from humanity,
159	his secret vice of drunkenness, his evident sympathy with the Beast People,
159	tainted him to me.  Several times I let him go alone among them.
159	I avoided intercourse with them in every possible way.
159	I spent an increasing proportion of my time upon the beach,
159	looking for some liberating sail that never appeared,--until one day
159	there fell upon us an appalling disaster, which put an altogether
159	different aspect upon my strange surroundings.
159	
159	It was about seven or eight weeks after my landing,--rather more,
159	I think, though I had not troubled to keep account of the time,--when
159	this catastrophe occurred.  It happened in the early morning--I
159	should think about six.  I had risen and breakfasted early, having
159	been aroused by the noise of three Beast Men carrying wood into the
159	enclosure.
159	
159	After breakfast I went to the open gateway of the enclosure,
159	and stood there smoking a cigarette and enjoying the freshness
159	of the early morning.  Moreau presently came round the corner
159	of the enclosure and greeted me.  He passed by me, and I heard him
159	behind me unlock and enter his laboratory.  So indurated was I
159	at that time to the abomination of the place, that I heard without
159	a touch of emotion the puma victim begin another day of torture.
159	It met its persecutor with a shriek, almost exactly like that of an
159	angry virago.
159	
159	Then suddenly something happened,--I do not know what,
159	to this day.  I heard a short, sharp cry behind me, a fall,
159	and turning saw an awful face rushing upon me,--not human,
159	not animal, but hellish, brown, seamed with red branching scars,
159	red drops starting out upon it, and the lidless eyes ablaze.
159	I threw up my arm to defend myself from the blow that flung
159	me headlong with a broken forearm; and the great monster,
159	swathed in lint and with red-stained bandages fluttering about it,
159	leapt over me and passed.  I rolled over and over down the beach,
159	tried to sit up, and collapsed upon my broken arm.  Then Moreau appeared,
159	his massive white face all the more terrible for the blood that
159	trickled from his forehead.  He carried a revolver in one hand.
159	He scarcely glanced at me, but rushed off at once in pursuit of
159	the puma.
159	
159	I tried the other arm and sat up.  The muffled figure in front ran
159	in great striding leaps along the beach, and Moreau followed her.
159	She turned her head and saw him, then doubling abruptly made
159	for the bushes.  She gained upon him at every stride.  I saw her
159	plunge into them, and Moreau, running slantingly to intercept her,
159	fired and missed as she disappeared.  Then he too vanished
159	in the green confusion.  I stared after them, and then the pain
159	in my arm flamed up, and with a groan I staggered to my feet.
159	Montgomery appeared in the doorway, dressed, and with his revolver in
159	his hand.
159	
159	""Great God, Prendick!"" he said, not noticing that I was hurt,
159	""that brute's loose!  Tore the fetter out of the wall!
159	Have you seen them?""  Then sharply, seeing I gripped my arm,
159	""What's the matter?""
159	
159	""I was standing in the doorway,"" said I.
159	
159	He came forward and took my arm.  ""Blood on the sleeve,""
159	said he, and rolled back the flannel.  He pocketed his weapon,
159	felt my arm about painfully, and led me inside.  ""Your arm
159	is broken,"" he said, and then, ""Tell me exactly how it
159	happened--what happened?""
159	
159	I told him what I had seen; told him in broken sentences,
159	with gasps of pain between them, and very dexterously and swiftly
159	he bound my arm meanwhile.  He slung it from my shoulder,
159	stood back and looked at me.
159	
159	""You'll do,"" he said.  ""And now?""
159	
159	He thought.  Then he went out and locked the gates of the enclosure.
159	He was absent some time.
159	
159	I was chiefly concerned about my arm.  The incident seemed merely
159	one more of many horrible things.  I sat down in the deck chair,
159	and I must admit swore heartily at the island.  The first dull
159	feeling of injury in my arm had already given way to a burning pain
159	when Montgomery reappeared.  His face was rather pale, and he showed
159	more of his lower gums than ever.
159	
159	""I can neither see nor hear anything of him,"" he said.
159	""I've been thinking he may want my help.""  He stared at me with
159	his expressionless eyes.  ""That was a strong brute,"" he said.
159	""It simply wrenched its fetter out of the wall.""  He went to the window,
159	then to the door, and there turned to me.  ""I shall go after him,""
159	he said.  ""There's another revolver I can leave with you.
159	To tell you the truth, I feel anxious somehow.""
159	
159	He obtained the weapon, and put it ready to my hand on the table;
159	then went out, leaving a restless contagion in the air.
159	I did not sit long after he left, but took the revolver in hand and went
159	to the doorway.
159	
159	The morning was as still as death.  Not a whisper of wind was stirring;
159	the sea was like polished glass, the sky empty, the beach desolate.
159	In my half-excited, half-feverish state, this stillness of things
159	oppressed me.  I tried to whistle, and the tune died away.
159	I swore again,--the second time that morning.  Then I went to the corner
159	of the enclosure and stared inland at the green bush that had
159	swallowed up Moreau and Montgomery.  When would they return, and how?
159	Then far away up the beach a little grey Beast Man appeared,
159	ran down to the water's edge and began splashing about.
159	I strolled back to the doorway, then to the corner again,
159	and so began pacing to and fro like a sentinel upon duty.
159	Once I was arrested by the distant voice of Montgomery bawling,
159	""Coo-ee--Moreau!""  My arm became less painful, but very hot.
159	I got feverish and thirsty.  My shadow grew shorter.
159	I watched the distant figure until it went away again.  Would Moreau
159	and Montgomery never return?  Three sea-birds began fighting for some
159	stranded treasure.
159	
159	Then from far away behind the enclosure I heard a pistol-shot. A
159	long silence, and then came another.  Then a yelling cry nearer,
159	and another dismal gap of silence.  My unfortunate imagination
159	set to work to torment me.  Then suddenly a shot close by.
159	I went to the corner, startled, and saw Montgomery,--his face scarlet,
159	his hair disordered, and the knee of his trousers torn.
159	His face expressed profound consternation.  Behind him slouched
159	the Beast Man, M'ling, and round M'ling's jaws were some queer
159	dark stains.
159	
159	""Has he come?"" said Montgomery.
159	
159	""Moreau?"" said I. ""No.""
159	
159	""My God!""  The man was panting, almost sobbing.  ""Go back in,"" he said,
159	taking my arm.  ""They're mad.  They're all rushing about mad.  What can
159	have happened?  I don't know.  I'll tell you, when my breath comes.
159	Where's some brandy?""
159	
159	Montgomery limped before me into the room and sat down in the deck chair.
159	M'ling flung himself down just outside the doorway and began
159	panting like a dog.  I got Montgomery some brandy-and-water. He
159	sat staring in front of him at nothing, recovering his breath.
159	After some minutes he began to tell me what had happened.
159	
159	He had followed their track for some way.  It was plain enough at
159	first on account of the crushed and broken bushes, white rags torn
159	from the puma's bandages, and occasional smears of blood on the leaves
159	of the shrubs and undergrowth.  He lost the track, however, on the stony
159	ground beyond the stream where I had seen the Beast Man drinking,
159	and went wandering aimlessly westward shouting Moreau's name.
159	Then M'ling had come to him carrying a light hatchet.  M'ling had seen
159	nothing of the puma affair; had been felling wood, and heard him calling.
159	They went on shouting together.  Two Beast Men came crouching
159	and peering at them through the undergrowth, with gestures and a
159	furtive carriage that alarmed Montgomery by their strangeness.
159	He hailed them, and they fled guiltily.  He stopped shouting
159	after that, and after wandering some time farther in an undecided way,
159	determined to visit the huts.
159	
159	He found the ravine deserted.
159	
159	Growing more alarmed every minute, he began to retrace his steps.
159	Then it was he encountered the two Swine-men I had seen dancing
159	on the night of my arrival; blood-stained they were about the mouth,
159	and intensely excited.  They came crashing through the ferns,
159	and stopped with fierce faces when they saw him.  He cracked his whip
159	in some trepidation, and forthwith they rushed at him.  Never before
159	had a Beast Man dared to do that.  One he shot through the head;
159	M'ling flung himself upon the other, and the two rolled grappling.
159	M'ling got his brute under and with his teeth in its throat,
159	and Montgomery shot that too as it struggled in M'ling's grip.
159	He had some difficulty in inducing M'ling to come on with him.
159	Thence they had hurried back to me.  On the way, M'ling had suddenly
159	rushed into a thicket and driven out an under-sized Ocelot-man,
159	also blood-stained, and lame through a wound in the foot.
159	This brute had run a little way and then turned savagely at bay,
159	and Montgomery--with a certain wantonness, I thought--had shot
159	him.
159	
159	""What does it all mean?"" said I.
159	
159	He shook his head, and turned once more to the brandy.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XVIII.  THE FINDING OF MOREAU.
159	
159	
159	WHEN I saw Montgomery swallow a third dose of brandy, I took it
159	upon myself to interfere.  He was already more than half fuddled.
159	I told him that some serious thing must have happened to
159	Moreau by this time, or he would have returned before this,
159	and that it behoved us to ascertain what that catastrophe was.
159	Montgomery raised some feeble objections, and at last agreed.
159	We had some food, and then all three of us started.
159	
159	It is possibly due to the tension of my mind, at the time,
159	but even now that start into the hot stillness of the tropical
159	afternoon is a singularly vivid impression.  M'ling went first,
159	his shoulder hunched, his strange black head moving with quick
159	starts as he peered first on this side of the way and then on that.
159	He was unarmed; his axe he had dropped when he encountered
159	the Swine-man. Teeth were _his_ weapons, when it came to fighting.
159	Montgomery followed with stumbling footsteps, his hands in his pockets,
159	his face downcast; he was in a state of muddled sullenness
159	with me on account of the brandy.  My left arm was in a sling
159	(it was lucky it was my left), and I carried my revolver in my right.
159	Soon we traced a narrow path through the wild luxuriance of
159	the island, going northwestward; and presently M'ling stopped,
159	and became rigid with watchfulness.  Montgomery almost staggered
159	into him, and then stopped too.  Then, listening intently,
159	we heard coming through the trees the sound of voices and footsteps
159	approaching us.
159	
159	""He is dead,"" said a deep, vibrating voice.
159	
159	""He is not dead; he is not dead,"" jabbered another.
159	
159	""We saw, we saw,"" said several voices.
159	
159	""Hullo!"" suddenly shouted Montgomery, ""Hullo, there!""
159	
159	""Confound you!"" said I, and gripped my pistol.
159	
159	There was a silence, then a crashing among the interlacing vegetation,
159	first here, then there, and then half-a-dozen faces appeared,--strange
159	faces, lit by a strange light.  M'ling made a growling
159	noise in his throat.  I recognised the Ape-man: I had indeed
159	already identified his voice, and two of the white-swathed
159	brown-featured creatures I had seen in Montgomery's boat.
159	With these were the two dappled brutes and that grey, horribly crooked
159	creature who said the Law, with grey hair streaming down its cheeks,
159	heavy grey eyebrows, and grey locks pouring off from a central
159	parting upon its sloping forehead,--a heavy, faceless thing,
159	with strange red eyes, looking at us curiously from amidst
159	the green.
159	
159	For a space no one spoke.  Then Montgomery hiccoughed, ""Who--said
159	he was dead?""
159	
159	The Monkey-man looked guiltily at the hairy-grey Thing.  ""He is dead,""
159	said this monster.  ""They saw.""
159	
159	There was nothing threatening about this detachment, at any rate.
159	They seemed awestricken and puzzled.
159	
159	""Where is he?"" said Montgomery.
159	
159	""Beyond,"" and the grey creature pointed.
159	
159	""Is there a Law now?"" asked the Monkey-man. ""Is it still to be this
159	and that?  Is he dead indeed?""
159	
159	""Is there a Law?"" repeated the man in white.  ""Is there a Law,
159	thou Other with the Whip?""
159	
159	""He is dead,"" said the hairy-grey Thing.  And they all stood
159	watching us.
159	
159	""Prendick,"" said Montgomery, turning his dull eyes to me.
159	""He's dead, evidently.""
159	
159	I had been standing behind him during this colloquy.
159	I began to see how things lay with them.  I suddenly stepped in front
159	of Montgomery and lifted up my voice:--""Children of the Law,""
159	I said, ""he is _not_ dead!""  M'ling turned his sharp eyes on me.
159	""He has changed his shape; he has changed his body,"" I went on.
159	""For a time you will not see him.  He is--there,"" I pointed upward,
159	""where he can watch you.  You cannot see him, but he can see you.
159	Fear the Law!""
159	
159	I looked at them squarely.  They flinched.
159	
159	""He is great, he is good,"" said the Ape-man, peering fearfully
159	upward among the dense trees.
159	
159	""And the other Thing?""  I demanded.
159	
159	""The Thing that bled, and ran screaming and sobbing,--that is dead too,""
159	said the grey Thing, still regarding me.
159	
159	""That's well,"" grunted Montgomery.
159	
159	""The Other with the Whip--"" began the grey Thing.
159	
159	""Well?"" said I.
159	
159	""Said he was dead.""
159	
159	But Montgomery was still sober enough to understand my motive in denying
159	Moreau's death.  ""He is not dead,"" he said slowly, ""not dead at all.
159	No more dead than I am.""
159	
159	""Some,"" said I, ""have broken the Law:  they will die.  Some have died.
159	Show us now where his old body lies,--the body he cast away because
159	he had no more need of it.""
159	
159	""It is this way, Man who walked in the Sea,"" said the grey Thing.
159	
159	And with these six creatures guiding us, we went through the tumult
159	of ferns and creepers and tree-stems towards the northwest.
159	Then came a yelling, a crashing among the branches, and a little
159	pink homunculus rushed by us shrieking.  Immediately after appeared
159	a monster in headlong pursuit, blood-bedabbled, who was amongst us
159	almost before he could stop his career.  The grey Thing leapt aside.
159	M'ling, with a snarl, flew at it, and was struck aside.  Montgomery fired
159	and missed, bowed his head, threw up his arm, and turned to run.
159	I fired, and the Thing still came on; fired again, point-blank, into
159	its ugly face.  I saw its features vanish in a flash:  its face was
159	driven in.  Yet it passed me, gripped Montgomery, and holding him,
159	fell headlong beside him and pulled him sprawling upon itself in its
159	death-agony.
159	
159	I found myself alone with M'ling, the dead brute, and the prostrate man.
159	Montgomery raised himself slowly and stared in a muddled way at
159	the shattered Beast Man beside him.  It more than half sobered him.
159	He scrambled to his feet.  Then I saw the grey Thing returning cautiously
159	through the trees.
159	
159	""See,"" said I, pointing to the dead brute, ""is the Law not alive?
159	This came of breaking the Law.""
159	
159	He peered at the body.  ""He sends the Fire that kills,""
159	said he, in his deep voice, repeating part of the Ritual.
159	The others gathered round and stared for a space.
159	
159	At last we drew near the westward extremity of the island.
159	We came upon the gnawed and mutilated body of the puma,
159	its shoulder-bone smashed by a bullet, and perhaps twenty yards
159	farther found at last what we sought.  Moreau lay face downward
159	in a trampled space in a canebrake.  One hand was almost severed
159	at the wrist and his silvery hair was dabbled in blood.
159	His head had been battered in by the fetters of the puma.
159	The broken canes beneath him were smeared with blood.
159	His revolver we could not find.  Montgomery turned him over.
159	Resting at intervals, and with the help of the seven Beast People
159	(for he was a heavy man), we carried Moreau back to the enclosure.
159	The night was darkling.  Twice we heard unseen creatures howling
159	and shrieking past our little band, and once the little pink
159	sloth-creature appeared and stared at us, and vanished again.
159	But we were not attacked again.  At the gates of the enclosure
159	our company of Beast People left us, M'ling going with the rest.
159	We locked ourselves in, and then took Moreau's mangled
159	body into the yard and laid it upon a pile of brushwood.
159	Then we went into the laboratory and put an end to all we found living
159	there.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XIX.  MONTGOMERY'S ""BANK HOLIDAY.""
159	
159	
159	WHEN this was accomplished, and we had washed and eaten,
159	Montgomery and I went into my little room and seriously discussed
159	our position for the first time.  It was then near midnight.
159	He was almost sober, but greatly disturbed in his mind.
159	He had been strangely under the influence of Moreau's personality:
159	I do not think it had ever occurred to him that Moreau could die.
159	This disaster was the sudden collapse of the habits that had become part of
159	his nature in the ten or more monotonous years he had spent on the island.
159	He talked vaguely, answered my questions crookedly, wandered into
159	general questions.
159	
159	""This silly ass of a world,"" he said; ""what a muddle it all is!
159	I haven't had any life.  I wonder when it's going to begin.
159	Sixteen years being bullied by nurses and schoolmasters at
159	their own sweet will; five in London grinding hard at medicine,
159	bad food, shabby lodgings, shabby clothes, shabby vice, a blunder,--I
159	didn't know any better,--and hustled off to this beastly island.
159	Ten years here!  What's it all for, Prendick?  Are we bubbles blown by
159	a baby?""
159	
159	It was hard to deal with such ravings.  ""The thing we have to think
159	of now,"" said I, ""is how to get away from this island.""
159	
159	""What's the good of getting away?  I'm an outcast.
159	Where am _I_ to join on?  It's all very well for _you_, Prendick.
159	Poor old Moreau!  We can't leave him here to have his bones picked.
159	As it is--And besides, what will become of the decent part of the
159	Beast Folk?""
159	
159	""Well,"" said I, ""that will do to-morrow. I've been thinking we might make
159	the brushwood into a pyre and burn his body--and those other things.
159	Then what will happen with the Beast Folk?""
159	
159	""_I_ don't know.  I suppose those that were made of beasts of prey will
159	make silly asses of themselves sooner or later.  We can't massacre
159	the lot--can we?  I suppose that's what _your_ humanity would suggest?
159	But they'll change.  They are sure to change.""
159	
159	He talked thus inconclusively until at last I felt my temper going.
159	
159	""Damnation!"" he exclaimed at some petulance of mine; ""can't you see I'm
159	in a worse hole than you are?""  And he got up, and went for the brandy.
159	""Drink!"" he said returning, ""you logic-chopping, chalky-faced saint
159	of an atheist, drink!""
159	
159	""Not I,"" said I, and sat grimly watching his face under the yellow
159	paraffine flare, as he drank himself into a garrulous misery.
159	
159	I have a memory of infinite tedium.  He wandered into a maudlin
159	defence of the Beast People and of M'ling. M'ling, he said,
159	was the only thing that had ever really cared for him.
159	And suddenly an idea came to him.
159	
159	""I'm damned!"" said he, staggering to his feet and clutching
159	the brandy bottle.
159	
159	By some flash of intuition I knew what it was he intended.
159	""You don't give drink to that beast!""  I said, rising and facing him.
159	
159	""Beast!"" said he.  ""You're the beast.  He takes his liquor
159	like a Christian.  Come out of the way, Prendick!""
159	
159	""For God's sake,"" said I.
159	
159	""Get--out of the way!"" he roared, and suddenly whipped out his revolver.
159	
159	""Very well,"" said I, and stood aside, half-minded to fall upon him
159	as he put his hand upon the latch, but deterred by the thought
159	of my useless arm.  ""You've made a beast of yourself,--to the beasts
159	you may go.""
159	
159	He flung the doorway open, and stood half facing me between
159	the yellow lamp-light and the pallid glare of the moon;
159	his eye-sockets were blotches of black under his stubbly eyebrows.
159	
159	""You're a solemn prig, Prendick, a silly ass!  You're always fearing
159	and fancying.  We're on the edge of things.  I'm bound to cut my
159	throat to-morrow. I'm going to have a damned Bank Holiday to-night.""
159	He turned and went out into the moonlight.  ""M'ling!"" he cried;
159	""M'ling, old friend!""
159	
159	Three dim creatures in the silvery light came along the edge
159	of the wan beach,--one a white-wrapped creature, the other two
159	blotches of blackness following it.  They halted, staring.
159	Then I saw M'ling's hunched shoulders as he came round the corner
159	of the house.
159	
159	""Drink!"" cried Montgomery, ""drink, you brutes!  Drink and be men!
159	Damme, I'm the cleverest.  Moreau forgot this; this is the last touch.
159	Drink, I tell you!""  And waving the bottle in his hand he started
159	off at a kind of quick trot to the westward, M'ling ranging himself
159	between him and the three dim creatures who followed.
159	
159	I went to the doorway.  They were already indistinct in the mist
159	of the moonlight before Montgomery halted.  I saw him administer
159	a dose of the raw brandy to M'ling, and saw the five figures melt
159	into one vague patch.
159	
159	""Sing!""  I heard Montgomery shout,--""sing all together, 'Confound
159	old Prendick!'  That's right; now again, 'Confound old Prendick!'""
159	
159	The black group broke up into five separate figures,
159	and wound slowly away from me along the band of shining beach.
159	Each went howling at his own sweet will, yelping insults at me,
159	or giving whatever other vent this new inspiration of brandy demanded.
159	Presently I heard Montgomery's voice shouting, ""Right turn!""
159	and they passed with their shouts and howls into the blackness
159	of the landward trees.  Slowly, very slowly, they receded
159	into silence.
159	
159	The peaceful splendour of the night healed again.
159	The moon was now past the meridian and travelling down the west.
159	It was at its full, and very bright riding through the empty blue sky.
159	The shadow of the wall lay, a yard wide and of inky blackness, at my feet.
159	The eastward sea was a featureless grey, dark and mysterious;
159	and between the sea and the shadow the grey sands (of volcanic
159	glass and crystals) flashed and shone like a beach of diamonds.
159	Behind me the paraffine lamp flared hot and ruddy.
159	
159	Then I shut the door, locked it, and went into the enclosure where
159	Moreau lay beside his latest victims,--the staghounds and the llama
159	and some other wretched brutes,--with his massive face calm even
159	after his terrible death, and with the hard eyes open, staring at
159	the dead white moon above.  I sat down upon the edge of the sink,
159	and with my eyes upon that ghastly pile of silvery light and ominous
159	shadows began to turn over my plans.  In the morning I would gather
159	some provisions in the dingey, and after setting fire to the pyre
159	before me, push out into the desolation of the high sea once more.
159	I felt that for Montgomery there was no help; that he was, in truth,
159	half akin to these Beast Folk, unfitted for human kindred.
159	
159	I do not know how long I sat there scheming.  It must have been
159	an hour or so.  Then my planning was interrupted by the return of
159	Montgomery to my neighbourhood.  I heard a yelling from many throats,
159	a tumult of exultant cries passing down towards the beach,
159	whooping and howling, and excited shrieks that seemed to come to a stop
159	near the water's edge.  The riot rose and fell; I heard heavy blows
159	and the splintering smash of wood, but it did not trouble me then.
159	A discordant chanting began.
159	
159	My thoughts went back to my means of escape.  I got up, brought the lamp,
159	and went into a shed to look at some kegs I had seen there.
159	Then I became interested in the contents of some biscuit-tins, and
159	opened one.  I saw something out of the tail of my eye,--a red
159	figure,--and turned sharply.
159	
159	Behind me lay the yard, vividly black-and-white in the moonlight,
159	and the pile of wood and faggots on which Moreau and his mutilated
159	victims lay, one over another.  They seemed to be gripping one another
159	in one last revengeful grapple.  His wounds gaped, black as night,
159	and the blood that had dripped lay in black patches upon the sand.
159	Then I saw, without understanding, the cause of my phantom,--a
159	ruddy glow that came and danced and went upon the wall opposite.
159	I misinterpreted this, fancied it was a reflection of my
159	flickering lamp, and turned again to the stores in the shed.
159	I went on rummaging among them, as well as a one-armed man could,
159	finding this convenient thing and that, and putting them
159	aside for to-morrow's launch.  My movements were slow,
159	and the time passed quickly.  Insensibly the daylight crept
159	upon me.
159	
159	The chanting died down, giving place to a clamour; then it
159	began again, and suddenly broke into a tumult.  I heard cries of,
159	""More! more!"" a sound like quarrelling, and a sudden wild shriek.
159	The quality of the sounds changed so greatly that it arrested
159	my attention.  I went out into the yard and listened.
159	Then cutting like a knife across the confusion came the crack of
159	a revolver.
159	
159	I rushed at once through my room to the little doorway.
159	As I did so I heard some of the packing-cases behind me go sliding down
159	and smash together with a clatter of glass on the floor of the shed.
159	But I did not heed these.  I flung the door open and looked out.
159	
159	Up the beach by the boathouse a bonfire was burning, raining up
159	sparks into the indistinctness of the dawn.  Around this struggled
159	a mass of black figures.  I heard Montgomery call my name.
159	I began to run at once towards this fire, revolver in hand.  I saw the pink
159	tongue of Montgomery's pistol lick out once, close to the ground.
159	He was down.  I shouted with all my strength and fired into the air.
159	I heard some one cry, ""The Master!""  The knotted black struggle
159	broke into scattering units, the fire leapt and sank down.
159	The crowd of Beast People fled in sudden panic before me, up the beach.
159	In my excitement I fired at their retreating backs as they
159	disappeared among the bushes.  Then I turned to the black heaps upon
159	the ground.
159	
159	Montgomery lay on his back, with the hairy-grey Beast-man
159	sprawling across his body.  The brute was dead, but still
159	gripping Montgomery's throat with its curving claws.
159	Near by lay M'ling on his face and quite still, his neck bitten
159	open and the upper part of the smashed brandy-bottle in his hand.
159	Two other figures lay near the fire,--the one motionless, the other
159	groaning fitfully, every now and then raising its head slowly,
159	then dropping it again.
159	
159	I caught hold of the grey man and pulled him off Montgomery's body;
159	his claws drew down the torn coat reluctantly as I dragged him away.
159	Montgomery was dark in the face and scarcely breathing.  I splashed
159	sea-water on his face and pillowed his head on my rolled-up coat.
159	M'ling was dead.  The wounded creature by the fire--it was a Wolf-brute
159	with a bearded grey face--lay, I found, with the fore part of its
159	body upon the still glowing timber.  The wretched thing was injured
159	so dreadfully that in mercy I blew its brains out at once.
159	The other brute was one of the Bull-men swathed in white.
159	He too was dead.  The rest of the Beast People had vanished from
159	the beach.
159	
159	I went to Montgomery again and knelt beside him, cursing my ignorance
159	of medicine.  The fire beside me had sunk down, and only charred
159	beams of timber glowing at the central ends and mixed with a grey
159	ash of brushwood remained.  I wondered casually where Montgomery
159	had got his wood.  Then I saw that the dawn was upon us.
159	The sky had grown brighter, the setting moon was becoming pale
159	and opaque in the luminous blue of the day.  The sky to the eastward
159	was rimmed with red.
159	
159	Suddenly I heard a thud and a hissing behind me, and, looking round,
159	sprang to my feet with a cry of horror.  Against the warm dawn
159	great tumultuous masses of black smoke were boiling up out of
159	the enclosure, and through their stormy darkness shot flickering
159	threads of blood-red flame.  Then the thatched roof caught.
159	I saw the curving charge of the flames across the sloping straw.
159	A spurt of fire jetted from the window of my room.
159	
159	I knew at once what had happened.  I remembered the crash I had heard.
159	When I had rushed out to Montgomery's assistance, I had overturned
159	the lamp.
159	
159	The hopelessness of saving any of the contents of the enclosure
159	stared me in the face.  My mind came back to my plan of flight,
159	and turning swiftly I looked to see where the two boats lay upon
159	the beach.  They were gone!  Two axes lay upon the sands beside me;
159	chips and splinters were scattered broadcast, and the ashes
159	of the bonfire were blackening and smoking under the dawn.
159	Montgomery had burnt the boats to revenge himself upon me and prevent our
159	return to mankind!
159	
159	A sudden convulsion of rage shook me.  I was almost moved to batter
159	his foolish head in, as he lay there helpless at my feet.
159	Then suddenly his hand moved, so feebly, so pitifully, that my
159	wrath vanished.  He groaned, and opened his eyes for a minute.
159	I knelt down beside him and raised his head.  He opened his
159	eyes again, staring silently at the dawn, and then they met mine.
159	The lids fell.
159	
159	""Sorry,"" he said presently, with an effort.  He seemed trying to think.
159	""The last,"" he murmured, ""the last of this silly universe.
159	What a mess--""
159	
159	I listened.  His head fell helplessly to one side.  I thought some drink
159	might revive him; but there was neither drink nor vessel in which to
159	bring drink at hand.  He seemed suddenly heavier.  My heart went cold.
159	I bent down to his face, put my hand through the rent in his blouse.
159	He was dead; and even as he died a line of white heat, the limb
159	of the sun, rose eastward beyond the projection of the bay,
159	splashing its radiance across the sky and turning the dark sea into
159	a weltering tumult of dazzling light.  It fell like a glory upon his
159	death-shrunken face.
159	
159	I let his head fall gently upon the rough pillow I had made for him,
159	and stood up.  Before me was the glittering desolation of the sea,
159	the awful solitude upon which I had already suffered so much; behind me
159	the island, hushed under the dawn, its Beast People silent and unseen.
159	The enclosure, with all its provisions and ammunition, burnt noisily,
159	with sudden gusts of flame, a fitful crackling, and now and then a crash.
159	The heavy smoke drove up the beach away from me, rolling low
159	over the distant tree-tops towards the huts in the ravine.
159	Beside me were the charred vestiges of the boats and these five
159	dead bodies.
159	
159	Then out of the bushes came three Beast People, with hunched shoulders,
159	protruding heads, misshapen hands awkwardly held, and inquisitive,
159	unfriendly eyes and advanced towards me with hesitating gestures.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XX.  ALONE WITH THE BEAST FOLK.
159	
159	
159	I FACED these people, facing my fate in them, single-handed
159	now,--literally single-handed, for I had a broken arm.  In my pocket was
159	a revolver with two empty chambers.  Among the chips scattered about
159	the beach lay the two axes that had been used to chop up the boats.
159	The tide was creeping in behind me.  There was nothing for it but
159	courage.  I looked squarely into the faces of the advancing monsters.
159	They avoided my eyes, and their quivering nostrils investigated
159	the bodies that lay beyond me on the beach.  I took half-a-dozen steps,
159	picked up the blood-stained whip that lay beneath the body
159	of the Wolf-man, and cracked it.  They stopped and stared
159	at me.
159	
159	""Salute!"" said I. ""Bow down!""
159	
159	They hesitated.  One bent his knees.  I repeated my command,
159	with my heart in my mouth, and advanced upon them.  One knelt,
159	then the other two.
159	
159	I turned and walked towards the dead bodies, keeping my face
159	towards the three kneeling Beast Men, very much as an actor passing
159	up the stage faces the audience.
159	
159	""They broke the Law,"" said I, putting my foot on the Sayer of the Law.
159	""They have been slain,--even the Sayer of the Law; even the Other with
159	the Whip.  Great is the Law!  Come and see.""
159	
159	""None escape,"" said one of them, advancing and peering.
159	
159	""None escape,"" said I. ""Therefore hear and do as I command.""
159	They stood up, looking questioningly at one another.
159	
159	""Stand there,"" said I.
159	
159	I picked up the hatchets and swung them by their heads from
159	the sling of my arm; turned Montgomery over; picked up his revolver
159	still loaded in two chambers, and bending down to rummage,
159	found half-a-dozen cartridges in his pocket.
159	
159	""Take him,"" said I, standing up again and pointing with the whip;
159	""take him, and carry him out and cast him into the sea.""
159	
159	They came forward, evidently still afraid of Montgomery,
159	but still more afraid of my cracking red whip-lash; and after
159	some fumbling and hesitation, some whip-cracking and shouting,
159	they lifted him gingerly, carried him down to the beach, and went
159	splashing into the dazzling welter of the sea.
159	
159	""On!"" said I, ""on!  Carry him far.""
159	
159	They went in up to their armpits and stood regarding me.
159	
159	""Let go,"" said I; and the body of Montgomery vanished with a splash.
159	Something seemed to tighten across my chest.
159	
159	""Good!"" said I, with a break in my voice; and they came back,
159	hurrying and fearful, to the margin of the water, leaving long
159	wakes of black in the silver.  At the water's edge they stopped,
159	turning and glaring into the sea as though they presently expected
159	Montgomery to arise therefrom and exact vengeance.
159	
159	""Now these,"" said I, pointing to the other bodies.
159	
159	They took care not to approach the place where they had thrown
159	Montgomery into the water, but instead, carried the four dead
159	Beast People slantingly along the beach for perhaps a hundred
159	yards before they waded out and cast them away.
159	
159	As I watched them disposing of the mangled remains of M'ling, I
159	heard a light footfall behind me, and turning quickly saw the big
159	Hyena-swine perhaps a dozen yards away.  His head was bent down,
159	his bright eyes were fixed upon me, his stumpy hands clenched
159	and held close by his side.  He stopped in this crouching attitude
159	when I turned, his eyes a little averted.
159	
159	For a moment we stood eye to eye.  I dropped the whip and snatched
159	at the pistol in my pocket; for I meant to kill this brute, the most
159	formidable of any left now upon the island, at the first excuse.
159	It may seem treacherous, but so I was resolved.  I was far
159	more afraid of him than of any other two of the Beast Folk.
159	His continued life was I knew a threat against mine.
159	
159	I was perhaps a dozen seconds collecting myself.  Then cried I, ""Salute!
159	Bow down!""
159	
159	His teeth flashed upon me in a snarl.  ""Who are _you_ that I should--""
159	
159	Perhaps a little too spasmodically I drew my revolver, aimed quickly
159	and fired.  I heard him yelp, saw him run sideways and turn, knew I
159	had missed, and clicked back the cock with my thumb for the next shot.
159	But he was already running headlong, jumping from side to side,
159	and I dared not risk another miss.  Every now and then he looked
159	back at me over his shoulder.  He went slanting along the beach,
159	and vanished beneath the driving masses of dense smoke that were
159	still pouring out from the burning enclosure.  For some time I
159	stood staring after him.  I turned to my three obedient Beast Folk
159	again and signalled them to drop the body they still carried.
159	Then I went back to the place by the fire where the bodies had fallen
159	and kicked the sand until all the brown blood-stains were absorbed
159	and hidden.
159	
159	I dismissed my three serfs with a wave of the hand, and went up
159	the beach into the thickets.  I carried my pistol in my hand,
159	my whip thrust with the hatchets in the sling of my arm.
159	I was anxious to be alone, to think out the position in which I
159	was now placed.  A dreadful thing that I was only beginning
159	to realise was, that over all this island there was now no safe
159	place where I could be alone and secure to rest or sleep.
159	I had recovered strength amazingly since my landing, but I was still
159	inclined to be nervous and to break down under any great stress.
159	I felt that I ought to cross the island and establish myself
159	with the Beast People, and make myself secure in their confidence.
159	But my heart failed me.  I went back to the beach, and turning
159	eastward past the burning enclosure, made for a point where a shallow
159	spit of coral sand ran out towards the reef.  Here I could sit down
159	and think, my back to the sea and my face against any surprise.
159	And there I sat, chin on knees, the sun beating down upon my head
159	and unspeakable dread in my mind, plotting how I could live on against
159	the hour of my rescue (if ever rescue came). I tried to review the whole
159	situation as calmly as I could, but it was difficult to clear the thing
159	of emotion.
159	
159	I began turning over in my mind the reason of Montgomery's despair.
159	""They will change,"" he said; ""they are sure to change.""  And Moreau,
159	what was it that Moreau had said?  ""The stubborn beast-flesh grows
159	day by day back again.""  Then I came round to the Hyena-swine. I
159	felt sure that if I did not kill that brute, he would kill me.
159	The Sayer of the Law was dead:  worse luck.  They knew now that we
159	of the Whips could be killed even as they themselves were killed.
159	Were they peering at me already out of the green masses of ferns
159	and palms over yonder, watching until I came within their spring?
159	Were they plotting against me?  What was the Hyena-swine telling them?
159	My imagination was running away with me into a morass of unsubstantial
159	fears.
159	
159	My thoughts were disturbed by a crying of sea-birds hurrying
159	towards some black object that had been stranded by the waves
159	on the beach near the enclosure.  I knew what that object was,
159	but I had not the heart to go back and drive them off.
159	I began walking along the beach in the opposite direction,
159	designing to come round the eastward corner of the island and so
159	approach the ravine of the huts, without traversing the possible
159	ambuscades of the thickets.
159	
159	Perhaps half a mile along the beach I became aware of one of my three
159	Beast Folk advancing out of the landward bushes towards me.  I was now
159	so nervous with my own imaginings that I immediately drew my revolver.
159	Even the propitiatory gestures of the creature failed to disarm me.
159	He hesitated as he approached.
159	
159	""Go away!"" cried I.
159	
159	There was something very suggestive of a dog in the cringing attitude
159	of the creature.  It retreated a little way, very like a dog being
159	sent home, and stopped, looking at me imploringly with canine
159	brown eyes.
159	
159	""Go away,"" said I. ""Do not come near me.""
159	
159	""May I not come near you?"" it said.
159	
159	""No; go away,"" I insisted, and snapped my whip.  Then putting
159	my whip in my teeth, I stooped for a stone, and with that threat
159	drove the creature away.
159	
159	So in solitude I came round by the ravine of the Beast People,
159	and hiding among the weeds and reeds that separated this
159	crevice from the sea I watched such of them as appeared,
159	trying to judge from their gestures and appearance how the death
159	of Moreau and Montgomery and the destruction of the House of Pain
159	had affected them.  I know now the folly of my cowardice.
159	Had I kept my courage up to the level of the dawn, had I not
159	allowed it to ebb away in solitary thought, I might have grasped
159	the vacant sceptre of Moreau and ruled over the Beast People.
159	As it was I lost the opportunity, and sank to the position of a mere
159	leader among my fellows.
159	
159	Towards noon certain of them came and squatted basking in the hot sand.
159	The imperious voices of hunger and thirst prevailed over my dread.
159	I came out of the bushes, and, revolver in hand, walked down towards
159	these seated figures.  One, a Wolf-woman, turned her head and stared
159	at me, and then the others.  None attempted to rise or salute me.
159	I felt too faint and weary to insist, and I let the moment pass.
159	
159	""I want food,"" said I, almost apologetically, and drawing near.
159	
159	""There is food in the huts,"" said an Ox-boar-man, drowsily,
159	and looking away from me.
159	
159	I passed them, and went down into the shadow and odours of the almost
159	deserted ravine.  In an empty hut I feasted on some specked
159	and half-decayed fruit; and then after I had propped some branches
159	and sticks about the opening, and placed myself with my face
159	towards it and my hand upon my revolver, the exhaustion of the last
159	thirty hours claimed its own, and I fell into a light slumber,
159	hoping that the flimsy barricade I had erected would cause
159	sufficient noise in its removal to save me from surprise.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XXI.  THE REVERSION OF THE BEAST FOLK.
159	
159	
159	IN this way I became one among the Beast People in the Island
159	of Doctor Moreau.  When I awoke, it was dark about me.  My arm ached
159	in its bandages.  I sat up, wondering at first where I might be.
159	I heard coarse voices talking outside.  Then I saw that my
159	barricade had gone, and that the opening of the hut stood clear.
159	My revolver was still in my hand.
159	
159	I heard something breathing, saw something crouched together
159	close beside me.  I held my breath, trying to see what it was.
159	It began to move slowly, interminably.  Then something soft and warm
159	and moist passed across my hand.  All my muscles contracted.  I snatched
159	my hand away.  A cry of alarm began and was stifled in my throat.
159	Then I just realised what had happened sufficiently to stay my fingers on
159	the revolver.
159	
159	""Who is that?""  I said in a hoarse whisper, the revolver still pointed.
159	
159	""I--Master.""
159	
159	""Who are you?""
159	
159	""They say there is no Master now.  But I know, I know.  I carried the
159	bodies into the sea, O Walker in the Sea! the bodies of those you slew.
159	I am your slave, Master.""
159	
159	""Are you the one I met on the beach?"" I asked.
159	
159	""The same, Master.""
159	
159	The Thing was evidently faithful enough, for it might have fallen
159	upon me as I slept.  ""It is well,"" I said, extending my hand for
159	another licking kiss.  I began to realise what its presence meant,
159	and the tide of my courage flowed.  ""Where are the others?""
159	I asked.
159	
159	""They are mad; they are fools,"" said the Dog-man.  ""Even now they
159	talk together beyond there.  They say, 'The Master is dead.
159	The Other with the Whip is dead.  That Other who walked in the Sea is
159	as we are.  We have no Master, no Whips, no House of Pain, any more.
159	There is an end.  We love the Law, and will keep it; but there
159	is no Pain, no Master, no Whips for ever again.'  So they say.
159	But I know, Master, I know.""
159	
159	I felt in the darkness, and patted the Dog-man's head.  ""It is well,""
159	I said again.
159	
159	""Presently you will slay them all,"" said the Dog-man.
159	
159	""Presently,"" I answered, ""I will slay them all,--after certain
159	days and certain things have come to pass.  Every one of them save
159	those you spare, every one of them shall be slain.""
159	
159	""What the Master wishes to kill, the Master kills,"" said the Dog-man
159	with a certain satisfaction in his voice.
159	
159	""And that their sins may grow,"" I said, ""let them live in their folly
159	until their time is ripe.  Let them not know that I am the Master.""
159	
159	""The Master's will is sweet,"" said the Dog-man, with the ready tact
159	of his canine blood.
159	
159	""But one has sinned,"" said I. ""Him I will kill, whenever I may meet him.
159	When I say to you, 'That is he,' see that you fall upon him.
159	And now I will go to the men and women who are assembled together.""
159	
159	For a moment the opening of the hut was blackened by the exit of
159	the Dog-man. Then I followed and stood up, almost in the exact spot
159	where I had been when I had heard Moreau and his staghound pursuing me.
159	But now it was night, and all the miasmatic ravine about me was black;
159	and beyond, instead of a green, sunlit slope, I saw a red fire,
159	before which hunched, grotesque figures moved to and fro.
159	Farther were the thick trees, a bank of darkness, fringed above
159	with the black lace of the upper branches.  The moon was just riding
159	up on the edge of the ravine, and like a bar across its face drove
159	the spire of vapour that was for ever streaming from the fumaroles of
159	the island.
159	
159	""Walk by me,"" said I, nerving myself; and side by side we walked
159	down the narrow way, taking little heed of the dim Things that peered
159	at us out of the huts.
159	
159	None about the fire attempted to salute me.  Most of them
159	disregarded me, ostentatiously.  I looked round for the Hyena-swine,
159	but he was not there.  Altogether, perhaps twenty of the Beast
159	Folk squatted, staring into the fire or talking to one another.
159	
159	""He is dead, he is dead! the Master is dead!"" said the voice
159	of the Ape-man to the right of me.  ""The House of Pain--there
159	is no House of Pain!""
159	
159	""He is not dead,"" said I, in a loud voice.  ""Even now he watches us!""
159	
159	This startled them.  Twenty pairs of eyes regarded me.
159	
159	""The House of Pain is gone,"" said I. ""It will come again.
159	The Master you cannot see; yet even now he listens among you.""
159	
159	""True, true!"" said the Dog-man.
159	
159	They were staggered at my assurance.  An animal may be ferocious
159	and cunning enough, but it takes a real man to tell a lie.
159	
159	""The Man with the Bandaged Arm speaks a strange thing,""
159	said one of the Beast Folk.
159	
159	""I tell you it is so,"" I said.  ""The Master and the House of Pain
159	will come again.  Woe be to him who breaks the Law!""
159	
159	They looked curiously at one another.  With an affectation of indifference
159	I began to chop idly at the ground in front of me with my hatchet.
159	They looked, I noticed, at the deep cuts I made in the turf.
159	
159	Then the Satyr raised a doubt.  I answered him.  Then one of the dappled
159	things objected, and an animated discussion sprang up round the fire.
159	Every moment I began to feel more convinced of my present security.
159	I talked now without the catching in my breath, due to the intensity
159	of my excitement, that had troubled me at first.  In the course of about
159	an hour I had really convinced several of the Beast Folk of the truth
159	of my assertions, and talked most of the others into a dubious state.
159	I kept a sharp eye for my enemy the Hyena-swine, but he never appeared.
159	Every now and then a suspicious movement would startle me, but my
159	confidence grew rapidly.  Then as the moon crept down from the zenith,
159	one by one the listeners began to yawn (showing the oddest teeth in
159	the light of the sinking fire), and first one and then another retired
159	towards the dens in the ravine; and I, dreading the silence and darkness,
159	went with them, knowing I was safer with several of them than with
159	one alone.
159	
159	In this manner began the longer part of my sojourn upon this
159	Island of Doctor Moreau.  But from that night until the end came,
159	there was but one thing happened to tell save a series of innumerable
159	small unpleasant details and the fretting of an incessant uneasiness.
159	So that I prefer to make no chronicle for that gap of time,
159	to tell only one cardinal incident of the ten months I spent as an
159	intimate of these half-humanised brutes.  There is much that sticks
159	in my memory that I could write,--things that I would cheerfully
159	give my right hand to forget; but they do not help the telling of
159	the story.
159	
159	In the retrospect it is strange to remember how soon I fell
159	in with these monsters' ways, and gained my confidence again.
159	I had my quarrels with them of course, and could show some of
159	their teeth-marks still; but they soon gained a wholesome respect
159	for my trick of throwing stones and for the bite of my hatchet.
159	And my Saint-Bernard-man's loyalty was of infinite service to me.
159	I found their simple scale of honour was based mainly on the capacity
159	for inflicting trenchant wounds.  Indeed, I may say--without vanity,
159	I hope--that I held something like pre-eminence among them.
159	One or two, whom in a rare access of high spirits I had scarred
159	rather badly, bore me a grudge; but it vented itself chiefly
159	behind my back, and at a safe distance from my missiles,
159	in grimaces.
159	
159	The Hyena-swine avoided me, and I was always on the alert for him.
159	My inseparable Dog-man hated and dreaded him intensely.
159	I really believe that was at the root of the brute's attachment to me.
159	It was soon evident to me that the former monster had tasted blood,
159	and gone the way of the Leopard-man. He formed a lair somewhere in
159	the forest, and became solitary.  Once I tried to induce the Beast Folk to
159	hunt him, but I lacked the authority to make them co-operate for one end.
159	Again and again I tried to approach his den and come upon him unaware;
159	but always he was too acute for me, and saw or winded me and got away.
159	He too made every forest pathway dangerous to me and my ally
159	with his lurking ambuscades.  The Dog-man scarcely dared to leave
159	my side.
159	
159	In the first month or so the Beast Folk, compared with their
159	latter condition, were human enough, and for one or two besides
159	my canine friend I even conceived a friendly tolerance.
159	The little pink sloth-creature displayed an odd affection for me,
159	and took to following me about.  The Monkey-man bored me, however;
159	he assumed, on the strength of his five digits, that he was my equal,
159	and was for ever jabbering at me,--jabbering the most arrant nonsense.
159	One thing about him entertained me a little:  he had a fantastic trick
159	of coining new words.  He had an idea, I believe, that to gabble
159	about names that meant nothing was the proper use of speech.
159	He called it ""Big Thinks"" to distinguish it from ""Little Thinks,""
159	the sane every-day interests of life.  If ever I made a remark
159	he did not understand, he would praise it very much, ask me to say
159	it again, learn it by heart, and go off repeating it, with a word
159	wrong here or there, to all the milder of the Beast People.
159	He thought nothing of what was plain and comprehensible.
159	I invented some very curious ""Big Thinks"" for his especial use.
159	I think now that he was the silliest creature I ever met;
159	he had developed in the most wonderful way the distinctive silliness
159	of man without losing one jot of the natural folly of a monkey.
159	
159	This, I say, was in the earlier weeks of my solitude among these brutes.
159	During that time they respected the usage established by the Law,
159	and behaved with general decorum.  Once I found another rabbit torn
159	to pieces,--by the Hyena-swine, I am assured,--but that was all.
159	It was about May when I first distinctly perceived a growing difference
159	in their speech and carriage, a growing coarseness of articulation,
159	a growing disinclination to talk.  My Monkey-man's jabber multiplied
159	in volume but grew less and less comprehensible, more and more simian.
159	Some of the others seemed altogether slipping their hold upon speech,
159	though they still understood what I said to them at that time.
159	(Can you imagine language, once clear-cut and exact, softening and
159	guttering, losing shape and import, becoming mere lumps of sound again?)
159	And they walked erect with an increasing difficulty.  Though they
159	evidently felt ashamed of themselves, every now and then I would come
159	upon one or another running on toes and finger-tips, and quite unable
159	to recover the vertical attitude.  They held things more clumsily;
159	drinking by suction, feeding by gnawing, grew commoner every day.
159	I realised more keenly than ever what Moreau had told me about
159	the ""stubborn beast-flesh."" They were reverting, and reverting very
159	rapidly.
159	
159	Some of them--the pioneers in this, I noticed with some surprise,
159	were all females--began to disregard the injunction of decency,
159	deliberately for the most part.  Others even attempted public outrages
159	upon the institution of monogamy.  The tradition of the Law was clearly
159	losing its force.  I cannot pursue this disagreeable subject.
159	
159	My Dog-man imperceptibly slipped back to the dog again; day by day
159	he became dumb, quadrupedal, hairy.  I scarcely noticed the transition
159	from the companion on my right hand to the lurching dog at my side.
159	
159	As the carelessness and disorganisation increased from day to day,
159	the lane of dwelling places, at no time very sweet, became so
159	loathsome that I left it, and going across the island made myself
159	a hovel of boughs amid the black ruins of Moreau's enclosure.
159	Some memory of pain, I found, still made that place the safest from
159	the Beast Folk.
159	
159	It would be impossible to detail every step of the lapsing of
159	these monsters,--to tell how, day by day, the human semblance left them;
159	how they gave up bandagings and wrappings, abandoned at last every
159	stitch of clothing; how the hair began to spread over the exposed limbs;
159	how their foreheads fell away and their faces projected;
159	how the quasi-human intimacy I had permitted myself with some
159	of them in the first month of my loneliness became a shuddering
159	horror to recall.
159	
159	The change was slow and inevitable.  For them and for me it came
159	without any definite shock.  I still went among them in safety,
159	because no jolt in the downward glide had released the increasing
159	charge of explosive animalism that ousted the human day by day.
159	But I began to fear that soon now that shock must come.
159	My Saint-Bernard-brute followed me to the enclosure every night,
159	and his vigilance enabled me to sleep at times in something like peace.
159	The little pink sloth-thing became shy and left me, to crawl back
159	to its natural life once more among the tree-branches. We were in just
159	the state of equilibrium that would remain in one of those ""Happy Family""
159	cages which animal-tamers exhibit, if the tamer were to leave it
159	for ever.
159	
159	Of course these creatures did not decline into such beasts as
159	the reader has seen in zoological gardens,--into ordinary bears,
159	wolves, tigers, oxen, swine, and apes.  There was still something
159	strange about each; in each Moreau had blended this animal with that.
159	One perhaps was ursine chiefly, another feline chiefly, another
159	bovine chiefly; but each was tainted with other creatures,--a kind
159	of generalised animalism appearing through the specific dispositions.
159	And the dwindling shreds of the humanity still startled me every
159	now and then,--a momentary recrudescence of speech perhaps,
159	an unexpected dexterity of the fore-feet, a pitiful attempt to
159	walk erect.
159	
159	I too must have undergone strange changes.  My clothes hung about
159	me as yellow rags, through whose rents showed the tanned skin.
159	My hair grew long, and became matted together.  I am told that
159	even now my eyes have a strange brightness, a swift alertness
159	of movement.
159	
159	At first I spent the daylight hours on the southward beach
159	watching for a ship, hoping and praying for a ship.
159	I counted on the ""Ipecacuanha"" returning as the year wore on;
159	but she never came.  Five times I saw sails, and thrice smoke;
159	but nothing ever touched the island.  I always had a bonfire ready,
159	but no doubt the volcanic reputation of the island was taken to account
159	for that.
159	
159	It was only about September or October that I began to think of making
159	a raft.  By that time my arm had healed, and both my hands were at
159	my service again.  At first, I found my helplessness appalling.
159	I had never done any carpentry or such-like work in my life, and I spent
159	day after day in experimental chopping and binding among the trees.
159	I had no ropes, and could hit on nothing wherewith to make ropes;
159	none of the abundant creepers seemed limber or strong enough,
159	and with all my litter of scientific education I could not devise
159	any way of making them so.  I spent more than a fortnight
159	grubbing among the black ruins of the enclosure and on
159	the beach where the boats had been burnt, looking for nails
159	and other stray pieces of metal that might prove of service.
159	Now and then some Beast-creature would watch me, and go leaping
159	off when I called to it.  There came a season of thunder-storms
159	and heavy rain, which greatly retarded my work; but at last the raft
159	was completed.
159	
159	I was delighted with it.  But with a certain lack of practical sense
159	which has always been my bane, I had made it a mile or more from the sea;
159	and before I had dragged it down to the beach the thing had fallen
159	to pieces.  Perhaps it is as well that I was saved from launching it;
159	but at the time my misery at my failure was so acute that for some
159	days I simply moped on the beach, and stared at the water and thought
159	of death.
159	
159	I did not, however, mean to die, and an incident occurred that warned
159	me unmistakably of the folly of letting the days pass so,--for each
159	fresh day was fraught with increasing danger from the Beast People.
159	
159	I was lying in the shade of the enclosure wall, staring out to sea,
159	when I was startled by something cold touching the skin of my heel,
159	and starting round found the little pink sloth-creature blinking
159	into my face.  He had long since lost speech and active movement,
159	and the lank hair of the little brute grew thicker every day and his
159	stumpy claws more askew.  He made a moaning noise when he saw he had
159	attracted my attention, went a little way towards the bushes and looked
159	back at me.
159	
159	At first I did not understand, but presently it occurred to me that
159	he wished me to follow him; and this I did at last,--slowly, for the day
159	was hot.  When we reached the trees he clambered into them, for he could
159	travel better among their swinging creepers than on the ground.
159	And suddenly in a trampled space I came upon a ghastly group.
159	My Saint-Bernard-creature lay on the ground, dead; and near
159	his body crouched the Hyena-swine, gripping the quivering flesh
159	with its misshapen claws, gnawing at it, and snarling with delight.
159	As I approached, the monster lifted its glaring eyes to mine,
159	its lips went trembling back from its red-stained teeth,
159	and it growled menacingly.  It was not afraid and not ashamed;
159	the last vestige of the human taint had vanished.  I advanced a step
159	farther, stopped, and pulled out my revolver.  At last I had him face
159	to face.
159	
159	The brute made no sign of retreat; but its ears went back,
159	its hair bristled, and its body crouched together.
159	I aimed between the eyes and fired.  As I did so, the Thing rose
159	straight at me in a leap, and I was knocked over like a ninepin.
159	It clutched at me with its crippled hand, and struck me in the face.
159	Its spring carried it over me.  I fell under the hind part of its body;
159	but luckily I had hit as I meant, and it had died even as it leapt.
159	I crawled out from under its unclean weight and stood up trembling,
159	staring at its quivering body.  That danger at least was over;
159	but this, I knew was only the first of the series of relapses that
159	must come.
159	
159	I burnt both of the bodies on a pyre of brushwood; but after that I saw
159	that unless I left the island my death was only a question of time.
159	The Beast People by that time had, with one or two exceptions,
159	left the ravine and made themselves lairs according to their taste
159	among the thickets of the island.  Few prowled by day, most of
159	them slept, and the island might have seemed deserted to a new-comer;
159	but at night the air was hideous with their calls and howling.
159	I had half a mind to make a massacre of them; to build traps,
159	or fight them with my knife.  Had I possessed sufficient cartridges,
159	I should not have hesitated to begin the killing.  There could
159	now be scarcely a score left of the dangerous carnivores;
159	the braver of these were already dead.  After the death of this poor
159	dog of mine, my last friend, I too adopted to some extent the practice
159	of slumbering in the daytime in order to be on my guard at night.
159	I rebuilt my den in the walls of the enclosure, with such a narrow
