159	opening that anything attempting to enter must necessarily make
159	a considerable noise.  The creatures had lost the art of fire too,
159	and recovered their fear of it.  I turned once more, almost passionately
159	now, to hammering together stakes and branches to form a raft for
159	my escape.
159	
159	I found a thousand difficulties.  I am an extremely unhandy man
159	(my schooling was over before the days of Slojd); but most
159	of the requirements of a raft I met at last in some clumsy,
159	circuitous way or other, and this time I took care of the strength.
159	The only insurmountable obstacle was that I had no vessel to contain
159	the water I should need if I floated forth upon these untravelled seas.
159	I would have even tried pottery, but the island contained no clay.
159	I used to go moping about the island trying with all my might
159	to solve this one last difficulty.  Sometimes I would give
159	way to wild outbursts of rage, and hack and splinter some
159	unlucky tree in my intolerable vexation.  But I could think
159	of nothing.
159	
159	And then came a day, a wonderful day, which I spent in ecstasy.
159	I saw a sail to the southwest, a small sail like that of a little schooner;
159	and forthwith I lit a great pile of brushwood, and stood by it in
159	the heat of it, and the heat of the midday sun, watching.  All day I
159	watched that sail, eating or drinking nothing, so that my head reeled;
159	and the Beasts came and glared at me, and seemed to wonder,
159	and went away.  It was still distant when night came and swallowed
159	it up; and all night I toiled to keep my blaze bright and high,
159	and the eyes of the Beasts shone out of the darkness, marvelling.
159	In the dawn the sail was nearer, and I saw it was the dirty
159	lug-sail of a small boat.  But it sailed strangely.  My eyes were
159	weary with watching, and I peered and could not believe them.
159	Two men were in the boat, sitting low down,--one by the bows,
159	the other at the rudder.  The head was not kept to the wind; it yawed and
159	fell away.
159	
159	As the day grew brighter, I began waving the last rag of my jacket to them;
159	but they did not notice me, and sat still, facing each other.  I went
159	to the lowest point of the low headland, and gesticulated and shouted.
159	There was no response, and the boat kept on her aimless course,
159	making slowly, very slowly, for the bay.  Suddenly a great white bird
159	flew up out of the boat, and neither of the men stirred nor noticed it;
159	it circled round, and then came sweeping overhead with its strong
159	wings outspread.
159	
159	Then I stopped shouting, and sat down on the headland and rested my chin
159	on my hands and stared.  Slowly, slowly, the boat drove past towards
159	the west.  I would have swum out to it, but something--a cold, vague
159	fear--kept me back.  In the afternoon the tide stranded the boat, and left
159	it a hundred yards or so to the westward of the ruins of the enclosure.
159	The men in it were dead, had been dead so long that they fell
159	to pieces when I tilted the boat on its side and dragged them out.
159	One had a shock of red hair, like the captain of the ""Ipecacuanha,"" and
159	a dirty white cap lay in the bottom of the boat.
159	
159	As I stood beside the boat, three of the Beasts came slinking
159	out of the bushes and sniffing towards me.  One of my spasms
159	of disgust came upon me.  I thrust the little boat down the beach
159	and clambered on board her.  Two of the brutes were Wolf-beasts,
159	and came forward with quivering nostrils and glittering eyes;
159	the third was the horrible nondescript of bear and bull.
159	When I saw them approaching those wretched remains, heard them
159	snarling at one another and caught the gleam of their teeth,
159	a frantic horror succeeded my repulsion.  I turned my back upon them,
159	struck the lug and began paddling out to sea.  I could not bring myself
159	to look behind me.
159	
159	I lay, however, between the reef and the island that night,
159	and the next morning went round to the stream and filled the empty
159	keg aboard with water.  Then, with such patience as I could command,
159	I collected a quantity of fruit, and waylaid and killed two rabbits
159	with my last three cartridges.  While I was doing this I left
159	the boat moored to an inward projection of the reef, for fear
159	of the Beast People.
159	
159	
159	
159	
159	XXII.  THE MAN ALONE.
159	
159	
159	IN the evening I started, and drove out to sea before a gentle wind
159	from the southwest, slowly, steadily; and the island grew smaller
159	and smaller, and the lank spire of smoke dwindled to a finer and
159	finer line against the hot sunset.  The ocean rose up around me,
159	hiding that low, dark patch from my eyes.  The daylight, the trailing
159	glory of the sun, went streaming out of the sky, was drawn aside
159	like some luminous curtain, and at last I looked into the blue
159	gulf of immensity which the sunshine hides, and saw the floating
159	hosts of the stars.  The sea was silent, the sky was silent.
159	I was alone with the night and silence.
159	
159	So I drifted for three days, eating and drinking sparingly, and meditating
159	upon all that had happened to me,--not desiring very greatly then to see
159	men again.  One unclean rag was about me, my hair a black tangle:
159	no doubt my discoverers thought me a madman.
159	
159	It is strange, but I felt no desire to return to mankind.
159	I was only glad to be quit of the foulness of the Beast People.
159	And on the third day I was picked up by a brig from Apia to San Francisco.
159	Neither the captain nor the mate would believe my story, judging that
159	solitude and danger had made me mad; and fearing their opinion might
159	be that of others, I refrained from telling my adventure further,
159	and professed to recall nothing that had happened to me between
159	the loss of the ""Lady Vain"" and the time when I was picked up again,--the
159	space of a year.
159	
159	I had to act with the utmost circumspection to save myself from the
159	suspicion of insanity.  My memory of the Law, of the two dead sailors,
159	of the ambuscades of the darkness, of the body in the canebrake,
159	haunted me; and, unnatural as it seems, with my return to mankind came,
159	instead of that confidence and sympathy I had expected, a strange
159	enhancement of the uncertainty and dread I had experienced
159	during my stay upon the island.  No one would believe me;
159	I was almost as queer to men as I had been to the Beast People.
159	I may have caught something of the natural wildness of my companions.
159	They say that terror is a disease, and anyhow I can witness that for
159	several years now a restless fear has dwelt in my mind,--such a restless
159	fear as a half-tamed lion cub may feel.
159	
159	My trouble took the strangest form.  I could not persuade myself
159	that the men and women I met were not also another Beast People,
159	animals half wrought into the outward image of human souls, and that they
159	would presently begin to revert,--to show first this bestial mark
159	and then that.  But I have confided my case to a strangely able
159	man,--a man who had known Moreau, and seemed half to credit my story;
159	a mental specialist,--and he has helped me mightily, though I do not
159	expect that the terror of that island will ever altogether leave me.
159	At most times it lies far in the back of my mind, a mere distant cloud,
159	a memory, and a faint distrust; but there are times when the little
159	cloud spreads until it obscures the whole sky.  Then I look about me
159	at my fellow-men; and I go in fear.  I see faces, keen and bright;
159	others dull or dangerous; others, unsteady, insincere,--none that
159	have the calm authority of a reasonable soul.  I feel as though
159	the animal was surging up through them; that presently the degradation
159	of the Islanders will be played over again on a larger scale.
159	I know this is an illusion; that these seeming men and women about
159	me are indeed men and women,--men and women for ever, perfectly
159	reasonable creatures, full of human desires and tender solicitude,
159	emancipated from instinct and the slaves of no fantastic
159	Law,--beings altogether different from the Beast Folk.  Yet I shrink
159	from them, from their curious glances, their inquiries and assistance,
159	and long to be away from them and alone.  For that reason I live near
159	the broad free downland, and can escape thither when this shadow
159	is over my soul; and very sweet is the empty downland then, under the
159	wind-swept sky.
159	
159	When I lived in London the horror was well-nigh insupportable.
159	I could not get away from men:  their voices came through windows;
159	locked doors were flimsy safeguards.  I would go out into the streets
159	to fight with my delusion, and prowling women would mew after me;
159	furtive, craving men glance jealously at me; weary, pale workers
159	go coughing by me with tired eyes and eager paces, like wounded
159	deer dripping blood; old people, bent and dull, pass murmuring
159	to themselves; and, all unheeding, a ragged tail of gibing children.
159	Then I would turn aside into some chapel,--and even there,
159	such was my disturbance, it seemed that the preacher gibbered
159	""Big Thinks,"" even as the Ape-man had done; or into some library,
159	and there the intent faces over the books seemed but patient
159	creatures waiting for prey.  Particularly nauseous were the blank,
159	expressionless faces of people in trains and omnibuses;
159	they seemed no more my fellow-creatures than dead bodies would be,
159	so that I did not dare to travel unless I was assured of being alone.
159	And even it seemed that I too was not a reasonable creature,
159	but only an animal tormented with some strange disorder in its
159	brain which sent it to wander alone, like a sheep stricken
159	with gid.
159	
159	This is a mood, however, that comes to me now, I thank God,
159	more rarely.  I have withdrawn myself from the confusion of cities
159	and multitudes, and spend my days surrounded by wise books,--bright
159	windows in this life of ours, lit by the shining souls of men.
159	I see few strangers, and have but a small household.
159	My days I devote to reading and to experiments in chemistry,
159	and I spend many of the clear nights in the study of astronomy.
159	There is--though I do not know how there is or why there is--a sense
159	of infinite peace and protection in the glittering hosts of heaven.
159	There it must be, I think, in the vast and eternal laws of matter,
159	and not in the daily cares and sins and troubles of men, that whatever
159	is more than animal within us must find its solace and its hope.  I hope,
159	or I could not live.
159	
159	And so, in hope and solitude, my story ends.
159	
159	EDWARD PRENDICK.
159	
159	
159	NOTE.  The substance of the chapter entitled ""Doctor Moreau explains,""
159	which contains the essential idea of the story, appeared as a middle
159	article in the ""Saturday Review"" in January, 1895.  This is
159	the only portion of this story that has been previously published,
159	and it has been entirely recast to adapt it to the narrative form.

5230	
5230	CHAPTER I
5230	
5230	THE STRANGE MAN'S ARRIVAL
5230	
5230	
5230	The stranger came early in February, one wintry day, through a
5230	biting wind and a driving snow, the last snowfall of the year, over
5230	the down, walking from Bramblehurst railway station, and carrying a
5230	little black portmanteau in his thickly gloved hand. He was wrapped
5230	up from head to foot, and the brim of his soft felt hat hid every
5230	inch of his face but the shiny tip of his nose; the snow had piled
5230	itself against his shoulders and chest, and added a white crest to
5230	the burden he carried. He staggered into the ""Coach and Horses"" more
5230	dead than alive, and flung his portmanteau down. ""A fire,"" he cried,
5230	""in the name of human charity! A room and a fire!"" He stamped and
5230	shook the snow from off himself in the bar, and followed Mrs. Hall
5230	into her guest parlour to strike his bargain. And with that much
5230	introduction, that and a couple of sovereigns flung upon the table,
5230	he took up his quarters in the inn.
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall lit the fire and left him there while she went to prepare
5230	him a meal with her own hands. A guest to stop at Iping in the
5230	wintertime was an unheard-of piece of luck, let alone a guest who
5230	was no ""haggler,"" and she was resolved to show herself worthy of her
5230	good fortune. As soon as the bacon was well under way, and Millie,
5230	her lymphatic maid, had been brisked up a bit by a few deftly chosen
5230	expressions of contempt, she carried the cloth, plates, and glasses
5230	into the parlour and began to lay them with the utmost _eclat_.
5230	Although the fire was burning up briskly, she was surprised to see
5230	that her visitor still wore his hat and coat, standing with his back
5230	to her and staring out of the window at the falling snow in the yard.
5230	His gloved hands were clasped behind him, and he seemed to be lost
5230	in thought. She noticed that the melting snow that still sprinkled
5230	his shoulders dripped upon her carpet. ""Can I take your hat and coat,
5230	sir?"" she said, ""and give them a good dry in the kitchen?""
5230	
5230	""No,"" he said without turning.
5230	
5230	She was not sure she had heard him, and was about to repeat her
5230	question.
5230	
5230	He turned his head and looked at her over his shoulder. ""I prefer to
5230	keep them on,"" he said with emphasis, and she noticed that he wore
5230	big blue spectacles with sidelights, and had a bush side-whisker
5230	over his coat-collar that completely hid his cheeks and face.
5230	
5230	""Very well, sir,"" she said. ""_As_ you like. In a bit the room will
5230	be warmer.""
5230	
5230	He made no answer, and had turned his face away from her again, and
5230	Mrs. Hall, feeling that her conversational advances were ill-timed,
5230	laid the rest of the table things in a quick staccato and whisked
5230	out of the room. When she returned he was still standing there, like
5230	a man of stone, his back hunched, his collar turned up, his dripping
5230	hat-brim turned down, hiding his face and ears completely. She put
5230	down the eggs and bacon with considerable emphasis, and called
5230	rather than said to him, ""Your lunch is served, sir.""
5230	
5230	""Thank you,"" he said at the same time, and did not stir until she
5230	was closing the door. Then he swung round and approached the table
5230	with a certain eager quickness.
5230	
5230	As she went behind the bar to the kitchen she heard a sound repeated
5230	at regular intervals. Chirk, chirk, chirk, it went, the sound of a
5230	spoon being rapidly whisked round a basin. ""That girl!"" she said.
5230	""There! I clean forgot it. It's her being so long!"" And while she
5230	herself finished mixing the mustard, she gave Millie a few verbal
5230	stabs for her excessive slowness. She had cooked the ham and eggs,
5230	laid the table, and done everything, while Millie (help indeed!) had
5230	only succeeded in delaying the mustard. And him a new guest and
5230	wanting to stay! Then she filled the mustard pot, and, putting it
5230	with a certain stateliness upon a gold and black tea-tray, carried
5230	it into the parlour.
5230	
5230	She rapped and entered promptly. As she did so her visitor moved
5230	quickly, so that she got but a glimpse of a white object disappearing
5230	behind the table. It would seem he was picking something from the
5230	floor. She rapped down the mustard pot on the table, and then she
5230	noticed the overcoat and hat had been taken off and put over a chair
5230	in front of the fire, and a pair of wet boots threatened rust to her
5230	steel fender. She went to these things resolutely. ""I suppose I may
5230	have them to dry now,"" she said in a voice that brooked no denial.
5230	
5230	""Leave the hat,"" said her visitor, in a muffled voice, and turning
5230	she saw he had raised his head and was sitting and looking at her.
5230	
5230	For a moment she stood gaping at him, too surprised to speak.
5230	
5230	He held a white cloth--it was a serviette he had brought with
5230	him--over the lower part of his face, so that his mouth and jaws
5230	were completely hidden, and that was the reason of his muffled
5230	voice. But it was not that which startled Mrs. Hall. It was the fact
5230	that all his forehead above his blue glasses was covered by a white
5230	bandage, and that another covered his ears, leaving not a scrap of
5230	his face exposed excepting only his pink, peaked nose. It was bright,
5230	pink, and shiny just as it had been at first. He wore a dark-brown
5230	velvet jacket with a high, black, linen-lined collar turned up about
5230	his neck. The thick black hair, escaping as it could below and
5230	between the cross bandages, projected in curious tails and horns,
5230	giving him the strangest appearance conceivable. This muffled and
5230	bandaged head was so unlike what she had anticipated, that for a
5230	moment she was rigid.
5230	
5230	He did not remove the serviette, but remained holding it, as she
5230	saw now, with a brown gloved hand, and regarding her with his
5230	inscrutable blue glasses. ""Leave the hat,"" he said, speaking very
5230	distinctly through the white cloth.
5230	
5230	Her nerves began to recover from the shock they had received. She
5230	placed the hat on the chair again by the fire. ""I didn't know, sir,""
5230	she began, ""that--"" and she stopped embarrassed.
5230	
5230	""Thank you,"" he said drily, glancing from her to the door and then
5230	at her again.
5230	
5230	""I'll have them nicely dried, sir, at once,"" she said, and carried
5230	his clothes out of the room. She glanced at his white-swathed head
5230	and blue goggles again as she was going out of the door; but his
5230	napkin was still in front of his face. She shivered a little as she
5230	closed the door behind her, and her face was eloquent of her surprise
5230	and perplexity. ""I _never_,"" she whispered. ""There!"" She went quite
5230	softly to the kitchen, and was too preoccupied to ask Millie what
5230	she was messing about with _now_, when she got there.
5230	
5230	The visitor sat and listened to her retreating feet. He glanced
5230	inquiringly at the window before he removed his serviette, and
5230	resumed his meal. He took a mouthful, glanced suspiciously at the
5230	window, took another mouthful, then rose and, taking the serviette
5230	in his hand, walked across the room and pulled the blind down to
5230	the top of the white muslin that obscured the lower panes. This
5230	left the room in a twilight. This done, he returned with an easier
5230	air to the table and his meal.
5230	
5230	""The poor soul's had an accident or an op'ration or somethin',"" said
5230	Mrs. Hall. ""What a turn them bandages did give me, to be sure!""
5230	
5230	She put on some more coal, unfolded the clothes-horse, and extended
5230	the traveller's coat upon this. ""And they goggles! Why, he looked
5230	more like a divin' helmet than a human man!"" She hung his muffler
5230	on a corner of the horse. ""And holding that handkerchief over his
5230	mouth all the time. Talkin' through it! ... Perhaps his mouth was
5230	hurt too--maybe.""
5230	
5230	She turned round, as one who suddenly remembers. ""Bless my soul
5230	alive!"" she said, going off at a tangent; ""ain't you done them
5230	taters _yet_, Millie?""
5230	
5230	When Mrs. Hall went to clear away the stranger's lunch, her idea
5230	that his mouth must also have been cut or disfigured in the accident
5230	she supposed him to have suffered, was confirmed, for he was smoking
5230	a pipe, and all the time that she was in the room he never loosened
5230	the silk muffler he had wrapped round the lower part of his face to
5230	put the mouthpiece to his lips. Yet it was not forgetfulness, for
5230	she saw he glanced at it as it smouldered out. He sat in the corner
5230	with his back to the window-blind and spoke now, having eaten and
5230	drunk and being comfortably warmed through, with less aggressive
5230	brevity than before. The reflection of the fire lent a kind of red
5230	animation to his big spectacles they had lacked hitherto.
5230	
5230	""I have some luggage,"" he said, ""at Bramblehurst station,"" and he
5230	asked her how he could have it sent. He bowed his bandaged head
5230	quite politely in acknowledgment of her explanation. ""To-morrow?"" he
5230	said. ""There is no speedier delivery?"" and seemed quite disappointed
5230	when she answered, ""No."" Was she quite sure? No man with a trap who
5230	would go over?
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall, nothing loath, answered his questions and developed a
5230	conversation. ""It's a steep road by the down, sir,"" she said in
5230	answer to the question about a trap; and then, snatching at an
5230	opening, said, ""It was there a carriage was upsettled, a year ago
5230	and more. A gentleman killed, besides his coachman. Accidents, sir,
5230	happen in a moment, don't they?""
5230	
5230	But the visitor was not to be drawn so easily. ""They do,"" he said
5230	through his muffler, eyeing her quietly through his impenetrable
5230	glasses.
5230	
5230	""But they take long enough to get well, don't they? ... There was
5230	my sister's son, Tom, jest cut his arm with a scythe, tumbled on it
5230	in the 'ayfield, and, bless me! he was three months tied up sir.
5230	You'd hardly believe it. It's regular given me a dread of a scythe,
5230	sir.""
5230	
5230	""I can quite understand that,"" said the visitor.
5230	
5230	""He was afraid, one time, that he'd have to have an op'ration--he
5230	was that bad, sir.""
5230	
5230	The visitor laughed abruptly, a bark of a laugh that he seemed to
5230	bite and kill in his mouth. ""_Was_ he?"" he said.
5230	
5230	""He was, sir. And no laughing matter to them as had the doing for
5230	him, as I had--my sister being took up with her little ones so
5230	much. There was bandages to do, sir, and bandages to undo. So that
5230	if I may make so bold as to say it, sir--""
5230	
5230	""Will you get me some matches?"" said the visitor, quite abruptly.
5230	""My pipe is out.""
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall was pulled up suddenly. It was certainly rude of him,
5230	after telling him all she had done. She gasped at him for a moment,
5230	and remembered the two sovereigns. She went for the matches.
5230	
5230	""Thanks,"" he said concisely, as she put them down, and turned his
5230	shoulder upon her and stared out of the window again. It was
5230	altogether too discouraging. Evidently he was sensitive on the
5230	topic of operations and bandages. She did not ""make so bold as to
5230	say,"" however, after all. But his snubbing way had irritated her,
5230	and Millie had a hot time of it that afternoon.
5230	
5230	The visitor remained in the parlour until four o'clock, without
5230	giving the ghost of an excuse for an intrusion. For the most part
5230	he was quite still during that time; it would seem he sat in the
5230	growing darkness smoking in the firelight--perhaps dozing.
5230	
5230	Once or twice a curious listener might have heard him at the coals,
5230	and for the space of five minutes he was audible pacing the room.
5230	He seemed to be talking to himself. Then the armchair creaked as
5230	he sat down again.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER II
5230	
5230	MR. TEDDY HENFREY'S FIRST IMPRESSIONS
5230	
5230	
5230	At four o'clock, when it was fairly dark and Mrs. Hall was screwing
5230	up her courage to go in and ask her visitor if he would take some
5230	tea, Teddy Henfrey, the clock-jobber, came into the bar. ""My sakes!
5230	Mrs. Hall,"" said he, ""but this is terrible weather for thin boots!""
5230	The snow outside was falling faster.
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall agreed, and then noticed he had his bag with him. ""Now
5230	you're here, Mr. Teddy,"" said she, ""I'd be glad if you'd give th'
5230	old clock in the parlour a bit of a look. 'Tis going, and it strikes
5230	well and hearty; but the hour-hand won't do nuthin' but point at
5230	six.""
5230	
5230	And leading the way, she went across to the parlour door and rapped
5230	and entered.
5230	
5230	Her visitor, she saw as she opened the door, was seated in the
5230	armchair before the fire, dozing it would seem, with his bandaged
5230	head drooping on one side. The only light in the room was the red
5230	glow from the fire--which lit his eyes like adverse railway signals,
5230	but left his downcast face in darkness--and the scanty vestiges of
5230	the day that came in through the open door. Everything was ruddy,
5230	shadowy, and indistinct to her, the more so since she had just been
5230	lighting the bar lamp, and her eyes were dazzled. But for a second
5230	it seemed to her that the man she looked at had an enormous mouth
5230	wide open--a vast and incredible mouth that swallowed the whole of
5230	the lower portion of his face. It was the sensation of a moment:
5230	the white-bound head, the monstrous goggle eyes, and this huge yawn
5230	below it. Then he stirred, started up in his chair, put up his hand.
5230	She opened the door wide, so that the room was lighter, and she saw
5230	him more clearly, with the muffler held up to his face just as she
5230	had seen him hold the serviette before. The shadows, she fancied,
5230	had tricked her.
5230	
5230	""Would you mind, sir, this man a-coming to look at the clock, sir?""
5230	she said, recovering from the momentary shock.
5230	
5230	""Look at the clock?"" he said, staring round in a drowsy manner,
5230	and speaking over his hand, and then, getting more fully awake,
5230	""certainly.""
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall went away to get a lamp, and he rose and stretched
5230	himself. Then came the light, and Mr. Teddy Henfrey, entering, was
5230	confronted by this bandaged person. He was, he says, ""taken aback.""
5230	
5230	""Good afternoon,"" said the stranger, regarding him--as Mr. Henfrey
5230	says, with a vivid sense of the dark spectacles--""like a lobster.""
5230	
5230	""I hope,"" said Mr. Henfrey, ""that it's no intrusion.""
5230	
5230	""None whatever,"" said the stranger. ""Though, I understand,"" he said
5230	turning to Mrs. Hall, ""that this room is really to be mine for my
5230	own private use.""
5230	
5230	""I thought, sir,"" said Mrs. Hall, ""you'd prefer the clock--""
5230	
5230	""Certainly,"" said the stranger, ""certainly--but, as a rule, I
5230	like to be alone and undisturbed.
5230	
5230	""But I'm really glad to have the clock seen to,"" he said, seeing a
5230	certain hesitation in Mr. Henfrey's manner. ""Very glad."" Mr. Henfrey
5230	had intended to apologise and withdraw, but this anticipation
5230	reassured him. The stranger turned round with his back to the
5230	fireplace and put his hands behind his back. ""And presently,"" he
5230	said, ""when the clock-mending is over, I think I should like to
5230	have some tea. But not till the clock-mending is over.""
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall was about to leave the room--she made no conversational
5230	advances this time, because she did not want to be snubbed in front
5230	of Mr. Henfrey--when her visitor asked her if she had made any
5230	arrangements about his boxes at Bramblehurst. She told him she had
5230	mentioned the matter to the postman, and that the carrier could
5230	bring them over on the morrow. ""You are certain that is the
5230	earliest?"" he said.
5230	
5230	She was certain, with a marked coldness.
5230	
5230	""I should explain,"" he added, ""what I was really too cold and
5230	fatigued to do before, that I am an experimental investigator.""
5230	
5230	""Indeed, sir,"" said Mrs. Hall, much impressed.
5230	
5230	""And my baggage contains apparatus and appliances.""
5230	
5230	""Very useful things indeed they are, sir,"" said Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	""And I'm very naturally anxious to get on with my inquiries.""
5230	
5230	""Of course, sir.""
5230	
5230	""My reason for coming to Iping,"" he proceeded, with a certain
5230	deliberation of manner, ""was ... a desire for solitude. I do not
5230	wish to be disturbed in my work. In addition to my work, an
5230	accident--""
5230	
5230	""I thought as much,"" said Mrs. Hall to herself.
5230	
5230	""--necessitates a certain retirement. My eyes--are sometimes so
5230	weak and painful that I have to shut myself up in the dark for
5230	hours together. Lock myself up. Sometimes--now and then. Not at
5230	present, certainly. At such times the slightest disturbance, the
5230	entry of a stranger into the room, is a source of excruciating
5230	annoyance to me--it is well these things should be understood.""
5230	
5230	""Certainly, sir,"" said Mrs. Hall. ""And if I might make so bold as
5230	to ask--""
5230	
5230	""That I think, is all,"" said the stranger, with that quietly
5230	irresistible air of finality he could assume at will. Mrs. Hall
5230	reserved her question and sympathy for a better occasion.
5230	
5230	After Mrs. Hall had left the room, he remained standing in front of
5230	the fire, glaring, so Mr. Henfrey puts it, at the clock-mending. Mr.
5230	Henfrey not only took off the hands of the clock, and the face, but
5230	extracted the works; and he tried to work in as slow and quiet and
5230	unassuming a manner as possible. He worked with the lamp close to
5230	him, and the green shade threw a brilliant light upon his hands,
5230	and upon the frame and wheels, and left the rest of the room
5230	shadowy. When he looked up, coloured patches swam in his eyes.
5230	Being constitutionally of a curious nature, he had removed the
5230	works--a quite unnecessary proceeding--with the idea of delaying his
5230	departure and perhaps falling into conversation with the stranger.
5230	But the stranger stood there, perfectly silent and still. So still,
5230	it got on Henfrey's nerves. He felt alone in the room and looked up,
5230	and there, grey and dim, was the bandaged head and huge blue lenses
5230	staring fixedly, with a mist of green spots drifting in front of
5230	them. It was so uncanny to Henfrey that for a minute they remained
5230	staring blankly at one another. Then Henfrey looked down again. Very
5230	uncomfortable position! One would like to say something. Should he
5230	remark that the weather was very cold for the time of year?
5230	
5230	He looked up as if to take aim with that introductory shot. ""The
5230	weather--"" he began.
5230	
5230	""Why don't you finish and go?"" said the rigid figure, evidently in
5230	a state of painfully suppressed rage. ""All you've got to do is to
5230	fix the hour-hand on its axle. You're simply humbugging--""
5230	
5230	""Certainly, sir--one minute more. I overlooked--"" and Mr. Henfrey
5230	finished and went.
5230	
5230	But he went feeling excessively annoyed. ""Damn it!"" said Mr. Henfrey
5230	to himself, trudging down the village through the thawing snow; ""a
5230	man must do a clock at times, surely.""
5230	
5230	And again, ""Can't a man look at you?--Ugly!""
5230	
5230	And yet again, ""Seemingly not. If the police was wanting you you
5230	couldn't be more wropped and bandaged.""
5230	
5230	At Gleeson's corner he saw Hall, who had recently married the
5230	stranger's hostess at the ""Coach and Horses,"" and who now drove
5230	the Iping conveyance, when occasional people required it, to
5230	Sidderbridge Junction, coming towards him on his return from that
5230	place. Hall had evidently been ""stopping a bit"" at Sidderbridge,
5230	to judge by his driving. ""'Ow do, Teddy?"" he said, passing.
5230	
5230	""You got a rum un up home!"" said Teddy.
5230	
5230	Hall very sociably pulled up. ""What's that?"" he asked.
5230	
5230	""Rum-looking customer stopping at the 'Coach and Horses,'"" said
5230	Teddy. ""My sakes!""
5230	
5230	And he proceeded to give Hall a vivid description of his grotesque
5230	guest. ""Looks a bit like a disguise, don't it? I'd like to see a
5230	man's face if I had him stopping in _my_ place,"" said Henfrey. ""But
5230	women are that trustful--where strangers are concerned. He's took
5230	your rooms and he ain't even given a name, Hall.""
5230	
5230	""You don't say so!"" said Hall, who was a man of sluggish apprehension.
5230	
5230	""Yes,"" said Teddy. ""By the week. Whatever he is, you can't get rid
5230	of him under the week. And he's got a lot of luggage coming
5230	to-morrow, so he says. Let's hope it won't be stones in boxes, Hall.""
5230	
5230	He told Hall how his aunt at Hastings had been swindled by a
5230	stranger with empty portmanteaux. Altogether he left Hall vaguely
5230	suspicious. ""Get up, old girl,"" said Hall. ""I s'pose I must see
5230	'bout this.""
5230	
5230	Teddy trudged on his way with his mind considerably relieved.
5230	
5230	Instead of ""seeing 'bout it,"" however, Hall on his return was
5230	severely rated by his wife on the length of time he had spent in
5230	Sidderbridge, and his mild inquiries were answered snappishly and
5230	in a manner not to the point. But the seed of suspicion Teddy
5230	had sown germinated in the mind of Mr. Hall in spite of these
5230	discouragements. ""You wim' don't know everything,"" said Mr. Hall,
5230	resolved to ascertain more about the personality of his guest at
5230	the earliest possible opportunity. And after the stranger had gone
5230	to bed, which he did about half-past nine, Mr. Hall went very
5230	aggressively into the parlour and looked very hard at his wife's
5230	furniture, just to show that the stranger wasn't master there,
5230	and scrutinised closely and a little contemptuously a sheet of
5230	mathematical computations the stranger had left. When retiring
5230	for the night he instructed Mrs. Hall to look very closely at
5230	the stranger's luggage when it came next day.
5230	
5230	""You mind your own business, Hall,"" said Mrs. Hall, ""and I'll mind
5230	mine.""
5230	
5230	She was all the more inclined to snap at Hall because the stranger
5230	was undoubtedly an unusually strange sort of stranger, and she was
5230	by no means assured about him in her own mind. In the middle of the
5230	night she woke up dreaming of huge white heads like turnips, that
5230	came trailing after her, at the end of interminable necks, and with
5230	vast black eyes. But being a sensible woman, she subdued her
5230	terrors and turned over and went to sleep again.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER III
5230	
5230	THE THOUSAND AND ONE BOTTLES
5230	
5230	
5230	So it was that on the twenty-ninth day of February, at the beginning
5230	of the thaw, this singular person fell out of infinity into Iping
5230	village. Next day his luggage arrived through the slush--and very
5230	remarkable luggage it was. There were a couple of trunks indeed,
5230	such as a rational man might need, but in addition there were
5230	a box of books--big, fat books, of which some were just in an
5230	incomprehensible handwriting--and a dozen or more crates, boxes,
5230	and cases, containing objects packed in straw, as it seemed to
5230	Hall, tugging with a casual curiosity at the straw--glass bottles.
5230	The stranger, muffled in hat, coat, gloves, and wrapper, came out
5230	impatiently to meet Fearenside's cart, while Hall was having a word
5230	or so of gossip preparatory to helping bring them in. Out he came,
5230	not noticing Fearenside's dog, who was sniffing in a _dilettante_
5230	spirit at Hall's legs. ""Come along with those boxes,"" he said.
5230	""I've been waiting long enough.""
5230	
5230	And he came down the steps towards the tail of the cart as if to
5230	lay hands on the smaller crate.
5230	
5230	No sooner had Fearenside's dog caught sight of him, however, than
5230	it began to bristle and growl savagely, and when he rushed down the
5230	steps it gave an undecided hop, and then sprang straight at his
5230	hand. ""Whup!"" cried Hall, jumping back, for he was no hero with
5230	dogs, and Fearenside howled, ""Lie down!"" and snatched his whip.
5230	
5230	They saw the dog's teeth had slipped the hand, heard a kick, saw the
5230	dog execute a flanking jump and get home on the stranger's leg, and
5230	heard the rip of his trousering. Then the finer end of Fearenside's
5230	whip reached his property, and the dog, yelping with dismay,
5230	retreated under the wheels of the waggon. It was all the business of
5230	a swift half-minute. No one spoke, everyone shouted. The stranger
5230	glanced swiftly at his torn glove and at his leg, made as if he
5230	would stoop to the latter, then turned and rushed swiftly up the
5230	steps into the inn. They heard him go headlong across the passage
5230	and up the uncarpeted stairs to his bedroom.
5230	
5230	""You brute, you!"" said Fearenside, climbing off the waggon with his
5230	whip in his hand, while the dog watched him through the wheel.
5230	""Come here,"" said Fearenside--""You'd better.""
5230	
5230	Hall had stood gaping. ""He wuz bit,"" said Hall. ""I'd better go and
5230	see to en,"" and he trotted after the stranger. He met Mrs. Hall in
5230	the passage. ""Carrier's darg,"" he said ""bit en.""
5230	
5230	He went straight upstairs, and the stranger's door being ajar, he
5230	pushed it open and was entering without any ceremony, being of a
5230	naturally sympathetic turn of mind.
5230	
5230	The blind was down and the room dim. He caught a glimpse of a most
5230	singular thing, what seemed a handless arm waving towards him, and
5230	a face of three huge indeterminate spots on white, very like the
5230	face of a pale pansy. Then he was struck violently in the chest,
5230	hurled back, and the door slammed in his face and locked. It was so
5230	rapid that it gave him no time to observe. A waving of indecipherable
5230	shapes, a blow, and a concussion. There he stood on the dark little
5230	landing, wondering what it might be that he had seen.
5230	
5230	A couple of minutes after, he rejoined the little group that had
5230	formed outside the ""Coach and Horses."" There was Fearenside telling
5230	about it all over again for the second time; there was Mrs. Hall
5230	saying his dog didn't have no business to bite her guests; there
5230	was Huxter, the general dealer from over the road, interrogative;
5230	and Sandy Wadgers from the forge, judicial; besides women and
5230	children, all of them saying fatuities: ""Wouldn't let en bite
5230	_me_, I knows""; ""'Tasn't right _have_ such dargs""; ""Whad _'e_ bite
5230	'n for, then?"" and so forth.
5230	
5230	Mr. Hall, staring at them from the steps and listening, found it
5230	incredible that he had seen anything so very remarkable happen
5230	upstairs. Besides, his vocabulary was altogether too limited to
5230	express his impressions.
5230	
5230	""He don't want no help, he says,"" he said in answer to his wife's
5230	inquiry. ""We'd better be a-takin' of his luggage in.""
5230	
5230	""He ought to have it cauterised at once,"" said Mr. Huxter;
5230	""especially if it's at all inflamed.""
5230	
5230	""I'd shoot en, that's what I'd do,"" said a lady in the group.
5230	
5230	Suddenly the dog began growling again.
5230	
5230	""Come along,"" cried an angry voice in the doorway, and there stood
5230	the muffled stranger with his collar turned up, and his hat-brim
5230	bent down. ""The sooner you get those things in the better I'll be
5230	pleased."" It is stated by an anonymous bystander that his trousers
5230	and gloves had been changed.
5230	
5230	""Was you hurt, sir?"" said Fearenside. ""I'm rare sorry the darg--""
5230	
5230	""Not a bit,"" said the stranger. ""Never broke the skin. Hurry up
5230	with those things.""
5230	
5230	He then swore to himself, so Mr. Hall asserts.
5230	
5230	Directly the first crate was, in accordance with his directions,
5230	carried into the parlour, the stranger flung himself upon it with
5230	extraordinary eagerness, and began to unpack it, scattering the
5230	straw with an utter disregard of Mrs. Hall's carpet. And from it he
5230	began to produce bottles--little fat bottles containing powders,
5230	small and slender bottles containing coloured and white fluids,
5230	fluted blue bottles labeled Poison, bottles with round bodies and
5230	slender necks, large green-glass bottles, large white-glass bottles,
5230	bottles with glass stoppers and frosted labels, bottles with fine
5230	corks, bottles with bungs, bottles with wooden caps, wine bottles,
5230	salad-oil bottles--putting them in rows on the chiffonnier, on the
5230	mantel, on the table under the window, round the floor, on the
5230	bookshelf--everywhere. The chemist's shop in Bramblehurst could not
5230	boast half so many. Quite a sight it was. Crate after crate yielded
5230	bottles, until all six were empty and the table high with straw; the
5230	only things that came out of these crates besides the bottles were
5230	a number of test-tubes and a carefully packed balance.
5230	
5230	And directly the crates were unpacked, the stranger went to the
5230	window and set to work, not troubling in the least about the litter
5230	of straw, the fire which had gone out, the box of books outside,
5230	nor for the trunks and other luggage that had gone upstairs.
5230	
5230	When Mrs. Hall took his dinner in to him, he was already so
5230	absorbed in his work, pouring little drops out of the bottles into
5230	test-tubes, that he did not hear her until she had swept away the
5230	bulk of the straw and put the tray on the table, with some little
5230	emphasis perhaps, seeing the state that the floor was in. Then he
5230	half turned his head and immediately turned it away again. But she
5230	saw he had removed his glasses; they were beside him on the table,
5230	and it seemed to her that his eye sockets were extraordinarily
5230	hollow. He put on his spectacles again, and then turned and faced
5230	her. She was about to complain of the straw on the floor when he
5230	anticipated her.
5230	
5230	""I wish you wouldn't come in without knocking,"" he said in the tone
5230	of abnormal exasperation that seemed so characteristic of him.
5230	
5230	""I knocked, but seemingly--""
5230	
5230	""Perhaps you did. But in my investigations--my really very urgent
5230	and necessary investigations--the slightest disturbance, the jar
5230	of a door--I must ask you--""
5230	
5230	""Certainly, sir. You can turn the lock if you're like that, you
5230	know. Any time.""
5230	
5230	""A very good idea,"" said the stranger.
5230	
5230	""This stror, sir, if I might make so bold as to remark--""
5230	
5230	""Don't. If the straw makes trouble put it down in the bill."" And he
5230	mumbled at her--words suspiciously like curses.
5230	
5230	He was so odd, standing there, so aggressive and explosive, bottle
5230	in one hand and test-tube in the other, that Mrs. Hall was quite
5230	alarmed. But she was a resolute woman. ""In which case, I should
5230	like to know, sir, what you consider--""
5230	
5230	""A shilling--put down a shilling. Surely a shilling's enough?""
5230	
5230	""So be it,"" said Mrs. Hall, taking up the table-cloth and beginning
5230	to spread it over the table. ""If you're satisfied, of course--""
5230	
5230	He turned and sat down, with his coat-collar toward her.
5230	
5230	All the afternoon he worked with the door locked and, as Mrs. Hall
5230	testifies, for the most part in silence. But once there was a
5230	concussion and a sound of bottles ringing together as though the
5230	table had been hit, and the smash of a bottle flung violently down,
5230	and then a rapid pacing athwart the room. Fearing ""something was
5230	the matter,"" she went to the door and listened, not caring to
5230	knock.
5230	
5230	""I can't go on,"" he was raving. ""I _can't_ go on. Three hundred
5230	thousand, four hundred thousand! The huge multitude! Cheated! All
5230	my life it may take me! ... Patience! Patience indeed! ... Fool!
5230	fool!""
5230	
5230	There was a noise of hobnails on the bricks in the bar, and Mrs.
5230	Hall had very reluctantly to leave the rest of his soliloquy.
5230	When she returned the room was silent again, save for the faint
5230	crepitation of his chair and the occasional clink of a bottle.
5230	It was all over; the stranger had resumed work.
5230	
5230	When she took in his tea she saw broken glass in the corner of the
5230	room under the concave mirror, and a golden stain that had been
5230	carelessly wiped. She called attention to it.
5230	
5230	""Put it down in the bill,"" snapped her visitor. ""For God's sake
5230	don't worry me. If there's damage done, put it down in the bill,""
5230	and he went on ticking a list in the exercise book before him.
5230	
5230	""I'll tell you something,"" said Fearenside, mysteriously. It was
5230	late in the afternoon, and they were in the little beer-shop of
5230	Iping Hanger.
5230	
5230	""Well?"" said Teddy Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""This chap you're speaking of, what my dog bit. Well--he's black.
5230	Leastways, his legs are. I seed through the tear of his trousers
5230	and the tear of his glove. You'd have expected a sort of pinky to
5230	show, wouldn't you? Well--there wasn't none. Just blackness. I
5230	tell you, he's as black as my hat.""
5230	
5230	""My sakes!"" said Henfrey. ""It's a rummy case altogether. Why, his
5230	nose is as pink as paint!""
5230	
5230	""That's true,"" said Fearenside. ""I knows that. And I tell 'ee what
5230	I'm thinking. That marn's a piebald, Teddy. Black here and white
5230	there--in patches. And he's ashamed of it. He's a kind of half-breed,
5230	and the colour's come off patchy instead of mixing. I've heard of
5230	such things before. And it's the common way with horses, as any one
5230	can see.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER IV
5230	
5230	MR. CUSS INTERVIEWS THE STRANGER
5230	
5230	
5230	I have told the circumstances of the stranger's arrival in Iping
5230	with a certain fulness of detail, in order that the curious
5230	impression he created may be understood by the reader. But
5230	excepting two odd incidents, the circumstances of his stay until
5230	the extraordinary day of the club festival may be passed over very
5230	cursorily. There were a number of skirmishes with Mrs. Hall on
5230	matters of domestic discipline, but in every case until late April,
5230	when the first signs of penury began, he over-rode her by the easy
5230	expedient of an extra payment. Hall did not like him, and whenever
5230	he dared he talked of the advisability of getting rid of him; but
5230	he showed his dislike chiefly by concealing it ostentatiously, and
5230	avoiding his visitor as much as possible. ""Wait till the summer,""
5230	said Mrs. Hall sagely, ""when the artisks are beginning to come.
5230	Then we'll see. He may be a bit overbearing, but bills settled
5230	punctual is bills settled punctual, whatever you'd like to say.""
5230	
5230	The stranger did not go to church, and indeed made no difference
5230	between Sunday and the irreligious days, even in costume. He
5230	worked, as Mrs. Hall thought, very fitfully. Some days he would
5230	come down early and be continuously busy. On others he would rise
5230	late, pace his room, fretting audibly for hours together, smoke,
5230	sleep in the armchair by the fire. Communication with the world
5230	beyond the village he had none. His temper continued very
5230	uncertain; for the most part his manner was that of a man suffering
5230	under almost unendurable provocation, and once or twice things were
5230	snapped, torn, crushed, or broken in spasmodic gusts of violence.
5230	He seemed under a chronic irritation of the greatest intensity. His
5230	habit of talking to himself in a low voice grew steadily upon him,
5230	but though Mrs. Hall listened conscientiously she could make
5230	neither head nor tail of what she heard.
5230	
5230	He rarely went abroad by daylight, but at twilight he would go out
5230	muffled up invisibly, whether the weather were cold or not, and he
5230	chose the loneliest paths and those most overshadowed by trees and
5230	banks. His goggling spectacles and ghastly bandaged face under the
5230	penthouse of his hat, came with a disagreeable suddenness out of
5230	the darkness upon one or two home-going labourers, and Teddy
5230	Henfrey, tumbling out of the ""Scarlet Coat"" one night, at half-past
5230	nine, was scared shamefully by the stranger's skull-like head (he
5230	was walking hat in hand) lit by the sudden light of the opened inn
5230	door. Such children as saw him at nightfall dreamt of bogies, and
5230	it seemed doubtful whether he disliked boys more than they disliked
5230	him, or the reverse; but there was certainly a vivid enough dislike
5230	on either side.
5230	
5230	It was inevitable that a person of so remarkable an appearance and
5230	bearing should form a frequent topic in such a village as Iping.
5230	Opinion was greatly divided about his occupation. Mrs. Hall was
5230	sensitive on the point. When questioned, she explained very
5230	carefully that he was an ""experimental investigator,"" going
5230	gingerly over the syllables as one who dreads pitfalls. When asked
5230	what an experimental investigator was, she would say with a touch
5230	of superiority that most educated people knew such things as that,
5230	and would thus explain that he ""discovered things."" Her visitor had
5230	had an accident, she said, which temporarily discoloured his face
5230	and hands, and being of a sensitive disposition, he was averse to
5230	any public notice of the fact.
5230	
5230	Out of her hearing there was a view largely entertained that he was
5230	a criminal trying to escape from justice by wrapping himself up so
5230	as to conceal himself altogether from the eye of the police. This
5230	idea sprang from the brain of Mr. Teddy Henfrey. No crime of any
5230	magnitude dating from the middle or end of February was known to
5230	have occurred. Elaborated in the imagination of Mr. Gould, the
5230	probationary assistant in the National School, this theory took the
5230	form that the stranger was an Anarchist in disguise, preparing
5230	explosives, and he resolved to undertake such detective operations
5230	as his time permitted. These consisted for the most part in looking
5230	very hard at the stranger whenever they met, or in asking people
5230	who had never seen the stranger, leading questions about him. But
5230	he detected nothing.
5230	
5230	Another school of opinion followed Mr. Fearenside, and either
5230	accepted the piebald view or some modification of it; as, for
5230	instance, Silas Durgan, who was heard to assert that ""if he chooses
5230	to show enself at fairs he'd make his fortune in no time,"" and
5230	being a bit of a theologian, compared the stranger to the man with
5230	the one talent. Yet another view explained the entire matter by
5230	regarding the stranger as a harmless lunatic. That had the
5230	advantage of accounting for everything straight away.
5230	
5230	Between these main groups there were waverers and compromisers.
5230	Sussex folk have few superstitions, and it was only after the
5230	events of early April that the thought of the supernatural was
5230	first whispered in the village. Even then it was only credited
5230	among the women folk.
5230	
5230	But whatever they thought of him, people in Iping, on the whole,
5230	agreed in disliking him. His irritability, though it might have
5230	been comprehensible to an urban brain-worker, was an amazing thing
5230	to these quiet Sussex villagers. The frantic gesticulations they
5230	surprised now and then, the headlong pace after nightfall that
5230	swept him upon them round quiet corners, the inhuman bludgeoning
5230	of all tentative advances of curiosity, the taste for twilight
5230	that led to the closing of doors, the pulling down of blinds,
5230	the extinction of candles and lamps--who could agree with such
5230	goings on? They drew aside as he passed down the village, and when
5230	he had gone by, young humourists would up with coat-collars and
5230	down with hat-brims, and go pacing nervously after him in imitation
5230	of his occult bearing. There was a song popular at that time called
5230	""The Bogey Man"". Miss Statchell sang it at the schoolroom concert
5230	(in aid of the church lamps), and thereafter whenever one or two of
5230	the villagers were gathered together and the stranger appeared, a
5230	bar or so of this tune, more or less sharp or flat, was whistled in
5230	the midst of them. Also belated little children would call ""Bogey
5230	Man!"" after him, and make off tremulously elated.
5230	
5230	Cuss, the general practitioner, was devoured by curiosity. The
5230	bandages excited his professional interest, the report of the
5230	thousand and one bottles aroused his jealous regard. All through
5230	April and May he coveted an opportunity of talking to the stranger,
5230	and at last, towards Whitsuntide, he could stand it no longer, but
5230	hit upon the subscription-list for a village nurse as an excuse. He
5230	was surprised to find that Mr. Hall did not know his guest's name.
5230	""He give a name,"" said Mrs. Hall--an assertion which was quite
5230	unfounded--""but I didn't rightly hear it."" She thought it seemed
5230	so silly not to know the man's name.
5230	
5230	Cuss rapped at the parlour door and entered. There was a fairly
5230	audible imprecation from within. ""Pardon my intrusion,"" said Cuss,
5230	and then the door closed and cut Mrs. Hall off from the rest of
5230	the conversation.
5230	
5230	She could hear the murmur of voices for the next ten minutes, then
5230	a cry of surprise, a stirring of feet, a chair flung aside, a bark
5230	of laughter, quick steps to the door, and Cuss appeared, his face
5230	white, his eyes staring over his shoulder. He left the door open
5230	behind him, and without looking at her strode across the hall and
5230	went down the steps, and she heard his feet hurrying along the
5230	road. He carried his hat in his hand. She stood behind the door,
5230	looking at the open door of the parlour. Then she heard the
5230	stranger laughing quietly, and then his footsteps came across the
5230	room. She could not see his face where she stood. The parlour door
5230	slammed, and the place was silent again.
5230	
5230	Cuss went straight up the village to Bunting the vicar. ""Am I mad?""
5230	Cuss began abruptly, as he entered the shabby little study. ""Do I
5230	look like an insane person?""
5230	
5230	""What's happened?"" said the vicar, putting the ammonite on the
5230	loose sheets of his forth-coming sermon.
5230	
5230	""That chap at the inn--""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""Give me something to drink,"" said Cuss, and he sat down.
5230	
5230	When his nerves had been steadied by a glass of cheap sherry--the
5230	only drink the good vicar had available--he told him of the
5230	interview he had just had. ""Went in,"" he gasped, ""and began to
5230	demand a subscription for that Nurse Fund. He'd stuck his hands in
5230	his pockets as I came in, and he sat down lumpily in his chair.
5230	Sniffed. I told him I'd heard he took an interest in scientific
5230	things. He said yes. Sniffed again. Kept on sniffing all the time;
5230	evidently recently caught an infernal cold. No wonder, wrapped up
5230	like that! I developed the nurse idea, and all the while kept my
5230	eyes open. Bottles--chemicals--everywhere. Balance, test-tubes
5230	in stands, and a smell of--evening primrose. Would he subscribe?
5230	Said he'd consider it. Asked him, point-blank, was he researching.
5230	Said he was. A long research? Got quite cross. 'A damnable long
5230	research,' said he, blowing the cork out, so to speak. 'Oh,' said
5230	I. And out came the grievance. The man was just on the boil, and my
5230	question boiled him over. He had been given a prescription, most
5230	valuable prescription--what for he wouldn't say. Was it medical?
5230	'Damn you! What are you fishing after?' I apologised. Dignified
5230	sniff and cough. He resumed. He'd read it. Five ingredients. Put it
5230	down; turned his head. Draught of air from window lifted the paper.
5230	Swish, rustle. He was working in a room with an open fireplace, he
5230	said. Saw a flicker, and there was the prescription burning and
5230	lifting chimneyward. Rushed towards it just as it whisked up the
5230	chimney. So! Just at that point, to illustrate his story, out came
5230	his arm.""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""No hand--just an empty sleeve. Lord! I thought, _that's_ a
5230	deformity! Got a cork arm, I suppose, and has taken it off. Then, I
5230	thought, there's something odd in that. What the devil keeps that
5230	sleeve up and open, if there's nothing in it? There was nothing in
5230	it, I tell you. Nothing down it, right down to the joint. I could
5230	see right down it to the elbow, and there was a glimmer of light
5230	shining through a tear of the cloth. 'Good God!' I said. Then he
5230	stopped. Stared at me with those black goggles of his, and then
5230	at his sleeve.""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""That's all. He never said a word; just glared, and put his sleeve
5230	back in his pocket quickly. 'I was saying,' said he, 'that there
5230	was the prescription burning, wasn't I?' Interrogative cough.
5230	'How the devil,' said I, 'can you move an empty sleeve like that?'
5230	'Empty sleeve?' 'Yes,' said I, 'an empty sleeve.'
5230	
5230	""'It's an empty sleeve, is it? You saw it was an empty sleeve?' He
5230	stood up right away. I stood up too. He came towards me in three
5230	very slow steps, and stood quite close. Sniffed venomously. I
5230	didn't flinch, though I'm hanged if that bandaged knob of his, and
5230	those blinkers, aren't enough to unnerve any one, coming quietly
5230	up to you.
5230	
5230	""'You said it was an empty sleeve?' he said. 'Certainly,' I said.
5230	At staring and saying nothing a barefaced man, unspectacled, starts
5230	scratch. Then very quietly he pulled his sleeve out of his pocket
5230	again, and raised his arm towards me as though he would show it to
5230	me again. He did it very, very slowly. I looked at it. Seemed an
5230	age. 'Well?' said I, clearing my throat, 'there's nothing in it.'
5230	
5230	""Had to say something. I was beginning to feel frightened. I could
5230	see right down it. He extended it straight towards me, slowly,
5230	slowly--just like that--until the cuff was six inches from my
5230	face. Queer thing to see an empty sleeve come at you like that!
5230	And then--""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""Something--exactly like a finger and thumb it felt--nipped my
5230	nose.""
5230	
5230	Bunting began to laugh.
5230	
5230	""There wasn't anything there!"" said Cuss, his voice running up into
5230	a shriek at the ""there."" ""It's all very well for you to laugh, but
5230	I tell you I was so startled, I hit his cuff hard, and turned
5230	around, and cut out of the room--I left him--""
5230	
5230	Cuss stopped. There was no mistaking the sincerity of his panic.
5230	He turned round in a helpless way and took a second glass of the
5230	excellent vicar's very inferior sherry. ""When I hit his cuff,"" said
5230	Cuss, ""I tell you, it felt exactly like hitting an arm. And there
5230	wasn't an arm! There wasn't the ghost of an arm!""
5230	
5230	Mr. Bunting thought it over. He looked suspiciously at Cuss. ""It's
5230	a most remarkable story,"" he said. He looked very wise and grave
5230	indeed. ""It's really,"" said Mr. Bunting with judicial emphasis, ""a
5230	most remarkable story.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER V
5230	
5230	THE BURGLARY AT THE VICARAGE
5230	
5230	
5230	The facts of the burglary at the vicarage came to us chiefly
5230	through the medium of the vicar and his wife. It occurred in the
5230	small hours of Whit Monday, the day devoted in Iping to the Club
5230	festivities. Mrs. Bunting, it seems, woke up suddenly in the
5230	stillness that comes before the dawn, with the strong impression
5230	that the door of their bedroom had opened and closed. She did not
5230	arouse her husband at first, but sat up in bed listening. She then
5230	distinctly heard the pad, pad, pad of bare feet coming out of the
5230	adjoining dressing-room and walking along the passage towards the
5230	staircase. As soon as she felt assured of this, she aroused the
5230	Rev. Mr. Bunting as quietly as possible. He did not strike a light,
5230	but putting on his spectacles, her dressing-gown and his bath
5230	slippers, he went out on the landing to listen. He heard quite
5230	distinctly a fumbling going on at his study desk down-stairs, and
5230	then a violent sneeze.
5230	
5230	At that he returned to his bedroom, armed himself with the most
5230	obvious weapon, the poker, and descended the staircase as
5230	noiselessly as possible. Mrs. Bunting came out on the landing.
5230	
5230	The hour was about four, and the ultimate darkness of the night was
5230	past. There was a faint shimmer of light in the hall, but the study
5230	doorway yawned impenetrably black. Everything was still except the
5230	faint creaking of the stairs under Mr. Bunting's tread, and the
5230	slight movements in the study. Then something snapped, the drawer
5230	was opened, and there was a rustle of papers. Then came an
5230	imprecation, and a match was struck and the study was flooded with
5230	yellow light. Mr. Bunting was now in the hall, and through the
5230	crack of the door he could see the desk and the open drawer and a
5230	candle burning on the desk. But the robber he could not see. He
5230	stood there in the hall undecided what to do, and Mrs. Bunting, her
5230	face white and intent, crept slowly downstairs after him. One thing
5230	kept Mr. Bunting's courage; the persuasion that this burglar was a
5230	resident in the village.
5230	
5230	They heard the chink of money, and realised that the robber had
5230	found the housekeeping reserve of gold--two pounds ten in half
5230	sovereigns altogether. At that sound Mr. Bunting was nerved to
5230	abrupt action. Gripping the poker firmly, he rushed into the room,
5230	closely followed by Mrs. Bunting. ""Surrender!"" cried Mr. Bunting,
5230	fiercely, and then stooped amazed. Apparently the room was
5230	perfectly empty.
5230	
5230	Yet their conviction that they had, that very moment, heard somebody
5230	moving in the room had amounted to a certainty. For half a minute,
5230	perhaps, they stood gaping, then Mrs. Bunting went across the room
5230	and looked behind the screen, while Mr. Bunting, by a kindred
5230	impulse, peered under the desk. Then Mrs. Bunting turned back the
5230	window-curtains, and Mr. Bunting looked up the chimney and probed it
5230	with the poker. Then Mrs. Bunting scrutinised the waste-paper basket
5230	and Mr. Bunting opened the lid of the coal-scuttle. Then they came
5230	to a stop and stood with eyes interrogating each other.
5230	
5230	""I could have sworn--"" said Mr. Bunting.
5230	
5230	""The candle!"" said Mr. Bunting. ""Who lit the candle?""
5230	
5230	""The drawer!"" said Mrs. Bunting. ""And the money's gone!""
5230	
5230	She went hastily to the doorway.
5230	
5230	""Of all the strange occurrences--""
5230	
5230	There was a violent sneeze in the passage. They rushed out, and as
5230	they did so the kitchen door slammed. ""Bring the candle,"" said Mr.
5230	Bunting, and led the way. They both heard a sound of bolts being
5230	hastily shot back.
5230	
5230	As he opened the kitchen door he saw through the scullery that
5230	the back door was just opening, and the faint light of early dawn
5230	displayed the dark masses of the garden beyond. He is certain that
5230	nothing went out of the door. It opened, stood open for a moment,
5230	and then closed with a slam. As it did so, the candle Mrs. Bunting
5230	was carrying from the study flickered and flared. It was a minute
5230	or more before they entered the kitchen.
5230	
5230	The place was empty. They refastened the back door, examined the
5230	kitchen, pantry, and scullery thoroughly, and at last went down
5230	into the cellar. There was not a soul to be found in the house,
5230	search as they would.
5230	
5230	Daylight found the vicar and his wife, a quaintly-costumed little
5230	couple, still marvelling about on their own ground floor by the
5230	unnecessary light of a guttering candle.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER VI
5230	
5230	THE FURNITURE THAT WENT MAD
5230	
5230	
5230	Now it happened that in the early hours of Whit Monday, before
5230	Millie was hunted out for the day, Mr. Hall and Mrs. Hall both rose
5230	and went noiselessly down into the cellar. Their business there was
5230	of a private nature, and had something to do with the specific
5230	gravity of their beer. They had hardly entered the cellar when Mrs.
5230	Hall found she had forgotten to bring down a bottle of sarsaparilla
5230	from their joint-room. As she was the expert and principal operator
5230	in this affair, Hall very properly went upstairs for it.
5230	
5230	On the landing he was surprised to see that the stranger's door was
5230	ajar. He went on into his own room and found the bottle as he had
5230	been directed.
5230	
5230	But returning with the bottle, he noticed that the bolts of the
5230	front door had been shot back, that the door was in fact simply on
5230	the latch. And with a flash of inspiration he connected this with
5230	the stranger's room upstairs and the suggestions of Mr. Teddy
5230	Henfrey. He distinctly remembered holding the candle while Mrs.
5230	Hall shot these bolts overnight. At the sight he stopped, gaping,
5230	then with the bottle still in his hand went upstairs again. He
5230	rapped at the stranger's door. There was no answer. He rapped
5230	again; then pushed the door wide open and entered.
5230	
5230	It was as he expected. The bed, the room also, was empty. And what
5230	was stranger, even to his heavy intelligence, on the bedroom chair
5230	and along the rail of the bed were scattered the garments, the only
5230	garments so far as he knew, and the bandages of their guest. His
5230	big slouch hat even was cocked jauntily over the bed-post.
5230	
5230	As Hall stood there he heard his wife's voice coming out of the
5230	depth of the cellar, with that rapid telescoping of the syllables
5230	and interrogative cocking up of the final words to a high note,
5230	by which the West Sussex villager is wont to indicate a brisk
5230	impatience. ""George! You gart whad a wand?""
5230	
5230	At that he turned and hurried down to her. ""Janny,"" he said, over
5230	the rail of the cellar steps, ""'tas the truth what Henfrey sez.
5230	'E's not in uz room, 'e en't. And the front door's onbolted.""
5230	
5230	At first Mrs. Hall did not understand, and as soon as she did she
5230	resolved to see the empty room for herself. Hall, still holding the
5230	bottle, went first. ""If 'e en't there,"" he said, ""'is close are.
5230	And what's 'e doin' 'ithout 'is close, then? 'Tas a most curious
5230	business.""
5230	
5230	As they came up the cellar steps they both, it was afterwards
5230	ascertained, fancied they heard the front door open and shut, but
5230	seeing it closed and nothing there, neither said a word to the other
5230	about it at the time. Mrs. Hall passed her husband in the passage
5230	and ran on first upstairs. Someone sneezed on the staircase. Hall,
5230	following six steps behind, thought that he heard her sneeze. She,
5230	going on first, was under the impression that Hall was sneezing.
5230	She flung open the door and stood regarding the room. ""Of all the
5230	curious!"" she said.
5230	
5230	She heard a sniff close behind her head as it seemed, and turning,
5230	was surprised to see Hall a dozen feet off on the topmost stair.
5230	But in another moment he was beside her. She bent forward and put
5230	her hand on the pillow and then under the clothes.
5230	
5230	""Cold,"" she said. ""He's been up this hour or more.""
5230	
5230	As she did so, a most extraordinary thing happened. The bed-clothes
5230	gathered themselves together, leapt up suddenly into a sort of peak,
5230	and then jumped headlong over the bottom rail. It was exactly as if
5230	a hand had clutched them in the centre and flung them aside.
5230	Immediately after, the stranger's hat hopped off the bed-post,
5230	described a whirling flight in the air through the better part of
5230	a circle, and then dashed straight at Mrs. Hall's face. Then as
5230	swiftly came the sponge from the washstand; and then the chair,
5230	flinging the stranger's coat and trousers carelessly aside, and
5230	laughing drily in a voice singularly like the stranger's, turned
5230	itself up with its four legs at Mrs. Hall, seemed to take aim at her
5230	for a moment, and charged at her. She screamed and turned, and then
5230	the chair legs came gently but firmly against her back and impelled
5230	her and Hall out of the room. The door slammed violently and was
5230	locked. The chair and bed seemed to be executing a dance of triumph
5230	for a moment, and then abruptly everything was still.
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall was left almost in a fainting condition in Mr. Hall's
5230	arms on the landing. It was with the greatest difficulty that Mr.
5230	Hall and Millie, who had been roused by her scream of alarm,
5230	succeeded in getting her downstairs, and applying the restoratives
5230	customary in such cases.
5230	
5230	""'Tas sperits,"" said Mrs. Hall. ""I know 'tas sperits. I've read in
5230	papers of en. Tables and chairs leaping and dancing...""
5230	
5230	""Take a drop more, Janny,"" said Hall. ""'Twill steady ye.""
5230	
5230	""Lock him out,"" said Mrs. Hall. ""Don't let him come in again.
5230	I half guessed--I might ha' known. With them goggling eyes and
5230	bandaged head, and never going to church of a Sunday. And all
5230	they bottles--more'n it's right for any one to have. He's put the
5230	sperits into the furniture.... My good old furniture! 'Twas in
5230	that very chair my poor dear mother used to sit when I was a
5230	little girl. To think it should rise up against me now!""
5230	
5230	""Just a drop more, Janny,"" said Hall. ""Your nerves is all upset.""
5230	
5230	They sent Millie across the street through the golden five o'clock
5230	sunshine to rouse up Mr. Sandy Wadgers, the blacksmith. Mr.
5230	Hall's compliments and the furniture upstairs was behaving most
5230	extraordinary. Would Mr. Wadgers come round? He was a knowing man,
5230	was Mr. Wadgers, and very resourceful. He took quite a grave view
5230	of the case. ""Arm darmed if thet ent witchcraft,"" was the view of
5230	Mr. Sandy Wadgers. ""You warnt horseshoes for such gentry as he.""
5230	
5230	He came round greatly concerned. They wanted him to lead the way
5230	upstairs to the room, but he didn't seem to be in any hurry. He
5230	preferred to talk in the passage. Over the way Huxter's apprentice
5230	came out and began taking down the shutters of the tobacco window.
5230	He was called over to join the discussion. Mr. Huxter naturally
5230	followed over in the course of a few minutes. The Anglo-Saxon
5230	genius for parliamentary government asserted itself; there was a
5230	great deal of talk and no decisive action. ""Let's have the facts
5230	first,"" insisted Mr. Sandy Wadgers. ""Let's be sure we'd be acting
5230	perfectly right in bustin' that there door open. A door onbust is
5230	always open to bustin', but ye can't onbust a door once you've
5230	busted en.""
5230	
5230	And suddenly and most wonderfully the door of the room upstairs
5230	opened of its own accord, and as they looked up in amazement,
5230	they saw descending the stairs the muffled figure of the stranger
5230	staring more blackly and blankly than ever with those unreasonably
5230	large blue glass eyes of his. He came down stiffly and slowly,
5230	staring all the time; he walked across the passage staring, then
5230	stopped.
5230	
5230	""Look there!"" he said, and their eyes followed the direction of his
5230	gloved finger and saw a bottle of sarsaparilla hard by the cellar
5230	door. Then he entered the parlour, and suddenly, swiftly,
5230	viciously, slammed the door in their faces.
5230	
5230	Not a word was spoken until the last echoes of the slam had died
5230	away. They stared at one another. ""Well, if that don't lick
5230	everything!"" said Mr. Wadgers, and left the alternative unsaid.
5230	
5230	""I'd go in and ask'n 'bout it,"" said Wadgers, to Mr. Hall. ""I'd
5230	d'mand an explanation.""
5230	
5230	It took some time to bring the landlady's husband up to that pitch.
5230	At last he rapped, opened the door, and got as far as, ""Excuse me--""
5230	
5230	""Go to the devil!"" said the stranger in a tremendous voice, and
5230	""Shut that door after you."" So that brief interview terminated.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER VII
5230	
5230	THE UNVEILING OF THE STRANGER
5230	
5230	
5230	The stranger went into the little parlour of the ""Coach and Horses""
5230	about half-past five in the morning, and there he remained until
5230	near midday, the blinds down, the door shut, and none, after Hall's
5230	repulse, venturing near him.
5230	
5230	All that time he must have fasted. Thrice he rang his bell, the
5230	third time furiously and continuously, but no one answered him.
5230	""Him and his 'go to the devil' indeed!"" said Mrs. Hall. Presently
5230	came an imperfect rumour of the burglary at the vicarage, and two
5230	and two were put together. Hall, assisted by Wadgers, went off to
5230	find Mr. Shuckleforth, the magistrate, and take his advice. No one
5230	ventured upstairs. How the stranger occupied himself is unknown.
5230	Now and then he would stride violently up and down, and twice came
5230	an outburst of curses, a tearing of paper, and a violent smashing
5230	of bottles.
5230	
5230	The little group of scared but curious people increased. Mrs. Huxter
5230	came over; some gay young fellows resplendent in black ready-made
5230	jackets and _pique_ paper ties--for it was Whit Monday--joined
5230	the group with confused interrogations. Young Archie Harker
5230	distinguished himself by going up the yard and trying to peep
5230	under the window-blinds. He could see nothing, but gave reason
5230	for supposing that he did, and others of the Iping youth
5230	presently joined him.
5230	
5230	It was the finest of all possible Whit Mondays, and down the
5230	village street stood a row of nearly a dozen booths, a shooting
5230	gallery, and on the grass by the forge were three yellow and
5230	chocolate waggons and some picturesque strangers of both sexes
5230	putting up a cocoanut shy. The gentlemen wore blue jerseys, the
5230	ladies white aprons and quite fashionable hats with heavy plumes.
5230	Wodger, of the ""Purple Fawn,"" and Mr. Jaggers, the cobbler, who
5230	also sold old second-hand ordinary bicycles, were stretching a
5230	string of union-jacks and royal ensigns (which had originally
5230	celebrated the first Victorian Jubilee) across the road.
5230	
5230	And inside, in the artificial darkness of the parlour, into which
5230	only one thin jet of sunlight penetrated, the stranger, hungry we
5230	must suppose, and fearful, hidden in his uncomfortable hot wrappings,
5230	pored through his dark glasses upon his paper or chinked his dirty
5230	little bottles, and occasionally swore savagely at the boys, audible
5230	if invisible, outside the windows. In the corner by the fireplace
5230	lay the fragments of half a dozen smashed bottles, and a pungent
5230	twang of chlorine tainted the air. So much we know from what was
5230	heard at the time and from what was subsequently seen in the room.
5230	
5230	About noon he suddenly opened his parlour door and stood glaring
5230	fixedly at the three or four people in the bar. ""Mrs. Hall,"" he
5230	said. Somebody went sheepishly and called for Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall appeared after an interval, a little short of breath, but
5230	all the fiercer for that. Hall was still out. She had deliberated
5230	over this scene, and she came holding a little tray with an
5230	unsettled bill upon it. ""Is it your bill you're wanting, sir?"" she
5230	said.
5230	
5230	""Why wasn't my breakfast laid? Why haven't you prepared my meals
5230	and answered my bell? Do you think I live without eating?""
5230	
5230	""Why isn't my bill paid?"" said Mrs. Hall. ""That's what I want to
5230	know.""
5230	
5230	""I told you three days ago I was awaiting a remittance--""
5230	
5230	""I told you two days ago I wasn't going to await no remittances.
5230	You can't grumble if your breakfast waits a bit, if my bill's been
5230	waiting these five days, can you?""
5230	
5230	The stranger swore briefly but vividly.
5230	
5230	""Nar, nar!"" from the bar.
5230	
5230	""And I'd thank you kindly, sir, if you'd keep your swearing to
5230	yourself, sir,"" said Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	The stranger stood looking more like an angry diving-helmet than
5230	ever. It was universally felt in the bar that Mrs. Hall had the
5230	better of him. His next words showed as much.
5230	
5230	""Look here, my good woman--"" he began.
5230	
5230	""Don't 'good woman' _me_,"" said Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	""I've told you my remittance hasn't come.""
5230	
5230	""Remittance indeed!"" said Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	""Still, I daresay in my pocket--""
5230	
5230	""You told me three days ago that you hadn't anything but a
5230	sovereign's worth of silver upon you.""
5230	
5230	""Well, I've found some more--""
5230	
5230	""'Ul-lo!"" from the bar.
5230	
5230	""I wonder where you found it,"" said Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	That seemed to annoy the stranger very much. He stamped his foot.
5230	""What do you mean?"" he said.
5230	
5230	""That I wonder where you found it,"" said Mrs. Hall. ""And before I
5230	take any bills or get any breakfasts, or do any such things
5230	whatsoever, you got to tell me one or two things I don't understand,
5230	and what nobody don't understand, and what everybody is very anxious
5230	to understand. I want to know what you been doing t'my chair
5230	upstairs, and I want to know how 'tis your room was empty, and how
5230	you got in again. Them as stops in this house comes in by the
5230	doors--that's the rule of the house, and that you _didn't_ do, and
5230	what I want to know is how you _did_ come in. And I want to know--""
5230	
5230	Suddenly the stranger raised his gloved hands clenched, stamped his
5230	foot, and said, ""Stop!"" with such extraordinary violence that he
5230	silenced her instantly.
5230	
5230	""You don't understand,"" he said, ""who I am or what I am. I'll show
5230	you. By Heaven! I'll show you."" Then he put his open palm over his
5230	face and withdrew it. The centre of his face became a black cavity.
5230	""Here,"" he said. He stepped forward and handed Mrs. Hall something
5230	which she, staring at his metamorphosed face, accepted automatically.
5230	Then, when she saw what it was, she screamed loudly, dropped it, and
5230	staggered back. The nose--it was the stranger's nose! pink and
5230	shining--rolled on the floor.
5230	
5230	Then he removed his spectacles, and everyone in the bar gasped. He
5230	took off his hat, and with a violent gesture tore at his whiskers
5230	and bandages. For a moment they resisted him. A flash of horrible
5230	anticipation passed through the bar. ""Oh, my Gard!"" said some one.
5230	Then off they came.
5230	
5230	It was worse than anything. Mrs. Hall, standing open-mouthed and
5230	horror-struck, shrieked at what she saw, and made for the door of
5230	the house. Everyone began to move. They were prepared for scars,
5230	disfigurements, tangible horrors, but nothing! The bandages and
5230	false hair flew across the passage into the bar, making a
5230	hobbledehoy jump to avoid them. Everyone tumbled on everyone else
5230	down the steps. For the man who stood there shouting some incoherent
5230	explanation, was a solid gesticulating figure up to the coat-collar
5230	of him, and then--nothingness, no visible thing at all!
5230	
5230	People down the village heard shouts and shrieks, and looking up
