5230	the street saw the ""Coach and Horses"" violently firing out its
5230	humanity. They saw Mrs. Hall fall down and Mr. Teddy Henfrey jump
5230	to avoid tumbling over her, and then they heard the frightful
5230	screams of Millie, who, emerging suddenly from the kitchen at the
5230	noise of the tumult, had come upon the headless stranger from
5230	behind. These increased suddenly.
5230	
5230	Forthwith everyone all down the street, the sweetstuff seller,
5230	cocoanut shy proprietor and his assistant, the swing man, little
5230	boys and girls, rustic dandies, smart wenches, smocked elders
5230	and aproned gipsies--began running towards the inn, and in a
5230	miraculously short space of time a crowd of perhaps forty people,
5230	and rapidly increasing, swayed and hooted and inquired and
5230	exclaimed and suggested, in front of Mrs. Hall's establishment.
5230	Everyone seemed eager to talk at once, and the result was Babel. A
5230	small group supported Mrs. Hall, who was picked up in a state of
5230	collapse. There was a conference, and the incredible evidence of a
5230	vociferous eye-witness. ""O Bogey!"" ""What's he been doin', then?""
5230	""Ain't hurt the girl, 'as 'e?"" ""Run at en with a knife, I believe.""
5230	""No 'ed, I tell ye. I don't mean no manner of speaking. I mean _marn
5230	'ithout a 'ed_!"" ""Narnsense! 'tis some conjuring trick."" ""Fetched
5230	off 'is wrapping, 'e did--""
5230	
5230	In its struggles to see in through the open door, the crowd formed
5230	itself into a straggling wedge, with the more adventurous apex
5230	nearest the inn. ""He stood for a moment, I heerd the gal scream,
5230	and he turned. I saw her skirts whisk, and he went after her.
5230	Didn't take ten seconds. Back he comes with a knife in uz hand and
5230	a loaf; stood just as if he was staring. Not a moment ago. Went in
5230	that there door. I tell 'e, 'e ain't gart no 'ed at all. You just
5230	missed en--""
5230	
5230	There was a disturbance behind, and the speaker stopped to step
5230	aside for a little procession that was marching very resolutely
5230	towards the house; first Mr. Hall, very red and determined, then
5230	Mr. Bobby Jaffers, the village constable, and then the wary Mr.
5230	Wadgers. They had come now armed with a warrant.
5230	
5230	People shouted conflicting information of the recent circumstances.
5230	""'Ed or no 'ed,"" said Jaffers, ""I got to 'rest en, and 'rest en I
5230	_will_.""
5230	
5230	Mr. Hall marched up the steps, marched straight to the door of the
5230	parlour and flung it open. ""Constable,"" he said, ""do your duty.""
5230	
5230	Jaffers marched in. Hall next, Wadgers last. They saw in the dim
5230	light the headless figure facing them, with a gnawed crust of bread
5230	in one gloved hand and a chunk of cheese in the other.
5230	
5230	""That's him!"" said Hall.
5230	
5230	""What the devil's this?"" came in a tone of angry expostulation from
5230	above the collar of the figure.
5230	
5230	""You're a damned rum customer, mister,"" said Mr. Jaffers. ""But 'ed
5230	or no 'ed, the warrant says 'body,' and duty's duty--""
5230	
5230	""Keep off!"" said the figure, starting back.
5230	
5230	Abruptly he whipped down the bread and cheese, and Mr. Hall just
5230	grasped the knife on the table in time to save it. Off came the
5230	stranger's left glove and was slapped in Jaffers' face. In another
5230	moment Jaffers, cutting short some statement concerning a warrant,
5230	had gripped him by the handless wrist and caught his invisible
5230	throat. He got a sounding kick on the shin that made him shout, but
5230	he kept his grip. Hall sent the knife sliding along the table to
5230	Wadgers, who acted as goal-keeper for the offensive, so to speak,
5230	and then stepped forward as Jaffers and the stranger swayed and
5230	staggered towards him, clutching and hitting in. A chair stood in
5230	the way, and went aside with a crash as they came down together.
5230	
5230	""Get the feet,"" said Jaffers between his teeth.
5230	
5230	Mr. Hall, endeavouring to act on instructions, received a sounding
5230	kick in the ribs that disposed of him for a moment, and Mr.
5230	Wadgers, seeing the decapitated stranger had rolled over and got
5230	the upper side of Jaffers, retreated towards the door, knife in
5230	hand, and so collided with Mr. Huxter and the Sidderbridge carter
5230	coming to the rescue of law and order. At the same moment down came
5230	three or four bottles from the chiffonnier and shot a web of
5230	pungency into the air of the room.
5230	
5230	""I'll surrender,"" cried the stranger, though he had Jaffers down,
5230	and in another moment he stood up panting, a strange figure,
5230	headless and handless--for he had pulled off his right glove now
5230	as well as his left. ""It's no good,"" he said, as if sobbing for
5230	breath.
5230	
5230	It was the strangest thing in the world to hear that voice coming
5230	as if out of empty space, but the Sussex peasants are perhaps the
5230	most matter-of-fact people under the sun. Jaffers got up also and
5230	produced a pair of handcuffs. Then he stared.
5230	
5230	""I say!"" said Jaffers, brought up short by a dim realization of the
5230	incongruity of the whole business, ""Darn it! Can't use 'em as I can
5230	see.""
5230	
5230	The stranger ran his arm down his waistcoat, and as if by a miracle
5230	the buttons to which his empty sleeve pointed became undone. Then
5230	he said something about his shin, and stooped down. He seemed to be
5230	fumbling with his shoes and socks.
5230	
5230	""Why!"" said Huxter, suddenly, ""that's not a man at all. It's just
5230	empty clothes. Look! You can see down his collar and the linings of
5230	his clothes. I could put my arm--""
5230	
5230	He extended his hand; it seemed to meet something in mid-air, and
5230	he drew it back with a sharp exclamation. ""I wish you'd keep your
5230	fingers out of my eye,"" said the aerial voice, in a tone of savage
5230	expostulation. ""The fact is, I'm all here--head, hands, legs, and
5230	all the rest of it, but it happens I'm invisible. It's a confounded
5230	nuisance, but I am. That's no reason why I should be poked to
5230	pieces by every stupid bumpkin in Iping, is it?""
5230	
5230	The suit of clothes, now all unbuttoned and hanging loosely upon
5230	its unseen supports, stood up, arms akimbo.
5230	
5230	Several other of the men folks had now entered the room, so that it
5230	was closely crowded. ""Invisible, eh?"" said Huxter, ignoring the
5230	stranger's abuse. ""Who ever heard the likes of that?""
5230	
5230	""It's strange, perhaps, but it's not a crime. Why am I assaulted by
5230	a policeman in this fashion?""
5230	
5230	""Ah! that's a different matter,"" said Jaffers. ""No doubt you are a
5230	bit difficult to see in this light, but I got a warrant and it's
5230	all correct. What I'm after ain't no invisibility,--it's burglary.
5230	There's a house been broke into and money took.""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""And circumstances certainly point--""
5230	
5230	""Stuff and nonsense!"" said the Invisible Man.
5230	
5230	""I hope so, sir; but I've got my instructions.""
5230	
5230	""Well,"" said the stranger, ""I'll come. I'll _come_. But no
5230	handcuffs.""
5230	
5230	""It's the regular thing,"" said Jaffers.
5230	
5230	""No handcuffs,"" stipulated the stranger.
5230	
5230	""Pardon me,"" said Jaffers.
5230	
5230	Abruptly the figure sat down, and before any one could realise was
5230	was being done, the slippers, socks, and trousers had been kicked
5230	off under the table. Then he sprang up again and flung off his coat.
5230	
5230	""Here, stop that,"" said Jaffers, suddenly realising what was
5230	happening. He gripped at the waistcoat; it struggled, and the shirt
5230	slipped out of it and left it limp and empty in his hand. ""Hold
5230	him!"" said Jaffers, loudly. ""Once he gets the things off--""
5230	
5230	""Hold him!"" cried everyone, and there was a rush at the fluttering
5230	white shirt which was now all that was visible of the stranger.
5230	
5230	The shirt-sleeve planted a shrewd blow in Hall's face that stopped
5230	his open-armed advance, and sent him backward into old Toothsome
5230	the sexton, and in another moment the garment was lifted up and
5230	became convulsed and vacantly flapping about the arms, even as a
5230	shirt that is being thrust over a man's head. Jaffers clutched at
5230	it, and only helped to pull it off; he was struck in the mouth out
5230	of the air, and incontinently threw his truncheon and smote Teddy
5230	Henfrey savagely upon the crown of his head.
5230	
5230	""Look out!"" said everybody, fencing at random and hitting at
5230	nothing. ""Hold him! Shut the door! Don't let him loose! I got
5230	something! Here he is!"" A perfect Babel of noises they made.
5230	Everybody, it seemed, was being hit all at once, and Sandy Wadgers,
5230	knowing as ever and his wits sharpened by a frightful blow in the
5230	nose, reopened the door and led the rout. The others, following
5230	incontinently, were jammed for a moment in the corner by the
5230	doorway. The hitting continued. Phipps, the Unitarian, had a front
5230	tooth broken, and Henfrey was injured in the cartilage of his ear.
5230	Jaffers was struck under the jaw, and, turning, caught at something
5230	that intervened between him and Huxter in the melee, and prevented
5230	their coming together. He felt a muscular chest, and in another
5230	moment the whole mass of struggling, excited men shot out into the
5230	crowded hall.
5230	
5230	""I got him!"" shouted Jaffers, choking and reeling through them all,
5230	and wrestling with purple face and swelling veins against his
5230	unseen enemy.
5230	
5230	Men staggered right and left as the extraordinary conflict swayed
5230	swiftly towards the house door, and went spinning down the
5230	half-dozen steps of the inn. Jaffers cried in a strangled
5230	voice--holding tight, nevertheless, and making play with his
5230	knee--spun around, and fell heavily undermost with his head on
5230	the gravel. Only then did his fingers relax.
5230	
5230	There were excited cries of ""Hold him!"" ""Invisible!"" and so forth,
5230	and a young fellow, a stranger in the place whose name did not come
5230	to light, rushed in at once, caught something, missed his hold,
5230	and fell over the constable's prostrate body. Half-way across the
5230	road a woman screamed as something pushed by her; a dog, kicked
5230	apparently, yelped and ran howling into Huxter's yard, and with
5230	that the transit of the Invisible Man was accomplished. For a space
5230	people stood amazed and gesticulating, and then came panic, and
5230	scattered them abroad through the village as a gust scatters dead
5230	leaves.
5230	
5230	But Jaffers lay quite still, face upward and knees bent, at the foot
5230	of the steps of the inn.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER VIII
5230	
5230	IN TRANSIT
5230	
5230	
5230	The eighth chapter is exceedingly brief, and relates that Gibbons,
5230	the amateur naturalist of the district, while lying out on the
5230	spacious open downs without a soul within a couple of miles of him,
5230	as he thought, and almost dozing, heard close to him the sound as
5230	of a man coughing, sneezing, and then swearing savagely to himself;
5230	and looking, beheld nothing. Yet the voice was indisputable. It
5230	continued to swear with that breadth and variety that distinguishes
5230	the swearing of a cultivated man. It grew to a climax, diminished
5230	again, and died away in the distance, going as it seemed to him in
5230	the direction of Adderdean. It lifted to a spasmodic sneeze and
5230	ended. Gibbons had heard nothing of the morning's occurrences, but
5230	the phenomenon was so striking and disturbing that his philosophical
5230	tranquillity vanished; he got up hastily, and hurried down the
5230	steepness of the hill towards the village, as fast as he could go.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER IX
5230	
5230	MR. THOMAS MARVEL
5230	
5230	
5230	You must picture Mr. Thomas Marvel as a person of copious, flexible
5230	visage, a nose of cylindrical protrusion, a liquorish, ample,
5230	fluctuating mouth, and a beard of bristling eccentricity. His figure
5230	inclined to embonpoint; his short limbs accentuated this inclination.
5230	He wore a furry silk hat, and the frequent substitution of twine and
5230	shoe-laces for buttons, apparent at critical points of his costume,
5230	marked a man essentially bachelor.
5230	
5230	Mr. Thomas Marvel was sitting with his feet in a ditch by the
5230	roadside over the down towards Adderdean, about a mile and a half
5230	out of Iping. His feet, save for socks of irregular open-work, were
5230	bare, his big toes were broad, and pricked like the ears of a
5230	watchful dog. In a leisurely manner--he did everything in a
5230	leisurely manner--he was contemplating trying on a pair of boots.
5230	They were the soundest boots he had come across for a long time, but
5230	too large for him; whereas the ones he had were, in dry weather, a
5230	very comfortable fit, but too thin-soled for damp. Mr. Thomas Marvel
5230	hated roomy shoes, but then he hated damp. He had never properly
5230	thought out which he hated most, and it was a pleasant day, and
5230	there was nothing better to do. So he put the four shoes in a
5230	graceful group on the turf and looked at them. And seeing them there
5230	among the grass and springing agrimony, it suddenly occurred to him
5230	that both pairs were exceedingly ugly to see. He was not at all
5230	startled by a voice behind him.
5230	
5230	""They're boots, anyhow,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	""They are--charity boots,"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel, with his head
5230	on one side regarding them distastefully; ""and which is the ugliest
5230	pair in the whole blessed universe, I'm darned if I know!""
5230	
5230	""H'm,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	""I've worn worse--in fact, I've worn none. But none so owdacious
5230	ugly--if you'll allow the expression. I've been cadging boots--in
5230	particular--for days. Because I was sick of _them_. They're sound
5230	enough, of course. But a gentleman on tramp sees such a thundering
5230	lot of his boots. And if you'll believe me, I've raised nothing in
5230	the whole blessed country, try as I would, but _them_. Look at 'em!
5230	And a good country for boots, too, in a general way. But it's just
5230	my promiscuous luck. I've got my boots in this country ten years or
5230	more. And then they treat you like this.""
5230	
5230	""It's a beast of a country,"" said the Voice. ""And pigs for people.""
5230	
5230	""Ain't it?"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel. ""Lord! But them boots! It beats
5230	it.""
5230	
5230	He turned his head over his shoulder to the right, to look at the
5230	boots of his interlocutor with a view to comparisons, and lo! where
5230	the boots of his interlocutor should have been were neither legs
5230	nor boots. He was irradiated by the dawn of a great amazement.
5230	""Where _are_ yer?"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel over his shoulder and
5230	coming on all fours. He saw a stretch of empty downs with the wind
5230	swaying the remote green-pointed furze bushes.
5230	
5230	""Am I drunk?"" said Mr. Marvel. ""Have I had visions? Was I talking
5230	to myself? What the--""
5230	
5230	""Don't be alarmed,"" said a Voice.
5230	
5230	""None of your ventriloquising _me_,"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel, rising
5230	sharply to his feet. ""Where _are_ yer? Alarmed, indeed!""
5230	
5230	""Don't be alarmed,"" repeated the Voice.
5230	
5230	""_You'll_ be alarmed in a minute, you silly fool,"" said Mr. Thomas
5230	Marvel. ""Where _are_ yer? Lemme get my mark on yer...
5230	
5230	""Are yer _buried_?"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel, after an interval.
5230	
5230	There was no answer. Mr. Thomas Marvel stood bootless and amazed,
5230	his jacket nearly thrown off.
5230	
5230	""Peewit,"" said a peewit, very remote.
5230	
5230	""Peewit, indeed!"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel. ""This ain't no time for
5230	foolery."" The down was desolate, east and west, north and south;
5230	the road with its shallow ditches and white bordering stakes, ran
5230	smooth and empty north and south, and, save for that peewit, the
5230	blue sky was empty too. ""So help me,"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel,
5230	shuffling his coat on to his shoulders again. ""It's the drink!
5230	I might ha' known.""
5230	
5230	""It's not the drink,"" said the Voice. ""You keep your nerves
5230	steady.""
5230	
5230	""Ow!"" said Mr. Marvel, and his face grew white amidst its patches.
5230	""It's the drink!"" his lips repeated noiselessly. He remained staring
5230	about him, rotating slowly backwards. ""I could have _swore_ I heard
5230	a voice,"" he whispered.
5230	
5230	""Of course you did.""
5230	
5230	""It's there again,"" said Mr. Marvel, closing his eyes and clasping
5230	his hand on his brow with a tragic gesture. He was suddenly taken
5230	by the collar and shaken violently, and left more dazed than ever.
5230	""Don't be a fool,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	""I'm--off--my--blooming--chump,"" said Mr. Marvel. ""It's no good.
5230	It's fretting about them blarsted boots. I'm off my blessed blooming
5230	chump. Or it's spirits.""
5230	
5230	""Neither one thing nor the other,"" said the Voice. ""Listen!""
5230	
5230	""Chump,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""One minute,"" said the Voice, penetratingly, tremulous with
5230	self-control.
5230	
5230	""Well?"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel, with a strange feeling of having
5230	been dug in the chest by a finger.
5230	
5230	""You think I'm just imagination? Just imagination?""
5230	
5230	""What else _can_ you be?"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel, rubbing the back of
5230	his neck.
5230	
5230	""Very well,"" said the Voice, in a tone of relief. ""Then I'm going
5230	to throw flints at you till you think differently.""
5230	
5230	""But where _are_ yer?""
5230	
5230	The Voice made no answer. Whizz came a flint, apparently out of
5230	the air, and missed Mr. Marvel's shoulder by a hair's-breadth.
5230	Mr. Marvel, turning, saw a flint jerk up into the air, trace a
5230	complicated path, hang for a moment, and then fling at his feet
5230	with almost invisible rapidity. He was too amazed to dodge. Whizz
5230	it came, and ricochetted from a bare toe into the ditch. Mr. Thomas
5230	Marvel jumped a foot and howled aloud. Then he started to run,
5230	tripped over an unseen obstacle, and came head over heels into a
5230	sitting position.
5230	
5230	""_Now_,"" said the Voice, as a third stone curved upward and hung in
5230	the air above the tramp. ""Am I imagination?""
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel by way of reply struggled to his feet, and was
5230	immediately rolled over again. He lay quiet for a moment. ""If you
5230	struggle any more,"" said the Voice, ""I shall throw the flint at
5230	your head.""
5230	
5230	""It's a fair do,"" said Mr. Thomas Marvel, sitting up, taking his
5230	wounded toe in hand and fixing his eye on the third missile. ""I
5230	don't understand it. Stones flinging themselves. Stones talking.
5230	Put yourself down. Rot away. I'm done.""
5230	
5230	The third flint fell.
5230	
5230	""It's very simple,"" said the Voice. ""I'm an invisible man.""
5230	
5230	""Tell us something I don't know,"" said Mr. Marvel, gasping with
5230	pain. ""Where you've hid--how you do it--I _don't_ know. I'm beat.""
5230	
5230	""That's all,"" said the Voice. ""I'm invisible. That's what I want
5230	you to understand.""
5230	
5230	""Anyone could see that. There is no need for you to be so confounded
5230	impatient, mister. _Now_ then. Give us a notion. How are you hid?""
5230	
5230	""I'm invisible. That's the great point. And what I want you to
5230	understand is this--""
5230	
5230	""But whereabouts?"" interrupted Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""Here! Six yards in front of you.""
5230	
5230	""Oh, _come_! I ain't blind. You'll be telling me next you're just
5230	thin air. I'm not one of your ignorant tramps--""
5230	
5230	""Yes, I am--thin air. You're looking through me.""
5230	
5230	""What! Ain't there any stuff to you. _Vox et_--what is it?--jabber.
5230	Is it that?""
5230	
5230	""I am just a human being--solid, needing food and drink, needing
5230	covering too--But I'm invisible. You see? Invisible. Simple idea.
5230	Invisible.""
5230	
5230	""What, real like?""
5230	
5230	""Yes, real.""
5230	
5230	""Let's have a hand of you,"" said Marvel, ""if you _are_ real. It won't
5230	be so darn out-of-the-way like, then--_Lord_!"" he said, ""how you made
5230	me jump!--gripping me like that!""
5230	
5230	He felt the hand that had closed round his wrist with his disengaged
5230	fingers, and his fingers went timorously up the arm, patted a
5230	muscular chest, and explored a bearded face. Marvel's face was
5230	astonishment.
5230	
5230	""I'm dashed!"" he said. ""If this don't beat cock-fighting! Most
5230	remarkable!--And there I can see a rabbit clean through you, 'arf
5230	a mile away! Not a bit of you visible--except--""
5230	
5230	He scrutinised the apparently empty space keenly. ""You 'aven't been
5230	eatin' bread and cheese?"" he asked, holding the invisible arm.
5230	
5230	""You're quite right, and it's not quite assimilated into the system.""
5230	
5230	""Ah!"" said Mr. Marvel. ""Sort of ghostly, though.""
5230	
5230	""Of course, all this isn't half so wonderful as you think.""
5230	
5230	""It's quite wonderful enough for _my_ modest wants,"" said Mr. Thomas
5230	Marvel. ""Howjer manage it! How the dooce is it done?""
5230	
5230	""It's too long a story. And besides--""
5230	
5230	""I tell you, the whole business fairly beats me,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""What I want to say at present is this: I need help. I have come to
5230	that--I came upon you suddenly. I was wandering, mad with rage,
5230	naked, impotent. I could have murdered. And I saw you--""
5230	
5230	""_Lord_!"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""I came up behind you--hesitated--went on--""
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel's expression was eloquent.
5230	
5230	""--then stopped. 'Here,' I said, 'is an outcast like myself. This is
5230	the man for me.' So I turned back and came to you--you. And--""
5230	
5230	""_Lord_!"" said Mr. Marvel. ""But I'm all in a tizzy. May I ask--How
5230	is it? And what you may be requiring in the way of help?--Invisible!""
5230	
5230	""I want you to help me get clothes--and shelter--and then, with
5230	other things. I've left them long enough. If you won't--well! But
5230	you _will--must_.""
5230	
5230	""Look here,"" said Mr. Marvel. ""I'm too flabbergasted. Don't knock
5230	me about any more. And leave me go. I must get steady a bit. And
5230	you've pretty near broken my toe. It's all so unreasonable. Empty
5230	downs, empty sky. Nothing visible for miles except the bosom of
5230	Nature. And then comes a voice. A voice out of heaven! And stones!
5230	And a fist--Lord!""
5230	
5230	""Pull yourself together,"" said the Voice, ""for you have to do the
5230	job I've chosen for you.""
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel blew out his cheeks, and his eyes were round.
5230	
5230	""I've chosen you,"" said the Voice. ""You are the only man except
5230	some of those fools down there, who knows there is such a thing as
5230	an invisible man. You have to be my helper. Help me--and I will
5230	do great things for you. An invisible man is a man of power."" He
5230	stopped for a moment to sneeze violently.
5230	
5230	""But if you betray me,"" he said, ""if you fail to do as I direct you--""
5230	He paused and tapped Mr. Marvel's shoulder smartly. Mr. Marvel
5230	gave a yelp of terror at the touch. ""I don't want to betray you,""
5230	said Mr. Marvel, edging away from the direction of the fingers.
5230	""Don't you go a-thinking that, whatever you do. All I want to do is
5230	to help you--just tell me what I got to do. (Lord!) Whatever you
5230	want done, that I'm most willing to do.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER X
5230	
5230	MR. MARVEL'S VISIT TO IPING
5230	
5230	
5230	After the first gusty panic had spent itself Iping became
5230	argumentative. Scepticism suddenly reared its head--rather nervous
5230	scepticism, not at all assured of its back, but scepticism
5230	nevertheless. It is so much easier not to believe in an invisible
5230	man; and those who had actually seen him dissolve into air, or felt
5230	the strength of his arm, could be counted on the fingers of two
5230	hands. And of these witnesses Mr. Wadgers was presently missing,
5230	having retired impregnably behind the bolts and bars of his own
5230	house, and Jaffers was lying stunned in the parlour of the ""Coach
5230	and Horses."" Great and strange ideas transcending experience often
5230	have less effect upon men and women than smaller, more tangible
5230	considerations. Iping was gay with bunting, and everybody was in
5230	gala dress. Whit Monday had been looked forward to for a month or
5230	more. By the afternoon even those who believed in the Unseen were
5230	beginning to resume their little amusements in a tentative fashion,
5230	on the supposition that he had quite gone away, and with the
5230	sceptics he was already a jest. But people, sceptics and believers
5230	alike, were remarkably sociable all that day.
5230	
5230	Haysman's meadow was gay with a tent, in which Mrs. Bunting and
5230	other ladies were preparing tea, while, without, the Sunday-school
5230	children ran races and played games under the noisy guidance of the
5230	curate and the Misses Cuss and Sackbut. No doubt there was a slight
5230	uneasiness in the air, but people for the most part had the sense
5230	to conceal whatever imaginative qualms they experienced. On the
5230	village green an inclined strong [rope?], down which, clinging
5230	the while to a pulley-swung handle, one could be hurled violently against
5230	a sack at the other end, came in for considerable favour among the
5230	adolescents, as also did the swings and the cocoanut shies. There
5230	was also promenading, and the steam organ attached to a small
5230	roundabout filled the air with a pungent flavour of oil and with
5230	equally pungent music. Members of the club, who had attended
5230	church in the morning, were splendid in badges of pink and green,
5230	and some of the gayer-minded had also adorned their bowler hats
5230	with brilliant-coloured favours of ribbon. Old Fletcher, whose
5230	conceptions of holiday-making were severe, was visible through the
5230	jasmine about his window or through the open door (whichever way
5230	you chose to look), poised delicately on a plank supported on two
5230	chairs, and whitewashing the ceiling of his front room.
5230	
5230	About four o'clock a stranger entered the village from the direction
5230	of the downs. He was a short, stout person in an extraordinarily
5230	shabby top hat, and he appeared to be very much out of breath. His
5230	cheeks were alternately limp and tightly puffed. His mottled face
5230	was apprehensive, and he moved with a sort of reluctant alacrity. He
5230	turned the corner of the church, and directed his way to the ""Coach
5230	and Horses."" Among others old Fletcher remembers seeing him, and
5230	indeed the old gentleman was so struck by his peculiar agitation
5230	that he inadvertently allowed a quantity of whitewash to run down
5230	the brush into the sleeve of his coat while regarding him.
5230	
5230	This stranger, to the perceptions of the proprietor of the cocoanut
5230	shy, appeared to be talking to himself, and Mr. Huxter remarked the
5230	same thing. He stopped at the foot of the ""Coach and Horses"" steps,
5230	and, according to Mr. Huxter, appeared to undergo a severe internal
5230	struggle before he could induce himself to enter the house. Finally
5230	he marched up the steps, and was seen by Mr. Huxter to turn to the
5230	left and open the door of the parlour. Mr. Huxter heard voices from
5230	within the room and from the bar apprising the man of his error.
5230	""That room's private!"" said Hall, and the stranger shut the door
5230	clumsily and went into the bar.
5230	
5230	In the course of a few minutes he reappeared, wiping his lips with
5230	the back of his hand with an air of quiet satisfaction that somehow
5230	impressed Mr. Huxter as assumed. He stood looking about him for
5230	some moments, and then Mr. Huxter saw him walk in an oddly furtive
5230	manner towards the gates of the yard, upon which the parlour window
5230	opened. The stranger, after some hesitation, leant against one of
5230	the gate-posts, produced a short clay pipe, and prepared to fill
5230	it. His fingers trembled while doing so. He lit it clumsily, and
5230	folding his arms began to smoke in a languid attitude, an attitude
5230	which his occasional glances up the yard altogether belied.
5230	
5230	All this Mr. Huxter saw over the canisters of the tobacco window,
5230	and the singularity of the man's behaviour prompted him to maintain
5230	his observation.
5230	
5230	Presently the stranger stood up abruptly and put his pipe in his
5230	pocket. Then he vanished into the yard. Forthwith Mr. Huxter,
5230	conceiving he was witness of some petty larceny, leapt round his
5230	counter and ran out into the road to intercept the thief. As he did
5230	so, Mr. Marvel reappeared, his hat askew, a big bundle in a blue
5230	table-cloth in one hand, and three books tied together--as it proved
5230	afterwards with the Vicar's braces--in the other. Directly he saw
5230	Huxter he gave a sort of gasp, and turning sharply to the left,
5230	began to run. ""Stop, thief!"" cried Huxter, and set off after him.
5230	Mr. Huxter's sensations were vivid but brief. He saw the man just
5230	before him and spurting briskly for the church corner and the hill
5230	road. He saw the village flags and festivities beyond, and a face or
5230	so turned towards him. He bawled, ""Stop!"" again. He had hardly gone
5230	ten strides before his shin was caught in some mysterious fashion,
5230	and he was no longer running, but flying with inconceivable rapidity
5230	through the air. He saw the ground suddenly close to his face. The
5230	world seemed to splash into a million whirling specks of light, and
5230	subsequent proceedings interested him no more.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XI
5230	
5230	IN THE ""COACH AND HORSES""
5230	
5230	
5230	Now in order clearly to understand what had happened in the inn, it
5230	is necessary to go back to the moment when Mr. Marvel first came
5230	into view of Mr. Huxter's window.
5230	
5230	At that precise moment Mr. Cuss and Mr. Bunting were in the parlour.
5230	They were seriously investigating the strange occurrences of the
5230	morning, and were, with Mr. Hall's permission, making a thorough
5230	examination of the Invisible Man's belongings. Jaffers had partially
5230	recovered from his fall and had gone home in the charge of his
5230	sympathetic friends. The stranger's scattered garments had been
5230	removed by Mrs. Hall and the room tidied up. And on the table under
5230	the window where the stranger had been wont to work, Cuss had hit
5230	almost at once on three big books in manuscript labelled ""Diary.""
5230	
5230	""Diary!"" said Cuss, putting the three books on the table. ""Now, at
5230	any rate, we shall learn something."" The Vicar stood with his hands
5230	on the table.
5230	
5230	""Diary,"" repeated Cuss, sitting down, putting two volumes to
5230	support the third, and opening it. ""H'm--no name on the fly-leaf.
5230	Bother!--cypher. And figures.""
5230	
5230	The vicar came round to look over his shoulder.
5230	
5230	Cuss turned the pages over with a face suddenly disappointed.
5230	""I'm--dear me! It's all cypher, Bunting.""
5230	
5230	""There are no diagrams?"" asked Mr. Bunting. ""No illustrations
5230	throwing light--""
5230	
5230	""See for yourself,"" said Mr. Cuss. ""Some of it's mathematical and
5230	some of it's Russian or some such language (to judge by the
5230	letters), and some of it's Greek. Now the Greek I thought _you_--""
5230	
5230	""Of course,"" said Mr. Bunting, taking out and wiping his spectacles
5230	and feeling suddenly very uncomfortable--for he had no Greek
5230	left in his mind worth talking about; ""yes--the Greek, of course,
5230	may furnish a clue.""
5230	
5230	""I'll find you a place.""
5230	
5230	""I'd rather glance through the volumes first,"" said Mr. Bunting,
5230	still wiping. ""A general impression first, Cuss, and _then_, you
5230	know, we can go looking for clues.""
5230	
5230	He coughed, put on his glasses, arranged them fastidiously, coughed
5230	again, and wished something would happen to avert the seemingly
5230	inevitable exposure. Then he took the volume Cuss handed him in a
5230	leisurely manner. And then something did happen.
5230	
5230	The door opened suddenly.
5230	
5230	Both gentlemen started violently, looked round, and were relieved
5230	to see a sporadically rosy face beneath a furry silk hat. ""Tap?""
5230	asked the face, and stood staring.
5230	
5230	""No,"" said both gentlemen at once.
5230	
5230	""Over the other side, my man,"" said Mr. Bunting. And ""Please shut
5230	that door,"" said Mr. Cuss, irritably.
5230	
5230	""All right,"" said the intruder, as it seemed in a low voice
5230	curiously different from the huskiness of its first inquiry. ""Right
5230	you are,"" said the intruder in the former voice. ""Stand clear!"" and
5230	he vanished and closed the door.
5230	
5230	""A sailor, I should judge,"" said Mr. Bunting. ""Amusing fellows, they
5230	are. Stand clear! indeed. A nautical term, referring to his getting
5230	back out of the room, I suppose.""
5230	
5230	""I daresay so,"" said Cuss. ""My nerves are all loose to-day. It quite
5230	made me jump--the door opening like that.""
5230	
5230	Mr. Bunting smiled as if he had not jumped. ""And now,"" he said with
5230	a sigh, ""these books.""
5230	
5230	Someone sniffed as he did so.
5230	
5230	""One thing is indisputable,"" said Bunting, drawing up a chair next
5230	to that of Cuss. ""There certainly have been very strange things
5230	happen in Iping during the last few days--very strange. I cannot
5230	of course believe in this absurd invisibility story--""
5230	
5230	""It's incredible,"" said Cuss--""incredible. But the fact remains
5230	that I saw--I certainly saw right down his sleeve--""
5230	
5230	""But did you--are you sure? Suppose a mirror, for instance--
5230	hallucinations are so easily produced. I don't know if you
5230	have ever seen a really good conjuror--""
5230	
5230	""I won't argue again,"" said Cuss. ""We've thrashed that out,
5230	Bunting. And just now there's these books--Ah! here's some of
5230	what I take to be Greek! Greek letters certainly.""
5230	
5230	He pointed to the middle of the page. Mr. Bunting flushed slightly
5230	and brought his face nearer, apparently finding some difficulty
5230	with his glasses. Suddenly he became aware of a strange feeling at
5230	the nape of his neck. He tried to raise his head, and encountered
5230	an immovable resistance. The feeling was a curious pressure, the
5230	grip of a heavy, firm hand, and it bore his chin irresistibly to
5230	the table. ""Don't move, little men,"" whispered a voice, ""or I'll
5230	brain you both!"" He looked into the face of Cuss, close to his own,
5230	and each saw a horrified reflection of his own sickly astonishment.
5230	
5230	""I'm sorry to handle you so roughly,"" said the Voice, ""but it's
5230	unavoidable.""
5230	
5230	""Since when did you learn to pry into an investigator's private
5230	memoranda,"" said the Voice; and two chins struck the table
5230	simultaneously, and two sets of teeth rattled.
5230	
5230	""Since when did you learn to invade the private rooms of a man in
5230	misfortune?"" and the concussion was repeated.
5230	
5230	""Where have they put my clothes?""
5230	
5230	""Listen,"" said the Voice. ""The windows are fastened and I've taken
5230	the key out of the door. I am a fairly strong man, and I have the
5230	poker handy--besides being invisible. There's not the slightest
5230	doubt that I could kill you both and get away quite easily if I
5230	wanted to--do you understand? Very well. If I let you go will you
5230	promise not to try any nonsense and do what I tell you?""
5230	
5230	The vicar and the doctor looked at one another, and the doctor
5230	pulled a face. ""Yes,"" said Mr. Bunting, and the doctor repeated it.
5230	Then the pressure on the necks relaxed, and the doctor and the
5230	vicar sat up, both very red in the face and wriggling their heads.
5230	
5230	""Please keep sitting where you are,"" said the Invisible Man.
5230	""Here's the poker, you see.""
5230	
5230	""When I came into this room,"" continued the Invisible Man, after
5230	presenting the poker to the tip of the nose of each of his visitors,
5230	""I did not expect to find it occupied, and I expected to find, in
5230	addition to my books of memoranda, an outfit of clothing. Where is
5230	it? No--don't rise. I can see it's gone. Now, just at present,
5230	though the days are quite warm enough for an invisible man to run
5230	about stark, the evenings are quite chilly. I want clothing--and
5230	other accommodation; and I must also have those three books.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XII
5230	
5230	THE INVISIBLE MAN LOSES HIS TEMPER
5230	
5230	
5230	It is unavoidable that at this point the narrative should break off
5230	again, for a certain very painful reason that will presently be
5230	apparent. While these things were going on in the parlour, and
5230	while Mr. Huxter was watching Mr. Marvel smoking his pipe against
5230	the gate, not a dozen yards away were Mr. Hall and Teddy Henfrey
5230	discussing in a state of cloudy puzzlement the one Iping topic.
5230	
5230	Suddenly there came a violent thud against the door of the parlour,
5230	a sharp cry, and then--silence.
5230	
5230	""Hul-lo!"" said Teddy Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""Hul-lo!"" from the Tap.
5230	
5230	Mr. Hall took things in slowly but surely. ""That ain't right,"" he
5230	said, and came round from behind the bar towards the parlour door.
5230	
5230	He and Teddy approached the door together, with intent faces. Their
5230	eyes considered. ""Summat wrong,"" said Hall, and Henfrey nodded
5230	agreement. Whiffs of an unpleasant chemical odour met them, and
5230	there was a muffled sound of conversation, very rapid and subdued.
5230	
5230	""You all right thur?"" asked Hall, rapping.
5230	
5230	The muttered conversation ceased abruptly, for a moment silence,
5230	then the conversation was resumed, in hissing whispers, then a
5230	sharp cry of ""No! no, you don't!"" There came a sudden motion and
5230	the oversetting of a chair, a brief struggle. Silence again.
5230	
5230	""What the dooce?"" exclaimed Henfrey, _sotto voce_.
5230	
5230	""You--all--right thur?"" asked Mr. Hall, sharply, again.
5230	
5230	The Vicar's voice answered with a curious jerking intonation:
5230	""Quite ri-right. Please don't--interrupt.""
5230	
5230	""Odd!"" said Mr. Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""Odd!"" said Mr. Hall.
5230	
5230	""Says, 'Don't interrupt,'"" said Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""I heerd'n,"" said Hall.
5230	
5230	""And a sniff,"" said Henfrey.
5230	
5230	They remained listening. The conversation was rapid and subdued.
5230	""I _can't_,"" said Mr. Bunting, his voice rising; ""I tell you, sir,
5230	I _will_ not.""
5230	
5230	""What was that?"" asked Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""Says he wi' nart,"" said Hall. ""Warn't speaking to us, wuz he?""
5230	
5230	""Disgraceful!"" said Mr. Bunting, within.
5230	
5230	""'Disgraceful,'"" said Mr. Henfrey. ""I heard it--distinct.""
5230	
5230	""Who's that speaking now?"" asked Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""Mr. Cuss, I s'pose,"" said Hall. ""Can you hear--anything?""
5230	
5230	Silence. The sounds within indistinct and perplexing.
5230	
5230	""Sounds like throwing the table-cloth about,"" said Hall.
5230	
5230	Mrs. Hall appeared behind the bar. Hall made gestures of silence and
5230	invitation. This aroused Mrs. Hall's wifely opposition. ""What yer
5230	listenin' there for, Hall?"" she asked. ""Ain't you nothin' better to
5230	do--busy day like this?""
5230	
5230	Hall tried to convey everything by grimaces and dumb show, but Mrs.
5230	Hall was obdurate. She raised her voice. So Hall and Henfrey, rather
5230	crestfallen, tiptoed back to the bar, gesticulating to explain to
5230	her.
5230	
5230	At first she refused to see anything in what they had heard at
5230	all. Then she insisted on Hall keeping silence, while Henfrey told
5230	her his story. She was inclined to think the whole business
5230	nonsense--perhaps they were just moving the furniture about. ""I
5230	heerd'n say 'disgraceful'; _that_ I did,"" said Hall.
5230	
5230	""_I_ heerd that, Mrs. Hall,"" said Henfrey.
5230	
5230	""Like as not--"" began Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	""Hsh!"" said Mr. Teddy Henfrey. ""Didn't I hear the window?""
5230	
5230	""What window?"" asked Mrs. Hall.
5230	
5230	""Parlour window,"" said Henfrey.
5230	
5230	Everyone stood listening intently. Mrs. Hall's eyes, directed
5230	straight before her, saw without seeing the brilliant oblong of the
5230	inn door, the road white and vivid, and Huxter's shop-front
5230	blistering in the June sun. Abruptly Huxter's door opened and Huxter
5230	appeared, eyes staring with excitement, arms gesticulating. ""Yap!""
5230	cried Huxter. ""Stop thief!"" and he ran obliquely across the oblong
5230	towards the yard gates, and vanished.
5230	
5230	Simultaneously came a tumult from the parlour, and a sound of
5230	windows being closed.
5230	
5230	Hall, Henfrey, and the human contents of the tap rushed out at once
5230	pell-mell into the street. They saw someone whisk round the corner
5230	towards the road, and Mr. Huxter executing a complicated leap in
5230	the air that ended on his face and shoulder. Down the street people
5230	were standing astonished or running towards them.
5230	
5230	Mr. Huxter was stunned. Henfrey stopped to discover this, but Hall
5230	and the two labourers from the Tap rushed at once to the corner,
5230	shouting incoherent things, and saw Mr. Marvel vanishing by the
5230	corner of the church wall. They appear to have jumped to the
5230	impossible conclusion that this was the Invisible Man suddenly
5230	become visible, and set off at once along the lane in pursuit. But
5230	Hall had hardly run a dozen yards before he gave a loud shout of
5230	astonishment and went flying headlong sideways, clutching one of
5230	the labourers and bringing him to the ground. He had been charged
5230	just as one charges a man at football. The second labourer came
5230	round in a circle, stared, and conceiving that Hall had tumbled
5230	over of his own accord, turned to resume the pursuit, only to be
5230	tripped by the ankle just as Huxter had been. Then, as the first
5230	labourer struggled to his feet, he was kicked sideways by a blow
5230	that might have felled an ox.
5230	
5230	As he went down, the rush from the direction of the village green
5230	came round the corner. The first to appear was the proprietor of
5230	the cocoanut shy, a burly man in a blue jersey. He was astonished
5230	to see the lane empty save for three men sprawling absurdly on the
5230	ground. And then something happened to his rear-most foot, and he
5230	went headlong and rolled sideways just in time to graze the feet
5230	of his brother and partner, following headlong. The two were then
5230	kicked, knelt on, fallen over, and cursed by quite a number of
5230	over-hasty people.
5230	
5230	Now when Hall and Henfrey and the labourers ran out of the house,
5230	Mrs. Hall, who had been disciplined by years of experience,
5230	remained in the bar next the till. And suddenly the parlour door
5230	was opened, and Mr. Cuss appeared, and without glancing at her
5230	rushed at once down the steps toward the corner. ""Hold him!"" he
5230	cried. ""Don't let him drop that parcel.""
5230	
5230	He knew nothing of the
5230	existence of Marvel. For the Invisible Man had handed over the
5230	books and bundle in the yard. The face of Mr. Cuss was angry and
5230	resolute, but his costume was defective, a sort of limp white kilt
5230	that could only have passed muster in Greece. ""Hold him!"" he
5230	bawled. ""He's got my trousers! And every stitch of the Vicar's
5230	clothes!""
5230	
5230	""'Tend to him in a minute!"" he cried to Henfrey as he passed the
5230	prostrate Huxter, and, coming round the corner to join the tumult,
5230	was promptly knocked off his feet into an indecorous sprawl.
5230	Somebody in full flight trod heavily on his finger. He yelled,
5230	struggled to regain his feet, was knocked against and thrown on all
5230	fours again, and became aware that he was involved not in a capture,
5230	but a rout. Everyone was running back to the village. He rose again
5230	and was hit severely behind the ear. He staggered and set off back
5230	to the ""Coach and Horses"" forthwith, leaping over the deserted
5230	Huxter, who was now sitting up, on his way.
5230	
5230	Behind him as he was halfway up the inn steps he heard a sudden
5230	yell of rage, rising sharply out of the confusion of cries, and a
5230	sounding smack in someone's face. He recognised the voice as that
5230	of the Invisible Man, and the note was that of a man suddenly
5230	infuriated by a painful blow.
5230	
5230	In another moment Mr. Cuss was back in the parlour. ""He's coming
5230	back, Bunting!"" he said, rushing in. ""Save yourself!""
5230	
5230	Mr. Bunting was standing in the window engaged in an attempt to
5230	clothe himself in the hearth-rug and a _West Surrey Gazette_. ""Who's
5230	coming?"" he said, so startled that his costume narrowly escaped
5230	disintegration.
5230	
5230	""Invisible Man,"" said Cuss, and rushed on to the window. ""We'd
5230	better clear out from here! He's fighting mad! Mad!""
5230	
5230	In another moment he was out in the yard.
5230	
5230	""Good heavens!"" said Mr. Bunting, hesitating between two horrible
5230	alternatives. He heard a frightful struggle in the passage of the
5230	inn, and his decision was made. He clambered out of the window,
5230	adjusted his costume hastily, and fled up the village as fast as
5230	his fat little legs would carry him.
5230	
5230	From the moment when the Invisible Man screamed with rage and Mr.
5230	Bunting made his memorable flight up the village, it became
5230	impossible to give a consecutive account of affairs in Iping.
5230	Possibly the Invisible Man's original intention was simply to cover
5230	Marvel's retreat with the clothes and books. But his temper, at no
5230	time very good, seems to have gone completely at some chance blow,
5230	and forthwith he set to smiting and overthrowing, for the mere
5230	satisfaction of hurting.
5230	
5230	You must figure the street full of running figures, of doors
5230	slamming and fights for hiding-places. You must figure the tumult
5230	suddenly striking on the unstable equilibrium of old Fletcher's
5230	planks and two chairs--with cataclysmic results. You must figure
5230	an appalled couple caught dismally in a swing. And then the whole
5230	tumultuous rush has passed and the Iping street with its gauds and
5230	flags is deserted save for the still raging unseen, and littered
5230	with cocoanuts, overthrown canvas screens, and the scattered stock
5230	in trade of a sweetstuff stall. Everywhere there is a sound of
5230	closing shutters and shoving bolts, and the only visible humanity
5230	is an occasional flitting eye under a raised eyebrow in the corner
5230	of a window pane.
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man amused himself for a little while by breaking all
5230	the windows in the ""Coach and Horses,"" and then he thrust a street
5230	lamp through the parlour window of Mrs. Gribble. He it must have
5230	been who cut the telegraph wire to Adderdean just beyond Higgins'
5230	cottage on the Adderdean road. And after that, as his peculiar
5230	qualities allowed, he passed out of human perceptions altogether,
5230	and he was neither heard, seen, nor felt in Iping any more. He
5230	vanished absolutely.
5230	
5230	But it was the best part of two hours before any human being
5230	ventured out again into the desolation of Iping street.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XIII
5230	
5230	MR. MARVEL DISCUSSES HIS RESIGNATION
5230	
5230	
5230	When the dusk was gathering and Iping was just beginning to peep
5230	timorously forth again upon the shattered wreckage of its Bank
5230	Holiday, a short, thick-set man in a shabby silk hat was marching
5230	painfully through the twilight behind the beechwoods on the road to
5230	Bramblehurst. He carried three books bound together by some sort
5230	of ornamental elastic ligature, and a bundle wrapped in a blue
5230	table-cloth. His rubicund face expressed consternation and fatigue;
5230	he appeared to be in a spasmodic sort of hurry. He was accompanied
5230	by a voice other than his own, and ever and again he winced under
5230	the touch of unseen hands.
5230	
5230	""If you give me the slip again,"" said the Voice, ""if you attempt to
5230	give me the slip again--""
5230	
5230	""Lord!"" said Mr. Marvel. ""That shoulder's a mass of bruises as it
5230	is.""
5230	
5230	""On my honour,"" said the Voice, ""I will kill you.""
5230	
5230	""I didn't try to give you the slip,"" said Marvel, in a voice that
5230	was not far remote from tears. ""I swear I didn't. I didn't know the
5230	blessed turning, that was all! How the devil was I to know the
5230	blessed turning? As it is, I've been knocked about--""
5230	
5230	""You'll get knocked about a great deal more if you don't mind,""
5230	said the Voice, and Mr. Marvel abruptly became silent. He blew out
5230	his cheeks, and his eyes were eloquent of despair.
5230	
5230	""It's bad enough to let these floundering yokels explode my little
5230	secret, without _your_ cutting off with my books. It's lucky for some
5230	of them they cut and ran when they did! Here am I ... No one knew I
5230	was invisible! And now what am I to do?""
5230	
5230	""What am _I_ to do?"" asked Marvel, _sotto voce_.
5230	
5230	""It's all about. It will be in the papers! Everybody will be
5230	looking for me; everyone on their guard--"" The Voice broke off
5230	into vivid curses and ceased.
5230	
5230	The despair of Mr. Marvel's face deepened, and his pace slackened.
5230	
5230	""Go on!"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel's face assumed a greyish tint between the ruddier
5230	patches.
5230	
5230	""Don't drop those books, stupid,"" said the Voice, sharply--overtaking
5230	him.
5230	
5230	""The fact is,"" said the Voice, ""I shall have to make use of you....
5230	You're a poor tool, but I must.""
5230	
5230	""I'm a _miserable_ tool,"" said Marvel.
5230	
5230	""You are,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	""I'm the worst possible tool you could have,"" said Marvel.
5230	
5230	""I'm not strong,"" he said after a discouraging silence.
5230	
5230	""I'm not over strong,"" he repeated.
5230	
5230	""No?""
5230	
5230	""And my heart's weak. That little business--I pulled it through,
5230	of course--but bless you! I could have dropped.""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""I haven't the nerve and strength for the sort of thing you want.""
5230	
5230	""_I'll_ stimulate you.""
5230	
5230	""I wish you wouldn't. I wouldn't like to mess up your plans, you
5230	know. But I might--out of sheer funk and misery.""
5230	
5230	""You'd better not,"" said the Voice, with quiet emphasis.
5230	
5230	""I wish I was dead,"" said Marvel.
5230	
5230	""It ain't justice,"" he said; ""you must admit.... It seems to me I've
5230	a perfect right--""
5230	
5230	""_Get_ on!"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel mended his pace, and for a time they went in silence
5230	again.
5230	
5230	""It's devilish hard,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	This was quite ineffectual. He tried another tack.
5230	
5230	""What do I make by it?"" he began again in a tone of unendurable
5230	wrong.
5230	
5230	""Oh! _shut up_!"" said the Voice, with sudden amazing vigour. ""I'll
5230	see to you all right. You do what you're told. You'll do it all
5230	right. You're a fool and all that, but you'll do--""
5230	
5230	""I tell you, sir, I'm not the man for it. Respectfully--but
5230	it _is_ so--""
5230	
5230	""If you don't shut up I shall twist your wrist again,"" said the
5230	Invisible Man. ""I want to think.""
5230	
5230	Presently two oblongs of yellow light appeared through the trees,
5230	and the square tower of a church loomed through the gloaming. ""I
5230	shall keep my hand on your shoulder,"" said the Voice, ""all through
5230	the village. Go straight through and try no foolery. It will be the
5230	worse for you if you do.""
5230	
5230	""I know that,"" sighed Mr. Marvel, ""I know all that.""
5230	
5230	The unhappy-looking figure in the obsolete silk hat passed up the
5230	street of the little village with his burdens, and vanished into
5230	the gathering darkness beyond the lights of the windows.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XIV
5230	
5230	AT PORT STOWE
5230	
5230	
5230	Ten o'clock the next morning found Mr. Marvel, unshaven, dirty, and
5230	travel-stained, sitting with the books beside him and his hands deep
5230	in his pockets, looking very weary, nervous, and uncomfortable, and
5230	inflating his cheeks at infrequent intervals, on the bench outside
5230	a little inn on the outskirts of Port Stowe. Beside him were the
5230	books, but now they were tied with string. The bundle had been
5230	abandoned in the pine-woods beyond Bramblehurst, in accordance with
5230	a change in the plans of the Invisible Man. Mr. Marvel sat on the
5230	bench, and although no one took the slightest notice of him, his
5230	agitation remained at fever heat. His hands would go ever and again
5230	to his various pockets with a curious nervous fumbling.
5230	
5230	When he had been sitting for the best part of an hour, however, an
5230	elderly mariner, carrying a newspaper, came out of the inn and sat
5230	down beside him. ""Pleasant day,"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel glanced about him with something very like terror.
5230	""Very,"" he said.
5230	
5230	""Just seasonable weather for the time of year,"" said the mariner,
5230	taking no denial.
5230	
5230	""Quite,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	The mariner produced a toothpick, and (saving his regard) was
5230	engrossed thereby for some minutes. His eyes meanwhile were at
5230	liberty to examine Mr. Marvel's dusty figure, and the books beside
5230	him. As he had approached Mr. Marvel he had heard a sound like the
5230	dropping of coins into a pocket. He was struck by the contrast of
5230	Mr. Marvel's appearance with this suggestion of opulence. Thence
5230	his mind wandered back again to a topic that had taken a curiously
5230	firm hold of his imagination.
5230	
5230	""Books?"" he said suddenly, noisily finishing with the toothpick.
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel started and looked at them. ""Oh, yes,"" he said. ""Yes,
5230	they're books.""
5230	
5230	""There's some extra-ordinary things in books,"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""I believe you,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""And some extra-ordinary things out of 'em,"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""True likewise,"" said Mr. Marvel. He eyed his interlocutor, and
5230	then glanced about him.
5230	
5230	""There's some extra-ordinary things in newspapers, for example,""
5230	said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""There are.""
5230	
5230	""In _this_ newspaper,"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""Ah!"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""There's a story,"" said the mariner, fixing Mr. Marvel with an eye
5230	that was firm and deliberate; ""there's a story about an Invisible
5230	Man, for instance.""
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel pulled his mouth askew and scratched his cheek and felt
5230	his ears glowing. ""What will they be writing next?"" he asked
5230	faintly. ""Ostria, or America?""
5230	
5230	""Neither,"" said the mariner. ""_Here_.""
5230	
5230	""Lord!"" said Mr. Marvel, starting.
5230	
5230	""When I say _here_,"" said the mariner, to Mr. Marvel's intense
5230	relief, ""I don't of course mean here in this place, I mean
5230	hereabouts.""
5230	
5230	""An Invisible Man!"" said Mr. Marvel. ""And what's _he_ been up to?""
5230	
5230	""Everything,"" said the mariner, controlling Marvel with his eye,
5230	and then amplifying, ""every--blessed--thing.""
5230	
5230	""I ain't seen a paper these four days,"" said Marvel.
5230	
5230	""Iping's the place he started at,"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""In-_deed_!"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""He started there. And where he came from, nobody don't seem to
5230	know. Here it is: 'Pe-culiar Story from Iping.' And it says in this
5230	paper that the evidence is extra-ordinary strong--extra-ordinary.""
5230	
5230	""Lord!"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""But then, it's an extra-ordinary story. There is a clergyman and a
5230	medical gent witnesses--saw 'im all right and proper--or leastways
5230	didn't see 'im. He was staying, it says, at the 'Coach an' Horses,'
5230	and no one don't seem to have been aware of his misfortune, it says,
5230	aware of his misfortune, until in an Altercation in the inn, it
5230	says, his bandages on his head was torn off. It was then ob-served
5230	that his head was invisible. Attempts were At Once made to secure
5230	him, but casting off his garments, it says, he succeeded in
5230	escaping, but not until after a desperate struggle, in which he
5230	had inflicted serious injuries, it says, on our worthy and able
5230	constable, Mr. J. A. Jaffers. Pretty straight story, eh? Names and
5230	everything.""
5230	
5230	""Lord!"" said Mr. Marvel, looking nervously about him, trying to
5230	count the money in his pockets by his unaided sense of touch, and
5230	full of a strange and novel idea. ""It sounds most astonishing.""
5230	
5230	""Don't it? Extra-ordinary, _I_ call it. Never heard tell of Invisible
5230	Men before, I haven't, but nowadays one hears such a lot of
5230	extra-ordinary things--that--""
5230	
5230	""That all he did?"" asked Marvel, trying to seem at his ease.
5230	
5230	""It's enough, ain't it?"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""Didn't go Back by any chance?"" asked Marvel. ""Just escaped and
5230	that's all, eh?""
5230	
5230	""All!"" said the mariner. ""Why!--ain't it enough?""
5230	
5230	""Quite enough,"" said Marvel.
5230	
5230	""I should think it was enough,"" said the mariner. ""I should think
5230	it was enough.""
5230	
5230	""He didn't have any pals--it don't say he had any pals, does it?""
5230	asked Mr. Marvel, anxious.
5230	
5230	""Ain't one of a sort enough for you?"" asked the mariner. ""No, thank
5230	Heaven, as one might say, he didn't.""
5230	
5230	He nodded his head slowly. ""It makes me regular uncomfortable,
5230	the bare thought of that chap running about the country! He is at
5230	present At Large, and from certain evidence it is supposed that he
5230	has--taken--_took_, I suppose they mean--the road to Port Stowe. You
5230	see we're right _in_ it! None of your American wonders, this time.
5230	And just think of the things he might do! Where'd you be, if he took
5230	a drop over and above, and had a fancy to go for you? Suppose he
5230	wants to rob--who can prevent him? He can trespass, he can burgle,
5230	he could walk through a cordon of policemen as easy as me or you
5230	could give the slip to a blind man! Easier! For these here blind
5230	chaps hear uncommon sharp, I'm told. And wherever there was liquor
5230	he fancied--""
5230	
5230	""He's got a tremenjous advantage, certainly,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	""And--well...""
5230	
5230	""You're right,"" said the mariner. ""He _has_.""
5230	
5230	All this time Mr. Marvel had been glancing about him intently,
5230	listening for faint footfalls, trying to detect imperceptible
5230	movements. He seemed on the point of some great resolution. He
5230	coughed behind his hand.
5230	
5230	He looked about him again, listened, bent towards the mariner, and
5230	lowered his voice: ""The fact of it is--I happen--to know just a
5230	thing or two about this Invisible Man. From private sources.""
5230	
5230	""Oh!"" said the mariner, interested. ""_You_?""
5230	
5230	""Yes,"" said Mr. Marvel. ""Me.""
5230	
5230	""Indeed!"" said the mariner. ""And may I ask--""
5230	
5230	""You'll be astonished,"" said Mr. Marvel behind his hand. ""It's
5230	tremenjous.""
5230	
5230	""Indeed!"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""The fact is,"" began Mr. Marvel eagerly in a confidential undertone.
5230	Suddenly his expression changed marvellously. ""Ow!"" he said. He rose
5230	stiffly in his seat. His face was eloquent of physical suffering.
5230	""Wow!"" he said.
5230	
5230	""What's up?"" said the mariner, concerned.
5230	
5230	""Toothache,"" said Mr. Marvel, and put his hand to his ear. He caught
5230	hold of his books. ""I must be getting on, I think,"" he said. He
5230	edged in a curious way along the seat away from his interlocutor.
5230	""But you was just a-going to tell me about this here Invisible Man!""
5230	protested the mariner. Mr. Marvel seemed to consult with himself.
5230	""Hoax,"" said a Voice. ""It's a hoax,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""But it's in the paper,"" said the mariner.
5230	
5230	""Hoax all the same,"" said Marvel. ""I know the chap that started the
5230	lie. There ain't no Invisible Man whatsoever--Blimey.""
5230	
5230	""But how 'bout this paper? D'you mean to say--?""
5230	
5230	""Not a word of it,"" said Marvel, stoutly.
5230	
5230	The mariner stared, paper in hand. Mr. Marvel jerkily faced about.
5230	""Wait a bit,"" said the mariner, rising and speaking slowly, ""D'you
5230	mean to say--?""
5230	
5230	""I do,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""Then why did you let me go on and tell you all this blarsted
5230	stuff, then? What d'yer mean by letting a man make a fool of
5230	himself like that for? Eh?""
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel blew out his cheeks. The mariner was suddenly very red
5230	indeed; he clenched his hands. ""I been talking here this ten
5230	minutes,"" he said; ""and you, you little pot-bellied, leathery-faced
5230	son of an old boot, couldn't have the elementary manners--""
5230	
5230	""Don't you come bandying words with _me_,"" said Mr. Marvel.
5230	
5230	""Bandying words! I'm a jolly good mind--""
5230	
5230	""Come up,"" said a Voice, and Mr. Marvel was suddenly whirled about
5230	and started marching off in a curious spasmodic manner. ""You'd
5230	better move on,"" said the mariner. ""Who's moving on?"" said Mr.
5230	Marvel. He was receding obliquely with a curious hurrying gait, with
5230	occasional violent jerks forward. Some way along the road he began
5230	a muttered monologue, protests and recriminations.
5230	
5230	""Silly devil!"" said the mariner, legs wide apart, elbows akimbo,
5230	watching the receding figure. ""I'll show you, you silly ass--hoaxing
5230	_me_! It's here--on the paper!""
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel retorted incoherently and, receding, was hidden by a bend
5230	in the road, but the mariner still stood magnificent in the midst
5230	of the way, until the approach of a butcher's cart dislodged him.
5230	Then he turned himself towards Port Stowe. ""Full of extra-ordinary
5230	asses,"" he said softly to himself. ""Just to take me down a bit--that
5230	was his silly game--It's on the paper!""
5230	
5230	And there was another extraordinary thing he was presently to hear,
5230	that had happened quite close to him. And that was a vision of a
5230	""fist full of money"" (no less) travelling without visible agency,
5230	along by the wall at the corner of St. Michael's Lane. A brother
5230	mariner had seen this wonderful sight that very morning. He had
5230	snatched at the money forthwith and had been knocked headlong, and
5230	when he had got to his feet the butterfly money had vanished. Our
5230	mariner was in the mood to believe anything, he declared, but that
5230	was a bit _too_ stiff. Afterwards, however, he began to think things
5230	over.
5230	
5230	The story of the flying money was true. And all about that
5230	neighbourhood, even from the august London and Country Banking
5230	Company, from the tills of shops and inns--doors standing that sunny
5230	weather entirely open--money had been quietly and dexterously making
5230	off that day in handfuls and rouleaux, floating quietly along by
5230	walls and shady places, dodging quickly from the approaching eyes of
5230	men. And it had, though no man had traced it, invariably ended its
5230	mysterious flight in the pocket of that agitated gentleman in the
5230	obsolete silk hat, sitting outside the little inn on the outskirts
5230	of Port Stowe.
5230	
5230	It was ten days after--and indeed only when the Burdock story was
5230	already old--that the mariner collated these facts and began to
5230	understand how near he had been to the wonderful Invisible Man.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XV
5230	
5230	THE MAN WHO WAS RUNNING
5230	
5230	
5230	In the early evening time Dr. Kemp was sitting in his study in the
5230	belvedere on the hill overlooking Burdock. It was a pleasant little
5230	room, with three windows--north, west, and south--and bookshelves
5230	covered with books and scientific publications, and a broad
5230	writing-table, and, under the north window, a microscope, glass
5230	slips, minute instruments, some cultures, and scattered bottles of
5230	reagents. Dr. Kemp's solar lamp was lit, albeit the sky was still
5230	bright with the sunset light, and his blinds were up because there
5230	was no offence of peering outsiders to require them pulled down.
5230	Dr. Kemp was a tall and slender young man, with flaxen hair and a
5230	moustache almost white, and the work he was upon would earn him, he
5230	hoped, the fellowship of the Royal Society, so highly did he think
5230	of it.
5230	
5230	And his eye, presently wandering from his work, caught the sunset
5230	blazing at the back of the hill that is over against his own. For a
5230	minute perhaps he sat, pen in mouth, admiring the rich golden
5230	colour above the crest, and then his attention was attracted by the
5230	little figure of a man, inky black, running over the hill-brow
5230	towards him. He was a shortish little man, and he wore a high hat,
5230	and he was running so fast that his legs verily twinkled.
5230	
5230	""Another of those fools,"" said Dr. Kemp. ""Like that ass who ran
5230	into me this morning round a corner, with the ''Visible Man
5230	a-coming, sir!' I can't imagine what possesses people. One might
5230	think we were in the thirteenth century.""
5230	
5230	He got up, went to the window, and stared at the dusky hillside, and
5230	the dark little figure tearing down it. ""He seems in a confounded
5230	hurry,"" said Dr. Kemp, ""but he doesn't seem to be getting on. If
5230	his pockets were full of lead, he couldn't run heavier.""
5230	
5230	""Spurted, sir,"" said Dr. Kemp.
5230	
5230	In another moment the higher of the villas that had clambered up the
5230	hill from Burdock had occulted the running figure. He was visible
5230	again for a moment, and again, and then again, three times between
5230	the three detached houses that came next, and then the terrace hid
5230	him.
5230	
5230	""Asses!"" said Dr. Kemp, swinging round on his heel and walking
5230	back to his writing-table.
5230	
5230	But those who saw the fugitive nearer, and perceived the abject
5230	terror on his perspiring face, being themselves in the open roadway,
5230	did not share in the doctor's contempt. By the man pounded, and as
5230	he ran he chinked like a well-filled purse that is tossed to and
5230	fro. He looked neither to the right nor the left, but his dilated
5230	eyes stared straight downhill to where the lamps were being lit, and
5230	the people were crowded in the street. And his ill-shaped mouth fell
5230	apart, and a glairy foam lay on his lips, and his breath came hoarse
5230	and noisy. All he passed stopped and began staring up the road and
5230	down, and interrogating one another with an inkling of discomfort
5230	for the reason of his haste.
5230	
5230	And then presently, far up the hill, a dog playing in the road
5230	yelped and ran under a gate, and as they still wondered
5230	something--a wind--a pad, pad, pad,--a sound like a panting breathing,
5230	rushed by.
5230	
5230	People screamed. People sprang off the pavement: It passed in
5230	shouts, it passed by instinct down the hill. They were shouting in
5230	the street before Marvel was halfway there. They were bolting into
5230	houses and slamming the doors behind them, with the news. He heard
5230	it and made one last desperate spurt. Fear came striding by, rushed
5230	ahead of him, and in a moment had seized the town.
5230	
5230	""The Invisible Man is coming! The Invisible Man!""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XVI
5230	
5230	IN THE ""JOLLY CRICKETERS""
5230	
5230	
5230	The ""Jolly Cricketers"" is just at the bottom of the hill, where the
5230	tram-lines begin. The barman leant his fat red arms on the counter
5230	and talked of horses with an anaemic cabman, while a black-bearded
5230	man in grey snapped up biscuit and cheese, drank Burton, and
5230	conversed in American with a policeman off duty.
5230	
5230	""What's the shouting about!"" said the anaemic cabman, going off at a
5230	tangent, trying to see up the hill over the dirty yellow blind in
5230	the low window of the inn. Somebody ran by outside. ""Fire, perhaps,""
5230	said the barman.
5230	
5230	Footsteps approached, running heavily, the door was pushed open
5230	violently, and Marvel, weeping and dishevelled, his hat gone, the
5230	neck of his coat torn open, rushed in, made a convulsive turn, and
5230	attempted to shut the door. It was held half open by a strap.
5230	
5230	""Coming!"" he bawled, his voice shrieking with terror. ""He's coming.
5230	The 'Visible Man! After me! For Gawd's sake! 'Elp! 'Elp! 'Elp!""
5230	
5230	""Shut the doors,"" said the policeman. ""Who's coming? What's the
5230	row?"" He went to the door, released the strap, and it slammed. The
5230	American closed the other door.
5230	
5230	""Lemme go inside,"" said Marvel, staggering and weeping, but still
5230	clutching the books. ""Lemme go inside. Lock me in--somewhere. I
5230	tell you he's after me. I give him the slip. He said he'd kill me
5230	and he will.""
5230	
5230	""_You're_ safe,"" said the man with the black beard. ""The door's shut.
5230	What's it all about?""
5230	
5230	""Lemme go inside,"" said Marvel, and shrieked aloud as a blow
5230	suddenly made the fastened door shiver and was followed by a hurried
5230	rapping and a shouting outside. ""Hullo,"" cried the policeman, ""who's
5230	there?"" Mr. Marvel began to make frantic dives at panels that looked
5230	like doors. ""He'll kill me--he's got a knife or something. For
5230	Gawd's sake--!""
5230	
5230	""Here you are,"" said the barman. ""Come in here."" And he held up the
5230	flap of the bar.
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel rushed behind the bar as the summons outside was
5230	repeated. ""Don't open the door,"" he screamed. ""_Please_ don't open
5230	the door. _Where_ shall I hide?""
5230	
5230	""This, this Invisible Man, then?"" asked the man with the black
5230	beard, with one hand behind him. ""I guess it's about time we saw
5230	him.""
5230	
5230	The window of the inn was suddenly smashed in, and there was a
5230	screaming and running to and fro in the street. The policeman had
5230	been standing on the settee staring out, craning to see who was at
5230	the door. He got down with raised eyebrows. ""It's that,"" he said.
5230	The barman stood in front of the bar-parlour door which was now
5230	locked on Mr. Marvel, stared at the smashed window, and came round
5230	to the two other men.
5230	
5230	Everything was suddenly quiet. ""I wish I had my truncheon,"" said
5230	the policeman, going irresolutely to the door. ""Once we open, in he
5230	comes. There's no stopping him.""
5230	
5230	""Don't you be in too much hurry about that door,"" said the anaemic
5230	cabman, anxiously.
5230	
5230	""Draw the bolts,"" said the man with the black beard, ""and if he
5230	comes--"" He showed a revolver in his hand.
5230	
5230	""That won't do,"" said the policeman; ""that's murder.""
5230	
5230	""I know what country I'm in,"" said the man with the beard. ""I'm
5230	going to let off at his legs. Draw the bolts.""
5230	
5230	""Not with that blinking thing going off behind me,"" said the
5230	barman, craning over the blind.
5230	
5230	""Very well,"" said the man with the black beard, and stooping down,
5230	revolver ready, drew them himself. Barman, cabman, and policeman
5230	faced about.
5230	
5230	""Come in,"" said the bearded man in an undertone, standing back and
5230	facing the unbolted doors with his pistol behind him. No one came
5230	in, the door remained closed. Five minutes afterwards when a second
5230	cabman pushed his head in cautiously, they were still waiting, and
5230	an anxious face peered out of the bar-parlour and supplied
5230	information. ""Are all the doors of the house shut?"" asked Marvel.
5230	""He's going round--prowling round. He's as artful as the devil.""
5230	
5230	""Good Lord!"" said the burly barman. ""There's the back! Just watch
5230	them doors! I say--!"" He looked about him helplessly. The
5230	bar-parlour door slammed and they heard the key turn. ""There's
5230	the yard door and the private door. The yard door--""
5230	
5230	He rushed out of the bar.
5230	
5230	In a minute he reappeared with a carving-knife in his hand. ""The
5230	yard door was open!"" he said, and his fat underlip dropped. ""He may
5230	be in the house now!"" said the first cabman.
5230	
5230	""He's not in the kitchen,"" said the barman. ""There's two women
5230	there, and I've stabbed every inch of it with this little beef
5230	slicer. And they don't think he's come in. They haven't noticed--""
5230	
5230	""Have you fastened it?"" asked the first cabman.
5230	
5230	""I'm out of frocks,"" said the barman.
5230	
5230	The man with the beard replaced his revolver. And even as he did so
5230	the flap of the bar was shut down and the bolt clicked, and then
5230	with a tremendous thud the catch of the door snapped and the
5230	bar-parlour door burst open. They heard Marvel squeal like a caught
5230	leveret, and forthwith they were clambering over the bar to his
5230	rescue. The bearded man's revolver cracked and the looking-glass at
5230	the back of the parlour starred and came smashing and tinkling down.
5230	
5230	As the barman entered the room he saw Marvel, curiously crumpled up
5230	and struggling against the door that led to the yard and kitchen.
5230	The door flew open while the barman hesitated, and Marvel was
5230	dragged into the kitchen. There was a scream and a clatter of pans.
5230	Marvel, head down, and lugging back obstinately, was forced to the
5230	kitchen door, and the bolts were drawn.
5230	
5230	Then the policeman, who had been trying to pass the barman, rushed
5230	in, followed by one of the cabmen, gripped the wrist of the
5230	invisible hand that collared Marvel, was hit in the face and went
5230	reeling back. The door opened, and Marvel made a frantic effort to
5230	obtain a lodgment behind it. Then the cabman collared something.
5230	""I got him,"" said the cabman. The barman's red hands came clawing
5230	at the unseen. ""Here he is!"" said the barman.
5230	
5230	Mr. Marvel, released, suddenly dropped to the ground and made an
5230	attempt to crawl behind the legs of the fighting men. The struggle
5230	blundered round the edge of the door. The voice of the Invisible
5230	Man was heard for the first time, yelling out sharply, as the
5230	policeman trod on his foot. Then he cried out passionately and
5230	his fists flew round like flails. The cabman suddenly whooped
5230	and doubled up, kicked under the diaphragm. The door into the
5230	bar-parlour from the kitchen slammed and covered Mr. Marvel's
5230	retreat. The men in the kitchen found themselves clutching at and
5230	struggling with empty air.
5230	
5230	""Where's he gone?"" cried the man with the beard. ""Out?""
5230	
5230	""This way,"" said the policeman, stepping into the yard and
5230	stopping.
5230	
5230	A piece of tile whizzed by his head and smashed among the crockery
5230	on the kitchen table.
5230	
5230	""I'll show him,"" shouted the man with the black beard, and suddenly
5230	a steel barrel shone over the policeman's shoulder, and five
5230	bullets had followed one another into the twilight whence the
5230	missile had come. As he fired, the man with the beard moved his
5230	hand in a horizontal curve, so that his shots radiated out into the
5230	narrow yard like spokes from a wheel.
5230	
5230	A silence followed. ""Five cartridges,"" said the man with the black
5230	beard. ""That's the best of all. Four aces and a joker. Get a
5230	lantern, someone, and come and feel about for his body.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XVII
5230	
5230	DR. KEMP'S VISITOR
5230	
5230	
5230	Dr. Kemp had continued writing in his study until the shots
5230	aroused him. Crack, crack, crack, they came one after the other.
5230	
5230	""Hullo!"" said Dr. Kemp, putting his pen into his mouth again and
5230	listening. ""Who's letting off revolvers in Burdock? What are the
5230	asses at now?""
5230	
5230	He went to the south window, threw it up, and leaning out stared
5230	down on the network of windows, beaded gas-lamps and shops, with its
5230	black interstices of roof and yard that made up the town at night.
5230	""Looks like a crowd down the hill,"" he said, ""by 'The Cricketers,'""
5230	and remained watching. Thence his eyes wandered over the town to far
5230	away where the ships' lights shone, and the pier glowed--a little
5230	illuminated, facetted pavilion like a gem of yellow light. The moon
5230	in its first quarter hung over the westward hill, and the stars were
5230	clear and almost tropically bright.
5230	
5230	After five minutes, during which his mind had travelled into a
5230	remote speculation of social conditions of the future, and lost
5230	itself at last over the time dimension, Dr. Kemp roused himself
5230	with a sigh, pulled down the window again, and returned to his
5230	writing desk.
5230	
5230	It must have been about an hour after this that the front-door bell
5230	rang. He had been writing slackly, and with intervals of
5230	abstraction, since the shots. He sat listening. He heard the servant
5230	answer the door, and waited for her feet on the staircase, but she
5230	did not come. ""Wonder what that was,"" said Dr. Kemp.
5230	
5230	He tried to resume his work, failed, got up, went downstairs from
5230	his study to the landing, rang, and called over the balustrade to
5230	the housemaid as she appeared in the hall below. ""Was that a
5230	letter?"" he asked.
5230	
5230	""Only a runaway ring, sir,"" she answered.
5230	
5230	""I'm restless to-night,"" he said to himself. He went back to his
5230	study, and this time attacked his work resolutely. In a little
5230	while he was hard at work again, and the only sounds in the room
5230	were the ticking of the clock and the subdued shrillness of his
5230	quill, hurrying in the very centre of the circle of light his
5230	lampshade threw on his table.
5230	
5230	It was two o'clock before Dr. Kemp had finished his work for the
5230	night. He rose, yawned, and went downstairs to bed. He had already
5230	removed his coat and vest, when he noticed that he was thirsty. He
5230	took a candle and went down to the dining-room in search of a
5230	syphon and whiskey.
5230	
5230	Dr. Kemp's scientific pursuits have made him a very observant
5230	man, and as he recrossed the hall, he noticed a dark spot on the
5230	linoleum near the mat at the foot of the stairs. He went on
5230	upstairs, and then it suddenly occurred to him to ask himself what
5230	the spot on the linoleum might be. Apparently some subconscious
5230	element was at work. At any rate, he turned with his burden, went
5230	back to the hall, put down the syphon and whiskey, and bending
5230	down, touched the spot. Without any great surprise he found it had
5230	the stickiness and colour of drying blood.
5230	
5230	He took up his burden again, and returned upstairs, looking about
