5230	him and trying to account for the blood-spot. On the landing he saw
5230	something and stopped astonished. The door-handle of his own room
5230	was blood-stained.
5230	
5230	He looked at his own hand. It was quite clean, and then he
5230	remembered that the door of his room had been open when he came down
5230	from his study, and that consequently he had not touched the handle
5230	at all. He went straight into his room, his face quite calm--perhaps
5230	a trifle more resolute than usual. His glance, wandering
5230	inquisitively, fell on the bed. On the counterpane was a mess of
5230	blood, and the sheet had been torn. He had not noticed this before
5230	because he had walked straight to the dressing-table. On the further
5230	side the bedclothes were depressed as if someone had been recently
5230	sitting there.
5230	
5230	Then he had an odd impression that he had heard a low voice say,
5230	""Good Heavens!--Kemp!"" But Dr. Kemp was no believer in voices.
5230	
5230	He stood staring at the tumbled sheets. Was that really a voice? He
5230	looked about again, but noticed nothing further than the disordered
5230	and blood-stained bed. Then he distinctly heard a movement across
5230	the room, near the wash-hand stand. All men, however highly
5230	educated, retain some superstitious inklings. The feeling that is
5230	called ""eerie"" came upon him. He closed the door of the room, came
5230	forward to the dressing-table, and put down his burdens. Suddenly,
5230	with a start, he perceived a coiled and blood-stained bandage of
5230	linen rag hanging in mid-air, between him and the wash-hand stand.
5230	
5230	He stared at this in amazement. It was an empty bandage, a bandage
5230	properly tied but quite empty. He would have advanced to grasp it,
5230	but a touch arrested him, and a voice speaking quite close to him.
5230	
5230	""Kemp!"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	""Eh?"" said Kemp, with his mouth open.
5230	
5230	""Keep your nerve,"" said the Voice. ""I'm an Invisible Man.""
5230	
5230	Kemp made no answer for a space, simply stared at the bandage.
5230	""Invisible Man,"" he said.
5230	
5230	""I am an Invisible Man,"" repeated the Voice.
5230	
5230	The story he had been active to ridicule only that morning rushed
5230	through Kemp's brain. He does not appear to have been either very
5230	much frightened or very greatly surprised at the moment.
5230	Realisation came later.
5230	
5230	""I thought it was all a lie,"" he said. The thought uppermost in his
5230	mind was the reiterated arguments of the morning. ""Have you a
5230	bandage on?"" he asked.
5230	
5230	""Yes,"" said the Invisible Man.
5230	
5230	""Oh!"" said Kemp, and then roused himself. ""I say!"" he said. ""But
5230	this is nonsense. It's some trick."" He stepped forward suddenly,
5230	and his hand, extended towards the bandage, met invisible fingers.
5230	
5230	He recoiled at the touch and his colour changed.
5230	
5230	""Keep steady, Kemp, for God's sake! I want help badly. Stop!""
5230	
5230	The hand gripped his arm. He struck at it.
5230	
5230	""Kemp!"" cried the Voice. ""Kemp! Keep steady!"" and the grip
5230	tightened.
5230	
5230	A frantic desire to free himself took possession of Kemp. The hand
5230	of the bandaged arm gripped his shoulder, and he was suddenly
5230	tripped and flung backwards upon the bed. He opened his mouth to
5230	shout, and the corner of the sheet was thrust between his teeth.
5230	The Invisible Man had him down grimly, but his arms were free and
5230	he struck and tried to kick savagely.
5230	
5230	""Listen to reason, will you?"" said the Invisible Man, sticking to
5230	him in spite of a pounding in the ribs. ""By Heaven! you'll madden
5230	me in a minute!
5230	
5230	""Lie still, you fool!"" bawled the Invisible Man in Kemp's ear.
5230	
5230	Kemp struggled for another moment and then lay still.
5230	
5230	""If you shout, I'll smash your face,"" said the Invisible Man,
5230	relieving his mouth.
5230	
5230	""I'm an Invisible Man. It's no foolishness, and no magic. I really
5230	am an Invisible Man. And I want your help. I don't want to hurt
5230	you, but if you behave like a frantic rustic, I must. Don't you
5230	remember me, Kemp? Griffin, of University College?""
5230	
5230	""Let me get up,"" said Kemp. ""I'll stop where I am. And let me sit
5230	quiet for a minute.""
5230	
5230	He sat up and felt his neck.
5230	
5230	""I am Griffin, of University College, and I have made myself
5230	invisible. I am just an ordinary man--a man you have known--made
5230	invisible.""
5230	
5230	""Griffin?"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Griffin,"" answered the Voice. A younger student than you were,
5230	almost an albino, six feet high, and broad, with a pink and white
5230	face and red eyes, who won the medal for chemistry.""
5230	
5230	""I am confused,"" said Kemp. ""My brain is rioting. What has this to
5230	do with Griffin?""
5230	
5230	""I _am_ Griffin.""
5230	
5230	Kemp thought. ""It's horrible,"" he said. ""But what devilry must
5230	happen to make a man invisible?""
5230	
5230	""It's no devilry. It's a process, sane and intelligible enough--""
5230	
5230	""It's horrible!"" said Kemp. ""How on earth--?""
5230	
5230	""It's horrible enough. But I'm wounded and in pain, and tired ...
5230	Great God! Kemp, you are a man. Take it steady. Give me some food
5230	and drink, and let me sit down here.""
5230	
5230	Kemp stared at the bandage as it moved across the room, then saw a
5230	basket chair dragged across the floor and come to rest near the bed.
5230	It creaked, and the seat was depressed the quarter of an inch or so.
5230	He rubbed his eyes and felt his neck again. ""This beats ghosts,"" he
5230	said, and laughed stupidly.
5230	
5230	""That's better. Thank Heaven, you're getting sensible!""
5230	
5230	""Or silly,"" said Kemp, and knuckled his eyes.
5230	
5230	""Give me some whiskey. I'm near dead.""
5230	
5230	""It didn't feel so. Where are you? If I get up shall I run into you?
5230	_There_! all right. Whiskey? Here. Where shall I give it to you?""
5230	
5230	The chair creaked and Kemp felt the glass drawn away from him. He
5230	let go by an effort; his instinct was all against it. It came to
5230	rest poised twenty inches above the front edge of the seat of the
5230	chair. He stared at it in infinite perplexity. ""This is--this
5230	must be--hypnotism. You have suggested you are invisible.""
5230	
5230	""Nonsense,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	""It's frantic.""
5230	
5230	""Listen to me.""
5230	
5230	""I demonstrated conclusively this morning,"" began Kemp, ""that
5230	invisibility--""
5230	
5230	""Never mind what you've demonstrated!--I'm starving,"" said the
5230	Voice, ""and the night is chilly to a man without clothes.""
5230	
5230	""Food?"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	The tumbler of whiskey tilted itself. ""Yes,"" said the Invisible Man
5230	rapping it down. ""Have you a dressing-gown?""
5230	
5230	Kemp made some exclamation in an undertone. He walked to a wardrobe
5230	and produced a robe of dingy scarlet. ""This do?"" he asked. It was
5230	taken from him. It hung limp for a moment in mid-air, fluttered
5230	weirdly, stood full and decorous buttoning itself, and sat down in
5230	his chair. ""Drawers, socks, slippers would be a comfort,"" said the
5230	Unseen, curtly. ""And food.""
5230	
5230	""Anything. But this is the insanest thing I ever was in, in my
5230	life!""
5230	
5230	He turned out his drawers for the articles, and then went downstairs
5230	to ransack his larder. He came back with some cold cutlets and
5230	bread, pulled up a light table, and placed them before his guest.
5230	""Never mind knives,"" said his visitor, and a cutlet hung in mid-air,
5230	with a sound of gnawing.
5230	
5230	""Invisible!"" said Kemp, and sat down on a bedroom chair.
5230	
5230	""I always like to get something about me before I eat,"" said the
5230	Invisible Man, with a full mouth, eating greedily. ""Queer fancy!""
5230	
5230	""I suppose that wrist is all right,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Trust me,"" said the Invisible Man.
5230	
5230	""Of all the strange and wonderful--""
5230	
5230	""Exactly. But it's odd I should blunder into _your_ house to get my
5230	bandaging. My first stroke of luck! Anyhow I meant to sleep in this
5230	house to-night. You must stand that! It's a filthy nuisance, my
5230	blood showing, isn't it? Quite a clot over there. Gets visible as
5230	it coagulates, I see. It's only the living tissue I've changed, and
5230	only for as long as I'm alive.... I've been in the house three hours.""
5230	
5230	""But how's it done?"" began Kemp, in a tone of exasperation.
5230	""Confound it! The whole business--it's unreasonable from
5230	beginning to end.""
5230	
5230	""Quite reasonable,"" said the Invisible Man. ""Perfectly reasonable.""
5230	
5230	He reached over and secured the whiskey bottle. Kemp stared at the
5230	devouring dressing gown. A ray of candle-light penetrating a torn
5230	patch in the right shoulder, made a triangle of light under the
5230	left ribs. ""What were the shots?"" he asked. ""How did the shooting
5230	begin?""
5230	
5230	""There was a real fool of a man--a sort of confederate of
5230	mine--curse him!--who tried to steal my money. _Has_ done so.""
5230	
5230	""Is _he_ invisible too?""
5230	
5230	""No.""
5230	
5230	""Well?""
5230	
5230	""Can't I have some more to eat before I tell you all that? I'm
5230	hungry--in pain. And you want me to tell stories!""
5230	
5230	Kemp got up. ""_You_ didn't do any shooting?"" he asked.
5230	
5230	""Not me,"" said his visitor. ""Some fool I'd never seen fired at
5230	random. A lot of them got scared. They all got scared at me. Curse
5230	them!--I say--I want more to eat than this, Kemp.""
5230	
5230	""I'll see what there is to eat downstairs,"" said Kemp. ""Not much,
5230	I'm afraid.""
5230	
5230	After he had done eating, and he made a heavy meal, the Invisible
5230	Man demanded a cigar. He bit the end savagely before Kemp could
5230	find a knife, and cursed when the outer leaf loosened. It was
5230	strange to see him smoking; his mouth, and throat, pharynx and
5230	nares, became visible as a sort of whirling smoke cast.
5230	
5230	""This blessed gift of smoking!"" he said, and puffed vigorously.
5230	""I'm lucky to have fallen upon you, Kemp. You must help me. Fancy
5230	tumbling on you just now! I'm in a devilish scrape--I've been mad,
5230	I think. The things I have been through! But we will do things yet.
5230	Let me tell you--""
5230	
5230	He helped himself to more whiskey and soda. Kemp got up, looked
5230	about him, and fetched a glass from his spare room. ""It's wild--but
5230	I suppose I may drink.""
5230	
5230	""You haven't changed much, Kemp, these dozen years. You fair men
5230	don't. Cool and methodical--after the first collapse. I must tell
5230	you. We will work together!""
5230	
5230	""But how was it all done?"" said Kemp, ""and how did you get like
5230	this?""
5230	
5230	""For God's sake, let me smoke in peace for a little while! And then
5230	I will begin to tell you.""
5230	
5230	But the story was not told that night. The Invisible Man's wrist
5230	was growing painful; he was feverish, exhausted, and his mind came
5230	round to brood upon his chase down the hill and the struggle about
5230	the inn. He spoke in fragments of Marvel, he smoked faster, his
5230	voice grew angry. Kemp tried to gather what he could.
5230	
5230	""He was afraid of me, I could see that he was afraid of me,"" said
5230	the Invisible Man many times over. ""He meant to give me the slip--he
5230	was always casting about! What a fool I was!
5230	
5230	""The cur!
5230	
5230	""I should have killed him!""
5230	
5230	""Where did you get the money?"" asked Kemp, abruptly.
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man was silent for a space. ""I can't tell you
5230	to-night,"" he said.
5230	
5230	He groaned suddenly and leant forward, supporting his invisible
5230	head on invisible hands. ""Kemp,"" he said, ""I've had no sleep for
5230	near three days, except a couple of dozes of an hour or so. I
5230	must sleep soon.""
5230	
5230	""Well, have my room--have this room.""
5230	
5230	""But how can I sleep? If I sleep--he will get away. Ugh! What
5230	does it matter?""
5230	
5230	""What's the shot wound?"" asked Kemp, abruptly.
5230	
5230	""Nothing--scratch and blood. Oh, God! How I want sleep!""
5230	
5230	""Why not?""
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man appeared to be regarding Kemp. ""Because I've a
5230	particular objection to being caught by my fellow-men,"" he said
5230	slowly.
5230	
5230	Kemp started.
5230	
5230	""Fool that I am!"" said the Invisible Man, striking the table
5230	smartly. ""I've put the idea into your head.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XVIII
5230	
5230	THE INVISIBLE MAN SLEEPS
5230	
5230	
5230	Exhausted and wounded as the Invisible Man was, he refused to accept
5230	Kemp's word that his freedom should be respected. He examined the
5230	two windows of the bedroom, drew up the blinds and opened the
5230	sashes, to confirm Kemp's statement that a retreat by them would be
5230	possible. Outside the night was very quiet and still, and the new
5230	moon was setting over the down. Then he examined the keys of the
5230	bedroom and the two dressing-room doors, to satisfy himself that
5230	these also could be made an assurance of freedom. Finally he
5230	expressed himself satisfied. He stood on the hearth rug and Kemp
5230	heard the sound of a yawn.
5230	
5230	""I'm sorry,"" said the Invisible Man, ""if I cannot tell you all that
5230	I have done to-night. But I am worn out. It's grotesque, no doubt.
5230	It's horrible! But believe me, Kemp, in spite of your arguments of
5230	this morning, it is quite a possible thing. I have made a discovery.
5230	I meant to keep it to myself. I can't. I must have a partner. And
5230	you.... We can do such things ... But to-morrow. Now, Kemp, I feel
5230	as though I must sleep or perish.""
5230	
5230	Kemp stood in the middle of the room staring at the headless garment.
5230	""I suppose I must leave you,"" he said. ""It's--incredible. Three
5230	things happening like this, overturning all my preconceptions--would
5230	make me insane. But it's real! Is there anything more that I can
5230	get you?""
5230	
5230	""Only bid me good-night,"" said Griffin.
5230	
5230	""Good-night,"" said Kemp, and shook an invisible hand. He walked
5230	sideways to the door. Suddenly the dressing-gown walked quickly
5230	towards him. ""Understand me!"" said the dressing-gown. ""No attempts
5230	to hamper me, or capture me! Or--""
5230	
5230	Kemp's face changed a little. ""I thought I gave you my word,"" he
5230	said.
5230	
5230	Kemp closed the door softly behind him, and the key was turned upon
5230	him forthwith. Then, as he stood with an expression of passive
5230	amazement on his face, the rapid feet came to the door of the
5230	dressing-room and that too was locked. Kemp slapped his brow with
5230	his hand. ""Am I dreaming? Has the world gone mad--or have I?""
5230	
5230	He laughed, and put his hand to the locked door. ""Barred out of my
5230	own bedroom, by a flagrant absurdity!"" he said.
5230	
5230	He walked to the head of the staircase, turned, and stared at the
5230	locked doors. ""It's fact,"" he said. He put his fingers to his
5230	slightly bruised neck. ""Undeniable fact!
5230	
5230	""But--""
5230	
5230	He shook his head hopelessly, turned, and went downstairs.
5230	
5230	He lit the dining-room lamp, got out a cigar, and began pacing the
5230	room, ejaculating. Now and then he would argue with himself.
5230	
5230	""Invisible!"" he said.
5230	
5230	""Is there such a thing as an invisible animal? ... In the sea, yes.
5230	Thousands--millions. All the larvae, all the little nauplii and
5230	tornarias, all the microscopic things, the jelly-fish. In the sea
5230	there are more things invisible than visible! I never thought of
5230	that before. And in the ponds too! All those little pond-life
5230	things--specks of colourless translucent jelly! But in air? No!
5230	
5230	""It can't be.
5230	
5230	""But after all--why not?
5230	
5230	""If a man was made of glass he would still be visible.""
5230	
5230	His meditation became profound. The bulk of three cigars had passed
5230	into the invisible or diffused as a white ash over the carpet before
5230	he spoke again. Then it was merely an exclamation. He turned aside,
5230	walked out of the room, and went into his little consulting-room and
5230	lit the gas there. It was a little room, because Dr. Kemp did not
5230	live by practice, and in it were the day's newspapers. The morning's
5230	paper lay carelessly opened and thrown aside. He caught it up,
5230	turned it over, and read the account of a ""Strange Story from Iping""
5230	that the mariner at Port Stowe had spelt over so painfully to Mr.
5230	Marvel. Kemp read it swiftly.
5230	
5230	""Wrapped up!"" said Kemp. ""Disguised! Hiding it! 'No one seems to
5230	have been aware of his misfortune.' What the devil _is_ his game?""
5230	
5230	He dropped the paper, and his eye went seeking. ""Ah!"" he said, and
5230	caught up the _St. James' Gazette_, lying folded up as it arrived.
5230	""Now we shall get at the truth,"" said Dr. Kemp. He rent the paper
5230	open; a couple of columns confronted him. ""An Entire Village in
5230	Sussex goes Mad"" was the heading.
5230	
5230	""Good Heavens!"" said Kemp, reading eagerly an incredulous account
5230	of the events in Iping, of the previous afternoon, that have
5230	already been described. Over the leaf the report in the morning
5230	paper had been reprinted.
5230	
5230	He re-read it. ""Ran through the streets striking right and left.
5230	Jaffers insensible. Mr. Huxter in great pain--still unable to
5230	describe what he saw. Painful humiliation--vicar. Woman ill with
5230	terror! Windows smashed. This extraordinary story probably a
5230	fabrication. Too good not to print--_cum grano_!""
5230	
5230	He dropped the paper and stared blankly in front of him. ""Probably
5230	a fabrication!""
5230	
5230	He caught up the paper again, and re-read the whole business. ""But
5230	when does the Tramp come in? Why the deuce was he chasing a tramp?""
5230	
5230	He sat down abruptly on the surgical bench. ""He's not only
5230	invisible,"" he said, ""but he's mad! Homicidal!""
5230	
5230	When dawn came to mingle its pallor with the lamp-light and cigar
5230	smoke of the dining-room, Kemp was still pacing up and down, trying
5230	to grasp the incredible.
5230	
5230	He was altogether too excited to sleep. His servants, descending
5230	sleepily, discovered him, and were inclined to think that
5230	over-study had worked this ill on him. He gave them extraordinary
5230	but quite explicit instructions to lay breakfast for two in the
5230	belvedere study--and then to confine themselves to the basement
5230	and ground-floor. Then he continued to pace the dining-room until
5230	the morning's paper came. That had much to say and little to tell,
5230	beyond the confirmation of the evening before, and a very badly
5230	written account of another remarkable tale from Port Burdock. This
5230	gave Kemp the essence of the happenings at the ""Jolly Cricketers,""
5230	and the name of Marvel. ""He has made me keep with him twenty-four
5230	hours,"" Marvel testified. Certain minor facts were added to the
5230	Iping story, notably the cutting of the village telegraph-wire.
5230	But there was nothing to throw light on the connexion between
5230	the Invisible Man and the Tramp; for Mr. Marvel had supplied no
5230	information about the three books, or the money with which he was
5230	lined. The incredulous tone had vanished and a shoal of reporters
5230	and inquirers were already at work elaborating the matter.
5230	
5230	Kemp read every scrap of the report and sent his housemaid out to
5230	get every one of the morning papers she could. These also he
5230	devoured.
5230	
5230	""He is invisible!"" he said. ""And it reads like rage growing to
5230	mania! The things he may do! The things he may do! And he's
5230	upstairs free as the air. What on earth ought I to do?""
5230	
5230	""For instance, would it be a breach of faith if--? No.""
5230	
5230	He went to a little untidy desk in the corner, and began a note. He
5230	tore this up half written, and wrote another. He read it over and
5230	considered it. Then he took an envelope and addressed it to ""Colonel
5230	Adye, Port Burdock.""
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man awoke even as Kemp was doing this. He awoke in an
5230	evil temper, and Kemp, alert for every sound, heard his pattering
5230	feet rush suddenly across the bedroom overhead. Then a chair was
5230	flung over and the wash-hand stand tumbler smashed. Kemp hurried
5230	upstairs and rapped eagerly.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XIX
5230	
5230	CERTAIN FIRST PRINCIPLES
5230	
5230	
5230	""What's the matter?"" asked Kemp, when the Invisible Man admitted him.
5230	
5230	""Nothing,"" was the answer.
5230	
5230	""But, confound it! The smash?""
5230	
5230	""Fit of temper,"" said the Invisible Man. ""Forgot this arm; and it's
5230	sore.""
5230	
5230	""You're rather liable to that sort of thing.""
5230	
5230	""I am.""
5230	
5230	Kemp walked across the room and picked up the fragments of broken
5230	glass. ""All the facts are out about you,"" said Kemp, standing up
5230	with the glass in his hand; ""all that happened in Iping, and down
5230	the hill. The world has become aware of its invisible citizen. But
5230	no one knows you are here.""
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man swore.
5230	
5230	""The secret's out. I gather it was a secret. I don't know what your
5230	plans are, but of course I'm anxious to help you.""
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man sat down on the bed.
5230	
5230	""There's breakfast upstairs,"" said Kemp, speaking as easily as
5230	possible, and he was delighted to find his strange guest rose
5230	willingly. Kemp led the way up the narrow staircase to the
5230	belvedere.
5230	
5230	""Before we can do anything else,"" said Kemp, ""I must understand a
5230	little more about this invisibility of yours."" He had sat down,
5230	after one nervous glance out of the window, with the air of a man
5230	who has talking to do. His doubts of the sanity of the entire
5230	business flashed and vanished again as he looked across to
5230	where Griffin sat at the breakfast-table--a headless, handless
5230	dressing-gown, wiping unseen lips on a miraculously held serviette.
5230	
5230	""It's simple enough--and credible enough,"" said Griffin, putting
5230	the serviette aside and leaning the invisible head on an invisible
5230	hand.
5230	
5230	""No doubt, to you, but--"" Kemp laughed.
5230	
5230	""Well, yes; to me it seemed wonderful at first, no doubt. But now,
5230	great God! ... But we will do great things yet! I came on the stuff
5230	first at Chesilstowe.""
5230	
5230	""Chesilstowe?""
5230	
5230	""I went there after I left London. You know I dropped medicine and
5230	took up physics? No; well, I did. _Light_ fascinated me.""
5230	
5230	""Ah!""
5230	
5230	""Optical density! The whole subject is a network of riddles--a
5230	network with solutions glimmering elusively through. And being but
5230	two-and-twenty and full of enthusiasm, I said, 'I will devote my
5230	life to this. This is worth while.' You know what fools we are at
5230	two-and-twenty?""
5230	
5230	""Fools then or fools now,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""As though knowing could be any satisfaction to a man!
5230	
5230	""But I went to work--like a slave. And I had hardly worked and
5230	thought about the matter six months before light came through one
5230	of the meshes suddenly--blindingly! I found a general principle
5230	of pigments and refraction--a formula, a geometrical expression
5230	involving four dimensions. Fools, common men, even common
5230	mathematicians, do not know anything of what some general expression
5230	may mean to the student of molecular physics. In the books--the
5230	books that tramp has hidden--there are marvels, miracles! But this
5230	was not a method, it was an idea, that might lead to a method by
5230	which it would be possible, without changing any other property of
5230	matter--except, in some instances colours--to lower the refractive
5230	index of a substance, solid or liquid, to that of air--so far as all
5230	practical purposes are concerned.""
5230	
5230	""Phew!"" said Kemp. ""That's odd! But still I don't see quite ... I
5230	can understand that thereby you could spoil a valuable stone, but
5230	personal invisibility is a far cry.""
5230	
5230	""Precisely,"" said Griffin. ""But consider, visibility depends on the
5230	action of the visible bodies on light. Either a body absorbs light,
5230	or it reflects or refracts it, or does all these things. If it
5230	neither reflects nor refracts nor absorbs light, it cannot of
5230	itself be visible. You see an opaque red box, for instance, because
5230	the colour absorbs some of the light and reflects the rest, all the
5230	red part of the light, to you. If it did not absorb any particular
5230	part of the light, but reflected it all, then it would be a shining
5230	white box. Silver! A diamond box would neither absorb much of the
5230	light nor reflect much from the general surface, but just here
5230	and there where the surfaces were favourable the light would
5230	be reflected and refracted, so that you would get a brilliant
5230	appearance of flashing reflections and translucencies--a sort of
5230	skeleton of light. A glass box would not be so brilliant, nor so
5230	clearly visible, as a diamond box, because there would be less
5230	refraction and reflection. See that? From certain points of view
5230	you would see quite clearly through it. Some kinds of glass would
5230	be more visible than others, a box of flint glass would be brighter
5230	than a box of ordinary window glass. A box of very thin common
5230	glass would be hard to see in a bad light, because it would absorb
5230	hardly any light and refract and reflect very little. And if you
5230	put a sheet of common white glass in water, still more if you
5230	put it in some denser liquid than water, it would vanish almost
5230	altogether, because light passing from water to glass is only
5230	slightly refracted or reflected or indeed affected in any way.
5230	It is almost as invisible as a jet of coal gas or hydrogen is in
5230	air. And for precisely the same reason!""
5230	
5230	""Yes,"" said Kemp, ""that is pretty plain sailing.""
5230	
5230	""And here is another fact you will know to be true. If a sheet of
5230	glass is smashed, Kemp, and beaten into a powder, it becomes much
5230	more visible while it is in the air; it becomes at last an opaque
5230	white powder. This is because the powdering multiplies the surfaces
5230	of the glass at which refraction and reflection occur. In the sheet
5230	of glass there are only two surfaces; in the powder the light is
5230	reflected or refracted by each grain it passes through, and very
5230	little gets right through the powder. But if the white powdered
5230	glass is put into water, it forthwith vanishes. The powdered glass
5230	and water have much the same refractive index; that is, the light
5230	undergoes very little refraction or reflection in passing from one
5230	to the other.
5230	
5230	""You make the glass invisible by putting it into a liquid of nearly
5230	the same refractive index; a transparent thing becomes invisible if
5230	it is put in any medium of almost the same refractive index. And if
5230	you will consider only a second, you will see also that the powder
5230	of glass might be made to vanish in air, if its refractive index
5230	could be made the same as that of air; for then there would be no
5230	refraction or reflection as the light passed from glass to air.""
5230	
5230	""Yes, yes,"" said Kemp. ""But a man's not powdered glass!""
5230	
5230	""No,"" said Griffin. ""He's more transparent!""
5230	
5230	""Nonsense!""
5230	
5230	""That from a doctor! How one forgets! Have you already forgotten
5230	your physics, in ten years? Just think of all the things that are
5230	transparent and seem not to be so. Paper, for instance, is made up
5230	of transparent fibres, and it is white and opaque only for the same
5230	reason that a powder of glass is white and opaque. Oil white paper,
5230	fill up the interstices between the particles with oil so that there
5230	is no longer refraction or reflection except at the surfaces, and
5230	it becomes as transparent as glass. And not only paper, but cotton
5230	fibre, linen fibre, wool fibre, woody fibre, and _bone_, Kemp,
5230	_flesh_, Kemp, _hair_, Kemp, _nails_ and _nerves_, Kemp, in fact
5230	the whole fabric of a man except the red of his blood and the black
5230	pigment of hair, are all made up of transparent, colourless tissue.
5230	So little suffices to make us visible one to the other. For the
5230	most part the fibres of a living creature are no more opaque than
5230	water.""
5230	
5230	""Great Heavens!"" cried Kemp. ""Of course, of course! I was thinking
5230	only last night of the sea larvae and all jelly-fish!""
5230	
5230	""_Now_ you have me! And all that I knew and had in mind a year after
5230	I left London--six years ago. But I kept it to myself. I had to do
5230	my work under frightful disadvantages. Oliver, my professor, was a
5230	scientific bounder, a journalist by instinct, a thief of ideas--he
5230	was always prying! And you know the knavish system of the scientific
5230	world. I simply would not publish, and let him share my credit. I
5230	went on working; I got nearer and nearer making my formula into an
5230	experiment, a reality. I told no living soul, because I meant to
5230	flash my work upon the world with crushing effect and become famous
5230	at a blow. I took up the question of pigments to fill up certain
5230	gaps. And suddenly, not by design but by accident, I made a
5230	discovery in physiology.""
5230	
5230	""Yes?""
5230	
5230	""You know the red colouring matter of blood; it can be made
5230	white--colourless--and remain with all the functions it has now!""
5230	
5230	Kemp gave a cry of incredulous amazement.
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man rose and began pacing the little study. ""You may
5230	well exclaim. I remember that night. It was late at night--in the
5230	daytime one was bothered with the gaping, silly students--and I
5230	worked then sometimes till dawn. It came suddenly, splendid and
5230	complete in my mind. I was alone; the laboratory was still, with the
5230	tall lights burning brightly and silently. In all my great moments
5230	I have been alone. 'One could make an animal--a tissue--transparent!
5230	One could make it invisible! All except the pigments--I could be
5230	invisible!' I said, suddenly realising what it meant to be an albino
5230	with such knowledge. It was overwhelming. I left the filtering I was
5230	doing, and went and stared out of the great window at the stars.
5230	'I could be invisible!' I repeated.
5230	
5230	""To do such a thing would be to transcend magic. And I beheld,
5230	unclouded by doubt, a magnificent vision of all that invisibility
5230	might mean to a man--the mystery, the power, the freedom. Drawbacks
5230	I saw none. You have only to think! And I, a shabby, poverty-struck,
5230	hemmed-in demonstrator, teaching fools in a provincial college,
5230	might suddenly become--this. I ask you, Kemp if _you_ ... Anyone, I
5230	tell you, would have flung himself upon that research. And I worked
5230	three years, and every mountain of difficulty I toiled over showed
5230	another from its summit. The infinite details! And the exasperation!
5230	A professor, a provincial professor, always prying. 'When are you
5230	going to publish this work of yours?' was his everlasting question.
5230	And the students, the cramped means! Three years I had of it--
5230	
5230	""And after three years of secrecy and exasperation, I found that to
5230	complete it was impossible--impossible.""
5230	
5230	""How?"" asked Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Money,"" said the Invisible Man, and went again to stare out of the
5230	window.
5230	
5230	He turned around abruptly. ""I robbed the old man--robbed my
5230	father.
5230	
5230	""The money was not his, and he shot himself.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XX
5230	
5230	AT THE HOUSE IN GREAT PORTLAND STREET
5230	
5230	
5230	For a moment Kemp sat in silence, staring at the back of the
5230	headless figure at the window. Then he started, struck by a thought,
5230	rose, took the Invisible Man's arm, and turned him away from the
5230	outlook.
5230	
5230	""You are tired,"" he said, ""and while I sit, you walk about. Have
5230	my chair.""
5230	
5230	He placed himself between Griffin and the nearest window.
5230	
5230	For a space Griffin sat silent, and then he resumed abruptly:
5230	
5230	""I had left the Chesilstowe cottage already,"" he said, ""when that
5230	happened. It was last December. I had taken a room in London, a
5230	large unfurnished room in a big ill-managed lodging-house in a slum
5230	near Great Portland Street. The room was soon full of the appliances
5230	I had bought with his money; the work was going on steadily,
5230	successfully, drawing near an end. I was like a man emerging from a
5230	thicket, and suddenly coming on some unmeaning tragedy. I went to
5230	bury him. My mind was still on this research, and I did not lift
5230	a finger to save his character. I remember the funeral, the cheap
5230	hearse, the scant ceremony, the windy frost-bitten hillside, and the
5230	old college friend of his who read the service over him--a shabby,
5230	black, bent old man with a snivelling cold.
5230	
5230	""I remember walking back to the empty house, through the place that
5230	had once been a village and was now patched and tinkered by the
5230	jerry builders into the ugly likeness of a town. Every way the
5230	roads ran out at last into the desecrated fields and ended in
5230	rubble heaps and rank wet weeds. I remember myself as a gaunt black
5230	figure, going along the slippery, shiny pavement, and the strange
5230	sense of detachment I felt from the squalid respectability, the
5230	sordid commercialism of the place.
5230	
5230	""I did not feel a bit sorry for my father. He seemed to me to be
5230	the victim of his own foolish sentimentality. The current cant
5230	required my attendance at his funeral, but it was really not my
5230	affair.
5230	
5230	""But going along the High Street, my old life came back to me
5230	for a space, for I met the girl I had known ten years since.
5230	Our eyes met.
5230	
5230	""Something moved me to turn back and talk to her. She was a very
5230	ordinary person.
5230	
5230	""It was all like a dream, that visit to the old places. I did not
5230	feel then that I was lonely, that I had come out from the world
5230	into a desolate place. I appreciated my loss of sympathy, but I put
5230	it down to the general inanity of things. Re-entering my room
5230	seemed like the recovery of reality. There were the things I knew
5230	and loved. There stood the apparatus, the experiments arranged and
5230	waiting. And now there was scarcely a difficulty left, beyond the
5230	planning of details.
5230	
5230	""I will tell you, Kemp, sooner or later, all the complicated
5230	processes. We need not go into that now. For the most part, saving
5230	certain gaps I chose to remember, they are written in cypher in
5230	those books that tramp has hidden. We must hunt him down. We must
5230	get those books again. But the essential phase was to place the
5230	transparent object whose refractive index was to be lowered between
5230	two radiating centres of a sort of ethereal vibration, of which I
5230	will tell you more fully later. No, not those Roentgen vibrations--I
5230	don't know that these others of mine have been described. Yet
5230	they are obvious enough. I needed two little dynamos, and these I
5230	worked with a cheap gas engine. My first experiment was with a bit
5230	of white wool fabric. It was the strangest thing in the world to
5230	see it in the flicker of the flashes soft and white, and then to
5230	watch it fade like a wreath of smoke and vanish.
5230	
5230	""I could scarcely believe I had done it. I put my hand into the
5230	emptiness, and there was the thing as solid as ever. I felt it
5230	awkwardly, and threw it on the floor. I had a little trouble
5230	finding it again.
5230	
5230	""And then came a curious experience. I heard a miaow behind me, and
5230	turning, saw a lean white cat, very dirty, on the cistern cover
5230	outside the window. A thought came into my head. 'Everything ready
5230	for you,' I said, and went to the window, opened it, and called
5230	softly. She came in, purring--the poor beast was starving--and
5230	I gave her some milk. All my food was in a cupboard in the
5230	corner of the room. After that she went smelling round the room,
5230	evidently with the idea of making herself at home. The invisible
5230	rag upset her a bit; you should have seen her spit at it! But I
5230	made her comfortable on the pillow of my truckle-bed. And I gave
5230	her butter to get her to wash.""
5230	
5230	""And you processed her?""
5230	
5230	""I processed her. But giving drugs to a cat is no joke, Kemp! And
5230	the process failed.""
5230	
5230	""Failed!""
5230	
5230	""In two particulars. These were the claws and the pigment stuff,
5230	what is it?--at the back of the eye in a cat. You know?""
5230	
5230	""_Tapetum_.""
5230	
5230	""Yes, the _tapetum_. It didn't go. After I'd given the stuff to
5230	bleach the blood and done certain other things to her, I gave the
5230	beast opium, and put her and the pillow she was sleeping on, on the
5230	apparatus. And after all the rest had faded and vanished, there
5230	remained two little ghosts of her eyes.""
5230	
5230	""Odd!""
5230	
5230	""I can't explain it. She was bandaged and clamped, of course--so
5230	I had her safe; but she woke while she was still misty, and miaowed
5230	dismally, and someone came knocking. It was an old woman from
5230	downstairs, who suspected me of vivisecting--a drink-sodden old
5230	creature, with only a white cat to care for in all the world. I
5230	whipped out some chloroform, applied it, and answered the door.
5230	'Did I hear a cat?' she asked. 'My cat?' 'Not here,' said I, very
5230	politely. She was a little doubtful and tried to peer past me into
5230	the room; strange enough to her no doubt--bare walls, uncurtained
5230	windows, truckle-bed, with the gas engine vibrating, and the
5230	seethe of the radiant points, and that faint ghastly stinging of
5230	chloroform in the air. She had to be satisfied at last and went
5230	away again.""
5230	
5230	""How long did it take?"" asked Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Three or four hours--the cat. The bones and sinews and the fat
5230	were the last to go, and the tips of the coloured hairs. And, as I
5230	say, the back part of the eye, tough, iridescent stuff it is,
5230	wouldn't go at all.
5230	
5230	""It was night outside long before the business was over, and nothing
5230	was to be seen but the dim eyes and the claws. I stopped the gas
5230	engine, felt for and stroked the beast, which was still insensible,
5230	and then, being tired, left it sleeping on the invisible pillow and
5230	went to bed. I found it hard to sleep. I lay awake thinking weak
5230	aimless stuff, going over the experiment over and over again, or
5230	dreaming feverishly of things growing misty and vanishing about me,
5230	until everything, the ground I stood on, vanished, and so I came to
5230	that sickly falling nightmare one gets. About two, the cat began
5230	miaowing about the room. I tried to hush it by talking to it, and
5230	then I decided to turn it out. I remember the shock I had when
5230	striking a light--there were just the round eyes shining green--and
5230	nothing round them. I would have given it milk, but I hadn't any. It
5230	wouldn't be quiet, it just sat down and miaowed at the door. I tried
5230	to catch it, with an idea of putting it out of the window, but it
5230	wouldn't be caught, it vanished. Then it began miaowing in different
5230	parts of the room. At last I opened the window and made a bustle. I
5230	suppose it went out at last. I never saw any more of it.
5230	
5230	""Then--Heaven knows why--I fell thinking of my father's funeral
5230	again, and the dismal windy hillside, until the day had come. I
5230	found sleeping was hopeless, and, locking my door after me,
5230	wandered out into the morning streets.""
5230	
5230	""You don't mean to say there's an invisible cat at large!"" said
5230	Kemp.
5230	
5230	""If it hasn't been killed,"" said the Invisible Man. ""Why not?""
5230	
5230	""Why not?"" said Kemp. ""I didn't mean to interrupt.""
5230	
5230	""It's very probably been killed,"" said the Invisible Man. ""It
5230	was alive four days after, I know, and down a grating in Great
5230	Titchfield Street; because I saw a crowd round the place, trying
5230	to see whence the miaowing came.""
5230	
5230	He was silent for the best part of a minute. Then he resumed
5230	abruptly:
5230	
5230	""I remember that morning before the change very vividly. I must have
5230	gone up Great Portland Street. I remember the barracks in Albany
5230	Street, and the horse soldiers coming out, and at last I found the
5230	summit of Primrose Hill. It was a sunny day in January--one of those
5230	sunny, frosty days that came before the snow this year. My weary
5230	brain tried to formulate the position, to plot out a plan of action.
5230	
5230	""I was surprised to find, now that my prize was within my grasp, how
5230	inconclusive its attainment seemed. As a matter of fact I was worked
5230	out; the intense stress of nearly four years' continuous work left
5230	me incapable of any strength of feeling. I was apathetic, and I
5230	tried in vain to recover the enthusiasm of my first inquiries,
5230	the passion of discovery that had enabled me to compass even the
5230	downfall of my father's grey hairs. Nothing seemed to matter. I saw
5230	pretty clearly this was a transient mood, due to overwork and want
5230	of sleep, and that either by drugs or rest it would be possible to
5230	recover my energies.
5230	
5230	""All I could think clearly was that the thing had to be carried
5230	through; the fixed idea still ruled me. And soon, for the money I
5230	had was almost exhausted. I looked about me at the hillside, with
5230	children playing and girls watching them, and tried to think of all
5230	the fantastic advantages an invisible man would have in the world.
5230	After a time I crawled home, took some food and a strong dose of
5230	strychnine, and went to sleep in my clothes on my unmade bed.
5230	Strychnine is a grand tonic, Kemp, to take the flabbiness out of
5230	a man.""
5230	
5230	""It's the devil,"" said Kemp. ""It's the palaeolithic in a bottle.""
5230	
5230	""I awoke vastly invigorated and rather irritable. You know?""
5230	
5230	""I know the stuff.""
5230	
5230	""And there was someone rapping at the door. It was my landlord
5230	with threats and inquiries, an old Polish Jew in a long grey coat
5230	and greasy slippers. I had been tormenting a cat in the night, he
5230	was sure--the old woman's tongue had been busy. He insisted on
5230	knowing all about it. The laws in this country against vivisection
5230	were very severe--he might be liable. I denied the cat. Then the
5230	vibration of the little gas engine could be felt all over the
5230	house, he said. That was true, certainly. He edged round me into
5230	the room, peering about over his German-silver spectacles, and a
5230	sudden dread came into my mind that he might carry away something
5230	of my secret. I tried to keep between him and the concentrating
5230	apparatus I had arranged, and that only made him more curious. What
5230	was I doing? Why was I always alone and secretive? Was it legal?
5230	Was it dangerous? I paid nothing but the usual rent. His had always
5230	been a most respectable house--in a disreputable neighbourhood.
5230	Suddenly my temper gave way. I told him to get out. He began to
5230	protest, to jabber of his right of entry. In a moment I had him by
5230	the collar; something ripped, and he went spinning out into his own
5230	passage. I slammed and locked the door and sat down quivering.
5230	
5230	""He made a fuss outside, which I disregarded, and after a time he
5230	went away.
5230	
5230	""But this brought matters to a crisis. I did not know what he
5230	would do, nor even what he had the power to do. To move to fresh
5230	apartments would have meant delay; altogether I had barely twenty
5230	pounds left in the world, for the most part in a bank--and I
5230	could not afford that. Vanish! It was irresistible. Then there
5230	would be an inquiry, the sacking of my room.
5230	
5230	""At the thought of the possibility of my work being exposed or
5230	interrupted at its very climax, I became very angry and active. I
5230	hurried out with my three books of notes, my cheque-book--the tramp
5230	has them now--and directed them from the nearest Post Office to a
5230	house of call for letters and parcels in Great Portland Street. I
5230	tried to go out noiselessly. Coming in, I found my landlord going
5230	quietly upstairs; he had heard the door close, I suppose. You would
5230	have laughed to see him jump aside on the landing as I came tearing
5230	after him. He glared at me as I went by him, and I made the house
5230	quiver with the slamming of my door. I heard him come shuffling up
5230	to my floor, hesitate, and go down. I set to work upon my
5230	preparations forthwith.
5230	
5230	""It was all done that evening and night. While I was still sitting
5230	under the sickly, drowsy influence of the drugs that decolourise
5230	blood, there came a repeated knocking at the door. It ceased,
5230	footsteps went away and returned, and the knocking was resumed.
5230	There was an attempt to push something under the door--a blue
5230	paper. Then in a fit of irritation I rose and went and flung the
5230	door wide open. 'Now then?' said I.
5230	
5230	""It was my landlord, with a notice of ejectment or something. He
5230	held it out to me, saw something odd about my hands, I expect, and
5230	lifted his eyes to my face.
5230	
5230	""For a moment he gaped. Then he gave a sort of inarticulate cry,
5230	dropped candle and writ together, and went blundering down the dark
5230	passage to the stairs. I shut the door, locked it, and went to the
5230	looking-glass. Then I understood his terror.... My face was
5230	white--like white stone.
5230	
5230	""But it was all horrible. I had not expected the suffering. A night
5230	of racking anguish, sickness and fainting. I set my teeth, though my
5230	skin was presently afire, all my body afire; but I lay there like
5230	grim death. I understood now how it was the cat had howled until I
5230	chloroformed it. Lucky it was I lived alone and untended in my room.
5230	There were times when I sobbed and groaned and talked. But I stuck
5230	to it.... I became insensible and woke languid in the darkness.
5230	
5230	""The pain had passed. I thought I was killing myself and I did not
5230	care. I shall never forget that dawn, and the strange horror of
5230	seeing that my hands had become as clouded glass, and watching them
5230	grow clearer and thinner as the day went by, until at last I could
5230	see the sickly disorder of my room through them, though I closed my
5230	transparent eyelids. My limbs became glassy, the bones and arteries
5230	faded, vanished, and the little white nerves went last. I gritted
5230	my teeth and stayed there to the end. At last only the dead tips of
5230	the fingernails remained, pallid and white, and the brown stain of
5230	some acid upon my fingers.
5230	
5230	""I struggled up. At first I was as incapable as a swathed
5230	infant--stepping with limbs I could not see. I was weak and very
5230	hungry. I went and stared at nothing in my shaving-glass, at nothing
5230	save where an attenuated pigment still remained behind the retina of
5230	my eyes, fainter than mist. I had to hang on to the table and press
5230	my forehead against the glass.
5230	
5230	""It was only by a frantic effort of will that I dragged myself back
5230	to the apparatus and completed the process.
5230	
5230	""I slept during the forenoon, pulling the sheet over my eyes to shut
5230	out the light, and about midday I was awakened again by a knocking.
5230	My strength had returned. I sat up and listened and heard a
5230	whispering. I sprang to my feet and as noiselessly as possible began
5230	to detach the connections of my apparatus, and to distribute it
5230	about the room, so as to destroy the suggestions of its arrangement.
5230	Presently the knocking was renewed and voices called, first my
5230	landlord's, and then two others. To gain time I answered them. The
5230	invisible rag and pillow came to hand and I opened the window and
5230	pitched them out on to the cistern cover. As the window opened, a
5230	heavy crash came at the door. Someone had charged it with the idea
5230	of smashing the lock. But the stout bolts I had screwed up some
5230	days before stopped him. That startled me, made me angry. I began
5230	to tremble and do things hurriedly.
5230	
5230	""I tossed together some loose paper, straw, packing paper and so
5230	forth, in the middle of the room, and turned on the gas. Heavy
5230	blows began to rain upon the door. I could not find the matches. I
5230	beat my hands on the wall with rage. I turned down the gas again,
5230	stepped out of the window on the cistern cover, very softly lowered
5230	the sash, and sat down, secure and invisible, but quivering with
5230	anger, to watch events. They split a panel, I saw, and in another
5230	moment they had broken away the staples of the bolts and stood in
5230	the open doorway. It was the landlord and his two step-sons, sturdy
5230	young men of three or four and twenty. Behind them fluttered the
5230	old hag of a woman from downstairs.
5230	
5230	""You may imagine their astonishment to find the room empty. One of
5230	the younger men rushed to the window at once, flung it up and stared
5230	out. His staring eyes and thick-lipped bearded face came a foot
5230	from my face. I was half minded to hit his silly countenance, but I
5230	arrested my doubled fist. He stared right through me. So did the
5230	others as they joined him. The old man went and peered under the
5230	bed, and then they all made a rush for the cupboard. They had to
5230	argue about it at length in Yiddish and Cockney English. They
5230	concluded I had not answered them, that their imagination had
5230	deceived them. A feeling of extraordinary elation took the place
5230	of my anger as I sat outside the window and watched these four
5230	people--for the old lady came in, glancing suspiciously about her
5230	like a cat, trying to understand the riddle of my behaviour.
5230	
5230	""The old man, so far as I could understand his _patois_, agreed with
5230	the old lady that I was a vivisectionist. The sons protested in
5230	garbled English that I was an electrician, and appealed to the
5230	dynamos and radiators. They were all nervous about my arrival,
5230	although I found subsequently that they had bolted the front door.
5230	The old lady peered into the cupboard and under the bed, and one of
5230	the young men pushed up the register and stared up the chimney. One
5230	of my fellow lodgers, a coster-monger who shared the opposite room
5230	with a butcher, appeared on the landing, and he was called in and
5230	told incoherent things.
5230	
5230	""It occurred to me that the radiators, if they fell into the hands
5230	of some acute well-educated person, would give me away too much,
5230	and watching my opportunity, I came into the room and tilted one of
5230	the little dynamos off its fellow on which it was standing, and
5230	smashed both apparatus. Then, while they were trying to explain the
5230	smash, I dodged out of the room and went softly downstairs.
5230	
5230	""I went into one of the sitting-rooms and waited until they came
5230	down, still speculating and argumentative, all a little disappointed
5230	at finding no 'horrors,' and all a little puzzled how they stood
5230	legally towards me. Then I slipped up again with a box of matches,
5230	fired my heap of paper and rubbish, put the chairs and bedding
5230	thereby, led the gas to the affair, by means of an india-rubber
5230	tube, and waving a farewell to the room left it for the last time.""
5230	
5230	""You fired the house!"" exclaimed Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Fired the house. It was the only way to cover my trail--and no
5230	doubt it was insured. I slipped the bolts of the front door quietly
5230	and went out into the street. I was invisible, and I was only just
5230	beginning to realise the extraordinary advantage my invisibility
5230	gave me. My head was already teeming with plans of all the wild and
5230	wonderful things I had now impunity to do.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXI
5230	
5230	IN OXFORD STREET
5230	
5230	
5230	""In going downstairs the first time I found an unexpected difficulty
5230	because I could not see my feet; indeed I stumbled twice, and there
5230	was an unaccustomed clumsiness in gripping the bolt. By not looking
5230	down, however, I managed to walk on the level passably well.
5230	
5230	""My mood, I say, was one of exaltation. I felt as a seeing man
5230	might do, with padded feet and noiseless clothes, in a city of the
5230	blind. I experienced a wild impulse to jest, to startle people, to
5230	clap men on the back, fling people's hats astray, and generally
5230	revel in my extraordinary advantage.
5230	
5230	""But hardly had I emerged upon Great Portland Street, however (my
5230	lodging was close to the big draper's shop there), when I heard a
5230	clashing concussion and was hit violently behind, and turning saw
5230	a man carrying a basket of soda-water syphons, and looking in
5230	amazement at his burden. Although the blow had really hurt me, I
5230	found something so irresistible in his astonishment that I laughed
5230	aloud. 'The devil's in the basket,' I said, and suddenly twisted
5230	it out of his hand. He let go incontinently, and I swung the whole
5230	weight into the air.
5230	
5230	""But a fool of a cabman, standing outside a public house, made a
5230	sudden rush for this, and his extending fingers took me with
5230	excruciating violence under the ear. I let the whole down with a
5230	smash on the cabman, and then, with shouts and the clatter of feet
5230	about me, people coming out of shops, vehicles pulling up, I
5230	realised what I had done for myself, and cursing my folly, backed
5230	against a shop window and prepared to dodge out of the confusion. In
5230	a moment I should be wedged into a crowd and inevitably discovered.
5230	I pushed by a butcher boy, who luckily did not turn to see the
5230	nothingness that shoved him aside, and dodged behind the cab-man's
5230	four-wheeler. I do not know how they settled the business. I hurried
5230	straight across the road, which was happily clear, and hardly
5230	heeding which way I went, in the fright of detection the incident
5230	had given me, plunged into the afternoon throng of Oxford Street.
5230	
5230	""I tried to get into the stream of people, but they were too thick
5230	for me, and in a moment my heels were being trodden upon. I took to
5230	the gutter, the roughness of which I found painful to my feet, and
5230	forthwith the shaft of a crawling hansom dug me forcibly under the
5230	shoulder blade, reminding me that I was already bruised severely. I
5230	staggered out of the way of the cab, avoided a perambulator by a
5230	convulsive movement, and found myself behind the hansom. A happy
5230	thought saved me, and as this drove slowly along I followed in its
5230	immediate wake, trembling and astonished at the turn of my
5230	adventure. And not only trembling, but shivering. It was a bright
5230	day in January and I was stark naked and the thin slime of mud that
5230	covered the road was freezing. Foolish as it seems to me now, I had
5230	not reckoned that, transparent or not, I was still amenable to the
5230	weather and all its consequences.
5230	
5230	""Then suddenly a bright idea came into my head. I ran round and got
5230	into the cab. And so, shivering, scared, and sniffing with the first
5230	intimations of a cold, and with the bruises in the small of my back
5230	growing upon my attention, I drove slowly along Oxford Street and
5230	past Tottenham Court Road. My mood was as different from that in
5230	which I had sallied forth ten minutes ago as it is possible to
5230	imagine. This invisibility indeed! The one thought that possessed
5230	me was--how was I to get out of the scrape I was in.
5230	
5230	""We crawled past Mudie's, and there a tall woman with five or six
5230	yellow-labelled books hailed my cab, and I sprang out just in time
5230	to escape her, shaving a railway van narrowly in my flight. I made
5230	off up the roadway to Bloomsbury Square, intending to strike north
5230	past the Museum and so get into the quiet district. I was now
5230	cruelly chilled, and the strangeness of my situation so unnerved me
5230	that I whimpered as I ran. At the northward corner of the Square a
5230	little white dog ran out of the Pharmaceutical Society's offices,
5230	and incontinently made for me, nose down.
5230	
5230	""I had never realised it before, but the nose is to the mind of a
5230	dog what the eye is to the mind of a seeing man. Dogs perceive the
5230	scent of a man moving as men perceive his vision. This brute began
5230	barking and leaping, showing, as it seemed to me, only too plainly
5230	that he was aware of me. I crossed Great Russell Street, glancing
5230	over my shoulder as I did so, and went some way along Montague
5230	Street before I realised what I was running towards.
5230	
5230	""Then I became aware of a blare of music, and looking along the
5230	street saw a number of people advancing out of Russell Square, red
5230	shirts, and the banner of the Salvation Army to the fore. Such a
5230	crowd, chanting in the roadway and scoffing on the pavement, I
5230	could not hope to penetrate, and dreading to go back and farther
5230	from home again, and deciding on the spur of the moment, I ran up
5230	the white steps of a house facing the museum railings, and stood
5230	there until the crowd should have passed. Happily the dog stopped
5230	at the noise of the band too, hesitated, and turned tail, running
5230	back to Bloomsbury Square again.
5230	
5230	""On came the band, bawling with unconscious irony some hymn about
5230	'When shall we see His face?' and it seemed an interminable time
5230	to me before the tide of the crowd washed along the pavement by me.
5230	Thud, thud, thud, came the drum with a vibrating resonance, and for
5230	the moment I did not notice two urchins stopping at the railings by
5230	me. 'See 'em,' said one. 'See what?' said the other. 'Why--them
5230	footmarks--bare. Like what you makes in mud.'
5230	
5230	""I looked down and saw the youngsters had stopped and were gaping
5230	at the muddy footmarks I had left behind me up the newly whitened
5230	steps. The passing people elbowed and jostled them, but their
5230	confounded intelligence was arrested. 'Thud, thud, thud, when,
5230	thud, shall we see, thud, his face, thud, thud.' 'There's a
5230	barefoot man gone up them steps, or I don't know nothing,' said
5230	one. 'And he ain't never come down again. And his foot was
5230	a-bleeding.'
5230	
5230	""The thick of the crowd had already passed. 'Looky there, Ted,'
5230	quoth the younger of the detectives, with the sharpness of surprise
5230	in his voice, and pointed straight to my feet. I looked down and
5230	saw at once the dim suggestion of their outline sketched in
5230	splashes of mud. For a moment I was paralysed.
5230	
5230	""'Why, that's rum,' said the elder. 'Dashed rum! It's just like
5230	the ghost of a foot, ain't it?' He hesitated and advanced with
5230	outstretched hand. A man pulled up short to see what he was
5230	catching, and then a girl. In another moment he would have touched
5230	me. Then I saw what to do. I made a step, the boy started back with
5230	an exclamation, and with a rapid movement I swung myself over into
5230	the portico of the next house. But the smaller boy was sharp-eyed
5230	enough to follow the movement, and before I was well down the
5230	steps and upon the pavement, he had recovered from his momentary
5230	astonishment and was shouting out that the feet had gone over the
5230	wall.
5230	
5230	""They rushed round and saw my new footmarks flash into being on the
5230	lower step and upon the pavement. 'What's up?' asked someone.
5230	'Feet! Look! Feet running!'
5230	
5230	""Everybody in the road, except my three pursuers, was pouring along
5230	after the Salvation Army, and this blow not only impeded me but them.
5230	There was an eddy of surprise and interrogation. At the cost of
5230	bowling over one young fellow I got through, and in another moment
5230	I was rushing headlong round the circuit of Russell Square, with
5230	six or seven astonished people following my footmarks. There was
5230	no time for explanation, or else the whole host would have been
5230	after me.
5230	
5230	""Twice I doubled round corners, thrice I crossed the road and came
5230	back upon my tracks, and then, as my feet grew hot and dry, the
5230	damp impressions began to fade. At last I had a breathing space
5230	and rubbed my feet clean with my hands, and so got away altogether.
5230	The last I saw of the chase was a little group of a dozen people
5230	perhaps, studying with infinite perplexity a slowly drying
5230	footprint that had resulted from a puddle in Tavistock Square, a
5230	footprint as isolated and incomprehensible to them as Crusoe's
5230	solitary discovery.
5230	
5230	""This running warmed me to a certain extent, and I went on with a
5230	better courage through the maze of less frequented roads that runs
5230	hereabouts. My back had now become very stiff and sore, my tonsils
5230	were painful from the cabman's fingers, and the skin of my neck
5230	had been scratched by his nails; my feet hurt exceedingly and I
5230	was lame from a little cut on one foot. I saw in time a blind
5230	man approaching me, and fled limping, for I feared his subtle
5230	intuitions. Once or twice accidental collisions occurred and I left
5230	people amazed, with unaccountable curses ringing in their ears.
5230	Then came something silent and quiet against my face, and across
5230	the Square fell a thin veil of slowly falling flakes of snow. I had
5230	caught a cold, and do as I would I could not avoid an occasional
5230	sneeze. And every dog that came in sight, with its pointing nose
5230	and curious sniffing, was a terror to me.
5230	
5230	""Then came men and boys running, first one and then others, and
5230	shouting as they ran. It was a fire. They ran in the direction of
5230	my lodging, and looking back down a street I saw a mass of black
5230	smoke streaming up above the roofs and telephone wires. It was my
5230	lodging burning; my clothes, my apparatus, all my resources indeed,
5230	except my cheque-book and the three volumes of memoranda that
5230	awaited me in Great Portland Street, were there. Burning! I had
5230	burnt my boats--if ever a man did! The place was blazing.""
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man paused and thought. Kemp glanced nervously out of
5230	the window. ""Yes?"" he said. ""Go on.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXII
5230	
5230	IN THE EMPORIUM
5230	
5230	
5230	""So last January, with the beginning of a snowstorm in the air
5230	about me--and if it settled on me it would betray me!--weary,
5230	cold, painful, inexpressibly wretched, and still but half convinced
5230	of my invisible quality, I began this new life to which I am
5230	committed. I had no refuge, no appliances, no human being in the
5230	world in whom I could confide. To have told my secret would have
5230	given me away--made a mere show and rarity of me. Nevertheless, I
5230	was half-minded to accost some passer-by and throw myself upon his
5230	mercy. But I knew too clearly the terror and brutal cruelty my
5230	advances would evoke. I made no plans in the street. My sole object
5230	was to get shelter from the snow, to get myself covered and warm;
5230	then I might hope to plan. But even to me, an Invisible Man, the
5230	rows of London houses stood latched, barred, and bolted
5230	impregnably.
5230	
5230	""Only one thing could I see clearly before me--the cold exposure
5230	and misery of the snowstorm and the night.
5230	
5230	""And then I had a brilliant idea. I turned down one of the roads
5230	leading from Gower Street to Tottenham Court Road, and found myself
5230	outside Omniums, the big establishment where everything is to be
5230	bought--you know the place: meat, grocery, linen, furniture,
5230	clothing, oil paintings even--a huge meandering collection of shops
5230	rather than a shop. I had thought I should find the doors open, but
5230	they were closed, and as I stood in the wide entrance a carriage
5230	stopped outside, and a man in uniform--you know the kind of
5230	personage with 'Omnium' on his cap--flung open the door. I contrived
5230	to enter, and walking down the shop--it was a department where they
5230	were selling ribbons and gloves and stockings and that kind of
5230	thing--came to a more spacious region devoted to picnic baskets and
5230	wicker furniture.
5230	
5230	""I did not feel safe there, however; people were going to and fro,
5230	and I prowled restlessly about until I came upon a huge section in
5230	an upper floor containing multitudes of bedsteads, and over these I
5230	clambered, and found a resting-place at last among a huge pile of
5230	folded flock mattresses. The place was already lit up and agreeably
5230	warm, and I decided to remain where I was, keeping a cautious
5230	eye on the two or three sets of shopmen and customers who were
5230	meandering through the place, until closing time came. Then I
5230	should be able, I thought, to rob the place for food and clothing,
5230	and disguised, prowl through it and examine its resources, perhaps
5230	sleep on some of the bedding. That seemed an acceptable plan.
5230	My idea was to procure clothing to make myself a muffled but
5230	acceptable figure, to get money, and then to recover my books
5230	and parcels where they awaited me, take a lodging somewhere and
5230	elaborate plans for the complete realisation of the advantages my
5230	invisibility gave me (as I still imagined) over my fellow-men.
5230	
5230	""Closing time arrived quickly enough. It could not have been more
5230	than an hour after I took up my position on the mattresses before I
5230	noticed the blinds of the windows being drawn, and customers being
5230	marched doorward. And then a number of brisk young men began with
5230	remarkable alacrity to tidy up the goods that remained disturbed. I
5230	left my lair as the crowds diminished, and prowled cautiously out
5230	into the less desolate parts of the shop. I was really surprised to
5230	observe how rapidly the young men and women whipped away the goods
5230	displayed for sale during the day. All the boxes of goods, the
5230	hanging fabrics, the festoons of lace, the boxes of sweets in the
5230	grocery section, the displays of this and that, were being whipped
5230	down, folded up, slapped into tidy receptacles, and everything that
5230	could not be taken down and put away had sheets of some coarse
5230	stuff like sacking flung over them. Finally all the chairs were
5230	turned up on to the counters, leaving the floor clear. Directly
5230	each of these young people had done, he or she made promptly for
5230	the door with such an expression of animation as I have rarely
5230	observed in a shop assistant before. Then came a lot of youngsters
5230	scattering sawdust and carrying pails and brooms. I had to dodge
5230	to get out of the way, and as it was, my ankle got stung with the
5230	sawdust. For some time, wandering through the swathed and darkened
5230	departments, I could hear the brooms at work. And at last a good
5230	hour or more after the shop had been closed, came a noise of
5230	locking doors. Silence came upon the place, and I found myself
5230	wandering through the vast and intricate shops, galleries, show-rooms
5230	of the place, alone. It was very still; in one place I remember
5230	passing near one of the Tottenham Court Road entrances and listening
5230	to the tapping of boot-heels of the passers-by.
5230	
5230	""My first visit was to the place where I had seen stockings and
5230	gloves for sale. It was dark, and I had the devil of a hunt after
5230	matches, which I found at last in the drawer of the little cash
5230	desk. Then I had to get a candle. I had to tear down wrappings and
5230	ransack a number of boxes and drawers, but at last I managed to turn
5230	out what I sought; the box label called them lambswool pants, and
5230	lambswool vests. Then socks, a thick comforter, and then I went to
5230	the clothing place and got trousers, a lounge jacket, an overcoat
5230	and a slouch hat--a clerical sort of hat with the brim turned down.
5230	I began to feel a human being again, and my next thought was food.
5230	
5230	""Upstairs was a refreshment department, and there I got cold meat.
5230	There was coffee still in the urn, and I lit the gas and warmed it
5230	up again, and altogether I did not do badly. Afterwards, prowling
5230	through the place in search of blankets--I had to put up at last
5230	with a heap of down quilts--I came upon a grocery section with
5230	a lot of chocolate and candied fruits, more than was good for me
5230	indeed--and some white burgundy. And near that was a toy department,
5230	and I had a brilliant idea. I found some artificial noses--dummy
5230	noses, you know, and I thought of dark spectacles. But Omniums had
5230	no optical department. My nose had been a difficulty indeed--I had
5230	thought of paint. But the discovery set my mind running on wigs and
5230	masks and the like. Finally I went to sleep in a heap of down
5230	quilts, very warm and comfortable.
5230	
5230	""My last thoughts before sleeping were the most agreeable I had had
5230	since the change. I was in a state of physical serenity, and that
5230	was reflected in my mind. I thought that I should be able to slip
5230	out unobserved in the morning with my clothes upon me, muffling my
5230	face with a white wrapper I had taken, purchase, with the money I
5230	had taken, spectacles and so forth, and so complete my disguise. I
5230	lapsed into disorderly dreams of all the fantastic things that had
5230	happened during the last few days. I saw the ugly little Jew of a
5230	landlord vociferating in his rooms; I saw his two sons marvelling,
5230	and the wrinkled old woman's gnarled face as she asked for her cat.
5230	I experienced again the strange sensation of seeing the cloth
5230	disappear, and so I came round to the windy hillside and the
5230	sniffing old clergyman mumbling 'Earth to earth, ashes to ashes,
5230	dust to dust,' at my father's open grave.
5230	
5230	""'You also,' said a voice, and suddenly I was being forced towards
5230	the grave. I struggled, shouted, appealed to the mourners, but they
5230	continued stonily following the service; the old clergyman, too,
5230	never faltered droning and sniffing through the ritual. I realised
5230	I was invisible and inaudible, that overwhelming forces had their
5230	grip on me. I struggled in vain, I was forced over the brink, the
5230	coffin rang hollow as I fell upon it, and the gravel came flying
5230	after me in spadefuls. Nobody heeded me, nobody was aware of me. I
5230	made convulsive struggles and awoke.
5230	
5230	""The pale London dawn had come, the place was full of a chilly grey
5230	light that filtered round the edges of the window blinds. I sat up,
5230	and for a time I could not think where this ample apartment, with
5230	its counters, its piles of rolled stuff, its heap of quilts and
5230	cushions, its iron pillars, might be. Then, as recollection came
5230	back to me, I heard voices in conversation.
5230	
5230	""Then far down the place, in the brighter light of some department
5230	which had already raised its blinds, I saw two men approaching. I
5230	scrambled to my feet, looking about me for some way of escape, and
5230	even as I did so the sound of my movement made them aware of me. I
5230	suppose they saw merely a figure moving quietly and quickly away.
5230	'Who's that?' cried one, and 'Stop there!' shouted the other. I
5230	dashed around a corner and came full tilt--a faceless figure,
5230	mind you!--on a lanky lad of fifteen. He yelled and I bowled him
5230	over, rushed past him, turned another corner, and by a happy
5230	inspiration threw myself behind a counter. In another moment feet
5230	went running past and I heard voices shouting, 'All hands to the
5230	doors!' asking what was 'up,' and giving one another advice how to
5230	catch me.
5230	
5230	""Lying on the ground, I felt scared out of my wits. But--odd as
5230	it may seem--it did not occur to me at the moment to take off my
5230	clothes as I should have done. I had made up my mind, I suppose, to
5230	get away in them, and that ruled me. And then down the vista of the
5230	counters came a bawling of 'Here he is!'
5230	
5230	""I sprang to my feet, whipped a chair off the counter, and sent it
5230	whirling at the fool who had shouted, turned, came into another
5230	round a corner, sent him spinning, and rushed up the stairs. He
5230	kept his footing, gave a view hallo, and came up the staircase hot
5230	after me. Up the staircase were piled a multitude of those
5230	bright-coloured pot things--what are they?""
5230	
5230	""Art pots,"" suggested Kemp.
5230	
5230	""That's it! Art pots. Well, I turned at the top step and swung
5230	round, plucked one out of a pile and smashed it on his silly head
5230	as he came at me. The whole pile of pots went headlong, and I heard
5230	shouting and footsteps running from all parts. I made a mad rush
5230	for the refreshment place, and there was a man in white like a man
5230	cook, who took up the chase. I made one last desperate turn and
5230	found myself among lamps and ironmongery. I went behind the counter
5230	of this, and waited for my cook, and as he bolted in at the head of
5230	the chase, I doubled him up with a lamp. Down he went, and I
5230	crouched down behind the counter and began whipping off my clothes
5230	as fast as I could. Coat, jacket, trousers, shoes were all right,
5230	but a lambswool vest fits a man like a skin. I heard more men
5230	coming, my cook was lying quiet on the other side of the counter,
5230	stunned or scared speechless, and I had to make another dash for
5230	it, like a rabbit hunted out of a wood-pile.
5230	
5230	""'This way, policeman!' I heard someone shouting. I found myself in
5230	my bedstead storeroom again, and at the end of a wilderness of
5230	wardrobes. I rushed among them, went flat, got rid of my vest after
5230	infinite wriggling, and stood a free man again, panting and scared,
5230	as the policeman and three of the shopmen came round the corner.
5230	They made a rush for the vest and pants, and collared the trousers.
5230	'He's dropping his plunder,' said one of the young men. 'He _must_
5230	be somewhere here.'
5230	
5230	""But they did not find me all the same.
5230	
5230	""I stood watching them hunt for me for a time, and cursing my
5230	ill-luck in losing the clothes. Then I went into the refreshment-room,
5230	drank a little milk I found there, and sat down by the fire to
5230	consider my position.
5230	
5230	""In a little while two assistants came in and began to talk over
5230	the business very excitedly and like the fools they were. I heard a
5230	magnified account of my depredations, and other speculations as to
5230	my whereabouts. Then I fell to scheming again. The insurmountable
5230	difficulty of the place, especially now it was alarmed, was to get
5230	any plunder out of it. I went down into the warehouse to see if
5230	there was any chance of packing and addressing a parcel, but I
5230	could not understand the system of checking. About eleven o'clock,
5230	the snow having thawed as it fell, and the day being finer and a
5230	little warmer than the previous one, I decided that the Emporium
5230	was hopeless, and went out again, exasperated at my want of
5230	success, with only the vaguest plans of action in my mind.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXIII
5230	
5230	IN DRURY LANE
5230	
5230	
5230	""But you begin now to realise,"" said the Invisible Man, ""the full
5230	disadvantage of my condition. I had no shelter--no covering--to
5230	get clothing was to forego all my advantage, to make myself a
5230	strange and terrible thing. I was fasting; for to eat, to fill
5230	myself with unassimilated matter, would be to become grotesquely
5230	visible again.""
5230	
5230	""I never thought of that,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Nor had I. And the snow had warned me of other dangers. I could not
5230	go abroad in snow--it would settle on me and expose me. Rain, too,
5230	would make me a watery outline, a glistening surface of a man--a
5230	bubble. And fog--I should be like a fainter bubble in a fog,
5230	a surface, a greasy glimmer of humanity. Moreover, as I went
5230	abroad--in the London air--I gathered dirt about my ankles, floating
5230	smuts and dust upon my skin. I did not know how long it would be
5230	before I should become visible from that cause also. But I saw
5230	clearly it could not be for long.
5230	
5230	""Not in London at any rate.
5230	
5230	""I went into the slums towards Great Portland Street, and found
5230	myself at the end of the street in which I had lodged. I did not
5230	go that way, because of the crowd halfway down it opposite to the
5230	still smoking ruins of the house I had fired. My most immediate
5230	problem was to get clothing. What to do with my face puzzled me.
5230	Then I saw in one of those little miscellaneous shops--news,
5230	sweets, toys, stationery, belated Christmas tomfoolery, and so
5230	forth--an array of masks and noses. I realised that problem was
5230	solved. In a flash I saw my course. I turned about, no longer
5230	aimless, and went--circuitously in order to avoid the busy ways,
5230	towards the back streets north of the Strand; for I remembered,
5230	though not very distinctly where, that some theatrical costumiers
5230	had shops in that district.
5230	
5230	""The day was cold, with a nipping wind down the northward running
5230	streets. I walked fast to avoid being overtaken. Every crossing was
5230	a danger, every passenger a thing to watch alertly. One man as I
5230	was about to pass him at the top of Bedford Street, turned upon
5230	me abruptly and came into me, sending me into the road and almost
5230	under the wheel of a passing hansom. The verdict of the cab-rank
5230	was that he had had some sort of stroke. I was so unnerved by this
5230	encounter that I went into Covent Garden Market and sat down for
5230	some time in a quiet corner by a stall of violets, panting and
5230	trembling. I found I had caught a fresh cold, and had to turn out
5230	after a time lest my sneezes should attract attention.
5230	
5230	""At last I reached the object of my quest, a dirty, fly-blown little
5230	shop in a by-way near Drury Lane, with a window full of tinsel
5230	robes, sham jewels, wigs, slippers, dominoes and theatrical
5230	photographs. The shop was old-fashioned and low and dark, and the
5230	house rose above it for four storeys, dark and dismal. I peered
5230	through the window and, seeing no one within, entered. The opening
5230	of the door set a clanking bell ringing. I left it open, and walked
