5230	round a bare costume stand, into a corner behind a cheval glass. For
5230	a minute or so no one came. Then I heard heavy feet striding across
5230	a room, and a man appeared down the shop.
5230	
5230	""My plans were now perfectly definite. I proposed to make my way
5230	into the house, secrete myself upstairs, watch my opportunity, and
5230	when everything was quiet, rummage out a wig, mask, spectacles, and
5230	costume, and go into the world, perhaps a grotesque but still a
5230	credible figure. And incidentally of course I could rob the house
5230	of any available money.
5230	
5230	""The man who had just entered the shop was a short, slight,
5230	hunched, beetle-browed man, with long arms and very short bandy
5230	legs. Apparently I had interrupted a meal. He stared about the shop
5230	with an expression of expectation. This gave way to surprise, and
5230	then to anger, as he saw the shop empty. 'Damn the boys!' he said.
5230	He went to stare up and down the street. He came in again in a
5230	minute, kicked the door to with his foot spitefully, and went
5230	muttering back to the house door.
5230	
5230	""I came forward to follow him, and at the noise of my movement he
5230	stopped dead. I did so too, startled by his quickness of ear. He
5230	slammed the house door in my face.
5230	
5230	""I stood hesitating. Suddenly I heard his quick footsteps returning,
5230	and the door reopened. He stood looking about the shop like one who
5230	was still not satisfied. Then, murmuring to himself, he examined the
5230	back of the counter and peered behind some fixtures. Then he stood
5230	doubtful. He had left the house door open and I slipped into the
5230	inner room.
5230	
5230	""It was a queer little room, poorly furnished and with a number of
5230	big masks in the corner. On the table was his belated breakfast,
5230	and it was a confoundedly exasperating thing for me, Kemp, to have
5230	to sniff his coffee and stand watching while he came in and resumed
5230	his meal. And his table manners were irritating. Three doors opened
5230	into the little room, one going upstairs and one down, but they
5230	were all shut. I could not get out of the room while he was there;
5230	I could scarcely move because of his alertness, and there was a
5230	draught down my back. Twice I strangled a sneeze just in time.
5230	
5230	""The spectacular quality of my sensations was curious and novel, but
5230	for all that I was heartily tired and angry long before he had done
5230	his eating. But at last he made an end and putting his beggarly
5230	crockery on the black tin tray upon which he had had his teapot, and
5230	gathering all the crumbs up on the mustard stained cloth, he took
5230	the whole lot of things after him. His burden prevented his shutting
5230	the door behind him--as he would have done; I never saw such a man
5230	for shutting doors--and I followed him into a very dirty underground
5230	kitchen and scullery. I had the pleasure of seeing him begin to wash
5230	up, and then, finding no good in keeping down there, and the brick
5230	floor being cold on my feet, I returned upstairs and sat in his
5230	chair by the fire. It was burning low, and scarcely thinking, I put
5230	on a little coal. The noise of this brought him up at once, and
5230	he stood aglare. He peered about the room and was within an ace
5230	of touching me. Even after that examination, he scarcely seemed
5230	satisfied. He stopped in the doorway and took a final inspection
5230	before he went down.
5230	
5230	""I waited in the little parlour for an age, and at last he came up
5230	and opened the upstairs door. I just managed to get by him.
5230	
5230	""On the staircase he stopped suddenly, so that I very nearly
5230	blundered into him. He stood looking back right into my face and
5230	listening. 'I could have sworn,' he said. His long hairy hand
5230	pulled at his lower lip. His eye went up and down the staircase.
5230	Then he grunted and went on up again.
5230	
5230	""His hand was on the handle of a door, and then he stopped again
5230	with the same puzzled anger on his face. He was becoming aware of
5230	the faint sounds of my movements about him. The man must have had
5230	diabolically acute hearing. He suddenly flashed into rage. 'If
5230	there's anyone in this house--' he cried with an oath, and left the
5230	threat unfinished. He put his hand in his pocket, failed to find
5230	what he wanted, and rushing past me went blundering noisily and
5230	pugnaciously downstairs. But I did not follow him. I sat on the
5230	head of the staircase until his return.
5230	
5230	""Presently he came up again, still muttering. He opened the door of
5230	the room, and before I could enter, slammed it in my face.
5230	
5230	""I resolved to explore the house, and spent some time in doing so
5230	as noiselessly as possible. The house was very old and tumble-down,
5230	damp so that the paper in the attics was peeling from the walls, and
5230	rat infested. Some of the door handles were stiff and I was afraid
5230	to turn them. Several rooms I did inspect were unfurnished, and
5230	others were littered with theatrical lumber, bought second-hand, I
5230	judged, from its appearance. In one room next to his I found a lot
5230	of old clothes. I began routing among these, and in my eagerness
5230	forgot again the evident sharpness of his ears. I heard a stealthy
5230	footstep and, looking up just in time, saw him peering in at the
5230	tumbled heap and holding an old-fashioned revolver in his hand.
5230	I stood perfectly still while he stared about open-mouthed and
5230	suspicious. 'It must have been her,' he said slowly. 'Damn her!'
5230	
5230	""He shut the door quietly, and immediately I heard the key turn in
5230	the lock. Then his footsteps retreated. I realised abruptly that I
5230	was locked in. For a minute I did not know what to do. I walked
5230	from door to window and back, and stood perplexed. A gust of anger
5230	came upon me. But I decided to inspect the clothes before I did
5230	anything further, and my first attempt brought down a pile from an
5230	upper shelf. This brought him back, more sinister than ever. That
5230	time he actually touched me, jumped back with amazement and stood
5230	astonished in the middle of the room.
5230	
5230	""Presently he calmed a little. 'Rats,' he said in an undertone,
5230	fingers on lips. He was evidently a little scared. I edged quietly
5230	out of the room, but a plank creaked. Then the infernal little brute
5230	started going all over the house, revolver in hand and locking door
5230	after door and pocketing the keys. When I realised what he was up to
5230	I had a fit of rage--I could hardly control myself sufficiently to
5230	watch my opportunity. By this time I knew he was alone in the house,
5230	and so I made no more ado, but knocked him on the head.""
5230	
5230	""Knocked him on the head?"" exclaimed Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Yes--stunned him--as he was going downstairs. Hit him from
5230	behind with a stool that stood on the landing. He went downstairs
5230	like a bag of old boots.""
5230	
5230	""But--I say! The common conventions of humanity--""
5230	
5230	""Are all very well for common people. But the point was, Kemp, that
5230	I had to get out of that house in a disguise without his seeing me.
5230	I couldn't think of any other way of doing it. And then I gagged
5230	him with a Louis Quatorze vest and tied him up in a sheet.""
5230	
5230	""Tied him up in a sheet!""
5230	
5230	""Made a sort of bag of it. It was rather a good idea to keep the
5230	idiot scared and quiet, and a devilish hard thing to get out
5230	of--head away from the string. My dear Kemp, it's no good your
5230	sitting glaring as though I was a murderer. It had to be done. He
5230	had his revolver. If once he saw me he would be able to describe
5230	me--""
5230	
5230	""But still,"" said Kemp, ""in England--to-day. And the man was in
5230	his own house, and you were--well, robbing.""
5230	
5230	""Robbing! Confound it! You'll call me a thief next! Surely, Kemp,
5230	you're not fool enough to dance on the old strings. Can't you see
5230	my position?""
5230	
5230	""And his too,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man stood up sharply. ""What do you mean to say?""
5230	
5230	Kemp's face grew a trifle hard. He was about to speak and checked
5230	himself. ""I suppose, after all,"" he said with a sudden change of
5230	manner, ""the thing had to be done. You were in a fix. But still--""
5230	
5230	""Of course I was in a fix--an infernal fix. And he made me wild
5230	too--hunting me about the house, fooling about with his revolver,
5230	locking and unlocking doors. He was simply exasperating. You don't
5230	blame me, do you? You don't blame me?""
5230	
5230	""I never blame anyone,"" said Kemp. ""It's quite out of fashion. What
5230	did you do next?""
5230	
5230	""I was hungry. Downstairs I found a loaf and some rank cheese--more
5230	than sufficient to satisfy my hunger. I took some brandy and
5230	water, and then went up past my impromptu bag--he was lying quite
5230	still--to the room containing the old clothes. This looked out
5230	upon the street, two lace curtains brown with dirt guarding the
5230	window. I went and peered out through their interstices. Outside
5230	the day was bright--by contrast with the brown shadows of the
5230	dismal house in which I found myself, dazzlingly bright. A brisk
5230	traffic was going by, fruit carts, a hansom, a four-wheeler with a
5230	pile of boxes, a fishmonger's cart. I turned with spots of colour
5230	swimming before my eyes to the shadowy fixtures behind me. My
5230	excitement was giving place to a clear apprehension of my position
5230	again. The room was full of a faint scent of benzoline, used, I
5230	suppose, in cleaning the garments.
5230	
5230	""I began a systematic search of the place. I should judge the
5230	hunchback had been alone in the house for some time. He was a
5230	curious person. Everything that could possibly be of service to me
5230	I collected in the clothes storeroom, and then I made a deliberate
5230	selection. I found a handbag I thought a suitable possession, and
5230	some powder, rouge, and sticking-plaster.
5230	
5230	""I had thought of painting and powdering my face and all that
5230	there was to show of me, in order to render myself visible, but
5230	the disadvantage of this lay in the fact that I should require
5230	turpentine and other appliances and a considerable amount of time
5230	before I could vanish again. Finally I chose a mask of the better
5230	type, slightly grotesque but not more so than many human beings,
5230	dark glasses, greyish whiskers, and a wig. I could find no
5230	underclothing, but that I could buy subsequently, and for the time I
5230	swathed myself in calico dominoes and some white cashmere scarfs. I
5230	could find no socks, but the hunchback's boots were rather a loose
5230	fit and sufficed. In a desk in the shop were three sovereigns and
5230	about thirty shillings' worth of silver, and in a locked cupboard I
5230	burst in the inner room were eight pounds in gold. I could go forth
5230	into the world again, equipped.
5230	
5230	""Then came a curious hesitation. Was my appearance really
5230	credible? I tried myself with a little bedroom looking-glass,
5230	inspecting myself from every point of view to discover any
5230	forgotten chink, but it all seemed sound. I was grotesque to the
5230	theatrical pitch, a stage miser, but I was certainly not a physical
5230	impossibility. Gathering confidence, I took my looking-glass down
5230	into the shop, pulled down the shop blinds, and surveyed myself
5230	from every point of view with the help of the cheval glass in the
5230	corner.
5230	
5230	""I spent some minutes screwing up my courage and then unlocked the
5230	shop door and marched out into the street, leaving the little man
5230	to get out of his sheet again when he liked. In five minutes a
5230	dozen turnings intervened between me and the costumier's shop. No
5230	one appeared to notice me very pointedly. My last difficulty seemed
5230	overcome.""
5230	
5230	He stopped again.
5230	
5230	""And you troubled no more about the hunchback?"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""No,"" said the Invisible Man. ""Nor have I heard what became of him.
5230	I suppose he untied himself or kicked himself out. The knots were
5230	pretty tight.""
5230	
5230	He became silent and went to the window and stared out.
5230	
5230	""What happened when you went out into the Strand?""
5230	
5230	""Oh!--disillusionment again. I thought my troubles were over.
5230	Practically I thought I had impunity to do whatever I chose,
5230	everything--save to give away my secret. So I thought. Whatever I
5230	did, whatever the consequences might be, was nothing to me. I had
5230	merely to fling aside my garments and vanish. No person could hold
5230	me. I could take my money where I found it. I decided to treat
5230	myself to a sumptuous feast, and then put up at a good hotel, and
5230	accumulate a new outfit of property. I felt amazingly confident;
5230	it's not particularly pleasant recalling that I was an ass. I went
5230	into a place and was already ordering lunch, when it occurred to me
5230	that I could not eat unless I exposed my invisible face. I finished
5230	ordering the lunch, told the man I should be back in ten minutes,
5230	and went out exasperated. I don't know if you have ever been
5230	disappointed in your appetite.""
5230	
5230	""Not quite so badly,"" said Kemp, ""but I can imagine it.""
5230	
5230	""I could have smashed the silly devils. At last, faint with the
5230	desire for tasteful food, I went into another place and demanded a
5230	private room. 'I am disfigured,' I said. 'Badly.' They looked at
5230	me curiously, but of course it was not their affair--and so at
5230	last I got my lunch. It was not particularly well served, but it
5230	sufficed; and when I had had it, I sat over a cigar, trying to plan
5230	my line of action. And outside a snowstorm was beginning.
5230	
5230	""The more I thought it over, Kemp, the more I realised what a
5230	helpless absurdity an Invisible Man was--in a cold and dirty
5230	climate and a crowded civilised city. Before I made this mad
5230	experiment I had dreamt of a thousand advantages. That afternoon
5230	it seemed all disappointment. I went over the heads of the things
5230	a man reckons desirable. No doubt invisibility made it possible
5230	to get them, but it made it impossible to enjoy them when they
5230	are got. Ambition--what is the good of pride of place when you
5230	cannot appear there? What is the good of the love of woman when
5230	her name must needs be Delilah? I have no taste for politics, for
5230	the blackguardisms of fame, for philanthropy, for sport. What was
5230	I to do? And for this I had become a wrapped-up mystery, a swathed
5230	and bandaged caricature of a man!""
5230	
5230	He paused, and his attitude suggested a roving glance at the
5230	window.
5230	
5230	""But how did you get to Iping?"" said Kemp, anxious to keep his
5230	guest busy talking.
5230	
5230	""I went there to work. I had one hope. It was a half idea! I have
5230	it still. It is a full blown idea now. A way of getting back! Of
5230	restoring what I have done. When I choose. When I have done all I
5230	mean to do invisibly. And that is what I chiefly want to talk to
5230	you about now.""
5230	
5230	""You went straight to Iping?""
5230	
5230	""Yes. I had simply to get my three volumes of memoranda and my
5230	cheque-book, my luggage and underclothing, order a quantity of
5230	chemicals to work out this idea of mine--I will show you the
5230	calculations as soon as I get my books--and then I started. Jove!
5230	I remember the snowstorm now, and the accursed bother it was to
5230	keep the snow from damping my pasteboard nose.""
5230	
5230	""At the end,"" said Kemp, ""the day before yesterday, when they found
5230	you out, you rather--to judge by the papers--""
5230	
5230	""I did. Rather. Did I kill that fool of a constable?""
5230	
5230	""No,"" said Kemp. ""He's expected to recover.""
5230	
5230	""That's his luck, then. I clean lost my temper, the fools! Why
5230	couldn't they leave me alone? And that grocer lout?""
5230	
5230	""There are no deaths expected,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""I don't know about that tramp of mine,"" said the Invisible Man,
5230	with an unpleasant laugh.
5230	
5230	""By Heaven, Kemp, you don't know what rage _is_! ... To have worked
5230	for years, to have planned and plotted, and then to get some
5230	fumbling purblind idiot messing across your course! ... Every
5230	conceivable sort of silly creature that has ever been created has
5230	been sent to cross me.
5230	
5230	""If I have much more of it, I shall go wild--I shall start
5230	mowing 'em.
5230	
5230	""As it is, they've made things a thousand times more difficult.""
5230	
5230	""No doubt it's exasperating,"" said Kemp, drily.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXIV
5230	
5230	THE PLAN THAT FAILED
5230	
5230	
5230	""But now,"" said Kemp, with a side glance out of the window, ""what
5230	are we to do?""
5230	
5230	He moved nearer his guest as he spoke in such a manner as to
5230	prevent the possibility of a sudden glimpse of the three men who
5230	were advancing up the hill road--with an intolerable slowness, as
5230	it seemed to Kemp.
5230	
5230	""What were you planning to do when you were heading for Port
5230	Burdock? _Had_ you any plan?""
5230	
5230	""I was going to clear out of the country. But I have altered that
5230	plan rather since seeing you. I thought it would be wise, now the
5230	weather is hot and invisibility possible, to make for the South.
5230	Especially as my secret was known, and everyone would be on the
5230	lookout for a masked and muffled man. You have a line of steamers
5230	from here to France. My idea was to get aboard one and run the
5230	risks of the passage. Thence I could go by train into Spain, or else
5230	get to Algiers. It would not be difficult. There a man might always
5230	be invisible--and yet live. And do things. I was using that tramp
5230	as a money box and luggage carrier, until I decided how to get my
5230	books and things sent over to meet me.""
5230	
5230	""That's clear.""
5230	
5230	""And then the filthy brute must needs try and rob me! He _has_ hidden
5230	my books, Kemp. Hidden my books! If I can lay my hands on him!""
5230	
5230	""Best plan to get the books out of him first.""
5230	
5230	""But where is he? Do you know?""
5230	
5230	""He's in the town police station, locked up, by his own request, in
5230	the strongest cell in the place.""
5230	
5230	""Cur!"" said the Invisible Man.
5230	
5230	""But that hangs up your plans a little.""
5230	
5230	""We must get those books; those books are vital.""
5230	
5230	""Certainly,"" said Kemp, a little nervously, wondering if he heard
5230	footsteps outside. ""Certainly we must get those books. But that
5230	won't be difficult, if he doesn't know they're for you.""
5230	
5230	""No,"" said the Invisible Man, and thought.
5230	
5230	Kemp tried to think of something to keep the talk going, but the
5230	Invisible Man resumed of his own accord.
5230	
5230	""Blundering into your house, Kemp,"" he said, ""changes all my plans.
5230	For you are a man that can understand. In spite of all that has
5230	happened, in spite of this publicity, of the loss of my books, of
5230	what I have suffered, there still remain great possibilities, huge
5230	possibilities--""
5230	
5230	""You have told no one I am here?"" he asked abruptly.
5230	
5230	Kemp hesitated. ""That was implied,"" he said.
5230	
5230	""No one?"" insisted Griffin.
5230	
5230	""Not a soul.""
5230	
5230	""Ah! Now--"" The Invisible Man stood up, and sticking his arms akimbo
5230	began to pace the study.
5230	
5230	""I made a mistake, Kemp, a huge mistake, in carrying this thing
5230	through alone. I have wasted strength, time, opportunities. Alone--it
5230	is wonderful how little a man can do alone! To rob a little,
5230	to hurt a little, and there is the end.
5230	
5230	""What I want, Kemp, is a goal-keeper, a helper, and a hiding-place,
5230	an arrangement whereby I can sleep and eat and rest in peace, and
5230	unsuspected. I must have a confederate. With a confederate, with
5230	food and rest--a thousand things are possible.
5230	
5230	""Hitherto I have gone on vague lines. We have to consider all that
5230	invisibility means, all that it does not mean. It means little
5230	advantage for eavesdropping and so forth--one makes sounds. It's
5230	of little help--a little help perhaps--in housebreaking and so
5230	forth. Once you've caught me you could easily imprison me. But on
5230	the other hand I am hard to catch. This invisibility, in fact, is
5230	only good in two cases: It's useful in getting away, it's useful in
5230	approaching. It's particularly useful, therefore, in killing. I can
5230	walk round a man, whatever weapon he has, choose my point, strike
5230	as I like. Dodge as I like. Escape as I like.""
5230	
5230	Kemp's hand went to his moustache. Was that a movement
5230	downstairs?
5230	
5230	""And it is killing we must do, Kemp.""
5230	
5230	""It is killing we must do,"" repeated Kemp. ""I'm listening to your
5230	plan, Griffin, but I'm not agreeing, mind. _Why_ killing?""
5230	
5230	""Not wanton killing, but a judicious slaying. The point is, they
5230	know there is an Invisible Man--as well as we know there is an
5230	Invisible Man. And that Invisible Man, Kemp, must now establish a
5230	Reign of Terror. Yes; no doubt it's startling. But I mean it. A
5230	Reign of Terror. He must take some town like your Burdock and
5230	terrify and dominate it. He must issue his orders. He can do that
5230	in a thousand ways--scraps of paper thrust under doors would
5230	suffice. And all who disobey his orders he must kill, and kill
5230	all who would defend them.""
5230	
5230	""Humph!"" said Kemp, no longer listening to Griffin but to the sound
5230	of his front door opening and closing.
5230	
5230	""It seems to me, Griffin,"" he said, to cover his wandering
5230	attention, ""that your confederate would be in a difficult
5230	position.""
5230	
5230	""No one would know he was a confederate,"" said the Invisible Man,
5230	eagerly. And then suddenly, ""Hush! What's that downstairs?""
5230	
5230	""Nothing,"" said Kemp, and suddenly began to speak loud and fast.
5230	""I don't agree to this, Griffin,"" he said. ""Understand me, I don't
5230	agree to this. Why dream of playing a game against the race? How
5230	can you hope to gain happiness? Don't be a lone wolf. Publish
5230	your results; take the world--take the nation at least--into your
5230	confidence. Think what you might do with a million helpers--""
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man interrupted--arm extended. ""There are
5230	footsteps coming upstairs,"" he said in a low voice.
5230	
5230	""Nonsense,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Let me see,"" said the Invisible Man, and advanced, arm extended,
5230	to the door.
5230	
5230	And then things happened very swiftly. Kemp hesitated for a second
5230	and then moved to intercept him. The Invisible Man started and stood
5230	still. ""Traitor!"" cried the Voice, and suddenly the dressing-gown
5230	opened, and sitting down the Unseen began to disrobe. Kemp made
5230	three swift steps to the door, and forthwith the Invisible Man--his
5230	legs had vanished--sprang to his feet with a shout. Kemp flung the
5230	door open.
5230	
5230	As it opened, there came a sound of hurrying feet downstairs and
5230	voices.
5230	
5230	With a quick movement Kemp thrust the Invisible Man back, sprang
5230	aside, and slammed the door. The key was outside and ready. In
5230	another moment Griffin would have been alone in the belvedere
5230	study, a prisoner. Save for one little thing. The key had been
5230	slipped in hastily that morning. As Kemp slammed the door it fell
5230	noisily upon the carpet.
5230	
5230	Kemp's face became white. He tried to grip the door handle with
5230	both hands. For a moment he stood lugging. Then the door gave six
5230	inches. But he got it closed again. The second time it was jerked a
5230	foot wide, and the dressing-gown came wedging itself into the
5230	opening. His throat was gripped by invisible fingers, and he left
5230	his hold on the handle to defend himself. He was forced back,
5230	tripped and pitched heavily into the corner of the landing. The
5230	empty dressing-gown was flung on the top of him.
5230	
5230	Halfway up the staircase was Colonel Adye, the recipient of Kemp's
5230	letter, the chief of the Burdock police. He was staring aghast at
5230	the sudden appearance of Kemp, followed by the extraordinary sight
5230	of clothing tossing empty in the air. He saw Kemp felled, and
5230	struggling to his feet. He saw him rush forward, and go down again,
5230	felled like an ox.
5230	
5230	Then suddenly he was struck violently. By nothing! A vast weight,
5230	it seemed, leapt upon him, and he was hurled headlong down the
5230	staircase, with a grip on his throat and a knee in his groin. An
5230	invisible foot trod on his back, a ghostly patter passed downstairs,
5230	he heard the two police officers in the hall shout and run, and the
5230	front door of the house slammed violently.
5230	
5230	He rolled over and sat up staring. He saw, staggering down the
5230	staircase, Kemp, dusty and disheveled, one side of his face white
5230	from a blow, his lip bleeding, and a pink dressing-gown and some
5230	underclothing held in his arms.
5230	
5230	""My God!"" cried Kemp, ""the game's up! He's gone!""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXV
5230	
5230	THE HUNTING OF THE INVISIBLE MAN
5230	
5230	
5230	For a space Kemp was too inarticulate to make Adye understand the
5230	swift things that had just happened. They stood on the landing,
5230	Kemp speaking swiftly, the grotesque swathings of Griffin still on
5230	his arm. But presently Adye began to grasp something of the
5230	situation.
5230	
5230	""He is mad,"" said Kemp; ""inhuman. He is pure selfishness. He thinks
5230	of nothing but his own advantage, his own safety. I have listened
5230	to such a story this morning of brutal self-seeking.... He has wounded
5230	men. He will kill them unless we can prevent him. He will create a
5230	panic. Nothing can stop him. He is going out now--furious!""
5230	
5230	""He must be caught,"" said Adye. ""That is certain.""
5230	
5230	""But how?"" cried Kemp, and suddenly became full of ideas. ""You must
5230	begin at once. You must set every available man to work; you must
5230	prevent his leaving this district. Once he gets away, he may go
5230	through the countryside as he wills, killing and maiming. He dreams
5230	of a reign of terror! A reign of terror, I tell you. You must set a
5230	watch on trains and roads and shipping. The garrison must help. You
5230	must wire for help. The only thing that may keep him here is the
5230	thought of recovering some books of notes he counts of value. I will
5230	tell you of that! There is a man in your police station--Marvel.""
5230	
5230	""I know,"" said Adye, ""I know. Those books--yes. But the tramp....""
5230	
5230	""Says he hasn't them. But he thinks the tramp has. And you must
5230	prevent him from eating or sleeping; day and night the country must
5230	be astir for him. Food must be locked up and secured, all food, so
5230	that he will have to break his way to it. The houses everywhere must
5230	be barred against him. Heaven send us cold nights and rain! The
5230	whole country-side must begin hunting and keep hunting. I tell you,
5230	Adye, he is a danger, a disaster; unless he is pinned and secured,
5230	it is frightful to think of the things that may happen.""
5230	
5230	""What else can we do?"" said Adye. ""I must go down at once and begin
5230	organising. But why not come? Yes--you come too! Come, and we
5230	must hold a sort of council of war--get Hopps to help--and the
5230	railway managers. By Jove! it's urgent. Come along--tell me as we
5230	go. What else is there we can do? Put that stuff down.""
5230	
5230	In another moment Adye was leading the way downstairs. They found
5230	the front door open and the policemen standing outside staring at
5230	empty air. ""He's got away, sir,"" said one.
5230	
5230	""We must go to the central station at once,"" said Adye. ""One of you
5230	go on down and get a cab to come up and meet us--quickly. And
5230	now, Kemp, what else?""
5230	
5230	""Dogs,"" said Kemp. ""Get dogs. They don't see him, but they wind
5230	him. Get dogs.""
5230	
5230	""Good,"" said Adye. ""It's not generally known, but the prison
5230	officials over at Halstead know a man with bloodhounds. Dogs. What
5230	else?""
5230	
5230	""Bear in mind,"" said Kemp, ""his food shows. After eating, his food
5230	shows until it is assimilated. So that he has to hide after eating.
5230	You must keep on beating. Every thicket, every quiet corner. And
5230	put all weapons--all implements that might be weapons, away. He
5230	can't carry such things for long. And what he can snatch up and
5230	strike men with must be hidden away.""
5230	
5230	""Good again,"" said Adye. ""We shall have him yet!""
5230	
5230	""And on the roads,"" said Kemp, and hesitated.
5230	
5230	""Yes?"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	""Powdered glass,"" said Kemp. ""It's cruel, I know. But think of what
5230	he may do!""
5230	
5230	Adye drew the air in sharply between his teeth. ""It's
5230	unsportsmanlike. I don't know. But I'll have powdered glass got
5230	ready. If he goes too far....""
5230	
5230	""The man's become inhuman, I tell you,"" said Kemp. ""I am as sure he
5230	will establish a reign of terror--so soon as he has got over the
5230	emotions of this escape--as I am sure I am talking to you. Our
5230	only chance is to be ahead. He has cut himself off from his kind.
5230	His blood be upon his own head.""
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXVI
5230	
5230	THE WICKSTEED MURDER
5230	
5230	
5230	The Invisible Man seems to have rushed out of Kemp's house in a
5230	state of blind fury. A little child playing near Kemp's gateway was
5230	violently caught up and thrown aside, so that its ankle was broken,
5230	and thereafter for some hours the Invisible Man passed out of human
5230	perceptions. No one knows where he went nor what he did. But one
5230	can imagine him hurrying through the hot June forenoon, up the
5230	hill and on to the open downland behind Port Burdock, raging and
5230	despairing at his intolerable fate, and sheltering at last, heated
5230	and weary, amid the thickets of Hintondean, to piece together again
5230	his shattered schemes against his species. That seems the most
5230	probable refuge for him, for there it was he re-asserted himself in
5230	a grimly tragical manner about two in the afternoon.
5230	
5230	One wonders what his state of mind may have been during that time,
5230	and what plans he devised. No doubt he was almost ecstatically
5230	exasperated by Kemp's treachery, and though we may be able to
5230	understand the motives that led to that deceit, we may still
5230	imagine and even sympathise a little with the fury the attempted
5230	surprise must have occasioned. Perhaps something of the stunned
5230	astonishment of his Oxford Street experiences may have returned to
5230	him, for he had evidently counted on Kemp's co-operation in his
5230	brutal dream of a terrorised world. At any rate he vanished from
5230	human ken about midday, and no living witness can tell what he did
5230	until about half-past two. It was a fortunate thing, perhaps, for
5230	humanity, but for him it was a fatal inaction.
5230	
5230	During that time a growing multitude of men scattered over the
5230	countryside were busy. In the morning he had still been simply a
5230	legend, a terror; in the afternoon, by virtue chiefly of Kemp's
5230	drily worded proclamation, he was presented as a tangible
5230	antagonist, to be wounded, captured, or overcome, and the
5230	countryside began organising itself with inconceivable rapidity.
5230	By two o'clock even he might still have removed himself out of
5230	the district by getting aboard a train, but after two that became
5230	impossible. Every passenger train along the lines on a great
5230	parallelogram between Southampton, Manchester, Brighton and Horsham,
5230	travelled with locked doors, and the goods traffic was almost
5230	entirely suspended. And in a great circle of twenty miles round Port
5230	Burdock, men armed with guns and bludgeons were presently setting
5230	out in groups of three and four, with dogs, to beat the roads and
5230	fields.
5230	
5230	Mounted policemen rode along the country lanes, stopping at every
5230	cottage and warning the people to lock up their houses, and keep
5230	indoors unless they were armed, and all the elementary schools had
5230	broken up by three o'clock, and the children, scared and keeping
5230	together in groups, were hurrying home. Kemp's proclamation--signed
5230	indeed by Adye--was posted over almost the whole district by four or
5230	five o'clock in the afternoon. It gave briefly but clearly all the
5230	conditions of the struggle, the necessity of keeping the Invisible
5230	Man from food and sleep, the necessity for incessant watchfulness
5230	and for a prompt attention to any evidence of his movements. And
5230	so swift and decided was the action of the authorities, so prompt
5230	and universal was the belief in this strange being, that before
5230	nightfall an area of several hundred square miles was in a stringent
5230	state of siege. And before nightfall, too, a thrill of horror
5230	went through the whole watching nervous countryside. Going from
5230	whispering mouth to mouth, swift and certain over the length and
5230	breadth of the country, passed the story of the murder of Mr.
5230	Wicksteed.
5230	
5230	If our supposition that the Invisible Man's refuge was the
5230	Hintondean thickets, then we must suppose that in the early
5230	afternoon he sallied out again bent upon some project that involved
5230	the use of a weapon. We cannot know what the project was, but the
5230	evidence that he had the iron rod in hand before he met Wicksteed
5230	is to me at least overwhelming.
5230	
5230	Of course we can know nothing of the details of that encounter.
5230	It occurred on the edge of a gravel pit, not two hundred yards
5230	from Lord Burdock's lodge gate. Everything points to a desperate
5230	struggle--the trampled ground, the numerous wounds Mr. Wicksteed
5230	received, his splintered walking-stick; but why the attack was made,
5230	save in a murderous frenzy, it is impossible to imagine. Indeed the
5230	theory of madness is almost unavoidable. Mr. Wicksteed was a man of
5230	forty-five or forty-six, steward to Lord Burdock, of inoffensive
5230	habits and appearance, the very last person in the world to provoke
5230	such a terrible antagonist. Against him it would seem the Invisible
5230	Man used an iron rod dragged from a broken piece of fence. He
5230	stopped this quiet man, going quietly home to his midday meal,
5230	attacked him, beat down his feeble defences, broke his arm, felled
5230	him, and smashed his head to a jelly.
5230	
5230	Of course, he must have dragged this rod out of the fencing before
5230	he met his victim--he must have been carrying it ready in his hand.
5230	Only two details beyond what has already been stated seem to bear
5230	on the matter. One is the circumstance that the gravel pit was not
5230	in Mr. Wicksteed's direct path home, but nearly a couple of hundred
5230	yards out of his way. The other is the assertion of a little girl
5230	to the effect that, going to her afternoon school, she saw the
5230	murdered man ""trotting"" in a peculiar manner across a field towards
5230	the gravel pit. Her pantomime of his action suggests a man pursuing
5230	something on the ground before him and striking at it ever and
5230	again with his walking-stick. She was the last person to see him
5230	alive. He passed out of her sight to his death, the struggle being
5230	hidden from her only by a clump of beech trees and a slight
5230	depression in the ground.
5230	
5230	Now this, to the present writer's mind at least, lifts the murder
5230	out of the realm of the absolutely wanton. We may imagine that
5230	Griffin had taken the rod as a weapon indeed, but without any
5230	deliberate intention of using it in murder. Wicksteed may then have
5230	come by and noticed this rod inexplicably moving through the air.
5230	Without any thought of the Invisible Man--for Port Burdock is ten
5230	miles away--he may have pursued it. It is quite conceivable that
5230	he may not even have heard of the Invisible Man. One can then
5230	imagine the Invisible Man making off--quietly in order to avoid
5230	discovering his presence in the neighbourhood, and Wicksteed,
5230	excited and curious, pursuing this unaccountably locomotive
5230	object--finally striking at it.
5230	
5230	No doubt the Invisible Man could easily have distanced his
5230	middle-aged pursuer under ordinary circumstances, but the position
5230	in which Wicksteed's body was found suggests that he had the
5230	ill luck to drive his quarry into a corner between a drift of
5230	stinging nettles and the gravel pit. To those who appreciate the
5230	extraordinary irascibility of the Invisible Man, the rest of the
5230	encounter will be easy to imagine.
5230	
5230	But this is pure hypothesis. The only undeniable facts--for stories
5230	of children are often unreliable--are the discovery of Wicksteed's
5230	body, done to death, and of the blood-stained iron rod flung among
5230	the nettles. The abandonment of the rod by Griffin, suggests that
5230	in the emotional excitement of the affair, the purpose for which
5230	he took it--if he had a purpose--was abandoned. He was certainly
5230	an intensely egotistical and unfeeling man, but the sight of his
5230	victim, his first victim, bloody and pitiful at his feet, may have
5230	released some long pent fountain of remorse which for a time may
5230	have flooded whatever scheme of action he had contrived.
5230	
5230	After the murder of Mr. Wicksteed, he would seem to have struck
5230	across the country towards the downland. There is a story of a
5230	voice heard about sunset by a couple of men in a field near Fern
5230	Bottom. It was wailing and laughing, sobbing and groaning, and ever
5230	and again it shouted. It must have been queer hearing. It drove up
5230	across the middle of a clover field and died away towards the
5230	hills.
5230	
5230	That afternoon the Invisible Man must have learnt something of
5230	the rapid use Kemp had made of his confidences. He must have
5230	found houses locked and secured; he may have loitered about
5230	railway stations and prowled about inns, and no doubt he read the
5230	proclamations and realised something of the nature of the campaign
5230	against him. And as the evening advanced, the fields became dotted
5230	here and there with groups of three or four men, and noisy with the
5230	yelping of dogs. These men-hunters had particular instructions in
5230	the case of an encounter as to the way they should support one
5230	another. But he avoided them all. We may understand something of
5230	his exasperation, and it could have been none the less because
5230	he himself had supplied the information that was being used so
5230	remorselessly against him. For that day at least he lost heart; for
5230	nearly twenty-four hours, save when he turned on Wicksteed, he was
5230	a hunted man. In the night, he must have eaten and slept; for in
5230	the morning he was himself again, active, powerful, angry, and
5230	malignant, prepared for his last great struggle against the world.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXVII
5230	
5230	THE SIEGE OF KEMP'S HOUSE
5230	
5230	
5230	Kemp read a strange missive, written in pencil on a greasy sheet of
5230	paper.
5230	
5230	""You have been amazingly energetic and clever,"" this letter ran,
5230	""though what you stand to gain by it I cannot imagine. You are
5230	against me. For a whole day you have chased me; you have tried to
5230	rob me of a night's rest. But I have had food in spite of you, I
5230	have slept in spite of you, and the game is only beginning. The
5230	game is only beginning. There is nothing for it, but to start the
5230	Terror. This announces the first day of the Terror. Port Burdock
5230	is no longer under the Queen, tell your Colonel of Police, and
5230	the rest of them; it is under me--the Terror! This is day one of
5230	year one of the new epoch--the Epoch of the Invisible Man. I am
5230	Invisible Man the First. To begin with the rule will be easy. The
5230	first day there will be one execution for the sake of example--a
5230	man named Kemp. Death starts for him to-day. He may lock himself
5230	away, hide himself away, get guards about him, put on armour
5230	if he likes--Death, the unseen Death, is coming. Let him take
5230	precautions; it will impress my people. Death starts from the
5230	pillar box by midday. The letter will fall in as the postman comes
5230	along, then off! The game begins. Death starts. Help him not, my
5230	people, lest Death fall upon you also. To-day Kemp is to die.""
5230	
5230	Kemp read this letter twice, ""It's no hoax,"" he said. ""That's
5230	his voice! And he means it.""
5230	
5230	He turned the folded sheet over and saw on the addressed side of it
5230	the postmark Hintondean, and the prosaic detail ""2d. to pay.""
5230	
5230	He got up slowly, leaving his lunch unfinished--the letter had
5230	come by the one o'clock post--and went into his study. He rang
5230	for his housekeeper, and told her to go round the house at once,
5230	examine all the fastenings of the windows, and close all the
5230	shutters. He closed the shutters of his study himself. From a
5230	locked drawer in his bedroom he took a little revolver, examined it
5230	carefully, and put it into the pocket of his lounge jacket. He
5230	wrote a number of brief notes, one to Colonel Adye, gave them to
5230	his servant to take, with explicit instructions as to her way of
5230	leaving the house. ""There is no danger,"" he said, and added a
5230	mental reservation, ""to you."" He remained meditative for a space
5230	after doing this, and then returned to his cooling lunch.
5230	
5230	He ate with gaps of thought. Finally he struck the table sharply.
5230	""We will have him!"" he said; ""and I am the bait. He will come too
5230	far.""
5230	
5230	He went up to the belvedere, carefully shutting every door after
5230	him. ""It's a game,"" he said, ""an odd game--but the chances are
5230	all for me, Mr. Griffin, in spite of your invisibility. Griffin
5230	_contra mundum_ ... with a vengeance.""
5230	
5230	He stood at the window staring at the hot hillside. ""He must get
5230	food every day--and I don't envy him. Did he really sleep last
5230	night? Out in the open somewhere--secure from collisions. I wish
5230	we could get some good cold wet weather instead of the heat.
5230	
5230	""He may be watching me now.""
5230	
5230	He went close to the window. Something rapped smartly against the
5230	brickwork over the frame, and made him start violently back.
5230	
5230	""I'm getting nervous,"" said Kemp. But it was five minutes before he
5230	went to the window again. ""It must have been a sparrow,"" he said.
5230	
5230	Presently he heard the front-door bell ringing, and hurried
5230	downstairs. He unbolted and unlocked the door, examined the chain,
5230	put it up, and opened cautiously without showing himself. A
5230	familiar voice hailed him. It was Adye.
5230	
5230	""Your servant's been assaulted, Kemp,"" he said round the door.
5230	
5230	""What!"" exclaimed Kemp.
5230	
5230	""Had that note of yours taken away from her. He's close about here.
5230	Let me in.""
5230	
5230	Kemp released the chain, and Adye entered through as narrow an
5230	opening as possible. He stood in the hall, looking with infinite
5230	relief at Kemp refastening the door. ""Note was snatched out of her
5230	hand. Scared her horribly. She's down at the station. Hysterics.
5230	He's close here. What was it about?""
5230	
5230	Kemp swore.
5230	
5230	""What a fool I was,"" said Kemp. ""I might have known. It's not an
5230	hour's walk from Hintondean. Already?""
5230	
5230	""What's up?"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	""Look here!"" said Kemp, and led the way into his study. He handed
5230	Adye the Invisible Man's letter. Adye read it and whistled softly.
5230	""And you--?"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	""Proposed a trap--like a fool,"" said Kemp, ""and sent my proposal
5230	out by a maid servant. To him.""
5230	
5230	Adye followed Kemp's profanity.
5230	
5230	""He'll clear out,"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	""Not he,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	A resounding smash of glass came from upstairs. Adye had a silvery
5230	glimpse of a little revolver half out of Kemp's pocket. ""It's a
5230	window, upstairs!"" said Kemp, and led the way up. There came a
5230	second smash while they were still on the staircase. When they
5230	reached the study they found two of the three windows smashed,
5230	half the room littered with splintered glass, and one big flint
5230	lying on the writing table. The two men stopped in the doorway,
5230	contemplating the wreckage. Kemp swore again, and as he did so the
5230	third window went with a snap like a pistol, hung starred for a
5230	moment, and collapsed in jagged, shivering triangles into the room.
5230	
5230	""What's this for?"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	""It's a beginning,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""There's no way of climbing up here?""
5230	
5230	""Not for a cat,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""No shutters?""
5230	
5230	""Not here. All the downstairs rooms--Hullo!""
5230	
5230	Smash, and then whack of boards hit hard came from downstairs.
5230	""Confound him!"" said Kemp. ""That must be--yes--it's one of the
5230	bedrooms. He's going to do all the house. But he's a fool. The
5230	shutters are up, and the glass will fall outside. He'll cut his
5230	feet.""
5230	
5230	Another window proclaimed its destruction. The two men stood on the
5230	landing perplexed. ""I have it!"" said Adye. ""Let me have a stick or
5230	something, and I'll go down to the station and get the bloodhounds
5230	put on. That ought to settle him! They're hard by--not ten
5230	minutes--""
5230	
5230	Another window went the way of its fellows.
5230	
5230	""You haven't a revolver?"" asked Adye.
5230	
5230	Kemp's hand went to his pocket. Then he hesitated. ""I haven't
5230	one--at least to spare.""
5230	
5230	""I'll bring it back,"" said Adye, ""you'll be safe here.""
5230	
5230	Kemp, ashamed of his momentary lapse from truthfulness, handed him
5230	the weapon.
5230	
5230	""Now for the door,"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	As they stood hesitating in the hall, they heard one of the
5230	first-floor bedroom windows crack and clash. Kemp went to the door
5230	and began to slip the bolts as silently as possible. His face was a
5230	little paler than usual. ""You must step straight out,"" said Kemp. In
5230	another moment Adye was on the doorstep and the bolts were dropping
5230	back into the staples. He hesitated for a moment, feeling more
5230	comfortable with his back against the door. Then he marched, upright
5230	and square, down the steps. He crossed the lawn and approached the
5230	gate. A little breeze seemed to ripple over the grass. Something
5230	moved near him. ""Stop a bit,"" said a Voice, and Adye stopped dead
5230	and his hand tightened on the revolver.
5230	
5230	""Well?"" said Adye, white and grim, and every nerve tense.
5230	
5230	""Oblige me by going back to the house,"" said the Voice, as tense
5230	and grim as Adye's.
5230	
5230	""Sorry,"" said Adye a little hoarsely, and moistened his lips with
5230	his tongue. The Voice was on his left front, he thought. Suppose he
5230	were to take his luck with a shot?
5230	
5230	""What are you going for?"" said the Voice, and there was a quick
5230	movement of the two, and a flash of sunlight from the open lip of
5230	Adye's pocket.
5230	
5230	Adye desisted and thought. ""Where I go,"" he said slowly, ""is my own
5230	business."" The words were still on his lips, when an arm came round
5230	his neck, his back felt a knee, and he was sprawling backward. He
5230	drew clumsily and fired absurdly, and in another moment he was
5230	struck in the mouth and the revolver wrested from his grip. He made
5230	a vain clutch at a slippery limb, tried to struggle up and fell
5230	back. ""Damn!"" said Adye. The Voice laughed. ""I'd kill you now if it
5230	wasn't the waste of a bullet,"" it said. He saw the revolver in
5230	mid-air, six feet off, covering him.
5230	
5230	""Well?"" said Adye, sitting up.
5230	
5230	""Get up,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	Adye stood up.
5230	
5230	""Attention,"" said the Voice, and then fiercely, ""Don't try any
5230	games. Remember I can see your face if you can't see mine. You've
5230	got to go back to the house.""
5230	
5230	""He won't let me in,"" said Adye.
5230	
5230	""That's a pity,"" said the Invisible Man. ""I've got no quarrel with
5230	you.""
5230	
5230	Adye moistened his lips again. He glanced away from the barrel of
5230	the revolver and saw the sea far off very blue and dark under the
5230	midday sun, the smooth green down, the white cliff of the Head, and
5230	the multitudinous town, and suddenly he knew that life was very
5230	sweet. His eyes came back to this little metal thing hanging
5230	between heaven and earth, six yards away. ""What am I to do?"" he
5230	said sullenly.
5230	
5230	""What am _I_ to do?"" asked the Invisible Man. ""You will get help. The
5230	only thing is for you to go back.""
5230	
5230	""I will try. If he lets me in will you promise not to rush the
5230	door?""
5230	
5230	""I've got no quarrel with you,"" said the Voice.
5230	
5230	Kemp had hurried upstairs after letting Adye out, and now crouching
5230	among the broken glass and peering cautiously over the edge of the
5230	study window sill, he saw Adye stand parleying with the Unseen.
5230	""Why doesn't he fire?"" whispered Kemp to himself. Then the revolver
5230	moved a little and the glint of the sunlight flashed in Kemp's
5230	eyes. He shaded his eyes and tried to see the source of the
5230	blinding beam.
5230	
5230	""Surely!"" he said, ""Adye has given up the revolver.""
5230	
5230	""Promise not to rush the door,"" Adye was saying. ""Don't push a
5230	winning game too far. Give a man a chance.""
5230	
5230	""You go back to the house. I tell you flatly I will not promise
5230	anything.""
5230	
5230	Adye's decision seemed suddenly made. He turned towards the house,
5230	walking slowly with his hands behind him. Kemp watched him--puzzled.
5230	The revolver vanished, flashed again into sight, vanished again,
5230	and became evident on a closer scrutiny as a little dark object
5230	following Adye. Then things happened very quickly. Adye leapt
5230	backwards, swung around, clutched at this little object, missed it,
5230	threw up his hands and fell forward on his face, leaving a little
5230	puff of blue in the air. Kemp did not hear the sound of the shot.
5230	Adye writhed, raised himself on one arm, fell forward, and lay
5230	still.
5230	
5230	For a space Kemp remained staring at the quiet carelessness of
5230	Adye's attitude. The afternoon was very hot and still, nothing
5230	seemed stirring in all the world save a couple of yellow butterflies
5230	chasing each other through the shrubbery between the house and the
5230	road gate. Adye lay on the lawn near the gate. The blinds of all
5230	the villas down the hill-road were drawn, but in one little green
5230	summer-house was a white figure, apparently an old man asleep. Kemp
5230	scrutinised the surroundings of the house for a glimpse of the
5230	revolver, but it had vanished. His eyes came back to Adye. The game
5230	was opening well.
5230	
5230	Then came a ringing and knocking at the front door, that grew at
5230	last tumultuous, but pursuant to Kemp's instructions the servants
5230	had locked themselves into their rooms. This was followed by a
5230	silence. Kemp sat listening and then began peering cautiously out
5230	of the three windows, one after another. He went to the staircase
5230	head and stood listening uneasily. He armed himself with his
5230	bedroom poker, and went to examine the interior fastenings of the
5230	ground-floor windows again. Everything was safe and quiet. He
5230	returned to the belvedere. Adye lay motionless over the edge of the
5230	gravel just as he had fallen. Coming along the road by the villas
5230	were the housemaid and two policemen.
5230	
5230	Everything was deadly still. The three people seemed very slow in
5230	approaching. He wondered what his antagonist was doing.
5230	
5230	He started. There was a smash from below. He hesitated and went
5230	downstairs again. Suddenly the house resounded with heavy blows and
5230	the splintering of wood. He heard a smash and the destructive clang
5230	of the iron fastenings of the shutters. He turned the key and
5230	opened the kitchen door. As he did so, the shutters, split and
5230	splintering, came flying inward. He stood aghast. The window frame,
5230	save for one crossbar, was still intact, but only little teeth of
5230	glass remained in the frame. The shutters had been driven in with
5230	an axe, and now the axe was descending in sweeping blows upon the
5230	window frame and the iron bars defending it. Then suddenly it leapt
5230	aside and vanished. He saw the revolver lying on the path outside,
5230	and then the little weapon sprang into the air. He dodged back. The
5230	revolver cracked just too late, and a splinter from the edge of the
5230	closing door flashed over his head. He slammed and locked the door,
5230	and as he stood outside he heard Griffin shouting and laughing.
5230	Then the blows of the axe with its splitting and smashing
5230	consequences, were resumed.
5230	
5230	Kemp stood in the passage trying to think. In a moment the
5230	Invisible Man would be in the kitchen. This door would not keep him
5230	a moment, and then--
5230	
5230	A ringing came at the front door again. It would be the policemen.
5230	He ran into the hall, put up the chain, and drew the bolts. He made
5230	the girl speak before he dropped the chain, and the three people
5230	blundered into the house in a heap, and Kemp slammed the door
5230	again.
5230	
5230	""The Invisible Man!"" said Kemp. ""He has a revolver, with two
5230	shots--left. He's killed Adye. Shot him anyhow. Didn't you see him on
5230	the lawn? He's lying there.""
5230	
5230	""Who?"" said one of the policemen.
5230	
5230	""Adye,"" said Kemp.
5230	
5230	""We came in the back way,"" said the girl.
5230	
5230	""What's that smashing?"" asked one of the policemen.
5230	
5230	""He's in the kitchen--or will be. He has found an axe--""
5230	
5230	Suddenly the house was full of the Invisible Man's resounding
5230	blows on the kitchen door. The girl stared towards the kitchen,
5230	shuddered, and retreated into the dining-room. Kemp tried to
5230	explain in broken sentences. They heard the kitchen door give.
5230	
5230	""This way,"" said Kemp, starting into activity, and bundled the
5230	policemen into the dining-room doorway.
5230	
5230	""Poker,"" said Kemp, and rushed to the fender. He handed the poker
5230	he had carried to the policeman and the dining-room one to the
5230	other. He suddenly flung himself backward.
5230	
5230	""Whup!"" said one policeman, ducked, and caught the axe on his poker.
5230	The pistol snapped its penultimate shot and ripped a valuable Sidney
5230	Cooper. The second policeman brought his poker down on the little
5230	weapon, as one might knock down a wasp, and sent it rattling to the
5230	floor.
5230	
5230	At the first clash the girl screamed, stood screaming for a moment
5230	by the fireplace, and then ran to open the shutters--possibly
5230	with an idea of escaping by the shattered window.
5230	
5230	The axe receded into the passage, and fell to a position about two
5230	feet from the ground. They could hear the Invisible Man breathing.
5230	""Stand away, you two,"" he said. ""I want that man Kemp.""
5230	
5230	""We want you,"" said the first policeman, making a quick step
5230	forward and wiping with his poker at the Voice. The Invisible Man
5230	must have started back, and he blundered into the umbrella stand.
5230	
5230	Then, as the policeman staggered with the swing of the blow he had
5230	aimed, the Invisible Man countered with the axe, the helmet crumpled
5230	like paper, and the blow sent the man spinning to the floor at the
5230	head of the kitchen stairs. But the second policeman, aiming behind
5230	the axe with his poker, hit something soft that snapped. There was a
5230	sharp exclamation of pain and then the axe fell to the ground. The
5230	policeman wiped again at vacancy and hit nothing; he put his foot on
5230	the axe, and struck again. Then he stood, poker clubbed, listening
5230	intent for the slightest movement.
5230	
5230	He heard the dining-room window open, and a quick rush of feet
5230	within. His companion rolled over and sat up, with the blood
5230	running down between his eye and ear. ""Where is he?"" asked the man
5230	on the floor.
5230	
5230	""Don't know. I've hit him. He's standing somewhere in the hall.
5230	Unless he's slipped past you. Doctor Kemp--sir.""
5230	
5230	Pause.
5230	
5230	""Doctor Kemp,"" cried the policeman again.
5230	
5230	The second policeman began struggling to his feet. He stood up.
5230	Suddenly the faint pad of bare feet on the kitchen stairs could be
5230	heard. ""Yap!"" cried the first policeman, and incontinently flung
5230	his poker. It smashed a little gas bracket.
5230	
5230	He made as if he would pursue the Invisible Man downstairs. Then he
5230	thought better of it and stepped into the dining-room.
5230	
5230	""Doctor Kemp--"" he began, and stopped short.
5230	
5230	""Doctor Kemp's a hero,"" he said, as his companion looked over his
5230	shoulder.
5230	
5230	The dining-room window was wide open, and neither housemaid nor
5230	Kemp was to be seen.
5230	
5230	The second policeman's opinion of Kemp was terse and vivid.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	CHAPTER XXVIII
5230	
5230	THE HUNTER HUNTED
5230	
5230	
5230	Mr. Heelas, Mr. Kemp's nearest neighbour among the villa holders,
5230	was asleep in his summer house when the siege of Kemp's house
5230	began. Mr. Heelas was one of the sturdy minority who refused to
5230	believe ""in all this nonsense"" about an Invisible Man. His wife,
5230	however, as he was subsequently to be reminded, did. He insisted
5230	upon walking about his garden just as if nothing was the matter,
5230	and he went to sleep in the afternoon in accordance with the custom
5230	of years. He slept through the smashing of the windows, and then
5230	woke up suddenly with a curious persuasion of something wrong. He
5230	looked across at Kemp's house, rubbed his eyes and looked again.
5230	Then he put his feet to the ground, and sat listening. He said he
5230	was damned, but still the strange thing was visible. The house
5230	looked as though it had been deserted for weeks--after a violent
5230	riot. Every window was broken, and every window, save those of the
5230	belvedere study, was blinded by the internal shutters.
5230	
5230	""I could have sworn it was all right""--he looked at his watch--""twenty
5230	minutes ago.""
5230	
5230	He became aware of a measured concussion and the clash of glass,
5230	far away in the distance. And then, as he sat open-mouthed, came a
5230	still more wonderful thing. The shutters of the drawing-room window
5230	were flung open violently, and the housemaid in her outdoor hat and
5230	garments, appeared struggling in a frantic manner to throw up the
5230	sash. Suddenly a man appeared beside her, helping her--Dr. Kemp!
5230	In another moment the window was open, and the housemaid was
5230	struggling out; she pitched forward and vanished among the shrubs.
5230	Mr. Heelas stood up, exclaiming vaguely and vehemently at all these
5230	wonderful things. He saw Kemp stand on the sill, spring from the
5230	window, and reappear almost instantaneously running along a path in
5230	the shrubbery and stooping as he ran, like a man who evades
5230	observation. He vanished behind a laburnum, and appeared again
5230	clambering over a fence that abutted on the open down. In a second
5230	he had tumbled over and was running at a tremendous pace down the
5230	slope towards Mr. Heelas.
5230	
5230	""Lord!"" cried Mr. Heelas, struck with an idea; ""it's that Invisible
5230	Man brute! It's right, after all!""
5230	
5230	With Mr. Heelas to think things like that was to act, and his cook
5230	watching him from the top window was amazed to see him come pelting
5230	towards the house at a good nine miles an hour. There was a
5230	slamming of doors, a ringing of bells, and the voice of Mr. Heelas
5230	bellowing like a bull. ""Shut the doors, shut the windows, shut
5230	everything!--the Invisible Man is coming!"" Instantly the house was
5230	full of screams and directions, and scurrying feet. He ran himself
5230	to shut the French windows that opened on the veranda; as he did so
5230	Kemp's head and shoulders and knee appeared over the edge of the
5230	garden fence. In another moment Kemp had ploughed through the
5230	asparagus, and was running across the tennis lawn to the house.
5230	
5230	""You can't come in,"" said Mr. Heelas, shutting the bolts. ""I'm very
5230	sorry if he's after you, but you can't come in!""
5230	
5230	Kemp appeared with a face of terror close to the glass, rapping and
5230	then shaking frantically at the French window. Then, seeing his
5230	efforts were useless, he ran along the veranda, vaulted the end,
5230	and went to hammer at the side door. Then he ran round by the side
5230	gate to the front of the house, and so into the hill-road. And Mr.
5230	Heelas staring from his window--a face of horror--had scarcely
5230	witnessed Kemp vanish, ere the asparagus was being trampled this
5230	way and that by feet unseen. At that Mr. Heelas fled precipitately
5230	upstairs, and the rest of the chase is beyond his purview. But as
5230	he passed the staircase window, he heard the side gate slam.
5230	
5230	Emerging into the hill-road, Kemp naturally took the downward
5230	direction, and so it was he came to run in his own person the very
5230	race he had watched with such a critical eye from the belvedere
5230	study only four days ago. He ran it well, for a man out of
5230	training, and though his face was white and wet, his wits were cool
5230	to the last. He ran with wide strides, and wherever a patch of
5230	rough ground intervened, wherever there came a patch of raw flints,
5230	or a bit of broken glass shone dazzling, he crossed it and left the
5230	bare invisible feet that followed to take what line they would.
5230	
5230	For the first time in his life Kemp discovered that the hill-road
5230	was indescribably vast and desolate, and that the beginnings of the
5230	town far below at the hill foot were strangely remote. Never had
5230	there been a slower or more painful method of progression than
5230	running. All the gaunt villas, sleeping in the afternoon sun,
5230	looked locked and barred; no doubt they were locked and barred--by
5230	his own orders. But at any rate they might have kept a lookout
5230	for an eventuality like this! The town was rising up now, the sea
5230	had dropped out of sight behind it, and people down below were
5230	stirring. A tram was just arriving at the hill foot. Beyond that
5230	was the police station. Was that footsteps he heard behind him?
5230	Spurt.
5230	
5230	The people below were staring at him, one or two were running, and
5230	his breath was beginning to saw in his throat. The tram was quite
5230	near now, and the ""Jolly Cricketers"" was noisily barring its doors.
5230	Beyond the tram were posts and heaps of gravel--the drainage
5230	works. He had a transitory idea of jumping into the tram and
5230	slamming the doors, and then he resolved to go for the police
5230	station. In another moment he had passed the door of the ""Jolly
5230	Cricketers,"" and was in the blistering fag end of the street, with
5230	human beings about him. The tram driver and his helper--arrested
5230	by the sight of his furious haste--stood staring with the tram
5230	horses unhitched. Further on the astonished features of navvies
5230	appeared above the mounds of gravel.
5230	
5230	His pace broke a little, and then he heard the swift pad of his
5230	pursuer, and leapt forward again. ""The Invisible Man!"" he cried to
5230	the navvies, with a vague indicative gesture, and by an inspiration
5230	leapt the excavation and placed a burly group between him and the
5230	chase. Then abandoning the idea of the police station he turned
5230	into a little side street, rushed by a greengrocer's cart,
5230	hesitated for the tenth of a second at the door of a sweetstuff
5230	shop, and then made for the mouth of an alley that ran back into
5230	the main Hill Street again. Two or three little children were
5230	playing here, and shrieked and scattered at his apparition, and
5230	forthwith doors and windows opened and excited mothers revealed
5230	their hearts. Out he shot into Hill Street again, three hundred
5230	yards from the tram-line end, and immediately he became aware of a
5230	tumultuous vociferation and running people.
5230	
5230	He glanced up the street towards the hill. Hardly a dozen yards off
5230	ran a huge navvy, cursing in fragments and slashing viciously with
5230	a spade, and hard behind him came the tram conductor with his fists
5230	clenched. Up the street others followed these two, striking and
5230	shouting. Down towards the town, men and women were running, and he
5230	noticed clearly one man coming out of a shop-door with a stick in
5230	his hand. ""Spread out! Spread out!"" cried some one. Kemp suddenly
5230	grasped the altered condition of the chase. He stopped, and looked
5230	round, panting. ""He's close here!"" he cried. ""Form a line across--""
5230	
5230	He was hit hard under the ear, and went reeling, trying to face
5230	round towards his unseen antagonist. He just managed to keep his
5230	feet, and he struck a vain counter in the air. Then he was hit
5230	again under the jaw, and sprawled headlong on the ground. In
5230	another moment a knee compressed his diaphragm, and a couple of
5230	eager hands gripped his throat, but the grip of one was weaker than
5230	the other; he grasped the wrists, heard a cry of pain from his
5230	assailant, and then the spade of the navvy came whirling through
5230	the air above him, and struck something with a dull thud. He felt
5230	a drop of moisture on his face. The grip at his throat suddenly
5230	relaxed, and with a convulsive effort, Kemp loosed himself, grasped
5230	a limp shoulder, and rolled uppermost. He gripped the unseen elbows
5230	near the ground. ""I've got him!"" screamed Kemp. ""Help! Help--hold!
5230	He's down! Hold his feet!""
5230	
5230	In another second there was a simultaneous rush upon the struggle,
5230	and a stranger coming into the road suddenly might have thought an
5230	exceptionally savage game of Rugby football was in progress. And
5230	there was no shouting after Kemp's cry--only a sound of blows
5230	and feet and heavy breathing.
5230	
5230	Then came a mighty effort, and the Invisible Man threw off a couple
5230	of his antagonists and rose to his knees. Kemp clung to him in
5230	front like a hound to a stag, and a dozen hands gripped, clutched,
5230	and tore at the Unseen. The tram conductor suddenly got the neck
5230	and shoulders and lugged him back.
5230	
5230	Down went the heap of struggling men again and rolled over. There
5230	was, I am afraid, some savage kicking. Then suddenly a wild scream
5230	of ""Mercy! Mercy!"" that died down swiftly to a sound like choking.
5230	
5230	""Get back, you fools!"" cried the muffled voice of Kemp, and there
5230	was a vigorous shoving back of stalwart forms. ""He's hurt, I tell
5230	you. Stand back!""
5230	
5230	There was a brief struggle to clear a space, and then the circle of
5230	eager faces saw the doctor kneeling, as it seemed, fifteen inches
5230	in the air, and holding invisible arms to the ground. Behind him a
5230	constable gripped invisible ankles.
5230	
5230	""Don't you leave go of en,"" cried the big navvy, holding a
5230	blood-stained spade; ""he's shamming.""
5230	
5230	""He's not shamming,"" said the doctor, cautiously raising his knee;
5230	""and I'll hold him."" His face was bruised and already going red; he
5230	spoke thickly because of a bleeding lip. He released one hand and
5230	seemed to be feeling at the face. ""The mouth's all wet,"" he said.
5230	And then, ""Good God!""
5230	
5230	He stood up abruptly and then knelt down on the ground by the side
5230	of the thing unseen. There was a pushing and shuffling, a sound of
5230	heavy feet as fresh people turned up to increase the pressure of
5230	the crowd. People now were coming out of the houses. The doors of
5230	the ""Jolly Cricketers"" stood suddenly wide open. Very little was said.
5230	
5230	Kemp felt about, his hand seeming to pass through empty air. ""He's
5230	not breathing,"" he said, and then, ""I can't feel his heart. His
5230	side--ugh!""
5230	
5230	Suddenly an old woman, peering under the arm of the big navvy,
5230	screamed sharply. ""Looky there!"" she said, and thrust out a
5230	wrinkled finger.
5230	
5230	And looking where she pointed, everyone saw, faint and transparent
5230	as though it was made of glass, so that veins and arteries and
5230	bones and nerves could be distinguished, the outline of a hand, a
5230	hand limp and prone. It grew clouded and opaque even as they stared.
5230	
5230	""Hullo!"" cried the constable. ""Here's his feet a-showing!""
5230	
5230	And so, slowly, beginning at his hands and feet and creeping along
5230	his limbs to the vital centres of his body, that strange change
5230	continued. It was like the slow spreading of a poison. First came
5230	the little white nerves, a hazy grey sketch of a limb, then the
5230	glassy bones and intricate arteries, then the flesh and skin, first
5230	a faint fogginess, and then growing rapidly dense and opaque.
5230	Presently they could see his crushed chest and his shoulders, and
5230	the dim outline of his drawn and battered features.
5230	
5230	When at last the crowd made way for Kemp to stand erect, there lay,
5230	naked and pitiful on the ground, the bruised and broken body of a
5230	young man about thirty. His hair and brow were white--not grey
5230	with age, but white with the whiteness of albinism--and his eyes
5230	were like garnets. His hands were clenched, his eyes wide open, and
5230	his expression was one of anger and dismay.
5230	
5230	""Cover his face!"" said a man. ""For Gawd's sake, cover that face!""
5230	and three little children, pushing forward through the crowd, were
5230	suddenly twisted round and sent packing off again.
5230	
5230	Someone brought a sheet from the ""Jolly Cricketers,"" and having
5230	covered him, they carried him into that house. And there it was, on
5230	a shabby bed in a tawdry, ill-lighted bedroom, surrounded by a crowd
5230	of ignorant and excited people, broken and wounded, betrayed and
5230	unpitied, that Griffin, the first of all men to make himself
5230	invisible, Griffin, the most gifted physicist the world has ever
5230	seen, ended in infinite disaster his strange and terrible career.
5230	
5230	
5230	
5230	THE EPILOGUE
5230	
5230	
5230	So ends the story of the strange and evil experiments of the
5230	Invisible Man. And if you would learn more of him you must go to a
5230	little inn near Port Stowe and talk to the landlord. The sign of
5230	the inn is an empty board save for a hat and boots, and the name is
5230	the title of this story. The landlord is a short and corpulent
5230	little man with a nose of cylindrical proportions, wiry hair, and a
5230	sporadic rosiness of visage. Drink generously, and he will tell you
5230	generously of all the things that happened to him after that time,
5230	and of how the lawyers tried to do him out of the treasure found
5230	upon him.
5230	
5230	""When they found they couldn't prove whose money was which, I'm
5230	blessed,"" he says, ""if they didn't try to make me out a blooming
5230	treasure trove! Do I _look_ like a Treasure Trove? And then a
5230	gentleman gave me a guinea a night to tell the story at the Empire
5230	Music 'All--just to tell 'em in my own words--barring one.""
5230	
5230	And if you want to cut off the flow of his reminiscences abruptly,
5230	you can always do so by asking if there weren't three manuscript
5230	books in the story. He admits there were and proceeds to explain,
5230	with asseverations that everybody thinks _he_ has 'em! But bless you!
5230	he hasn't. ""The Invisible Man it was took 'em off to hide 'em when
5230	I cut and ran for Port Stowe. It's that Mr. Kemp put people on with
5230	the idea of _my_ having 'em.""
5230	
5230	And then he subsides into a pensive state, watches you furtively,
5230	bustles nervously with glasses, and presently leaves the bar.
5230	
5230	He is a bachelor man--his tastes were ever bachelor, and there
5230	are no women folk in the house. Outwardly he buttons--it is
5230	expected of him--but in his more vital privacies, in the matter
5230	of braces for example, he still turns to string. He conducts his
5230	house without enterprise, but with eminent decorum. His movements
5230	are slow, and he is a great thinker. But he has a reputation for
5230	wisdom and for a respectable parsimony in the village, and his
5230	knowledge of the roads of the South of England would beat Cobbett.
5230	
5230	And on Sunday mornings, every Sunday morning, all the year round,
5230	while he is closed to the outer world, and every night after ten,
5230	he goes into his bar parlour, bearing a glass of gin faintly tinged
5230	with water, and having placed this down, he locks the door and
5230	examines the blinds, and even looks under the table. And then,
5230	being satisfied of his solitude, he unlocks the cupboard and a box
5230	in the cupboard and a drawer in that box, and produces three
5230	volumes bound in brown leather, and places them solemnly in the
5230	middle of the table. The covers are weather-worn and tinged with an
5230	algal green--for once they sojourned in a ditch and some of the
5230	pages have been washed blank by dirty water. The landlord sits down
5230	in an armchair, fills a long clay pipe slowly--gloating over the
5230	books the while. Then he pulls one towards him and opens it, and
5230	begins to study it--turning over the leaves backwards and forwards.
5230	
5230	His brows are knit and his lips move painfully. ""Hex, little two up
5230	in the air, cross and a fiddle-de-dee. Lord! what a one he was for
5230	intellect!""
5230	
5230	Presently he relaxes and leans back, and blinks through his smoke
5230	across the room at things invisible to other eyes. ""Full of
5230	secrets,"" he says. ""Wonderful secrets!""
5230	
5230	""Once I get the haul of them--_Lord_!""
5230	
5230	""I wouldn't do what _he_ did; I'd just--well!"" He pulls at his
5230	pipe.
5230	
5230	So he lapses into a dream, the undying wonderful dream of his life.
5230	And though Kemp has fished unceasingly, no human being save the
5230	landlord knows those books are there, with the subtle secret of
5230	invisibility and a dozen other strange secrets written therein.
5230	And none other will know of them until he dies.
